When Robert L. Darragh died he left only $500 to his first wife, from whom he was divorced, thirty years ago. He left each of his children by this wife the same amount. The rest of his estate he bequeathed to his second wife, with whom he was living at the time of his death.

ALBANY, June 12. -- The grab for patronage under the new Capitol Commission has begun in wholesale fashion. All the predictions which were made when the bill cresting the commission was signed by the Governor that such would be the case seem bound to be realized in short order.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- The cablegram published this morning, giving the substance of a Rome dispatch to the London Standard, to the effect that the Pope had announced his intention of appointing the papal nucios at Lisbon, Madrid, Paris and Vienna to membership in the College of Cardinals, was read with but languid interest at the Papal Legation in Washington.

In strong contrast to the protracted struggle of the trotters at Fleetwood on Tuesday was the rapid ending of the three events that occupied the second day of the circuit meeting. A southerly wind and a cloudy sky may be well enough for the hunters, but the sort of weather that was served up yesterday is ill suited to the harness racers.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 12. -- During the last few days the friends of ex-Senator John James Ingalls have set at rest all uncertainties as to the candidacy of that erratic statesman for the seat now occupied by Senator Peffer. Ingalls is in the field, without any equivocation or mental reservation, and all the numerous aspirants for the position will soon so understand it.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 12. -- The class of '95 passed from cadet ranks at 10:30 o'clock this morning and entered the Army stood on the greensward in front of Adjt. Gen. Ruggles of the United States Army stood on the green sward in front of the cadet library and handed the graduates their priceless diplomas.
Columbia College held its one hundred and forty-first annual commencement in Music Hall last evening.
The programme for the tableaux vivants to be given this evening at Palmer's Theatre for the benefit of the Music Room of the Woman's Building at the Atlanta Exposition, is as follows:

The prompt upsetting of Judge Goff's political decision in the South Carolina registration case by the Circuit Court of Appeals at Richmond is a fortunate circumstance, for it will put a stop to a most pernicious tendency of opinion toward a support of such quasi-judicial interference with State election laws.

SARATOGA, June. 12. -- The second day of the State Sunday School Convention was opened at 9 A.M., with a consecration service, led by the Rev. S.S. Eddy. It was conducted in three separate conferences.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12. -- There was a bitter struggle between the members of the Grocers and Importers' Exchange this afternoon over that organization's attitude on the question as to whether gold or silver coinage should be adopted as the country's monetary basis. The white-metal men openly charged their opponents with dishonest methods in trying to put the organization on record as against free silver.
After two adjournments, the trial of Capt. Joseph B. Eakins of the Mercer Street station was begun before the Police Commissioners yesterday morning on charges preferred by the Parkhurst society.

MILFORD, N.H., June 12. -- The Milford Savings Bank suspended payment this morning. Bank Commissioners Tyford and Baker Tuesday afternoon served a court injunction on the savings bank restraining the institution from receiving or paying deposits. The order was made by request of the Board of Trustees to the Bank Commissioners.
SARATOGA, June 12. -- In the Court of Appeals to-day, Galen R. Hitt of counsel for the defendant in the case of the People against Bartholomew Shea, began his argument in behalf of the appellant.
PANAMA, via Galveston, June 12. -- There is little confidence that the Ecuador Government at Quito will last a while longer.
JACKSON, June 12. -- Ex-Congressman Bryan of Nebraska spoke here last night on the financial question.

Ex-Assemblyman James L. Wells was yesterday appointed a Commissioner of Taxes and Assessments, to succeed John Whalen, Tammany. Mr. Wells is classed as a Platt Republican, although it is claimed that he has been rather lukewarm in his factional feeling of late. He had a talk with Mr. Platt at his office yesterday, however, a few hours before he was appointed.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 12. -- The fields were crowded in all of to-day's races of the Syracuse Athletic Association in the National Circuit. Thirty-six men were entered in the Class B events, and sixty-five in Class A. There were several bad falls during the day, caused by crowding. At the start of a heat of the half-mile open race, little Kisser of Dayton crowded Jenny and four men came down.

Richard Croker will return to this city early in September, if he does not change his mind and come over before that time. He will not actively engage in local political affairs, but he will advise with his friends in the Tammany organization as to the best policy to be pursued.

GENEVA, Ind., June 12. -- All the stores and dwellings between the Shamrock Hotel and the Grand Rapids and Indiana Railroad, both sides of the street, burned this morning, entailing a loss of over $100,000, with about $35,000 insurance. Thirty residences and store buildings were destroyed. The Grand Rapids station was burned.
BATH, N.Y., June 12. -- Steuben County was to-day divided into two Assembly districts, as follows:

Sidney Jacquelin of 139 West Forty-first Street, a dapper young law student at Columbia College, was arraigned before Police Justice Deuel in the Yorkville Court yesterday afternoon, on a charge of larceny.

SOUTHAMPTON, June 13. -- At 4:20 o'clock this morning, in broad daylight, the American Line steamship St. Louis slowly entered her dock, looming tall and majestic on the high water and dwarfing all the vessels near her. She had a tug at her bow and another at her stern, and they slowly swung her head seaward.

NEWPORT, June 12. -- James V. Parker of New-York, who has rented the Holmes cottage. Bellevue Avenue, arrived to-day for the season. Mrs. John Clinton Gray of Albany also arrived. Judge Gray will be here Saturday. Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin R. Smith of Philadelphia, Mrs. Jerome Napoleon Bonaparte of Washington, and Mrs. C.N. Beach of Hartford opened their cottages to-day.

There was a full attendance of members of the Southern Railway and Steamship Association when the annual meeting was called to order in the Hotel Waldorf yesterday forenoon. After Secretary Stone had called the roll, the reports of the various committees were submitted and properly referred.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Dr. Wolfred Nelson of New-York City, for eight years a resident of Central and South America and the West Indies, was in Washington yesterday to consult with Surgeon General Wyman of the Marine Hospital Service over the possibilities of danger from the introduction of yellow fever.
LONDON, June 12. -- The Post will tomorrow publish a dispatch from Berlin saying that the question of a Chinese loan seems to have caused a marked divergence of opinion between Russia and Germany.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 12. -- The celebration of the two hundredth anniversary of the First Congregational Church of this city was begun this afternoon. The edifice was elaborately decorated and crowded to the doors. Prayer was offered by the Rev. Frank Russell, pastor of the South Congregational Church.

Many persons are asking when work will actually be begun on the great bridge that is proposed to be built across the Hudson River from New-York to Weehawken. Others are speculating how long a time will be required to build the structure, the plans for which are beyond any ever undertaken before.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 12. -- The two days' musical festival of the Wilkesbarre Oratorio Society ended to-night with a concert performance of an opera called "Catrin," by Dr. J.J. Mason, conductor of the society. The opera is founded on a Welsh story of disappointed love and insanity. In setting the book to music Dr. Mason ingeniously introduced some Welsh airs, and these lent the principal attractiveness to a score which was otherwise conventional and uninteresting.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 12. -- The twelfth annual meeting of the International Missionary Union opened this evening, at Clifton Springs, with the President, the Rev. J.T. Gracey, D.D., of Rochester, in the chair. There were over 100 missionaries present from mission fields all over the world, and representing all denominations.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 12. -- The House this morning, by a vote of 22 in favor to 128 against, rejected the amendment to the anti-pool law, which provides that pools may be sold on racetracks for twelve days in each year, between May 1 and Nov. 1. The Senate passed the amendment two weeks ago by a vote of 12 to 8, but the action of the House to-day probably kills the measure.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 12. -- Pretty girls, stately matrons, athletic young men, business men, expert farmers, amateur farmers, and people who did not know anything about farming gathered here to-day at the opening of the twenty-ninth annual Summer exhibition of the Queens County Agricultural Society.

An interesting fight is promised between dealers in game in this city and State and the New-York State Association for the Protection of Game under the new law that was signed by Gov. Morton last Friday. The section of the law upon which the war will be waged is as follows:
CHICAGO, June 12. -- Henry Watterson, who arrived in the city to-day from Louisville, on his way to attend the commemoration exercises of the Iowa State University, said for publication:
PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 13. -- The following is the weekly bulletin issued by Chairman Gideon of the League of American Wheelmen:
One of the most successful poolroom raids made in years was carried out by Capt. Pickett of the Nineteenth Precinct and a squad of men in the heart of the "Tenderloin" district yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Secretary Olney instituted a novel and pleasant diplomatic function this morning when he received the chief representatives of foreign nations at present in Washington. Half an hour was spent in making their acquaintance and establishing agreeable relations with them. None of his predecessors held such a levee upon their induction into office.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward Candee have gone to the divorce courts with their domestic troubles. Mrs. Candee alleges that her husband was guilty of such conduct in Denver, Col., that she is entitled to an absolute divorce.

ALBANY, June 13. -- Gov. Morton to-day signed the Supplemental Supply bill. Two items of appropriation were vetoed. One was of $2,000 for some improvements on the river near this city, and the other was of $25,000 for payment to the Panama Railroad Company for taxes claimed to have been excessively levied by the State. In vetoing this clause in the bill, Gov. Morton gave out the following explanatory statement:

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- The Presidential proclamation admonishing the Cuban filibusters is somewhat extraordinary in the annals of the State Department. It is not, of course, without precedent, for at this late day almost any performanuce would find its justification in previous similar action, if one were looking for this sort of support.

CHICAGO, June 13. -- When the State Legislature adjourned this evening at Springfield, it cut off all possibility of the enactment of any race track legislation at this session of the General Assembly. It is now too late to report the Humphrey bill back to the House, and have it acted upon before the session expires.

The decision of the Supreme Court of Illinois with respect to the Distilling and Cattle Feeding Company (commonly called the Whisky Trust, although it may with more propriety be called the Alcohol Trust,) discloses what seems to be a very interesting disagreement between the Federal courts and the Illinois court of last resort.

CHICAGO, June 13. -- Soon after the receipt of the Supreme Court's decision in the Whisky Trust case, Receiver McNulta suggested to Marshal Arnold that additional deputies be sworn in and distributed among the local distilleries. The Marshal began enrolling the required number of men at noon, the greater number going to Riverdale, which place, it was rumored, would be attacked to-night.

Mr. Carter's opinion that the Governor may sign the Manhattan State Hospital bill and make it a law, notwithstanding the failure of the Mayor to certify its acceptance by the city, or, indeed, to attach any certificate to it at all, seems to be based upon the assumption that the Mayor's "veto" was not intended to be final upon special city bills after the adjournment of the Legislature, any more than during the session.

A conference was held in Cornelius Vanderbilt's office, in the Grand Central Station, yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of arranging the details under which the projected new railroad between Toronto and Buffalo will be operated as a part of the Vanderbilt system.

Three one-act plays by Mr. Russ Whytal were performed at the Fifth Avenue Theatre yesterday afternoon, before a large "professional" audience. In the first, called "Taps," the scene was a rampart of Fort Monroe. Anne Leslie, niece of the commanding officer, had promised to marry Lieut. Langdon of the garrison, but the presence of James Barrington, a middle-aged poet, had a disturbing influence upon the course of true love.

Mayor Strong has sold to Messrs. Weil Mayer, real estate brokers, the property at 535 Broadway, extending through to Mercer Street, 28 by 200. There is an old brick building at the Broadway end of the lot, which, many years ago, was the mansion of John Jacob Astor, the old fur dealer, who laid the foundation of the family fortune.
The New-Yorks played a good game of ball yesterday, and, through the assistance of the effective pitching of Rusie, defeated the St. Louis team.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 13. -- Senator Jones reported the resolutions when the Bimetallic Convention reassembled this afternoon. The platform is as follows:

If there can be degrees of meanness in forgery, the manufacture of sham pennies with intent to betray the confidence of slots must surely form the lowest of them. A man was sentenced to fourteen days' imprisonment, at the Mansion House, yesterday, for using counterfeits of this description to minister to a guilty passion for chocolate.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- At the conference this afternoon between the President, the Public Printer and the Civil Service Commission, the President signed the order placing the employes of the Government Printing Office under the civil service.

Commissioner Harburger of the Excise Board is conducting a rigid investigation into the character of the applicants for licenses, and the manner in which their papers are made out. He says he has discovered many irregularities, and a total disregard for the truth in many cases.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 13. -- The movement inaugurated at the Chicago conference to organize a distinctively free-silver party, with ex-Congressman Joseph C. Sibley of Pennsylvania as its candidate for President, received its quietus at the bimetallic convention to-day.

The congregation of the Church of St. Anthony, in Sullivan Street, was honored yesterday, at the celebration of the seventh centenary of its patron, St. Anthony of Padua, by the presence of Mgr. Satolli, Papal Delegate to United States.

The first papers touching real estate in the district recently annexed to this city were filed yesterday in the Register's office. They were a deed by Daniel Rothstein to Marks Kirschbaum, and a mortgage by Charles Schindler to Edward B. Reynolds.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13. -- Third Vice President Pugh of the Pennsylvania Railroad to-day announced several important changes in the transportation department of the company. L.F. Brooks, Superintendent of the Maryland Division of the Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore, has been appointed to the Superintendency of the New-York Division, to succeed Joseph Crawford, who, on account of illness, has been granted an indefinite leave of absence.

LONDON, June 13. -- The regatta of the Royal Southampton Yacht Club, in which only the Britannia and Ailsa took part, was delayed this morning by a calm that was not dissipated until nearly 11 o'clock, when a gentle northeasterly breeze sprang up. The yachts carried club topsails and jibtopsails at the start. A slack ebb tide assisted them over the first leg of the course, a stretch of about twelve miles.
President Roosevelt of the Police Board took evidence yesterday in the cases of sixty-one patrolmen who are accused of having violated the rules of the department.
TOPEKA, Kan., June 13. -- "Jerry" Simpson, in an interview last night, said:

MINEOLA, L.I., June 13. -- The second day of the Queen's County Agricultural Fair brought people from every Long Island village to the grounds. From early morning there was a continued procession of carriages entering the gates, and trains from the cities drew up at the station packed with visitors.

Alvin Thomas, twenty-seven years old, of 537 Third Avenue was held in the Tombs Police Court yesterday for examination on the charge of arson. Peter Schmitz of 2,551 Third Avenue swears that Thomas gave him $50 on account of $300 to set fire to his restaurant at 521 Third Avenue, in which Schmitz was cook.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., June 13. -- Passed East -Steam yachts Orients, E. R. Ladew; Emeline, Stephen J. Roach; Charlietta, W. B. Higgins, and Almy, Frederick Gallatin. Sloop yachts Sasqua, Henry Andruss, and Banshee, Henry Doscher. Raters Vorant II., George E. Tyson, and Wildcat.

PANAMA, via Galveston, June 13. -- Gov. Arango of Panama gave a grand banquet this evening to Gen. Ramon Ulloa, the officers of the regiment of Cauca from Cuarto and Cali, and the start of the regiment of Colombia, at the Central Hotel. The Government Secretaries and officials were present.

The stock market opened strong to-day, the bear raid just at the close yesterday being entirely ignored. Chicago Gas opened 1 1/4 points up, Sugar a point, Pacific Mail 5/8, and Southern and Northwestern each 1/2 point. The general list was about 1/4 point better than the close. London had buying orders, but at prices too low to be executed in this market.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 13. -- The mysterious disappearance of the Cornell student, Frederick Gordon Rew, the only son of E.B. Rew of Buffalo, N.Y., occurred the evening of Oct. 2, 1894. A reward of $1,000 is offered by Mr. Rew, based upon the following sworn statement by Charles H. Mix of Renovo, Clinton County, Penn.:

TRENTON, N.J., June 13. -- The long conflict between Gov. Werts and the Legislature came to an end at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon by the final adjournment of the Legislature. The struggle was continued to the last moment, and during the day vetoes by the Governor were overridden, and his nominations rejected.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 13. -- Cornelius Vanderbilt, accompanied by his private secretary, Alfred Skitts, passed the day here looking over his new Summer residence. Mr. Vanderbilt believes that the house can be made ready for use by June 25, and the family will probably arrive on that date.

Five down-town banks must look to the courts for $50,000 or more, which they gave up on forged paper, and the East River Silk Company of Astoria, L.I., has been involved by the operations of the company's Treasurer, Albert S. Moore. Exposure landed Moore in the Tombs yesterday, and placed attachments on the silk works to make good his stealings.

Let the small boy rejoice. There will be fire crackers to burn in more senses of the word than one this year. There is a larger supply on the market than usual, and the prices will be reduced one-half.
The present rebellion in Cuba is likely to have a serious and lasting effect upon the price of Havana tobacco.

BOSTON, June 13. -- A case of considerable financial magnitude was to-day taken up in the United States Circuit Court, before Judge Carpenter, on a plea filed by the defendants, to show that they should not be compelled to answer the plaintiffs' bill in equity. It is a suit brought by the American Graphophone Company vs. the New-England Phonograph Company and Augustus P. Martin, President, and Augustus N. Sampson, General Manager, of the defendant company.

Orlando K. Fay, twenty-seven years old, son of J.H. Fay of Winchendon, Mass., shot himself in a room at the Astor House yesterday afternoon, because he was unable to gain admission to the division of the United States Navy for which he thought he was qualified, and for the secondary reason that, after this failure, he could not find employment.

A peculiar case of blood poisoning has just been brought to the attention of physicians in this city, and it is likely to lead to investigation in a new field of research. A mosquito bite, it is claimed, caused the death on Tuesday of Bertha Wurr, the eighteen-months-old daughter of Henry Wurr, a cigarmaker, who lives in a rear house at 44 Morton Street.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 13. -- The Supreme Court this morning, in the Whisky Trust case, affirmed the decision of the Cook County Court, declaring the trust illegal. The decision is one of the strongest arraignments of combinations for the purpose of cornering or controlling prices in products ever promulgated by any court, and has given Attorney General Moloney and his assistants much satisfaction.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- A morning paper says that Messrs. W.L. Elkins, P.A.B. Widener, and Thomas Dolan of Philadelphia have disposed of all their interest in street and suburban railroads in the District of Columbia to the Maryland capitalists who are building the boulevard electric railroad between this city and Baltimore.

Having read the address of Bishop Doane of Albany to the graduating class of St. Agnes's School, touching on the woman suffrage question, and also the comments of Mrs. Julia Ward Howe and other suffragists on the same, I am tempted to write a few words on the subject from the standpoint of an anti-suffrage woman.

SOUTHAMPTON, June 13. -- The steamship St. Louis, 11,000 tons, of the American Line, built at Cramps' shipyards, in Philadelphia, completed her first voyage across the Atlantic by arriving at Southampton at 4:45 o'clock this morning.

PITTSBURG, June 13. -- The contract for the electrical equipment of the Manhattan Elevated Railway of New-York has been awarded to the Westinghouse Electric Company of Pittsburg. The contract covers between $7,000,000 and $8,000,000.

HOBOKEN, N.J., June 13. -- Work has been started on the North River Bridge whose projectors are President E.F.C. Young, of the First National Bank, Jersey City, Jordan L. Mott of New-York, ex-United States Treasurer Charles Canda, and Chief Engineer Charles Lindenthal. A gang of men is now at work sounding for a foundation in the yard of the house on the northwest corner of Garden and Twelfth Street, this city.

JERSEY CITY, June 13. -- Several stockholders of the North American Company have been trying to get a list of the company's stockholders in order to contest the election of Directors named by the Villard interest at the annual election appointed for June 19. They have not been successful.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- An inquiry is making into the ventilation on board ships of war. The investigation is the result of many complaints made by those who are forced to inhabit the vessels for long periods. The lack of good air is not confined to the firerooms, but is also noticeable in the living quarters and the sleeping places.

Every breath of encouragement extended to the advocates of the coinage of silver at the ratio of 16 to 1 or any other ratio will but contribute to the determination of the Republican managers to force an election of President in 1897 by the House of Representatives. Do the Republicans hope to have a silver President chosen in that roundabout and unsatisfactory fashion?

There were rumors at Police Headquarters yesterday of a tremendous "shake-up" in the department, which would not leave the humblest patrolman in his old berth. President Roosevelt was quoted as the authority for the statement of the big changes coming in a few days.

BRIGDEPORT, Conn., June 13. -- The beating of drums announced the commencement of services at the First Congregational Church this morning. Armed sentinels stood at the door. They were attired in Colonial costumes, and marched around the church, as was the custom in that dangerous period 200 years ago, when the church was founded. Inside the edifice was crowded.

A leading feature of the fifty-fourth athletic games of the New-York Athletic Club, which are to be held at Travers Island to-morrow, will be the one-mile race. The scratch men will be Thomas P. Conneff, holder of the world's record, and George W. Orton, the intercollegiate champion. The handicap limit has been placed at sixty yards, in order to choke off all but the leading cracks of the country.
There was a well-attended meeting of elocutionists and others at the St. Cloud Hotel last night to take preliminary steps to form the American Society for the Improvement of Speech.

ALBANY, June 13. -- It is more than likely that the State Civil Service Commission will make an attempt to check the patronage grab on the part of the Capitol Commission, of which something was said in the Albany dispatches to The New-York Times yesterday. If it does this it will be because it considers that the new Constitution puts appointments to the Capitol construction force into the classified service.
FLUSHING, L.I., June 13. -- The Flushing Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association opened its new home at 57 Locust Street to-day.

ALBANY, June 13. -- Gov. Morton will probably sign the bill which creates the Manhattan State Hospital and transfers the New-York City insane to the care of the State. This is the bill which Mayor Strong returned without a certificate either of approval or disapproval.

The quarterly meeting of Group 9 of the New-York State Bankers' Association was held last night at Sherry's, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street. J.M. Donald presided. The group is composed of the Presidents, Vice Presidents, and cashiers of the banks of this city.
These appointments were announced by Mayor Strong yesterday. It was said that he would have also appointed as the third Bridge Trustee Salem H. Wales, (Rep.,) had Mr. Wales been in the city.
Joseph H. Choate indulged in a bit of Summer relaxation yesterday. For two hours he cross-examined Russell Sage in the fifty-thousand-dollar damage suit brought by William R. Laidlaw.

Imputations of improper motives on the part of the twenty Aldermen who voted in favor of the resolution granting the application of the Third Avenue Railroad Company for a franchise to extend its road from One Hundred and Sixty-second Street and Amsterdam Avenue to King's Bridge, were freely bandied about at the public hearing given on the matter yesterday afternoon by Mayor Strong.
PANAMA, via Galveston, June 14. -- Steamer Areguipa, which arrived this morning two days overdue, reports that quiet reigns at Guayaquil, Ecuador.

The game between the New-York and Cleveland Clubs yesterday at the Polo Grounds was a little bit too interesting for comfort. It was a pitchers' game, as the batting on both sides was light, and the hits were scattered.

The Judges of the Court of Common Pleas have decided that their court is a "county court" in the sense designated by the new naturalization act passed recently by the Legislature, and they will therefore resume the work of naturalization.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 14. -- The Cornell freshmen had a practical walk-over in their eight-oared race against the University of Pennsylvania freshmen here to-day. The Quakers were not in the race after the first 100 yards. The Courtney stroke has proved successful for Cornell's twenty-fourth victory.

Mrs. Hetty Green, whose eccentricities and many legal conflicts have attracted attention for several years, prayed quietly yesterday in a business office, and the astonished lawyers and reporters present gave silent heed to her devotions.

The Thirteenth Precinct, in the heart of the east side, was selected by Police Commissioners Roosevelt and Andrews yesterday morning for a tour of observation, to learn in what manner police duty is performed in that section of the city. They were agreeably surprised to find a better state of affairs than Mr. Roosevelt discovered in his recent tour through the Twenty-first Precinct.

Albert S. Moore, whose forgeries brought him money from several down-town banks, said at the Tombs yesterday that claims against him might reach $75,000 or more. The list published in The New-York Times gave $25,000 as the amount obtained on forged paper from the Bank of America. This was the statement made at that bank.
WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Attorney General Harmon has addressed to all United States District Attorneys between New York and Brownsville, Texas, the following letter of instruction:

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 14. -Eight men, one of them accused of deliberate murder, escaped from the Middlesex County Jail, in this city, last night. The authorities think they had aid from the inside. The delivery of the prisoners had evidently been carefully planned and precaution taken that there should be no discovery.

UTICA, N.Y., June 14. -- Private Albert Mattey of Battery G, United States Army,, stationed at Governors Island, who is carrying a dispatch on a bicycle to Gen. Merritt at Fort Sheridan, Illinois, from Gen. Miles, stopped last night at Ilion and passed through here at 5:30 o'clock this morning.

LOUISVILLE, June 14. -- Secretary of the Treasury John G. Carlisle delivered his third sound-money speech in Kentucky to-night to an immense audience in Music Hall. Mr. Carlisle was introduced by Charles R. Long of the Democratic State Executive Committee. The Secretary directed his arguments mainly to the working classes, which composed the major portion of his audience.

To sensible men of all parties, and particularly to sound-money men of the Democratic Party, the action of the leading Democrats in the latest Memphis convention is decidedly encouraging. That convention met in the name of bimetallism, under the guidance of such furious free-silver zealots as Bryan of Nebraska and Sibley of Pennsylvania.

The Spring regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club will be sailed to-day. Forty-four yachts have entered, and the Regatta Committee will have a lively time taking their times at the starting line and turning marks. The start will be made off the clubhouse at 11 o'clock, and the tug Raymond will take members of the club out to see the races.

Fireworks at Coney Island. -- The first fireworks display of the season will be made at Pain's outdoor theatre at Manhattan Beach this evening, but the production of the spectacle based on scenes and incidents of the war between Japan and China will not be made until next week. In all probability the first regular presentation will be given next Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- The Government Printing Office rules, as signed by the President, provide for the grouping of the force into classes, on a basis of compensation. They provide for practical, competitive examinations, and for places for which examinations are not practicable for the registration of applicants, and their appointment in the order of registration.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 14. -- There is one day more of the Constitutional thirty-day period in which Gov. Morton may approve bills left in his hands when the Legislature adjourned. Those upon which he fails to act before midnight of Saturday cannot become laws.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- The Director of the Mint, R.E. Preston, estimates the world's production of gold for the calendar year 1894 to have approximated 8,780,518 fine ounces of the value of $181,510,100, against $158,836,000 for 1893, showing an increase of $22,678,000 in 1894.

The procedures of the new Police Commissioners shed an unpleasant light backward upon the conduct of their predecessors in office. The new Commissioners are not tremendous geniuses, to the best of our belief, or heaven-born administrators. They are simply intelligent and conscientious citizens who feel bound honestly to discharge the duties of offices of which they receive the salaries.

Your article this morning, "Mr. Choate and Mr. Sage," is not in keeping with the usual dignity of your editorials. I am a constant reader, and greatly admire the broad and statesmanlike views that generally pervade your columns, but surely this article is an exception.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 14. -- Mrs. Harriet Beecher Stowe was eighty-four years old to-day, and the event was celebrated in a quiet manner at her home on Forest Street, in this city. The aged authoress is in good health, and enjoys a walk in the grounds connected with her residence everyday. She is as agile and light of foot as a girl of sixteen.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 14. -- A fuss started in front of the Speaker's desk in the House at 11:50 to-night, which was precipitated by a "heeler" named Quinton.

ROCK ISLAND, Ill., June 14. -- Ben T. Cable, replying to a letter received by him from Chairman Hinrichsen of the Illinois State Central Committee, requesting his acquiescence as a member of the National Committee in a call for a national convention on the monetary issue, says:

The report of Mr. Henry Leipziger, Superintendent of Lectures, to the Committee on Evening Schools and the City Superintendent of Education calls attention to the increasing value of an agency of public instruction which Mr. Leipziger himself has done more than anybody else to develop. It is fashionable to say that the day of the lyceum has gone by.

Harmony among the Democratic factions in this city is apparently an interesting topic of talk just now. Ex-Mayor Grant put himself squarely on record for it before leaving for Europe. County Clerk Henry D. Purroy got back from Europe yesterday and raised his voice in favor of peace in the party.
FLUSHING, L.I., June 14. -- The Board of School Trustees of the village of College Point to-night passed upon the question "Is the riding of a bicycle by a young lady an improper practice?"

FALL RIVER, Mass., June 14. -- A catastrophe, which created the greatest excitement in the city since the Granite Mill fire, occurred this morning at the Langley Icom harness shop, on County Street, a three-story wooden building, owned by Henry I. Langley.

FLUSHING, L.I., June 14. -- The Zion Church Society, Little Neck, will celebrate next Sunday the sixty-fifth anniversary of its organization, which took place June 17, 1830. The church building was erected and presented to the parish by the late Wynant Van Zandt, Esq., July 30, 1830. It was consecrated to the worship of Almighty God by the Right Rev. Bishop Hobart.

Marble Hill, across the Harlem River from King's Bridge, has a hose cart, an abundant supply of hose, and other Fire Department apparatus loaned to the Marble Hill Volunteer Hose Company, which was organized about a month ago, by the New-York Fire Department. The hose cart and its equipments were delivered yesterday afternoon.

Charles W. Henry, seventy-two years old, who since Saturday last had lived alone in the house at 95 South Portland Avenue, Brooklyn, one of the most select neighborhoods on the Hill, was found lying dead on the floor at the foot of the basement stairs yesterday afternoon, but it was after ten o'clock last night when the police decided that he had been murdered.

HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., June 14. -Roslyn Wilkes, J. Pierpont Morgan's collie, winner of prizes at the dog shows of New-York, Boston, St. Louis, Philadelphia, Cincinnati, London, Paris and Vienna, drowned herself at "Cragstons," Mr. Morgan's country home to-day, according to the statement of "Bob" Armstrong, Mr. Morgan's kennel keeper.

From time to time the Congress is asked by members who are still so inexperienced as to be indifferent to a sort of popularity to pass a law abolishing the office of Public Printer and to provide that all the Government printing shall be done by contract, the work to be thrown open to competition.

In direct conflict with the General Term of the Court of Common Pleas, the General Term of the Supreme Court yesterday handed down a decision holding that the new Constitutional amendment wiping out the five-thousand-dollar limit of damages in cases of death by accident is not retroactive in any sense.

CHICAGO, June 14. -- Nine million eight hundred thousand dollars is offered for part of the property of the Distilling and Cattle Feeding Company by the Reorganization Committee, which owns and controls 347,067 shares of the company's stock, leaving 2,933 shares which stand in the name of Greenhut and others.
While trying to avoid arrest yesterday Michael Callahan, known to the police as a petty thief, was shot by Policeman Doyle of the East Fifty-first Street Police Station.

BOSTON, June 14. -- The opinion of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in the case of the American Bell Telephone Company and others, appellants, vs. The United States, appellee, in which the validity of the Berliner patent is involved, was filed this afternoon. The opinion is written by Judge Putnam.

BUFFALO, June 14 -- H. Walter Webb arrived here this morning and spent a few hours in consultation with some Buffalo men interested in the Depew Improvement Company. Regarding the election of a President for the company, Mr. Webb said that the corporation, now having a Vice President, Secretary, and Treasurer, was on a working basis, and the election of a President would be held in abeyance for a week or ten days.
Sebastian Krenacher of 2,395 Second Avenue, wished to secure a wife, and thought he could best attain his object through a matrimonial bureau. Thus far he has not found a wife.
The biggest shake-up in the history of Brooklyn's Police Department was made yesterday. Police Commissioner Welles transferred twenty Police Captains. He said it was for the benefit of the service.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- The United States ship Atlanta left New-London, Conn., to-day for the East River entrance to the Harlem Ship Canal, to attend the opening there on June 17. The cruiser Cincinnati will be at the Hudson River end.
The various city departments and local organizations that will take part in the opening of the Harlem Ship Canal on Monday have perfected their arrangements.
FRIEDRICHSRUH, June 14. -- Prince Bismarck is feeling very weak and in consequence has canceled his engagements for the present.

The Trustees of St. Luke's Hospital have sold, through Mr. Charles MacRae, four lots on the north side of Fifty-fourth Street, beginning 125 feet west of Fifth Avenue, and three lots in the rear, facing on Fifty-fifth Street, at about $400,000. The purchaser, it is understood, intends erecting a handsome detached mansion on the plot.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15. -- A mock duel with rifles, in which two young members of the Third Regiment, N.G.S.P., engaged to-night, with playful intention, had a tragic ending. One rifle proved to be loaded with a ball cartridge, and its discharge blew out the brains of Robert Cummings, aged nineteen years. His comrade, whose carelessness was attended with such terrible results, was Louis Carlin, of the same age.

In illustration of the mysterious peculiarities of the denizens of salt water, a story comes to town from Quartermaster Harbor concerning a colony of Australian shrimps. These shrimps were brought to the Sound with barnacles and other foreign matter, clinging to the hull of an Australian lumber schooner which was put on the dry dock for a general overhauling.

The Boston Methodist Preachers' meeting, in Wesleyan Hall, was addressed Monday morning by the Rev. E.E. Hoss, D.D., of the Methodist Episcopal Church, (South,) and editor of The Nashville Christian Advocate, the official organ of the Church. His topic was "The Negro Problem as a Southerner Sees It." He was most cordially received with loud and continuous applause.
The annual exhibition of the Manual Training Department of the Normal College was held yesterday.

June had come, a radiant June, and all at Frayne was joyous anticipation, despite the momentous fact that the Platte had overleaped its bounds and was raging like some mad mountain torrent far as the eye could see. The flats to the west of the post were one broad, muddy lake. The grassy bench beneath the bluffs to the east was partially torn away.

Vegetation and speculation were both revived by the abundant rainfall reported during the past ten days. A week or so ago it looked as if the stock market would be dull for the remainder of the month, but the bulls could not resist the influence of the weather reports, which told of rainfalls in the Western wheat and corn regions so abundant that it was said farmers were beginning to talk of a wet harvest.

Good blackberries may be purchased for 20 cents a quart. They come from North Carolina. Plums from California add to the attractiveness of the fruit stands. Large blue prunes are 35 cents a dozen. Gylman plums are 30 cents a dozen, and cherry plums are 10 cents a dozen. Huckleberries sell at 15 cents a quart, and gooseberries at 10 cents a quart.

It was a happy thought of those who are managing the celebration of the one hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the capture of Louisburg, on June 17, 1745, to use historical metal in making the medals which are to be memorials distributed at the exercises to-morrow. A French frigate, supposed to be Le Celebre, was blown up during the siege, and her cannon were recovered by divers.
LENOX, Mass., June 15. -- The current week has been given up to driving, rowing, golf, tennis, and other outdoor sports. There have also been a few informal dances and small dinner parties.

Thanks to a fortunate real estate purchase and the generosity of J. Pierpont Morgan, a long-needed and elaborate operating room is being added to the otherwise perfect equipment of the Orthopedic Dispensary and Hospital a 126 and 128 East Fifty-ninth Street, of whose Board of Supervisors Miss Roosevelt, 689 Madison Avenue, is the President.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- In a dozen track and field contests on the grounds of the Chicago Athletic Association this afternoon the team of athletes which represented that association defeated the University of California team. J.V. Crum, the Iowa sprinter, equaled the world's record for 100 yards -- 0:9 4-5. He made it in ten flat at the intercollegiate meet. Following are the summaries:

The progress made in applying mechanical modes of traction and propulsion gives hope of a time when horses may be excluded from the streets of cities, at least those occupied for purposes of residence. How much this will conduce to cleanliness, comfort, and health can easily be imagined.
ST. PETERSBURG, June 15.--The Czar has conferred on President Faure of France the Grand Collar ol' the Order of St. Andrew.

Capt. Eakins's trial before the Police Commissioners was resumed yesterday. The letter written May 13 by the Parkhurst Society to Chief Byrnes, copies of which were also sent to the Police Board and Mayor Strong, calling attention to the condition of things in the Fifteenth Precinct, has caused much talk. The letter came out in evidence during the examination Friday evening of "Angel" Dennett, Acting Superintendent of the Parkhurst Society.

The Hon. W.J. Coombs has made a suggestion that may commend itself to the next Congress when it shall be asked to consider the importance of a reformation of our Diplomatic and Consular Service. It is certainly worthy of consideration. Mr. Coombs's suggested reform would be radical.
Asked yesterday when he would act on the resolution of the Board of Aldermen granting the great King's Bridge Road franchise to the Third Avenue Railroad Company, Mayor Strong said:

LONDON, June 15. -- Many have been the assertions and denials that Prime Minister Rosebery was anxious to lay down the cares of office, but the first authoritative statement was made yesterday, when Lord Rosebery himself confessed in a speech in the Clerkenwell district his desire to retire from the Premiership, and that the time was near when the Government would be overthrown.

Once more we are confronted with evidence of the weird qualities of head and heart which seem to go with the ambition to take part in the supervision of public instruction. That Brooklyn builder and School Trustee who denounced Longfellow's "Building of the Ship" as an indecent poem made a record which has stood for some years.

ORANGE, N.J., June 15. -- The Orange Athletic Club defeated Cornell University at baseball at the Orange Oval this afternoon in a pretty game, in which there were but three errors made, and those by the visitors, all in one inning. The home team won by superior stick work, and shut out the visitors. The fielding was very clean on both sides.

Ex-Judge William H. Arnoux has received a decided setback at the hands of the General Term of the Supreme Court, which holds that certain testimony of alleged fraud on the part of Judge Arnoux was improperly excluded by the trial court.
The shake-up in the Brooklyn Police Department Friday has caused the Police Captains to feel blue, and many of them believe that instead of improving the service it will have the opposite effect.

" Hull House," the Chicago variant of that movement which here resulted in the University Settlement, has now been in existence for six years. Its members, or, as they are called, its "residents," have tried the effect of personal association with that part of Chicago's population among whom wages are lowest, and where the vice which grows from poverty is most pronounced.

The Casino show, which has been worked into shape, as the saying is, since a week ago last night, and the three little plays by Russ Whytal, tried at a "professional" matinee, were the only novelties of the week. The dramatic season is no more. From now until August even the "snaps" will be missing. The Casino review is excellent of its unclassifiable kind, and Mr. Daniel Daly is its hero.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- Five members of St. Hedwig's parish this morning filed a bill in the Superior Court for an injunction to restrain Archbishop Feehan from sending Father Sedlaczek to St. Hedwig's Polish Catholic Church to conduct the services there to-morrow morning.

Mayor Strong held a long consultation yesterday with President E.P. Barker and Commissioners Sutro and Wells of the Department of Taxes and Assessments. After this talk was over the Mayor sent for Civil Service Commissioner Watson and had a very earnest talk with him. One result of these conferences was the rumor that there would be a wholesale cleaning out of the present subordinates in the Tax Department.

In the Manchester Town Hall there are two life-sized marble statues. One is that of John Dalton, the other that of James Prescott Joule. The first shows the figure of the discoverer of the laws of chemical-combining proportions, the other the discoverer of the law of the conservation of energy.

WELLSVILLE, N. Y., June 15. -- Grand old Allegany, in her dotage, has decided to call together her grandchildren at Wellsville on June 26 and 27 for the purpose of celebrating the one hundredth anniversary of the settlement of the first white man who had the courage to claim her territory as a home.

The New-York Athletic Club held its fifty-fourth annual games on the picturesque grounds of the club at Travers Island yesterday. As a general rule the New-York Athletic Club is very favorably treated by the weather deities, and to-day was no exception, the atmospherical conditions being simply perfect.

A meeting of the Southern Railway and Steamship Association was held at the Waldorf Hotel yesterday morning. The delegates present were the executive officers of the various Southern transportation companies. The object of the meeting was to form a new freight-traffic agreement covering competitive business for the year beginning Aug. 1 next, and expiring by limitation July 31, 1895.

The Louis Down-Town Sabbath and Daily School is a magnificent example of what can be accomplished by noble-minded women among the young and old of their sex in the hearts of the slums. From that up-town section where the wealthiest of the community live a few of the philanthropic Jewish women have combined for the highly laudable purpose of elevating the children of the lowliest of the Jewish population in the thickly settled down-town districts.
WHITESTONE, L.I., June 15. -- The Sergeants and Corporals of the United States Engineer Battalion played a spirited game of baseball this forenoon. The Sergeants won by a score of 12 to 8.

KUSHAQUA, N.Y., June 15. -- Lake Kushaqua is the Indian name given to what was formerly known as Round Lake, a resting spot in the north woods of the Adirondacks, about half way between Paul Smith's noted resort and the station of Loon Lake. Kushaqua, freely translated, means Beautiful Resting Place, although Beautiful Water would be a more literal rendering of the word.

The Standard National Bank, the latest addition to the national banks of this city, will be opened for business at 9 o'clock to-morrow morning, in commodious and handsome quarters on the ground floor of the Metropolitan Life Building, Madison Avenue and Twenty-third Street.

H.H. Cabaniss, manager of The Atlanta Journal, has been at the Savoy Hotel several days. When asked last night if the rumor was true that Hoke Smith was to be a candidate for the seat in the United States Senate now held by Gen. J.B. Gordon, Mr. Cabaniss said:

Our Paris correspondent telegraphs: "The love letters addressed to Madame Recamier and all the correspondence she stored up have been sold for 5,000f. M. Rochefort wonders what use it is to be wealthy, no millionaire having tried to keep it all together. He attended the sale, bid for many of the letters that were sold separately, but only bought three.

Within the last century the organ, "the king of instruments," has bean greatly improved both in power and beauty of tone, but in the estimation of many musicians it has always lacked flexibility in the effect of the touch of the keys and the combination of the stops. This has, at length, been supplied in the electric organ. A new form of this instrument, recently exhibited in London, has some extraordinary and humanlike qualities.

In these days, when much prominence is given to Japan and things Japanese, Mr. Anderson's story of one phase of the art side of this wonderful nation will be found to be of more than usual interest to the general public. To the artists and connoisseurs, Japanese engravings have, of course, time out of mind been a most absorbing topic, both for study and collection.

NUTLEY, N.J., June 15. -- There was a carnival of sport this afternoon at Nutley, N.J., a delightful little colony which acquired much fame a few years ago by the antics of H.C. Bunner's donkey, and later by the amateur circus of March, 1804. A series of athletic games and gymokahna races was given for the benefit of Christ's Episcopal Church of Nutley, of which the Rev. Joseph P. Appleton is rector.

LACON, Ill., June 15. -- Knowles's Light of the West, an imported Shire stallion, valued at $10,000, owned by Burgess Brothers, died yesterday. The horse took first premium at the World's Columbian Exposition. Breeders considered Light of the West the best draught stallion in America.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 15. -- The fair for the Helping Hand Hospital will close to-night.

Outwardly, the house at 302 West Seventy-second Street is one of the most attractive dwellings in that quiet neighborhood of fine houses, but within there is being waged a merry war between the respective households of Mrs. Victoria Woodhull Martin and Dr. Charles Stuart Welles, who occupy it together, and all the trouble, it is said, is caused by Cupid.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 15. -- The old Colonial residence in this city, to which the poet Lydia Huntley Sigourney was taken as a bride seventy-five years ago, has passed into the hands of a wholesale Western beef syndicate, and will hereafter be used in connection with cold-storage projects.

TRENTON, N.J., June 15. -- John L. Kuser and Col. John T. Van Cleef, two of the eight persons indicted by the Grand Jury in connection with the State House frauds, gave bail to-day for their appearance in the Court of Oyer and Terminer next Wednesday, when the pleas will be taken.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 15. -- Judge Lippincott this morning sentenced Patrick Sheehan, convicted yesterday of the murder of Dietrick H. Garbs, to be hanged on Thursday, Aug. 8. Before that he asked the prisoner if he had anything to say.

A number of members of the New-York Chapter of the Society of Colonial Wars left the city Thursday for Louisburg, Cape Breton Island, where, to-morrow, the monument will be unveiled which has been erected by the General Society of Colonial Wars, to commemorate the one hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the capture of the fortress of Louisburg by the English and colonial troops from the French, June 17, 1745.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The Treasury Department has decided to strengthen the revenue cutter Patrol along the Atlantic coast from Charleston to Mobile, by ordering the cutters Morrill, McLane, and Forward to patrol those waters.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- There is destined to be considerable delay in acquiring the use of the large dry dock at Port Royal, S.C. It has been completed, and so far as can be judged, without an actual trial of the structure, it is entirely efficient. Before a big war vessel, such as the dock can accommodate, can be placed on the ways, there must be a considerable amount of dredging from the approach.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 15. -- The third annual reunion of the Underhill Society of America was held in the Women's Institute Building, in Palisade Avenue, this afternoon, and there were about seventy-five present.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 15. -- People who were anticipating going during the last week to the seashore for the Summer, and who have taken cottages at this place, have been arriving daily, and obtaining possession of them. Among the arrivals are noticed many who have never been seen at this resort before, while quite a number have spent their Summers at Long Branch for the last fifteen or twenty years.

Mr. Douglas Sladen lets us know at once that his somewhat massive volume "does not pretend to be a historical, or statistical, or in any way an authoritative book," This is both right and wise; the book is not either historical, or statistical, or in any way authoritative, but if an American reader wants to know all about Canada from an Englishman's point of view, here is his chance.

One hundred and forty-three thousand, three hundred and forty-nine watermelons were received in this city yesterday, when the watermelon season may be said to have fairly opened, although it is still in its infancy.

It is remarkable that so much has already been done in the advancement of wages in manufacturing establishments. The improvement in business is a matter of quite recent occurrence, and there may well be some question as to whether it will be reasonably permanent, in view of the uncertainty regarding the crops. Yet manufacturers have shown a most laudable disposition to give their workmen the benefit of the doubt, and to pay them higher wages.

The Summernight's festival of the German Liederkranz, New-York, was given last night at Ulmer Park, Bensonhurst. The members of the society and their friends thronged the park and the adjoining grounds, and, with music, dancing, and jollity, spent a most enjoyable day and evening.

The enmity of the late Secretary of State Gresham and ex-President Harrison was as well known as any familiar phase of Indiana politics could be, but the cause of it has never been shown in detail, although it is a matter of record in the United States District Court of this State. It came out of the trial of one of the most important and sensational political cases ever tried.

BERLIN, June 15. -- The Government desiring everything to go on smoothly, the semi-official press remains uninspired as to the question of how to deal with the developed aspects of the doubted alliance between France and Russia.

BALTIMORE, June 15. -- An Aldermanic committee from Birmingham, Ala., is here trying to save the credit of that city. The members say that the city has no intention of repudiating its financial obligations.
They call him "Snowball." Manifestly, however, that is not his name, but if you go to see "Black America" and do not see him, you miss the best half of the show and that is saying a great deal.

Mme. Blanc is so well and favorably known to us on this side of the water that, though M. Mario Bertaux's introduction is a pleasant one, such presentation was hardly necessary. Mme. Blanc, on an extended visit to the United States during the Chicago exhibition year, occupied her attention mostly with what American women were doing, their plans, their aspirations.

Half of the beautiful month has passed, the important weddings of the season have been celebrated, and now the outgoing trains and Sound boats are filled with seekers for pleasure amid cooler surroundings than those afforded by the crowded city.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 15. -The plot by which eight men secured their liberty from the Middlesex County Jail here early yesterday morning was made clear this morning by the discovery of letters in the pocket of the coat of Frank Williams, one of the fugitive firebugs.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., June 15. -- Passed East -Steam yachts Hirondelle, C.G. Evans; Theresa, Gustavus Sidenberg; Almy, Frederick Gallatin; Orienta, E.R. Ladew; Maspeth, C.M. Meyer; Linta. Walter Luttgen; Nomad, Thomas J. Byrne; Embla, John H. Hanan; Charlietta, W.B. Higgins; Alicia, H.M. Flagler, and Susquehanna, Joseph Stickney. Sloop yachts Bonito, F.T. Clayton, and Adelaide, R.W. Inman.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 15. -- When Gov, Morton, having signed his last bill, put on his hat and coat and started for Ellerslie, at 4:30 this afternoon, sixty-five measures died an inoffensive death by suffocation in a pocket veto. The thirty-day limit was ended. The last law of the late legislative session had been made.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 15. -- The season may be said to be fairly opened at this popular East End cottage resort. Nearly all the houses are now occupied, and before another week has passed the full number of Summer visitors will be here.

Scarcely had M. Daudet, with true Parisian provincialism, complained that we had presumed to lay the bones of great actors in Westminster Abbey alongside those of members of his profession, than our reply comes in the announcement that henceforth the leading actor in England shall have a title like the Presidents of the academies of music and painting.

Diversified as are the features of this country in climate, soil, surface, and exposure, no one style of architecture can be adopted to suit all conditions. A discussion of the subject in detail would embrace a range too wide for short articles like the present series, and a few general hints are all that can be given.

RONDOUT, N.Y., June 15. -- The rush of Summer visitors to the Catskills this season promises to be greater than for many years past. Already the proprietors of the majority of the Summer houses have made enough contracts to fill their rooms during the greater part of the season. New-York visitors will note many changes this Summer.

That the non-partisan platform upon which the present City Government was elected is not held in high respect by certain of the officials who have taken office under Mayor Strong has been frequently demonstrated, especially in the cases of certain ambitious Republicans.
ORANGE, N.J., June 15. -- The Junior Christian Endeavor Society of the Orange Valley Congregational Church held pleasant anniversary exercises this afternoon.
The arrangements for the parades at the opening of the Harlem Ship Canal were practically all completed last night.
An editorial paragraph recently in a New-York paper on the admittance of Utah as a State says: "Above all, polygamy is dead, never to be resurrected, either by Church or State."
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 15. -- The annual award of prizes at Yale was this noon announced, as follows:

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., June 15 -- At the bicycle meet on the grounds of the Mount Holly Athletic Association here this afternoon Zimmerman rode an exhibition mile, being paced by Starbuck and Bartholomew. After a warming-up heat, they got away together, and at the last quarter Zimmerman sped away and finished in 2:07 1-5 amid the plaudits of the large crowd in the grand stand.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., June 15. -- Mrs. Nelson A. Byers, wife of a prominent lumberman of this city, and her four-year-old grandson, Nelson S. Allen, of Buffalo, N.Y., were killed this morning by being struck by a trolley car.

-- The National Free Art League having attained the object for which it was founded, a final meeting of the Executive Committee was held March 12, when it was resolved "that the balance of the funds in the treasury be turned over to the Municipal Art Society of New-York," and the committee then adjourned, sine die. A brief report of its work is of interest.
The Rev. Dr. Merritt Hulburd of Wilmington, Del., having had it proved to him that he had told a falsehood in saying that President Cleveland fished on Sunday, made the following amazing reply:

There are times when Niagara River hereabout is a poor fishing ground and old anglers are willing to assert that there isn't a fish in it. It isn't that way now. Up to date this has been an unusually good season for all kinds of fishing. So say men who live by their efforts with hook and line.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 15. -- The State flag that has been designed for Connecticut in response to the agitation started by the Daughters of the Revolution in Stonington is likely to cause no end of trouble.
WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The navy is to have three seagoing torpedo boats with the almost incredible speed of 26 nautical miles per hour.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 15. -- The announcement that Mrs. Maud Craig Burke Davis is under arrest in San Francisco causes a great sensation here, where she is well known.

At a recent social gathering of men who are well known in political life, most of whom had at one time or another represented his party in the New-York State Legislature, reminiscences of life at Albany were indulged in. Many stories were told, and many almost forgotten incidents were recounted.

ALBANY, Jun 15. -- Half an hour before closing his work on the thirty-day bills this afternoon, Gov. Morton made public his decision not to sign the bill to create the Manhattan State Hospital and put the indigent insane of New-York City under the State Care act. This was the bill which Mayor Strong returned without either approval or disapproval.

When referred to by racegoers and horsemen generall, such a race as yesterday's Suburban, in which Lazzarone was successful, is not called highway robbery. It is politely called a "change of form." Form is supposed to be the racing condition of a horse as shown in past races. It is all that the public which supports racing has to judge the racehorses by.

BAYONNE, N.J., June 15. -- A garden fete will be given Thursday evening, June 27, at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Solon Humphreys. Avenue A and Newark Bay shore, to raise funds for the Bayonne Hospital and Dispensary. An attractive entertainment will be provided. Recently the hospital management made a public appeal for funds, owing to decreased revenue and a large increase in work.

A joint rehearsal of the three divisions of the Christian Endeavor chorus took place in the People's Temple Thursday evening, under the direction of George K. Somerby, Chairman of the Music Committee of the appoaching convention. It was an inspiring sight when, at a signal from the leader, the 2,200 singers arose and gave the Chautauqua salute.

Col. Waring seems to be sailing over the calmest of seas nowadays. The storms that made the first part of his official voyage so dangerously exciting have all subsided, and among his crew and passengers hardly a trace of discontent now manifests itself. This is very delightful. It shows, among other things, that what a man does may be considerably more important than what he says.

Greater New-Yorkers who admire cycling as a sport, together with enthusiast from all parts of the East and the Empire State, attended the division race meet at the new track at Manhattan Beach yesterday. Probably there were 10,000 persons present. Many good judges placed the figures even higher.

CHICAGO, Ill., June 15. -- "Little Robinson Crusoe," an operatic burlesque, was given its first presentation to-night at the Schiller Theatre, and seemed to hit the fancy of the large audience present.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 15. -- The senior reception of the Montclair Military Academy was held last night in the gymnasium.

" Shiga San! Shiga San! Have you lost your hand?" And Shiga San, with a soft little Japanese smile, drew from the ample folds of the sleeve of her bright-colored kimono a small brown hand, that had been so entirely out of sight that, to all outward appearance, Miss Shiga was a handless little lady.

The rumor that ex-Mayor James Howell is soon to be succeeded as President of the Bridge Trustees by J. Seaver Page, the Republican appointed by Mayor Strong in place of E.V. Skinner, is causing a good deal of discussion among the bridge force. The outcome of next Tuesday's meeting of the board is awaited by them with great interest.

The Law Enforcement Society, of which George F. Elliott is the President, sent Friday, through its attorney, Eugene V. Brewster, a communication to Police Superintendent McKelvey asking him to see that the law was enforced, and gave a list of places which were designated as disorderly houses and gambling dens.

The common argument of the silver men is that the country needs more money. That is the substance of everything that was said at the Memphis silver convention, and it is the substance of all the most elaborate reasoning of our "scientific" bimetallists. Yet in the money markets of the world there is no sign of scarcity.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Capt. Sigsbee, the naval hydrographer, has developed a remarkable fact relative to steam navigation on the Pacific Ocean, which seems to indicate that the strategical importance of the Hawaiian Islands is not so great as has been claimed by promoters of annexation sentiment.

The latest exploit of the young Afghan whom the English are entertaining is in keeping with his preceding performances. This time he found it more convenient and comfortable to lie abed than to take part in a function that had been arranged at great trouble and expense to signalize his visit to Glasgow.

Manhattan Beach was as crowded yesterday as if the dog days had come. The day was a fine one for a trip to the ocean side, with its clear sky, cooling breezes, and sufficient heat in the air to make the breezes comforting.
The mystery of the murder of the rich old miser, Charles W. Henry, in the basement of his house, 95 South Portland Avenue, Brooklyn, some time Thursday or Friday, was partly unraveled yesterday.

MILFORD, Conn., June 15. -- Theron B. Platt, a farmer of Orange, witnessed a curious struggle a few weeks ago. The Wepawang River, which crosses his land just north of the Derby Railroad Bridge, is quite a small stream at that point, though a quarter of a mile below it becomes deep and swift where its waters are joined by those of the Race Brook.

With the final completion of the Sault Ste. Marie (Ontario) Ship Canal and Lock, which was formally opened last Thursday, the Canadians have a continuous waterway 2,384 miles long, from the head of Lake Superior to the Atlantic Ocean. This lock is the second largest in the world, being inferior only to the big lock now in course of construction across the rapids on the American side.

PAMRAPO, N.J., June 15. -- The Bayswater Yacht Club held a regatta yesterday afternoon over a triangular course of ten miles on NewYork Bay, the start and finish being off the clubhouse, situated at the foot of East Forty-fourth Street. The Harry Miner, owned by Charles Rae of the Audubon Yacht Club, was the winner in Class A, for open catboats between 17 and 20 feet.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 15. -- Part of the Chicago and West Michigan Bridge, in the southern part of this city, gave way this morning, and seven persons were injured, one perhaps fatally.

LONDON, June 15. -- Variable breezes, light airs, and calms made the duel between the Britannia and the Ailsa, under the auspices of the Royal Southern Yacht Club, unsatisfactory and inconclusive. The same thing may be said of the race of the twenty-raters Niagara, Audrey, Inyoni, Luna, and Stephanie. The Britannia won on time allowance, but was led all over the fortyfive-mile course by the Ailsa.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 15. -- The steamer Summer Girl made her first run up the river this evening and gave a good-sized party of boating enthusiasts an opportunity to see the crews at practice. When the steamer started for New-London on the return, there was not a person aboard who did not express the conviction that the Yale 'Varsity eight was as fine a crew as was ever seen on the Thames.

Yachtsmen have seldom had such a brilliant day's sport as that furnished yesterday in the Spring regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club. Forty-one yachts started in the different classes, and of these thirtysix finished. This of itself is something to be proud of, as it is the largest fleet that ever sailed in a Spring regatta.

William the Silent, Prince of Orange, was a distinctive character, cast in a peculiar period of history. He was in thought and desire centuries ahead of the possibilities of his time, and had to contend with ideas among those he served that were as difficult to overcome as were the forces of the Spanish Crown, with which his life was spent in doing battle.

The Reinhard Assembly committee, which is investigating the sweating system, and the employment of girls in the stores and manufactories of New-York, met yesterday in the Aldermanic Chamber, City Hall.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., June 15. -- The last week at Hot Springs has been a particularly lively one. The Casino, a beautiful new building, was formally opened with a ball. Three concerts are given in the Casino daily. At the sacred concert held there last Sunday evening, Miss Florence De Vere Boese of New-York, recently soprano soloist of All Souls' Unitarian Church, sang several appropriate selections.

LONDON, June 5. -- The Royal Harwich Jubilee Regatta, as it has been called, cannot be regarded as a success. Very paltry winds and very paltry arrangements have so far spoiled it, among the latter being the course for the twenty-tonners, an exceptional novelty at Harwich, and intended, as has been freely confessed, to puzzle the American arrival, Niagara.

One thousand persons were present at the Seaside Athletic Club at Coney Island last evening to see the bouts which it was said would be fought between Young Corbett of San Francisco and Eddie Pierce of New-York, and between Dixon and Erne.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Although the trial of Broker E.H. Chapman of New York upon the indictment charging him with refusing to answer questions asked him by the Senate committee investigating the alleged Sugar Trust scandal in connection with the passage of the Tariff bill is fixed to begin in the Criminal Court of the District on Monday next, it is probable that it will not then take place.

Negotiations have been pending for several months with the object of healing the breach that has existed so long between the New-York and Brooklyn Association of Congregational Churches and the Manhattan Conference. This latter body grew out of the Beecher troubles, when a number of churches withdrew from the parent organization and formed the Manhattan Conference.

An event of more than passing interest to Jersey cyclists has been arranged by the Hudson County Wheelmen for Thursday evening of this week. It will be the presentation to the successful riders of the medals won in the second annual tri-State relay race promoted by The New-York Times. The affair will take place in the spacious assembly room of the Hudson County's Club house, at 111 Belmont Avenue, Jersey City.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 16. -- The preparations for the meeting of the Society of the Army of the Potomac are apparent everywhere in this city, for the principal business houses are handsomely decorated, and thet city is taking on a gala apeparance. The old Court House facing State Street is resplendent with flags and bunting.

The New-York, Brooklyn, and Connecticut delegates to the National Convention of the League of Republican Clubs, which is to open Wednesday at Cleveland, Ohio, will leave the Grand Central Station on a special train at 7 o'clock to-morrow morning. Secretary John W. Totten was kept busy yesterday in the league headquarters, in the Fifth Avenue Hotel, perfecting the arrangements for the trip.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 16. -- W.H. Kerr, a wealthy resident of Catonsville, near Baltimore, and President of the Thistle Cotton Mills Company of Ilchester, Howard County, Md., was drowned to-day. With his family and a party of friends he came to Annapolis on board his steam yacht Watanga.

The police of Brooklyn on Saturday night did what they ought to have been ordered to do long since. They arrested the principals in a "bout" at Coney Island which ended with a "knock-out," and the Inspector announced that two other bruisers who had been advertised would be arrested as soon as they began to fight.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 16. -- To-day is about the first Sunday for the opening of the Summer season at this place that has been noticeable of any account. The perfect weather which has displayed itself for nearly a week, and to-morrow's New-York holiday, have had a tendency to invite people to take a trip to the seashore for a couple of days, at least.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 16. -- All examinations in the several colleges ended for the year on Thursday. The old system of final examination was reverted to at the beginning of the Spring term, for as many professors as chose to give only one examination a term.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 16. -- The Rev. John L. Scudder, pastor of the Congregational Tabernacle, preached a sermon on "The Bicycle as a Revolutionist" this morning, to the Hudson County Wheelmen. The club attended in a body, riding to the church on their wheels.

DOUGLASTON, L.I., June 16. -- Zion's Episcopal Church celebrated the sixty-fifth anniversary of its organization to-day. The services were conducted by the rector, the Rev. C.N.F. Jeffery, assisted by the pastor of St. Augustine's Chapel, an adjunct of Trinity Church, in New-York City.

Capt. William Leavitt of this city, who used to sail some of the best ships on the ocean, has compiled from the records a list of the full-rigged ships now flying the American flag. It is a sad showing compared with those glorious days when the ships were numbered by the thousands, and Bath alone built fifty or more in one year.

Everything seems to indicate that the coming theatrical season in this country will be one of the most prosperous on record. For the last two years the seasons have been very disastrous. A few of the more prominent attractions have weathered the storms and made money, but for one case of this kind the record contained a hundred disasters.

J.H. Wade's high-speed cruising steam yacht Wadena, which one year ago left this port for an extensive tour of distant waters, returned to harbor yesterday, having been absent just one year to the hour.

Sound discipline in the police force, as in an army, depends upon the complementary forces of ambition and fear -- on the dread of the consequences of lax conduct and the hope of recognition and reward for good conduct. The administration of the present Police Commission plainly tends toward sound discipline in both these directions.

TAMPA, Fla., June 16. -- Passengers by the steamship Mascotte, this afternoon, say that Gen. Maceo, on Wednesday, charged a Government train between Holquin and Givaia and secured a large booty. He got 80,000 of Spanish money, 1,000 Mauser rifles, and a large quantity of ammunition. Besides this, he captured a large quantity of Government supplies.

The programme mapped out for the entertainment of the visiting cyclists ended yesterday with half a dozen runs to points of popular interest. Perfect weather again favored the wheelmen, and the out-of-town folks particularly enjoyed themselves. Everybody spoke in high terms of praise of the State race meet, the big parade, the long path, and the hospitality of the local wheelmen.

To the query how unlimited silver coinage would affect the working men and women who make up the great body of depositors in the savings banks, President James MacMahon of the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank of this city has made a plain answer. The loans made by the savings banks for their depositors would be repaid in "silver dollars actually worth 50 cents."

With one successful meeting just ended at Fleetwood Park and another which promises equally well at the Parkway track in Brooklyn, this week, the local trotting turfites are in high feather. The determined effort of the Driving Club or New-York to keep light harness sport alive in the metropolis is an encouragement to similar organizations in the State.

LONDON, June 16. -- Devotional services in connection with the World's Women's Christian Temperance Convention commenced in the City Temple by the Rev. Joseph Parker, Holborn Viaduct, this afternoon at 3 o'clock. Lady Henry Somerset, President of the British Women's Temperance Association, presided.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 16. -- The Cornell 'Varsity crew took its first spin on the Hudson River at 11 o'clock this morning, followed by Coach Fred V. White in the yacht Wallawalla. Usually, the Cornell men do not row on Sunday, but, as they had not had any practice since Friday morning, and Moore and Tatum had not been out with the 'Varsity eight in a week, Capt. Troy felt that they must row to-day.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., June 16. -- In his sermon to-day the Rev. T. De Witt Talmage, who is now on his Western tour, chose for his subject a theme of widespread interest at the present time, namely, "Woman's Opportunity." The text selected was, "She shall be called woman," Genesis, ii., 23.

Ralph Swinburn, whose funeral services were held at Charleston, West Va., on Monday evening, was not only the oldest locomotive engineer in the world, but he was the first to sit in a cab and handle the throttle. Mr. Swinburn was a little past his ninety-first year when he died last Friday at his Davis Creek home, just a short distance from Charleston, having been born at Newcastle-on-the-Tyne in January, 1805.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., June 16. -- The subjoined letter, written in Greek cipher, has been received by a gentleman in Jacksonville from Major Hann, formerly of Pennsylvania, who has been in the Cuban service for three months:
