An important meeting of the City Council of the Irish National Federation of America was held yesterday at Cooper Union. The object of the meeting was to formulate an organized plan by which funds can be raised for the Irish Parliamentary Party, which is under the leadership of Justin McCarthy.
The old Police Justice system was rung out and the new system of City Magistrates was rung in when yesterday passed into today.

RICHMOND, Va., June 30. -- While the last hymn of the service, "Awake, My Soul, Stretch Every Nerve," was being sung at the Second Presbyterian Church this morning a report that sounded like a pistol shot was heard, as if coming from the rear of the building.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 30. -- Attorney General Hancock, in a statement late tonight, said he has seen nothing which, in his opinion, would operate as a stay of the execution of Buchanan. "I have not advised his execution," he said; "that is not part of my duty, and I do not propose to do so, as it seems to me the present proceedings are a repetition of those ended several weeks ago."

ALBANY, N.Y., June 30. -- The following schools have been designated by State Superintendent of Public Instruction Charles R. Skinner to conduct teachers' training classes for the ensuing school year. The remainder of the appointments will be announced after the return of the State Superintendent from Denver:

A cricket eleven made up from Harvard, Haverford, and the University of Pennsylvania will today meet a representative eleven from Canada at Philadelphia. There will be a large and interested crowd of spectators at the grounds to witness this first international inter-university match, which will become an annual fixture. Only the three universities named have teams strong enough to join the Intercollegiate Cricket Association, which, at present, they constitute.
Annie Mars, twenty-five years old, a tailoress, who lived with her parents at 622 East Thirteenth Street, disappeared from her home yesterday morning and cannot be found.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- It is now three days since the report of the capture of the insurgent General, Maceo, was first made public, and no one in Washington, not even the Spanish Minister, is able to confirm the story. It is looked upon in diplomatic quarters as erroneous. Minister de Lome himself said that had there been any truth in the report he would have been advised of it before this.
Regarding the general subject of "The Water Supply," as brought up in your leading editorial of to-day's issue, permit me to make the following observations:

CLEAR LAKE, Iowa, June 30. -- The Rev. T. De Witt Talmage, D.D., of Brooklyn, N.Y., preached here to-day, in the presence of an enormous congregation. Excursion trains had been advertised to run from all sections of the State, to enable people to hear the eloquent Brooklynite. This led to much criticism, Dr. Talmage being roundly denounced by strict Sabbatarians for permitting excursion trains to be run, he being the attraction.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Robert Strong, familiarly known as "Colonel Bob" Strong, who executed Guiteau, the assassin of President Garfield, died in this city yesterday, of infirmities incident to old age, being close upon his eightieth year. He had been on officer of the District jail for nearly thirty years, and during that ported executed eighteen criminals, the last one only a year ago.

CHATHAM, N.Y., June 30. -- The three-year-old daughter of Mrs. George Taafe, a widow, was abducted from her bed soon after midnight last night by an unknown person who had gained entrance to the bedroom, which was on the second floor, by means of a ladder which had been placed outside a window.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., June 30. -- New-York's dry Sunday made no appreciable difference in the patronage of the resorts in and near this city whose proprietors are permitted to violate the law that the residents of other places may enjoy themselves on the Sabbath.

Miss Emma Fischer, who was found in an unconscious condition in the cellar of the house in which she lived, 102 East One Hundred and Twenty-first Street, Saturday morning, died yesterday morning in the Harlem Hospital, where she had been removed.

Senator David B. Hill and ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt met, shook hands, discussed political topics in an off-hand, good-natured tone, and extended to each other the compliments of the season yesterday.

TAMPA, Fla., June 30. -- The Mascotte brought a heavy passenger list from Key West this afternoon, among whom were a number of cigarmakers for new factories in this State. The list from Havana was light, but among them was a gentleman who is well informed on Cuban affairs. He states that Maximo Gomez surprised a garrison of 1,500 Spanish at Alta Garcia, and had a severe battle with them.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 30. -- Judge Ross in his decision yesterday on the demurrer in the fifteen-million-dollar suit of the Government against the Stanford estate to recover the share due from Stanford as a shareholder of the Southern Pacific, reviewed the National legislation by which the construction of the Union Pacific and Central Pacific Railways was authorized and provisions made for the issuance of bonds and for their redemption.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, June 30. -- A representative of The United Press visited this place to-day for the purpose of seeing the crews that are to take part in the coming rowing regatta. He found the river rather lower than usual, owing to the light rainfall of late, but the reaches from Kingston upward were as green and as beautiful as ever.

Some of the political correspondence from Kentucky suggests the possibility that Senator Blackburn, smarting from the defeat of his attempt to commit Kentucky Democrats to an unsound-money policy and the Senatorial aspirations of an unsound Democrat, may now exert what he may choose to call his influence to assure the election of the Republican candidate.

SHELTER ISLAND, L.I., June 29. -- The inclement weather of the latter part of the week had some effect upon the arrival of Summer visitors at Shelter Island, but early this morning the rush commenced. The boats brought an unusually large number, while the first trains were crowded with people.
KIEL, June 30. -- The United States warships New-York, Columbia, and Marblehead sailed from this port to-day. The San Francisco will remain here.
John Storck is a fisherman. He is a great fisherman. This fact is established by his catch yesterday. He pulled in a sixty-three-pound muskallonge.

ASBURY PARK., N.J., June 30. -- The Summer religious services were begun to-day at the Asbury Park Auditorium, and the several meetings were largely attended. The sermon in the morning was preached by the Rev. S. Edward Young of Newark, formerly of this place. His subject was "The Moral and Religious Mission of Asbury Park."

A correspondent suggests that the really serious element in the problem of the supply and distribution of water in this city is that of waste. He thinks that if the full pressure were allowed the consumption would rise to 200 gallons per head per day, and "the reservoir would be pulled dry in a week."

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., June 30. -- At the meeting in the Auditorium at Prohibition Park this afternoon a request was made for an explanation of the reason for the arrest of two of the officers of the Brooklyn Law Enforcement League, and the attacks which are being made upon the organization by the press of that city.

The Very Rev. P.J. McNamara, Vicar General, is celebrating his twenty-fifth year as a priest, and in honor of the silver jubilee there was a solmn high mass in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, Pacific Street, near Vanderbilt Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday morning.

Since 1885 Yale and Harvard have rowed nine races on the Thames course and Yale has been the winner eight times. Harvard has had, we think, as much and as good raw material out of which racing crews could be made as Yale has had; indeed, the supply of material, as indicated by the number of students, has been larger at Cambridge than at New-Haven.
Mr. and Mrs. Dave Hennon Morris will soon sail for Europe. Since their romantic marriage they have been living quietly in Boston.

TACOMA, Washington, June 30. -- Indications point to an old-fashioned Orangemen's fight on the Fourth of July. The celebration Committee has been arranging for the biggest celebration in the Northwest, including a procession two miles long. Hibernian and other Irish societies are taking a deep interest, having contributed money and written communications saying they would display no flags save the Stars and Stripes.

There was a series of curious stabbing and assault cases on the east side yesterday morning, the assailant in each being unknown to his victim. In every case the police arrived too late to make any arrest, and they are now searching for the authors of the outrages, aided only by the meagre descriptions furnished by the men assaulted.

" Has the Republican fictional fight in this State, with ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt on one side and the Union League on the other, been extended outside the State lines? Is there, in other words, a National movement against the ex-Senator?"

Carroll D. Wright, United States Commissioner of Labor, is in this city attending a meeting of the Executive Committee of the National Statisticians' Association, which is to arrange for a convention in Minneapolis early in September. Concerning this association, Mr. Wright spoke enthusiastically. "It is not generally realized," said he, "that there are as many as thirty-two States in the Union that have created since 1869 offices similar to mine.

Nobody can fail to admire the pluck and liberality with which British yachtsmen continue to challenge for the America's Cup, after an unbroken series of defeats and disappointments. It would have been a matter of regret to American yachtsmen, and even to those who are now busy with preparations to defend the cup, if Valkyrie III. had not shown any marked improvement over her unsuccessful predecessor.

Considered collectively, there has been no team of road races brought out this year that approaches the team that so successfully represented New-Jersey in the tri-State relay race promoted by The New-York Times. Each of the six proved himself a game and a fast rider, and by his great showing added an interesting page to his personal racing history.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 30. -- Bishop Potter of New-York officiated at Trinity Church to-day, in the absence of the rector. The church was filled. Cottagers of Jamestown and Narragansett Pier were well represented in the congregation.

STAPLETON, S.I., June 30. -- The Staten Island police renewed the raids upon the hotel keepers at South Beach to-day, and arrested thirteen proprietors and bartenders. All were arraigned before Justices, and held for trial during the coming week. Notwithstanding the vigilance of the police, the crowd which visited the beach did not go dry, and found many ways of amusing themselves.

All of us, excepting the Controller, are gratefully aware of the service which Col. Waring has done the city in cleaning the streets. There is, however, a suspicion abroad that he does not trouble himself enough about economy and that he is disposed to clean the streets regardless of expense.

Over in England it seems to be the fashion just at present to use the word "predecease" as a transitive verb. For instance, one Londoner, in writing about the late Sir Charles Murray, dares to say: "Sir Charles's younger brother, Admiral Henry Murray, predeceased him by thirty years."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 30. -- The Rev. William H. Tole caused a surprise this morning when he announced to his congregation that he had resigned his charge at St. John's Church, Roman Catholic, and that his resignation had been accepted. Many of his parishoners do not believe that the resignation was voluntary, and do believe that it was called for.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 30. -- Two firemen were killed and several were injured this morning by the collapse of a floor in the building occupied by the Hubley Manufacturing Supply Company. The dead are:

CONCORD, N.H., June 30. -- Senator Chandler hopes to be the Republican candidate for Vice President next year. He thinks his party could not do better than to make its ticket Harrison and Chandler. There was a time while the tariff debate was in progress in the Senate that his aspirations soared still higher.

Another chapter is added to the complicated story of the infamous firebug gang of this city in a statement made public yesterday by Deputy Sheriff Joseph M. Fox of 79 Clinton Street, who charges ex-Detective Sergeant George V. Zundt, formerly of the Brooklyn Central Office, who was detailed for duty at Fire Headquarters, with direct complicity with the gang in its operations in that city.

Under date June 11, a well-informed New-York correspondent writes: "There has been a gradual and steady appreciation in the value of copper from 9 1/2, cents per pound two months ago to 10 3/4 cents to-day. The upward movement has also been accompanied with a large business to consumers and exporters.

The only saloon open last night on Avenue A is at 241. It is kept by John Kelly. In attempting to arrest Kelly Policeman Kidney of the East Twenty-second Street Station was roughly handled by a mob of twenty-two men, and would have been seriously injured but for his brother policeman, Frank Dunne.

The crusade against free-silver coinage is making splendid progress in the South, according to reports received at the sound-money headquarters of the Chamber of Commerce. One of the most prominent Southerners has just addressed a strong circular letter to his confreres below Mason and Dixon's line, the substance of which will figure in more than one Fourth of July oration.

M. Wirz and M. Monnier, members of the Geneva Conseil d'Etat, have been denouncing a very serious abuse which is creeping into the rites or functions of baptism. M. Wirz has a greivance against the owners of horses and races in his own and other lands, and M. Monnier writes to denounce Anarchists and Socialists who will persist in civilly christening their children Beelzebub, Lucifer, and Satan.
WILLIMANTIC, Conn., June 30. -- Two attempts have been made this week to burn the large mills of the Willimantic Linen Company.

It is reported from Concord, N.H., that Senator Chandler has made up his mind to try to secure the nomination for Vice President on the Republican ticket, and that Mr. Harrison is the leading man to whom he aspires to be understudy. There are some things more unlikely than his success.

The first target contests of the first National Schuetzen Fest were had at Glendale Schuetzen Park, Long Island, yesterday, with results that were extremely gratifying to all concerned. The threatening clouds that darkened the horizon all day long did not deter the thousands from attending who were desirous of witnessing the opening ceremonies of the shooting tournament, which will continue until July 8.

BRISTOL, R.I., June 30. -- It is the irony of fate for the Herreshoffs that after guarding the Defender with the most scrupulous care while building, fortune should play them false in the launching and leave the boat with her entire hull out of water for every one to see who cares to take the trouble of a boating excursion in the harbor and a row around her.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 30. -- The seventh annual regatta of the Yonkers Corinthian Yacht Club was held yesterday over a triangular course from off the clubhouse to Alpine, to Egg Beach, and to the clubhouse. It was a long race, and after struggling through a calm for seven hours the Edna, owned by Dickson, Quick, and Kellock, won in 6 hours 58 minutes.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 30. -- A thunder and rain storm of unusual violence swept through the highlands to-day. The weather had been threatening from yesterday noon, and during the night heavy rains fell.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- It is reported here that the startling statement was made yesterday by a prominent local Democratic politician that Gov. Altgeld is in possession of evidence which, if properly presented in court, will convict at least five members of the Thirty-ninth General Assembly of bribery, and land them in the penitentiary.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 30. -- The weather seems to be against the Forty-seventh Regiment for some reason. Besides yesterday's storm they were treated to an even worse one this morning. It was a very severe storm, but it spent its force before the morning was over.
NEWARK, N.J., July 1. -- One horse was killed, another horse and a man severely shocked, and considerable excitement caused by a derelict electric wire at an early hour this morning.

The seven-story printing house and storage building of the wholesale drug firm of McKesson Robbins, at 79 Ann Street, immediately behind the headquarters of the firm, was completely wrecked by fire at 8 o'clock last night.

ALBANY, July 1. -- The Land Office Commissioners to-day declined to authorize a grant of land under water at Southold which has been pending before the Commissioners. The application was made by James Wickham and others six months ago, and the territory applied for consists of sixty-one and a fraction acres.

In answer to the City of Brooklyn's suit against ex-Excise Commissioners John Schliemann and John W. Cahill to recover $19,400, the amount taken by William D. Lohman while cashier of the Department of Excise, Mr. Schliemann yesterday filed a statement in which he contends that as Lohman was a public officer appointed by the Police Commissioner, as the sole appointive power in the Board of Excise, that he was not responsible for his wrongdoing.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Secretary Herbert has assigned the six-year naval cadet graduates to the corps in which they will hereafter serve, filling the twenty-one existing vacancies in the line, eight in the Engineer, and one each in the Constructors', and the Marine Officers' Corps. The new ensigns are:

A cabbage-leaf in your hat is a time-honored precaution against sunstroke. A little seasonable knowledge in the brain that the hat protects will serve the same good purpose. Never is excess of labor, eating, fretting, or drinking more severely punished than in hot weather. Never are good sense and self restraint more promptly rewarded.

A great collection of paintings will pass to the Metropolitan Museum of Art under the will of James Renwick, the celebrated architect, if the Trustees of the Museum agree to place the pictures in a separate room or alcove.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1. -- The first innings of the cricket match between the Universities of the United States and Canada was completed here to-day, and the Americans obtained a bare lead of 1 run. The game was most stubbornly contested, and the manner in which young P.H. Clark, Harvard's Captain, deprived the Canadians of the lead after they had got within one of it, with still three wickets to fall, evoked great cheers.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., July 1. -- The beautiful bronze statue of Major Gen. John Buford was dedicated this morning with most impressive exercises and before a distinguished audience of military men. Major Gen. Wesley Merritt, United States Army, commanding the Department of the Missouri, occupied the chair, and every detail of the exercises went off with promptness.

At the meeting of the Board of Education yesterday Commissioner Robert Maclay, by a unanimous vote of the seventeen members present, was elected President of the board in place of Charles H. Knox, who resigned that position last week.

HAVANA, July 1. -- Col. Aldavo reports from Ciego de Avila that a Government force, under command of Major Chabran, has routed the insurgent bands under Castillo and Zayas, killing three men and capturing number of saddle horses and a quantity of arms.

The City Solicitor's office presented an unusually busy scene at noon yesterday, when City Solicitor Kinsey and Director of Public Safety Beitler received one by one policemen from different districts throughout the city and obtained from them affidavits of instances which have come under the policemen's observation where the ordinance requiring cars to be provided with fenders had been violated.

Amos Rusie could not help the New-Yorks win yesterday. He was put in to pitch out of his turn, and was not in good form, giving seven bases on balls, and was hit when men were on bases. The Brooklyns were able to win by a score of 7 to 1.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1. -- For the fifth consecutive time since the present receivership, the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad to-day defaulted upon the interest due on the general mortgage bonds, but paid all prior liens, the only other default being upon the principal of $19,000 Schuylkill Navigation bonds.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 1. -- The decorators practically have concluded their work at Cornelius Vanderbilt's villa and only a few gilders have been left behind to put on the finishing touches. All the apartments, except the salon, have their furniture in place. The house will be ready for occupancy by the close of the week, and it is understood that the family will, be here as early as Saturday.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 1. -- In the trial of "Bob" Fitzsimmons for the killing of "Con" Riordan during a sparring contest, the day was taken up in listening to expert medical testimony. Dr. D.M. Tolman was required to state what he considered the cause of Riordan's death. He said it was concentrated violence on the man's jaw.

Just before the civil service regulation compelling the registration of laborers by the Civil Service Commission went into effect May 1, the Dock Department, with the evident intention of making places for men recommended by Republican politicians, dismissed a large number of the laborers who had been employed under the Tammany administration and appointed in their places a number of men belonging to Republican organizations.

Commander George E. Ide, of the United States Navy, who was recently detached from the command of the Alert by a cable order from the Secretary of the Navy, was a passenger by the Colombia Line steamship, Finance, which arrived here yesterday from Colon.

PARIS, July 1. -- One of the largest fires that has occurred in this city in some time broke out at noon to-day in the military equipment works in the Rue Rochechouart, in the northern part of the city.

The five police courts of the city were opened yesterday morning promptly at 9 o'clock by the new City Magistrates respectively assigned to them. The superseded Police Justices and their clerks presented formal protests against the occupancy of their seats and the discharge of their duties by the new men.
Mayor Strong, shorn of all his power of removal, sat in his office in the City Hall yesterday talking with visitors on various topics, apparently happy and content.
NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 1. -- Arrived -- Schooner Alsacienne, Caius C. Bragg.

UTICA, July 1. -- Senator Coggeshall is by no means disposed to permit himself to be "turned down" without a struggle, and though the Platt machine is very strong throughout Oneida County it is not at all certain that Coggeshall's nomination can be defeated at the Republican Senatorial Convention.

The last feature of the inauguration of the first National Schuetzen Fest took place yesterday under the most favorable auspices. The rain early in the morning and the dark sky of the forenoon did not keep any of the sharpshooters and societies who had promised from taking part in the parade in this city.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1. -- An estimate is made that in the contest for the control of the Republican State Convention, which will be held Aug. 28, Gov. Hastings and his friends will have 145 delegates and Senator Quay and his followers 117 delegates. Sixteen delegates are classed as doubtful.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 1. -- The Jersey City Street and Water Board this morning received three bids for a new water supply. The bidders were the East Jersey Water Company, the Jersey City Water Company, and the Hudson and Rockaway Water Company.

There is a lack of harmony among the members of the Loyal Club, the Republican club of the Twenty-eighth Assembly District. The regular monthly meeting of the club was held last night. It was a stormy one.

RICHMOND, S. I., July 1. -- The third session of the National Reform conference, at Prohibition Park, to-day, was attended by a small audience. Ernest Crosby of New-York presided. Erastus Wiman spoke on the subject of free trade.

The two great American telegraphic news gatherers, The United Press and The Associated Press, conducted warfare against each other similar to that of two newspapers. In Los Angeles it happens that all the daily papers are patrons of The Associated Press, and accordingly as organs for that company in its fight against a lively competitor very little could heretofore be learned from our local papers, except of a detrimental nature, about The United Press.

BRISTOL, R.I., July 1. -- The launch of the Defender was completed this afternoon, when the boat yielded very unexpectedly to a pull by the tug Right Arm, and came off the ways, where she had been firmly fixed. She is now safely afloat by the side of the Herreshoffs' north pier, and is apparently uninjured, so that, beyond the delay of a day in fitting her out, no harm has been done.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 1. -- The forty-first annual meeting of the New-Jersey State Teachers' Association began here to-day. There were over one hundred educators present at the first session. An address was made by the President, H. Brewster Willis of New-Brunswick. Next followed an address on "What and How to Read," by A.W. Edson, State Agent of the Massachusetts Board of Education.

Alfred R. Page, counsel to the Excise Board, yesterday got what is known in "pugilistic" circles as an "undercut" at the hands of the General Term of the Superior Court, and Judge McAdam of that tribunal is exceedingly, though dignifiedly, rejoiced.

Outside one of the big Paris stores there were lately grouped a lady, a nursemaid with a baby in her arms, and an Inspector of Police in the execution of his duty. The lady had just been given into custody on a charge of unlawful sampling off the counters. She was protesting her innocence in the most eloquent and moving terms.

" Nine-tenths of the valves in the city water mains were partly or wholly shut down by my orders," said George W. Birdsall, chief engineer of the Department of Public Works, yesterday, to a reporter for The New-York Times.
Luther F. McKinney of New-Hampshire, United States Minister to Colombia, was a passenger on the Colombian Line steamship Finance, which arrived at this port yesterday.

PITTSBURG, July 1. -- The trial of the Rev. C.B. Lincoln was begun in the First Cumberland Presbyterian Church this morning. The charges against him are: First, false and slanderous accusations against brethren; second, stirring up strife and dissensions; third, official unfitness and misconduct; fourth, insubordination and contempt of Presbytery.

The execution yesterday of Buchanan puts an end to a case which had lasted long enough to bring the administration of justice into grave reproach. Buchanan committed a willful and cold-blooded murder in April, 1892, and his punishment did not overtake him for more than three years.

JEFFERSONVILLE, Ind., July 1. -- A horrifying sight met the eyes of Mrs. John Ganote at 10 o'clock this morning, when she visited the Bennett family at 278 Maple Street. In a room on the ground floor she found the lifeless forms of Ella Bennett, aged ten, and Omer, aged five, with their mother, the latter gasping for breath and unconscious.
BUFFALO, July 1. -- Clarence and Sadie Robinson, convicted of killing Montgomery Gibbs, will, through their counsel, Judge L. Q. Hardesty, apply for a new trial on newly-discovered evidence.

In a little room on the corner of Bleecker and West Third Streets, to the right of the elevated trains as they turn the corner on the way up town, the daily travelers who are not entirely engrossed in their papers or their own private affairs may see a group of children sitting at their desks and busy with their books.
If last Sunday was "dry" in this city, it is probable that next Sunday will be even more so.

A member of the Boston Police Department, who prefers to have his name suppressed, came through from New-York the other morning on the steamer Puritan. During the voyage it leaked out that the Boston cop had been bunkoed out of his gold watch and $20 by two smart New-York chaps.

BOSTON, July 1. -- Regarding the published reports that Director Pierson of the Concord and Montreal Railroad Company would institute legal proceedings to annul the lease of the Concord and Montreal Railroad to the Boston and Maine Railroad that gentleman says: "There is a probability that the lease will be opposed through the courts.

There was a gathering of old friends and the introduction of several new faces at the first trip for the twentieth season of that marvel of modern philanthropic enterprises, the Floating Hospital of St. John's Guild, yesterday. Monday is a west-side day, and the first passengers were taken on at the foot of Fifty-second Street.

The latest of the admirable series of publications issued by Messrs. G.P. Putnam's Sons, under the title of "Questions of the Day," is "Real Bimetallism," by Everett P. Wheeler, Esq., of this city. It is worthy of note because its author is neither a professional student of economics nor, in the ordinary sense, a politician.
WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The debt statement, issued this afternoon, shows a net decrease in the public debt, less cash in the Treasury, during June, of $10,730,324.97.
The closing exercises of the male department of Grammar School No. 20, at 160 Chrystie Street, were held yesterday morning.

The Board of Aldermen met yesterday for the special purpose of receiving the tax assessment rolls for 1895. As soon as they were presented they were, as usual, referred to the Committee on Finance for a report which will fix the tax rate for the year. This report will be made either late in August or early in September.

NEWARK, N.J., July 1. -- A trial trip on one track was made to-day over the Newark and Elizabeth trolley line, and it is hoped that everything will be in readiness for patrons on the Fourth of July. On Thursday, if everything works, it is expected there will be an excursion directly from Elizabeth to Eagle Rock.

ASBURY PARK, July 1. -- With the approach of the opening day of the big national race tournament this Summer city is becoming unusually active. People interested in the meet have already begun to arrive from distant points, and by the end of the present week cyclists and cycling will be the general topics for discussion.

FRANKFORT, Ky., July 1. -- Gov. John Young Brown to-night gave out a card withdrawing from the Senatorial race. Recent family bereavements in the death of his daughter and the untimely loss of his son are the prime causes for his action. He is for free silver and it was his purpose to make an active canvass of the State to begin the day before the murder of his son.

ALBANY, July 1. -- Ex-Senator Jacob Worth of Brooklyn was a caller at the Executive Chamber to-day. His visit was for the purpose of securing the appointment by the Governor of persons who are in sympathy with the regular Republican organization in Kings County upon the Beard of Managers of the new Long Island State Hospital.

A mortgage for $1,000,000 was recorded yesterday on the property at the northeast corner of Broadway and Prince Street, formerly part of the Metropolitan Hotel, and now owned by Henry O. Havemeyer. The Bowery Savings Bank loaned the money for three years.
NORRISTOWN, Penn., July 1. -- Nearly 2,000 persons went to work at this place to-day at increased wages.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The flagship San Francisco alone remains at Kiel, the cruisers New-York and Columbia having left that port yesterday on their way home, and the Marblehead, which sailed last Friday, having reached Cronstadt, Russia, this morning.

Col. John Grandison, a Scotchman, seventy-eight years old, who lives on Salt Creek, near Vanceburg, Ky., lately told some interesting stories about Gen. Grant. Col. Grandison was a partner of Simpson Grant, the General's brother, in the tanning business.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Among diplomats who are in a position to be informed regarding the movements of Russia in the Orient, the published statements that that Government has mobilized an army of 80,000 men at Vladivostock and massed her ships in the harbor at that port for the purpose of striking a blow at Japan, receive but little credence.

SING SING, July 1. -- Dr. Buchanan, the condemned wife-poisoner, was put to death by electricity at the State prison here this morning. The current was applied twice before the attending physicians pronounced the condemned man dead. The first application of the current was continued for fifty-seven seconds. The full current of 1,760 volts was again sent through his body and he was then examined by Drs. Irvine and Gibbs.

Official burglary, defiance, surrender, excitement, and many new formalities made the installation of the Justices of the Court of Special Sessions and the equipment of the court with its personnel memorable events yesterday.

The funeral of the late Police Inspector Edward Reilly took place from St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church, Summit and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn, yesterday morning. The church was crowded with former associates and prominent politicians.

When Postmaster Dayton went to his office yesterday he found that his private room resembled a bower of roses more than it did the room in which for two years he has transacted the business of his department. Cards on some of the floral pieces bore the inscription wishing Mr. Dayton "that all his ventures may be as successful as his career for two years as Postmaster." This told the story.

MANASQUAN, N.J., July 1. -- Everybody here is a friend of Champion Arthur A. Zimmerman, and when the proposed match with Johnny Johnson is mentioned it naturally arouses a storm of indignation. The star pedal pusher does not care to race Johnson, or any other man, but he was driven into negotiating for a series of races with Eck's crack, and did his part to bring take matter to a head.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 1. -- The Elizabeth Democrats are jubilant over the break in the Republican majority in the new City Council, which resulted to-night in the re-election of James J. Manning, a Democrat, as City Clerk for three years, over E.L.P. Coleman, the Republican caucus nominee. The rest of the Republican slate went through, but it took half a dozen ballots to elect the City Attorney. Edward S. Atwater, Republican, finally won.

BOSTON, July 1. -- The new heads of departments assumed their duties this morning in the different City Hall departments under the new city charter. The result has been a wholesale reduction in the forces and salaries.

Fewer people were at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday than on any day of the meeting. This was in part due to the fact that the regulars among the racegoers knew that there would be a heavy track, and thought that in consequence the very promising card provided would probably be badly marred by scratches.

LONDON, July 1. -- The sitting of the House of Commons to-day was marked by a very small attendance. As is customary upon the occasion of a change in the Ministry the leading members of the Opposition and their followers changed their seats, taking the side of the House formerly occupied by the leaders and members of the majority.

Your esteemed favor of June 28, offering to provide two gold medals, as prizes for a New-York Times Winners' Race, Class A, Saturday, July 13, was laid before the Race Committee last night, and I am pleased to advise you that it was accepted, and the members of the committee were very much pleased with the suggestion and method outlined for the race.
LEWISTON, Me., July 1. -- The wages of the 500 operatives in the Lewiston bleachery and dye works have been increased 10 per cent. without any request from the workmen.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The Navy Department to-day invited proposals for the construction of three steel twin-screw sea-going torpedo boats for the navy. The boats are to be of about 180 tons displacement. The material used in their construction is to be of domestic manufacture. The vessels may be constructed of steel or other metal, or of alloy.

WEST NEWTON, Mass, July . -- The great Pim scored his final victory of the week by defeating Mahony, the Irish crack, in a close five-set match at the Neighborhood Club's courts this afternoon. The English champion won by a score of 6 -- 4, 6 -- 8, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4. The match developed scientific tennis on both sides, but lacked the brilliant features which usually characterize the play of American experts.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., July 1. -- The wheelmen of this town, all of whom are members of the Bloomfield Cycling and Athletic Association, are practically to have entire charge of the celebration of the Fourth of July, and that they are patriotic Americans as well as enthusiastic roadsters is shown by the programme which they have arranged.
The stock brokerage firm of Cyrus C. Staples Co., 213 Montague Street, Brooklyn, will this morning make an assignment to Col. Albert E. Lamb.

DETROIT, Mich., July 1. -- It was learned to-day that delegates from the Grand Council Canadian Protective Association and the Supreme Council American Protective Association held a secret convention here last week, the sessions lasting until Saturday night. The meeting was for the purpose of organizing the International Protective Association.

A writer in one of our papers complains that some of the teachers of Boston do not comply with the rules of grammar in speaking to their pupils. I suppose this is the case only in exceptional instances, but a remarkable example of it has come under my observation which leads me to believe that the use of bad grammar is something which may affect intelligent and well-educated men.

The future of ex-Police Justice Patrick Divver in the politics of the Second Assembly District will be interesting. He is out of Tammany Hall. He will not join the reform element nor the Republicans. But he will use what power he has in the district, not in the interest of Tammany Hall, as was his wont, but in the interest of the friends and against the enemies of Patrick Divver.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2. -- The International Intercollegiate cricket match between the colleges of the United States and Canada was brought to a conclusion here to-day, and the representatives of Uncle Sam scored a victory by 50 runs. The game was full of interest from the start, and the evenness of the first innings indicated how closely the teams were matched.

PATERSON, N.J., July 2. -- The Tourist Cycle Club has broken the season's record for entries, having received 240 individual nominations for its two days' race tournament, which begins to-morrow. The number is remarkable when the many counter attractions and other cycle meets are taken into consideration, and can only be accounted for through the desire of the fast pedal pushers to secure a share of the diamond prizes.
A meeting of the Board of Managers of the United Societies for Liberal Sunday Laws was held at Terrace Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- The Treasury circulation statement issued to-day shows a decrease in the circulation of all kinds of money in the United States, in the fiscal year just ended, of $60,000,000. The population increased during the same period 1,481,000. These changes are noted:

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- The plans for the new battleships authorized by the last Congress, and which have been opposed by members of the naval board of bureau chiefs, were submitted to the Secretary of the Navy to-day by Commodore Hichborne, Chief of the Bureau of Construction, together with a voluminous letter from him showing his reasons for not agreeing with his colleagues.

Mr. George R. Read has leased, for Dr. C.F. Hoffman, to A.J. Drexel Biddle, for two years, at about $6,000 per year, the four-story brownstone dwelling 589 Fifth Avenue, east side, adjoining Robert Goelet's, at the corner of Forty-eighth Street.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 2. -- Mrs. Calvin S. Brice gave an elaborate dinner party to-night in honor of the English Legation. It was an affair that hardly will be surpassed in brilliancy this season. The table decorations were of maidenhair ferns and American Beauty roses. Mrs. Brice received alone, Senator Brice not being in town.
The trial of Capt. Eakins of the Mercer Street Station on charges made by the Parkhurst society was resumed before Commissioner Andrews at Police Headquarters yesterday.

GRANT'S PASS, Oregon, July 2. -- The Southern Pacific overland northbound train was stopped last night at 10:15 o'clock by three highwaymen near Riddles, about thirty miles south of Roseburg. Sticks of dynamite were placed on the rail, which disabled the engine by blowing the flanges off the pony trucks.

HAMBURG, July 2. -- A dispatch from Friedrichsruh to The Hamburgische Correspondent says that, notwithstanding a heavy rain, Prince Bismarck drove out for two hours in an open carriage. The condition of the ex-Chancellor, the dispatch says, has greatly improved.

This is a magnificent work, with its careful text and superb illustrations. Prof. von Marilaun follows the various lines of botanical research, and treats of the plant from its very beginning to its end. The whole process of plant life is explained, and all the wonders of it. Here are vital phenomena revealed, and, when possible, traced back to their causes.
" No Man's Land" must remain as the Board of Aldermen left it.
The Volks Fest Vereine mingled in large numbers yesterday with the Schuetzen at Glendale Park, Long Island.

ALBANY, July 2. -- Gov. Morton returned to-day from Ellerslie. He appointed the members of the commission to recommend changes in legislative procedure, pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 1,025 of the Laws of 1895, as follows: Charles T. Saxton of Clyde, Danforth E. Ainsworth of Sandy Creek, John J. Linson of Kingston, Simon Sterne of New-York, and John S. Kenyon of Syracuse.
LONDON, July 2. -- The following additional Ministerial appointments have beeen announced:

LONDON, July 2. -- The wind blew quite a gale down the Henley course this morning, but the crews were all out, nevertheless. When the Cornells came out of their boat they were greeted with the Cornell cry by a number of Americans on the river bank. They rowed over the entire course at the rate of forty strokes a minute, but did not try to make a racing pace.

PATERSON, N.J., July 2. -- Mayor Braun of this city this afternoon performed a marriage ceremony which united as husband and wife Miss Cornelia Ann Ruppert and Nahan Franko. The bride is a daughter of Jacob Ruppert, the millionaire brewer. She is twenty-nine years old. Her residence, as stated by her at the City Hall before the marriage, is 1,116 Fifth Avenue, New-York.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 2. -- More than 1,000 men and women were in attendance at this morning's session of the State Teachers' Association. The first paper presented was by William R. Eastman of the State Library. His topic was "The Public Library and the Public Schools." The paper was discussed by Superintendent Griffith of Utica and E.H. Cook of New-York.

The contest for the street railroad franchise to King's Bridge,. between the Metropolitan Street Railroad Company and the Third Avenue Railroad Company, was resumed yesterday before the Board of Aldermen on new grounds.
Speaking of the new specifications for the paving of streets with asphalt, Gen. C.H.T. Collis, Deputy Commissioner of Public Works, said yesterday:

Grammar School No. 90, situated at One Hundred and Sixty-third Street and Eagle Avenue, of which Evander Childs is Principal, gave a reception yesterday in honor of the class of '95. The graduates were:
DENVER, Col., July 2. -- The alleged Democratic Silver Convention held here to-day was chiefly remarkable for the absence from it of the Democratic leaders, of Colorado.

The Aldermen took no action at yesterday's meeting on the resolution, which the Mayor vetoed, granting consent to the Third Avenue Railroad Company to extend its lines on the west side up town, but new applications were filed by that company and the Metropolitan Traction Company, accompanied by certain "offers to bid" for the franchise.

Women took part in the proceedings of the Brooklyn Board of Education yesterday for the first time in the half century of its existence. They made no speeches and offered no resolutions, but voted solidly together on every proposition that came before the board.

BOSTON, July 2. -- There will open in Boston one week from to-morrow one of the most remarkable meetings, as it will certainly be the largest religious gathering, that has ever assembled in America. From the information already received in this city there will be more than 50,000 delegates present during the five days of the Christian Endeavor Convention, July 10-15, and these will represent seventeen different nations.

" Monk" 0verton, a sable jockey of considerable ability, rode at the Sheepshead Bay track of the Coney Island Jockey Club yesterday for the last time this Summer. While the races were in progress it was announced that the Stewards of the club, Messrs. Galway, Donner, and Burke, had suspended him for the remainder of the meeting and recommended to the Stewards of The Jockey Club that his license be revoked.

LONDON, July 2. -- Lord Rosebery, in a speech made at a social gathering of the Eighty Club in this city to-night, said that he did not intend to issue either a manifesto or a programme. He was rather in the position of those heroic soldiers who politely requested the enemy to fire first.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment met yesterday afternoon to provide the first installment of funds to meet the expected deficiency in the Street-Cleaning Department. It adopted a resolution upon the certificate of the Board of Health authorizing the issue of $80,938.66 revenue bonds for the Health Board, to use in putting the streets in proper condition when it becomes necessary.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 2. -- Justice Dykman to-day handed down his decision in the annexation case, which was argued before him on June 22, in the case of the Town of Westchester against Louis F. Haffen, John McCullough, and William R. Revel, in which application was made for an injunction to restrain certain public officials from interfering with property and public records of the town of Westchester.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 2. -- The several properties constituting the Toledo, Ann Arbor and North Michigan Railroad were sold a second time, under a decree of the Federal court, in this city, to-day. R.C. Martin of New-York was the purchaser, representing the first mortgage bondholders.
It hardly needs the statements of General Manager Phillips, published yesterday, to convince the readers of The Call that The United Press is now far in advance of all its rivals as a news-gatherer.

During the fiscal year which ended on June 30 the exports of wheat (including flour in terms of wheat) from this country amounted to about 145,500,000 bushels, in round numbers, as against 164,000,000 in the fiscal year 1894, 192,000,000 in 1893, 225,000,000 in 1892, and 106,000,000 in 1891.

Justice Stover, in Supreme Court, Chambers, decided yesterday that there was no evidence to warrant the charge that the former Justices of the Court of Special Sessions had combined to shield Emma Parker, indicted for keeping a disorderly house.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 2. -- The annual fete for the benefit of the Mountainside Hospital was held this afternoon and evening on the grounds of the Montclair Athletic Club, and was attended by a large and fashionable throng of people, both young and old. The booths and other attractions were all prettily arranged, and the decorations were effective and artistic.

It is rather to be wished that Yale had confined her reply to the English challenge to an offer to meet the winner of the athletic competition between Oxford and Cambridge, which occurs to-day. Yale has the right, as the winner of the intercollegiate championship on this side, to challenge the champion on the other.

It was announced two or three days ago that freight rates for the shipment of wheat flour from Tacoma to Japan and China had been reduced one-third by the Northern Pacific Steamship Company. This is a change of some importance, because of the attempt, to which we directed attention on the 22d ult., of Australian millers and exporters to supplant American flour in Japan by their own product.

Here is a new thing. Recent dispatches to the papers announce that highwaymen have attacked and robbed in broad daylight an artist, taking from him not only his purse, but a score of sketches freshly painted!

The painter of "L'Embarquement pour Cythre" narrowly missed being not, only in race but in nationality a Fleming. On Feb. 28, 1677, the army of Louis XIV. invested Valenciennes, and on March 17 in the same year carried all the defenses and took then city. The new frontier was marked out by the treaty of Nymwegen, signed on Aug. 11, 1678, which left Valenciennes definitely to France.

PANAMA, via Galveston, July 2. -- Gen. Ramon Ulloa, whose refusal of the Colombian mission to Ecuador has been construed into a refusal to interfere with the progress of the patriots for "La Honra Nacional," has informed the correspondent of The New-York Times personally that his non-acceptance of the Colombian Legation at Ecuador's capital was not connected in any manner with the political affairs of the two countries.

President Edward B. Harper of the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association died at 12:20 o'clock yesterday afternoon, in the Dakotah apartment house, of cardiac pneumonia, after an illness of several months. He had been feeling much better, and made plans Monday for spending the Summer at Alexandria Lake.
LONDON, July 2. -- Mr. E.S. Horan, President of the Cambridge Athletic Club, was interviewed to-day on the subject of Yale's reply to the challenge of the Cambridge and Oxford teams.
HUNTINGTON, L.I. July 2. -- The July meeting of the Huntington Driving Park, under the management of J.D.W. Sherman, was begun to-day with three trots. The attendance was rather small. The summaries:

We trust that our readers have already observed with appropriate sentiments the announcement of the resignation by Dr. John A. Brooks of the pastorate of the Christian Church of Memphis. The Christian Church, it may be observed, differs from other Christian Churches doubtless upon several points of doctrine and discipline, but most obviously in that its members pronounce the first syllable of Christian with the "i" long.

In fact, though not in form, Lord Rosebery's speech in London night before last was an apology for the behavior of his Government, and especially for its failure to keep any of the pledges under which it obtained power. There can be no reasonable dispute that the present House of Commons assembled with as plain and specific a popular "mandate" as that under which the present House of Representatives met.

The Young Men's Christian Association of the City of New-York has desired for several years to establish a branch on the west side of the city, within reach of young men residing west of Eighth Avenue and south of Fifty-ninth Street and west of Central Park.

There is no probability of a special session of the Legislature to modify the excise law so as to permit a restricted selling of liquor on Sunday. Neither is there any probability that the present authorities of the city will "let up" in their policy of enforcing the law strictly so long as it stands as it is.
WASHINGTON, July 3. -- Wills L. Moore, Chicago's local forecaster of the weather, it is said, will be appointed to succeed Prof. Mark W. Harrington as Chief of the Weather Bureau.
WOODCLIFF, N.J., July 3. -- Six men were injured this morning when two trolley cars on the North Hudson County line were in collision between this place and Guttenberg. The list is as follows:

CHICAGO, July 3. -- Chicago will go to Atlanta 1,000 strong during the opening weeks of the Cotton States and International Exposition. The leading business men of Chicago have decided that in this way they can best cement the bond of good feeling which exists between the South and Northwest, which was strengthened by the ceremonies attendant upon the dedication of the Confederate monument at Oakwoods.

CHICAGO, July 3. -- The body of Mrs. Minie Uhl, which now lies in Oakwood Cemetery, will, in all probability, be exhumed by the Coroner for examination, to ascertain whether or not she died from poison.

LONDON, July 3. -- The Standard will tomorrow publish a despatch from Berlin saying that Dr. Schweninger, Prince Bismarck's physician, is accompanying Herr Krupp on a Norwegian tour. Dr. Eisenberg, his substitute, has been in attendance on Prince Bismarck only one day a week.

The first appearance of the Valkyrie in very light weather was more impressive than her second appearance in what sailors, with their delightful nautical redundancy, call "a breeze of wind." It is true that the Clyde courses are not very conducive to the exhibition of "true form," and that races upon them are by no means always to the swift.
The members of the Chamber of Commerce are very much gratified over the daily reports that reach them regarding the status of the "silver craze" in various parts of the country.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., July 3. -- 4 Three Indictments pending since 1881 against Henry S. De Bevoise, formerly Mayor of this city, were dismissed to-day in the County Court by Judge Garretsom Two of the indictments charged the ex Mayor with embezzlement of city funds by the overissue of bonds, and the other with obstructing an officer in the discharge of his duty.

TUXEDO, N.Y., July 3. -- The annual invitation tennis tournament was continued here to-day under favorable circumstances. The doubles, handicap singles, and consolation singles were started this afternoon, while the scratch singles were reduced to four players, who will meet in the semi-final round to-morrow. The scores:

BRISTOL, R.I., July 3. -- The Defender above the bulwarks is looming up into the air over anything about Bristol, and through the historic old elms of Bower, Hope, and other streets she can be distinguished as the yacht of all yachts. The topmast was got on end at 5 o'cloek this afternoon. There are a number of the Defender's crew at work on the yacht with the riggers.

CHICAGO, July 3. -- Speaker John Meyer of the Illinois House of Representatives died at Freeport, Ill., this morning. Nervous prostration was the cause of his death, though he suffered from a chronic ailment.
LONDON, July 3. -- Mr. Gladstone's promised letter to his Midlothian constituents in connection with his retirement from political life was published to-day. He says:

CHICAGO, July 3. -- Three unsuccessful attempts were made last night to burn the Mecca apartment building, occupying an entire block at Thirty-fourth and State Streets. The first fire was discovered in the basement at 7:30 P.M. Little damage was done.
HAVANA, July 3. -- The rebel band that was commanded by Zayas has surrendered to the Spanish commander at Remedios. Zayas was not among those who surrendered, and his fate is unknown.

Sir William Haynes-Smith, who has recently been appointed Governor of the Bahamas, arrived in this city yesterday on the Teutonic. He was accompanied by Lady Haynes-Smith and Miss Haynes-Smith. They are en route for Nassau, where Sir William will enter on his duties as soon as the requisite formalities are over.

Veterans' Day at the first National Schuetzen Fest passed off very quietly yesterday. The attendance did not equal that of some of the previous days, probably because many have reserved the pleasure of visiting Glendale Park until to-day, when "there will be an old-fashioned Fourth of July celebration.

It is currently reported that the manager of the municipal baseball team of Oshkosh has communicated with the manager of the baseball team of New-York, offering to take over what is known in Oshkosh as the "outfit" at a valuation. It is even said that he has offered $10,000 for the refusal of the New-York team.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- Col. Abner Taylor, ex-member of Congress, and a leading member of the Farwell Chicago syndicate which built the Texas State Capitol and received in return a grant of several million acres of State lands, recently addressed a letter to Secretary Morton criticising his order for the admission of Mexican cattle over the Texas border without obstructive restrictions
Weather Forecaster Dunn has promised that this will be a Fourth of July long to be remembered, as the serenity of the day is not to be marred by dark clouds or a drop of rain.

The decisions of Judge Patterson and Judge Dykman as to the effect upon the legislative apportionment of the annexation of a portion of Westchester County to the City and County of New-York are in complete accord, and the reasoning on which they are based seems quite convincing.
LA PLATA, Md., July 3. -- Mrs. Belle Farrall, charged with the murder of her husband, Frederick Farrall, Dec. 17 last, was put on trial to-day.
VANCOUVER, British Columbia, July 3. -- The following advices have been received by the steamer Empress of China:

" There are some things about the negro character," said a Southern man, "which you folks can never understand, because you don't see that peculiar character as closely as we do. First and foremost, it is next to impossible to get good continuous service out of the negro. Whether as river roustabout, farm hand, or general workman in business employment in the cities, he's naturally a restless creature.

Do the writers of Republican editorial articles about the condition of the United States Treasury really consider it essential to the convincingness of their comments upon the last statement of the public debt that we should all forget Secretary Foster, his expedients, flounderings, flippant and contradictory givings out toward the close of the Harrison Administration?

LONDON, July 3. -- Richard Croker's colt, Montauk, the half-brother to Clifford, was started at Newmarket to-day in the race for the Plantation Stakes, for two-year-olds, at five furlongs. The best he could do was to finish in fourth place. John Porter's colt, Chinkara, won the stake, with Douglas Baird's Donegal second, and Lord Radnor's Longford Lady third.

Vassar College is in a flourishing condition, according to the annual statements which will soon appear. The President's report at Vassar is never made public, but for some years past a small pamphlet has been issued annually by the Alumnae Trustees, entitled "Vassar College; Items Regarding Its Condition and Progress."

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 3. -- The second day of the harness races at the driving park here was a complete success. Good fields started, good time was made, and nothing occurred to mar the pleasure of those in attendance. The summaries:
Controller Fitch opened bids yesterday for $2,746,310.24 in gold bonds and stocks of the City of New-York bearing interest at 3 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- The Bureau of Navigation has received preliminary returns showing that 682 steam and sail vessels of 132,719 gross tons were built and documented in the United States during the last fiscal year, compared with 776 steam and sail vessels of 121,547 tons during 1894, an increase of 11,000 tons.

Mr. N. Bringham Hall has sold for Katherine A. Kingsland to Paul Fuller at $32,500, the four-storey brick dwelling 70 South Washington Square, 25 by 100, and for Eliza H. McCullagh to J. Howard Wright, 1t $40,000, the four storey and basement brick and stone dwelling 32 West Twenty-seventh Street, 16.8 by 98.9.

LYNN, Mass., July 3. -- The Sagamore Hotel block, Union and Mulberry Streets, was fired this afternoon by an explosion of fireworks in the store of the L.A. May Company, which occupied the lower part of the block.

Under the will of Lewis S. Levy a number of charitable institutions in this city will eventually benefit, iIr. Levy's will, disposing of property valued at $55,000, was filed yesterday for probate in the Surrogate's office.

Mrs. Margaret Cryen was shot in the right side while sitting on the stoop at her home, 437 East Sixteenth Street, last night. She was taken to Bellevue Hospital, where until early this morning the doctors were probing for the bullet.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 3. -- Cottagers are entertaining many guests who will remain over July 4. The special attractions of the day will be the first outing of the Clambake Club, in the morning, and Mrs. James P. Kernochan's lawn party, from 4 to 7 o'clock in the afternoon. Scores of invitations for the lawn party were sent out of town, and many guests are expected to arrive to-morrow morning.
NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 3. -- Arrived -- Steam yachts Sylvia, Commodore Brown; Mindora,Fedalma. J. E. Reyburn. Sloop Thistle, J. Howard Ford.

Just where Nick Young, President of the National League of Baseball Players, found Ben Tuthill no one knows. Why he sent him on here yesterday to umpire the game between the Baltimore and New-York ball clubs is a mystery.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3. -- Senator Quay to-night received word that Bradford County would indorse Gov. Hastings. Immediately upon receipt of the information he sent the following telegram to ex-Lieut. Gov. Davies of that county: "This is the most cold-blooded stab I have yet received in this mercenary attempt at political assassination.''
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., July 3. -- Trotting races here to-day resulted:

Judge McAdam of the Superior Court has refused the application which was made in behalf of Thomas Coggy for a peremptory mandamus to compel the Commissioner of Public Works to reinstate him as a laborer in the department.

The stock market to-day was intensely dull and very little interest was displayed in speculation. Stocks, nevertheless, were firm and at the close were as a rule higher than on Tuesday. Chicago Gas was the only really weak spot in the market. It sold down from 62 1/4 to 60 1/2, and closed at 61, a net loss of 1 1/8 points.

On board the Clyde Line steamship Algonquin, which reached her pier at 12:30 o'clock this morning, were two prisoners who have figured in one of the most sensational murder cases that have occurred in recent years.

PATERSON, July 3. -- The Tourist Cycle Club's fourth annual race tournament began at the Clifton track to-day under particularly favorable auspices. The weather was beautiful, the path as smooth as a billiard table, the attendance flattering, and the sport considerably above the average.

LONDON, July 3. -- To-day's session of the International Railway Congress (Sections 4 and 5 combined) was presided over by M. Leon Say. The topic of discussion was the method adopted by the great railways to encourage the building or working of light feeder lines.

John V. Hectrer, President of the great Hecker-Jones-Jewell Milling Company, and Josiah W. Wentworth, a Director in the same concern, misappropriated property valued at $148,750, according to George Putnam Smith, acting as referee.

South America has been unexpectedly fortunate this year in escaping a destructive epidemic of Asiatic cholera. The disease was present in Brazil and Argentina for about five months, but now appears to have been stamped out with a record, as officially reported, of less than 400 deaths.

HONOLULU, June 27. -- The Senate yesterday confirmed the appointment of William R. Castle as Minister to Washington. The closest secrecy is observed as to the nature of the committee's report, the ensuing discussion, and the vote.

The Blaine Republican Club, which is the leading organization of the party in the Eleventh Assembly District, celebrated the eve of the Fourth of July by refusing to admit to membership a negro Republican, and serving notice on all negroes that they may flock by themselves.

By a vote of 2 to 1 the Board of Excise yesterday declined to grant an all-night license for a Park Row saloon, primarily on the ground that no public necessity exists for such action, and secondarily, that inasmuch as there are thirty-seven saloons near that for which a license is sought all could with equal property lay claim to all-night privileges on the ground of public necessity.

HUNTER'S QUAY, Scotland, July 3. -- Lord Dunraven's new cup challenger, the Valkyrie III., was fairly beaten to-day over the fifty-mile course of the Mudhook Yacht Club by the Prince of Wales's cutter, the Britannia, and A. Barclay Walker's Ailsa. The Britannia averaged 11.27 knots per hour.

The East River Bridge Commission met yesterday afternoon in the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association Building, Broadway and Duane Street, after the members had been entertained by Commissioner Deeves at the Arkwright Club. Mayor Strong and Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn were present at the meeting. Andrew D. Baird presided.

CHICAGO, July 3. -- The Reorganization Committee of the Whisky Trust this afternoon practically reached the end of its work, and scored a final victory over the Greenhut-Morris interests, which have bitterly contested every step. The consideration of the order for a judicial sale, which has been in progress two days, was finished and all its points agreed upon.
WASHINGTON, July 3. -- A circular issued by the Civil Service Commission gives a schedule of the examinations to be held in the last six months of this year.

BOSTON, July 4. -- There was rioting in East Boston to-day. It began with the exchange of insults between paraders and the thousands of sightseers who lined the sidewalks; it ended with the killing of one person and the injury of two others, after the parade had gone over the route and disbanded, and portions of it were on their way home.
LONDON, July 4. -- The American Society in London to-night gave a banquet at the Holborn restaurant in honor of Independence Day. The Hon. Wayne MacVeagh, the American Ambassador to Italy, presided.
BERLIN, July 4. -- Emperor William started for Stockholm to-day.

LONDON, July 4. -- Mrs. Bayard, wife of the United States Ambassador, gave a reception at her residence, in Easton Square, this afternoon. The rooms were adorned with masses of flowers, and the doorways were draped with American and British flags. The archway and staircases were covered with the Stars and Stripes.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 4. -- A torrent of rain falling nearly all day seriously interferred with the elaborate programme arranged by the cottagers for the observance of the Fourth. The Clambake Club had their first outing despite the weather, but the bake, which was at Easton's Point, was indoors. T.A. Havemeyer took a big load out in his drag, and barges conveyed file rest.

BAYONNE, N.J., July 4. -- Individual championships of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States were contested this afternoon by six men on the New-Jersey A.C. grounds, during a heavy downpour of rain. Record breaking was naturally out of the question. The track was slow and muddy, and in several places water was several inches deep. The field was not favorable, contestants jumping at personal risk.

The general opinion expressed yesterday by New-Yorkers who had laid plans for a day's outing on the strength of Weather Forecaster Elias Dunn's prediction of "fair weather with light variable winds" was not favorable to the man who presides in the eyrie on top of the Manhattan Life Building.

The young ex-cow puncher was ruminating. His stalwart figure was stretched out at full length on the family sofa, his arms were over his head, and his feet, as he had gradually slipped down, so that his whole body was on a level, were hanging over the lower edge for a foot or two. There is no attempt at a pun in that last statement.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 4. -- The patriotism of Americans never has been displayed with more intensity than in the Fourth of July celebration to-day on the Pacific coast. Especially in San Francisco and in Los Angeles, the metropolitan city of the south, the National spirit assumed a degree of enthusiasm which only some new inspiration or a new birth of liberty might be expected to evoke.

A Brooklyn dentist who shot three cats that were singing in his back yard at midnight has been arrested, arraigned in a police court, and seems to stand a good chance of being fined. This is as it should be. Three cats, indeed! Had it been thirty, now, his act might have been excused as showing at least good-will, and public commendation would have rewarded it as the beginning of an effective campaign.

WINFIELD, L.I., July 4. -- The members of the Winfield Athletic Club celebrated the Fourth by taking part in a series of outdoor games. The events were the finals in a series of preliminary monthly games that were had during the past season. Gold, silver, and bronze medals were awarded to the first, second, and third men scoring the highest points.

Stockholders of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company received yesterday the annual report of the company's operations for the year ending March 31, which was sent out from the main office at Pittsburg under Tuesday's date. It makes a cheering exhibit of the company's condition and prospects.

For the second time since its inauguration, in 1889, the rich Realization Stakes of the Coney Island Jockey Club was run over a heavy track and in a rainstorm. Tournament won it under practically the same conditions in 1890, when he made a runaway race of it, simply beating his field out of sight, that field including Banquet, who has since proved such a grand handicap horse.

BOSTON, July 4. -- The fourth annual inter-State cricket match between New-York and Massachusetts was commenced here to-day on the grounds of the Longwood Cricket Club, and the representatives of the Empire State have obtained a lead of eighty runs in the first innings.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers in this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 4. -- Westchester County intended to have several grand celebrations in honor of the Fourth, but many of them were postponed for a year, because of the wet weather. Yonkers and Rye held theirs in the morning, and escaped the downpour of the later hours.

The leaves drooped-and the flags and bunting hung limp at Glendale Park yesterday, betokening utter disgust at Mr. Dunn's terrible blunder in predicting that the Hay "would be a perfect Fourth of July." He had given false hope to the promoters of the Schuetzen Fest, and on his authority they made preparations for immense crowds.

The spectacular and enterprising trio of Post Office burglars, Messrs. Henry Russell, Charles Allen, and Joseph Killoran, appeared -- and disappeared -- in a one-act comedy of their own composition, yesterday, at the Ludlow Street Jail. They scored an immediate and distinct success, which presages for these talented artists a fine run on the road.

Larchmont yachtsmen have not yet found a means of providing suitable weather for their regattas, otherwise yesterday's races would have been sailed in sunshine and with a steady breeze. Instead of this there was a heavy downpour of rain from the time the yachts began to cross the line until the last boat had finished.

The letter carriers of this city paid grateful tribute yesterday to the memory of S.S. Cox. His statue, which has stood four years at Fourth Avenue and Astor Place, was formally presented to the city and accepted on behalf of Mayor Strong by his private secretary, Job E. Hedges, and Postmaster Dayton delivered an oration.
For the one hundred and sixth time the Tammany Society or Columbian Order has celebrated the Fourth of July.

WALTHAM, Mass., July 4. -- The conditions for the cycle meat at the Waltham Park this afternoon could not well have been more unfavorable, although 6,000 people were present. The wind blew in heavy squalls and there were occasionally showers of rain.

BRISTOL, Ind., July 4. -- While a boat race on the St. Joseph River was in progress this afternoon, six hundred persons crowded on a three-span iron bridge. At the finish of an exciting race and while the crowd was cheering tremendously, the bridge gave way. The mass of humanity was precipitated into the water, forty feet below.
NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 4. -- Arrived -- Schooner Meteor, Henry Pearce; Rover, Atlantic Yacht Club, J.S. Manning.

WEST POINT, July 4. -- The National holiday was celebrated at the Military Academy in a manner worthy of the occasion. At 10:30 o'clock the assembly call sounded, and the cadets gathered on the parade grounds in front of camp. Since the lightning smote the flagstaff on Trophy Point, Old Glory has waved from a new temporary pole between the visitors' and guards' tents.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, July 4. -- The tenth annual field day of the Third District of the State Young Men's Christian Association was held on Woodlawn Oval this afternoon, and largely attended. The seventeen events were hotly contested by representatives of the Albany, Troy, Schenectady, Glens Falls, Waterford, Cohoes, West Troy, and Saratoga Associations.

CHICAGO, July 4. -- One of the largest patriotic demonstrations of organized labor ever made in this city took place to-day at Sharpshooters' Park, under the auspices of the Illinois State Federation of Labor and the Trade and Labor Assembly of Chicago. The chief speakers of the day were Vice-President Stevenson and Gov. McKinley.

MONTREAL, July 4. -- It is learned here upon the best authority that President Hill of the Great Northern Road has for some time been preparing plans for a line of Pacific steamships to be established in connection with that road and to be run in opposition to the Canadian Pacific steamship line, and that the new scheme will be announced at an early day.

PORTLAND, Oregon, July 4. -- Frank E. Davis, for five years representative of the Fire Insurance Association of Philadelphia, committed suicide by taking poison yesterday. Davis was widely known in the Northwest. He dropped in his office and was removed to the hospital, where he died within ten minutes, and it was reported that his death was due to brain paralysis.

HUNTER'S QUAY, Scotland, July 4. -- The twenty-raters raced again to-day over the course they sailed yesterday. The weather was clear and there was a light northwesterly wind. The Dakotah received the same time allowance as yesterday by the Niagara, 12 minutes and 30 seconds.
The Times, in its issue of the 3d inst., under the head "Grain Crops and Exports," editorially says, in part:

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 4. -- The people of this city turned out in crowds to-day to attend the bicycle races given by the Press Cycling Club, of which Edward "Cannon" Bald, the king of Class B riders, is a member. The track, a mile horse course, was in fairly good condition, but a stiff breeze up the home stretch caused slow time.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., July 4. -- Despite the threatening aspect of the weather about 4,000 persons attended the races at the St. Joseph Driving Park this afternoon and they witnessed the best sport of the meeting. It showered twice during the afternoon, but the water did not hurt the track as the time made will show.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., July 4. -- It was expected that the harness racer would draw 10,000 people here to-day, but less than half that number were at Comstock Park. Quite the most interesting contests the week were finished in the first two classes, which required the best part of the afternoon.
PANAMA, June 15. -- The army of Salvador is being quietly increased.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4. -- The finals in the Cup and People's Regatta were rowed this afternoon under as unfavorable conditions as could have happened. Strong northwest winds, rough river, and a driving rain chilled both oarsmen and spectators alike. Despite the storm the entire programme was carried out, and several thousand people remained throughout the afternoon upon the banks of the river and took a drenching to witness the races.
CLAYTON, N.Y., July 4. -- In the grand international sailing regatta here to-day the canoe Shamrock of Gananoque, Canada, won first place, the second place being given to the America of Clayton.

LONDON, July 4. -- The Pall Mall Gazette, commenting on yesterday's yacht race, says: "Mudhook regatta day is an unlucky day for Lord Dunraven. In the regatta of 1894 his Valkyrie II, sank, and probably the failure of his new Valkyrie yesterday is even a more bitter blow to him, for the latest Valkyrie was constructed with no other idea than to wipe out the defeat of her predecessor.

The man who knows just what is necessary for health and comfort in hot weather is around once more. He talks to us in the street, and he writes to us in the newspapers. He admonishes us as to food, drink, and clothing. He means well, but he is rather tedious.

RAHWAY, N.J., July 4. -- This city saw one of the funniest pieces of spitework today the town has yet recorded. A contract was entered into some time ago between a committee of the Union County Roadsters, the local cycling club, and the Rahway Cornet Band for the services of the band on the afternoon of the Fourth.

The weather yesterday was disastrous to baseball about New-York. It was something of an experiment to play League championship games in this vicinity July 4, but the general belief is that it would have proved a success but for the storm.

LONDON, July 4. -- The American driving meet, which took place in Hyde Park to-day, was in every respect a great success. The weather was cool, and there was present a big crowd of spectators on horseback and afoot, while carriages, filled with fashionably attired onlookers, lined the roadway the whole length of the Serpentine.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4. -- The attention of racing men is called to the following rule regarding entries to handicap and class races: "All entries must be accompanied by a statement of the best two performances of the rider, and all entries not so accompanied shall be thrown out by the handicapper." Handicappers are instructed to enforce this rule.

Nothing has happened for years that is better adapted to bring the administration of justice into ridicule and contempt than the escape of three thieves yesterday from Ludlow Street Jail. Considering what has been proved from time to time about the courts and what has been proved at great length within a year about the police, this is a strong saying.

" The Mayor's appointments to the police bench have not in all cases been ideal." When in another part of the same paper it is stated that every one of the appointees, has taken his place on the "bench," it would be hard to find any better evidence that the appointments have been very real.

HOTEL KAATERSKILL, July 4. -- Independence Day was celebrated here by giving several musical concerts during the day, and to-night a select dancing party was given in the hotel parlors. Fires burned in the hotel grates all day, making the gloomy day more cheerful.
