Palmer of Brooklyn, and Frank Debevoise, a car conductor, of 624 Lorimer Street, were arraigned before Justice Goetting, in the Lee Avenue Police Court, yesterday, on charges of fighting in the street the night before. When Justice Goetting heard Palmer's statement he discharged both prisoners.

The question will shortly be raised in the courts as to the right to sell liquor, not only on Sundays, but week days as well, on the excursion boats that irregularly ply in the rivers and harbor. The Starin Harbor Transportation Company has instructed its lawyers to apply to the courts for an injunction to restrain the police from interfering with the sale of liquor on their barges.

In addition to the big factional fight between the Platt and anti-Platt factions of the Republicans in the city and State, and the minor troubles, such as that in the Eleventh Assembly District between Job E. Hedges and John Sabine Smith, another came to the surface yesterday, which is of especial interest since its origin was away back in the days when Chester A. Arthur was a figure in city politics.

President Theodore Roosevelt of the Police Commission took occasion last night at a meeting of Good Government Club I to score Senator David B. Hill for his recent utterances on the excise question, Mr. Roosevelt characterized it as a shame and a disgrace to the State that one of its United States Senators should venture openly to appear as a champion of the dishonest enforcement of law.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The recent trial of the double turreted monitor Amphitrite, under conditions pertaining in battle, was very successful, and demonstrated the superiority of the vessel, according to Capt. W.C. Wise, her commanding officer, whose report was made public by the Navy Department to-day. Capt. Wise's opinion of the manner in which his ship stood the test is set forth in the concluding paragraph of his report, as follows:

Wall Street is interested in a new swindle, of which C.B. Greene, a Consolidated Exchange broker, is the victim. Mr. Greene received a telegram last week purporting to come from W.B. Dinsmore, Secretary of Adams Express Company. It asked Mr. Greene to receive for Mr. Dinsmore a package, which would be delivered by a Captain of a ship soon due, and to pay on it on Mr. Dinsmore's account $331.

ALBANY, July 16. -- Gov. Morton returned to the city to-day and drove directly to the Capitol, where he received a number of callers, and gave attention to routine matters which had accumulated on his desk. He will remain here over to-morrow, if there should be enough doing to require his presence.

MONTREAL, Quebec, July 16. -- The Post Office authorities here have again succeeded in circumventing the attempts of those who are engaged in shipping reprints of valuable music to the United States, thereby infringing the American Copyright act.

PATERSON, N.J., July 16. -- The New Jersey Traction Company recently purchased a plot of land on the Little Falls Road, about three miles above this city, for the purpose of making a park for the trolley parties that are carried over the company's different roads. For several days past a gang of men have been hard at work laying out the park, and this morning went to start on the baseball ground.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 16. -- The Supreme Council of the Ladies' Catholic Benevolent Association began its fourth convention in Cathedral Hall this morning. The full quota of 165 delegates, in addition to the eighteen members of the Supreme Council, were reported to the Supreme President, Mrs. F.B. McGowan of Buffalo.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 16. -- The Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club began its tournament this afternoon. Rain fell during the morning, but as the courts were in fair shape at 3 in the afternoon, it was decided to begin. The crowd was not up to expectation, as there was the making of another big shower in the sky, and the rain stopped play during the match between Stevens and Walton.

The Rev. Dr. Arthur Brooks, pastor of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Thirty-sixth Street and Madison Avenue, died July 10 on board the steamship Fulda, which arrived yesterday from Southampton, England.

It was our fixed resolve to press to a solution another great, aye, one of the greatest measures -- I speak of the Local Option bill. [Loud cheers.] I have some right to speak upon that question, and I speak upon it with a sense of the deepest responsibility. It has been insinuated that I stood alone in this matter. That statement is false.

ASBURY PARK, July 16. -- Harry H. Maddox, the ten-mile Class B champion, who is a resident of this place, and a member of the Asbury Park Wheelmen, said to-day that he would not ride under the colors of the club in the future.

The sixth annual regatta of the Middle States 1.egatta Association will be hold this year on tho, Harlem. iver,Saturday, Aug. 10. All the races willl be one mile straightaway. The events will be junior single sculls, intermediate single sculls, senior single sculls, intermediate double sculls, senior double sculls, intermediate our-oared gigs, Junior four-oared shells, senior four-oared gigs, junior eight-oared shells, senior eight-oared shells, { and senior four-oared barg.

Messrs. Hoffman Brothers have sold, for the Wallace estate, the property at 28 to 44 Laight Street, near Hudson Street, 91.4 by 100, at about $90,000. The purchaser will erect a seven-story building on the plot, which has been leased by Messrs. Hoffman Brothers and David H. Carroll to one firm for ten years at an aggregate rental of $125,000.
A down-town cable car and an up-town car and trailer came into collision with a wagon belonging to Jacob Meyer of 28 Rivington Street at Fifth Street and Third Avenue at 6:30 o'clock last night.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 16. -- Mrs. Towns end Burden gave the largest dinner party of the season to-night. The tables were set in the ballroom. It was decorated beautifully with roses. There were twenty-six guests, including the members of the English Legation, now here.

Col. B. Frank Gott, ex-President of the Kings County Board of Charities and Correction, yesterday told the Assembly Committee on Cities, which is investigating his administration of the Charities Department, that he is out of work and is looking for employment. He was on the witness stand in the City Court room all day.

The contest for the cricket championship of New-York keeps close, although the victory of Brooklyn over Staten Island on Saturday gives that organization a good lead, and they will do their best to maintain it until the end of the season. In the race for the Batter's Cup, M.R. Cobb has got into first place, a position to which he is justly entitled, but he will have to work hard to keep it.

Whether the trousseau of Miss Bechtel, daughter of the Staten Island brewer, which she prepared for her recent marriage to Joseph Keppler, son of Puck's former illustrator, was smuggled or not, is a question that Collector Kilbreth is trying to decide.

CHICAGO, July 16. -- There began this afternoon at 2 o'clock, at the Illinois Club, what promises to be a noteworthy debate. The issue is gold or silver for the National currency. The champion of gold is Roswell G. Horr of Michigan; of silver, W.H. Harvey of Chicago. The debate is expected to continue eight days.

LONDON, July 16. -- Augustin Daly and Miss Ada Rehan, with twenty members of Mr. Daly's company, were entertained at luncheon by Sir Joseph Renals, the Lord Mayor, at the Mansion House to-day. Among those present were Ambassador Bayard and Mrs. Bayard, United States Consul General Patrick A. Collins, Beerbohm Tree, Edward Terry, and Charles Wyndham.

HIGHLANDS OF NAVESINK, N.J., July 16. -- The order from the War Department through Col. Gillespie to the squatters on the Sandy Hook Peninsula not having been enforced to-day has put old "Capt. Ci," alias "Capt. Bill" Cipher, in exhuberant spirits.

The United States Secret Service men made four arrests last night which they regard as important, as the three men and one woman whom they took into custody have been engaged in counterfeiting United States silver coin for nine months past at the rate of $50 per day.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 16. -- Brooklyn outplayed Louisville again to-day. The same number of base hits were made off of each pitcher, but Daub kept his so well scattered that Louisville could not score after the first inning. Attendance, 700. Score:

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Ex-Congressman Timothy J. Campbell of New-York had an audience to-day with Acting Secretary Adee of the State Department, with reference to the recent expulsion from Calceta, Ecuador, of several American nuns, who settled in that country eight years ago.

The United States Grand Jury concluded yesterday its investigation into the escape of the Post Office thieves, Killoran, Russell, and Allen, from Ludlow Street Jail July 4. It handed to Justice Lacombe a presentment, in which the methods of Sheriff Tamsen, Warden Raabe, and Keepers McCabe, Schoen, and Schneer are severely criticised.

Chicago's population at the present time is greater than that of any other city in the United States. Chicago is the metropolis of the country, and, on careful calculation based on the number of names in the new directory, has more than 2,000,000 population.

There is something pathetic in the exhibition of the poverty of the Republican State Committee made in Chairman Hackett's sad, though envious, retort to Commissioner Brookfield's cruel remark that it had failed to do anything for the local reform ticket last Fall, and would have been "delighted" to see it defeated, provided a Republican Governor and Legislature were elected.

SOFIA, July 16. -- M. Stambuloff was reported at one time to-day to be unconscious and sinking rapidly as the result of the attack upon him last night by four assassins. But later he recovered, and a Magistrate was at once summoned to his bedside to take his deposition.

The heirs of the estate of Jesse Seligman, the banker, who died at Coronado Beach, I California, in April, 1894, have takYen measiures to set aside all assessment upon the I estate for 1895, which they claim has been levied through a blunder of the Commlsi stoners of Taxes and Assessment.

The pheasants which the Peabody Society is carefully rearing into strength and beauty at Forest Park for exhibition there are thriving well under artificial care. The society has at present nine Japanese golden pheasants, and two of the ring-neck variety, all full-grown birds, with their plumage at the height of its beauty.
Police Superintendent William J. McKelvey of Brooklyn yesterday handed to the Police Commissioner a list of the number of burglaries reported in that city since July 1. His report was as follows:

Stockholders in the various dry dock companies in this vicinity were informed yesterday by circular that the control of their properties had been bought by a combination of capital represented by W.P. Shaw of 41 Wall Street. It is proposed to consolidate all interests into a single company and to pay to the original stock a dividend of 2 per cent. annually in the form of rental.

MONTREAL, July 16. -- President Grenier of the Banque du Peuple, which suspended yesterday, states that it is impossible as yet to give an exact statement of the bank's affairs. The Government Inspector will hold an investigation. The assets are claimed to exceed $9,000,000, and the liabilities $7,000,000. The Directors are personally responsible for the liabilities.

LONDON, July 16. -- As the borough results develop, it becomes evident that the reaction against the Liberal Party is not confined to any issue or locality. Nothing could be more impartially distributed than its evil fortune. To-night's list of losses covers all sorts and conditions of electors and smashes another group of Ministers, among whom Arnold Morley can extremely well be spared.

A company of Tennessee Christian Endeavorers went to Cambridge on Friday. First they visited Harvard College, and, after going through the college grounds, boarded a car for Mount Auburn, where they saw the graves of the famous dead. In the course of their trip they came to the tomb of Henry W. Longfellow, which many people were looking at and thinking of the great poet.

BALTIMORE, July 17. -- The advance guard of the great throng of 15,000 delegates and visitors who are expected from all parts of the country to participate in the convention of the Baptists' Young People's Union of America, which will open its sessions to-morrow, arrived in large numbers to-day.

There was a fine exihibition of free hitting given in the game yesterday at Staten Island between the Brooklyn and Staten Island Cricket Clubs. Had time allowed, there is no telling how many runs would have been complied, for the islanders ran up 235 for six wickets, and the Brooklyns had put on 107 for two when the game ended in a draw.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 17. -- Around a well-laden dinner table at Kebo to-night are sitting a distinguished company of guests. Presiding at the feast is Robert Pendleton Bowler, Secretary of the Kebo Valley Club. The young lady at his side is Miss Susie Sturgis of Philadelphia, one of the prettiest of the season's belles. Next to Miss Sturgis is Miss Garland, the daughter of the President of the First National Bank of New-York City.

OLD FORGE, N.Y., July 17. -- A story is going the rounds here that Mr. Harrison has announced with positiveness that he is not a candidate for the Presidency, and would not accept the nomination of his party for that office if it should be tendered him.

NEWARK, N.J., July 17. -- Edward Joyce, a cripple, twenty-two years old, whose deformity had stunted him so that he was no larger than a child of twelve years, died at his home, near the Washington Avenue crossing of the Erie Railroad at Avondale, on Monday night. He was known to every trainman on the Erie, and to many of the passengers.
A number of East Twenty-ninth Street cats have been minus their tails since Sunday morning.

Stuyvesant Fish, President of the Illinois Central Railroad Company; George Mosle of Mosle Brothers, and Charles A. Peabody' announced themselves yesterday as the Reorganization Committee chosen by the Bondholders' Protective Committee of the United States Cordage Company. The new committee has prepared a plan of reorganization, to which security holders are to be asked to assent, instead of depositing with the Reorganization Committee which was organized when the company collapsed.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 17. -- It is now known that almost all the clothing of the murdeder Pietzel girls was burned. Some articles of attire belonging to them, however, were stuffed into the chimney and into holes around the house at 16 St. Vincent Street. Some of that clothing has been traced, and the last link in the chain of evidence against Holmes has been practically forged by that discovery.

The death of Chief Justice Simon M. Ehrlich of the City Court came as a great surprise to his friends and acquaintances, as but few knew of his serious illness. He had been sick for about three weeks with typhoid fever at his Summer residence, Throgg's Neck, L.I., and for nearly ten days had been in a precarious condition.

LONDON, July 17. -- It had hardly seemed possible that anything could have been worse from the Liberal point of view than the elections of the previous days. But to-night's returns disclose new depths of gloom. For the first time there is not a single Liberal gain to alleviate despair.
The contest over the will and estate of Henry King, who died in April, was brought up before Justice Stover in the Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Orders were telegraphed from the Navy Department to-day directing Capt. Wise of the double-turreted monitor Amphitrite to proceed to Wilmington, N.C.; Charleston, S.C., and Brunswick, Ga., to take on board the naval militia organizations of the three States named for their annual practice cruise, in conjunction with officers and men of the regular navy.

The ferryboat Whitehall of the Hamilton Avenue line entered her South Ferry slip yesterday in such a precipitate way that most all of her passengers were jolted off their feet. The bridge was half wrecked by the shock, and it required considerable time to get it in such condition that teams could cross.

President Roosevelt's determined attitude and that of his associates in the Police Board respecting the enforcement of the excise law, as has been shown by interviews published in The New-York Times, has been widely commended by all classes of citizens.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 17, -- Elkwood Park at this place was thronged to-day, the bicycle races postponed on account of the bad weather from July 4 being the attraction. The course is a one-mile egg-shaped track, very fast, and well packed.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 17. -- Mrs. Alva Vanderbilt and Miss Consuelo Vanderbilt went to Narragansett Pier to-day for a short stay.

BOSTON, Mass., July 17. -- The annual regatta of the Eastern Yacht Club, sailed to-day off Marblehead, brought out the schooners Mayflower, Marguerite, and Mon Reve, the forty-footers Tomahawk and Gorilla, and the thirty-footers Handsel, Ashumet, Memory, Salmon, Anoatok, Harbinger, and Tom Boy. The race was sailed in a light easterly breeze and a rolling sea, and was started and finished at Marblehead Neck instead of at Halfway Rock, as usual.
The Vigilant was safely placed on the Boston dry dock in Erie Basin, South Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, and her crew were immediately set to work at cleaning and polishing her bottom.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., July 17. -- Passed East -- Steam yachts Judge, W.J. Arkell; Helvetia, Columbus O'D. Iselin; Katrina, Henry F. Noyes; Charlietta, W.B. Higgins; Nereid and Halcyon, Edward C. Potter. Yawl Hebe. Schooner yacht Meteor. Alfred Peats.

SOFIA, July 17. -- A representative of Prince Ferdinand called at the residence of M. Stambuloff to-day to express the sovereign's sympathy' and condolence, but Mme. Stambuloff refused to receive him or hold any communication with him.

TRENTON, N.J., July 17. -- All the evidence has been submitted in the trial of John S. Collins, colored, for the murder of Frederick Ohl, a Princeton student. There was a large attendance at the trial to-day, among the visitors in the courtroom being Mrs. Barclay Warburton of Philadelphia, and Miss Morgan, daughter of Pierpont Morgan of New-York.

A glorious day rewarded the patience of the horsemen yesterday, the opening day of the midsummer meeting at old Fleetwood Park. An excellent day's sport was had, as the track was fast. The reduction of the entrance fee to 50 cents did not make any apparent difference in the number of spectators.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., July 17. -- The American iron and Steel Association has received from the manufacturers complete statistics of the production of all kinds of pig iron in the United States in the first half of 1895; also complete statistics of the stocks of pig iron which were on hand and for sale at the close of the half hour. LONDON, July 17. --M. F. Dwyer's Don Alonzo ran third at Newmarket to-day in a selling plate of 103 sovereigns for three-year-olds and upward, the winner to be sold for 200 sovereigns, which was won by Favour Royal by three lengths. Don Alonzo was beaten a head for the place. The distance was five furlongs and the summary of the race is as follows:

David L. Fineman of the firm of Simon Fineman of 315 Church Street, and a salesman in his employ, Thomas Hall of 427 Waverly Avenue, Brooklyn, were taken before Magistrate Brann, at the Tombs Police Court, yesterday, charged with committing an aggravated assault upon Gustave Meyers of 3 Essex Street.

There are more separate and distinct political fights raging within the Republican Party these midsummer days than has been the case before in years. They vary in size from those involving the State machine to those involving control of a district.

LONDON, July 17. -- A letter written by Mr. R. C. Lehmann, Captain of the Leander Rowing Club, to Mr. C.S. Francis, manager of the Cornell crew, which expresses the feeling which is now generally prevalent among oarsmen, is as follows:

PANAMA, July 6. -- The sight of a dredge in the channel of the canal in the Bay of Panama on Saturday last was a pleasing one, forming the subject of general comment. It was towed from La Boca by a steam launch Saturday morning and anchored about midway between Isla de Naos and La Boca.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 17. -- The primary students of the Chautauqua Assembly spent the morning hour reviewing the lessons of tile last week. The normal pupils considered the subject of "Inspiration," and the post-graduates "The Living Christ." At the round table this afternoon, "Education and Life" was discussed.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17. -- District Attorney Graham, it is said, has been put in possession of new evidence of a circumstantial kind against H.H. Holmes, suspected of the murder of B.F. Pietzel, and the latter's three children. Mr. Graham is running down every clue that may lead to the unearthing of Holmes's crimes, and is doing all he can to aid the Toronto authorities in their collection of evidence.
Two of the three men and the woman arrested at 95 Fourth Avenue Tuesday evening by Secret Service officers for counterfeiting were arraigned before United States Commissioner Shields.

The work of reorganizing Tammany Hall under the new apportionment is now well under way. Several of the District General Committees met last night to elect Inspectors of Elections for the primaries, which are to be held Aug. 1 in all the districts. The Inspectors are very important officials in districts where there are contests. In some of the districts, however, where contests were threatened peace has evidently been patched up.
WASHINGTON, July 17. -- The Secretary of the Interior to-day received the following telegram from Governor W.A. Richards of Wyoming, dated July 15:

BISLEY, July 17. -- The winners of money prizes in the shooting for the St. Martin's Cup, seven shots at 200 yards, were Hayhurst and Simpson, who each scored 31, and Russell, who scored. In the Jeffrey contest, seven shots at 200 yards. Anderson scored 35 and took a money prize. In the Elkington contest, seven shots at 600 yards, Spearling scored 35 and Rolston 31.

There will be a fine display of horses and traps at Long Branch from Aug. 8 to 10 inclusive, when the Monmouth County Horse Show Association has its second annual show. Last Summer the show of fine teams and traps was not only a big social success, but a success from the horseman's standpoint also.
The investigation of the management of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge by the sub-committee of the Assembly Committee on Cities was resumed yesterday in Part II of the Superior Court in this city.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 17. -- Gov. Morton, having finished consideration of matters which had accumulated in his absence, again left this city this afternoon for his home, Ellerslie. He will go to Bar Harbor to join his family in August.

NORWALK, Conn., July 17. -- The body of Katie Valentine, daughter of Charles E. Valentine, of Butler Street, this city, was found in the fields at the rear of the Summer residence of Mrs. Rebecca D. Matthews of New-York at about 10 o'clock this morning, face downward and lying across a telephone wire.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- The problem of the proper disposition of the garbage of large cities, which is perplexing New-York, is in a small way affecting Washington. Washington has not the resources available to New-York, as discussed by the recent report of Lieut. Commander Delehanty of the Board of Engineers of the United States Army, of towing its garbage out to sea, and within certain reasonable restrictions as to location dumping it.

OSWEGO, N.Y., July 17. -- The Fulton Worsted Mills, which manufacture the finest grades of cloth and employ more than 800 persons, have just been sold to a syndicate of English capitalists, who are understood to have options on many of the knitting mills in this section and New-England.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, July 9, via Key West, July 17. -- The revolution in this district is increasing in extent every day. Within the last three days more than 100 men of the common class have left this city to join the insurgents, and a great number of the most distinguished men have also gone.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 17. -- The Times-Union has received the following from its correspondent at West Palm Beach, Fla.:

SAGINAW, Mich., July 17. -- This was the banner day of the Grand Circuit meeting in attendance, and the horses were equal to the occasion, Two pacing classes were on the card, and both proved difficult problems for the pool buyers.

The New-York Yacht Club announces races for first-class sloops, to be sailed next Saturday and Monday, over the course outside of Sandy Hook, far a two-hundred-dollar cup for the winner, if two or more start, and a one-hundred-dollar cup for the second should four or more start. Entries for the reces close Friday evening at the clubhouse at 10 P.M.

The downfall of the Rosebery Government seems to have excited the French press to a remarkable degree. The tone of the French papers had not been any too friendly toward England when the Liberals were in power, but it is greatly irritated by the accession of Lord Salisbury. Two incidents, which are regarded as triumphs of French diplomacy, have served to make the feeling toward England more imperious than ever.

MONUMENT, Cal., July 17. -- A Santa Fe freight train, bound from Denver to Colorado Springs, fell through a bridge just south of here at 11 o'clock this morning, killing three persons, fatally injuring three, and seriously injuring fifteen others.

ALBUQUERQUE, New-Mexico, July 17. -- A bill was filed yesterday in the United States Court here by the United State Trust Company of New-York, trustee under the first mortgage of the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad, asking for foreclosure and sale of the property, no interest having been paid on the first mortgage since the road went into the hands of receivers, in January, 1894.

BALTIMORE, July 17. -- As the facts become known President Samuel Spencer of the Southern Railway Company engineered a clever deal in acquiring control of the Georgia Southern and Florida Railroad. It is not often that one corporation secures control of another which is paying handsomely for nothing, and makes a good profit in the bargain.
LONDON, July 17. -- Up to midnight the returns from the elections were as follows:
" I concluded that if it was longevity or a long beard, I would take the longevity."

Maria Barberi, the Italian girl convicted of murder in the first degree for the killing of Domenico Cataldo, and who is locked up in the Tombs awaiting sentence, after having borne the strain of the trial remarkably well, broke down on Tuesday night, when she appears to have realized for the first time that she would be sentenced to death.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 17. -- Willie Park, the expert English professional golfer, lost his first match in this country to-day to William F. Davis, the professional of the Newport Club. A great crowd of society people followed the players of the Newport links, though the ground was very wet from recent rains. The men played 18 holes this morning and 18 this afternoon for a purse.

SHELTER ISLAND, July 17. -- The harbor here is filled with the yachts of the combined squadron, which is about seventy strong. The run from New-London to-day was uninteresting and fluky from a racing standpoint until after getting through Plum Gut, and then in a rattling breeze they beat to the finish.

GLASGOW, July 10. -- The Royal Clyde Yacht Club, the old Thistle's "patron saint." started its regatta on Saturday, July 6, and its first match was an opportunity for Valkyrie III. to put herself on her best behavior and not give herself away as she did in the breeze of the 3d. The cutter had against her Watson's Britannia, and Fife's Ailsa, and she made a bad example of both.
After he had noisily tramped through most of the flat once, the prospective tenant turned on the little woman who was to remain in possession until the first of the month and asked abruptly:

Republican politicians and journals are casting about in great perplexity and distress for something that will prevent their tariff issue from sinking out of sight. Even after the beginning of the extraordinary industrial and commercial revival they were saying that no such upward movement could take place under the present tariff, which, as they admitted, must remain in force for at least two years.

One of the largest transactions of the season in real estate was concluded yesterday in the purchase of the Ottendorfer property of about 200 lots, extending from the Boulevard to the Hudson River, and between One Hundred and Thirty-third and One Hundred and Thirty-seventh Streets. The property is not continuous but is in detached parcels.

Several leading citizens of Cincinnati visited the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday morning and presented, on behalf of the city which they represented, an elegant silver service to the United States cruiser Cincinnati.

CINCINNATI, July 17. -- A fire at 3 o'clock this afternoon, in the main part of the shipping quarter of the city, resulted in the instant death of two firemen and the probably fatal injury of a half dozen others. The fatalities were caused by the falling of the walls of the burning building.

HIGHLANDS OF NAVESINK, N.J., July 17. -- Capt. "Ci," cat and kittens made a move early this morning for Seabright. A padlock was on the door of his cabin, and strewn around were the wreckage of the huts of other fishermen and squatters on the Federal strip, who obeyed the order, at 12:20 o'clock, to leave.

SARATOGA, July 17. -- Perfect weather, a well-nigh perfect course, and close contests in the several events made the first day's racing of the twenty-third annual regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen a success. One race in particular will be long remembered. It was the intermediate eight-oared shell race, and for the last half mile the prows of two boats cut the water on even terms.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- Frank W. Hawley, Vice-President of the Cataract General Electric Company, was asked to-day as to the truth of the published report that an English syndicate had purchased a controlling interest in his company, which enjoys the exlcusive and perpetual right to use all of the canal lines of the State of New-York in the introduction of electricity generated at Niagara for commercial purposes and as a medium for canalboat propulsion.

Senor Emilio Castelar complains that "North Americans are not just to the country which was the mother and discoverer of America." The Spanish statesman refers, probably, to the fact that many residents of the United States sympathize with the Cubans in their struggle to throw off the galling yoke of foreign rule.

Arrangements are being perfected by the Medico-Legal Society of this city for the holding of a medico-legal congress in or near this city on Sept. 4, 5, and 6 of this year, The congress will be open to all students of medical jurisprudence.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 17. -- Justice J.O. Dykman has just handed down a decision in a suit upon which depends the determination of some forty or fifty other suits. It was that of Hawley D. Clapp against William Moore for the recovery of real property in the town of Mamaroneck, Westchester County, valued at about $75,000.

The Aqueduct Commissioners met yesterday in executive session, and after a long discussion they decided to postpone action until next Wednesday in the matter of awarding the contract for the construction of the Jerome Park Reservoir.

A new scheme for a cycle path of more than usual attractiveness has been hatched in Brooklyn, and if it should go through, it will, without doubt, give Long Island one of the best cycleways that could possibly be devised. The plan is to give the aqueduct leading from Brooklyn to Massapequa, a distance of nearly twenty-three miles, a suitable top dressing, and there you are.

RICHMOND, S.I., July 18. -- The Grand Jury of the Richmond County Court of Sessions, which has been investigating the affairs of the County Board of Excise, presented a report of the findings to the Court to-day. The jury had before presented four indictments against Frederick W. Clifford, clerk of the Excise Board, two for extortion and two for neglect of duty.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

There were some interesting statements in the interview with the editor of The Wine and Spirit Gazette which was published in The Times yesterday. One of them was the statement that a formal agreement was made between a committee of the Central Association of Liquor Dealers and "the leaders of Tammany Hall," according to which "the monetary blackmail paid to the police should be discontinued in return for political support."

SOFIA, July 18. -- Stefan Nicolas Stambuloff, ex-Prime Minister of Bulgaria, died at 3:30 o'clock this morning from the effects of the wounds inflicted upon him Monday evening, when he was returning to his home from the Union Club.

HACKENSACK, N.J., July 18. -- Dr. Anna W. Williams has almost entirely recovered from a slight throat trouble that confined her to her home for several days. She expects to return soon to her work as assistant bacteriologist in the New-York Health Department, where she has been engaged in the preparation of antitoxine.

The Ottendorfer property, the sale of which was exclusively announced in The New-York Times yesterday, has as its southerly boundary two lots, 50 by 100, on the north side of One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street, between the Boulevard and Twelfth Avenue. Above and connecting with it is a plot filling the block on the south side of One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street, between the Boulevard and Twelfth Avenue, 775 by 100 feet.

TRENTON, N.J., July 18. -- An application for a receiver for the Central Jersey Traction Company has been made in the Court of Chancery by ex-Senator Lemuel E. Miller of Cape May. The company is controlled by New-York and Philadelphia capitalists. The New-York and Philadelphia Traction Companies and the Central Jersey Traction Company are operated in connection with each other by the same officers.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, July 18. -- A strong breeze made to-day a pleasant one at State Camp. Drilling was comfortable, both at the early morning and forenoon exercises. A large party of excursionists came up from Yonkers, and there was also an excursion by barge of the friends of the Eleventh Company of Mount Vernon. The visitors were serenaded by the band.

BALTIMORE, July 18. -- The delegates and visitors to the fifth International Convention of the Baptist Young People's Union of America continued to arrive throughout the night and early morning hours until, at 10 o'clock, there were 10,000 congregated in the mammoth tent situated at the Madison Avenue entrance to Druid Hill Park.
The Commissioners of Education, as Trustees of the College of the City of New-York, decided yesterday afternoon to secure a portion of Convent Hill for the site of the new college buildings.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The official report of Capt. Sumner concerning the accident to the cruiser Columbia while in dry dock at Southampton, England, was received at the Navy Department to-day. Capt. Sumner says the damage to the vessel was very slight and will not interfere with her trip to New-York.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 18. -- Farmers and cattle owners of Long Island are greatly interested as to whether they will have the privilege of using Montauk as a pasture land for cattle, sheep, and horses. According to the order of Austin Corbin, the 5,500 acres recently purchased by himself and Charles M. Pratt were cleared to-day of all cattle.
CITY ISLAND, N.J., July 18. -- Passed East -Steam yachts Lorna, W.L. Stow; Orienta, E.R. Ladew, and Nada, C.R. Flint. Schooner yacht Lydia, Henry M. Banks.

ALBANY, July 18. -- The John Palmer boom was started upon its course to-night. A public meeting of Republicans was called at Republican headquarters here. Every ward in Albany and Cohoes cities, as well as every town in the county was represented. The sentiment was unanimous that John Palmer's name be presented to the Republican State Convention for renomination for Secretary of State.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 18. -- The Pan-American Congress of Religion and Education was formally opened this afternoon at the Horticultural Gardens Pavilion. Numerous distinguished visitors have arrived to participate in the programme, and more are expected daily.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 18. -- The sub-committee of the Democratic State Committee appointed to consider the situation and endeavor to harmonize the several factions in Monroe County, met this morning. The following members were present: Chairman J.W. Hinkley, Poughkeepsie; Charles R. De Freest, Troy; Judge Wilbur F. Porter, Watertown; Norman E. Mack, Buffalo; James H. Flannagan, North Bay, Oneida County.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 18. -- The new electric railroad on the American side of the river, running from Niagara Falls City to Lewiston, N.Y., was formally opened to the public this afternoon, and the first passenger train was run over the line, carrying a large party of railroad officials and prominent local citizens and invited guests.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Controller Bowler, the law officer of the Treasury whose decision on matters of allowing accounts is supreme by law to that of the Secretary of the Treasury himself, has set Wednesday, July 24, next to hear argument on the constitutionality of the sugar bounty law.

NEWARK, N.J., July 18. -- Two men were killed, one fatally injured, and two others frightfully maimed by the cave-in of 400 tons of earth in a sewer excavation at Harrison at 3:15 o'clock this afternoon. The dead are:
Tammany districts meetings to elect Inspectors for the primaries were held in many Assembly districts last night.
The funeral of the Rev. Dr. Arthur Brooks, pastor of the Church of the Incarnation, was held yesterday afternoon at the church, which was crowded to the doors.

The Committee on Election Officers of the Republican County Committee held a session at County headquarters in West Thirty-eighth Street last night, and did the best it could to select an eligible list of names to be submitted to the Police Board.

There will be bustle and excitement aboard the old man-of-war New-Hampshire, lying at the foot of East Twenty-eighth Street, this afternoon and evening, for the members of the Naval Reserve will start at 8 o'clock for a week's encampment at Shelter Island.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 18. -- Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor were among the day's arrivals. They came up on their yacht, the Nourmahal, and went to Beechwood, where they will spend the season with Mrs. William Astor. The Misses Ogden of New-York arrived at Clover Patch cottage, and Mr. and Mrs. Warham Whitney of Rochester took possession of one of the Cliff cottages for the season.

Livery stable keepers in this city are rapidly substituting rubber tires for those made of steel. This ought to result in a great diminution of unnecessary noises. A rubber-tired hansom hops over the roughest granite pavement with little more noise than the pneumatic tire of a bicycle.

The first step in the interest of harmony among Brooklyn Democrats was taken yesterday by the two Democratic members of the Board of Elections. Commissioners Charles J. Edwards and Jacob W. Erreger -- the first-named representing the Reform Democracy, the second the regular Democratic machine organization -- addressed the following letter to Bernard J. York, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the General Committee of the Bell faction.

At a meeting yesterday of the Executive Committee of the Trunk Line Association measures were taken to put in practice the policy formulated by the Presidents on July 8. It was agreed to cancel at once all outstanding rate contracts between members of the association and shippers. Special rates will thus be summarily abolished.
LONDON, July 18. -- Up to midnight the returns from the elections were as follows:

WATERTOWN, July 18. -- Northern New-York has a candidate for Attorney General this year on the Democratic ticket in the person of Daniel G. Griffin of Watertown, whose candidacy was formally announced to-night by the Jeffersonian Club of his city.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18. -- Judge Acheson to-day filed an opinion in the United States Circuit Court, overruling all the demurrers to the bill of complaint of the Pennsylvania Company for insurances on lives, and granting authority for the foreclosure of the Reading Railroad general mortgage. It was held that the demand made in writing was within the fair meaning of Article 4 of the mortgage.

We were mistaken the other day in saying that the discussion of the drink question had played no part in the canvass preceding the Parliamentary elections. The remark was just according to the information then accessible, but later London papers contain full reports of the speeches of the leaders on both sides, and in these the Local Veto bill receives its share of attention.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 18. -- The Defender came to anchor in the harbor at 10:30 this morning, mooring to a white can buoy near the entrance, and about a mile from All View, the liver-and-white-colored residence of C. Oliver Iselin, practical manager of the new yacht. The Colonia came to anchor a short distance away and nearer to Mr. Iselin's cottage, on Premium Point.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Details of the declaration of independence by the Island of Formosa have been received at the State Department from Charles Denby, United States Minister to Pekin. Mr. Denby confirms the statements made that a republican form of government was instituted.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18. -- The Rev. N.E. Howland, the young Pasadena minister, passed through this city on his way to the San Quentin Penitentiary, to which institution he has been sentenced to serve two years by the Superior Court of Los Angeles County.

William J. Connolly, clerk in the office of the cashier of the Excise Board and formerly an Excise Inspector, has been included in the charges of bribery made by John Liebenow and his reputed wife, Mary Heuer, against Inspector Edward Lion and Julius Steinberger, appointees of the new Board of Excise Commissioners.

Hundreds of civil engineers, builders, and real estate dealers, interested in modern devices for securing safe foundations for high buildings, went yesterday to the lots on the southwest corner of Exchange Place and Broad Street, where a sixteen-story business structure is to be erected for the John Taylor Johnston estate, at a cost, for the building, of $800,000.

PANAMA, via Galveston, July 18. -- A cable from Guayaquil reports the death of the Rev. Suere, the Venezuelan Minister. The Supreme Chief has decreed that he shall be paid the greatest funeral honors at the expense of the Government.
TRENTON, N.J., July 18. -- The jury in the case of John Collins for killing Frederick P. Ohl, at 11:45 to-night rendered a verdict of murder in the second degree.

BOSTON, July 18. -- A Bulgarian gentleman, at present living in Cambridge. Stoyan Krstoff Vatralsky, a Harvard graduate, thinks that the dispatches from abroad describing the assassination of ex-Premier Stambuloff have conveyed a wrong impression concerning the part which they imply the Government and the police have played in the tragedy.
LONDON, July 18. -- The Pall Mall Gazette, in an article on the assassination of ex-Premier Stambuloff of Bulgaria, says:
BERLIN, July 18. -- Auguste Reichensperger, a well-known litterateur, and sometime leader of the German Clerical Party, died in Cologne Tuesday, aged eightyseven years.

MOBILE, Ala., July 18. -- Andrew Thomas, colored, accused of a brutal assault on an aged white woman named Mrs. Vise, near Moss Point, Miss., captured here some ten days ago, and held for a requisition from the Governor of Mississippi, was taken to Scranton, Miss., by Sheriff Minor on an early freight train.

Maria Barbella, generally spoken of as Maria Barberi, but whose right name, according to her mother, is Barbella, was sentenced to die by electricity by Recorder Goff in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, for the murder of Domenico Cataldo. The execution is to take place in the week beginning Aug. 19.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 18. -- At the meeting of the Executive Committee of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen, held this forenoon, Charles Catlin of Chicago was elected President to succeed Harry W. Garfield of Albany, who has held the position for the last sixteen years, and under whose fostering care the association has grown to the position it now occupies.

It was announced yesterday that the sale of soda water and non-intoxicants was not to be stopped on Sunday next or on any other Sunday, as had been anticipated. The Evening Post printed the following statement:

The long-expected reorganization of the Detective Bureau has been effected, and to-day practically a new force will be detailed for duty. All the old detectives, with the exception of Sergt. McClosky and, perhaps, one or two others, will go back to patrol duty or retire, as the case may be.

LONDON, July 18. -- The country districts turn out even more uniformly worse for the Liberals than the boroughs were. There now have been ten Liberal rural seats heard from, and actually nine are losses.

ALBANY, July 18. -- With a brief intermission for luncheon, the Capitol Commission held a session lasting from 9:30 o'clock this morning until 7 o'clock this evening. The time was given up to scrutinizing the names of persons urged for appointment on the Capitol construction, under the $400,000 which the Aldridge Republican machine has to expend before the contract work goes into effect.

LONDON, July 18. -- In Plaistow, an eastern suburb of London, this morning, two boys named Combes, aged thirteen and eleven years, were brought before a magistrate upon the charge of having murdered their mother. The accusation was substantiated by their own confession of the crime.
NEW-ORLEANS, July 18. -- The Daily States, in a leading editorial under the caption, "Our Telegraph Service," says:

The special Assembly committtee that is investigating the railroads in Brooklyn took up the Kings County Elevated Road yesterday. James H. Frothingham, the Treasurer, was a witness. He said the contract under which the road was built called for a payment of $500,000 a mile, and bonds for $550,000 a mile were issued, the extra $50,000 being for legal fees,

The journals of the iron and steel trade report activity which is exceptional at this season of the year. "Usually at this time," says The Iron Age, "when the efficiency of labor is reduced by the hot weather, the majority of rolling mills stop for repairs and stock taking. This year every wheel must be kept turning to satisfy customers."

MANCHESTER-BY-THE-SEA, Mass., July 18. -- Manchester for the long-contemplated and elaborately planned celebration of the two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the incorporation of the town. At sunrise the bells rang and guns volleyed a salute. Early trains brought large crowds of visitors, and the country around poured its population into the town by every kind of conveyance, until the streets swarmed with the multitude.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18. -- J.M. Baldwin, the fast Newark rider, has been suspended from Class A, pending an investigation by the Racing Board. Baldwin competed last at the National meet at Asbury Park. He won the half-mile handicap from a fine field, thus qualifying to ride in "The New-York Times Winners' Race," which took place at Asbury Park Monday. The suspension of Baldwin is the chief item in this week's bulletin of the Racing Board.
WASHINGTON, July 18. --Commissioner of Indian Affairs Browning has telegraphed the following orders to Indian agents near the scene of the trouble with the Bannock Indians:

WASHINGTON, July 18. -Contemporaneously with the announcement that the Spanish Cabinet has agreed to pay the Mora claim the Treasury Department has issued orders to the revenue marine to act with increased vigilance in guarding the South Atlantic coast, to prevent filibustering expeditions for Cuba departing from our shores, and to protect our southern seaport towns from the introduction of yellow fever from Cuba.

One of the most formidable arguments used by the silver men is that the United States and all gold-standard countries are at a great disadvantage in competition with silver-standard countries. We call this argument formidable because it is almost the only one on that side that has the air of being scientific and because it gives what appears a broad basis for a policy essentially narrow.

THURSDAY -- P.M. There was little that was interesting in to-day's stock market. The bear combination sold some of the industrial stocks in the early trading, then bought them back, and in the last hour put them out again. Their operations bore strong resemblance to "washing," the evident object being to cause depression without the loss of any material amount of stock.

The Times yesterday contained an authentic exposition of the woes of barkeepers in the present state of affairs that was calculated to touch every feeling heart. It is not likely to win many sympathizers, however, for among the sympathetic classes, and especially in ostentatiously and professionally sympathetic circles, the line is commonly drawn at barkeepers.
Commissioner Parker sat in judgment at the trials of delinquent policemen yesterday at Police Headquarters. The calendar was an unsusally heavy one, there being ninety-nine complaints.

NEWARK, N.J., July 18. -- The police in the hill section of this city for some time past have had complaints made to them nearly every day that a gang of burglars was operating in that part of the city. An investigation was made, but it was not until last night that they secured any clue to the culprits.

There was a meeting of the Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge yesterday afternoon for the purpose of filling the position of Treasurer at a salary of $4,000 a year, which was formerly held by Edward Clark, a brother of ex-Corporation Counsel Clark of this city. Edward Clark's resignation was accepted at the previous meeting of the board.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 18. -- The bimetallists of Georgia met in convention at Griffin to-day. Every part of the State was represented. Senator John T. Morgan of Alabama made the speech of the day. Resolutions calling for the immediate and independent free coinage of silver and gold were adopted, and an address to the people of the State was prepared.

SAGINAW, Mich., July 18. -- Liberal as was the patronage at the first three days of the Grand Circuit meeting, the attendance this afternoon surpassed it. The big grand stand was packed, and over 6,000 people were on the grounds. They saw Robert J. pace the fastest mile that has been covered this year, when he turned the track in 2:03.

Madeline Braguglia Troy, the daughter of Raymondo Braguglia of the firm of Braguglia Carreno, restaurant keepers at 13 Broadway, has brought an action in the Superior Court for a separation from her husband, John Joseph Troy, who is in the employ of the Commercial Cable Company.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18. -- The principal development in the Pietzel case to-day was the appearance upon the scene of a witness who is to prove an alibi for Holmes on the charge of murdering the two children in Toronto. The witness refused to give his name or to tell where he is staying in this city.

" Dave" Carmine, John Linde, Thomas McKenna, James Durkee, Frank Carr, and Sarah Ryan, alleged counterfeiters, were arraigned before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday. Carr's correct name is said to be Manning.
GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., July 18. -- The Republican District Convention here to-day resulted in a split and the nomination of two candidates for member of the Assembly.

TORONTO, July 18. -- Mrs. Pietzel, mother of the two children believed to have been murdered by Holmes, the insurance swindler, arrived here from Chicago at 9 o'clock this evening. She had not been recognized by her fellow travelers, though several ladies, noticing her dress of deep black and her mournful face, had entered into conversation with her.

ST. LOUIS, July 18. -- The Democratic State Convention, which will be held at Pertle Springs Aug. 6, undoubtedly will declare for the free coinage of silver and the sixteen to one ratio. The silver men, having a majority in the State Committee, at the meeting here last Monday determined to take a snap judgment on the Democrats of Missouri on the great National question of the day.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 18. -- The best regatta in the history of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen closed this afternoon with one of those exciting finishes between eight-oared shells that set oarsmen wild with delight. It even stirred the blood in the veins of landsmen who can't tell the difference between a "pair oar" and "double sculls."

Gen. Campos is now in a position to speak with knowledge of the fighting abilities of the Cuban rebels. At last he has encountered his despised antagonists face to face, and though there are conflicting accounts as to the results of the battle, yet it was evidently severe enough to convince the old Marshal that a state of war really exists.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 19. -- Gov. Morrill is in receipt of a communication from Assistant Secretary of State Uhl informing him that he had received a communication from C. Raven, sexton of the Roman Catholic Church at Uithuizen, Province of Groingen, Holland, informing him that Dr. Fraker, who is wanted by several American life insurance companies, is in that country, and that he can furnish information that will lead to his arrest.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 19. -- The closing exercises of the Sunday School and Chautauqua Assembly were held today. The feature of the day was the parade of the graduates, flower girls, Faculty, and members of the Ocean Grove Association around the camp grounds, and to and from the beach.

At the special meeting of the Fire Commissioners yesterday, Attorney Martin M. Hollister, a Republican, whose office is at 206 Broadway, was appointed Fire Marshal in place of James Mitchel, dismissed. The salary of the office was fixed at $3,000 a year.

SAGINAW, Mich., July 19. -- After five days of capital racing with the card cleared up on time every afternoon it was expected that the Grand Circuit Meeting would come to an end, as the free-for-all trot was one of the three regular events, and Alix was to be exhibited. The attendance kept up as before, over 5,000 persons being present.

ST. CLAIR, Mich., July 19. -- A fierce windstorm, accompanied by a heavy rainfall, burst upon this city soon after 1 o'clock this afternoon. For several weeks prayers have been offered in this vicinity for rain. The storm was cyclonic in fury, and before it ceased a child had been killed, two men injured, and much property destroyed.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Willis L. Moore, chief of the Weather Bureau, announces in a circular isued to-day further proposed improvements in the service rendered by the bureau. The monthly weather review, he says, will be issued not later than forty-five days after the close of the month for which it is a record, instead of six months after, as it is now issued.

The Myrale Avenue Police Court, Brooklyn, was again crowded yesterday morning, when Justice Haggerty called the case of the People vs. William Starr Henry, who is accused of the murder of his father, Charles W. Henry, the aged miser, at 95 South Portland Avenue, Brooklyn, on June 14.

These two stories, though separate and distinct, have the same characteristics. In them Balzac, who knew everything, and who had explored every social field, describes the criminal class in France, and for a type he selects Vautrin, and never has such a Napoleonic figure been drawn. For courage, combined with subtlety, for quickness of perception, for ability in changing himself according to his surroundings, Vautrin never had an equal.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 19. -- The Elmira Tennis Club began an invitation round robin tournament for doubles only here this afternoon. Among the four teams invited are players from New-York, Boston, Chicago, Detroit, Brooklyn, and Elmira. Each of the teams will meet the other three, and the matters will be finished tomorrow. To-day's scores follows:

Frederick Sterling Massey, who at one time was one of the best-known men in political life in Brooklyn, died yesterday morning at 18 East Twenty-eighth Street, this city, having some months ago moved from his Brooklyn home in order to be near his physician. Heart disease was the cause of death.

TORONTO, July 19. -- The inquest into the death of the Pietzel children was resumed this evening. Mrs. Pietzel, though still very weak and agitated, had during the day ventured to go to the morgue where the dead bodies of her supposed children are lying, and had satisfied herself of their identity.

The mind of Robert Tong of the Ninth Ward has been relieved. For weeks he has been bothered about a flock of ducks which he owns and is very proud of. Everybody knows "Bob" Tong. He keeps a meat shamble, and as a means of diversion is a poultry fancier on a small scale.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- The answer filed by Hilary A. Herbert, Secretary of the Navy, to the rule issued by Judge Bradley of the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia upon the petition of John N. Quackenbush, formerly a Commander in the navy, reveals facts not hitherto generally known in connection with this unique and somewhat famous controversy.

Superintendent and Chief Engineer C.C. Martin of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge was again on the witness stand yesterday before the sub-committee of the Assembly Committee of Cities, which is investigating the management of the bridge, in Part II. of the Superior Court. He was interrogated by James King Duffy, counsel to the committee.

Royalty has departed from Greenwich Street, and with it has gone all that riot of color which has for a few days made bright that thoroughfare. The gypsy band that invaded it Wednesday went its way yesterday. That way led down Rector Street, and up West to the Cortlandt Street Ferry.

" I have known the Rev. Hugh Montgomery for twenty-five years," says Dr. Dorchester, in his introduction to Mr. Montgomery's little book. "He is one of the liveliest of Irishmen. Witty, quaint, eccentric, but, withal, tender, gentle, and persistent; as devoted to humanity as Wilberforce, as incessant in labor as Wesley, as abundant in resources as Gen. Grant, and as true to God as St. Paul."
The Defender and the Vigilant will have their first trial race over the Sandy Hook triangular course this morning at 11 o'clock.
Messrs. Slawson Hobbs have sold for Dr. John H. Burry, at $38,000, the four-story brownstone and brick dwelling 116 West Sixty-ninth Street, 21 by 60, with extension, by 100.5.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., July 19. -- State Officer A.J. Kilbride, who was sent to Brookhaven to arrest William Egbert Sweezy and take him to the Asylum for the Insane at Middletown, was mobbed by over 100 of Brookhaven's leading citizens at midnight Wednesday, and now State officials say the whole mob will be prosecuted at once.

Arthur C.K. Newsam, formerly a Warden and Magistrate on the Island of Trinidad, who was arrested several days ago at his home, 325 Evergreen Avenue, Brooklyn, charged with having committed forgeries and embezzling funds to the amount of about $250,000, was before Commissioner Shields in the Federal Building yesterday on extradition proceedings.
KINGSTON, July 19. -- It is a pretty well-established fact that another filibustering expedition has either landed in Cuba, or is hovering off the coast, awaiting an opportunity to land.
BALTIMORE, July 19. -- The proceedings of the second day of the Baptist Young People's Convention began with six sunrise prayer meetings in various parts of the city. They were largely attended.

LONDON, July 19. -- Chauncey M. Depew, of New-York, and his son, who arrived at Southampton yesterday on the American Line steamer Paris, are at the Savoy Hotel. Mr. Depew's private sitting room windows overlook the Thames. A number of vases with fresh flowers were in the room, which the sunlight made cheerful and bright.
ROCHESTER, July 19. -- The sub-committee of the State Democratic Committee has come and gone, and Monroe County Democrats now know just where they are at for the first time in many months.

What they are pleased to term racing was continued at the Aqueduct track yesterday, a few people making the trip out to the grounds for the sake of betting on the horses. Five of the six favorites had won on Thursday, and so the few spectators backed favorites yesterday, with the usual results. The favorites were all beaten, with one exception.

BOSTON, July 19. -- Harry G. Green, sixteen years old, who says he is a student at the University of Pennsylvania and claims to live in Harrisburg, was arrested this morning as he was reading in the parlor of the Hotel Vendome.

SHELTER ISLAND, July 19. -- The flagship Ramona weighed anchor at 7 o'clock this evening. A gun was fired. All the yachts in the harbor answered the salute, and the cruise of the combined squadron came to an end.

Undoubtedly the purpose of classifying cities in the new Constitution of this State was to facilitate their government under a uniform general charter for each class, though that was not absolutely required. Whether or not this would be practicable for cities of the first class differing so widely as New-York and Buffalo, there is nothing in the conditions of cities of the second class that makes different charters in the least necessary.

The question whether the public prefers strictly amateur cycle racing to racing by professionals, or vice versa, can be pretty well determined this afternoon. At the Manhattan Field track, under the auspices of the Riverside Wheelmen, there will be matinee contests by young men who race for the love of the sport and not for cash.

CHARLESTON, N.H., July 15. -- It is Ruskin who declares that architecture is the expression of a people's morality, that the ethical idea finds its unfading form in stone, growing and taking shape for all to understand under the unconscious hands of the workman, the instrument. The theory is fascinating.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 19. -- The cottage-renting season is not yet over. Mrs. J.A. Hamilton of New-York to-day leased the Pumpelly cottage, Gibbs Avenue, for the remainder of the season. This is the fourth rental of the week.

CHICAGO, July 19. -- Northern and Southern delegates to the silver conference, being held at the Auditorium Hotel, came near an open rupture this morning. At one time a split in the ranks seemed imminent over the desire of the Southern delegates to ignore the Bimetallic League. They maintained that the avowed purpose of the league was to assist the aspirations of its Presidential candidate, Joseph Sibley.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19. -- South American advices brought to-day by the steamer San Blas state that the south coast of Peru and the coast of Chile north of Valparaiso have been visited by a tidal wave, which has done a great deal of damage.

The memorial tribute to Mr. Daniel Ravenel, published for private distribution by the family, contains historical facts of curious interest and value but recently brought to light by the investigations of the indefatigable and accomplished author. Witness the following extract:
J.E. Graybill, Commissioner for New-York State to the International Cotton Exposition at Atlanta, Ga., has made the following statement for the information of the business men of this city and State:
STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 19. -- The men of the Twelfth Regiment and the separate companies find that the routine of life in camp is not productive of laziness.

Traces of the struggle for the Tammany leadership of three Assembly districts appeared at the meeting of the Executive Committee of Tammany yesterday afternoon. The trouble at the meetings to elect Inspectors for the primaries in the Eighth, Eleventh, Nineteenth, and Thirty-third Districts was aired by the friends of the various would-be leaders, and protests were filed from three of these districts.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 19. -- Social gayety to-night centred on board William K. Vanderbilt's yacht, the Valiant. Mrs. R.H. Townsend of Washington, D.C., gave a dinner this evening in honor of Mr. Vanderbilt, after which the party adjourned to the Valiant to join the company of invited guests already there.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- It is stated that one of the matters which Third Assistant Secretary Rockhill of the State Department, will investigate in his trip abroad to inspect the Consular Service is the peculiar condition of things which prevails in the Consulate at Tangier, Morocco. At the instigation of The New-York Times an investigation was had a few years ago as to abuses of the protege system which prevails there.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19. -- The wide publicity given to the Pietzel murder case has brought out the "crank," and it is to this genius that the stranger who visited the office of Holmes's counsel yesterday belongs.

The Excise Board yesterday definitely announced its policy in regard to all-night licenses. No licenses of this kind are to be granted to saloons. They will be issued only for balls, picnics, and like occasions.

The number of near relations by blood or marriage in the new Administration is interesting. We have a father and son, Mr. Chamberlain and Mr. Austen Chamberlain; a father-in-law and a son-in-law, Lord Salisbury and Lord Selborne; two brothers, Messrs. Arthur and Gerald Balfour; an uncle and two nephews, Lord Salisbury and the Messrs Balfour, and two brothers-in-law, Lord George Hamilton and Lord Lansdowne.

The General Term of the Superior Court, Presiding Justice Van Brunt, and Justices O'Brien and Stover, heard argument yesterday upon the appeal taken by Augustus M. Field of the Town of Westchester from the recent order made by Justice Patterson denying the application for a mandamus to direct the Board of Aldermen of this city to reconvene and reapportion the Assembly districts of the City and County of New-York.
Thirty thousand rotten watermelons that had been upward of three weeks in transit from Georgia plantations were sold yesterday at the pier of one of the Southern steamship lines.

Notwithstanding the evidence of discord that appears wherever a Republican meeting is held or politicians of the party give vent to their "views," it would be difficult to state any "issue" on which the party is divided in this State. Differences seem to have nothing to do with any principle or policy, but are caused entirely by the question of "control" in the organized action of the party.

Nearly 200 young men and women were admitted yesterday by the General Term of the Supreme Court, sitting in this city, to the practice of law. On only one or two other occasions have so many persons been admitted to the bar in this city at one time. The interesting feature of the ceremony was the taking of the statutory oath by Miss Rosalie Loew and Miss Minnehaha Love McKinley Smith.

We recently directed attention to the successful attempts of the authorities in Brazil and Argentina to suppress incipient epidemics of Asiatic cholera in those countries. A few years ago infection introduced at Buenos Ayres from Italy caused an epidemic which spread throughout the southern half of the continent, and the total number of deaths was not less than 30,000.

A horseless carriage propelled by electricity is one of the latest novelties enjoyed by the thoughtful inhabitants of Boston. The new carriage is not a toy, but a vehicle weighing 5,100 pounds and carrying six or seven passengers.

PITTSBURG, July 19. -- At 1:30 o'clock this afternoon the press train, consisting of engine, combination car, and three coaches, all tastefully decorated with flags and bunting, left on the Pittsburg and Lake Erie Road for a record-breaking run to Cleveland. It is the intention to complete the journey inside of three hours. There were on board about 100 passengers and invited guests, and the officers and contestants of the inter-State bicycle race.

Interest in the alcohol rebate paragraph of the new Tariff act is revived on account of the published statement that certain persons have decided to ask the courts to compel a payment of the rebates, and now we shall see numerous references in the Republican papers to what some of them, a few months ago, called "the stupid mistake of the Democrats."

Republican leaders see so much trouble ahead in making up their State ticket and outlining the nature of the fight for this year that they are afraid of the early State convention, of which so much was said a few weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- General Master Workman Sovereign of the Knights of Labor has issued a circular letter, or manifesto, to the members of that organization, as well as to kindred organizations throughout the country, having in view the establishment of a boycott upon all National bank notes.

ALBANY, July 19. -- The commission appointed by Gov. Morton to recommend to the next Legislature a uniform charter for cities of the second class -- between 50,000 and 250,000 inhabitants -- will begin active work about Sept. 1.
WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Secretary Olney arrived suddenly and unexpectedly in Washington to-day, and summoned a council of those Cabinet officers now in town, which lasted for two hours.

There is no difficulty in assigning causes for the Liberal defeat in England. The party is indeed in the condition of the woman who was murdered the other day, and of whom the doctor who was summoned declared that any one of a dozen wounds she had received was necessarily fatal.
Beast, bird, fish, or fowl?"

ALBANY, July 19. -- On July 1, 1895, the trust companies, abstracts of whose reports on that hate are here given, had aggregate resources of $147,967,319. This is nearly $8,100,000 more than the same companies reported on Jan. 1, 1895, when the total of the resources was $139,869,867. The surplus, in the aggregate of these companies on July 1 was $19,334,032, while on Jan 1 it was $19,359,735.

SAYVILLE, L.I., July 19. -- Francis Ulrich, nineteen years old, fell overboard from a sloop near Islip last night and was drowned. The vessel is owned by Capt. Isaac Green. He was cooking supper in the cabin, and left the boy on deck cleaning clams. The Captain went on deck to call Ulrich and saw his hat and a pail floating in the water.
LONDON, July 18. -- Up to midnight the returns from the elections were as follows:
The reform Police Board made a vigorous beginning yesterday in the work of reorganizing the Detective Bureau at Headquarters.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 19. -- George Hufcut of Dover Plains, a former well-known farmer of that place, brother of ex-District Attorney Horace D. Hufcut of this city, whose mysterious disappearance in New-York in April 1894, excited so much interest, is reported to have been found at Montpelier, Vt., where he is sick, and is being cared for by a Masonic lodge.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Secretary Lamont has authorized the expenditure of $1,000 to allow the five companies of infantry at Columbus Barracks, Ohio, to march to Fort Thomas, Ky., to engage in their annual target practice. The distance is about 130 miles. The command will make the journey in about ten days each way.

Secretary Lamont says that he did not talk politics and did not see any politicians during his Western tour. He was on business, he said, and his business was with military people, and they are well known not to be politicians. He said he had not read the story sent out from San Francisco attributing to him a political motive in his trip.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 20. NOTWITHSTANDING the stormy weather, the last week has been a merry one among the Summer guests at this resort. There have been numerous dinner parties and receptions given by cottage residents.
SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 20. -- The Seabright Challenge Cup for single-handed tennis was won for the third and last time by the Summit expert, W.A. Larned, who is now its owner.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 20. -- MERRY days are at hand at last. There is not a cottager in all Newport who is not kept on the continual go. There will be no rest until October, at least. The Country Club's commodious and picturesque clubhouse is the Mecca of society.

No doubt the changes already made and yet to be made in the personnel of the Detective Bureau at the Police Headquarters are determined by the relative merits of the officers transferred, but they appear also to be part of a plan for reforming the methods of the detective service.

There is an old gentleman in this city who recently retired from active business life after having been connected with one banking house for nearly sixty years. He was born in New-York in 1813, and has always lived here. His memories of old New-York, the semi-village of fifty years ago, are most vivid.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 20. -- The Rev. Dr. Burns of Hamilton occupied the chair at the Pan-American Congress this morning. Mrs. Jane Adams of Hullhouse, Chicago, delivered an address upon the settlement idea. She explained that the term meant a group of persons in good circumstances who settle in an industrial and depressed district in the city and exert all the good they can.
There is a glut in the watermelon market. Along the North River front there were probably 50,000 melons lying yesterday afternoon for which no purchasers could be had.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20. -- The City Council passed an ordinance last Winter requiring the different street railway companies to equip their trolley cars with fenders. The ordinance fixed a date for all trolley cars to be so equipped, and imposed a penalty of $10 a day for non-compliance after the time specified.

BALTIMORE, July 20. -- The third day of the convention of the Baptist Young People's Union of America began with sunrise prayer meetings in several Baptist churches at 6:30 o'clock this morning. They were conducted by prominent out-of-town clergymen and were well attended.
WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Commissioner General Stump to-day telegraphed Immigrant Commissioner Bethel, at Tampa, Fla., to at once deport the seven Cuban cigarmakers now in his custody to Cuba.
ARVERNE-BY-THE-SEA, L.I., July 20. LIFE at Arverne continues to be decidedly worth the living. Cool breezes, pretty scenery, and comfort are some of the many attractions to entice one to remain here.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., July 20. AT this resort the week has been characterized by the usual round of gayety and amusements at the New Point, and the boatmen especially have been kept busy in supplying accommodations for the various fishing and sailing parties, which have amused themselves on the bay and outside Fire Island Inlet.

HUNTER, N.Y., July 20. -- More than usually backward is the opening of the social season in the Catskills. The many guests of the hotels seem to devote most of their time to riding, driving, and wheeling over the fine roads in the mountains. Saturday night hops are features at nearly all the large hotels, but, as yet, only a few teas and dinners have been given.
STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL., N.Y., July 20. -- The Twelfth Regiment and separate companies had warm weather for breaking camp this morning.

GREENPORT, L.I., July 20. SUMMER girls with their bicycles and bloomers have invaded Greenport, and the result is that the quiet, unassuming maidens of this village have shocked their mothers by taking to the new style of costume.

WILLET'S POINT, L.I., July 20. -- Not the least interesting of the many institutions of the United States Engineer Battalion here is the quaint looking little schoolhouse on the hill. It is here that the soldiers' children are educated. Their instructor is Sergt. James Reardon of Company A.

It is 8:30 o'clock in the morning. A compactly built young man, slightly above the medium size, plainly dressed in black clothes, turns into Mulberry Street from Bleecker. He walks sturdily, and there is a spring in his gait. Through his gold-rimmed eyeglasses he looks up and down and all around him. His movements are alert, but without any suggestion of nervousness.

LAKE RONKONKOMA, L.I., July 20. SO far this season, Lake Ronkonkoma has been an orderly and well-behaved body of water. Sometimes it overflow its banks and spoils the pleasure of the Summer visitors, but that occurs only once in seven years, and this happens not to be one of the years.

The National meet at Asbury was barely over before there was talk of next year's meet and the best place for holding it. Four cities jumped for the bait, but, of course, it was only a preliminary jump, for nobody will know which town gets it until the next National Assembly. Boston is in the field, and the other cities which want it are Syracuse, Toledo, and Columbus.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 20. -- At Kebo last Saturday was inaugurated the first of a series of golf tournaments which are to extend throughout the entire season. Mr. A.H. Hinkle, with a handicap of 40, succeeded in obtaining first prize. Mr. George Pendleton Bowles of New-York was second, while J.A. Tyng, the most famous of Harvard's baseball pitchers, was third.

Liverpool has faced with great energy the rivalry created in Manchester by the Ship Canal and at Southampton as an American traffic port, by bringing the railway terminus to the Prince's Dock, where the Atlantic liners anchor.

The aim of this book is to help those whose religious doubts trouble them, and to indicate to those who desire to overcome the doubts of others how they best may set to work to do it. The author starts with the proposition that the Christian religion is a matter of faith. Those who embrace it must take something on trust. Its truths may not be demonstrated.

The "shake-up" in the Detective Bureau at Police Headquarters was forgotten yesterday in preparations for another bout with the saloon keepers to-day, and Acting Chief Conlin laid plans to make a new record on "dry" Sundays.

Hand in hand with the love of classical old furniture, cherished by our ancestors for its beauty of design, artistic perfection, stability, and associations, goes the affection for old china and those wonderful productions of Delft, Holland. Furniture and ancestral portraits were most loved and cherished by the lord of the manor -- the china was dearest to the heart of the lady.
BAYONNE, N.J., July 20. -- Mr. and Mrs. Seaman Alaire of Avenue E have returned to their Summer home at Liberty Falls, N.Y.
SUMMIT, N.J., July 20. -- The members of St. Teresa's Total Abstinence Society enjoyed an excursion to Coney Island Thursday.

FIRE ISLAND, L.I., July 20. THERE has been no cessation in the round of pleasure at this place during the week. There has been something each evening to entertain the guests, and everybody says that Fire Island is keeping up its reputation as a resort where dullness is an entire stranger.
