One of the industries which languished during the recent period of depression was the manufacture and sale in the United States of ancient "unclaimed" or "undistributed" estates alleged to exist in England, Holland, Germany, or some other country on the other side of the Atlantic.

The present strike of the clothing makers against the "sweatshops" and the contractors is only an acute phase of a chronic trouble. The trouble is the oversupply of hands in this and allied industries. On the one hand it is contended that the workmen cannot live in comfort or decency on what they can earn.

Mayor Strong came home from his vacation at Richfield Springs yesterday. In the three weeks and more that he has been away he has gained some flesh, coated his face with a healthy tan, and succeeded in almost driving away his old enemy, the gout.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 29. -- The Arthur Kill Boat Club, which collapsed a couple of months ago owing to financial difficulties, has been reorganized on a sound financial basis by the older members of the club. The articles of its Incorporation were filed to-day with the Clerk of Union County.

DENVER, Col., July 29. -- The Union Bank suspended to-day and is in the hands of the Government. The County Treasurer's office was closed this morning, Bankers Moffett, Cooper, and McIntosh withdrawing from Treasurer Wygant's bond of $500,000. The failure of the Union affects no other Denver bank. It was a comparatively small affair.
ALLENTOWN, Penn., July 29. -- The spectacle of an heir to a large fortune carrying pig iron as a vagrant in the jail was presented here to-day.

It was the general opinion about Police Headquarters yesterday that Acting Chief Conlin will be appointed Chief of the department, and that the Acting Inspectors will be retained in their present positions.

OCEAN GROVE, July 29. -- The rules for the government of this Methodist resort are made by the Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Association, and, like the laws of the Medes and Persians, are unalterable. One of the rules prohibits the sale of cigars and tobacco within the association's territory. This rule has been violated in past seasons by the hotel keepers, who furnished their guests with cigars and cigarettes.
About a dozen members of the Republican State Committee were in this city last night, having come to attend the meeting which will be held at noon to-day at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., July 29. -- Passed East -- Steam yachts Embla, John H. Hanan; Alicia, H.M. Flagler; Halcyon, Howard C. Smith; Tillie, W.H. Starbuck; Theresa, Gustavus Sidenberg; Golden Rod, Archil ld Watt; Trophy, Edwin H. Bennett; Durgeness, Mrs. Lucy Carnegie; Rival, Francis F. Chrystie; Lorna, M.L. Stowe, and Emeline, Stephen J, Roach.

NEWARK, N.J., July 29. -- Deputy Revenue Collector Joseph F. Cavanagh successfully raided yesterday an illicit still, situated at 36 Union Street, Lodi, kept by a Pole named Abraham Sattenstine. The Collector started Saturday night through the woods to find the still. He walked all night through the storm. When he had located the moonshiners' hiding-place he returned to Newark for a rest and a change of clothing.

Whenever a vessel goes ashore on some out-of-the-way part of the coast, either in this country or Europe, it is almost invariably reported, a few weeks or months later, that the people living in that vicinity boarded the wreck, and stripped it of everything valuable -- in many cases of everything conveniently portable.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- The effects of the British occupation of Egypt are discussed in an interesting manner by Frederick C. Penfield, Agent and Consul of the United States at Cairo, in a dispatch to the State Department. The document presents some facts not generally known, and which indicate that British rule is not an unalloyed blessing. Mr. Penfield says:

LONDON, July 29. -- The Daily News, in mentioning to-morrow that the Pope has concluded an important work intended to be a programme to secure social order, says that before publishing the work his Holiness will ask for the opinions on it of eminent German, Swiss, Italian, and English sociologists.

A mass meeting of colored Republicans, under the auspices of the Colored Republican Association of the State of New-York, was held in the Zion Church, Bleecker and West Tenth Streets, last night. About 200 persons were present.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 29. -- Capt. Willard Thompson of this city, General Manager of the Baltimore, Chesapeake and Atlantic Railroad, has received a letter from the agents of 500 Dutch settlers who will locate on the Peninsula, announcing that they have decided to settle in Dorchester County, Md., on the Nanticoke River. The settlers will come direct from Holland.

The Police Board is "going up higher" in its determination to fix the responsibility in the department for whatever failure still exists in the enforcement of the Sunday excise law. The Captains are now to suffer directly for laxity on the part of their force. President Roosevelt said yesterday:

The statistics published from time to time by the London journals of the grain trade point to interesting tendencies and facts which American producers should not overlook. The growing movement of wheat at low prices from Russia and Argentina has bean indicated by reports to which we have heretofore directed attention.

The Grand Jury began an investigation yesterday into the escape from Ludlow Street Jail of Killoran, Allen, and Russell, who were under arrest on charges of having robbed the Post Office in Hoboken, N.J.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 29. -- The dance to-night was a great success. Mrs. John Jacob Astor undoubtedly was the most handsomely dressed lady on the floor. She wore a beautiful Nile green satin gown, cut decolletee, with a crimson belt. Miss Blight, one of Mrs. Astor's guests on board the Nourmahal, was dressed in black satin and diamonds. Mrs. Lawrence Lee of New-York wore a gown of lavender.

The Cunarder Aurania, which sailed from Liverpool July 20, and which should have arrived at this port yesterday morning, has had a mishap of some sort. Whatever the disability is, Capt. McKay did not see fit to confide its nature to any of the incomers who yesterday arrived and told of having sighted the Cunarder disabled at sea.

CHICAGO, July 29. -- Another arrest has been made in the Holmes case. H.S. Mack is now in the custody of the police. He worked for Holmes during the last six months Holmes lived in the Sixty-third Street house. The police have been looking for him since Friday, and they admit that they have the most important witness they have yet rounded up.

LONDON, July 29. -- At the general meeting of the International Geographical Congress in the Central Hall of the Imperial Institute to-day there was a greater number of women than of men. Dr. G. Neumayer delivered an address on Arctic exploration the necessity for which he urged very strongly. He expressed admiration for Admiral Markham and his works.

MADRID, July 29. -- An official dispatch from Manila says: "A treacherous attack was recently made upon the Spanish troops at Cabagan, in the Province of Cagayan, in the extreme northern part of the Island of Luzon.

BOSTON, July 9. -- A large company of colored women assembled in Berkeley Hall this forenoon. It was a notable gathering in many respects, and it was called for the purpose of establishing a National Conference of the Colored Women of America, the first movement of the kind ever attempted.

Charles Johnson, known also as Louis Gerard and "French Louis," the safe burglar, who escaped from United States Deputy Marshals Biggart and Lewis while on the way to Kansas several weeks ago, was arrested in Louisville, Ky., Sunday.

The fleet which will soon be assembled for the Summer drill and exercises will be the most formidable ever gathered under the United States flag. The manoeuvres will be relatively important. The officers who are charged with formulating plans for the fleet have maintained much reticence about the matter, and until yesterday it was not definitely known in which direction the flagship would lay her bow after sailing from this port.

John K. Van Ness of Plainfield, N.J., the lawyer who, after being accused of forgery, jumped his bail three times when the time for his trial came, was arrested yesterday at his home, on a warrant charging him with being a fugitive from justice, and brought to this city.

H. Ryan Co. That is the name of a new firm that has recently arisen above the business horizon of Brooklyn. The firm has a plain, old-fashioned name, and it might be supposed that its members are ordinary business men, and H. Ryan a comfortable, middle-aged capitalist, dropping occasionally into a capacious factory to give his partners the benefit of his advice as well as of his money.
The trial of Policeman Ambrose Hussey of the East Twenty-second Street Station, who is charged with oppression and tyranny, was resumed yesterday before Police Commissioner Grant.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., July 29. -- The king of Long Island snakes has been seen in this place again. This time the monster gave chase to I.W. Valentine, Superintendent of the Baptist Sunday School in this place. The reptile, which is reported to be about twelve feet long, and as thick around as an ordinary water pail, chased Mr. Valentine through the woods.

SALT LAKE, July 29. -- A reliable gentleman jst arrived at Ogden from the neighborhood of Jackson's Hole reports a fight between Indians and settlers at a point fifty miles from Jackson's Hole, Friday, in which three whites and ten or fifteen Indians were killed and one white man very badly wounded.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29. -- According to "a close friend," H.H. Holmes gives this version of the death of B.F. Pietzel. On the Saturday night preceding the death of Pietzel, he called on Holmes at a house on North Eleventh Street. Pietzel was greatly downcast and told a heartrending story of his pecuniary difficulties and of the sickness of his daughter in St. Louis.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 29. -- Justice Goldilg was visited this morning by the Rev. H.G. Jordan of the Wrightstown Colored Methodist Episcopal Church, who asked for warrants for the arrest of a number of the congregation of his church. The Minister said that he had been attending a conference and that he had telegraphed the official board of his church that he would be back in time to preach last night.

Police Inspector John Mackellar of Brooklyn and his staff of detectives have been busily at work trying to find the two men who lured Dr. George Drury of 115 Johnson Street into the unoccupied house at 67 Nevins Street, Saturday afternoon, and robbed him of his jewelry and money. Although a dozen clues have been worked upon, yet the police have not succeeded as yet in making an arrest.
LONDON, July 29. -- The returns now at hand show the election of:

A correspondent writes: The scientific truism, that in chemical composition the product his quite different properties from the substances of which it was composed, must be supposed to apply to political as well as genuine chemistry, and points to Coalition Ministries being generally destined to an early and unexpected death. Sir E. May details three Coalition Ministries as having distinguished English history from 1760 to 1870.

The first endeavors permitted me in the way of selling goods were in connection with the calico counter. This was situated at the right of the main entrance, and the critical dame or cautious girl who came in search of bargains had from seventy-five to a hundred pieces and patterns from which to make selections.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., July 29. -- Two white-throated black snakes made a portion of the afternoon lively for three city young men and Mrs. Charles Cochrane and Miss Nellie Rogers, who were out rowing on a stream that flows from Patchogue Lake. The three men were at the head of the stream, near the marsh, on the east side.

OTTAWA, July 29. -- Prof. Wiggins, in an interview to-day on the causes of the drought and low water in the lakes and rivers, says: "One cause is that the rivers that drain them are constantly wearing the earth away and gaining a deeper bed. But the chief cause is the constant decrease in rainfall on the southern half of the continent.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 29. -- The fight to-day against Gormanism in Maryland has reached the stage of a death struggle, which will only end with the convention here Wednesday. The friends of Judge Fisher, who has come to the front as the representative and champion of the anti-Gorman Democracy, opened headquarters this morning and hung out the sign, "Headquarters of the Cleveland Democracy."

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 29. -- There was another stupid day's racing at the track here to-day, and only a very bad lot of horses started, and but a very few people were at the track to see them run.

CLEVELAND, July 29. -- After two weeks of lively work with the light harness steppers in Michigan, the Grand Circuit carnival was resumed at the famous Glenville track here to-day. The three classes for the opening were all for trotters, and none of them was fast. The price of admission was reduced one-half, and this, with the special programme of bicycle races, brought some 5,000 people to the grounds.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, July 29. -- One of the greatest day's sport of the season was seen at the National circuit race meet of the Big Four Cycle Club in this city to-day. Mansfield is the home of Clinton R. Coulter, known as the transcontinental tourist, owing to his having left this city last Summer for a tour by wheel to San Francisco.
Mr. F.R. Carter, who is in the bicycle and sewing-machine business, confirms the report that his wife, Ellen Carter, is now the heir to property worth about $500,000.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- In the retirement of Col. William Winthrop, Assistant Judge Advocate General, which takes place Friday of this week, the army will lose the services of an able and conscientious officer. For more than thirty years Col. Winthrop has been connected with the office of the Judge Advocate General, serving in the first years under Judge Advocate General Joseph Holt. From 1886 to 1890 he was Professor of Law at West Point.
Three favorites won races at the Brighton Beach track yesterday, rank outsiders winning the first two events on the card.

Nine hundred Lithuanians joined the great strike of the tailors of New-York and vicinity yesterday. Both the strikers and the contractors held meetings in this city and expressed a determination to keep up the fight.

Wall Street was treated to a surprise yesterday when it was announced that the Morgan-Belmont bond syndicate had made good the recent withdrawals from the Treasury gold reserve by the deposit of $2,000,000 in exchange for greenbacks. The news came out only a few minutes before the close of the stock market. It gave a fresh impulse to prices, and the day ended with the bullish feeling even more assertive than it had been.

A writer for The Philadelphia Press who has recently recalled some interesting characteristics of Roscoe Conkling falls into error in representing that famous and impressive Republican leader as being averse to the reputation of preparing his speeches. The writer represented Mr. Conkling as being especially sensitive to reports of this kind, as imputations upon his power as an orator.
I had dreamed of and longed for a trip to Alaska for several years, and at last had a full realization of my dreams on the last trip of the steamer Queen.

A few weeks ago Gov. Atkinson put his foot on the threshold of death's door, and all the world, save a few friends, in whom hope founded on affection was stronger than reason, thought him about to enter in. But he did not. He was enabled to turn aside and enter again upon the path of active usefulness, along which he had been striding with so much vigor when disease struck him down.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, July 29. -- This was Governor's Day in camp, and the weather could not have been better. The early morning drill was platoon in extended order, and the forenoon drill was battalion in closed order.

The bosses of both parties count upon party fidelity -- the assurance that "regular" candidates will get the party vote, and so they use their machinery to control nominations, leaving party "loyalty " to do the rest. The only thing they have to fear is the independence of voters, and consequently there is nothing they so detest and affect to scorn.

KISSINGEN, July 29. -- The indignation here, particularly among the guests at the hotels, growing out of the arrest of Louis Stern of New-York, is increasing, and the action of Baron von Thuengen, Deputy Commissioner of the Spa, who caused the arrest, is strongly denounced as a highhanded outrage.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29. -- Cuban sympathizers were extremely cautious to-day in commenting on the report that a war ship has been secured by the insurgents and is now on its way to the rebellious island, the expectation being that the ship will reach the forbidden waters by to-morrow or Wednesday.

A peculiar result of the reform that has been instituted about the New-York Police Courts under the new administration is that a large number of "shyster" lawyers have been driven to seek small crumbs of practice about the County Court House.

Each Sunday's experience in the effort to enforce the excise law with rigid strictness in this city brings out more clearly the weak points of the present law and emphasizes the need of a change to make it completely enforceable.

Cholera infantum, the fatal scourge of children under three years of age, is not likely to cut as large a figure as usual in the total number of deaths in the city for the current year. Of this much Dr. Roger S. Tracy already feels sure, though the actual statistics are not yet separated from the mass of death certificates to show the comparative improvement of infantile health over the results of last year.

NEWARK, N.J., July 29. -- In the Chancery Chambers this morning Vice Chancellor Pitney heard an application of the Consolidated Traction Company to locate a crossing over the Watchung Railroad tracks on Bloomfield Avenue. The traction people want the crossing at grade, and the steam railroad company, through Cortlandt Parker, opposed the project.

Mrs. Mathilde Heinze and Oscar Heilman were arraigned before United States Commissioner Lyman yesterday on the charge of having poisoned Mrs. Heinze's husband last December in Sarnowko, Prussia. They were arrested in Philadelphia on the application of the German Government. Since their arrest the man and woman have been held in Ludlow Street Jail.

Mrs. Jennie Newman, wife of Joseph Newman, a barber, who lives at 337 Bridge Street, Brooklyn, told the police last night a story of being seized and dragged into a house and kept a prisoner more than thirty-six hours.

The Democratic Republican electors of the City and County of New-York are hereby notified that on Thursday, Aug. 1, 1895, between the hours of 7:30 and 9 o'clock P.M., primary elections will be held at the places and under the conditions hereinafter mentioned in the several Assembly districts, and they are hereby invited to participate therein.

Work is going on rapidly on the old Jefferson Davis mansion on North Twelfth Street, which is being remodeled for the ladies of the Confederate Museum Literary Society with a view of having it put back in exactly the same condition, or at least as nearly as possible, in which it was at the time of occupancy by President Davis and his family during the war.

The sale of seaside lots at Edgemere, between Arverne and Wave Crest, held on Saturday last by Messrs. Smyth Ryan, was very successful. In all, 130 lots were disposed of, in plots of not less than four, at a total of $61,865. The attendance was large and the bidding fairly good. Thirteen lots on the east side of Neptune Avenue, beginning at the beach, sold to George C. Taylor at $600 each.

The Police Magistrates held their regular monthly meeting last night at the Jefferson Market Building. The old Police Justices also tried to hold a meeting at the same place, but secured no quorum. Of the latter only Messrs. Ryan and Hogan were present, and after waiting on the steps for an hour, they went home, saying that they would be on hand again the last Monday night in next month.

HUNTINGTON HARBOR, L.I., July 29. -The yachts of the New-York Yacht Club started out on their annual cruise to the eastward to-day, after the meeting of the Captains on the flagship Sylvia. There were races in three classes for cups offered by Commodore E.M. Browne; one was for the cup defenders, one for schooners, in one class, and the third for sloops other than the big single-stickers.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 29. -- The Senate Committee on Fish and Game will leave New-York the evening of Aug. 15 for Watertown, from which place they will go to Toronto, and from there probably to Ottawa, Montreal, and Quebec, for the purpose of conferring with the Commissioners of Fisheries of Canada, to perfect an amicable arrangement which will operate as a protection to the fish which abound in the waters lying between the two countries.

WINNIPEG, July 29. -- Lord Aberdeen, Governor General of Canada, arrived here to-day and had a long conference with Sir John Schults, Governor of Manitoba. The subject of their conference was the perplexing parochial school question. Premier Greenway and several of his Ministers also conferred with Earl Aberdeen, but nothing can be learned of what took place at these conferences.

July 30, 1864, just thirty-one years ago, an engagement took place in front of Petersburg, Va., in which the losses in killed and wounded on the Union side, in proportion to the number of troops participating, were probably greater than in any other single battle during the civil war.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 29. -- The patronesses of the Casino subscription ball of Aug. 8 were announced to-day. They are Mrs. Brockholst Cutting, Mrs. John Clinton Gray, Mrs. F. Grand D'Hauteville, Mrs. Frederick Sheldon, Mrs. Victor Sorchan, Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Mrs. W. Fitzhugh Whitehouse, Mrs. Whitney Warren, and Mrs. Samuel F. Barger.

ALBANY, July 29. -- There was more political talk than usual at this time of year about the State offices to-day. The reason for this, no doubt, was the fact that a number of the Republican State Committeemen on their trip to New-York stopped off here.

YONKERS, July 29. -- Just as a gang of men quit work to-night on the Jackson Street sewer in this city, an embankment fifteen feet deep caved in, burying a number of the workmen. Pierre Contassio, thirty years old, of 40 Jefferson Street, was killed, and Dominico Federico, twenty-eight years old, of 175 Willow Street, died in the ambulance on the way to the hospital.
; NEWPORT, July 29. -- The former cud defender, Volunteer, arived here to-night, and I will await the arrlyal 'of the New-York

Quite a number of tropical nuts have recently been introduced into cultivation in this country. Already on the east coast of Florida are growing 250,000 cocoanut trees, 42,000 being on one plantation. It is believed that the first trees of this kind in the State sprouted from nuts brought from Central America and the West Indies by the Gulf Stream.

Ladies who ride cycles appear to be pretty evenly divided on the question whether a short skirt or knickerbocker is the most rational dress for their pastime, but an incident which occurred last night outside a newspaper office points to the suitability of the latter. There is a custom which is general here of carrying at night a paper Venetian lantern within the spokes of the wheel, instead of a regulation lamp.

BOSTON, July 29. -- The Massachusetts Benefit Life Association of this city was the first insurance company to unearth a series of frauds which were being practiced at Beaufort, N.C. This company, acting with others, has caused the arrest of ten persons on the charge of conspiracy. Among those arrested are several prominent citizens, including a minister and several physicians and agents who have heretofore represented the insurance companies defrauded.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- Senator Dubois of Idaho is not surprised at the trouble with the Bannocks. He says that the whites are entirely in the right. They contend that if they are not allowed to kill game out of season the same law should be enforced against the Indians.

Referee Henry H. Brewer, proprietor of a saloon at 178 Lincoln Avenue, was a prisoner in the Morrisania Court yesterday afternoon, charged with having sold a pint of beer to eleven-year-old Davis Healy of 527 East One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street last Saturday evening.

Police Commissioner Grant summoned before him at Headquarters yesterday Capt. Copeland and Sergts. Ivory and Brown of the police boat Patrol to hear what they had to say in answer to complaints made by the policemen doing duty on the boat that they didn't get enough to eat, and that the food supplied to them was of a poor quality.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 30. -- Cottagers had a quiet day, a violent rain and tempest in the middle of the afternoon seriously interfering with their plans.
Mayor Strong gripped the lever of the municipal engine yesterday morning, and before night the machinery which has been going only at vacation speed for three weeks was humming right briskly again.

Mrs. Jesse Mordaunt, founder of the Aged Ladies' Home for Gentlewomen, on the King's Bridge Road, near its junction with the William's Bridge Road, charged Mrs. Rose Ester, a former inmate of the home, in the Morrisania Court, yesterday, with being concerned in a conspiracy to kill her with poison.

The Defender was beaten to-day by the Vigilant, and in weather conditions that Mr. Iselin has claimed the new boat would romp right away from her. There was a strong wind and a heavy sea. It was on a broad reach, that is supposed to be the Defender's best point of sailing.

LONDON, July 30. -- Lord Salisbury presided over the Cabinet meeting which was held at the Foreign Office at noon to-day. The meeting was short, the business before it being confined to consideration of the Queen's speech, which, it is understood, is very brief and contains few if any recommendations.

Dr. Edward H. Peaslee, the School Commissioner, who lives at 29 Madison Avenue, declares that his sister, Fannie R. Peaslee, has such a weakness for stock gambling that she is not to be intrusted with a legacy for $10,000, left her for life by her mother, Martha K. Peaslee. The legacy is to revert to Dr. Peaslee in the event of his sister's death.

FLUSHING, N.Y., July 30. -- A bold attempt at robbery was made at the home of A.S. Post this morning. Mrs. Post and her family are in New-Hampshire, and the house is in charge of Mrs. James Kelly, during their absence. Mrs. Kelly and her daughter, Mrs. Charles Zeller, who is staying with her at the Post house, came down to the village to do some shopping this morning.
Deputy Sheriff Dunphy took charge of the Bartholdi Hotel, at Broadway and Twenty-third Street, yesterday, on executions for $17,169.

" Recreation plus education." That is what Dr. William Howe Johnan, the General Agent of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, says of the series of excursions of the vacation school children to the association's Seaside Home at West Coney Island, which Began yesterday.

ALBANY, July 30. -- The Clerk of the Court of Appeals said to-day that no notice of appeal has yet been filed from the judgment of the lower court sentencing Maria Barbella to be electrosecuted for the murder of her betrayer. The court will not meet until October, and if a notice of appeal is filed the arguments before the court of last resort will be heard next October, as capital cases have preference.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30. -- At the Wayfarers' Lodge, Lombard Street, homesick and destitute, are three negroes of Arkansas, who have just returned from Liberia, whither they went as colonists some months ago. Of nearly 100 companions in the expedition, some are said to have died of starvation, and others are eking out a wretched existence in Africa.

Police Commissioner Welles of Brooklyn will probably appoint an Inspector to succeed the late Inspector Reilly, and a Captain to fill the vacancy thus created. He declined yesterday to say who the fortunate men would be, but Capt. John Brennan is regarded as the probable Inspector. As Police Superintendent McKelvey and Inspector McLaughlin will start on their vacations to-day, the promotions may be announced this morning.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The cruiser Atlanta returned to Key West yesterday from another search after Cuban filibustering expeditions. A telegram announcing her return received at the Navy Department to-day was the first information given to the public by the Navy Department officials that she had been away from Key West.

The New-York Times banner, presented to the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs for the organization having the largest number of survivors in last Sunday's century run, will probably go to the Gramercy Wheelmen. They had twenty-seven starters and twenty-one survivors. The official count of the survivors will not be completed until this evening, but it will not change the result if the Gramercys had the number of survivors counted upon.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Secretary Herbert of the Navy Department has made a ruling, which, if generally adopted in the Government service, will materially decrease the attractions surrounding the position of private secretary.

ALBANY, July 30. -- Neither of the old-line political parties, in this city is in what may be called excellent shape for the Fall campaign. Of the two the Republican seems to be in the better condition to enter the arena. A month ago it was in much the worse order. But a political accident seemed to bring all factions but the Wilson reformers under the Barnes banner.
Oliver Sumner Teall, who paraded before the public in a bobtail coat as a political reformer until all prospect of obtaining an office for himself vanished, has put aside the mask.

While the contending Republican factions in the Empire State are more and more harshly condemning each other and are daily finding new causes for public dissatisfaction with all their factions, Democrats should be considering, calmly and seriously, the importance of suspending factional disputes for a season, and devote their energies to securing united party action at the polls.

STATE CAMP, Peekskill, July 30. -- The Twenty-second Regiment and the Sixty-ninth Battalion did some excellent work at the forenoon drill to-day. Their manoeuvres were like those of old soldiers, and were carried out without the need of any suggestions from the instructors.

CHICAGO, July 30. -- William Capps, the Forth Worth attorney who is here at the instance of the heirs of Minnie Williams, says that he is prepared to prove the murder of Minnie and Annie Williams. He insists that they were killed by Holmes, Quinian, Pietzel, and another man whose name he is not yet prepared to give.
DAYTON, Ohio, July 30. -- Five Class B races were run at the annual National circuit race meeting of the Dayton Bicycle Club at the fair grounds track to-day. No records fell, owing to the high wind.

SALT LAKE, Utah, July 30. -- The first reliable news of the Indian troubles at Jackson's Hole proper received for more than a week came by messenger this evening via Griggs, Idaho, from Fort Wilson, a little place in the centre of a valley in Jackson's Hole, over 100 miles from any railway.
The Saunterer is the victim of many woes. Imagine his conflicting emotions when reading the manuscript of contribution like the following:

The Republican State Committee held a meeting of ten minutes' duration yesterday and carried out the orders of the "boss" by deciding upon Saratoga as the place and Sept. 17 as the time for the State Convention and having nothing to say upon any possible issue of the coming campaign.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., July 30. -- Jayville, a village on the fringe of the Adirondack forest, above Carthage, has been the scene of the punishment of a woman, in a manner which has outraged decency.
-- Prof. Charles G.D. Roberts, the Canadian poet, has written a short popular history of Canada. Two years of work have been given to it.

The matches played yesterday in the Round Robin tennis tournament of the West Side Tennis Club brought the contest almost to a close. The tournament was given for the lesser lights in the club, Parker, E.P. Fischer, Bostwick, Worthington, and the other good players not having entered. Fennessy won a victory over Allen, who had hitherto been undefeated.

Mr. Theodore Roosevelt has a great deal to answer for, as he himself must be becoming aware. The defection of the German vote from the cause of reform will be, when it actually occurs, a matter for lamentation. But there is almost as much material for reflection in the extreme humidity of the suburban Sunday caused by the forcible desiccation of the urban Sunday.
Six of the Acting Captains appeared yesterday at Police Headquarters and filed bonds for $10,000 each with the Treasurer of the board.
GREENPORT, L.I., July 30. -- Charles Cheshire, steward of the steamboat Long Island, that runs between this place, Shelter Island, Sag Harbor, and New-London, Conn., is missing.
WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The following notice to all railroad companies transporting cattle within the United States has been issued by the Department of Agriculture:

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 30. -- Brookside, a mining camp, twenty miles west of here, was the scene of a race riot to-night. Two Deputy Sheriffs were killed, and it is said half a dozen negroes were shot, four or five fatally. The town is in a state of panic and the telegraph operator, the only source of information, is locked in his office, too frightened to go outside to obtain more details.
Charles Haldane, a lawyer, who came to this city from the West only a short time ago, created something of a sensation yesterday in Supreme Court, Chambers, before Justice O'Brien.

Mr. Scully, of whom we had heard nothing at all until his work was announced, writes of South Africa with the sure knowledge, the sympathy, and almost with the vigor that Mr. Kipling bestows upon his Hindu stories. The new-comer knows the hills and plains, the bush and the settlements of South Africa well, and he seems to write with a strong moral purpose.

TUESDAY -- P.M. The stock market halted to-day, but there we no evidences of a serious check impending. Sugar and Louisville were the strong features, and both closed higher by large fractions. The Grangers were left pretty much to themselves, and moved within narrow limits. Atchison advanced to 16, but closed unchanged at 15 5/8.
The Willows Journal says that when the great Glenn estate, with its 40,000 acres of land, is supplied with water, each ten acres will support a family. To this The Kern Californian replies:

SAVANNAH, July 30. -- The Directors of the Georgia and Alabama Railroad, formerly the Savannah, Americus and Montgomery, held a meeting to-day for the purpose of organization. The following officers were elected; President -- John Skelton Williams of Richmond; Vice President and General Manager -- Cecil Gabbitt; Secretary -- W.W. Mackall of Savannah; Treasurer -- J. Wilcox Brown.

" Self-inflicted, with suicidal intent," was the wound found in the head of Lillian Low, according to the unhesitating verdict of the jury impaneled by Coroner O'Meagher in the case of the daughter of James Low, Jr., who was found dead near Fort George July 23.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., July 30. -- A plot of farm land in this city owned by the Vandeventer estate was cut up into city lots and sold at public auction about two weeks ago. It was explained to the purchasers that the land was "being farmed, and they, supposed that they had a right to visit the property to locate their lots.
The festive game of draw poker did not go out of fashion in Ludlow Street Jail with the retirement of Tammany Hall Wardens, according to two witnesses called yesterday for the Grand Jury.

BALTIMORE, July 30. -- The Democratic State Convention will meet at noon to-morrow in the Baltimore Academy of Music to nominate candidates for Governor, Controller, and Attorney General. There are 117 delegates, and every one is at the Carrollion House to-night. Trying to figure out the situation.

Literary people will remember that Sir Walter Besant wrote the novel entitled "The Golden Butterfly," and that the theme of the story was founded upon an apparently corroborated statement that his brother had seen the celebrated golden butterfly in a mining camp in California. Mr. Besant's brother did not see the original butterfly, but he did see a photograph of it.
PHILADELPHIA, July 30. -- In speaking to-day of the run against time of the Columbia from Southampton to New-York, Charles H. Cramp, the head of the firm that built the cruiser, said:
The strike of the Brotherhood of Tailors seemed yesterday to be approaching an end in this city.

CHICAGO, July 30. -- Richard B. Hartshorne, Chairman of the Reorganization Committee of the Whisky Trust, arrived in Chicago to-day and was closeted all the afternoon with counsel for the committee. Advices from New-York to the effect that the Greenhut-Morris faction of the trust would try to stop the sale of Whisky Trust property Aug. 14 were called to Mr. Hartshorne's attention.

One would imagine that wasps and bees would flourish under the same or very similar conditions, yet it is not so in reality. Last Winter was very hard on bees. Hardly an apiary came out quite scatheless, and many were nearly ruined. Nevertheless, the wasp appears to be in a most flourishing condition, and is erecting more than the usual amount of irritation.

Police Superintendent McKelvey of Brooklyn yesterday received from Sergt. Thomas Walsh, Acting Captain of the Second Precinct, a report throwing discredit upon a story of robbery told by Mrs. Hiram H. Jones of 118 High Street. Mrs. Jones, he says, has told stories of being robbed before, and they have always turned out to be fictions of her vivid imagination.
Through stupidity, excess of zeal, or from a desire to bring the policy of the present Police Board into disrepute, several policemen have lately made arrests for trivial causes.
At the conclusion of some comments upon the appalling criminal career of the professional murderer Holmes. The Chicago Inter Ocean says:

It is a great pity that two of the most important departments of the City Government and two that have to do directly with the administration of justice, should have become objects of public odium and contempt.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 30. -- Instead of the long-drawn battles that have marked nearly every day of the Grand Circuit since it began at Saginaw, everything but the 2:30 trot was over in one-two-three order this afternoon. This suited the crowd, for the weather was quite raw and became chilly toward night.
" Oh! it is horrible! -- Horrible! horrible! horrible!" said the veteran ex-cavalry officer, in the most plaintive tones of one who suffers and without hope.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Dr. Rooker, secretary of Mgr. Satolli, the Papal Delegate to the United States, returned to the legation to-day after a vacation of a month's duration, spent at Albany. He found, he said this evening, nothing on the files of the legation of public interest or importance that had accumulated during his absence.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 30. -- It has been quiet here to-day -- no doubh the lull before the August storm. Society has been somewhat inactive the past few days, but with the arrival of the North Atlantic squadron interest will revive.

Simon Wormser, the millionaire banker of 836 Fifth Avenue and 15. Broad Street, was found by a district messenger boy dying on the stoop of the house of Dr. Gordon, 70 East Sixty-sixth Street, at 9:40 o'clock last night.

Notice was sent out bankers yesterday by Pinkerton's Detective Agency, representing the American Bankers' Association, warning them against a swindler who has operated in Chicago under the name of Z.B. or Z.P. Alford.

The Cunarder Aurania, whose mishap at sea was told by The New-York Times yesterday, reached port under her own steam early yesterday forenoon. A crack which had been opened in the vessel's main steam pipe was the cause of delay. Thirty-five hours were consumed in riveting a copper patch under the fissure.

Mr. Philip Jeselson has sold, for Edward Jansen, to Benjamin Altman of B. Altman Co., the property at 114 to 120 West Nineteenth Street, 100 by 100, with four four-story brick tenements. This property adjoins the store of the firm of B. Altman Co. The tenements will be removed and a large addition will be built to the firm's establishment.
LONDON, July 30. -- The team which will represent Cambridge University in the contests with Yale in America has been finally selected. The team is made up as follows:

ROCHESTER, July 30. -- The Republican Municipal League has decided to support in the coming Republican caucuses the following anti-machine municipal ticket: For Mayor, Richard Curran; Treasurer, Samuel B. Williams; Executive Board, John A. Levis and Frank Fritzsche; Municipal Court Judge, William L. Keefer.
The Republican State Committee began the campaign of 1895 with a ratification meeting yesterday.

LONDON, July 30. -- The United Press learns that some difficulty has arisen in the London Athletic Club in regard to the proposed contest between a team representing that club and a team of the New-York Athletic Club, which will possibly prevent the London team from going to New-York. It is not stated officially where the hitch is, but it is surmised that the trouble has arisen over the selection of a suitable team.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The British occupation of the Island of Trinidad does not seem to have attracted much attention as yet at the State Department, but it is feared in some quarters that it will result in trouble between Great Britain and Brazil. J.C. Redman, who is a brother-in-law of Minister Salvador de Medonca of Brazil and one of the best-informed men in Washington on South American politics, said today:

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 30. -- H.H. Holmes was once a resident of this (Clinton) county. He appeared at Mooers in 1883, under the name Herman W. Mudgett, as an agent for nursery stock, and created such a good impression that he was engaged to teach the village school. This occupation he found uncongenial.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 30. -- Police Sergeant George Krieger and Patrolman Henry O'Brien, who shot John Spellisy at Union Hill last Thursday night, were lodged in the county jail this morning.
WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The weekly crop and weather report issued to-day from the Weather Bureau contains the following from the several States:

A wind and rain storm struck Coney Island yesterday afternoon and made everybody and everything on and around the island jump about for more than an hour. Bathing houses, photograph galleries, tents, and sheds were blown down, and cane boards, lemonade, and bootblack stands were sent flying down Surf Avenue at a lively rate.

A heavy rainstorm preceded the running of the races at the Brighton Beach track yesterday afternoon. The downpour was so heavy that the track, which was a good and fast one when 3,000 spectators assembled, was made sloppy and very disagreeable to race over.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Secretary Lamont's recent transcontinental trip will have more important results than is supposed in some quarters. The tour was in no sense an excursion of pleasure, for there was a great deal of hard work in the 8,000 miles traversed in the four weeks of almost constant journeying.

LONDON, July 30. -- The sixth annual International Geographical Congress opened its fourth day's session in the great ball of the Imperial Institute at 10 o'clock this morning. The chief subjects of discussion were the reports upon Prof. Penck's proposed map of the world on the scale of 1-1,000,000.

There is an association of evildoers in Spain which practices the hidden treasure game. Their artifice is a well-known one, but human cupidity and credulity are inexhaustible mines. Those evildoers have thought that they could do their work successfully across the mountains; and we have to confess, even if the national pride should suffer, that they have won and are winning victories every day in our country. They proceed in the following manner:

Unless Policeman McCarthy of the Morrisania Station is a peculiarly and grotesquely stupid person, his arrest of a man for raking his lawn on Sunday afternoon proves almost beyond a peradventure that this officer is trying to hamper the efforts of his superiors by making the "Sunday closing movement" ridiculous and oppressive.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, July 30. -- Lord Aberdeen, Governor General of Canada, having concluded his conference with Sir John Schultz, Governor of Manitoba, and Premier Greenway, left for the West to-day with his suite. His Lordship declined to be interviewed on the subject of the conferences, and so also did Go. Schultz.

The reports of the officers of the revenue cutters patrolling Bering Sea seem to indicate that the seal question has been pretty nearly settled by the pelagic slaughter that has been going on in spite of modus vivendi and regulations of the Paris tribunal. Last season's experience showed that the regulations produced no perceptible check upon the slaughter, and this year's observation indicates that the seal herds have been pretty early enterminated.

Information was received in this city yesterday of the successful landing in Cuba last Thursday of two large bodies of insurgents, who brought with them two cannons, 700,000 rounds of ammunition, 500 pounds of dynamite, and hundreds of repeating rifles and revolvers. One expedition consisted, it is said, of 278 men, and the other of 75 men, almost all of them veterans of the last revolutionary war in Cuba.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Bank Examiner C.H. Brush to-day notified the Controller of the Currency that the Keystone National Bank of West Superior, Wis., had closed its doors, and that he had taken charge of the institution.

Some of the political financiers who are still urging the people in outlying districts of the land to vote for free silver in order to "raise prices," and because the "country needs more money" would do well to study the effects of the recent restoration of confidence in the honesty of the American people.

PANAMA, via Galveston, July 31. -- Carlos Caamano, Saenz, Dr. Borja, and Baquerizo, the four principal persons implicated in the recent unsuccessful conspiracy against the Supreme Chief of Ecuador, Eloy Alfaro, have arrived at Aconcagua with their families.

The first of a proposed series of parlor meetings in the interest of Maria Barbella, the Italian girl under sentence of death for the murder of Dominico Cataldo, was held last night in the apartments of Mrs. Mary C. Morrell, at 330 West Fifty-ninth Street.

Patrick J. Moriarity, forty-four years old, of 274 Jackson Avenue, Long Island City, approached a policeman at 9 o'clock Tuesday evening and demanded that he arrest Andrew H. Sutton, fifty-two years old, of 98 Cornelia Street, Brooklyn, for assaulting and injuring him in Patrick Farley's saloon, at Thirty-fourth Street and First Avenue.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., July 31. -Part of the skin shed by a boa constrictor was found by Major Fred Mather on top of the hill near his house. The piece is sixteen inches long and came from near the snake's tail.

DENVER, Col., July 31. -- Adelaide, flourishing mining town on the line of the Florence and Cripple Creek Railroad, about seventy-five miles from Cripple Creek, was yesterday struck by a series of cloudbursts that flooded the entire district, and demolished over fifty houses.

Secretary McIntyre of the Brooklyn Jockey Club has just announced the stakes for the Fall meeting of the club, which begins on Tuesday, Sept. 17. The stakes are more numerous than usual, and the club has been very liberal in guaranteeing them to be of considerable value, and well worth entering for. The stakes announced, their guaranteed value, and the distances of the races are thus stated:

The death of Richard Morris Hunt removes an architect whose professional career extended over almost the whole period of the aesthetic movement which may be said to have begun in this country with the importation of the Gothic revival. None of his contemporaries or successors have been more conspicuous and active and very few of them more successful in contributing to that movement.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The State Department to-day received a formal protest against the alleged seizure of the island of Trinidad by Great Britain, on behalf of "James I.," and signed by somebody, whose name could not be deciphered, as "Chancellor."
BAKER CITY, Oregon, July 31. -- Meagre reports were received here to-day of the almost total destruction by-fire, on the night of July 26, of Harney City, in Harney County.
SOCORRO, N.M., July 31. -- Chihuahua and Cuba, small suburbs, were flooded this afternoon, and several lives were lost.
MARIETTA, Wis., July 31. -- Fire in Menominee this evening destroyed a number of saw and planing mills and 25,000,000 feet of lumber.

There is consternation in the ranks on Brooklyn Loyal Leaguers -- the men who are opposed for sentimental reasons to the annexation of Brooklyn to New-York -- because City Treasurer John D. Keiley, who has heretofore been counted as one of the stanchest opponents of the Greater New-York, has announced frankly and unreservedly that in consolidation with New-York lies Brooklyn's only hope for progress.

Police Captain Michael Murphy died yesterday in his home, 159 West One Hundred and Fourth Street. He had been ill for some time suffering from a complication of diseases. The report of his death reached Police Headquarters about 11:30 A.M.

BAR HARBOR, July 31. -- The regular Wednesday evening dinner and dance took place to-night at the Kebo Valley Club. Sixty-six were present at the dinner. Mrs. Levi P. Morton and her party sat at the head of the table. Mrs. Morton was attired in a rich gown of black silk. At her left sat Mavroyeni Bey, the Turkish Minister, while on her right was James G. Blaine, Jr.

A one-mile professional invitation scratch race, with a three-hundred-dollar purse, has been added to the programme for Manhattan Beach next Saturday. This will, without doubt, be the greatest bicycle race seen in the vicinity of New-York this season, as, besides the regular entries, those of W.C. Sanger, H.C. Tyler, A.W. Porter, and H.C. Wheeler have also been received.

Trinidad is a Principality; Baron Harden Hickey, under the name of James I., is the sovereign. Great Britain has seized Trinidad for a cable station; Brazil has made a formal protest and sent the cruiser Newark to the island to emphasize its declaration of ownership of the territory. Baron Harden Hickey is in California.

The Turkish Government has never denied that serious disturbances have taken place at the district of Sassoun. What it has denied is the accusation that there was a premeditated massacre, and yet this is the absurd basis upon which is built the whole Armenian agitation, both in America and Europe.

LONDON, July 31. -- W.W. Rockhill of the State Department of Washington informally presented to the Vice Presidents of the congress an invitation to hold the seventh meeting of the International Congress in the American capital.
CHICAGO, July 31. -- Mrs. Quinlan, the wife of the janitor who is supposed to know much about the misdeeds of H. H. Holmes, is believed to have made a partial confession to the police this morning.

Last evening the count of the checks of the survivors in last Sunday's century run to New-Brunswick, N.J., and return, was made, and resulted in the confirmation of "Pop" Stahl's belief that the members of the Gramercy Wheelmen had won the handsome banner presented by The New-York Times.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- While there is no information at the State Department that the Spanish Council of Ministers has "accepted" the amount demanded by the United States for the payment of the Mora claim, the information is considered to be reliable there, and is taken to mean that Spain will pay the indemnity without delay.
Bibulous yachtsmen who have been seeing the sea serpent in Long Island Sound for a week or two are hereby advised to stick to the same and keep their goggle-eye open a little while longer.

EAST MORICHES, L.I., July 31. -- While a party of Summer guests were embarking in sailboats at the bay side of the outer beach to-day, some one espied a great big ugly head being pushed through the water at a rapid rate by an unseen body. Immediately there was a cry:

Police Commissioner Welles of Brooklyn yesterday filled the position of Inspector, made vacant by the death of Inspector Edward Reilly, by the promotion of Capt. John Brennan, who had been in command of the Vernon Avenue Precinct.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 31. -- The Defender to-day gave the Vigilant a twelve-minute beating, boat for boat, in the run from New-London. With the exception of four miles of a reach the yachts were dead before the wind all the day, and so the race was monotonous and uninteresting.
It has long been prophesied that the litigation in the Fayerweather will case would end sooner or later in a fine quarrel between the lawyers engaged in the contests.

The finances of the Board of Home Missions of the Presbyterian Church are sadly crippled. With a debt vastly increased in the last three years, and a number of its funds hypothecated, the board now finds itself unable to pay in full the salaries of some of its missionaries.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 31. -- Chairman Hinkley of the Democratic State Committee has telegraphed the leaders of the Democratic factions of Monroe County, that he had selected Aug. 20 as the day on which they must settle their differences, once for all, in the caucuses in the thirty-nine wards and towns of the county.

HAVANA, July 31. -- Private advices from Santa Clara are to the effect that an engagement took place on Saturday last near Solapa, in the Santa Clara district, between a reconnoitering party of cavalry and the insurgents, under Suarez Zayas.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- "The triumph the legalist revolution in 1892," says Consul Plumacher, at Maracaibo, in a report to the State Department upon the commercial statistics for the fiscal year just closed, "left Venezuela in a state of absolute prostration, with both her foreign trade and her domestic industries practically paralyzed, but on account of the general confidence inspired in the beginning by the new Government, the adoption of the eagerly desired reformed.

BOSTON, July 31. -- Miss Anthony of Missouri was one of the speakers to-day at Berkely Hall, where the last day's session of the National Conference of Colored Women was held. Miss Anthony spoke earnestly of the influence of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union and what it had accomplished in the South.

Senator Gorman, though a rather despotic boss, and oftentimes reckless of his party's welfare and of his own reputation, is not blind or a fool. There was a strong groundswell of opposition to him this year among the Maryland Democrats, and he knew it. Like a wise politician, he did not resort to bluster or to brute force. He yielded and compromised.

CINCINNATI, July 31. -- At a meeting of the Directors of the new Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton, (the consolidated Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton, and Cincinnati, Dayton and Ironton Railroads,) held in this city yesterday, the following new Directors were chosen: Rush Taggart, Fellows, and Davis of New-York; Robert C. Schenck, Dayton, and Frederick A. Short and George I. Balch of Cincinnati.

The Democratic Club held an adjourned meeting last night and issued an address to the people of the State of New-York, in which their attention was directed to the manner in which the Republican Party has legislated and conducted the affairs of this State since it has been in power.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 31. -- The report that ex-Gov. Flower, Senator Edward Murphy, W.F. Sheehan, and A.M. Brady conferred here last evening relative to the time and place for holding the Democratic State Convention is without foundation.

The 2,000 school children of the Hebrew Institute, in East Broadway, met in the big hall of the building yesterday afternoon to listen to an adress on clean streets by Col. Waring, Commissioner of Street Cleaning.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., July 31. -- Brooklyn was again defeated by Philadelphia to-day. The visitors put up the better fielding game, but the local team batted opportunely. Both pitchers were hit freely in the fourth inning. Thompson scored the winning run in the eighth, making a two-bagger, going to third on Cross's out at first, and scoring on the throw-in of Clements's fly to centre.

The Mayor's programme of appointing Gen. Anson G. McCook to succeed Joseph J. O'Donohue as City Chamberlain, as announced in The New-York Times yesterday, was carried out to the letter. Gen. McCook has taken the oath of office, and will begin his new duties to-day. He filed his surety bond for $500,000 yesterday, in the office of the Controller. The sureties are the American Surety Company and Gen. Samuel Thomas.

KEY WEST, Fla., July 31. -- Private telegrams received here confirm the story of the safe landing of the largest and best-equipped expedition that has ever landed in Cuba. As was stated, the expedition was commanded by Gens. Roloff, Sanchez, and Rodriguez. They carried 280 men, 28,000 rounds of ammunition, 450 rifles, 4,700 pounds of dynamite, one Gatling gun, and one cannon.

The Catholic Total Abstinence Bicycle Club of Philadelphia will send a big delegation of wheelmen to this city to attend the annual convention of the Catholic Total Abstinence Union of America, which is to be held here next week.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Some interest has been created in Administration circles over the report from Colon that work is to be resumed on the Panama Canal. If the report be true, it shows that the company has succeeded in collecting a new loan, but it is doubted if enough has been secured to complete the work.
STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, July 31. -- The weather in camp last night and to-day made sleeping under three blankets and the wearing of overcoats pleasant.
The Hebrew Orphan Asylum Society has sold, at $87,500, the southeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street, 145 by 102.2.

The many pretty melodies in waltz and other dance tempi with which "Die Fledermaus" abounds were enjoyed by a large audience at Terrace Garden last night. Strauss's sprightly music to Haffner and Genee's clever libretto make "The Bat" one of the most interesting of the numerous Strauss operettas. The announcement of its presentation is generally sure to result in large attendance.

Apparently the final effort of the Greenhut faction to obstruct the plans looking to the reorganization of the Distilling and Cattle Feeding Company came to an end yesterday in Chicago, when Judge Seaman, in the United States Circuit Court, denied the application of John F. Olmstead to be allowed an appeal from the final decree entered by Judge Showalter, ordering the sale of the assets of the company.

There was a special meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday, to provide for Col. Waring's department. It was the first meeting in nearly a month, and so much routine business had accumulated that it was decided to hold another meeting to-day.

WASHINGTON, July. 31. -- Secretary Morton went out to the experimental farm station yesterday. As he left his office his secretary handed him an umbrella and mentioned the fact that the Weather Bureau had prophesied showers during the day. The Secretary cast a glance upward and saw the sun shining out of a cloudless sky.

The industry of manufacturing clothing has grown to great dimensions in this city in the last few years and it has also produced a large amount of "labor trouble." Both the growth of the industry and the production of "labor trouble" have been due to conditions beyond the control either of the capital or the labor employed, but these conditions must be taken into account in dealing with their difficulties.

CHICAGO, July 31. -- The Grand Jury to-day voted indictments against six election judges, charging fraudulent practices in the First and Second Wards at the election last November. The indictments resulted from the evidence brought out by the McGann-Belknap Congressional election contest.

William Edgar, Jr., of 241 Washington Street, who was arraigned in the Tombs Police Court yesterday on charges of disorderly conduct and of using insulting language to Policeman Molony of the Leonard Street Police Station, said the policeman tried to borrow money from him.

Arrangements are rapidly being perfected for the opening of the Cotton States and International Exposition, at Atlanta, Ga., on Sept. 18. More than $2,000,000 has been spent in laying out the grounds and in the erection of buildings.

The Police Board, in executive session, yesterday devised a new plan of making promotions in the department. Their plan is embodied in the following resolution, which has been adopted, and which also received the approval of the State Civil Service Board at Albany:
Tammany Hall will hold its primaries tonight to select members of the next General Committee.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The report of the Board of Engineers detailed to examine Buffalo Harbor with a view to its extension and improvement has been submitted to Secretary Lamont by Capt. Dan C. Kingman.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 31. -- Notice has been given the employes of the National Water Tube Boiler Company of this city that, beginning with next pay day, their wages will be increased 10 per cent. The increase is general, and affects every department of the works, which is one of the most important industries of the city, giving employment to a large number of men.

SARATOGA, July 31. -- Although this was Ladies' Day at the race track here, with admission free to all women who cared to go to the course, the attendance at the track was very light. The weather was cold, the racing rather commonplace, and the fields small; but twenty horses started in the five races.

ALBANY, July 31. -- The State Civil Service Commission has written to the Board of Supervisors of Kings County in approval of the board's plan for providing a county Civil Service Commission, to have jurisdiction over employes on the public works of Kings County. Over $3,000,000 is to be expended on county works beyond the jurisdiction of the Brooklyn Civil Service Commission.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 31. -- The Sylvia, Commodore Brown's flagship, signaled that the fleet would proceed to Newport at 10:30 o'clock, early in the morning, and the yachts that were not going to take part in the races got under way and proceeded through Fisher's Island Sound, so as to head off the racing yachts and see something of the contests, if possible.

Pleasant weather and a good card served to draw a big crowd of people to the Brighton Beach race track yesterday. The track was dead, though pretty well dried out, rather to the surprise of everybody. This probably caused the wholesale scratching that was indulged in, nearly one-half of the horses entered being declared out of their engagements.

The question of the constitutionality of the act abolishing the old Board of Police Justices, and creating the new City Magistrates' Courts and the Court of Special Sessions, is at last to come squarely to an issue.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Commissioner of Indian Affairs Browning this morning received a telegram from Gov. Richards of Wyoming stating that he had reliable information that 200 Indians, supposed to be Utes, were seen yesterday near South Pass, Fremont County, Wyoming; also forty-seven Sioux on Bad Water Creek, in the same county.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Aug. 1. -- Brooklyn defeated Philadelphia to-day in the concluding game of the series. The visitors won in the eighth by scoring four runs on bases on balls to Abbey and Griffin, Lachance's double, and singles by Corcoran and Daly. Brooklyn got Lampe's measure in the fourth inning, and, at the beginning of the fifth, Taylor succeeded him.

The jolliest row in the Republican ranks in this city is in the old Eleventh District, where Mayor Strong's private secretary, Job E. Hedges, is accused of working his position to establish himself as a "petty boss."

Mayor Schieren is opposed to any increase in the speed of the trolley cars in Brooklyn and has so announced himself, and as a result the Board of Aldermen have failed to give the railroad companies the relief they demanded of having the speed increased.

Tammany laid the foundation of its new organization last night at the primary elections in all the thirty-five Assembly districts of the city. The Tiger was in a lively mood. He sniffed a combat not afar off. He shook out the fur that was so badly bedraggled last November and appeared in public once more.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The debt statement issued this afternoon shows a net increase in the public debt, less cash in the Treasury, during July, of $38,435,937.94. The interest-bearing debt increased $31,158,340; the non-interest-bearing debt decreased $813,025, and the cash in the Treasury decreased $8,090,622.94.

" I am case-hardened," said President Roosevelt of the Police Board yesterday, "about criticism and caricature that come from allies of the criminal classes, but I am not insensible to encouragement from those who side with law and order on the question of enforcing all valid statutes.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Aug. 1. -- A letter received at Police Headquarters this morning from the Superintendent of Constabulary at Glasgow, Scotland, contained information which apparently clears up the mysterious disappearance of the Rev. Dana Davenport, a young Episcopal clergyman, the son of the Rev. Mr. Davenport of Anacosta, a suburb of Washington.
ALBANY, Aug. 1. -- The contract for doing the legislative printing for two years, from Oct. 1 next, was let to John E. Milholland of New-York this afternoon.

The report that Turkey is to carry into effect the Armenian reforms demanded by the powers brings a feeling of great thankfulness, not only on the part of the Armenians in Asia Minor, but also to their countrymen and one time fellow sufferers in other lands.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1. -- There was some fine doubles tennis this afternoon on the Meadow Club course, and Howland and Foote succeeded in repeating their victory of Naragansett last year by downing the powerful Wrenn-Chace combination in an exciting three- set match. Howland and Foote should have made it two straight, but a bad bound spoiled Howland's shot when the score stood at 5 -- 3 and 30 -- 40 in the first set.

In your issue of to-day, Mr. John E. Parsons is quoted as saying that the affidavit of the brother-in-law of the late Mr. Daniel B. Fayerweather, Mr. John B. Reynolds, upon which Mr. Justice O'Brien issued a prohibition, "is a tissue of lies." He did say so.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The Washingtons took the odd game of the series from New-York to-day through good batting and fielding, and steady pitching by Mercer. The fielding of Selbach, Joyce, and Shiebeck for the home team, and of Butler, Stafford, and Doyle for the visitors, was brilliant. The weather was cool and attendance, 1,700. Score:

Perhaps the most effective part of the address of the Democratic Club of this city to the people of the State is that which shows the failure of the Republican Legislature to keep the pledge of economy. We do not attach much importance to the rate of taxation as a political issue unless it is shown that an increased rate is due to dishonesty or extravagance in expenditures.

A detailed article on "The Bond Syndicate: Its Excellent Work," is contributed to The Forum by President A.B. Hepburn of the Third National Bank. There are in it some remarks on the particular source of the Treasury difficulties that led to the syndicate loan of Feb. 8, with which we are not able wholly to agree, and which suggest a view of the currency question that we should not like to see prevail.

John O'Brien, flanked by ex-Lieut.-Gov. W.F. Sheehan, ex-Judge Edward Browne, and E.T. Lovett, as counsel, appeared before Justice O'Brien, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, to show why the Aqueduct Commissioners should be permanently restrained from making the final award for the Jerome Park reservoir contract to John B. McDonald. Assistant Corporation Counsel Turner appeared on behalf of the Commissioners.

From The San Francisco Chronicle. Capt. Martin T. Chester of the schooner Elwood has returned with his vessel from an Alaskan arm of the sea which not even the coast survey has visited. In the schooner he explored Turnagain arm, really a continuation of Cook's Inlet. The body of water is most appropriately named, for navigators have almost invariably obeyed its warning to "turn again."

The brewers of New-York City, in conjunction with those of the other great cities, of the country, are preparing to make a stubborn fight against the imposition of an additional tax of $1 a barrel on their products.

ST. GEORGE, S.I., Aug. 1. -- At a hastily convened meeting of the Board of Supervisors this evening at Stapleton, the Board of Police Commissioners and the Captain of the county police were called on to protect the County Engineer with all the forces at their command, and all extra men that might be needed.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1. -- H.H. Holmes has made a statement regarding the latest developments in the series of murders with which he is accused.

FLUSHING, L.I., Aug 1. -- The leading local paper to-night publishes an attack upon the police force of the village, giving a statement of more than twenty burglaries that have been committed during the last year, none of the perpetrators of which have been apprehended. In a majority of cases, no apparent effort has been made, it is alleged, to run down the criminals.
Herman Clarke, the former Wall Street broker, who is at present in Sing Sing Prison for forgery, was indicted again yesterday by he Grand Jury, this time for grand larceny.

The indictment of Sheriff Tamsen for allowing prisoners to escape from Ludlow Street Jail is a needful vindication of law and order. It is not charged, it is to be supposed, that the Sheriff was personally cognizant of the condition of the jail, or that he "willfully and corruptly" allowed the escape of the prisoners. In that case he would have been indicted for a felony instead of a misdemeanor.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, Aug. 1. -- The cool wave has made the splendid work of the Twenty-second Regiment and the Sixty-ninth Battalion in camp this week a work of pleasure. The early morning drill to-day was of the battalion in extended order, and the forenoon drill of battalion in closed order.

The latest prodigy in South Carolina is a negro girl named Claretta Norah Avery. She will be ten years old on Sept. 18, but for something less than three years she has been doing what she calls "Working for God" among the members of her own race. During the past few weeks she has developed into a wonderful preacher and all who come within the sound of her voice are amazed at her utterances.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1. -- Chairman Gideon continues to wage war on the St. Louis cyclists who persist in violating the rule regarding racing on Sunday. He proposes to punish the violators by permanent suspension, and to-day announced the following as having been relegated to that class: W. W. Gardner, George E. Storck, J.F. Barsaloux, and Joseph Laux.

A fire on the Brooklyn water front at the foot of Amity Street yesterday consumed a pier belonging to the Brooklyn Wharf and Warehouse Company, and destroyed several thousand dollars' worth of jute, saltpetre, sisal, and shellac, ignited a four-masted bark, which had to be towed out to Governors Island and sunk in order to save it, and destroyed several lighters and barges which were lying alongside the pier.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Inspectors throughout the State have been reporting to the State Board of Health and State Dairy Commissioner George McGuire that anthrax has broken out among the cattle, horses and other live stock in different counties. This report has considerably alarmed the State Board of Health and the Commissioner.

Favorites again had an inning at the Brighton Beach race track yesterday afternoon and won five races in succession. The only one to be bowled over was Gutta Percha, in the last race, Sheedy, who is riding like a star jockey, getting Ina home in front of the Morris horse after a lively brush through the stretch.

HOTEL WENTWORTH, NEW-CASTLE, N.H., Aug. 1. -- Bright weather again favored the tennis players here to-day, and the Hotel Wentworth open tournament was continued before an enthusiastic gathering of spectators. Much surprise was caused by the poor form of Budlong, the clever Brown University player, who was beaten badly by young Scudder of Chicago.

DENVER, Colorado, Aug. 1. -- Another heavy rainstorm swept this region this evening and all railroads continue to suffer great losses. An iron bridge over Hard Crabble Creek, on the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad, twenty miles west of Pueblo was swept away about the time the Atlantic express was due at that point.
BERLIN, Aug. 1. -- Prof. Heinrich von Sybel, German historian, died at Marburg to-day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The attention of Controller Eckels was called this morning to the editorial published yesterday in The Post of Hartford, Conn., accusing him of knowing that the First National Bank of Willimantic, Conn., was insolvent a year before its failure, and that information to that effect was furnished him by E.F. Dooley after an examination of the bank by him in the Spring of 1894.

The store of Ludwig T. Muench, dealer in furs, at 832 Broadway, was seized yesterday by a Deputy Sheriff on an attachment for $3,566 in favor of the Transatlantic Fur Company for furs and skins sold to him between Jan. 30 and Feb. 25, 1895.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Ambassador Runyon, in Berlin, announces the establishment by the Bundesrath of an obligatory quarantine of ruminating animals and swine imported by sea, in order to prevent the introduction of Texas fever, pulmonary consumption, mange, sheep pox, swine pest, swine plague, foot and mouth and other diseases.

In the State Department at Washington the clerks could not read the signature of Trinidad's Grand Chancellor. One wonders if they could have read that of Talleyrand. He signed "Ch. Mau. Tal." with a flourish of flies' legs on a window pane. He used no capital letters. Those of M. le Comte de la Boissiere are fantastic and delicate.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 1. -- The Rev. Dr. Thomas Hanlon, President of Pennington Seminary, is the leader of the Bible class which meets Sunday afternoons in the Ocean Grove Auditorium. The class is the largest in the world, the average attendance being over 2,000. Hundreds of ministers and college professors are members of the class, and at every session questions are asked by the scholars and anwered by the leader.

Of the hundreds of thousands of cattle brought into Kansas City alive every year and either taken out dead or not taken out at all in any recognizable form, it is to be presumed that the majority have horns. These horns are not a part of the frozen, canned, corned, or otherwise preserved carcasses of beef that leave the city in the unending procession of yellow freight cars.

LONDON, Aug. 1. -- Another consignment of California fruit, comprising 1,550 cases of pears, 730 cases of plums, and 270 cases of peaches, was sold at auction in the Covent Garden fruit, flower, and vegetable market to-day. Although the greater part of the fruit was in bad order, being considerably over-ripe, the prices realized were slightly in advance of those obtained at last week's sales.

Several long-contemplated changes in the Tax Department were made yesterday. President Barker and Commissioners Wells and Sutro held a long meeting behind closed doors and selected new Deputy Tax Commissioners to take the places of those whose services they had decided to dispense with.

Complaints have been renewed at the Custom House from importers against Simon Hess, who has the public carting contract. Mr. Hess was in trouble a few months ago, when the Collector called him to sharp account for delaying the removal of goods from the piers to the warehouse. He laid the blame on the steamship men.

LONG BRANCH, Aug. 1. -- The report of the elopement of Miss Louise V. Kissam and Louis Sayre Kerr, summer guests at the Monmouth Beach Club House, is denied by every body in the Club House circle. Miss Kissam and Mr. Kerr left the Club House yesterday and were quietly married in New-York City.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Paul H. Bray, stepson of ex-Consul Waller, to-day received a letter from Port Louis, Mauritius Island, announcing the arrival of Mrs. Waller in that island from Madagascar June 16.

The opponents of Gorman in Maryland announce an attitude of expectancy. The result of the convention for the nomination of Governor and State officers on Wednesday is declared to be a triumph of "Gormanism"; but it rests largely with the independent Democrats to decide how far it shall prove in reality to be that.

From The Los Angeles (Cal.) Herald. The Rev. David Utter of Salt Lake, the noted Unitarian minister, who recently made the descent of the Colorado River on a raft, preached an eloquent sermon in the First Congregational Church in San Bernardino, on Sunday morning, July 21.
The Campaign Committee of the Republican Club last night issued its address in favor of enlarging the State Committee.
SOCORRO, New-Mexico, Aug. 1. -- The flood of yesterday was the most serious in the history of New-Mexico. Sixteen persons are known to have lost their lives at Cuba and Chihuahua.
" Cody, the Texas Terror," was in town yesterday. He walked into a cut-rate ticket office at 641 Broadway and bought a ticket for Los Angeles, by Pacific Mail steamer.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 1. -- The yachts lay at anchor to-day in the harbor, and the yachtsmen fumed and fretted because a spanking breeze from the southwest was going to waste. It would have been a grand day for a race, and if there is a breeze like it to-morrow, the races for the Goelet Cups will be the best of the year.

Irregularity was the feature of to-day's stock market. There were realizing sales on yesterday's advances early in the day, but good buying about offset their influence. The news of the day was all favorable. There were engagement of $350,000 gold for export, but the incident attracted little attention.
The late Lord Exeter's father was a Tory of the most bigoted and intolerant type, and he worked irreparable harm to his family by his fatuous opposition to the Great Northern Railway.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- The Republican Senatorial fight between the Counties of Saratoga, Washington, and Schenectady, forming the new Twenty-eighth District, came to an end to-day with the nomination at Ballston Spa of Edgar T. Brackett of Saratoga Springs.
