BALTIMORE, Aug. 1. -- An interview between United States Senator Gorman and State Senator Hayes, which took place just before the State Democratic Convention met, has excited wide interest. A Democratic afternoon paper to-day prints what is claimed to be an accurate report of the conversation.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 1. -- All the other sensations of the Grand Circuit meeting here were forgotten this afternoon while the free-for- all pacers were fighting for a good-sized purse and putting in faster miles than had ever been seen before at this famous Glenville course. There were five candidates for the prize, but everybody agreed that Robert J. and Joe Patchen would furnish the sport.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- There is talk in War and Navy Department circles concerning the establishment of combined army and navy ordnance shops. Work of this character, for which the Government expends annually an immense sum, has hitherto been carried on at two establishments, that for naval ordnance being at the Washington Never Yard, and that for army guns being at Watervliet Arsenal, West Troy, N.Y.

Sheriff Tamsen was indicted yesterday by the Grand Jury sitting in and for the City and County of New-York for permitting Killoran, Allen and Russell, the alleged postage stamp thieves, to escape from Ludlow Street Jail, and for neglecting to perform various acts and duties, the omission of which led to the escape of the prisoners.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 1. -- The first day of August was spent in a rather quiet manner by society at Bar Harbor. It seemed as though its members were taking a much needed rest before getting into the whirl and bustle of social gayety which always characterizes this month.
LIVE OAK, Fla., Aug. 1. -- George Mitchell, colored, was hanged here to-day-for complicity in the murder and robbery of Alfred Ryberg, a white man. Mitchell protested his innocence.

It appears by a dispatch to The New York Times from Washington that the reason for the detachment of Capt. Henry Glass from the cruiser Cincinnati and his appointment to the command of the battleship Texas was that he had kept the Cincinnati in such a high condition of efficiency from the time he took command of that fine ship as to indicate to Secretary Herbert his peculiar fitness for a superior command.

WAUSEON, Ohio, Aug. 1. -- Ray McDonald won his first race since the national meet to-day, and Harry Maddox added a well-won prize. Surprises came thick and fast at the annual national meet of the Wauseon Cycling Club. Gardiner and "Charlie" Murphy failed to qualify in their heat of the half-mile open, and Bald ran fourth in the final, being beaten by McDonald, Zeigler, and Rigby.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1. -- The management of the Schiller Theatre was assumed this afternoon by Gustav Frohman, who leased the house for five years. Thomas Prior, the lessee, gave up the house on the agreement of Mr. Frohman to assume the indebtedness contracted during the eight months of Mr. Prior's management.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Aug. 1. -- At the conference between Lord Aberdeen, Canada's Gouevnor General; Sir John Schultz, Manitoba's Governor, and Premier Greenway on the Catholic school question, the Premier consented to consider a compromise measure, but conditionally. This condition is that Lord Aberdeen at once see that the order to restore Catholic parochial schools, recently passed by the Dominion Government, be canceled. He refused to do anything while the order was in existence.
BOSTON, Aug. 1. -- Facts just brought to light partly solve the mystery surrounding the disappearance of Mrs. Anna M. Gardner, the missing Christian Endeavorer of Nebraska

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 1. -- The Birmingham district, composed of the two great coal-producing counties of Jefferson and Walker and several smaller neighbors, is as busy now as it has been at any time for several years. Early in the Spring the production of iron received a great impetus when it was discovered that this district was actually shipping out more iron per day than was being produced.

ISLIP, L.I., Aug. 1. -- The Summer residents at this place have been awakened since early in June at a very early hour each morning by the shrill whistle of the fishing steamer Eclipse, owned by Capt. William Jeffries. The steamer ties up at night in Orowoc Creek, along which are many handsome country places.

Rumors are prevalent concerning the disposition of the property at the northwest corner of Pine and Nassau Streets, now occupied by the Clearing House and the Chase National Bank. The new building of the Clearing House will be ready for occupancy in September. The bank, as was exclusively announced in The New- York Times two months ago, will occupy a portion of the new building in Cedar Street.

On the application of Frederick W. Anness and George M. Pynchon, represented by Messrs. Guggenheimer, Untermyer Marshall, Judge Morgan J. O'Brien, in the New-York State Supreme Court, yesterday, granted a temporary injunction restraining the Reorganization Committee of the Distilling and Cattle Feeding Company from becoming purchasers of the property of the company at the sale ordered by the United States Circuit Court of Illinois, to be held on Aug. 14.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 1. -- Among the guests on some of the yachts were the following:

SARATOGA, Aug. 1. -- Fewer people were at the race track to-day than ever before in the history of racing here. The weather is so cold as to make the wearing of warm wraps necessary. Small fields also serve to destroy interest in the sport.
Detective Hugh Quinn of the East Twenty-second Street Station arraigned two bright, good-looking, well-dressed young fellows in Yorkville Court yesterday on charges of grand larceny and robbery.

LONDON, Aug. 1. -- The race for the Goodwood Cup to-day was a complete fizzle. The Prince of Wales won it with his horse Florizel II., the only starter against him being Lord Penrhyn's Thessalian. Florizel II. was the favorite at 1 to 11.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1. -- At the annual meeting of the National Apple Shippers' Association held here to-day and attended by delegates from Portland, Me., to Denver, Col., a committee of apple growers, packers and dealers reported that the July report of the United States Department of Agriculture indicating a short apple crop was entirely incorrect and misleading.
John E. Parsons and William Blaikie met again yesterday on opposite sides of the Fayerweather case, this time before Surrogate Arnold.
CASPER, Wyoming, Aug. 1. -- Four, and possibly more, lives were lost by a cloudburst on Casper Mountain, at the head of Garden Creek, last night.

TROY, Aug. 1. -- There is harmony in the ranks of neither Republicans nor Democrats in Rensselaer County just now. In the Republican camp the contention for leadership is being carried on in the most spirited manner by John A. Quackenbush and Sheriff Cornelius V. Collins. The latter is supported by Congressman Frank S. Black, and is considered to be in the lead.

SUMMIT, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Residents of Millburn and Short Hills have been puzzled for several weeks over an epidemic of curious worms that have infested shade and fruit trees, and done a great amount of damage. A number of the worms were sent to the entomological department at Washington last week, for identification and classification, and were there announced to be basket worms.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1. -- Attorney William Capps, representing the heirs of the Williams sisters, left to-night for Little Rock. He goes with a letter from States Attorney Kern authorizing him to represent Kern in the negotiations concerning Caldwell, alias Hatch, alias Allen, now in the Little Rock Penitentiary. At best the Chicago authorities do not believe Allen, alias Hatch, can give information that will develop evidence that will prove murder.

LONDON, Aug. 2. -- Mr. Bayard, the United States Ambassador, presented the prizes to the successful pupils of the ancient grammar school in Boston. Lincolnshire to-day. In the evening the Mayor of the town gave a dinner in honor of Mr. Bayard, and the municipal authorities presented an illuminated address to the Ambassador.
The funeral of Simon Wormser, the banker, was held yesterday at 836 Fifth Avenue, the home of his brother.

The history of the contests for the Goelet Cup is a serial illustration of the truth that the race is not always to the swift, and this truth was yesterday freshly illustrated. The Defender took the honors and the Vigilant won the cup. The public interest of the occasion was in the showing that the new boat would make, and that interest is not disappointed.

Corporations are a necessity in every civilized State. Great enterprises cannot be carried on without the aggregation of capital and the limitation of liability which distinguish them from ordinary partnerships. They have a practical monopoly of land transportation, of mining, manufacturing, banking, and insurance; and within their proper sphere they are a blessing to the community.

No man can live at an American university without becoming literary, even in vacation time, when athletes so prevail. Those who doubt it may consult the college papers, as they are termed. Few have not heard of The Harvard Lampoon. Fewer have ever seen it. The same is true of The Yale Review, Princeton Tiger, and, in fact, the whole array of them.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- As Erie train No. 722 east-bound, was passing through Stairway at 7 o'clock A.M. to-day Engineer Krauss saw a man lying on the track directly ahead of his engine. He rang the bell, but the man made no effort to move, and before the engine could be stopped the entire train passed over him.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Aug. 2. -- The Manitoba school question has taken a new turn and the prospects for a settlement are very gloomy. Premier Greenway has refused to recede from his position in regard to the Catholic schools, and announces that he will accept no compromise nor consent to the slightest change in the Manitoba school act.

The United States cruiser Brooklyn is to receive a testimonial from the residents of the city after which she is named. Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn will appoint a committee next week to take charge of this matter.

CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 2. -- A freight train on the Pittsburg, Fort Wayne and Chicago Railroad broke in two on a heavy grade near Stark Siding early this morning. The rear end crashed into the first section, and ten cars were wrecked. A dozen tramps were riding in a furniture car, which was smashed to splinters.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2. -- Mate Thomas Boyle of the schooner Henry P. Mason of Bath, Me., which arrived this morning, committed suicide at sea last Sunday morning in a peculiar manner. Boyle was about thirty-three years old and his home was Manchester, England. He sailed in the Mason over a year as first mate.

The Legislature of Texas was not controlled at the last session by Populists. The area and resources of which it boasts would seem to give sufficient scope for competition in the State to prevent it from being an easy victim of oppressive combinations. These facts make it more surprising that such a crazy piece of legislation should have been perpetrated as its so-called anti-trust law.

An explosion and fire in the house of William B. Miles of 139 West Forty-fifth. Street, formerly a mate in the United States Navy and now cashier of the Ocean Steamship Company, caused much excitement yesterday afternoon.

The temporary injunction granted on Thursday restraining the Reorganization Committee of the Whisky Trust from bidding in or acquiring the property of the company at the sale set for August was vacated yesterday by Justice O'Brien in the Supreme Court.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 2. -- A lawn party this evening was enjoyed by many Summer guests. It was held by the Presbyterian Church Sunday school. Mrs. W.D. Harper and Mrs. H.M. Alexander of New-York had charge of the affair.

ALBANY, N. Y., Aug. 2. -Superintendent C. M. Preston of the State Banking Department has completed his tbulation of the annual reports of the thirty-seven trust companies in the State, showing their financial operations for the year ended June 30, 1895.

On steamships sailing for Europe to-day will be taken $1,350,000 in gold coin, withdrawn yesterday from the Sub-Treasury, and $100,000 in bars, taken from the stock of Handy Harmon, bullion dealers. The Bank of Montreal withdrew from the Sub-Treasury $1,000,000 for deposit in its vaults in this city, and not to be sent away.

This is a dangerous time of the year for pets, as well as for babies, and Toms and Tabbies, Fidos, and all manner of feathered bipeds succumb to the various ills to which their kind is heir, and the taxidermist reaps a harvest.

NEWPORT, L.I., Aug. 2. -- A light northerly breeze was, blowing when the yachtsmen took a shunt around soon after sunrise this morning. Outside the harbor incoming steamers said there was a good roll on the sea. This was what might be expected after three day of strong southwesterly breezes.
Arthur C.K. Newsam, formerly of Cedros, Trinidad, was before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday for examination on the question of his extradition on charges of embezzlement and forgery.
While spending a Winter in the Black Hills, two years ago, the writer had an adventure which might prove of interest to those interested in ornithology and its branches.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 2. -- The great schooner prize of the year, the one-thousand-dollar Goelet Cup, called out ten entries, the pick of the New-York Yacht Club fleet. They were the Lasca, Emerald, Elsemarie, Merlin, Constellation, Mayflower, Marguerite, Loyal, and Neaera. After the signal for the sloops to start was given the big fleet of double-stickers were working round for good berths to start from.
The trial of Police Captain Joseph B. Eakins was resumed at Police Headquarters yesterday morning before Commissioner Andrews.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- Miss Elizabeth Flagler, daughter of Brig. Gen. Daniel W. Flagler, Chief of Ordnance, United States Army, shot and killed a colored youth named Ernest Green, whom she detected stealing fruit at the suburban residence of her father about noon to-day. Miss Flagler was discharged by the Coroner this evening on the ground that the homicide was unintentional.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 2. -- After hoping against hope for over two years the relatives of Frank Lenz, the missing bicycle rider, have come to the conclusion that he has been murdered, and in accordance with this fact this morning filed his will. The news which brought them to this decision was received by Arnold Schneider, the representative of the Turkish Government in this city.

" It was one of the tragedies of the plains whose history will never be known," remarked Col. W.H. Powell a few days since, in speaking of a thrilling scene which he witnessed nearly thirty years ago. The tragedy took place on the bank of the Platte River, in the region of Julesburg, this State.
Clifford Faithout Eagle, son of the late Commodore Henry Eagle, United States Navy, has been sued for a separation by his wife, Emily.

If it should transpire that there was building and fitting out somewhere a ship in the construction and equipment of which the object was to give her speed enough to overhaul any peaceable merchantman, force enough to overpower any peaceable merchantman, and speed enough to run away from any fighting ship, the announcement would be very startling.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- The case of Henry H. Spaulding, the broker, who was charged with grand larceny by George Lesher of Albion and arrested in New-York last week, came up in the police court this morning.

NEWPORT, Aug. 2. -- Of course the Vigilant people are happy over her victory, but Mr. Willard, when seen this evening, frankly confessed that the Defender had the Vigilant beaten when the accident occurred. He thought the Vigilant was sailing very well, but not quite so fast as she could be made to go.

ALBANY, Aug. 2. -- Gov. Morton this afternoon appointed Frederick W. Smith, M.D., of Syracuse, as a Commissioner of the State Board of Health to fill the vacancy caused by the expiration of the term of office of Dr. Florence O'Donohue. Dr. O'Donohue has been serving as the President of the board, and as a member of the tuberculosis commission.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 2. -- George J. Gould has won a Goelet cup with his yacht Vigilant. She was in luck to-day, and won the much-coveted trophy through the Defender's breaking down. The Defender had led all around the course, and was only five miles from the finish when her gaff snapped just about the middle of the spar, and she was put out of the race.

Henry F. Raabe, ex-Warden of Ludlow Street Jail, and Carl Schoen and Edward F. Schneer, the former keepers, gave bonds in $2,500 each yesterday to answer for their connection with the escape of the Post Office robbers on July 4.

Tenants in the fiat houses on the south side of East Twenty-fourth Street, between Second and Third Avenues, have complained lately that boys have reached the roofs of their houses by means of the dumbwaiters, which run from the cellars to the roofs of the houses.

Along in the late forties the papers were accustomed to run alleged witticisms, something in the style of a few of Hawthorne's writings, which pleased that gentleman so much that he kept up his lightest veins to the extent of outdoing them all.
ST. GEORGE, S.I., Aug. 2. -- Injunctions caused a temporary suspension of the three-cornered railroad war over the little triangular strip of property at Jay and South Streets to-day.

Dr. F.B. Peterson of Honesdale, Penn., was credited yesterday with writing a most peculiar letter. Should it be proved that he is really the author of the letter, the District Attorney may conclude to take the matter up.
Paul Grasser, sixty-two years old, sexton of the Ahawath Chesed Synagogue, Fifty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue, died suddenly in the vestibule of the place of worship last evening.

Tammany primaries having been held, and leaders selected in the thirty-five Assembly districts of this city, a natural curiosity exists among Democrats and Republicans alike, and those who, irrespective of party, were loudest in their condemnation of Tammany Hall last Fall, as to what are its plans for the coming campaign.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, Aug. 2. -- A beautiful day and clear, cool weather marked the last day of infantry work in the State Camp this year, and at both the early morning and forenoon drills the Twenty-second Regiment and Sixty-ninth Battalion made plenty of noise, as each soldier was provided with twenty rounds of blank ammunition. The drilling was up to the usual high standard of these two organizations.

Leffert L. Buck of 46 East Twenty-first Street was yesterday selected by the Commissioners of the new East River Bridge to be their chief engineer at an annual salary of $10,000. The Commissioners also agreed to ask Chief Engineer C.C. Martin of the Now-York and Brooklyn Bridge to accept the position of consulting engineer.

Dun's Review to-morrow: There is a perceptible halt which may deceive if attributed to wrong causes. Trade two months late in Spring pushed forward into July a large share of business belonging to April or May. Seeing a rush of orders out of time, many imagined it would continue, and-hurried to give other orders. The jam of two months business into one lifted prices.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- The performance of the Columbia is the subject of much favorable comment in the Navy Department and all the army and navy clubs.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 2. -- Gov. Morton of New-York arrived here this morning. His carriage awaited him at the wharf, and he went straight to the Bowlder, the beautiful little cottage where Mrs. Morton and the Misses Morton have been staying for some weeks past.

TRENTON, N.J. Aug. 2. -- In the absence of Frank A. Magowan, President and General Manager of the Trenton Rubber Company, an application was filed in the Court of Chancery to-day for the appointment of a receiver for the concern. Magowan is in Chicago and has telegraphed that he will be in Trenton in a day or two.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Aug. 2. -- Judge W.A. Millen of the law division of the Post Office Department has rendered a decision which will govern the delivery of mail matter by jail officials to convicts in penitentiaries. The same ruling will be applicable to inmates of charitable institutions, at the discretion of the officials. The ruling is as follows:

J.J. Quinn, a guard on the Sixth Avenue elevated road had to exert himself last night while his car was rounding the One Hundred and Tenth Street curve to keep from "being thrown from the platform of his car by an intoxicated or insane passenger, who had taken offense at Quinn's awakening him at the One Hundred and Fourth Street Station.

WEST POINT, Aug. 2. -- August is the most enjoyable part of the social season at West Point. Cadet life is then full of bustle and excitement, and the corps makes a special effort to amuse and entertain visitors. The color line entertainment is given before camp breaks up. The furlough men return and tents are struck Aug. 28, unless that date should fall on Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- The Bannock Indian scare seems to have ended. The Indians are returning to their reservation. They have not been fighting, and have no desire to fight.

SARATOGA, Aug. 2. -- This was the second day of the Third Annual Shakespearean Open-Air Festival at the Grand Union Hotel. On the lawn to-night, under the elms, was performed Shakespeare's comedy "The Merry Wives of Windsor" by the following cast:

There will be another cycle race meet at the Manhattan Beach track this afternoon, three Class A and four professional events comprising the programme The prospects are bright for better sport than was witnessed last Saturday. Sanger, Tyler, Porter, and Wheeler are announced as competitors, and doubtless many will have a curiosity to see what they will do in the cash prize contests.
BUFFALO, Aug. 2. -- Robert J. and Joe Patchen, the kings of the pacing division of the harness-horse world, will meet in a match race at the Buffalo Driving Park next Wednesday for $5,000 a side.

Sir Isaac Newton made several experiments with a view to the improvement of refracting telescopes, but came to the conclusion that it was impossible to get rid of the chromatic aberration produced by lenses! He then turned his attention to the construction of telescopes with metallic mirrors -- first suggested by James Gregory, a Scotchman, in 1663 -- and succeeded in making several which gave satisfactory results.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2. -- Congressman Samuel G. Hilborn has returned from a five weeks' trip to the Sandwich Islands, where he went to enjoy a rest and, incidentally, study the various questions that have racked the little Government from end to end within the last two years.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- The Duchess de Casteluccia of the Burlington, 10 West Thirtieth Street, New-York, died suddenly of heart failure at Cranston's Hotel this morning. The Duchess came here with her maid about ten days ago, with the hope of benefiting her failing health.

The strike of the United Garment Workers against the contractors is practically over. Nothing remains now to prevent a peaceful settlement except the time necessary to sign the contracts for the ensuing year.

What a magnificent cyclorama it would make if some artist could depict upon canvas the streets of Richmond as they appeared on the day of any of the great battles that were fought in the near vicinity of the city! What an opportunity to portray the human emotions and passions which possessed them on such thrilling occasions!

Nothing is more instructive than to notice how frequently and with what bitterness of righteous indignation men who are in politics for revenue only protest against the display by clergymen of any interest in local, State, or National politics. A case in point is that of certain ex-members of Good Government Club Z.

Mother Francis Raphael, who was Miss Augusta Drane, was one of the English Protestants who, at the time of the Oxford movement, went into the Catholic Church. She joined the Dominican Order and ultimately Lecame the head of their convent at Stone, where she died two years ago.

The climate of Italy renders it difficult and almost impossible to have flowers growing in the ground all through the Summer-After the magnificent efflorescence of May and June, the soil cakes into the consistence of terra cotta, and the sun, which has expanded and withered the roses and lilies and vines with such marvelous rapidity, toasts everything like so much corn or maize.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 2. -- The funeral services of the Right Rev. Mark Antony De Wolf Howe, D.D., LL, D., Bishop of Central Pennsylvania, were held at 2 o'clock to-day at Bristol.
SARATOGA, Aug. 2. -- In spite of the fact that the Racing Association has made admission to the track free to ladles accompanied by gentlemen, the attendance at the races was light again to-day.
Regardless of the fact that the New-York Baseball Club had some 6,000 spectators at the Polo Grounds yesterday to welcome them home, they were beaten by the ball-tossers from Brooklyn.

" Before the white men came we were men," said a Chippewa friend. These people look back upon their past as upon a lost paradise, in which there were happiness and innocence. They repudiate the descriptions of them written by white historians, as the work of enemies, seeking to justify cruelties and wrongs.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 2. -- The Directors of the University Extension movement, at Oak Beach, voted to-day to sustain Gilbert Elliott, Jr., Treasurer and Business Manager of the concern, in his attempt to keep the grounds open Sunday.

The late Col. Thomas L. Lang, who died recently in Oregon, was a very prominent Maine horse breeder about twenty-five years ago. He was then a man of wealth and could indulge in his fondness for fine horses to any extent that he fancied. He bought and bred many notable horses.

SARATOGA, Aug. 2. -- Ex-Lieut. Gov. Sheehan and Senator Cantor, who enjoyed the races this afternoon, know of no immediate conference of Democrats here. They think, however, that there will be an abundance of political gossip in the near future. Senator Murphy says substantially the same thing.

There is considerable mystery surrounding the death of Richard Pyne, forty years old, who was killed early yesterday morning by falling from a window on the third floor of his home at 217 Monroe Street.

The officials of the Navy Department will not be disappointed upon learning that the commerce destroyer Columbia, which arrived from Southampton yesterday, broke no speed records in transit. No one acquainted with the conditions of the test supposed that she would.

The members of the Brookfield League of the Eighth Assembly District, who are opposed to the Platt organization in that district, are going to hold a mass meeting soon to denounce the rule of ex-Police Commissioner Charles H. Murray and demand his retirement from the leadership.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 2. -- After nearly six hours of hard work the Grand Circuit cracks were not able to complete their engagements here to-day as was intended. In fact, only one race was over when darkness came. A very much mixed contest in the 2:17 trot was chiefly responsible for the delay, and this event, though it started the day's sport, is still at issue.
Favorites broke all records for Brighton Beach yesterday by winning all six of the races, Taral riding two of them -- Silk in the first race, and Our Jack in the fourth.

ONEIDA, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- A- conference of Republicans of Madison County was held here to-day to discuss propositions submitted by the Senatorial Committee of Oswego County, regarding representation in the coming Senatorial Convention. Oswego and Madison Counties were tied together by the new apportionment as the Thirty-seventh District.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Aug. 2. -- The first enjoyable time for driving or loafing out of doors since Monday was to-day. The baseball club took advantage of it to heat Waterville 7 to 3 before a large number of spectators. Clarence Levin seized the opportunity for the first good day's driving since his arrival. Every one who has horses followed his example.

The delightful weather and the fine programme drew a large crowd to the Brighton Beach race track yesterday. There were a number of withdrawals from the different events, and these proved very beneficial, as the entries in the original programme were too numerous for the narrow track. There were a number of surprises during the afternoon, but it was not a disastrous day for the crowd, as three of the six favorites were winners.

The "Immigration Restriction League," having its headquarters in Boston, announces that it has prepared a bill to be introduced in Congress at the next session. The bill is described, and its chief effects predicted, as follows:

A poolroom under the guise of a broker's office, of the kind usually denominated "bucket shops," has been doing business for some time at 5 New Street. The place has been conducted by Thomas Barrett, twenty-seven years old, of 127 East Thirty-fifth Street, who fitted up the establishment in a manner to give the public the impression that he was doing a stock brokerage business.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Carl Browne has not separated from his bride, nee Coxey, the heroine of last year's famous army of the Commonweal. At least Mr. and Mrs. Browne are quoted this afternoon as saying it is not true. Browne is preparing to issue a monthly paper to be called "Carl's Cactus,'' which is expected to make its first appearance on the 16th inst.
BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 3. GAYETY without end there has been here during the week. Not in years has Bay Shore been so full of life.
There is a tendency toward higher prices in meats. Beef of first quality is scarce and difficult to obtain, the retail dealers say.
The National Council of Jewish Women is a very promising offspring of the Woman's Congress held at Chicago in 1893 at the time of the Columbian Exposition.

CITY OF MEXICO, July 15. -- The train rolled out of the Americanisms of San Antonio -- the coal and lumber yards, the lines of freight cars, the innumerable tracks and black cinder paths -- and into the southern expanses of mesquite.
FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., Aug. 3. BLUEFISHING has given many of the guests here a taste of "life on the ocean wave" during the week. It has been the chief pastime.
LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 3. LONG BEACH continues to be a highly desirable resort, and those who love the quiet enjoyment of life afforded by this place have come year after year.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 3. -- The dates for the subscription concerts by the Orange Mendelssohn Union next season have been fixed for Dec. 9, Feb. 17, and April 27. The first concert, which will be a week before the one hundred and twenty-fifth anniversary of Beethoven's birthday, will consist entirely of selections from Beethoven's works. The union will begin rehearsals in High School Hall Sept. 30.

The championship cricket match between Staten Island and Brooklyn, played yesterday at Livingston, did not have the expected close termination, for the Islanders gained an easy victory by 53 runs and 6 wickets to spare, and the Brooklyns met with their first defeat.

LENOX, Aug. 3. -- The Saturday afternoon tea at the Mahkeenac Lake Boat Clubhouse was fairly well attended this afternoon, although the mercury did not reach much above 60, and the west wind was blowing briskly, with occasional flurries of rain. It was a good breeze for sailing, but many of the best skippers among the girls, including Miss Stokes, Miss Sands, and Miss Anna Sands, were away.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 3. SOCIETY has been surfeited with hopsand germans this week, and there have been progressive euchre parties, tally-ho excursions, and sailing trips galore. The german given at the Coleman Hotel was really a fashionable affair.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 3. -- It is learned here that Nat Herreshoff made an offer to Secretary Herbert of the navy yesterday, just before the Secretary left for Gray Gables, to build a torpedo boat capable of attaining 27 1/2 knots an hour for $150,000.

The funeral services of Police Captain Michael J. Murphy, former commander of the West One Hundredth Street Police Station, who died at his residence, 159 West One Hundred and Fourth Street, Wednesday morning, after being ill for several months with Bright's disease, were held yesterday morning at the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Name, Ninety-sixth Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

The trained nurse no longer excites comment. That stage of public incredulity which is sure to be developed at all advance that means innovation was in her case shortlived. The pupil so soon showed the value of study and training that antagonism quickly gave way. There was for a time, indeed, a semi-protest made against the stereotyped rules and regulations urged upon sick persons.

ALBANY, Aug. 3. -- Frank Fowler's oil portrait of ex-Gov. Flower has hung in the Executive Chamber for three weeks now, and the consensus of opinion is that the likeness is not a good one of the original.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., Aug. 3. -- Although this resort is considered as rather small, in comparison with some of the others along the New-Jersey coast, yet the people who live here during the Summer months are most of them prominent in society. There is not a resort along the coast that is any better patronized than this place.

The Government has just concluded the purchase of valuable property near the heart of the city for the use of a high school. It is the mansion which was built fifteen years ago at great cost by Princess Ruth Keelikolani, who had inherited all the great estates of the Kamehamehas. She soon after died. Her heir was her cousin, the very lovely and noble half-white Princess Bernice Panahi Bishop.
LENOX, Mass., Aug. 8. EW people have yet left Lenox. The weather continues cool and delightful, and the copious rains have made the roads excellent for driving and wheeling.
" Well, I agree with you," Police Commissioner Grant's acquiescent comment on Capt. Eakins's designation of his trial as "a crime" may result in Col. Grant's retirement from the Police Board.

BUFFALO, Aug. 8. -- A third figure was brought into the Emery-Cottle case to-day In the person of Herbert Auerbach, formerly of this city, whose parents reside in Boston. Lawyer Pentecost charges Auerbach with acting in collusion with Carlton Strong in securing money from Emery. It is said that Auerbach handled all the money.

The members of the St. James's Young Men's Catholic Association of Brooklyn are highly elated over the apostolic benediction sent to them in commemoration of the twenty-fifth anniversary, which was held Sunday, July 21. The society has a membership of 180.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 3. -- William Kent, a water expert employed by private parties to examine the water bids submitted by the East Jersey, Jersey City, and Rockaway and Hudson County Companies, to-day reported that the bid of the Rockaway and Hudson County Company was the best for the city.
SEA CLIFF, L.I., Aug. 3. SEA CLIFF has taken good care of Summer guests, as usual, this season, and an overflow of visitors is expected for the month of August.

LONDON, Aug. 3. -- The concluding meeting of the sixth International Geographical Congress was held in the Imperial Institute to-day. The President, Clements Markham, announced that it had been decided to hold the next meeting at Berlin in 1899.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of The New-York Times.

SANTA BARBARA, Cal., Aug. 3. -- Alexander McIver Tyndall, the mind reader, proposes to undertake a feat never before attempted in this country. This is to be buried alive for ten days, at the expiration of which period he promises to rise from the grave.

Full-dress suits and patent leather shoes do not always carry with them the ability to write fine letters. This was proved by a missive from the pen of William Swift, a burglar who broke into Dr. John C. McPherson's house Saturday, and after taking a bath stole a dress suit, patent leather shoes, silk hat, $70, and other things.

LITTLE SILVER, N.J., Aug. 3. -- This pretty little riverside resort is enjoying a prosperous season. The boarding-houses are well filled, and all the cottages occupied. The principal amusements of the Summer guests are boating, bathing, and crabbing.

The office of the United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers, of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by the United Press.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 3. -- Morris K. Jesup gave a dinner party to fourteen guests to-night in honor of Gov. Morton and Gen. Horace Porter.

Ex-Mayor Hugh J. Grant has returned to this city from his bridal trip in Europe. He and Mrs. Grant, who is the daughter of United States Senator Edward Murphy, Jr., arrived on the American Line steamship St. Louis, which reached her pier at 7 o'clock yesterday morning.

Europe has been fortunate thus far this season with respect to cholera. It will be recalled that the disease was carried last Summer from the infected Russian provinces into Germany, France, Belgium, and Austria, and that it lingered in those countries for months, although the mortality was not large, except in Galicia.

Stockholders of the Bank of America received a circular yesterday, accompanied by a notice for a special meeting, signed by President William H. Perkins, Frederic P. Olcott, Samuel Thorne, George A. Crocker, David S. Egleston, John Harson Rhoades, George G. Haven, James N. Jarvie, and Dallas B. Pratt, a majority of the Directors, asking them to consider a proposition to reduce the bank's capital from $3,000,000 to $1,500,000.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3. RAIN and cold wind have marred a week's programme of outdoor enjoyment. The ball club found three fair days in Monday, Wednesday, and Friday, and put in its schedule; but it was too chilly for comfort.
-- A table compiled by The Financial Chronicle shows that the gross earnings of eighty railroads for the third week in July aggregated $6,644,935, an increase of 5.65 per cent. over last year.

The readers of The New-York Times are herewith presented with a copy in full of the text of the treaty of peace between Japan and China, the ratifications of which were exchanged at Che-Foo, China, May 8, 1895. The substance of the convention has been made known, but the detailed and authorized translations of the language of the treaty have not been heretofore published.

Edward Earl Simpson, who says he is a capitalist and real estate dealer, was arraigned in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning on a charge of defrauding his landlady; Mrs. Sarah Beach of 244 West Thirty-fourth Street, out of $25, by means of a worthless draft.
The Chamber of Commerce is very much encouraged by the reports just received from prominent people in the several States as to the status of the silver craze.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- The body of citizen soldiery that came into camp last week as the Sixty-ninth Battalion marched proudly out to-day as the Sixty-ninth Regiment. In command of it was Col. George Moore Smith, prouder than any of the men who tramped behind him.

In prison life there is no immutability; either development or degeneracy prevail. The average convict, unless his fate be kindly -- which may mean unless he dies young -- goes out and then comes back for another term, which leads to a third, and then on and on in a dreary revolution of crime.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3. A TELEGRAM was sent from here this week stating that Judge Henry Hilton's mansion had been rented for a clubhouse, and would be opened as such inside of a week.
RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- The baseball cranks are despondent over another defeat at Cooperstown this afternoon. Richfield was outplayed, and lost the game on errors by a score of 7 to 2.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3. -- The police have nothing to announce in the Holmes case to-day. Superintendent Badenoch was not in his office during the day, and Inspector Fitzpatrick was engaged with other matters. He said work was being pursued on the case upon the lines suggested on information gained from the Quinlans.
SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Aug. 3. -- At the Democratic County Convention this afternoon two tickets were named and two sets of delegates to the State Convention selected. There was much disorder.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 8. -- Lumber merchants along the shore front and owners of boats have for the last few weeks been reporting almost daily to the police that their places were robbed. The police tried to get a clue as to the river thieves, but were unsuccessful until yesterday, when the police learned that the schooner.

In your notice of the death of the late Bishop Howe of Central Pennsylvania, published on the 1st inst,. I observe the statement that the recent Assistant Bishop, Dr. Rulison, will now assume the "title" as well as "duties" of Bishop. Lest this expression be misunderstood, please allow me to explain that Bishop Rulison assumed the full title and dignity of the episcopate on his consecration in 1884.
STAMFORD, N.Y., Aug. 3. THE mountain population was increased largely in every section and the large hotels have now assumed their old-time activity, with a large list of daily arrivals.
Acting Capt. Thompson of the Oak Street Police Station had a narrow escape from being shot last night by the proprietor of an alleged disorderly house he and his men were raiding at 9 James Street.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., Aug. 3. -- The new Hay Lake channel will pay for itself within a very few years. This result will be attained by reason of the saving that will be made owing to the shorter distance freight will be carried in using the new channel.

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- Another year has rolled around, and Sing Sing is upon the threshold of another Methodist Episcopal camp meeting -- one of the things for which this musically named village is famed far and wide, for everybody has heard of the old Methodist camp meetings On Sing Sing Heights.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 3. -- The Toledo Cycling Club gave its annual National Circuit meet today. A good field of Class B men was present. It was unfortunate that the track was in soft condition, being three inches deep in dust at the turns. Gardiner rode but one race, and then quit for the day. Murphy won his usual first and withdrew from further contests.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 3. -- Vice-President Alfred W. Booth, of the Mechanics' Trust Company of Bayonne, accompanied by his wife and the Misses Booth, will cruise along the Sound and off the Massachusetts coast on board their steam yacht Scionda, during the coming fortnight. The party will spend several weeks at their Summer home, on Brandt Island, Mass.

The undersigned begs to draw your attention to an article in to-day's issue of your paper purporting to give an account of the argument of certain motions argued yesterday before Judge Gaynor of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn in the case of the Tradesmen's National Bank against John W. Young Sons, but which is incorrect in various respects, and as a consequence is liable to injuriously affect the parties concerned.

It was an interesting morning a week ago at the Clark University Summer School when the subject of "Child Study" was taken up, and the great audience which listened to the various speakers forgot the day's heat and sultriness in the intensity of their attention and interest.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- The weather on the river to-day has been delightful and the spirits of the Summer visitors are rising accordingly. The rainy weather and bleak winds of the fore part of the week came quite unexpectedly and did not prove very congenial to the Summer population of the islands. Nevertheless, pople took the unseasonable weather good naturedly and made the best of the inevitable.

ELBERON, N.J., Aug. 3. -- The early August days have seen a few changes in the cottage settlement here, and quite a number of additions among the guests at Mr. Jordan's pretty hostelry, The Elberon. Prominent among these are Mayor Strong, Mrs. Strong, and their son, who arrived on Thursday and will remain throughout August.

SUMMIT, N.J., Aug. 3. -- The ladies interested report having netted $275 for the benefit of the Fresh-Air Home, at the fair given last week. The fair was under the direction of Mrs. W.H. Wheeler, Mrs. A.B. Kingsbury, and Miss Falconer.
With the aid of a ruby-colored vial, Mrs. Henrietta Reinhard, otherwise Dr. Henrietta Heidecker, made things exceedingly lively for a time yesterday in the Common Pleas, Special Term, courtroom.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 3. -- A.D. Brundage of Park Street has in his possession two fine live deer which he and F.B. Miller of Brooklyn captured while on a recent hunting trip in Michigan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The Navy Department is somewhat restive under the delay of President Cleveland in acting upon about twenty-five cases which affect officers of the navy. A number of these are court-martial cases, notable among which is that of Medical Inspector Kirshner, whose trial at the New-York Navy Yard grew out of a complaint formulated by Admiral Meade.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Machinery has just been installed in the Watervliet (N.Y.) Arsenal by the army ordnance officers for the mechanical work on rifles of sixteen-inch calibre, the largest guns made in this country. Congress has, so far, persistently refrained from making the appropriation necessary for the manufacture of these weapons.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3. -- Charles H. Cramp, President of the William Cramp Sons Ship and Engine Building Company, the builders of the cruiser Columbia, manifested no surprise over the vessel's fast run from Southampton. Some weeks ago Mr. Cramp made the statement that if the Columbia made an average speed of seventeen knots an hour continuously throughout a 3,000-mile voyage, she would do something that no war vessel had ever done before.

Just now one week is very much like its predecessor so far as real estate conditions and dealings go. The past seven days have shown the same kind of activity, unusual at this period of the year, which the other weeks of July exhibited. Much of the activity is that of preparation for Fall, but a fair proportion has to do with pending negotiations.

The Defender, after all, may be not very much faster than the Vigilant, and yet the trials, so far, have lacked one element of conclusiveness which might be supplied, and it is only by sailing under the same conditions that the relative merits of our two fastest yachts can be determined.

GOOD GROUND, L.I., Aug. 3. IN this picturesque little village, the name of which, more properly speaking, is Ponquogue, which surrounds the Shinnecock Light, there has recently been organized an association known as the Shinnecock Bay Improvement Association, whose members are made up of Summer residents, as well as permanent residents of the place.

When the stock market receives a sudden blow, that particular structure in it which happens for the moment to be top heavy, comes down with a run, and considerable confusion and scurrying away are observable about that time. When the gold shipments were announced Friday, the top-heavy speculative structure proved to be Sugar, and down it came. It made things lively for a while.

After a lapse of six years the managers of the New-York and Harlem Railroad have determined to resume within ninety days the running of storage battery cars on their city lines. Arrangements have been made with the Storage Battery Company to equip cars for immediate service.

COTTAGE CITY, Mass., Aug. 3. -- The Defender was towed down from Bristol early this morning to Newport, and was ready on time to start with the other yachts in the run to Vineyard Haven. She had a new hollow gaff, a new boom, and carried a new mainsail. These spars and sails were made by the Herreshoffs, and considerably increased her sail area.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 3. -- Founder James A. Bradley is opposed to "straw ride" parties, and he doesn't care who knows it. These after-dark excursions are made in old-fashioned hay wagons. They have been a favorite diversion for the hotel guests from time immemorial, and the liverymen hereabouts have thousands of dollars invested in "straw ride" outfits.

It was my very good fortune to be in Santa Fe some years ago during a National Indian festival. As the greater part of the programme consisted of dances by the different tribes, I was afforded an excellent opportunity to observe these curious ceremonies, which form such an important factor in the life of an Indian.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 3. -- Henry Seligman gave a dinner to ten of his friends at the Pennsylvania Club yesterday.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 3. -- ENJOYABLE has been the week for the large number of society people who are making their Summer homes at the hotels on the River Thames, and in the Pequot and Eastern Point colonies.

The attention of everybody in this town who reads the newspapers must have been arrested by the extraordinary incident in the trial of Capt. Eakins, reported in yesterday's Times. It came out, under the examination of Col. Fred Grant, that in almost thirty years of service on the force Capt. Eakins had saved about $14,000, and that this trial had put him to the necessity of spending $4,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- A cable message received at the State Department to-day from Mr. Jernigan, the United States Consul General at Shanghai, reports a massacre of Christians at Kucheng, China. No Americans were killed, but one was seriously wounded.

Seaside belles and dignified elderly men and women have set a new fashion at the watering places this season. Nine-tenths of them have displayed a fondness for the wheel that has scored a clean knock-out against equestrianism, boating, tennis, and bowling, and it has been noticeable that the ballrooms have been minus their brightest ornaments when moonlight runs were on the schedule.

If they do not do all things better abroad they certainly do some very differently. For some time past there has been a pretty lively discussion -- which not even the elections have entirely stopped -- in the English press of two strictly social questions which, in our older States at least, are regarded as fairly well settled.

SARATOGA, Aug. 3. -- To-day's attendance at the track showed a marked increase over that of yesterday. The weather was clear, but threatening, and the track was in excellent shape. The principal event on the card was the Kearney Stakes, valued at $2,000, which was won by Clifford, a hot favorite, by half a length.

LONG BRANCH, N.J. Aug. 3. IN spite of the cool weather of the last few days, the hotels all along the shore have had a better average of guests this week than at any other time since they opened their places this season.

BREWSTER, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- The Pittsfield train of the Harlem Division of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad was wrecked at she south switch, near Craryville Station, at 12:27 P.M. to-day. The train was in charge of Conductor John D. Cameron. The engineer was E. Hallett, and the fireman M. Elliott.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- (Copyright, 1895, by The New-York Times.) -- With all the good-will in the world, Europe is not permitted to take its mind off Bulgaria. By day and by night this wretched little community sits on the Old World's chest. It will not be shaken off. The week's developments seem on the surface to have wrought a great change in the Balkan outlook.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 3. PERFECT weather has made outdoor sports even more popular than ever this week. Everything at present is golf, the tennis courts presenting rather a deserted appearance.
The enforcement of the excise law forms the subject of an important letter from Dr. Parkhurst to Augustus W. Abbott, the Secretary of the City Vigilance League.

A romantic story comes from Brunn, the capital of Moravia. A journeyman baker and his sweetheart determined to commit suicide together by drowning themselves in the Schwarza. The young man was out of work and saw no prospect of being able to get married. The couple carried out their fatal resolve, and their bodies were found in the river.

The recent publication of a novel by George Gissing which embodies a powerful study of some of the evil effects of democratic influences on social life has been closely followed by the welcome appearance of a new volume of Prof. Dowden's collected essays, which he introduces with an amiable but not altogether hopeful discussion of the leveling influences of democracy upon literature.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 8. NEWPORT society has suddenly found itself very busy. From July to August it was but a step, yet it was from repose to great social activity, and now all are on the go.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- Unpropitious weather has caused a break in the three-day programme of the third annual Shakespearean lawn festival at the Grand Union Hotel. The annual carnival for children was to have been this afternoon's attraction, but at midday the weather looked threatening and compelled a postponement of the festival, including the Shakespearean ball, announced for to-night, until Monday.

We often hear of the "logical candidate" of a party, but the most remarkable reasoning power has been displayed by the Populist Convention of Ohio in reaching the conclusion of Coxey for Governor from the premises of its platform. The customary Populist platform was expanded with a special plank to fit the broad gauge of the Commander of the Army of the Commonweal, but it is harmonious with the rest of the structure.
Meyer Schoenfeld, of the Brotherhood of Tailors, said last night that most of the shops will be opened to-morrow, when 10,000 strikers will return to work.

SHELTER ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 3. DURING the pleasant weather of the week outdoor amusements have been more than usually popular, and only in the evenings could many of the guests be found together at the hotels.
FIRE ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 3. TUESDAY night the number of guests was greatly augmented. Among the arrivals was the Drexel party of New-York, consisting of Mrs. Joseph Drexel, Miss Drexel, and a friend.

NORMANDIE-BY-THE-SEA, N.J., Aug. 3. -- The social season of Normandie-by-the-Sea is at its height, and every evening sees some entertainment provided by the proprietor, Gen. F.P. Earle, for the amusement of his guests.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 3. -- While James Diggens, a plumber employed by George Leath, was making a water-pipe connection at the house 326 Atlantic Avenue, this city, this morning his shovel struck a piece of rotten wood. He pushed the wood aside, thinking nothing of it, but was surprised by seeing some coin looking like gold run out of the box.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- A sensational story was circulated this afternoon that a lad Oscar Reid, of this city had been killed in the alley in the rear of the Japanese Legation for an alleged attempt to steal fruit from one of the peach trees in the legation yard, the affair being to that extent parallel to the Flagler shooting on Washington Heights yesterday.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- Robert Wrenn, the United States tennis champion, will be a visitor to Lake Placid next week. He has just returned from a visit to his home in Boston, and proposes to enter the Paul Smith, Lake Placid, and Ampersand tourneys. George A. Stevens, the Stevens House champion, will play against Mr. Wrenn, "just for fun," when he comes.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Aug. 3. -- With the beginning of August, Hot Springs enters upon the best month of the season. The hotels and cottages are already well filled, but people and applications for rooms continue to pour in in a manner that promises to make this the red-letter month, not only of this, but of any previous season.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Aug. 3. -- Under Sheriff John J. Irwin and Constables Locke and MCCothick to-night made. a raid upon a pool room in the Amsterdam Hotel, Second and River Streets, and arrested John '. King and arraigned him before Justice of the Peace George Seymour, on a charge of conducting, aiding, and carrying on a pool room.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Aug. 3. -- One of the pleasantest social affairs ever held here was the second annual lawn fete of St. Mary's Guild, an energetic society connected with Christ Church, Tuesday afternoon and evening. It took place at W.F. Mott's, and was a profitable as well as highly successful social event, the net receipts amounting to over $300. Music was furnished by Winckler's Seventh Regiment (N.G.S.N.J.) Orchestra of Trenton.

READING, Mass., Aug. 3 -- The third annual ten-mile Austin road race was held here this afternoon and was witnessed by about 5,000 people. The roads and weather were very favorable. There were ninety-five men in the race. The prizese consisted of jewelry, clothing, medals, revolvers, and various other articles. The time prize, a bicycle, was won by "Eddie" McDuffee of Malden, a scratch man, in 27:33 2-5.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 3. -- A few days ago, George Beecher of Bridgeport and James Thompson of New-Haven came to this city, and introduced themselves to the most prominent citizens as special agents of the Granite State Provident Association, a building and loan organization situated at Manchester, N.H. They wished to start a branch of the concern in Norwalk, and they produced typewritten prospectuses which promised alluring returns.

So full and valuable a collection of "tracts of the times" as that bequeathed by Moses Sheppard of Baltimore to the asylum for the insane that bears his name is rarely to be met with in private libraries. Born in Pennsylvania in December, 1773, about six months before the destruction of tea in Boston Harbor, his early years were passed in close touch with the stirring incidents that marked the birth of the Republic.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Gen. Coppinger, in a telegram to Army Headquarters received to-day, thus describes the situation in the Bannock Indian country:

CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 3. MORE visitors are here at present than at any time since the season began. The season of gayety is at its height, too. Next week will be just as gay, and then the decline will begin. The week has been a notable one for brilliant events of the ordinary seashore kind.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 3. -- The tennis tournament of the South Orange Field Club ended here to-day, George Miles winning the handicap without any difficulty. He was greatly helped by the defaulting of Holcombe Ward, who has been playing such good tennis this week. The scores follow:

WESTCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- The announced invasion of the New-York dog catchers to-day upon this rural suburb of the metropolis created a great deal of excitement for a while, and the place is now minus many curs which never will be missed. At the same time, some really valuable dogs were indiscriminately bagged and carried to the pound

GLASGOW, July 24. -- American cablers have been sending across the Atlantic news of Defender's speed which has filled Glasgow with rejoicing. The cablers can only supply second-hand information, and in my experience the press has been generally well pleased to accept it.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- In an interview to-day Senator O'Connor said: "It has been claimed that the enforcement of the Sunday closing laws in New-York City will operate to the disadvantage of the party to which President Roosevelt is affiliated. I do not know why it should, and I do not believe it will.

Miss Flagler's unintentional killing of the negro boy at Washington establishes conclusively and for the nth time the only safe rule of conduct for a woman with firearms. Miss Flagler declares that she raised the window, and, without aiming the weapon, fired two shots into the wide, wide world, her design being merely to frighten the young African who was stealing her father's pears.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The American nuns who were compelled to leave Ecuador by the revolutionists, have not made any complaint to the State Department supplemental to the statement recently made in their behalf and that of the other inmates of the convent, by ex-Congressman Timothy J. Campbell of New-York.

The early settlers in America paid no attention toward protecting themselves against fire, and the different Colonies had grown into fair-sized communities, with several industries well established, before any steps were taken in that direction. About the earliest mention of a definite method of fire protection was made at Salem, Mass., in 1644, when each inhabitant was ordered to be supplied with a ladder, under penalty of a fine of 5s.
BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 3. AUGUST opened with no let up in the season's gayeties at this place. Many new guests have arrived at the Argyle, and the engagements for the month are large.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 3. -- Ex-City Judge William R. Coddington's family of Sanford Avenue is spending the Summer at Millington.

SOUTHAMPTON, Aug. 3. -- The ceremonies of opening the new graving dock which took place here to-day were marred somewhat by the heavy rain which fell throughout the forenoon, spoiling the decorations and making everything as disagreeable as possible for the thousands of visitors.

LONDON, Aug. 3. -- The week at Cowes promises to be a brilliant one. The distinguished assemblage will include Emperor William of Germany, the Prince of Wales, the Duke of York, and the Duke of Connaught, while the Queen, the Princess of Wales, and Princesses Victoria and Maud will be at Osborne, near by.
ARVERNE-BY-THE-SEA, Aug. 3. HOTEL Arverne continues to be the centre of attraction. Scarcely a day goes by without something of more than ordinary note taking place there.
He Has Driven Her from Home Many Times, She Declares -- Unpleasant Ways of Protecting Her.
LONDON, Aug. 4. -- The Telegraph to-morrow will print a dispatch from Shanghai, stating that the massacre at Kucheng occurred July 31. The officials suppressed the news for three days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- Private advices received from Guatemala this evening state that President Barrios of Guatemala has formed a secret alliance with Costa Rica, looking to the formation of a union of all the Central American States, with Guatemala exercising the dominant influence in the new federation.

There is no part of our country to which the bicycle has not now penetrated, carrying many blessings in its train -- the blessing of better roads, the blessing of better maps, the promise and potency of better rural inns. Among the first of these blessings we have not hesitated to reckon the abolition of trousers.

William Shaughnessy keeps a saloon at 50 Broad Street. He is only twenty-five years old, but is reputed to be wealthy. For the past month he has lived in the flat on the third floor of 19 Stuyvesant Place, but the hours he kept were such that he seldom met the other tenants in the house.

COWES, Isle of Wight, Aug. 4. -- Cowes Roads to-day presented a brilliant sight, at least 100 yachts being anchored there. Many of these craft fly racing flags, forty of which are displayed by the Prince of Wales's cutter Britania, while Mr. Howard Gould's Niagara flies thirty.

DANSVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- In consequence of the serious illness of Mrs. Talmage, the Rev. T. De Witt Talmage, D.D., has been compelled to cancel his engagements to preach and lecture in the West. He was to have preached to-day at Salem, Neb., and had prepared a sermon on the subject of "Man Overboard."

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 4. -- To-day has been one of the most delightful Sundays of the season at this resort, and more people have been seen around the hotels and upon the Ocean Drive than on any previous day this Summer.

As the Grand Circuit approaches the Empire State the vexed betting problem that has been a disturber of the trotting turfman's peace for the last nine months, comes up afresh. Knowing that it is out of the question to have poolselling at Buffalo, Rochester, or New-York, the auctioneers and those who look after the mutuals fled incontinently to Terre Haute from Cleveland.
PRINCETON, Ill., Aug. 4. -- Italian miners of Spring Valley to-day attacked the negro miners, and injured a large number. The trouble has been brewing for some time.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 4. -- The week which will open Monday no doubt will be the liveliest of the season. Great preparations are being made for various events, all of which promise to be great successes.

ANNAPOLIS, Aug. 3. -- While most of the naval cadets are away on the Summer cruise, yet there is still a goodly crowd who spend the hot months in Annapolis. They stay here for instruction in practical work on land. They consist of two large divisions. First there is the engineer division of the first class.

Charles M. Wood is a mining engineer. He is fifty years old, strong and robust. He has been living for about two weeks with his married sister and his mother, at 441 East One Hundred and Twenty-third Street, although his home is in Hoboken, where his wife now lives, at 616 Grand Street.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- Walter Barnes and Frank Williams were theorizing on the Holmes case last night while sitting in the rear part of O.A. Hesla Co.'s jewelry store, 570 West Madison Street. All the gruesome details had been recalled one by one, and the conversation became decidedly interesting to both young men.

NYACK, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- The heaviest rainfall in many years was recorded here this afternoon at about 3 o'clock, flooding parts of the town. There are deep wash-ours in all the streets running east and west, small rivers forming and running with terrible force down the hills. In some instances flagwalks were washed away, cellars were flooded, gardens were drowned, and on several streets it was impossible for a time to cross.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4. -- The Hawaiian sugar planters have undertaken to form a combination which has for its object the breaking down of the American Sugar Trust, and the establishment of a free market for sugar. Nearly $1,000,000 has been subscribed by leading and influential planters, and the Spreckels Brothers of this city have been asked to join the combination.
There was probably less liquor sold over the bars of saloons in this city yesterday than on any previous Sunday since the strict enforcement of the excise law was begun.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 4. -- The several services to-day on the camp grounds attracted large crowds of worshippers. The young people's meeting at 9 A.M. was conducted by Evangelist Charles H. Yattman, and the holiness meeting at the same hour was in charge of the Rev. Dr. R.J. Daniels.

Prince Francis of Teck recently wagered 10,000 against 1,000 on the result of a horse race. He didn't have the 10,000, but that was a wholly inconsequential matter, as he knew absolutely which horse it was that "couldn't lose," and which was, therefore, by the plainest rules of logic, dead sure to win.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- Passed East -- Steam yachts Aquila, Anita J., G. Cassett; Neaera, Charles A. Gould; Lorna, W.L. Stow, and Linta, Walter Luttgen; schooner yachts Trinculo, Morrill Goddard; Alert, C.A. Griscom: Atalanta, F.W. Savin, and Azalea, J. Clinch Smith; sloop yacht Hope, Joseph Bauer.
Any one who had the price yesterday could have bought unlimited quantities of rum and beer in Brooklyn -- the "City of Churches," the "City of Homes."

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 4. -- Excursions from Providence and Boston and adjoining places, bringing hundreds, gave Newport a busy appearence to-day. With the cottagers it was a quiet day, Perry Belmont's sailing party on the Satanella being the only important social event. Mrs. E.G.H. Slater entertained this evening at dinner.

SPOKANE, Washington, Aug. 4. -- Sprague, the county seat of Lincoln County, and the division point of the Northern Pacific Railroad, having a population of 3,000, was almost destroyed by fire yesterday. A high wind, amounting almost to a hurricane, was blowing at the time. Over $1,000,000 worth of property was burned in two hours' time.

At the New-York terminal of the Brooklyn Bridge a busy scene was to be witnessed all day yesterday. There were gangs of men sawing and chiseling timbers, tearing up tracks and relaying them on a trestle. Iron work for new platforms was put in place and bolted together with all possible speed, and great derricks were kept busy lifting beams and railroad iron and swinging them into place.

SOUTH BEACH, S.I., Aug. 4. -- During a heavy southeast squall that passed over the lower bay at 5 o'clock this afternoon, Jacob Schmidt of Rockaway, who was sailing in a small catboat, was struck by the squall between Hoffman Island and South Beach, S.I., and capsized.

ROCKAWAY BEACH, L.I., Aug. 4. -- The rainstorm this afternoon spoiled the pleasure of many thousands of visitors to this resort. Though warned of the approaching storm, the crowds did not pay heed to it until the rain fell upon them in torrents. Then followed a wild scramble for shelter.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 4. -- Syracuse is a city with an apparently amicable understanding on excise matters. The members of the Ministerial Association, which meets in star-chamber sessions once a week to discuss matters of public policy, understands that the city is as dry on Sunday as the sands of Sahara.

The invitation tennis tournament at Norwood Park is the main tennis attraction this week. In former years the Nahant Sporting Club held a round-robin tournament a few weeks before Newport, to which the dangerous candidates for the championships were invited. The results were looked upon as a good basis upon which to make championship predictions.

COTTAGE CITY, Mass., Aug. 4. -- The yachts remained at anchor to-day, and, at noon, dressed ship. The scene was a very pretty one, for it is several years since so large a squadron anchored in this port. Usually the yachts hold together as far as Newport, and then many of them wait there until the others return.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Aug. 4. -- The Government column, under the command of Col. Seguras, returned to Guantanamo on the 2d inst., after having defeated the insurgents under Jose Maceo, near Loma de la Galleta. The rebels lost ten killed and seventy wounded, and five of the band were taken prisoners.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of The New-York Times.
In rivers, sound, and bay yesterday the storm made havoc with lives and boats.

If the Brooklyn Good Roads Association keeps on in its crusade against poor pavements, that city will soon offer superior facilities for cycling. Its work to date has been attended with results of the most gratifying character, and its policy is to push its plans vigorously for the cyclers' welfare.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4. -- The famous Hale and Norcross mining suit, by which M.W. Fox, for the stockholders of the company, sought to recover millions from the Directors and managers of the concern, has been decided by the Supreme Court. The findings are partly favorable to the plaintiff and partly to the defendants.

Certain prominent Republicans who appear to be hoping that the threatening cloud of prosperity will blow over can find nothing to encourage them in the long list of additional increases of wages which we publish this morning.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- Charles Dunlap, General Superintendent of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad, died at 2:15 o'clock this morning, at his residence, 6,530 Ross Avenue, of injuries which he received at the chutes last Thursday night.
A table showing the expense imposed on each county in the State by the 3.24 tax rate has been prepared by The Albany Argus. It is made part of the following editorial, printed to-day:

Michael Pescento, an Italian, twenty-five years old, of 24 Mulberry Street, was murdered at 1 o'clock yesterday morning in the rear yard of 345 West Broadway. An hour later Acting Capt. O'Keefe of the Macdougal Street Station had the murderer, his accomplice, and all the witnesses in custody.

Commissioner Grant declined last night to discuss the occurrences of Friday and Saturday at Police Headquarters. He said he had no statement to make in regard to the "joint and authoritative" pronouncement of his colleagues.

The plans recently outlined in our Washington dispatches for the extension of the merit system in the Federal service are very important. Probably the greatest effect would be produced if it were found practicable to eliminate the patronage element from appointments to the fourth-class Post Offices -- that is, to offices now filled without nomination to the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- The march of improvement in that part of Washington formerly known as Georgetown, and older by many years than other parts of the city, has compelled the destruction of the tomb of Benjamin Homans, in the old Presbyterian Cemetery. The mention of Homans's name recalls Dolly Madison's famous feat in 1814.
PARIS, Aug. 4. -- An attempt was made to-day to murder M. Vuillemin, the Managing Director of the coal mines at Aniche, eight miles from Douai, in the Department of Nord.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, Aug. 4. -- To-day was a very quiet one in camp. The men of the four batteries and Signal Corps were all up at 5 o'clock this morning cleaning guns, feeding, shoeing, and cleaning their horses, and straightening out their company streets. A lecture of instruction by Major Burbank, Fifth Artillery, United States Army, was attended by all of the officers and a great many of the men.
ALBANY, Aug. 4. -- The city authorities have for two years been endeavoring to close the saloons on Sundays, but it cannot be said that they have met with complete success.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- The United States steamship Brooklyn may be launched in a few weeks at the Cramps' shipyard, where the vessel is being constructed. The naval constructors on duty in Washington say the ship can be launched within two weeks if there is necessity for such an action, but that, ordinarily, the vessel would not be removed from the ways for some months yet.

BERLIN, Aug. 4. -- The prevailing dullness of Berlin, especially in social circles, received a passing enlivener on Thursday, when the new Royal Opera and Thiergarten, formerly Kroll's Opera House, was opened with a splendid production of Nicolai's "Merry Wives of Windsor." The Emperor and his entire military household, in resplendent uniforms, were present, and occupied the grand imperial box, which faces the stage.

There is no justification in law, morals, or politics for Mayor Schieren's refusal to enforce in Brooklyn the law against Sunday liquor selling. He has made vague and colorless professions about the observance of "public order and decency," but so long as he refuses to enforce the laws he is himself the high priest of disorder and indecency.

Following are the additions to our list of increases of wages to which reference is made on the editorial page. The number of employing companies or firms included in the entire list is now about 685, and a conservative estimate of the number of employes affected by the increases thus reported is 514,000.

QUAKERTOWN, N.J., Aug. 4. -- Lightning struck the Methodist Episcopal Church at this place this afternoon just after the close of the services, and a number of persons, including the minister and his wife, were so badly injured that they may die.

The fruit rescources of Southwestern Missouri are not generally comprehended. Right now thousands of bushels of peaches are going to loss in that locality for want of means to care for them. There are 1,000 carloads of early apples in sight along the Memphis Road west of Thayer.

The editor of The American Wool and Cotton Reporter was asked last week by a correspondent to estimate the quantity of woolen machinery in operation in this country now, and also "at the most favorable time hitherto" in the history of the industry. The editor does not undertake to designate exactly "the most favorable time," but gives figures for May, 1892, and June 1, 1895.

The rumor we print to-day that Sir Julian Pauncefote will be transferred from Washington to Berlin does not seem to be fully credited at Washington. The indisposition to credit is complimentary to the subject of it, who has, in fact, discharged his duties in such a way as to make himself highly acceptable in this country, both politically and socially.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 5. -- The Prohibitionists of Senator Bradley's temperance town are waging their annual war against the rolling beer "arks" and the proprietors of the numerous "speak-easies," who, in defiance of general and special laws, are dispensing large quantities of intoxicants to the natives and hotel guests.

Not only have liquor sellers and their champions complained of the pecuniary loss incurred by stopping their saloon traffic on Sunday, but they have claimed that their rights and liberties are interfered with. This raises the question whether retailers of intoxicating drinks are entitled to rights and liberties not accorded to other citizens engaged in traffic.

Gen. William Mahone was as the head and front of the "Honest-Elections" Conference in Petersburg, and his evident purpose is to organize a "non-partisan" party to beat the Democrats. It appears that there is to be a fusion of Republicans and Populists to secure control of the Virginia Legislature, and to rule our State as the coalition of Republicans and Readjusters did in 1879 and 1881.

The advance guard of the temperance hosts, representing delegates and members of the Catholic Total Abstinence Union of America, which will assemble here to-morrow in National Council arrived yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Gen. and Mrs. D.W. Flagler, parents of Miss Elizabeth Flagler, who shot and killed Ernest Green last week, returned home this afternoon. Gen. Flagler did not report at the War Department, as he is still on leave, and his movements are not certainly known. It is supposed that he will take his daughter away with him for a time.
Spider McGuire, the lightweight champion of Mulberry Bend, in speaking yesterday of Mr. Cleveland and a renomination for the Presidency, said:

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 5. -- A long-planned sailing party, for which elaborate preparations had been made, was postponed this evening on account of the inclemency of the weather. Mrs. Potter Palmer had sent out over 100 invitations to her friends, and the affair gave promise of being a most enjoyable one.

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- Richard Leach the murderer of Mary Hope Newkirk, was killed in the electric chair in Sing Sing Prison this morning. The witnesses had been instructed to be present at 11 o'clock A.M. They were promptly there, and, at 11:05 o'clock, were escorted to the death chamber in the north yard.

Lieut. Gen. John M. Schofield came to this city last night, to be present at a meeting of the Army Board of Fortifications to-day. The General was accompanied by Mrs. Schofield and his civilian son, William. They staid over Sunday at Thompson, Conn., with John W. Doane, one of the receivers of the Union Pacific Railroad.

SARATOGA, Aug. 5. -- The card here to-day was a very fair one, and about 400 persons were present to see it decided.
