The weather was clear and warm, but the track was heavy and holding as a result of a rainstorm yesterday. It was a bad day for the backers of favorites, as in all but one event an outsider carried off the honors. The details:

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- James Scanlon, who represents the Seventeenth Assembly District of Kings County in the Legislature, had a fight with a bear yesterday. The bear is dead and Mr. Scanlon is suffering from injuries which may yet result fatally.

JERSEY CITY, N.J. Aug. 5. -- A prisoner concerning whom a great deal of secrecy is observed, is held at Police Headquarters. The police say they can give no information about the man, simply because they know nothing of the case.
BUFFALO, Aug. 5. -- Samuel L. Gracey of this city, formerly United States Consul at Foo-Chow, China, was interviewed to-day on the reported massacre at Ku-Cheng.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- Arthur Wilder, the Young native Hawaiian, who enjoyed the confidence of President Dole during the life of the provisional Government of the island, does not think there is anything in the story published by a San Francisco paper that a scheme had been hatched there for the restoration of the Queen to the throne.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- "It is probable that since we have shipped 1,400 tons of pig iron and steel from Youngstown, Ohio, into England, the Agrarians of England will soon demand microscopic inspection of American pig iron to see that trichinae is not contained therein.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSILL, Aug. 5. -- At battery drill this morning the east parade ground was occupied by the First Battery, Capt. Louis Wendel commanding, and the Sixth Battery, Capt. L.L. Olmsted commanding, drilled on the north parade ground.
OGUNQUIT, Me., Aug. 4. -- "Know where I can find Mr. Larrabee?" I asked of the Postmaster. "I've got to get an interview with him.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 5. -- Another beautiful day was enjoyed by the hotel and cottage guests at this resort to-day. Nearly all who arrived Saturday and yesterday are still here, waiting patiently for Thursday, the opening date of the open-air horse show, for which elaborate preparations are being made.

DANSVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- The wife of the Rev. T. De Witt Talmage died at the sanitarium here at 5:30 o'clock this morning. Her husband and children were present at her deathbed. The remains will be taken to Brooklyn to-night.

GLASGOW, July 27. -- The cables arriving here explaining the trials between the Defender and the Vigilant are so contradictory and unintelligible that the yachtsmen here are quite in the dark. However, the announcement made that the Vigilant has been much improved in speed explains that the Defender is not so fast as was expected.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- If it be true, as reported from London to-day, that Sir Julian Pauncefote, British Ambassador to the United States, is to succeed Sir Edward Malet as Ambassador to Germany, the transfer will not be in every sense a promotion.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The official report by Capt. Sumner on the speed trial of the cruiser Columbia across the Atlantic was received by Assistant Secretary McAdoo at the Navy Department to-day.

HASTINGS, England, Aug. 5. -- The great tournament of the chess masters was opened in the Brassey Institute here at 12:30 o'clock to-day with an appropriate address by the Mayor of the town in the presence of a brilliant gathering.

One of the duties of Daisy James of the Mail Inspection and Rating Department at the Post Office is to examine fourth-class mail packages. Yesterday in looking over a number of them she came to what appeared to be a box, wrapped in a square foot of manila paper, which was five inches long, two inches wide, and one and one-half inches high. Its source is in doubt, but it bore the address:

Harry Mortimer, alias Harry Fischer, known on the variety stage as a female impersonator, who was arrested in Chicago last week, charged with having stolen diamonds valued at $3,000 from Mrs. Johanna Simis, the mother of Commissioner Simis of the Department of Charities and Correction, while she was staying at the Eagle Hotel, in Fulton Street, Brooklyn, May 13, was commited to jail in default of bail yesterday.

The decision of Justice Patterson of the Supreme Court, that the section of Westchester County recently annexed to New York City must remain unattached to the city as far as legislative and judicial elections go, has been sustained by the General Term of the Supreme Court.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- A secret meeting between the representatives of almost every big wholesale grocer in Chicago and the Chicago agent and the New-York general manager of the Sugar Trust was held at the Auditorium on Saturday night. In accordance with the request of the wholesalers, the trust to-day issued a circular, in which it offers all wholesalers a rebate of one-eighth of a cent a pound on all sugar sold at trust prices.

The Trustees of "Scenic and Historic Places and Objects" have organized, and have established by-laws that provide for the election of Trustees by the qualified members of the corporation on the first Wednesday of next November.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Rear Admiral Carpenter, commanding the Asiatic naval station, has reported to the Navy Department, under date of Yokohama, July 6, that in the trial of John Thomas Bush, a mulatto seaman residing in Washington, D.C., and a member of the crew of the United States gunboat Yorktown, charged with the murder of a Japanese subject, the Consular court disagreed in their opinion on his guilt.
ALEXANDRIA BAY, Aug. 5. -- Warner Miller, Mrs. Miller, and Miss Bessie Miller arrived here this evening.
According to Chevalier Antonio Macchi, the Cotton States and International Exposition at Atlanta will be graced with a more complete and representative foreign exhibit than the Chicago Fair had.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 5. -- The mercury to-day has reached 78 in the shade, which is the highest in about a week. This, however, did not prevent the lovers of golf from going down to the links. Among those who were there and went round to-day were S. Parkman Shaw, the champion of the Lenox Club: J. Searle Barclay, Jr., John E. Alexandre, Mr. and Mrs. Carlos de Heridia, Jameson Cotting, and James Barnes.

COWES, Aug. 5. -- The Cowes yacht week opened to-day with the regatta of the Royal London Yacht Club. The weather was cloudy, but there was a whole-sail southwesterly breeze, which gave promise of a fine day's sport. The interest in the race for big cutters was greatly lessened when the spectators learned that the Ailsa would not compete, she having gone into dock to have her bottom cleaned.

Commissioner Grant admits his own full share of responsibility for the trial of Capt. Eakins which he has called a crime. Indeed, he admits rather a fuller share than that of his colleagues, since he in effect advised his colleagues that the case against Capt. Eakins should be brought to trial.

The Brooklyns gave a fine exhibition of "quitting" in the baseball game with the Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The latter started off with a rush, getting three runs in the first inning, and the Bridge Jumpers got discouraged and played miserable ball. The final score was 13 to 6.

ALBANY, Aug. 5. -- A committee consisting of Charles Monroe Holt, Chief Forester; Addison W. Baird, Treasurer; Martin Bohler, and Solomon Kelley has undertaken the plan to open up a bridle path and trail to the summit of Mount Marcy, the highest peak in New-York State and the second highest east of the Mississippi, and has asked the assistance of the State Fisheries, Game, and Forest Commissioners in the undertaking.
Discomfort assumed a concrete form yesterday to those who had to cross the Brooklyn Bridge.

LONDON, Aug. 5. -- I had an interview with Nasr Ullah Khan this evening. He broke a dinner engagement with her Majesty to receive me. The Grand Chancellor was present. "What do I think about the third term?" said Nasr Ullah in reply to my question. "Why, I look upon it as the most infamous plot against the liberties of a great people that ever stained the page of history.

PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 5. -- At a meeting of colored men to-night, twenty-six signed the roll to go to Bureau County and help their brethren. They will probably leave in the morning. They have arms and ammunition.
LONDON, Aug. 5. -- The United States cruiser Marblehead arrived at Gravesend to-day.

MONDAY -- P.M. Extreme dullness and narrow fluctuations were the features of to-day's stock market. The London exchange was closed over the usual first Monday in August holiday, and no business came from that centre. The total transactions footed up less than 138,000 shares.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Ex-Gov. Sims, First Assistant Secretary of the Interior, has returned to Washington from Mississippi, where he went several weeks ago to take part in the Senatorial contest in that State. Mr. Sims espoused the sound-money side of the controversy, and made a number of speeches.
Thomas C. Platt and his allies are active these days. They are saying that there is nothing going on in politics, and they are laying their wires as deftly as they know how.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Aug. 5. -- I have just secured the following highly important affidavit, the convincing character of which will scarcely be denied by the most skeptical and obdurate of those who deny the existence of the third-term plot:

The investigation into the affairs of the Charities Department of Kings County prior to the present administration by the Assembly sub-committee was resumed yesterday after a week's intermission, and Hugo Hirsh again took up the examination of witnesses. The committee met in the Brooklyn City Court room.

We, the people of Swat, have our own troubles -- are not the English in India? -- but ever since news reached us of what great dangers now threaten your land, private and personal woes have no longer been discussed among the foothills; instead, men gather in all the villages of Swat and say one to another, ofttimes weeping the while, words like these: "What, oh! what can we do to help the United States?"

Influential representatives of the Pennsylvania Railroad, the Atlantic Coast Line, the Merchants and Miners' Transportation Company of Baltimore, the Ocean Steamship Company of Savannah. Ga., and probably the Seaboard Air Line will have an important conference in the Hotel Waldorf, in this city, to-day.

VERSAILLES, Ky., Aug. 5. -- The most desperate and tragic shooting affray that has taken place in the Blue Grass region since the famous fight in which Goodloe and Swope killed each other occurred in the Woodford Hotel here this afternoon, when William Newton Lane of this city shot and instantly killed James Rodenbaugh and mortally wounded the young man's father, H.C. Rodenbaugh, proprietor of the hotel.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- The sacred concerts at the Spring House and Earlington Hotel last evening drew large audiences. The singing of Riccards Ricci and Mme. Ricci at the Earlington, and of Miss Boese, Miss Blumenberry, and Purdon Robinson at the Spring House, was thoroughly enjoyed.

TACOMA, Washington, Aug. 5. -- Homing pigeons, which had been sent out with mountain climbers, returned yesterday afternoon with messages stating that Frederick R. Cowden, H.J. Fires, F.A. Liin, William Love, Walter M. Bosworth, and Frederick Evans, nearly all experienced mountain climbers, had been badly frozen in attempting to reach the summit of Mount Tacoma.

The trial of Capt. Eakins of the Mercer Street Police Station, which was adjourned abruptly on Friday evening, when Commissioner Grant declared it to be a "crime," was continued before Commissioner Andrews yesterday afternoon. The courtroom was crowded with people.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Some curiosity is expressed in naval circles as to the destination of the Minneapolis. This speedy cruiser, the sister ship of the Columbia, is now at Norfolk, where she is being fitted out as a flagship.
It is just possible that Brooklyn contains one of the wonders in the business world of the United States -- the one woman wheelwright to be found in the Union.

HAVANA, Aug. 5. -- Gen. Mella reports that he returned to Puerto Principe on Friday last from the field of operations against the rebels. He says that the force under his command met the insurgent band under Maximo Gomez in the direction of Neuvitas, but that it was impossible to get the rebels to make a stand.
Mrs. Rosina Vollhart has sold, at $120,000, the seven-story brick apartments 235 to 239 West Forty-third Street, 75 by 100. She bought the property in February last of the Aldrich estate at $115,000.
PRINCETON, Ill., Aug. 5. -- The rioters and the lawless hold sway in Spring Valley to-night. No arrests or attempts at arrest have been made, and those anarchistically inclined are in high spirits.

A distinguished traveler, who had made the ascent of an Asiatic mountain, (which may be here called "Upapol,") was to return thanks for the visitors at a dinner of the Alpine Club, but though he was a bold mountaineer, he was a timid orator. "Got to make a speech?" said a friend whom he consulted at the club.

William C. Rehm, who has a friend who describes him as a "supporter of the reform movement," and who is a music teacher living at 230 East Thirteenth Street, told Mayor Strong's Commissioners of Accounts some time ago a story that was supposed to involve James J. Phelan, who was then a Dock Commissioner and was treasurer of the Dock Board.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The accession of Lord Salisbury to the head of the British Cabinet is causing a good deal of anxiety among the friends of Venezuela. They fear that it means a return to the policy of territorial aggression against Venezuela which was pursued by the English under the former Conservative Ministry, with even more insolence than under the Liberal administration.

Among other improvements under the republic is a conspicuous advance in the tone of the native members of the Legislature. This relates to the lower house, nearly half of whom are natives. In the Senate there is only one pure native who speaks English -- the Vice President -- a man of great elevation of character.

During the first half of Catherine's reign the leading statesman was Count Panin, almost the only one of the Empress's advisers who dared to think for himself. He was the most level-headed of her statesmen, and yet we read concerning him that his indolence and sloth were beyond expression, and that he passed his time with courtesans of the commonest kind.

CLEVELAND, Ohio., Aug. 5. -- After a delay of three days the Grand Circuit programme was finally disposed of to-day. The 2:17 trot which had seven heats settled on Friday, and the 2:10 pace with three were the remnants.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- Rose Coghlan has left for California, where she will play a seven weeks' engagement.

Mayor Strong yesterday signed the Board of Aldermen's resolution granting the application of the People's Traction Company for the establishment of about twenty-six miles of surface railroad in the annexed district.

PERTLE SPRINGS, Mo., Aug. 5. -- The Democratic Silver Convention will meet here to-morrow. About 550 delegates are expected to be in attendance, all of whom, it is thought, will be pronounced advocates of the sixteen-to-one idea. There will probably be no fight on the principal resolutions, though the rabid element of the party may try to force such radical declarations as to arouse the antagonism of the conservatives.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 5. -- There were many small dinners at the cottages to-night at which yachtsmen were entertained. There were several small dinners aboard the steam yachts. Mrs. J.H. Beekman and Mrs. Alexander Barret gave the largest cottage entertainments to-night.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 5. -- The Defender to-day gave the Vigilant the most decisive beating she has had this season over the thirty-seven-mile run from Vineyard Haven to Brenton's Reef Lightship. She beat her by nine minutes and nine seconds, elapsed time.
Some 3,000 people went to Brighton Beach yesterday to see a moderate lot of races decided over a dead track.

WOONSOCKET, R.I., Aug. 5. -- Notices were posted in the Harris Woolen, Lippitt Woolen, Perseverence Worsted, Simpson Worsted, and W.H. Prendergast's Woolen Mills to-day, announcing an average of wages averaging 5 per cent. to weavers, loom fixers and mule spinners. The increase goes into effect to-day. This is a restoration of a little more than half the cut in 1893. About 500 hands are affected.

An amusingly frank explanation appears in The London Spectator as to why the Duke of Connaught should not be considered, even by the Tories, as the proper person to succeed the Duke of Cambridge as Commander in Chief of the English Army. A strong and efficient military force, it says, is of vital importance to the national welfare.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 5. -- Arthur Gardiner, the young Chicago flier, was thrown in the final run-over of the mile open at to-day's National Circuit race meeting, in this city, given by the Fort Wayne Race Meet Association. The most decisive victory of the day was that of "Tom" Cooper, in the half-mile open, and following this, the victory of Titus in the two-mile lap race came next.

Mrs. Meta J.B. Caldwell, a granddaughter of the late Gov. Stacey Pitcher of New-Jersey, has begun an action in the Supreme Court to set aside the will of her mother, Maria A. Le Mon, who was Gov. Pitcher's daughter.

Japan has a battleship approaching, in displacement, horse power, and speed, to our Texas and Maine, and she got the ship by fighting for it. The Chen Yuen, the finest battleship of the Chinese Navy, which was captured at Wei-Hai-Wei, has been added to the Japanese Navy in a condition warranting the Japanese naval authorities in declaring that she is equal to a new vessel.

The announcement of the death of Ebenezer Kellogg Wright, President of the National Park Bank, caused many expressions of regret on the part of his large circle of friends yesterday. Few men were better known throughout the financial circles of the United States.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 6. -- This has been a lively day in Bar Harbor. Everyboly seems to have been affected by the rush of the August festivities. At the Kebo Valley Club all the interest was in the tennis tournament. Mr. Everett and Howard C. Colby of New-York were in fine form and played star games.

SARATOGA, Aug. 6. -- Franklin K. Gale was to open his Victoria Vaudeville Open-Air Theatre to-night, but a heavy rainstorm compelled a postponement till to-morrow evening. A full-dress rehearsal was substituted. New-York City actors have been engaged for the season. It is understood that H. Tompkins, W.E Woolley, H.C. Clement, and W.W. Worden, all hotel proprietors, are the financial backers of the enterprise, which is something entirely new for Saratoga.

PRINCETON, Ill., Aug. 6. -- The Italian miners of Spring Valley this afternoon made an attempt to carry out their resolution of yesterday to expel all the colored people remaining in the city, and the result was one of the most disgraceful outrages ever perpetrated in Bureau County. It was committed under protection of the Mayor and policemen.

There is a literary tendency to dwell now on the incidents of childhood. Occasionally such volumes are poetically conceived, but perhaps the natural child is not always presented. Bias leads the author sometimes to draw a morbid little being, who leads an unhappy existence. Even if Bernardin de St-pierre made a tragic-conclusion to "Paul and Virginia," that is no reason why his example should be followed.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 6. -- Press dipatches telling of the reported secret alliance between Guatemala and Costa Rica were read with considerable interest by Gen. Pierce M.B. Young, United States Minister to Guatemala and Honduras, now at home on leave, He said:

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 6. -- The American Dental Association commenced its annual meeting this morning in the Beach Auditorium. There was a large attendance. President Crawford called the meeting to order. Dr. Sanger, the new President of the New-Jersey State Dental Society, welcomed the delegates.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 6. -- The yacht Clara of the Greenville Yacht Club was sunk at her moorings, at the foot of Danforth Avenue, this morning, by an explosion, and Dr. S.A. Hollister, her owner, and Matthew Armstrong were severely injured.

PARK RIDGE, N.J., Aug. 6. -- A large number of persons were poisoned Saturday night by eating ice cream at a picnic given by the Reeves Brass Band in Serven's Park. The ice cream was made by the leader of the band, P.S. Tygert. He and J.A. Fisher were the first to partake of the ice cream, and were the first to become ill.

Messrs. Gutwillig Brothers have sold, to A. Johnsen, the property at 114 West Thirty-fourth Street, 25 by 98.9, with old building. Mr. Johnsen will build on the site an eight-story fireproof office building, which will be ready for occupancy on May 1 next.

The Republican politicians in this city are busily at work these days endeavoring to figure out an excise programme to follow in the coming campaign. Several little conferences on this subject have already been held in Thomas C. Platt's office on lower Broadway, and it is now proposed to call something in the way of a larger conference of Republican leaders to consider the subject within a few days.

ALBANY, Aug. 6. -- The sub-committee of the joint legislative committee appointed by the Legislature to investigate the State departments met here this afternoon in the rooms of the State Civil Service Commission, to inquire into the administration of the State civil service laws.

OSWEGO, Aug. 6. -- Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show was advertised to give a performance on the fair grounds, west of this city, at 2 o'clock this afternoon. About 1 o'clock dark clouds began to gather in the western sky, and there were ominous rumbles of thunder. This did not deter thousands of people from going to the show.
LONDON, Aug. 6. -- Mrs. Seligman, who is said by the Central News to be the wife of a New-York banker of that name, and her daughter, met with a serious accident to-day.

Several members of the Phoenix Club charged Gen. Collis yesterday with threatening to dismiss from the service of the city members of the club who are office holders in the Public Works Department if they did not cast their votes in club matters in accordance with his instructions.

From a circular issued by Mr. V.S. McClatchy of The Sacremento (Cal.) Bee, and General Manager of The Pacific Associated Press, it appears that The Chicago Associated Press has treated the newspapers on the Pacific coast just as it would have treated The Southern Associated Press if its plans had been successful -- that is, it would have got it in its power, and then raised the assessments of its members.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- The new Independent American Party, which is called to meet in convention at Topeka, Kan., Sept. 5, is said to favor, among other things, a removal of the National capital to a more central location. It is this article of its political faith which is of most interest to Washingtonians, although no one here believes that the Federal capital will ever be removed from its present site.

President Roosevelt of the Police Department called on Mayor Strong early yesterday afternoon, and was closeted with him in his inner office for nearly an hour. The familiar old rumor that the Mayor was urging the Commissioner to be a little less vigorous in the enforcement of the excise law was at once started on its merry round about the City Hall.
" They even send -- but I can't tell all they do send -- the funniest things."
A suit for the construction of a most peculiar will, involving over $1,000,000, has been begun in the Supreme Court by Col. S. Van Rensselaer Cruger as executor.

The combination formed by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company of Pittsburg and the Baldwin Locomotive Works of Philadelphia is attracting much interest among railway men. Important results are looked for.

BOSTON, Aug. 6. -- The Brooklyns and Bostons to-day played a game of baseball which was characterized by more wrangling than any seen here for years. Messrs. Burnham and Hunt acted as umpires, and gave renewed evidences of their incompetency. Burnham reversed decisions, and showed weakness by appealing to the reporters to back up his judgment on bails and strikes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Senator Gorman will leave in a few days for Saratoga, where he will remain at least two weeks. Before returning to his country home in Maryland he will visit Senator Hill at Wolfert's Roost, near Albany. Mr. Hill has asked him to be his guest, and it is likely that Mr. Gorman will remain several days with him.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- When Judge Seaman recently refused Frederick M. Olmstead the privilege of appealing from the decree of sale of Whisky Trust property, on the representations of counsel for the Reorganization Committee that he was merely a figurehead for Greenhut and Morris, he gave counsel for Olmstead leave to renew the motion before some other United States Judge.

Samuel Untermyer beseeching Justice O'Brien, in the Supreme Court, to save his clients in the Whisky Trust case from the direful possibility of violating the anti-trust and anti-monopoly laws of Illinois was an absorbing spectacle yesterday.

The position of the German voters in local politics has become more than ever difficult. Their energetic participation in last year's reform movement has been illy requited. Roosevelt's Sunday baiting, against which they have, up to the present, protested in vain to the Mayor, whom they elected, hits the Germans with particular, severity, as their places of recreation are necessarily peculiarly exposed to police interference, as they cannot be conducted in secret.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 6. -- F.S. Douglass of Newark, N.J., a cottage owner at Monmouth Beach, who is passing the Summer with his family at Newark, is expected to take possession of his cottage this week.
The silver jubilee convention of the Catholic Total Abstinence Union of America will be opened at 9 o'clock this morning in Columbus Hall, in Sixtieth Street, near Ninth Avenue.

The committee of citizens of Brooklyn appointed by Mayor Schieren to arrange for the reception of the Maryland officials who are coming to Brooklyn Aug. 27 to participate in the unveiling of the monument in Prospect Park to the memory of Maryland soldiers killed in the battle of Long Island in 1778 is short of funds, and unless more money is quickly raised by popular subscription the city will be placed in a humiliating position.

MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa, Aug. 6. -- The prospect is for a fight over the financial question in the Democratic State Convention, which will be held to-morrow. The free-silver element developed unexpected strength this afternoon. Its leaders demand a free-coinage plank and will not talk of compromise.
The regular traffic on the Brooklyn Bridge was carried on yesterday morning with not more than the usual crowding at the Brooklyn terminus and in the cars themselves.

Mayor Schieren's pretense of surprise at The Times's reports of the open sale of liquor in Brooklyn on Sunday will fool nobody -- not even himself. Mr. Schieren knows perfectly well that the saloons of Brooklyn have carried on a side-door traffic since the first Sunday after he became Mayor, and he knows that the police have made no effective effort to interfere with the traffic.

John McCullough came to the Pacific coast first in 1866, with Edwin Forrest when the great tragedian failed measurably in playing the notable ten-thousand-dollar engagement for Manager Thomas Maguire. McCullough was Forrest's leading man, and also his locum tenens when the blase old tragedian could not or would not attend rehearsal.

As a surpassingly grotesque illustration of our pension system, the ease of E.S. Smith, editor of The Williamstown Local, deserves appreciative attention. The details appear in The Oswego Palladium, though not as fully as might be desired. It seems that when Mr. Smith was two years old his father went to the war, and was shot.

Speculation in stocks has dwindled to very small proportions, and is almost wholly professional. Traders, as a rule, are short of the market, and consequently are loud in their opinion that a reaction is due. Owners of stocks, however, show no disposition to part with them, and all indications now point to a resumption of the upward movement without the intervention of the reaction which the professionals are so anxious should occur.

The Board of Aldermen met yesterday after their Summer recess, which began July 2. The batch applications for permits for street stands occasioned by the ruling of the Police Board was not acted upon, but will be at the next meeting. A few permits were acted upon.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 6. -- Nearly all the cottagers were afloat to-night, witnessing the illumination of the harbor in honor of the New-York Yacht Club. The yachts and other boats were gayly decorated with lanterns, and on shore there were gorgeous displays of fireworks from the lawns of many of the Summer residences.

Cyclists who ride to and from their work on the west side are now in a fair way to get what they have long wished for in the past, and that is an unbroken asphalt route from Harlem to Chambers Street.

Secretary Bell of the Police Civil Service Board yesterday called the attention of the Police Commissioners to a number of alleged irregularities in the recent mental examinations of candidates for appointment on the force.

A case that was shrouded in mystery was disposed of yesterday by Justice O'Brien, in Supreme Court Chambers, when Florence Fairfield, fifteen years old, was surrendered by the Protestant Episcopal Society of St. Martha, at 34 West Twenty-second Street, to her brother, Frank Fairfield, of 135 West Nineteenth Street.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- An evening paper says Miss Elizabeth M. Flagler is at the home of a physician on Lexington Street in Baltimore, Md.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Aug. 6. -- The steamship Topeka, which arrived at midnight, had on board the survivors of the crew of the sealing schooner C.G. White, which was wrecked on Wood Island, Alaska early in the Spring. The poor fellows who were maimed present a sickening sight. They are awaiting the sailing of the next San Francisco steamer, which will carry them home.

The statements of ex-Charities Commissioner B. Frank Gott, of Brooklyn, before the Assembly Committee on Cities, that he never was benefited by the products of the County Farm at St. Johnland and Kings Park were flatly contradicted yesterday by witnesses who testified that they shipped vegetables and fruit from those places direct to Col Gott, and to the late Commissioner Francis B. Nolan.

A fair sort of a card for Brighton Beach brought out an attendance something above the average yesterday to enjoy the sport. The speculation was livelier than usual, and the punters fared fairly well, for, while but two undisputed favorites -- Vision and Sir Dixon, Jr. -- won their races, the rest of the winners had good support in the ring.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- The Committee of Award for the Hodgkins Prizes of the Smithsonian Institution has completed its examination of the 218 papers submitted in competition by contestants from almost every quarter of the globe.

Capt. Joseph B. Eakins of the Mercer Street Station, whose trial before the Police Commissioners on charges made by the Parkhurst society for failing to suppress disorderly houses is to be resumed Friday, went to police Headquarters yesterday to get permission from President Roosevelt to take a few days' vacation.

Franklin is pre-eminently a city of fine distances. In one direction there rises to view a slope thickly built up with tasty cottages and imposing mansions. In another line the roofs and chimneys of large manufacturing establishments appear above the cool shade of wide-spreading trees. Another way a pastoral landscape and the white spire of a church are seen.

The Winter number of Modern Art, though somewhat unseasonable and a trifle late, has just made its appearance, hailing now from Boston under the publication seal of L. Prang Co. Mr. Bowles, the editor, explains that the delay is consequent upon the changes, of the removal of the publication office from Indianapolis, and various other causes, and promises promptness for the future.

SARATOGA, Aug. 6 -- Though the class of racing here was much higher and better than usual. the attendance was very light, only a handful of people being at the track to see the race for the Grand Union Hotel Stakes, usually one of the big events of the racing season here.

FOW-CHOO, Aug. 6. -- The survivors of the massacre at Wasang, in the course of an interview to-day, say that the work of the mob had evidently been carefully planned, and all the arrangements made for the destruction of the mission stations, and that the killing or driving out of the foreigners was carried out with diabolical cruelty.

Persons who are dissatisfied with the fine record made by the United States cruiser Columbia on her recent trip from Southampton to this port are suggesting that the Fifty-fourth Congress shall make appropriation for a vessel that shall be required to develop greater speed than that now made by the most rapid of ocean "greyhounds" or "liners."

Collector Kilbreth gave a hearing yesterday to several firms which import olives on an inquiry in regard to undervalued invoices. The firms concerned are two prominent wholesale grocery houses and two Italian houses. Their importations are said to have covered the bulk of the olive business in this country, and the customs authorities thought they had reason to suppose that invoices had been systematically undervalued for years.

While Miss Helen Twiggs, who lives with her mother at 176 St. Ann's Avenue, near the Southern Boulevard, was at home alone Monday afternoon, John Young, or John Miller, called at the house, and said he had come to buy it.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 6. -- The Toronto Baseball Club of the Eastern League came to Orange this afternoon and defeated the Orange Athletic Club baseball players on the Orange Oval in the presence of several hundred spectators. But for a lucky hit by McGrillis in the last inning the home team would have been shut out, for its men could not bat Payne, the visitor's pitcher.

Lawrence Macy, the thief who was arrested Saturday night, after a long chase on the roof of a house in the Elizabeth Street Precinct, has confessed to Acting Captain O'Brien that he robbed the following persons:

COWES, Aug. 6. -- Emperor William paid an unexpected visit to the German warship Woerth, which is one of the ships of the German fleet which accompanied the imperial yacht Hohenzollern to Cowes, before 8 o'clock this morning.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- In response to a call to arms addressed to the colored people of Chicago, over 200 negroes assembled at 500 State Street at 9 o'clock this morning. The call reads as follows:
The Advisory Council of Confederated Good Government Clubs declared last evening in favor of local option.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 6. -- In the United States Circuit Court here to-day, Judge Goff handed down a brief in the South Carolina registration eases dismissing complainant's bill for an injunction. The opinion is as follows:

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 6. -- Attorney Merle Walker has received a letter from his father, who has been doing missionary work among the Chinese for twenty-five years, which bears out the truth of press dispatches relative to outrages perpetrated on the missionaries.

The Washington baseball players barely furnished exercise for the New-York nine in their match game at the Polo Grounds yesterday. But about 2,500 enthusiasts were on hand to see the New-Yorkers brace up and play good baseball.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- The hearing on the sugar bounty question before the Controller of the Treasury to-morrow promises to be very interesting. An array of distinguished legal talent will be present.

LONDON, Aug. 6. -- A pro-Armenian meeting, presided over by the Duke of Westminster, was held at Chester this afternoon. Mr. Gladstone was received with great enthusiasm. In addressing the meeting Mr. Gladstone said he had attended rather to meet the expectation that he would be present than because he had any important contribution to make to the discussion of the subject under consideration.

NEWPORT, Aug. 6. -- The Defender won the Drexel Cup for the big single stickers, and defeated the Vigilant 6 minutes, 10 seconds, over a twenty-one-mile course. Only half the course was sailed, once around the triangle.

The Democratic papers throughout this State are manifesting an almost unanimous desire that the course of the party from this time forward shall be governed by a spirit of harmony that shall lead all men of Democratic principles and affiliations to forget the factional disputes that have divided and weakened the party, and with some sacrifices, if necessary, of personal ambition and factional pride, to unite for victory.
VERSAILLES, Ky., Aug. 6. -- H.C. Rodenbaugh is lying at death's door on account of the wounds inflicted on him by W. Newton Lane of Lexington, yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 6. -- Gov. Altgeld to-night dispatched Col. Hugh E. Boyle, Assistant Adjutant General, and George Schilling, Secretary of the State Bureau of Labor Statistics, to Spring Valley, to thoroughly investigate the situation and report to him.

Commissioner of Public Works Brookfield yesterday decided to award half of the work of asphalting several of the city streets, for which bids were opened last week, to the Fruin-Bambrick Construction Company of St. Louis, which was lowest in the aggregate bidding by about 14 per cent. New proposals for the other half of the work will be readvertised for.

If additional evidence was needed to prove that the business of this country is in a healthful state of improvement such evidence would be abundantly supplied in the reports of railway earnings for the month of July. Some surprising statements of increased earnings are made by various railroads in the East, West, and South.
Col. George E. Waring, Jr., Commissioner of Street Cleaning, returned to his office yesterday after an outing for a few days at Newport, R.I.

COWES, Aug. 6. -- Five yachts were expected to start to-day in the race for Her Majesty's Cup, over the old Queen's course, starting from off the castle, round the Bullock Patch Buoy, outside the Nab Lightship, thence around the Lymington Spit Buoy, and back to Cowes, fifty miles. They were the Britannia, the Hester, the Carina, the Meteor, belonging to Emperor William, and the Verena, all of which belong to the loyal .Yacht Squadron.

An application was made yesterday by John Mulholland, in behalf of Wiliam Reidell and David F. Gibb, to Justice Newburger, in the City Court, to set aside the report of Justice Bolte as referee in a suit against his clients instituted by Isaac Hoffman.

Gilt-edged security to the amount of $80,000 can secure temporary liberty for Sidney Smith, William E. Brockway, William S. Wagner, and Abbie L. Smith, charged by William P. Hazen, Chief of the Secret Service Division of the Treasury Department, with counterfeiting five-hundred-dollar United States gold bonds and one1hundred-dollar Bank of Montreal notes.

The New-York Times and public sentiment forced from Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn yesterday a statement which seems to be in direct conflict with some of his previous reported utterances concerning the enforcement of the excise law Sundays.
FLUSHING, L.I., Aug. 7. -- Flushing was deluged this morning. Rain fell in torrents for about twenty minutes. The storm was accompanied by a steady roll of thunder and almost incessant lightning.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, Aug. 7. -- The First Battery was drilling on the East Parade and the Sixth Battery on the North Parade at sunrise this morning, when they were interrupted by one of the heaviest rainstorms ever known in this part of the country. Two and one-half inches of rain fell in forty minutes. The batteries continued their drill despite the storm, which continued until 8:25.
AUBURN, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- Henry V. Whitlock, a prosperous and respected farmer of Cayuga County, was killed with an axe by his hired man, Charles Burgess, about 9 o'clock this morning.

Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn refused to-day to discuss the report of an interview with him which appeared in The Times this morning, in which he was represented as expressing surprise at learning of the non-enforcement of the excise laws on Sunday in that city. "I haven't had a chance to read the article you refer to, so don't bother me about it," he said.

In company with a number of distinguished gentlemen, in a running conversation on the subject of tipping, I gathered these ideas from them: Abroad, where waiters are paid nothing and have to rely upon their tips entirely, the diner is always expected to pay 5 per cent. of his check.

RAHWAY, N.J., Aug. 7. -- James McManus was attacked and nearly beaten to death last night by a gang of tramps at Colonia, about two miles from this place. McManus peddles dry goods and notions about the country, and was oh his way to Philadelphia. He was accompanied by his wife.

Tennessee was admitted to the Union June 1, 1796, and the Tennesseeans are making preparations to celebrate the centennial of that event by an exposition, to be held at Nashville, the State capital, in June of next year.

There was an unexpected sensation at the great mass meeting of delegates and citizens, held in Carnegie Hall last night in celebration of the Silver Jubilee of the Catholic Total Abstinence Union of America.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Aug. 7. -- The cruiser Atlanta, now at Key West on the lookout for Cuban filibusters, is badly in need of repairs, and it is understood that her contemplated recall is based principally on that fact.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- In point of attendance the first Grand Circuit trotting in this State under the new law was a success to-day. It remains to be seen, however, whether the people will forgive C.J. Hamlin for keeping Robert J. in the stable when he was advertised to meet Joe Patchen in what the card announced a "match race; purse $5,000."

The members of the East River Bridge Commission met yesterday afternoon at 51 Chambers Street, and, after a brief session, adjourned, to meet again on Wednesday next, when it is expected that definite action will be taken regarding the plan of Frederick Uhlman, President of the East River Bridge Company.

The letter of Mr. Willard, withdrawing the Vigilant from further competition with the Defender, is a very clear statement of a very clear case. According to the testimony of all competent observers, the Defender has twice, in racing with the Vigilant, transgressed the rules of the road.

In many aspects the contest in this State between the Republicans and the Democrats is bound to be advantageous to the Democrats. This must be apparent to every citizen who takes the interest in political affairs that all public-spirited Americans should take. A great change has come over the Democrats since last Fall, when the outlook was gloomy and the prospects for this year were discouraging.

Sarah Barton, twenty years old, of 2,215 Third Avenue, leaped from the roof of the four-story tenement house at 216 East One Hundred and Twenty-first Street, at 6:15 o'clock yesterday morning while laboring under temporary insanity, and sustained injuries from which she died two hours later.

The headquarters of Good Government Club G. of the Thirteenth and Fifteenth Assembly Districts, at 758 Eighth Avenue, was thronged last night because of the announcement that Col. George E. Waring, Jr., Commissioner of Street Cleaning, would make an address.

The cruiser New-York, flagship of the North Atlantic Station, left the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday morning and steamed down the river, en route for the rendezvous at Newport. The cruiser Montgomery followed in her wake.

The continued increase in the private deposits of the Bank of England and the very low discount rate in the face of the unmistakable improvement in business constitute a financial puzzle which The London Times attempts to solve. The Bank's private deposits now amount to 41,500,000, against 33,750,000 six months ago and 38,000,000 twelve months ago; while in the years previous to 1890 the July total of private deposits was 30,000,000 or less.
Brewer John W. Brown, head of the Long Island Brewing Company, said, yesterday.

Mayor Schieren, Controller Palmer, Bridge Trustees Keeney and Henriques, Engineers C.C. Martin, President Rossiter of the Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company, President Partridge of the De Kalb Avenue road, Superintendent Sullivan of the Jay and Smith Street lines, and Engineer Breckinridge of the Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company had a conference yesterday on the question of a surface railroad terminal at the bridge.

A letter printed in another column of The Times raises an incidental question which is more interesting if not more important than the question to which it is theoretically addressed. This question is whether the fact that the leading advocates of immunity for Maria Barberi, who killed her unfaithful lover, are women does or does not constitute an argument against the extension to women of the suffrage.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- The extraordinary argument which began in the office of the Controller of the Treasury to-day was brought about by Controller Bowler's refusal to issue a warrant for about $12,500 in favor of the Oxnard Beet Sugar Company of Nebraska, certified to the Auditor by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, and by the Auditor sent to the Controller for his action.

The twenty-fifth anniversary jubilee of the New-York Central Schuetzen Corps was held in Sulzer's Harlem River Park yesterday and Tuesday. The first day was devoted to a parade in the forenoon and prize shooting and a contest for King of Marksmen in the afternoon, while the night was given up to banqueting and a series of living pictures, after which dancing continued until past midnight.

That the excise law is generally and systematically violated in the City of Brooklyn on Sunday is not denied by anybody but Mayor Schieren. The brewers and liquor dealers express no doubt of it. That neither the Mayor nor the Police Commissioner makes any effort to have it enforced is admitted by everybody but themselves.

No stock was taken yesterday in the story that at the conference between Mayor Strong and President Roosevelt of the Police Department on Tuesday the Mayor had asked Mr. Roosevelt to order a halt in the enforcement of the excise law. Mr. Roosevelt laughed at this yarn. The Mayor has frequently said that the laws must be enforced.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 7. -- The call for the Republican State Convention, to be held in Trenton at noon Sept. 19 next, to nominate a candidate for Governor, was issued to-day. The apportionment of delegates is one for every 200 Republican votes cast at the last Gubernatorial election, and one for every additional 100 or fraction thereof, each ward and township to have at least one delegate.

The Assembly committee that is investigating the affairs of the Department of Charities of Kings County met in the City Court room, Brooklyn, yesterday, and Hugo Hirsh recalled William H. Hanna, the hardware dealer, who was on the stand Tuesday.

Funeral services over the body of Mrs. Susan Whittemore Talmage, wife of the Rev. Dr. T. De Witt Talmage, were held in the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. The church was crowded with the relatives and friends of the family.
Mr. F. Zittel, with Howard W. Badgeley, has sold for Ward Wheeler to W.B. Shepard, at $15,000, the three-story brick dwelling 592 West One Hundred and Fifty-second Street, 17 by 50 by 100.

Gold withdrawals from the Sub-Treasury yesterday amounted to $1,175,000, which will be shipped to Europe to-day. Handy Harmon, bullion dealers, took $170,000, on Assay Office cheeks, having deposited bullion in the Assay Office worth that amount. The Treasury supply lost nothing by this exchange.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 7. -- Perry Belmont gave a small dinner to-night in honor of Secretary Herbert. There were six guests. It was a very pleasant affair. Mr. Belmont early in the day took out a sailing party, consisting of Judge W.W. Douglass, H.F. Eldrige, Cambridge Livingston, Elisha Dyer, Jr., O.H.P. Belmont, and Nathaniel Thayer.

Senator John B. Gordon has the power of memorizing wonderfully developed. On more than one occasion the writer has followed him with proof slip in hand and been surprised at the accuracy with which he followed copy. On one occasion, while he was Governor of Georgia, the writer came down on the train with him from Atlanta to this city, where he was to deliver a speech.

The American Line steamship St. Louis sailed for Southampton yesterday with a full complement of saloon passengers. She will travel for the first time the northerly route, which is about ninety miles shorter than the southerly passage. This means a saving in time of between four and five hours.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 7. -- Hoke Smith, Secretary of the Interior, in an interview in regard to the business outlook of the South, based on investigations during his recent trip, says:

The greatest and, ultimately, the most beneficial movement set on foot by the City of New-York is the foundation of the botanic garden. It is quite true that only comparatively few citizens can grasp the importance of the undertaking because only a few can appreciate the ultimate aims and results of scientific research in general and botany in particular.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 7. -- The Associated Cycling Clubs of New-Jersey are sending out petitions requesting the wheeling organizations in this vicinity to work for an appropriation from the next Legislature for the construction of the proposed road from Piermont to Nyack, along the Palisades, to connect with the new boulevard which runs through Hudson County, beginning at Fort Lee and ending at Bergen Point.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Miss Elizabeth M. Flagler, the daughter of Gen. Flagler, Chief of Ordnance of the United States Army, who killed Ernest Green, a colored boy, last week, technically surrendered herself to the Warden of the District Jail this afternoon, to await the action of the Grand Jury.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 7. -- The Regatta Committee had a conference this morning, and the Cup Committee also took a hand in trying to straighten out the difficulty between the Defender and the Vigilant as to the right of way at the start in yesterday's race. During the afternoon A. Cass Canfield and J. Fred Tams of the Cup Committee visited Mr. Willard on board the Vigilant, and had a long talk with him.

LONDON, Aug. 7. -- The Pall Mall Gazette, commenting upon the withdrawal of the Vigilant from further contests with the Defender on the ground that the former took unfair advantage in the trials, says that an interesting contrast to this latest example of American sportsmanship is Lord Dunraven's action on the Clyde, when he made the Valkyrie, which crossed the line too soon, wait for the Ailsa and Britannia.
SARATOGA, Aug. 7. -- Saratoga had all kinds of weather to-day, including a thunderstorm and driving wind. It is very fine and warm to-night.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 7. -- The members of the Bloomfield Cycling and Athletic Association are considering a plan for the erection of a new clubhouse here. At present the association is quartered in the old Olympic Clubhouse on Bloomfield Avenue, which it leased about a year ago, and remodeled and furnished to suit its needs.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 7. -The bicycle races advertised for to-day brought out a large number of wheelmen, and as the prizes to be competed for were valuable and handsome, the disappointment was great when at about 10 o'clock in the morning the rain began pouring down in such quantities as to render all chance of riding a bicycle over country roads out of the question.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 7. -- Hugo Sager of 17 Belmont Place looked sheepish when arraigned in the Second Criminal Court to-day charged with having assaulted James A. Morgan of 369 Summer Avenue.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7. -- Fourteen jurors will be impaneled to try Theodore Durrant. Authority for impaneling fourteen jurymen comes from an act passed by the Legislature at its last session, providing for alternate jurors in cases that are likely to be protracted. As soon as the regular twelve jurors are impaneled, District Attorney Barnes will request Judge Murphy to allow the impaneling of two alternates.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 7. -- It was very warm here to-day, the thermometer at 4 P.M. registering 82 in the shade. Ordinarily this is the week in August that the Summer visitors journey from here to the mountains, but on account of the horse show this year they are stopping over for the week.

The Brooklyn police have another mysterious case on their hands -- one in some respects like the case of Dr. George Drury of 115 Johnson Street, who was lured to the vacant house at 67 Nevins Street and robbed two weeks ago.

With regard to the assertion of some of the individual coal shippers, that the railroads would not give them cars in which to send coal to market at cheaper rates than now exist, a railroad President said yesterday: "There are two roads that will give the individual shippers all the cars they can use at the rate of one-half a cent per ton. Those roads are the Ontario and Western, and the Susquehanna and Western."

Our Jack was the only out-and-out favorite that could win a race at Brighton Beach, though Palmerston was an even favorite with Bonaparte in the fourth race, and Kinglet was favorite for the last until "Dave" Pulsifer made a plunge on his old counterfeit, Governor Sheehan. The latter was supposed to be a dead-ripe watermelon, with Dave's money on, and so he went to the post at the short price.
The accident to La Touraine, caused by her port propeller striking against a bulged plate, is more serious than was at first supposed. The ship was placed in dry dock Tuesday night.

In your issue of July 31 you copy Mr. Frederick W. Peabody's declaration that "the cause of woman suffrage is daily receiving what are, or ought to be, its death blows at the hands of its friends. To any one who believes in the supremacy of law, recent published utterances of women advocates of woman suffrage will carry the deepest conviction that women should not be admitted to political equality with men."

There is what Federal officials call a New-York end to the Ann Street, West Hoboken, counterfeiting case, and Chief Hazen and his operatives were busy with it yesterday, while they would not give any particulars in regard to it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- The vacation of the Chinese Minister, Yang Yu, which he was spending at Niagara Falls and along the St. Lawrence River, has been brought to a sudden close by the reported massacres of missionaries, and the destruction of American and English missionary property in China.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Aug. 7. -- Two young men, who came to this place a few days ago, and opened business in rooms on Richmond Terrace, under the title of "The Electric News and Money Transfer Company," were arrested this morning on a charge of operating a poolroom. The warrant was issued by Justice of the Peace Acker upon the complaint of Lee J. Howell of 102 West One Hundred and Eighteenth Street, New-York City.

COWES, Aug. 7. -- Interest in to-day's race centred in the schooner match, but the Ailsa, having completed her alterations, again opposed the Britannia in the second race. The weather was fine, and there was a fine southwest breeze. The course was the old Queen's Course.
Two women made complaints against two policemen before Commissioner Andrew yesterday.

BUFFALO, Aug. 7. -- George Appo, the notorious New-York green-goods man, the star witness of the Lexow investigating committee, was arrested here last night, and is awaiting the arrival of a New-York officer.

DUBLIN, Aug. 7. -- The Freeman's Journal publishes a manifesto from Mr. Justin McCarthy addressed to "My Fellow-countrymen." The manifesto says that the dissensions in the ranks of the Irish party are ruinous to the Nationalist cause, and that the disasters can only be repaired by the restoration of discipline and by the party acting loyally together.

NORWOOD PARK, N.J., Aug. 7. -- Champion Wrenn had a close call with Stevens to-day in the Norwood Park tennis tournament, and may yet be defeated when the fifth set is played off. The champion managed to break even with Stevens on four sets, and the match will be played to-morrow from the point where it was stopped by darkness.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Aug. 7. -- A bolt of lightning during the storm this morning struck the tall flagstaff in Howell Park and shattered it into several pieces.

WOODHAVEN JUNCTION, L.I., Aug. 7. -- James Heyman, a carpenter employed by the New-York and Rockaway Beach Railroad Company, was killed by lightning during the shower early this morning. Stephen Remsen, a fellow-workman, was stunned by the same bolt.

JACKSON , Miss -- , Aug. 7. -- The Democratic Convention to-day began the construction of a ticket without adopting a platform. There is no doubt, however, that a resolution favoring the free coinage of silver at a ratio of 16 to 1 will eventually be adopted. Senator George was elected permanent Chairman, receiving 156 votes against 131 cast for C.C. Miller.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, July 31. -- Interesting advices, direct and unprejudiced, have just reached this island about France's little war on the Brazilian frontier. The story is told by an intelligent Jamaican who has been mine prospecting in British Guiana, and who proceeded from there to Carsevenne about the time of the Mapa incident.

Mayor Schieren's connivance at the open and flagrant violation of the Sunday excise law in Brooklyn is another grave scandal added to the many that have already made his administration a bad smell in the nostrils of good citizens.
William H. Rosenbach, a theatrical manager, is confronted with the possibility of spending 135 days in Ludlow Street Jail, and he does not like it.

The Lincoln Club, of which ex-Postmaster Cornelius Van Cott is President, put itself on record last night, at a meeting in its rooms in Clinton Place, as the first Republican organization in New-York State to take formal action in favor of the nomination of Gov. Morton as Republican candidate for President in 1896.
LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Aug. 7. -- Nina Gordon, at one time a member of the Wilbur Opera Company, was drowned in Bowery Bay this afternoon by the capsizing of a small boat.
LENOX, Mass., Aug. 7. -- Two of three thermometers agreed to-day that the highest point reached was 80 in the shade. The third one disputed the point, and made it only 79.

The efforts that were made in this country last Winter and Spring to alleviate the sufferings of those Armenians who escaped the Turkish massacres about Moush and Sassoun will need to be repeated to keep the thousands of destitute husbandless and fatherless Aremenians from starving this Winter.

Mrs. Phineas T. Barnum, widow of the great American showman, was married in this city yesterday afternoon to Demetrius Callias Bey, who is said to be a Greek, although bearing a Turkish title. The ceremony was private, and there was manifested on the part of those immediately concerned a disposition to keep the affair a profound secret.

ALBANY, Aug. 7. -- Three murderers made an unsuccessful attempt to escape from the Albany County Jail last night. They were Charles E. Davis, who murdered little May Shannon of Cohoes; Patrick Spain of this city, who stabbed his son to death, and Charles N. Smith, who killed Theodore Richymeyer of this city for his money. The three occupied a cell on the second floor of the jail.

MADRID, Aug. 7. -- Prime Minister Canovas del Castillo has replied to the protest of the Carlist Senators and Deputies against the payment of the Mora claim until the sanction of the Cortes shall have been obtained.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- United States Commissioner of Labor Carroll D. Wright, who succeeded Robert P. Porter as Superintendent of the eleventh census, to-day submitted to the Secretary of the Interior the report of the operations of the census for the fiscal year 1894-5. It shows that the total expense of the census up to date has been $10,531,142.

On the recommendation of Col. Grant the Police Board decided yesterday that every member of the force must get new buttons. The buttons worn by the police at present have on them the words "Municipal Police of New-York," while the proper title of the force is "Police Department of New-York."

The purchase of Carlyle's house, 24 Cheyne Row, Chelsea, has been completed, and the house will henceforward be open to public inspection. It was wisely determined that no formal ceremony should be held, as the place does not readily lend itself to a public celebration, and no time could be less suitable for such a purpose than the period of a general election.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 7. -- Otto Ziegler, the little California "demon," broke his arm in the mile open race at to-day's meet of the South Bend Cycling Club in this city. The arm was broken in two places. The fall occurred directly in front of the judges' stand. Scott was running sixth in the line, with Gardiner directly behind him and Ziegler behind Gardiner.

ALBANY, Aug. 7. -- The State Department at Washington to-day called the attention of authorities of the State of New-York to reports of damage inflicted on property and of danger to human life in the City of Niagara Falls, Ontario, resulting from blasting carried on by contractors who are constructing an electric railway on the American side of the Niagara River.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 7. -- The regular Wednesday evening dinner and dance was given to-night at the Kebo Valley Club. In spite of the disagreeable weather there was present one of the largest companies seen at Kebo this season. The guest of honor at the dinner was Gov. Morton. Mrs. Morton acted as the hostess of a party of twelve.

ALBANY, Aug. 7. -- Col. Cole, Gov. Morton's private secretary, said to-day that the Governor had decided that the report of the sub-committee of the joint legislative committee appointed to investigate the administration of affairs in the State prisons did not contain any charges against the State Superintendent of Prisons on which the Governor could act.

An exceedingly valuable article bearing upon the prehistoric inhabitants of Minnesota has been prepared by the Hon. J.V. Brower, embodying the results of investigations made by himself and Prof. T.H. Lewis about the head waters of the Mississippi. Mr. Brower is an adept in exploration and the best authority on the basin of the Upper Mississippi.

On the surface there was little or nothing of public interest about yesterday's meeting of the Tammany Executive Committee, or Committee of Sixty. It did not lose an hour. No suggestion looking to the broadening out of the organization as an important part of the Democratic Party in State and Nation emanated from this final meeting of the Sixty.

PRINCETON, Ill., Aug. 8. -- The Spring Valley miners did not return to work to-day, as promised yesterday, but the negroes will probably be permitted to return, and operations resumed in the mines to-morrow.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 8. -- The Casino subscription ball to-night was a grand affair. The Casino Theatre, where the dance took place, never appeared more attractive. Tall potted plants lined the entrance, and they were also grouped at the sides of the stage, which was set out with richly covered furniture and used as a point of view for the patronesses and their friends who did not dance.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 8. -- There was a large attendance to-day at the Summer School of Theology. Two lectures were delivered at the morning session. The first was by the Rev. Dr. Bowne, Professor of Philosophy in Boston University, on the subject, "Morals and Life." The doctor said the moral life had two poles, the subjective pole of good will and the objective pole of life itself.

There seems small prospect that the suit for an injunction instituted by Charles Haldane, on behalf of the old Police Justices and their Clerks, will bring about a ruling on the constitutionality of the act removing these officials and providing for the new Justices of the Courts of Special Session and the City Magistrates.

Recent exports of gold, with explanations by shippers that they sent out metal because bills of exchange were abnormally high, have led to guessing in the financial district in regard to the profit to be made from shipments. Several factors must enter into such a calculation. Much depends on the condition of the coin.

CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 8. -- The "Cannon Ball" train, over the White Mountain Division of the Boston and Maine Railroad, in charge of Conductor E.A. Bennett of Concord, left Plymouth at 5:30 this morning with clearance orders, and met a special freight which started from Concord at 2 o'clock, head on, at what is known as the "Fill," a short distance this side of Plymouth.

International copyright, the right of authors, artists, musicians, and publishers to protect and obtain payment for manuscripts and works of art in foreign countries, as well as in their own country, has been possible in the United States since Congress passed the Copyright bill on the last day of the session of 1891.
ROME, Aug 8. -- The American pilgrims who have been visiting this city have gone to Naples.

Solomon Goldstein, eleven years old, son of Morris Goldstein, a striking tailor, of 138 Madison Street, was committed by Magistrate Simms, in the Yorkville Court, yesterday to answer to a charge of burglary.

The Brooklyn police has induced Herbert McConnell, the nineteen-year-old clerk, who was employed by Druggist J. Fred Windolph, at State Street, near Flatbush Avenue, to confess that he was not robbed, as he alleged, Wednesday, but that his employer was robbed by himself and a friend, Charles Ernest Louthwood.

Filippo Giampata, proprietor of shoemaker's shops at 202 East One Hundred and Tenth Street and 181 East One Hundred and Seventeenth Street, who lives with his wife at the latter address, inflicted sixteen stiletto wounds on two young women yesterday afternoon, and, as he ran, pursued by two men, licked the blood from the stiletto.

BOSTON, Aug. 8. -- The Bostons played two games with the Brooklyns here this afternoon, and won both. Both victories were secured by good stick work. The Bostons used their old batting order, and the change worked to advantage. A crowd of about 6,000 persons was present. The Bostons' batting was clean and hard, Duffy and Bannon doing finely in both games.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 8. -- The mercury has behaved better to-day than yesterday, and only reached 74 at 2 o'clock, which was the maximum. The day was bright, with just breeze enough to make driving, bicycling, and golf delightful. After the two previous hot days everybody was out to enjoy all sorts of outdoor sports.
ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 8. -- William R. Morrison seemed surprised when asked to-day about a report that Senator David B. Hill had declared a preference for him for the Presidential nomination next year.

BUFFALO, Aug. 8. -- Miss Elizabeth Blaney Bird, well known in social and musical circles, committed suicide by shooting at 7 o'clock this morning, while suffering from melancholia. Miss Bird had been in bad health for a year or more. A few months ago she went to New-York for treatment, but obtained no relief. She returned to Buffalo about three months ago and became moody and subject to fits of melancholia.

The declaration of the Democratic Convention of Iowa on the currency question shows that the people of that State are advancing in their knowledge of the subject. The agitation of the last few months in the West has produced a notable educational effect, which is working its way to the South, and the author of "Coin's Financial School" has unwittingly done a public service by the impulse which he gave to the agitation.

Instant collapse of the middle section of the Ireland Building, on the northeast corner of West Broadway and West Third Street, at 10:53 o'clock yesterday morning resulted in death to three persons, injuries more or less grave to a dozen workmen, and damage that cannot be repaired short of $25,000.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The Post Office Department has prepared a statement showing the receipts of the twenty largest Post Offices in the United States for the second quarter ended July 31, 1895.

The construction of the two new 1,000-ton revenue cutters authorized by the last Congress has been let to the Atlantic Iron Works of Boston and the Globe Shipbuilding Company of Cleveland, Ohio. The Boston-built vessel will be called the Manning, in honor of the late Secretary of the Treasury, and that built at Cleveland will be named the Gresham, after the late Secretary of State.

NORWOOD PARK, N.J., Aug. 8. -- Wrenn and Stevens are still tied for first place in the invitation tennis tournament at the Casino court. Stevens kept up his magnificent work by taking three straight sets from Chace in a splendid contest. Stevens played like clockwork throughout, but toward the end of the match his passing down the lines was superb.

BERLIN, Aug. 8. -- Celebrations in commemoration of the German victories during the Franco-Prussian war continue to be held in various parts of the empire. At Aachen to-day the Hohenzollern Regiment (the Fortieth) held a demonstration, at which a telegram from Emperor William, who is at Cowes, Isle of Wight, attending the regatta of the Royal Yacht Squadron, was received. His Majesty, in his dispatch, said:

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 8. -- The second annual Horse Show of the Monmoutn County Association opened on the picturesque grounds of the Hoey estate, Hollywood, this afternoon at 2 o'clock, the grounds being crowded with a fashionable throng from the hotels and cottages, Mayor Strong being one of the interested spectators.
RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- The beautiful weather brought out about all the horses in town to-day. There was a great turn-out of riders, as well as of drivers.

At their meeting yesterday the Fire Commissioners abolished the places of Assistant Secretary, previously held by John R. Shields, at a salary of $2,500, and the clerkship held by Frank H. McLewee, at a salary of $1,500, and directed their duties to be performed by a Record Clerk, Dominique F. Derdinal, at a salary of $1,500; an index clerk, Louis A. Winkelbach, at a salary of $1,500, thus effecting a saving of $1,000.

There is a rather tiresome iteration of the argument in favor of letting saloon keepers violate the law, founded on the "rich man's" privilege of indulging in drink on Sunday at his club, and some go so far as to speak of the saloon as the "poor man's club." This is a case of arguing from analogy where there is no analogy.

NEWPORT, Aug. 8. -- In a fair clubtopsail sailing breeze and a rolling sea, the Defender defeated the Jubilee to-day 9 minutes 19 seconds. The race was sailed over a triangular course, the same as the course used in the races for the Drexel Cups.

Commissioner Feeney of the State Board of Arbitration, Andrew D. Best, Martin Connolly, and James Giblin of the Knights of Labor, had a conference with President Rossiter of the Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company yesterday afternoon. Subsequently Commissioner Feeney said:

The steam yacht Eleanor arrived in the harbor late yesterday afternoon. She is the property of W.A. Slater of Norwich, Conn., and is on a tour around the world. She is a long, white, slender vessel of graceful lines and handsome appearance.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 8. -- The weather up to 1 o'clock this afternoon was almost insufferably hot, but after that hour a good sea breeze came up, which cooled the air off and made it most invigorating.

H.O.R. Siefert, Assistant Superintendent of Schools, reports that out of 130 candidates examined for certificates permitting them to teach in the Milwaukee Schools, not one obtained the required percentage, and only two -- Norma Zinn of this city and Alice J. Garnett of Manitowoc -- stood sufficiently high to allow them another examination.

Bishop Potter held his last evening service at the Protestant Episcopal Mission, at 130 Stanton Street, yesterday, and to-day he will bring his month's residence there to a close, and return to the episcopal house in Lafayette Place.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The sentiment of prominent Democrats now in Washington is that the party is recovering rapidly from the crushing defeat of last fall.

There is but little doubt that from twenty to twenty-five thousand dozen eggs are taken for their albumen from nests in the Alaska hatcheries annually. In gathering these, nearly as many more are thrown away, having been partly hatched. Thus it will be seen that the destruction of eggs is something enormous.

The local racing men talked considerably yesterday of the intention of the Riverside Wheelmen to challenge the Kings County team to a match contest if the latter wins the ten-mile road race at New-Dorp to-morrow. Many argued that this course would not be as sportsmanlike as it would be to enter and compete against their rival in the regular race.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- Passed East -- Steam yachts Toinette, Robert D. Evans; Vision, F.H. Benedict; Jessie, Charles H. Murray; Orienta, E.R. Ladew; Tillie, W.H. Starbuck; Hirondelle. C.G. Evans; Golden Rod. A.C. Hoagland; Adira. H.M. Flagler, and Charlietta, W.B. Higgins; cutter yacht Huron, Edward S. Hatch.

The politicians of both the great political parties who have been all along assuming that the mass of votes in this city would be cast in favor of open saloons on Sunday are slowly recovering from the effect of the reception which Senator T.C. O'Sullivan's speech received from the Catholic Total Abstinence Union delegates on Wednesday evening in Carnegie Hall.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 8. -- Howell Edmunds Jackson, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, died at 2 P.M. to-day, at his residence at West Meade, six miles from this city.

That many of Mayor Strong's important appointees are violating the letter and spirit of the non-partisan platform upon which the Mayor was elected is being shown every day by the testimony of Republicans. The Mayor himself has endeavored to follow out the non-partisan spirit of the platform, but the Republican politicians are proving from day to day that certain of his subordinate officials are doing all in their power to violate it.
SARATOGA, Aug. 8. -- A grand musicale for the benefit of the free clergy rooms in the Bethesda Parish House was given in the Grand Union Hotel ballroom this noon.

Three months ago the corps of arithmetical experts upon whose services Chicago relies for the maintenance of her miraculous growth devoted forty-five minutes to scaling up the latest census. The result of this little effort was a grand total of 1,695,000 inhabitants within the boundaries of that modest municipality.

George Appo, who was used by Mr. Goff as a witness before the Lexow Committee, was yesterday taken before Recorder Goff to plead to the charge of assaulting Policeman Michael J. Ryan last April, at Sixth Avenue and Twenty-eighth Street. Appo cut the policeman in the neck.

To talk of Martian beings is not to mean Martian men. Just as the probabilities point to the one, so do they point away from the other. Even on this earth man is of the nature of an accident. He is the survival of by no means the highest physical organism. He is not even a high form of mammal.

It seems that the Samoans have developed a passion for the possession of large rowing boats built in European fashion. These have entirely taken the place of the canoes. Instead of cultivating their land, they now waste their time traveling about in these vessels from village to village, and from island to island, "discussing politics."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- There is already much speculation here concerning the vacancy on the Supreme Court bench, created by the death of Justice Jackson. The impression became quite general at the time of the reargument of the income tax cases that the Justice, who had come from Tennessee especially to be present at the hearing, was much improved in health, and would be able to resume his duties in the Fall.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- There is no longer any doubt about the respective merits of Joe Patchen and Robert J. When the champion fell before the prowess of the Kansas pacer at Cleveland, excuses were made for him that he lacked a race and had to face a wind that was too much for his strength, as compared with the big stallion.
ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- To-day's trains have still further augmented the river population. August will see high-water mark reached by the tide of arrivals.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Aug 8. -- Under the auspices of Mrs. Martha B. Stevens and other society leaders, a performance of "As You Like It" was given on the lawn of the Stevens mansion at Castle Point this afternoon in aid of the Edwin Booth Monument Fund.

A few months after the World's Fair closed there was a fire in the Manufactures Building which destroyed a number of valuable French exhibits. The exhibitors insisted that the exposition should make good their loss, alleging that if its officers had provided the necessary facilities for the removal of their goods they would have been out of the building long before the fire came.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- Sometimes a life insurance policy causes much trouble among those who are left to collect it. John Howard, a former resident of Yonkers, died in St. Vincent's Hospital, New-York, Tuesday. He obtained a separation from his wife some weeks ago, without her knowledge, she says, that it was necessary to send or make any answer to the summons.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 8. -- The Democratic State Convention to-day completed the State ticket and adjourned to-night. Congressman Money, the free-silver candidate for United States Senator, introduced the following resolution:

The fact that Excise Commissioner Julius Harburger had a long talk with Mayor Strong yesterday gave rise to the rumor that the enforcement of the excise law was under discussion. Mr. Harburger is pronounced in favor of a liberal construction of the law.

At the Grand Army encampment in Cleveland on Monday night Gen. Leggett related an incident which was vouched for to him as authentic. It is so remarkable that, coming from almost anybody else than the General, it would hardly be believed. During the war a squad of Confederate soldiers under command of a Captain captured a number of United States soldiers, and with them an American flag.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The Chinese Legation in this city is still without official information regarding the late outrages by the members of the "Vegetarian" Society in China upon the missionary and other foreign element residing near Kucheng. The members of the Legation claim never to have heard of the "Vegetarians" before.

LONDON, Aug. 8. -- A dispatch from Hongkong says that a large mob of infuriated Chinese attacked the British and American missions at Fatshan, near Canton, at noon yesterday.
