Some of the missionaries fled to Shameen for safety, but the others remained at Fatshan. Neither the Foreign Office nor the Wesleyan Mission has a report of this.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8. -- The principal items of news in this week's bulletin of the Racing Board, issued by Chairman Gideon, are as follows:

The accounts now at hand of the Belgian school law do not render any more explicable than they were before the riots that occurred in Brussels last month against the enforcement of the law. The last election showed that the Roman Catholics, or the "Clericals," had a clear and decisive popular majority in Belgium, and this although public education was known to be the main issue involved in the elections.

By the terms of her will, filed yesterday in the Surrogate's office. Mrs. Catherine Bradley disposes of an estate valued at $1,000,000, made almost entirely in the livery business. Mrs. Bradley was the widow of Daniel Bradley, a brother-in-law of Peter B. Sweeney of Tweed ring fame. She died last Saturday at Far Rockaway, where she had a Summer residence.

" Are the Southern women as energetic and as much interested in outside affairs as Northern women?" asked a reporter for The New-York Times of Mrs. Joseph Thompson, Chairman of the Board of Managers of the Woman's Building of the Atlanta Exposition in her charming room in the Waldorf last evening.

JERSEY CITY, N.J. Aug. 8. -- Commissioner Romaine said to-day that he did not feel disposed to reduce the amount of bail fixed in the case of Brockway, the counterfeiter, and he did not think the Treasury officials would consent to it in any event. He knew nothing about any further arrests.

I write to call attention to two decisions of the Supreme Court of Oregon, the highest tribunal of the State, handed down July 22, both of which affect disastrously important interests, and, if adopted as precedents outside of that State, must, it seems to me, greatly weaken general confidence in all securities and property interests dependent for their safety upon the protection of courts of equity, wherever situated.

President Roosevelt presided at the trial of delinquent policemen at Headquarters yesterday. There were seventy-eight cases on the calendar. Patrolman Wilkins of the High Bridge squad was accused by Acting Inspector McCullagh of having given false testimony while on trial on June 19.

Another easy victory at baseball for the New-York Club yesterday, and 3,000 or more spectators watched Freedman's men trample upon the Washingtons at the Polo Grounds. The New-Yorks certainly can play like "Giants" when they have no one in particular to play against.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 8. -- The decision of the Regatta Committee against the protest of Mr. Willard on behalf of the Vigilant was still the topic of conversation among yachtsmen. Opinions on both sides were heard, and the Regatta Committee was commended on the one hand, and condemned on the other.
Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn told a reporter for The New-York Times Tuesday that he had ordered the saloons closed Sundays, and had received reports from the police saying they were closed.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., Aug. 8. -- Senator B.R. Tillman, ex-Governor of South Carolina, spoke in debate in Prohibition Park to-night against Samuel Dickie, Chairman of the National Committee of the Prohibition Party. This was the first of two debates on the liquor question. Senator Tillman will enter the lists against ex-Gov. John P. St. John to-morrow night.

SARATOGA, Aug. 8. -- The feature of the racing here to-day was the race for the Albany Stakes for all ages, at seven furlongs. Rey del Carreres was the favorite, with Lissak, one of the best of the Western horses, second choice. But Pierre Lorillard's selling plater, Anisette, with Griffin up, beat both of them after a hard fight, the trio finishing short heads apart.

As a result of the disorder which attended the return parade of the Joseph Welling Association chowder party, when several Central Office detectives were mobbed by thieves Wednesday night, Acting Chief Conlin said yesterday that he would give no more permes for night parades of chowder parties.

The puzzlement of the politicians about the ground that "good politics" requires them to take concerning the enforcement of the law is one of the most comic and exhilarating incidents of an August that is beginning to need all the enlivenment it can get. The notion of the politicians at first was that "the people" were opposed to the enforcement of the Sunday features of the excise law.

That the best of intentions will not prevent men from doing the most injudicious of things, unless with the good intentions there is combined a saving portion of knowledge, is well illustrated by the case of Mr. W.K. Dexter. He is a rich St. Louis man who owns a large tract of land on the shore of Lake Hiawatha, in Hennepin County, Minn.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8. -- The story of the sinking of two vessels in collision and probable loss of about forty lives was told this evening by Capt. Henderson, late of the British ship Prince Oscar, who, with sixteen of his crew, arrived at this port this afternoon on the British steamer Capac from Chilean and Peruvian ports.
The new cup challenger may get here in time for her crew to see the new cup defender in her trial races off Sandy Hook, which take place beginning on the 20th inst.
PANAMA, via Galveston, Aug. 8. -- Guayaquil's advices from the army confirm the reports of the battle which was fought Aug. 6 at San Miguel, near Chimbo, south of Guaranda.

ALBANY, Aug. 8. -- Supreme Court Justices are to be elected in each of the eight judicial districts of New-York State. This is an uncommon event, and, as a result, ambitious lawyers are putting forth all their efforts to secure nominations where a nomination is equivalent to an election.

An interesting and wonderful feature of the natural scenery of Lake Erie shores are two immense conically shaped sand formations, in the Township of Houghton, Norfolk County, Ontario, just west of Long Point.

LONDON, Aug. 8. -- A dispatch to Lloyds from Sydney, New South Wales, says that the British steamer Catterthun, bound from Sydney for Hongkong, ran on the Seal Rocks, which lie between Sydney and Brisbane, and became a total wreck. The dispatch adds that some of the passengers and crew were saved, but that a number of persons are missing.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 8. -- A ball was given to-night at the Kebo Valley Club by James A. Garland of New-York, in honor of Miss Louise Garland, who makes her debut this evening. The ballroom and the entire clubhouse was decorated and illuminated beautifully. Japanese lanterns were placed at intervals of a few feet all over the large grounds.

Wrong impressions are hard to eradicate from the human mind. In the North and West it is a popular delusion that Southern Summers are extremely hot and oppressive, and that life here during the Summer months is almost unbearable. This impression is formed upon no knowledge of the matter, but simply upon the assumption that, as we are nearer the equator, it must necessarily be much warmer than in more northern latitudes.

CANANDAIGUA, Aug. 9. -- It is a tooth and nail fight that Senator Raines has on for renomination, and the forces are all drawn up in battle array for the engagement of the primaries to-morrow. The Senator is trying to create the impression that Frank H. Hamlin has not much of a show. Raines's friends are very sanguine, and many declare that he will carry the county with scarcely any opposition.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- The State Department this morning received a cable dispatch from Mr. Campbell, United States Consul at Port Louis, Mauritius, saying that the wife of ex-Consul Waller, now in prison in France, and her four children, who arrived there last June, will be sent to Paris by him on the steamer that sails Aug. 20.

The efforts to recover the bodies of those who went down with the interior part of the building at West Broadway and West Third Street Thursday morning were continued Thursday night, all day yesterday, and last night, under the direction of Contractor Galligan, acting under orders from the Department of Buildings and Fire.

Hugo Hirsh, counsel for the Assembly Committee that is investigating the Charities Department affairs in Kings County, is slowly dragging out the story of the mismanagement of the various institutions of the county.

Mrs. Diehl, wife of Samuel B. Diehl, superintendent of the Pinkerton Detective Agency, 66 Exchange Place, who lives at 450 Throop Avenue, Brooklyn, by a story told to the Brooklyn police yesterday added another to the criminal mysteries of the City of Churches and Sunday saloons.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 9. -- Knight B. Wade, ex-Manager of the Yale track athletic team, is here completing preparations for the Yale-Cambridge track games on Manhattan Field, New-York, Oct. 5. He says that the seats for the occasion will be disposed of by the application system used in dispensing the seats for all the intercollegiate matches the last year.

General usage and the consensus of the dictionaries appear to be at variance with respect to the word "princess." The members of the royal family have for so many years been in the habit of taking part in philanthropic undertakings that the words "prince," "princes," "princess," "princesses," have become among all classes of the community "familiar in their mouths as household words."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Arrangements for the funeral of the late Associate Justice Jackson, at West Mead, Nashville, Sunday afternoon, owing to the widely scattered locations of the members and officers of the Supreme Court, will necessarily have to be made by telegraph. Chief Justice Fuller was at his Summer home, Sorrento, Me., and the other Associate Justices are scattered over the country from the Atlantic to the Pacific.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9. -- Fred J. Titus won a most sensational five-mile race at to-day's National Circuit meet in this city, under the auspices of the Associated Cycling Club of this city and the Chicago Athletic Club. The contest had eleven starters, and but three remained at the close, Titus, who finished about 100 yards ahead of Murphy, and Scott, who was away back of the latter.

The election of Judges is going to be of special importance in this State this year. and the character of judicial nominations may have no slight effect upon the fate of party "tickets." The new judiciary system established by the revised Constitution takes effect at the beginning of next year.

DULUTH, Minn., Aug. 9. -- The $600,000 case of William McKinley, John McKinley and James Charnley of this city against John D. Rockefeller and the Lake Superior Consolidated Mines, in which the jury recently disagreed after being out forty-eight hours, will never again be brought to trial for it has been settled, the plaintiffs agreeing to accept in the neighborhood of $200,000 in lieu of all claims.

I had not long left a public school, and was unconscious of the possession of nerves. Given sufficient hold for hand and foot. I never felt any more inclination to fall in a place where a fall would carry me a couple of thousand feet to the bottom of a precipice than where it would only involve a tumble of a yard into soft snow.

When Socrates was asked whether it was better for a man to marry or remain single, he answered: "Let him take which course he will, he will repent of it." The reply recalls that of the youth who, on being asked which of two roads was less bad, said: "Take either, and before you get half way you will wish you had taken the other."

The resolutions of the Catholic Total Abstinence Union are very significant and to many readers will be very surprising. The general notion of the attitude of the Catholic Church toward the "Puritan Sabbath" has undoubtedly been that expressed the other night by Senator O'Sullivan, who was so astonished to find his expressions received with marked disfavor.

It is gratifying to notice that President Cleveland and his associates in his Cabinet, with their families, when they seek refuge from the heat of Summer and look for rest from official weariness, quickly turn to the waters, the forests, the valleys, and the hills of New-England.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 9. -- The horse show was continued at Hollywood to-day, some 2,000 people, mostly ladies, being in attendance. There were but few competitors in most of the classes, and the show was hardly first-class from a horseman's standpoint in consequence. But it is a marked success socially, and so fulfills its mission.
The convention of the Catholic Total Abstinence Union of America adopted clear and unmistakable resolutions yesterday against the use of intoxicants and in opposition to their sale on Sundays.

ROCKAWAY BEACH, L.I., Aug. 9. -- There is a whirlpool in Jamaica Bay. It is just off a point of low, seaweed-covered land, that juts out into the bay about a half mile west of the Long Island Railroad trestle, and the same distance from Beach Channel Station, on the trestle.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- Assemblyman Abell's special committee continued its tour of inspection of the Regents' Department to-day, and afterward Secretary Melvil Dewey took the stand and explained in detail the work of the Regents of the university and its various departments, and his own duties and authority.
SARATOGA, Aug. 9, -- There was another dull day at the track here to-day. The fields were small, the horses were a commonplace lot, and the racing was spiritless and without incident. The results:

The sixth annual regatta of the Middle States Regatta Association will be held to-day on the Harlem River. There are forty-six entries in the regatta, and the list in some of the events is so large that it is necessary to row the trial heats in the forenoon. Therefore, the junior singles, intermediate singles, intermediate doubles, and possibly the eight-oared junior shell race may have their trial heats decided in the forenoon.

NORWOOD PARK, N.J., Aug. 9. -- The tennis players here would reduce the most expert calculator to despair. Wrenn and Stevens, who have been both playing in excellent form, and who had not lost a match up to noon, struck a snag together, and there is a four-cornered tie for the big bowl.

RUTLAND, Vt., Aug. 9. -- A rare assembly of men gathered last week at the midsummer meeting of the Vermont Fish and Game League at he picturesque island home of Nelson W. Fiske, the President of the club, at Isle La Motte, one of the group of Grand Isles of the Vermont shore of Lake Champlain.
Acting Chief Conlin had all the Captains and precinct commanders before him at Headquarters yesterday afternoon. He talked to them for half an hour on matters pertaining to police business.
There is good reason to believe that the unknown ship which sank, with her crew, after being in collision with the British ship Prince Oscar off the coast of Brazil is the British ship Holt Hill.

" Well," said I to the Rev. Thomas Moody, after his lecture on Central Africa on Monday night, "what's the use of all the sacrifices you make to preach Christianity to those Africans? What good does it do them to be converted, after all, and how can you tell they are converted?" "You can tell they are converted easily enough," was the reply.

Pardon Ponder is a story teller with delightful powers -- your New-England improvisatore, if you choose to call him so -- for though he may tell of the customs of the ancients in good prose, he lapses every now and then into poetry, reciting old-fashioned ballads. Pokanoket House looked out on Mount Hoke and Narragansett Bays, and was hallowed with the memories of Hallowe'en.

It reads like one of "life's little ironies" that Oliver's wife and eldest daughter should actually take a journey to Hampton Court, to be presented to his Majesty the King. Tradition declares that, later on, when the shadow of a death, such as had befallen no other English monarch, loomed darkly over that same King, Elizabeth pleaded for his life.

SARATOGA, Aug 9. -- In conversation with The New-York Times's correspondent, Judge Robert A. Van Wyck of the New-York City Court, who is at the Grand Union Hotel, said:

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- The ex-champions had their innings at the Grand Circuit meeting to-day, when Mascot and Hal Pointer met in a special race for an alleged purse of $2,000. As in the race between Joe Patchen and Robert J., no money was at stake, but that did not detract from the merits of the contest.

While it is true that the alliance of the Westinghouse Electric Company and the Baldwin Locomotive Works is a logical union suggested by the requirements of the electric motor industry, it is something more, and it has a significance beyond that which attaches to a reasonable division of labor and an attempt to avoid the cost of an unnecessary duplication of plant.
" If you sit on that box you will sit on a nest of snakes," said the present proprietor of a hundred or more of the most deadly of the reptiles, down in a South Street store the other day.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 9. -- Fremont Smith was hanged in San Quentin Prison this morning for two brutal murders committed near the town of Colusa, in December, 1893. Smith and two companions known as Dolph and Charley were fishermen, and lived in a cabin together. The murderer chopped Dolph to pieces with an axe and shot Charley.

The last two weeks of the School of Ethics at Plymouth will be partly given up to educational subjects. Ray Greene Huling, Sc. D., head master of the English High School in Cambridge, Mass., opened the course with a lecture on the early movement toward the higher education of women.

Foreign military organizations in this State desirous of playing soldier will have to submit to the following tests before they can consider themselves legitimately organized. Gov. Budd has issued the following manifesto:

A society is now being organized for the elimination of the nasal twang from Yankee speech, for the suppression of the Irish brogue in public places, and for the retirement of German pronunciation from English words.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., Aug. 9. -- Ex-Govs. B.R. Tillman of South Carolina and John p. St. John of Kansas crossed verbal swords in debate on the liquor question in the Prohibition Park Auditorium to-night, but the swords were but as foils compared to those that gave such sharp cuts last night when Senator Tillman argued the question of State control of the liquor traffic with Chairman Samuel Dickie of the National Prohibition Committee.

STATE CAMP, Peekskill, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- All the powder that the State furnished the batteries, and there was a ton in all, has been burned. The First and Sixth fired all they had left before breakfast, making it impossible for the laggard to sleep within two miles of camp, and after breakfast the Fifth and Second continued the din.

In a quiet reach of water beside the walls of Soo-Chow we saw many flocks of ducks, each containing 500 to 1,000 birds. The shores were covered, and the water was alive with them. The herders sat idly in small boats, while the ducks swam freely about, each flock making a great, tremulous brown spot upon the water.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 9. -- Quite a number of the "crackajacks" of New-York and New-Jersey will compete in "The New-York Times Winners' Race," at the meet of the Tourist Cycle Club, at the Clifton track to-morrow. Foremost among them are Howard P. Mosher, the Storm King wonder, who won the mile event at the Tourist circuit meet on July 3, in 2:12; Ray Dawson, C.S. Henshaw, "Burt" Ripley, Elmer Hodgson, A.W. Able, and Jacob Kegelmann.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 9. -- The rush of social gayeties still continues and will culminate in the grand ball which will be given in honor of the Secretary of the Navy and the officers of the North Atlantic squadron on the 20th of the month.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 9. -- Vincenzo Siniscaleke of 290 Fifteenth Avenue was placed under $300 bail by Justice of the Peace Graul last night for having stabbed Rocco Blasi in the ear with a pair of scissors.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 9. -- Charles Stewart, William Fisher, Frank Chamberlain, and Benjamin Wagner, all residents of Philadelphia, hired a rowboat in that city last night and went sailing on the Delaware River. They brought a quantity of provisions and liquor with them, and rowed toward the Jersey shore.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- The hearing to convince Controller Bowler that he should pay the sugar bounty, as authorized by the last Congress, was continued to-day, Senator Caffery of Louisiana taking the floor. He contended that the judicial power was lodged in the Judicial Department alone, and that the law in question was Constitutional.

The first of these volumes, bound in law sheep, contains the excise laws, public officers' laws, provisions of the Penal Code and Code of Criminal Procedure applicable to violations of the excise laws; local acts relating to excise in New-York, Brooklyn, and Buffalo; United States statutes and regulations relating to the payment of taxes by liquor dealers; and statutes relating to the rights, liabilities, and duties of hotel keepers.
A detective from the Central Office is looking in the vicinity of Newark, N.J., for the man who abandoned five-year-old James Milton Rogers at the Continental Hotel last Monday evening.

One characteristic anecdote of Mrs. Kemble, which, so far as I know, has not got into print, may be mentioned. Two youthful friends of hers having given invitations for a picnic on the border of the Stockbridge Bowl, Mrs. Kemble, with the warm-hearted sympathy she always showed toward young people, associated herself with them in the plan and made the entertainment much more complete than they had intended.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 9. -- In Holsman Street, at No. 95, there is a small white-painted tenement house. For five years it has been occupied by three families. The Haights and the Whites occupied one-half of the house between them, while the Breens occupied the other half. The company of the Breens was never very acceptable to the Haights and the Whites, and there has been a coldness at times between them.

The question of a terminal for the surface railroads at the bridge station in Brooklyn is still unsolved. Another long conference was held yesterday. Those present were Mayor Schieren, Controller Palmer, Bridge Trustees Keeney and Henriques, President Rossiter, Bridge Engineer Martin, Brooklyn Heights Railroad Engineer Breckinridge, and Smith Street Railroad Superintendent Sullivan.

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- There was a large attendance at the Sing Sing Methodist Episcopal camp meeting to-day. Many of the new arrivals were from New-York. By Sunday everything will be in full operation.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 9. -- Twenty persons were injured in a street-car accident near Crown Hill Cemetery this afternoon. The most seriously injured are:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Political circles are interested in the announcement made to-day that Gen. W.W. Dudley of Indiana has declined to allow the use of his name as a delegate to the next Republican Presidential Convention. The reason assigned in the publication was that Gen. Dudley would antagonize his old Indiana friends, should he be sent to the convention and vote against the renomination of ex-President Harrison, as he would be compelled to do.

The death of Justice Jackson gives the President an opportunity which he will without doubt embrace to give the chief commercial community of the country a representation upon the bench of its highest tribunal. The argument for the appointment of a New-York lawyer to the vacancy is in fact overwhelming.

OCEAN GROVE, Aug. 9. -- The School of Theology met in the tabernacle to-day and several hundred ministers present were treated to four excellent addresses. The first lecture was by the Rev. Dr. B.P. Browne of Boston University. His theme was "Morals and Religion." The Rev. Dr. C.J. Little of Evanston, Ill., followed, reviewing the life of Bernard of Clairvaux.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 9. -- This has been a very warm day. The thermometer at 9 o'clock A.M. registered 75 in the shade, and at 2 o'clock P.M. 87.

SARATOGA, Aug. 9. -- United States Senator Edward Murphy and his family are quartered this season at the cottage of ex-Judge C.S. Lester, which the Senator has leased for the season. It is located on North Broadway and First Street, in a part of the village that suggests a well laid out park, with a few fine residences scattered among the lawns, trees, and shrubbery.
Tammany Hall is not going to display its hand in the forthcoming championship game of politics.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 9. -- The Defender ran aground this afternoon. She had been out sailing on Narragansett Bay to stretch the new Wilson mainsail, which was bent on yesterday. A strong wind was blowing from the southwest, and the water was quite rough. She had come into the channel between Fort Adams and Goat Island, and was rounding up to come to her anchorage.

BOSTON, Aug. 9. -- The American Board of Foreign Missions has received from Rev. James H. Pettee of Okayama, Japan, advance sheets of a report which covers "A Chapter of Mission History in Modern Japan," a sketch for the period since the beginning of modern missions in Japan in 1869.
SARATOGA, Aug. 9. -- Mr. and Mrs. C.E Spoon of New-York City last night celebrated the thirteenth anniversary of their marriage.
PANAMA, via Galveston, Aug. 9. -- Guayaquil (Ecuador) reports contain the announcement that the forces of Gen. Vernaza are still in control of Guaranda.

Walter Clarence Hoyt will devote the next three months to initiating the Summer boarders on Blackwell's Island into the mysteries of the Arapahoe, Navajo, Apache, Spanish, Portuguese, and other more or less living languages.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 9. -- G.S. Moulton of New-York arrived in Lenox on his four-in-hand last night. In the party are Mrs. Moulton, I.L. Rogers, Julien A. Ripley, and Louis E. Ripley. The vehicle is an omnibus road coach, with red and black running gear, and black body picked out in red. Mr. Moulton drives three bays and a brown. He came from Litchfield and will go on to Pittsfield and Williamstown.
Great excitement was caused at the Battery last night by an unknown man Jumping into the bay between the bath houses and committing suicide.

Not only am I of opinion that English amateur rowing would not occupy the high place it does to-day were it not for this definition, (the exclusion of mechanics, artisans, and laborers,) but, strange as it may sound to our American ideas of democracy. I believe we must adopt some very similar ruling if we ever hope to attain a correspondingly high standard.

AUBURN, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- Charles Burgess, the murderer of Farmer Whitlock, who was captured last night, was brought safely to the jail in this city to-day. He talked freely to the constable on his way here, and several times broke down and wept. "I don't know why I did it," he kept iterating.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 9. -- T. Dabney Marshall, Senator-elect from Warren and Hinds Counties, shot and killed R. T. Dinkins of Jackson in Brandon, this morning. Marshall and three friends, H. H. Coleman, R. P. Fox, and W. P. Vollens, drove to Brandon in a hack and met Dinkins at the station. As he turned a corner of the building, they opened fire on him and shot him fifteen times.
Tinge was the only one of the six favorites that could, or, at least, that did win a race at Brighton Beach yesterday afternoon. The other five were beaten out as is customary at the Beach track.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Acting Secretary Adee has received from United States Consul General Jernigan, at Shanghai, a dispatch, dated July 12, inclosing four letters received by him from missionaries giving in great detail accounts of the events in China leading up to the riots against the missionaries at Cheng-Tu in the Province of Szechuen.

BERLIN, Aug. 9. -- Among the regiments which took part yesterday in the celebrations in commemoration of the German victories in the Franco-Prussian war was the Forty-eighth, (Brandenburg) Regiment, which celebrated at Kuestrin, 17 miles northeast of Frankfort, the battle of Spicheren.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- A curious state of affairs to which attention is invited by the performance of the Columbia on its transatlantic trip exists concerning the ships built under Governmental auspices. It appears that there are very inadequate records of the speeding abilities of these vessels by which their work may be compared with vessels built by contract.
One of the phrases upon which defenders of connivance at violation of the excise law on Sunday are constantly ringing senseless changes is "liberal construction" of the law.

Acting Chief Conlin yesterday carried out his determination to put an end to the scenes of disorder which have attended night parades of returning chowder parties by refusing permits in three instances. Applications were made to the Acting Chief by three chowder parties to parade at night and have fireworks.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 9. -- That no fines were imposed nor players ordered out of to-day's two contests was remarkable. Every member of the respective teams seemed determined to bulldoze the umpires whenever there was the slightest pretext therefor. As a result of this cantankerous spirit, the first game was a record breaker, dragging along for three hours.

AS James Hanna and William Roke, woodchoppers, were about to take two young wildcats from a hollow log near Natalie, Penn., Wednesday morning, the mother cat appeared on the scene. In the fight that ensued, the female wildcat was brained, and both men were severely injured. Hanna and Roke were on their way to work, when their attention was attracted by cries that sounded like those of an infant.

SARATOGA, Aug. 9. -- The Democratic politicians are coming. They always do come here about this time in the Saratoga season. For conference? Certainly not. Did any one ever hear a Democratic politician say ho was going to Saratoga for a conference? Of course not. The idea is preposterous.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Aug. 9. -- The entertainment at the Summer Theatre last evening brought out a large audience, and was a pronounced success. After the audience had left the theatre, Dr. Howard of New-York discovered that he had lost a valuable diamond stud, worth $500. A search for it was unsuccessful, and the doctor returned to his hotel.

Thanks mainly to Mr. Carlyle, every one has heard of the tree Yggdrasill, the world tree of Norse mythology, on which Odin was hanged, a god sacrificed to himself. Apparently much that we have taken for granted about this tree is wrong -- at least, if Mr. Eirik Magnusson is right. In his "Odin's Horse," (S.P.C.K.,) Yggdrasill is not so much a tree, it seems, as a horse! The full name is Yggdrasill's askr."

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 9. -- The most important sale of trotters that has occurred here this season took place to-day, when W.C. France Son of New-York City sold all their remaining trotters. The famous stallion Red Wilkes was sold for $9,800 to A.H. Moore of the Cloverdell Stud, Colmar, Penn. E.E. de Cerna paid $10,000 for Allie Wilkes, and a long price for Clay King, presumably for James Gordon Bennett.

" The convention of the Catholic total abstainers of 1895 is going to have an incalculable effect in settling the excise question for New-York and Brooklyn," was the remark yesterday of the Rev. James M. Cleary, who has been, since 1882, President of the Catholic Total Abstinence Union of America, having been again re-elected to that position yesterday.

The Justices of the Court of Special Sessions have been very much worked up over the wholesale transfer of excise cases from their court to the Court of General Sessions. After much deliberation they sent an open letter on the subject to the District Attorney yesterday.

From The Fortnightly Review. It is only fifty-two years since Hongkong was occupied, as Singapore had been thirty-three years previously, under the idea that it might be made an emporium of trade. It was then a barren rock. To-day it contains a quarter of a million of inhabitants; it is the entrepot of a trade estimated at $40,000,000, and there pass through it annually some 14,000,000 tons of shipping.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 10. CHIEF among the events of the week were the annual Casino subscription ball, the yacht races, and the two dinners given by Mrs. William Astor at Beechwood.

One of my most interesting acquaintances at that period of my life was the Count Gonfalonieri, the friend and companion in prison of Silvio Pelico, who wrote "Le mie Prigione." The evening before we were to land at Venice he came to me when I happened to be alone on deck, and after ascertaining that no one was within hearing, he asked me if I would grant him a little favor.

The Chicago detectives continue to make fresh discoveries as to the methods which appear to have been used by Holmes in getting rid of the persons who disappeared in his house in that city, but it may be that the evidence which they have thus obtained is not sufficient to insure his conviction. It may be difficult, also, to fasten upon him the murder of Pietzel in Philadelphia.

Our London correspondent has taken note of a general expectation in Europe that Lord Salisbury is likely to play an important part in the complicated questions that have accumulated there. It is even probable that his accession to power has aggravated the complication through the fear that questions that have been allowed to slumber will now receive attention.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- The baseball game between the Waterville club and the Richfields drew a large number of people, and at least one-half of those in attendance were ladies. The game was close and exciting and was admirably played by both teams. Richfield won by a score of 9 to 7.

In the last number of Meehan's Monthly the editor tells of being summoned to hold an inquest over a dead sugar maple tree. It was supposed to have been destroyed by a leak in the city gas main, near its roots, but an examination convinced Mr. Meehan that the tree had died literally from sunstroke.

While it is almost an impossibility to give anything like a correct statement of what the output of bicycles will be this year, it is by common consent spoken of as between 400,000 and 500,000 wheels. A majority of close observers in the trade would doubtless fix the figures at 450,000.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10.--Lynn C. Troutman, a prominent contractor, was drowned in the Schuylkill River at Shawmont, a suburb of Philadelphia, yesterday afternoon.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 10. -- The sixth annual baby parade held on the shore front this afternoon was a record breaker in many respects. In the first place, there were more paraders in line than ever before, for to-day's procession, including the half-grown boys and girls and the babies, numbered over 800.

PARIS, July 31. -- The facts of the case are true. "Fresh, the American," is authentic. He is even now flesh and bone, and not a raw Yankee, as you may judge. He is, rather, one of those cosmopolitans, frequently born in our own land who know all without learning and graduate senior-wrangler without having gone through the tedium of the course.

ROSLYN, L.I., Aug. 10. SO FAR the Summer season at Roslyn has been a very delightful and prosperous one. There is a large number of people who enjoy the combination of beautiful scenery and the quiet home life here.

Joseph Guider of 773 Bergen Street, Brooklyn, the contractor for the plastering work on the building at West Broadway and West Third Street, in which portions of the floors fell Wednesday morning, was placed under arrest yesterday afternoon on a warrant issued by Coroner Fitzpatrick. It is supposed his arrest was due to the presumption that there was too much plaster stored on the floors.

WILLETS POINT, L.I., Aug. 10. -- This being the station of the Battalion of Engineers, the highest branch of the army, it is one of the most important military posts in the United States. Here are to be found much of the mighty machinery of war and the brains and hands constantly in training by which it would be manipulated in case of emergency.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- The annual garden party given this afternoon by the Saratoga Racing Association attracted the largest gathering seen at the running park this season. The hospitality of the clubhouse was extended to those who received special invitations.

The physicians of Colorado manifest much concern about an increase of the consumptive death rate in that State. This increase -- as to which we have no statistics -- is due partly, of course, to the fact that certain places in Colorado have become attractive resorts for consumptives not only from other States, but even from Europe.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., Aug. 10. REFRESHING breezes blue skies, charming Summer girls, and a surfeit of Saturday-night hops form a combination that is not easily beaten. This is just what has been going on at Far Rockaway during the last few weeks.

ROCKAWAY BEACH, L.I., Aug. 10. -- Fifty thousand persons came here to-day to attend the great Democratic harmony meeting. Seaside Avenue and the adjacent streets were brilliant with multicolored flags and arches that bespoke a hearty welcome to the Democratic hosts.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Aug. 10. AS expected, Sea Cliff is filled to overflowing with Summer guests, and will probably continue to be during the present month. In a recent swimming contest Miss May Ehrhardt of New-York won a silver watch as first prize.
" A thief is a pretty good fellow," remarked an old timer one day. "but I hain't got no use for a bum."

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 10. -- The annual field games of the Catholic Young Men's Diocesan Union of the Diocese of Newark, at Caledonian Park, this afternoon, attracted one of the largest crowds ever seen at an athletic meeting in Newark. The fair sex turned out in force, and fully equaled in numbers those of the masculine gender.
EDGEMERE, L.I., Aug. 10. -- The first of the series of invitation dances announced by the management of the Edgemere for August and September was brilliantly inaugurated to-night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- The Pension Office is threatened with a religious war, and some recent occurrences have lent a curious aspect to this impending conflict.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 10. -- The feature of to-day's matinee trots of the Mutual Driving Association at Waverly was a team race between J.D. Cuthill's Fred and mate, R. Jennings's Jenness and Gypsy, Mr. Decker's O.K. and Ashworth, and George Stengel's Aleck and Dick. Three heats were trotted, each team winning except Mr. Cuthill's, in the best time of 2:37 1/2. The race will be finished next Saturday.

It is a somewhat trying ordeal for a body of scientific men to be told that on many fundamental points of their professional belief they have always been in error. This was the experience of the members of the American Dental Association at the Thursday night session of its annual meeting, which was held last week at Asbury Park, N.J.

FORT HILL, S.C., Aug. 10. -- The home of John C. Calhoun, the great apostle of State's rights, who, standing alone, defeated the power of President Andrew Jackson, must ever remain a spot of interest to the student of the growth of nations.

One of the features of the day's sport was the bringing out of a new sculler, E.W. Gaillard of the Atalanta Boat Club of this city. He won his trial heat in the morning in 6:15 1/4, the best time of any of the trials, and in the afternoon won the final "in a gallop" in 6:13, beating his nearest competitor, Moran of the Beverwyck Club of Albany, 10 1/2 seconds.

" Tommy" Conneff ran a remarkably fast mile yesterday afternoon at the games of the St. George Athletic Club, at the club's grounds, Weehawken, N.J. He covered the distance in 4:21, and, had the track been in better condition, it was the opinion of the critics that the American record of 4:17 4-5 held by Conneff, would have been smashed.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10. -- Marshall T. Greene, President of the Chinese Lumber Company, one of the largest concerns of the kind in the country, was drowned last night, together with his coachman, Soren Sorenson, at Highland Park, a suburban Summer resort.

If that somewhat conceited entity which calls itself Civilization should find, at any time during the immediate future, a leisure half hour at its disposal, no more profitable way of employing those thirty minutes could be imagined for or by the entity in question than to retire into some sequestered nook and there ponder with great seriousness upon this subject: "Seals: or, Who Has Been a Silly?"

The protest of Mr. Willard against the action of those on the Defender in the second race sailed off Sandy Hook, and the subsequent trouble in the race for the Drexel Cup, still form a topic of conversation for yachtsmen, and despite the action of the Regatta Committee in disallowing the protest, it seems as though the majority of those who saw the starts of the two races think Mr. Willard was right.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., Aug. 10. -- No hostelry figured more conspicuously in the early history of the country than the old Sun Inn of this place. It still stands, but much of its old grandeur has given way to modern improvements. It is ornamented now, however, with the same old-fashioned etchings and prints that were placed in the inn when it was built.

There is little positive evidence that the larger quadrupeds, oxen, deer, the felidae, or dogs, have much sense of color; and their power of vision in its wider sense varies so greatly in different species as to suggest that the mental factor in sight is often so little exerted for the main purpose of discerning objects as to leave its more specialized use for distinguishing color very imperfectly developed.

ALBANY, Aug. 10. -- In opening the investigation into the Regents' Department, Chairman Abell of the legislative committee asked Director Dewey if he did not think it would be a good plan to do away with printed examination papers, and give a class being examined oral questions, each pupil being compelled to write down the questions as well as the answers.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- The social season in the Catskills is now in full swing. In fact, as is always the case, the first week in August has proved the liveliest thus far.

ELIZABETHTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- The present season is one of the most prosperous in the history of the Mansion House. The hotel has been filled with guests for some weeks. There have been many hops, euchre parties, The event of this week was a children's hop, given to the youthful guests of all the hotels in town by the management of the Mansion House.

Though unique in its chemical inactivity, it would be premature to conclude that argon may not form compounds under conditions yet untried, and that it is an absolutely "idle" and useless thing. Prof. Roberts-Austen suggests that it may possibly play a part in certain metallurgical operations in which air is largely employed.

Only 70,000 shares were done in to-day's stock market, but the business was particularly well distributed. Practically the whole list closed higher than yesterday. Manhattan was an exception, its loss on profit taking being 1 1/2 points.

Sir Brian Newcome lived in Park Lane, and in the same situation old Miss Crawley had an exceedingly snug and well-appointed house, dividing her time between her French novels and her fat spaniel. Mrs. Hobson Newcome had her receptions, "alternate Thursdays," in the less aristocratic though eminently respectable neighborhood of Bryanston Square.

LONDON, Aug. 10. -- While Lord Salisbury is determined to take action on the recent massacre of foreigners at Ku-Cheng and the other outrages committed by the Chinese mob at that place, he refuses to entertain the claims of the missionary societies that their agents be Protected wherever they may go, and in this action the Premier is backed up by the Liberals.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- The last week has been remarkably quiet here. This has been due in a great measure to the showery weather. A day seldom passes without destructive thunder showers, which gather suddenly and descend like cloudbursts.

In a Beaver Street basement, dimly lighted, musty, and removed from the madding crowd, is a second-hand bookstore -- a place beloved of bibliophiles. Into its cobwebbed shelves have strayed the outworn and shopworn, the disused and unused. All sorts and conditions of books are there.
The Brooklyn police have not yet been able to solve the mystery attending the attempted robbery of Mrs. Diehl, in Lexington Avenue, near her home in Throop Avenue, Brooklyn, Thursday night.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Aug. 10. -- It is generally supposed that cool weather has a tendency to prevent people from visiting Summer resorts. If this is true, Hot Springs must be an exception to the rule, for the cool weather has made this resort doubly delightful, and its patrons, well aware of this fact, are daily increasing in numbers.

Work on the Puget Sound and Lake Washington Ship Canal, which in this State has ranked in importance with the Nicaragua Canal, has been made the issue of a State campaign, and has received the attention and recommendation of United States Senators, Congressmen, and Government engineers has actually commenced.

PORTSMOUTH, Aug. 10. -- The twenty-raters raced to-day from Southsea, in connection with the regatta of the Royal Portsmouth Corinthian Yacht Club, for the Yachtsman' s Cup. The course was from an imaginary line off the station, to and around the Warner Lightship, then to and around the Northeast Middle Buoy, and back to the starting line, twice around, a distance of twenty-eight miles.

The course of business among real estate men during the past week, so far as it has been made public, calls for little, if any, comment. Transactions were very few, and none was of any moment. What negotiations are pending were retarded by the excessively hot weather, which drove out of town many who have hitherto prided themselves on their judgment in sticking to this city as a Summer resort.

The Times has already published an extended review of the first translation that was made of this famous Russian woman's biography and autobiography, but the intense interest of the book attracts one irresistibly to a second reading, although the present edition does not differ materially from the other.

If the promises of the Weather Bureau, as well as the hopes of the Police Commissioners, are fulfilled, this particular Sunday will be one of note. The local forecaster says it will be cry in one sense, and the police will try to make it so in another.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 10. THOUGH the weather has been quite warm this week, the sea breeze has made life very pleasant here, and the many pleasures, particularly the outdoor games, have been heartily indulged in.

SUMMIT, N.J., Aug. 10. -- A free concert and lawn sociable were given on Thursday afternoon and evening, on the grounds of W.A. Bainbridge of New-Providence, and under the auspices of the Ladies' Aid Society and Band of Willing Workers of the Methodist Church.

Stephen W. Dorsey is no longer numbered among the picturesque characters of New-Mexico. The log mansion, with its beautiful hardwood finish and elegant appointments, looking out from the edge of a high mesa over fifty miles of plain and mountain range, with fountain playing on the lawn, no longer knows the presence of the man who designed it and dispensed lavish hospitality which New-Mexican taste could not appreciate.

The conduct of the aluminium-plated Defender is tending to greatly popularize the use of that metal with owners and builders of yachts. Mr. James C. McGuire, who thus equipped the Defender, says the same metal will undoubtedly be applied to torpedo boats and torpedo chasers.

The Quakers defeated the Brooklyn baseball team yesterday at Eastern Park by a score of 6 to 2. Stein started in to pitch for the home team, but in the third inning was pounded for 5 runs. Kennedy took his place, and, after that, the visitors could only get one more run.

ARVERNE-BY-THE-SEA, Aug. 10. AN INTERESTING programme of events coupled with the delightful weather of the past week, has placed the Summer girl right in her element. At the Hotel Arverne the guests, as if realizing that the season is more than half over, are especially active.

Every condition necessary to a good boat race existed yesterday on the Harlem River, where the Middle States Regatta Association had its annual series of rowing races. There was a slight breeze blowing, which made it much more comfortable on the water than on shore, where the mercury indicated a temperature about the nineties.

It has been reported that the Chautauqua Woman's Club is an organization that has sprung into existence this Summer. On the contrary, it is eight years old. It was founded that length of time ago by Mrs. Emily Huntington Miller. Mrs. Miller is still deeply interested in this and her other work in the Chautauqua Assembly, which has covered a space of over fifteen years.
EDGEMERE, L.I., Aug. 10. NO MORE successful week than the last has been known at the Hotel Edgemere. Beginning early in the week, interesting events have followed each other almost without cessation.

China, in order to give security for the loan, is going to mortgage the receipts of the Maritime Customs. They will pay the coupon. Now, suppose Japan threatens to renew the war with China and to blockade the ports, and so stop the payment of customs dues. Russia a year ago might have taken up an attitude of indifference and declared that the matter was nothing to her.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 10. -- Cottagers had a quiet day, with nothing to do but to go driving. Quite a number accompanied the polo team to Narragansett Pier. The chief social event of the evening was the hop at Leland's Ocean House, in honor of the officers of the white squadron. The attendance was very large.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Aug. 10. -- The seventh annual regatta of the Great South Bay Yacht Club was sailed off Sayville to-day in a stiff southwest wind. It was the biggest yachting event the South Bay has ever seen. Thirty-five yachts were entered, while a fleet of steam and sail yachts gathered from all parts of the south shore to witness the races.

Let us consider in what the physical courage of woman has hitherto most differed from that of man, for the difference is one not only of degree, but quality, and the result partly of physiological conditions, partly of the influence of heredity, and partly of the necessities of her social life and the education which is habitually assigned to her -- all of which must affect the future as well as the past.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- IT is pretty hard for a man to be a Christian in Saratoga." This was the observation made by a distinguished Summer visitor, commenting on the crusade against the public gambling houses and referring to the conspicuous apathy displayed by some people occupying front pews in the sanctuaries.

CANANDAIGUA, Aug. 10.--The Republican caucuses in Ontario County to-day all went for Senator Raines except in the four towns of Canadice, East Bloomfield, Seneca, and South Bristol. This gives him 64 of the 80 delegates in the County Convention, to be held next Tuesday.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- A sail up the Hudson River on a cool, bright Summer's day is the height of enjoyment. One who has taken the trip by boat, particularly in a sailboat, which is much more exhilarating and exciting than by a steamer, will never have erased from his memory the charm and interest of the journey.

From the deck of a Cape steamer, far out on the wastes of ocean, one of the first birds that obtrudes itself upon the notice of the passengers is the Cape petrel, (Procellaria capensis,) known generally as the "Cape pigeon," although the reason why it is called a pigeon is not very clear, as it has nothing to do with the family of the Columbidae.

Birds are commonly credited with an extraordinary range of vision. Circumstances lend add to the development of the mental factors in their case. The usual distance at which terrestrial species use their eyes is limited by the ground horizon. But in the case of the soaring birds, such as vultures and eagles, the horizon, the natural limit of sight, is enormously extended.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- The result of the Republican caucuses held to-day and this evening throughout Oneida County is the emphatic defeat of Senator Henry J. Coggeshall in his efforts to secure a renomination. The wards in this city and Rome elect one delegate each, and the twenty-six country towns elect three delegates each.

Lying off the coast of Wisconsin and in sight of its wonderful shore are the Apostle Islands. They were discovered by a Catholic priest, and from him they received their name. While one may question his creed, none can question the immortal intensity of his faith.

Tyler's riding in the professional cycle races at Manhattan Beach yesterday was the feature of the usual Saturday meet at that place. The racing itself was very good throughout, but the attendance was discouraging, as to numbers. Tyler's most noteworthy feat was his win in the two-mile scratch race in 4:40 4-5. This is the best time ever made in competition, unpaced. Sanger showed very poor. The summaries:
" Would you mind tellin' me, jest to oblige, what a scab reely is?"

GLASGOW, July 31. -- The German Emperor, no doubt incited by the success of the Britannia and the popularity the cutter's racing record has obtained for the Prince of Wales, has determined to turn the popularity of the sport to account. In the meantime he owns the old Thistle, now known as the Meteor, and the Vineta, a new twenty-rater built at Kiel from Mr. G.L. Watson's design.

Now that the hot weather has finally come, the theatrical business, that was in a torpid state all through the cool month of July is beginning to wake up. The waking will be slow and not unaccompanied by pain, however, unless there is a fall of temperature. This is roof-garden weather, decidedly, and the open-air shows are getting the benefit of it.

Fully 3,000 spectators, many of whom were ladies, assembled at the Clifton race track yesterday to witness the postponed races of the Tourist Cycle Club of Paterson. The races were originally to have been held July 3 and 4, but, while the weather was very favorable July 3, the heavy rainstorm of the 4th caused an almost indefinite postponement. It was finally decided to hold the races yesterday.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 10. LANDLORDS in this section have regarded with a good deal of satisfaction the rise in temperature this week, and guests at the shore have anticipated it with no small degree of pleasure, for the weather up to this time has been altogether too cool.

The subject of the prevention of death from snake bite is one which has for many years past engaged the attention of the Government of India. The annual reports are interesting, but far from pleasant reading. In 1891 the mortality under this head was no fewer than 21,389; in 1892 it had fallen to 19,025; in 1893 it rose again to 21,213.

That was a curious bit of news which floated around in the newspapers some years ago, which was as follows: "At a recent sale of antiqulties in Edinburgh, two of the bones of Robert Bruce sold for 3, and one of the vertebrae of William the Lion for 5 10s." What may become of the bones of past worthies is not exactly a question of the phosphates of lime contained in them.

The Morristown golf course assumed something of its former appearance of activity yesterday, when an exciting and close match was played between teams of four men each from the Morristown Club and the Tuxedo Club. The Tuxedo Club is becoming quite prominent lately for its team matches, and it has arranged with other clubs in this vicinity for more of the same character during the present month.

London street names offer a subject of extraordinary interest, dramatic often, and many surprises, too. We will give a few of these derivations: The Minories were so called after a convent of Minorites of St. Clare. St. Mary Axe was St. Mary's Axe, a relic of a holy axe used in the martydom of some virgins.

An interesting celebration of a historical nature, commemorative of the life and deeds of the intrepid priest, missionary, and explorer, Father Marquette, of long ago, was held in St. Ignace, Mich., on Wednesday, Aug. 7. The purpose is to raise funds for the erection of a monument to his memory fitting the part he played in the history of this region, and to mark the site of his last resting place.

MILFORD, Conn., Aug. 10. -- Just above the North Street schoolhouse in the washed-out roots of the old oak that has fallen across Luther's Dam lives a big family of minks. These creatures are becoming very scarce in this vicinity, but if they were all as smart as this family it would take eleven enemies to outwit them.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 10. NO week of the season has been better than this. A number of theatrical people enjoying sea breezes here have made up a stock company to give entertainments for charitable purposes.
VICTORIA, B.C., Aug. 10. -- The following Honolulu advices, under date of Aug. 1 have been received here per steamship Warimoo:

ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- Genuine August weather marked the day here. Pleasure craft and midday excursion boats were crowded with hotel guests and tourists, who sought the river to avoid the humidity.

BLACK ROCK BEACH, near Bridgeport, Conn., Aug. 10. -- Life at the George these hot days is well worth the living. There is always a fine breeze blowing, and the numerous pagodas, piazzas, and piers make it possible to be very cool and comfortable. The hotel is filled on Saturday, there being hardly a vacant room. There is a large proportion of young people, which, of course, contributes to the gayety and life.

LONDON, Aug. 10. -- The regatta week at Cowes this year, judged from a racing point of view, was not equal to that of 1894, but in a social way it was as brilliant as ever. Emperor William of Germany, who dominated everything, had the satisfaction yesterday of seeing the schooner yacht Verena, owned by his chosen friend, the Earl of Lonsdale, win the Emperor's Cup.

Recorder Goff and other representatives of the bench and the bar have consented to give expression of official opinion upon the present system of legal criminal procedure. They discuss the discontent which seems to exist in the popular mind and which has found expression since the Carlyle Harris, Buchanan, and the Maria Barberi cases have been prominently before the public.

The experiments just completed in France by d'Arsonval on the electrical discharge of the electric eel, the malapterurus, and several other fishes, serve to recall a most interesting letter now in the possession of the electrical department of Armour Institute, written Aug. 12, 1772, by Benjamin Franklin's to an English scientist, during Franklin's second mission to England as the agent of the House of Representatives of Massachusetts Bay.

ORANGE N.J., Aug. 10. -- A very pleasant reception was given at the home of Rabbi Jacob Lubin in Main Street Wednesday evening, in honor of the Misses Kanegsberg. The young ladies assisting in receiving were Miss Nellie Schwartz, Miss. Ida Schwartz, Miss Laura Lehman, Miss Sarah Gerhardt, and Miss Ruth Livingston.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., Aug. 10. -- The annual club regatta of the Westhampton Country Club was sailed to-day. There were fifteen entries, most of which were boats belonging to the home club. There were only two -- the Druid, entered by Dr. C.F.W. Bodecker, and the Girl, entered by Frank Smith -- from the East Bay Club.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 10. -- Capt. Hank Haff said to-night that the Defender was not even scratched in the little accident, if it may be called such, that happened yesterday. That the Defender ran along the edge of the bar, which at high tide gave plenty of water, as the day before he had gone over nearly the same water at high tide without trouble.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 10. -- The Atlantic City Baseball Club came here to-day and defeated the Orange Athletic Club baseball players for the third time on the Orange Oval before 2,000 persons. The visitors won by hard hitting, although Westervelt for Orange struck out more men than Nevins for the visitors, who was, however. so puzzling that the home team could not place its hits.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 10. -- The members of the Verona Methodist Episcopal Church enjoyed a picnic at Verona Lake on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- The report of the Statistician of the Department of Agriculture on the 10th of the month relates to conditions as they stood on the 1st of the month. Thus understood, the returns show an improvement in the condition of corn about three points during the month of July, or from 99.3 to 102.5.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 10. -- This was the New-Jersey farmer's Salt Water Day at this place. The first arrival was seen after midnight last night, and so many farmers were on their way to the ocean this morning before sunrise that many of the residents were disturbed and could not sleep from the noise they made.

The fourteenth annual season of the New-York Camp of Instruction, which closed yesterday afternoon, proved remarkably successful. The general conduct of the camp has been on the same lines as were established by the late Adjt. Gen. Porter, and the present Adjutant General, Major Gen. E.A. McAlpin, used every effort to keep up the admirable record of previous years.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., Aug. 10. -- One of the many charms that Block Island holds for fishermen is its never-failing varieties of Sport. Let the bluefishing be ever so poor, the striped bass ever so few and far between, the sportsman does not waste these sunlit July days. Just now the great attraction is porpoise hunting.

I have heard very sensible women say this. And a charming authoress some time ago wrote a series of articles in a religious newspaper strongly defending this view.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Aug. 10. -- Register Barco and Receiver Wainwright of the United States office, have rendered a decision regarding naval reserve lands, the effect of which is to throw open for entry 44,260 acres of land in Alachua, Levy, Lafayette, St. John's, Suwannee, and Santa Rosa Counties.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 10 -- George Taggart of Washington Park is at the Manhanset House, Shelter Island.

Gen. Quesada, Secretary of the Cuban Revolutionary Campaign Committee, received a letter from Santiago, Cuba, yesterday, stating that the revolutionists held an election at Camaquey late in July, and chose Gen. G. Masso as President of their proposed republic.

The St. Andrew's Golf Club of Yonkers which has been remarkably active during the present season, is going to cut a still bigger figure in the golfing world during the coming Fall months. The golf tournaments are going to be both numerous and important, ending at last with the grand American championship meeting at Newport during the first week in October.
STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 10. -- Charles E. Butler gave a dinner at his country place. Linwood, this evening for the officers of Battery K, in camp at Tyringham.

CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 10. THE days are not long enough for pleasures here. Boating, baseball, fishing, driving, bathing, and dancing are some of the many diversions. A pleasant event was the moonlight sailing party given by Miss Grace Imlach of New-York Monday evening to a number of her young friends.

Judge H.A. Widemann had an agreeable day two weeks ago. He made a great feast to celebrate the opening of the Oahu Railway extension to his plantation, at Waianae. By special train he carried thither some thirty of his children and grandchildren, together with the officers of the road and a crowd of other guests, among whom were Chief Justice Judd and his guest, Dr. Joseph Cook.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- Surrogate Theodore H. Silkman of Westchester County, in a decision just handed down concerning a case brought before him from the town of Westchester, now annexed to New-York, has decided the Annexation act unconstitutional.

The name of the late George Frederick Root will never be written large in the annals of music, because the writers of those annals, more than the writers of any other annals, are fastidious and discriminating. It is ever the regret of the ambitious musician and musical amateur that, because of the limitations of the English language, the word music stands for so much.
LENOX, Mass., Aug. 10. GOLFERS here are much pleased with the new clubhouse, which was brought from New-York and put up on the grounds this week by Mr. J. Egmont Schermerhorn.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- The complimentary references of The London Post to the homobeneity of the American Navy, and its increased efficiency by reason of that fact, are highly appreciated by the officials of the Navy Department. One of these said to-day: "This commendation of the American Navy from a high English authority is the more to be appreciated because of its rarity.

The story told in The New-York Times yesterday of the arrest of Herman Schneck, and his commitment by Magistrate Mott in the Harlem Police Court in default of $2,000 bail on the charge of grand larceny, proves to be the opening chapter of the narration of extensive swindling operations against book publishers.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 10. EVERYBODY here enjoys the summer girl. She is the life of Bay Shore and enters into all the social and recreative features of the season. There are a large number of young men, which, of course, makes it pleasant for her.

SARATOGA, Aug. 10.--Street Commissioners Michael J. Fay and Charles L. Pond were found guilty by the new Board of Trustees of the village last evening of unlawfully expending $17,000 of the village funds during the last year, and were removed from office.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 10. BUSIER or gayer times have never been seen at this resort. Every house is filled. Some, indeed, have been obliged to turn intended guests away.

SARATOGA, Aug. 10. -- The general impression in this temporary Democratic political centre is that the Democratic State Committee, which has been called to meet at the Hoffman House, in New-York City, Aug. 15, will call the Democratic State Convention to meet in Syracuse on or about Sept. 24.

BERLIN, Aug. 10. -- The war celebrations that have taken place this week have been complete successes in all the German States where they were held. This proves the realness of the popular enthusiasm for German unity. Daily demonstrations occurred in front of the Niederwald monument at Ruedesheim.

TRENTON Aug. 10. -- The campaign in New-Jersey is now considered formally opened. The Republicans will hold their convention on Sept. 19, and the Democrats one week later. The time from the conventions to the election will be six and seven weeks, respectively, making a short contest before the people of the State.
The season of gladiolus has come.

The "Durham Rites" speak of a great store of ancient manuscripts possessed by the house to help the monks in their study. The "Rites" go on to say how the store included "the old auncient written Doctors of the Church, as other profane authors, with divers other holie men's wourks, so that every one dyd studye what Doctor pleased them best, havinge the Librairie at all times to go and studye in, besydes their carrells."
BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 10. -- J. Livingston Freeborn of Portland, Me., formerly of Brooklyn, is visiting friends and relatives in Bayonne and New-York.

This little talk is intended as a guide for the young men and women with a liking for private theatricals. Were they in the city within easy reach of costumers, wig makers, scenic artists, and the like, they might not, perhaps, need these suggestions from an old stager; but at the smaller and isolated Summer resorts, where one's ingenuity is taxed to the utmost to invent new amusements, it is hoped they will prove acceptable.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 10.--To look up from a peaceful cigar and behold a sixteen-inch revolver pointed at one's head, to be metamorphosed from a tourist into a prisoner of war in the twinkling of an eye, to argue vainly with short-spoken men bristling with eloquent firearms, and finally to be marooned--such incidents are crowded when brought within the limits of a few hours.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 10. NOTHING has made this resort appear the horse show. Its close to-day found the hotels enjoying a patronage equal to a Fourth of July night when Monmouth Park was in its glory.

BELLEVILLE, N.J., Aug. 10. -- The old lecture room of the Belleville Reformed Church has been demolished to make room for a new stone chapel, which is to be built to correspond with the main church edifice, which has an interesting history. The church was known for many years as the Church of Second River, and the exact date of its organization is not known, but is supposed to have been in 1675.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 10. -- This resort is in full season of gayety and prosperity. Its attractions are its own, each year sees it more appreciated, and before long it may be considered the queen of warm-weather refuges.

Dr. Caius, "a most shining light of the University of Cambridge, its jewel, its glory," according to his translator, in 1576, Abraham Fleming "wrote an epitome concerning British dogs, not so concise as elegant and useful, an epitome compact of the various arguments and experiences of many minds," for the use of Conrad Gesner, the Swiss naturalist.

GREENPORT, L.I., Aug. 10. -- The bicycle tournament and outdoor games held at the Greenport Driving Park this afternoon drew a crowd of some 1,500 persons. The weather was very warm, which had the effect of making some of the games drag rather slowly. Still, in the face of everything, records for this place were broken in many instances.

Justice Gaynor, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn yesterday, upon the application of the official of the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad Company, granted a writ of certiorari, directing the Board of Assessors to review their action in fixing the assessments upon the property of the company.

It is easy, of course, to understand how pen drawing should have come to be so largely employed and elaborated. It is a matter of reproduction for illustration. An etching will not print with type, nor with a steel engraving. This led in the early part of the century to the imitation of steel engravings by wood engravers, who did the business most skillfully with immense labor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- The compilation by Prof. Panton of the Ontario Agricultural College of data concerning the annual loss from the work of destructive insects was discussed to-day by Secretary Morton of the Agricultural Department in his usual breezy fashion.

In spite of the wild rumors which gained credence for a few hours yesterday, the contest between the saloon keepers and the police will be continued to-day without any practical variation in detail from the methods employed on previous Sundays during the present "dry" period.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 10. -- Rusie pitched a magnificent game to-day, except in one inning -- the seventh. In that round, Baltimore won the contest by scoring six tallies on four singles, a sacrifice, a base on balls, and two errors. The score when the inning opened was 4 to 2 in New-York's favor, and the home rooters had given up hope of winning.

Anna Zwanziger, or Anna Schonleben, known as the German Brinvilliers, committed her crime about the commencement of the present century. It is somewhat strange that this woman has also escaped the attention of Lombroso, for she exemplifies some of the most remarkable criminal traits, and her picture as handed down to us is so much direct evidence upon the outward aspect of her species.
FIRE ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 10. GUESTS here are looking forward to the water pageant that is to take place Tuesday afternoon. It is the first affair of the kind ever held in this section.

HOTEL CHAMPLAIN, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- The greatest interest among canoe men is always shown at the meet of the American Canoe Association, which brings together representatives from every section of the country. The big canoe meeting is simply a grand, good camping-out time. The gathering of from 150 to 200 jolly fellows, and a score of ladies, makes things lively while it lasts.

LAKE MASSAWEPIE, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- The present season at the Hotel Childwold is the most successful in the history of the hotel. The house has been filled for the last five weeks, and promises to be so for the rest of the season, which lasts until November.

Japan has learned a bitter lesson from the intervention of Russia. She realizes as she never realized before that Russia is her real enemy, or at any rate, that he who would China win, must with Russia first begin. She knows now that if she is to carry out her dream of supremacy in the far East, she must first settle accounts with Russia.

Mr. Isaac Hull Adams of Quincy, a grandson of President John Adams, has made public an interesting fact in regard to the birthplace of the two Presidents Adams. In a letter to William G. Spear, the Librarian of the Quincy Historical Society, Mr. Adams says:

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 10. -- The belles and beaus of this fashionable town and all the small boys for miles around made an interesting group in the Valley Road this afternoon. They clustered about the finish line in the Montclair Wheelmen's annual races, cheering in the infectious excitement of the sprints, and gossiping during the moments of inactivity.

Peaches are being sent to market from North Carolina, Maryland, and Delaware. The best ones in market yesterday were from North Carolina. Some of the fancy fruit stores asked as high as 60 and 70 cents a dozen for the best ones. At Washington Market and other general markets large Elberta peaches sold for 45 cents a dozen.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- The camp presented a scene of the liveliest activity this morning, for, besides the hurry and bustle of batteries, the Ordnance Department was out gathering up State property, while express wagons and trucks were around collecting trunks and chests of those who had been in camp all the season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- The protest sent to President Cleveland by American citizens in Shanghai against allowing a British Consular officer to represent the United States in the inquiry into the Ku-Cheng massacre was received by Acting Secretary Adee, by telegraph, this morning from Gray Gables.
" No, there's nuthin' the matter of me; sorter pensive, that's all."
SHELTER ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 10. IF THE first week of August is any indication of what the rest of the month will be, Shelter Island should have one of the best months it has ever known.

In England, as early as the twelfth century, Durham, London, and Winchester, with several celebrated monasteries, had each its school of binding. Durham still possesses a series of books, bound toward the close of the twelfth century, that are well worthy to compete in excellence and beauty with the work of foreign nations. Oxford and Cambridge both produced an interesting series of bindings, prized by connoisseurs.

ASBURY PARK N.J., Aug. 10. OCEAN GROVE and Asbury Park are entertaining 100,000 visitors to-night The procession seaward started early in the week, and the crowds arriving on to-day's trains were obliged to accept stuffy rooms on the top floors of the hotels.
Mr. William I. Marshall, Principal of the Chicago Lawn School, writes to The Chicago Inter Ocean, under date of Aug. 4, saying:

GREAT BARRINGTON, Aug. 10. -- A large number of city people are summering in this beautiful town. Since the first of this month the cottagers have all been here, and the hoarding houses and hotels have been full. There are many entertainments, including dances, rowing on the Housatonic, driving parties to Lake Buel, the fish hatchery clubhouse, and trips to Tyringham to see the encampment of the artillery company.

Hashmi, the cafe keeper, was in the best of humors. His house was full and doing a brisk trade. Fattah, the negro, was keeping the company merry, so he brewed a fresh pot of real "Meccan" in view of coming demands. The surroundings were grimy, and outside the rain came down in torrents; but that was a decided advantage, since it drove men to take refuge indoors and helped to keep them there.

The luxury of the Roman Empire created the first great development of the cultivated rose. Lower motives may lead to refined results, as Carlyle used to insist. The first use even of the wreath, which seems to have been to a Greek the final cause of roses, is said to have been only a glorification of the tight string tied around the head to avoid the next day's headache!

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- As time rolls on and the days approach when conventions will make nominations for the various offices to be filled at the next election, the list of Westchester aspirants assumes some definite shape.
SING SING, Aug. 10. -- Interest in the Methodist camp meeting here is demonstrated in steadily increasing attendance. This afternoon's steamer from New-York came up crowded with campers.

The Heine Monument Association has begun work in earnest to bring about a speedy realization of the project of erecting the memorial fountain on some prominent site in the metropolis of the New World.

STONINGTON, Conn., Aug. 10. -- A large firemen's parade took place here to-day in celebration of the eighty-first anniversary of Stonington's memorable battle with the English. There were twenty bands and fire companies.

Dogs are rarely dangerous to domestic sheep. The determined hostility shown to them at such times is a relic of the old, wild instinct, when the horned flock on the mountainside defended their young against jackals, dholes, and wolves. An angry ewe will stamp her foot when a dog comes within sight.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 10. MOST of the houses are now filled with guests, and social events of interest follow one another in rapid succession. Coaching parties to Paul Smith's, Lake Placid, and Loon Lake are very popular, but baseball is arousing the liveliest interest.

A philosopher dwelt in a house owned by Cleon. But one day Cleon came to the philosopher and said: "Why have you not sent me the money for last month's rent?" The philosopher said he knew of no reason except that he had no money, having gotten to the bottom of his purse.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., Aug. 10.--The "red-hot" debates on the liquor question between Senator B.R. Tilman, Samuel Dickie, and John P. St. John, held at the Prohibition Park Auditorium on Thursday and Friday evenings, resulted in a red-hot encounter between two clergymen and Prohibitionists this morning, in which the lie direct was given and a blow struck.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 10. -- Mrs. Belle R. Smith, wife of Silas S. Smith, who lives at 37 Fayette Street, Lynn, returned home this morning. She has been missing since July 22, when she left home suddenly.

LONDON, Aug. 10. -- [Copyright, 1895, by The New-York Times.] -- In ordinary times the popular English interest in missionary endeavor is largely confined to amused observation of the way some twenty rival organizations hate and fight with one another here at home. When something like this Chinese horror occurs, however, it is seen that England is at heart very keen about the whole missionary idea.
