The modern swordfisherman is a whaleman to all purposes, and a "crazy" swordfish is just as dangerous as an ugly whale. He swings his horn sword with such vengeance that it is as wicked a weapon to face as a blade of heavy steel. He doesn't jab, but slashes with a twisting, sawing motion like a flail full of business.

An eloping couple from Baltimore were married in this city yesterday afternoon. The groom was Dr. George C. Mann, a young dentist of that city. Miss Clara V. Walker, the bride, is but eighteen years old, and is said to have been recently graduated from the High School in Baltimore. The couple came over on one of the morning trains, and about noon appeared at the City Hall in search of a license.

Miss Alice Jewett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Jewett of New-Brighton, S.I., committed suicide yesterday morning by leaping from a second-story window of the Windsor Hotel, Forty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue. She fell in the inner court of the hotel. Death came in a few moments.

For weeks the streets have resounded with a nonsensical cry which has proved absolutely infectious, and "En voulez-vous des-z-homards?" has passed from lip to lip in almost every grade of society, and in endless variation has done journalistic duty over and over again. The phrase, bad French as it may be, has made all sorts of victims, and its constant reiteration has proved such a nuisance that it has become absolutely obnoxious.

M. Laisant, formerly a Deputy and member of the Boulangist Committee, has been appointed Professor at Sainte Barbe, a fashionable public school. It may be interesting to note what has become of the other members of the Committee of the Rue de Seze, which at one time fully expected to have France in its hands.
It was quiet on the Harlem River yesterday after the grand display of the day previous, when the most successful regatta the Middle States Association has ever held was rowed.

Sarah Russell, twelve years old, of 3 Ludlow Street, and Fannie Jones, six years old, of 2 Orchaxd Street, were arraigned before Justice Simms, in the Yorkville Court, yesterday, on a charge of larceny. The Russell girl was caught putting her hand in the pocket of Miss Annette Lange of 121 West One Hundred and Sixth Street, while in the monkey house in Central Park Saturday afternoon.

SARATOGA, Aug. 11. -- The Democratic revival in this State is growing stronger every day. Of its stability and solidity there no longer can be any doubt. Every Democratic leader now in Saratoga tells the same story as to what he hears from various sections of the State.

Maitland Aykroyd, the boat builder, has rescued over forty persons from drowning since 1873, and recovered eight bodies from the bay. In spite of this, however, Mr. Aykroyd's services remain unrecognized either by the city or by the organization which is supposed promptly to indicate its appreciation of such cases of bravery, viz., the Humane Society, while others who have done far less than he have received speedy recognition.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 11. -- The thermometer registered 90 in the shade the greater portion of the day. There was a lad breeze early in the morning, but about 10 o'clock the wind shifted around to the northeast, and those who spent the day around the beach could keep comfortable, although a block back from the shore the heat was almost suffocating.
The man with the Loudoun County whiskers was waiting at the Baltimore and Potomac station for a train to take him home, when a Star man, mousing around there for a stray bit of news, happened on him.

The law against Sunday shaving in barbers' shops was rigorously enforced in Brooklyn yesterday, but the law against the Sunday sale of liquors was violated as it has always been since Mayor Charles A. Schieren assumed office. As one disgusted Brooklynite expressed it:

A bundle containing some interesting papers has been received by Secretary Adams of the State Historical Society. They are from Charles A. Foster, one of the founders of Osawatomie, and one of the friends of Jim Lane. Among them is an interesting letter from Jim Lane, in which the plan to defeat the Lecompton Constitution is unfolded.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 11. -- Excursionists were present here in great numbers to-day. They came from Boston, Providence, and up the Sound, and flocked to the beach, which they literally crowded.

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 11. -- By request of the American Legation, Juan Lamedo, President of the Tahuililo Agricultural and Colonization Company, has made the first complete statement of an official nature regarding the troubles of his company with the large shipments of negroes made into Mexico from the United States. The declaration has been dispatched to the Department of State, Washington, and is as follows:
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 11. -- United States Senator Tillman of South Carolina, the author of the famous State liquor dispensary law, spoke to a large audience at the National service this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- The statement made in New-York to-day that the President had offered to Frederic R. Coudert, now in Europe, the post on the Supreme bench made vacant by the death of Associate Justice Jackson is regarded here as gossip too frivolous even for the dog days. It is customary, when a high officer of the Government dies, to permit him to be buried before taking steps to fill his place.

The Rev. Francis L. Patton, D.D., President of Princeton University, preached yesterday morning in the Rutgers Riverside Presbyterian Church from Ecclesiastics, xii., 13: "Fear God and Keep His Commandments."

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- Secretary of State Palmer was the only State official in town to-night. He returned from Buffallo about 9 o'clock, and was asked on his arrival what his opinion was on the success of Senator John Raines in winning in the caucus in Ontraio County, and the defeat of Senator Coggesshall in the caucuses in Oneida County.
" A man who has his wits about him," remarked a learned judge to a Star writer, "is greater than he who conquers a city, or words to that effect, for he is always sure of getting there."

Apropos of bundles, a correspondent who remembers things writes: "I met the Rev. Mr. Chickering one day when he was pastor of the High Street Church, and he carried a huge lobster under his arm. He shook it in my face, and said, laughingly, 'I guess my character will bear me out. Nobody will think I have robbed a lobster cart, though I am hurrying home with my spoil.'

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- The delegates to the Oneida County Republican Convention elected at yesterday's caucuses stand 64 for F.G. Weaver and 31 for Senator H.J. Coggeshall, on the Senatorial contest. W. El. Scripture of Rome carried two districts in the contest for the nomination for Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, and W.A. Matteson of Utica one.

PARIS, July 31. -- I do not think that Paris was much concerned about the Unionist Successes in England. Not that the French are indolent in comprehension, neither do they live out of the world -- their world -but they look around them with a mixture of intelligent, healthful indifference, and the home-made assurance that polities must vary, or where would be the fun?

More saloons were open for business yesterday than on the four or five previous Sundays. Any citizen who was known to a saloon keeper or his bartender found little difficulty in having his thirst satisfied.
Coney Island prospered yesterday, although the atmospheric conditions that prevailed there gave little relief to 85,000 visitors.

A special correspondent of The London Economist writes from Ottawa a particularly interesting letter on the workings of the protective policy adopted by Canada sixteen years ago. He ascribes to the adoption of the policy three purposes, to raise revenue, to remedy the depression that had followed the panic of 1873, and to force this country to open its markets to Canadian products.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- Navy officials say that it is with difficulty that enlistments of seamen, machinists, and others are made during the Summer season. At this period, men who possess a knowledge of such matters can always find more remunerative employment on private yachts and along shore, where a greater measure of individual freedom is enjoyed, and where the duty is not so exacting as it is in the navy.
Dwight L. Moody, the famous evangelist, has made a little town situated among the hills of Northwestern Massachusetts famous as a seat of religious learning.

The condition of the growing corn on July 1 was exceptionally high, (99.3,) but on Aug. 1 it was more three points higher, or 102.5. It is noticeable that the condition was very good in the chief producing States of the West, (Illinois, 106; Indiana 100; Iowa, 107; Missouri, 115;) in which nearly one-half of the entire crop-is grown.

A woman's piercing shriek at 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning aroused the neighborhood of Fifty-second Street and Broadway. A crowd of men soon surrounded the Hotel Lincoln, from which the alarming sound had issued. From the windows of the apartment houses in that vicinity peered anxious women, who had been aroused by the scream.

The office of the United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by the United Press.

The talk of amalgamation between the Brooklyn Bicycle Club and the South Brooklyn Wheelmen has resulted in considerable bad feeling on both sides, and it is not likely that the subject will again be broached.

There has been received during the past thirty days news from Chile which will not be regarded as joyful intelligence by the friends of Daniel Defoe. Poor old Robinson Crusoe's hut on Juan Fernandez Island is to be torn down, and in its place will be erected a prison station, to be used as an auxiliary to the Chilean penitentiary at Santiago.

HOTEL CHAMPLAIN, LAKE CHAMPLAIN, Aug. 11. -- In the lull that follows the excitement of opening the camp and precedes the week of the races the canoeists cruise to points of interest on the lake. Some of them have cruised to the islands in the northern end of the lake, and others have gone to Au Sable Chasm, about ten miles to the south.
LONDON, Aug. 11. -- Sir Julian Pauncefote, British Ambassador at Washington, who has for some time past been in Europe on leave of absence, has just returned to London from Dresden.

Felix Quinn, a Manayunk florist, is in hard luck, and all because his folks in Ireland are not as exact as they should be i the written use of the English language. Felix is prosperous. Aiany grave lots anc suburban lawns are intrusted to his care, and he has accumulated a store of 'the, world's goods.

Thursday of this week will be an important day for both managers of race tracks and owners of race horses. It will also foretell the prospects for Fall racing, as Aug. 15 is the date fixed for the closing of stake entries to the stakes announced by the Brooklyn Jockey Club, the Westchester Racing Association, and the New-York Steeplechase Association.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 11. -- The plant of the Central Stamping Company burned this afternoon. The loss is probably $500,000. The company carried $250,000 insurance.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Aug. 11. -- The family carriage of Otto Miller, grocer and butcher of 2,103 Second Avenue, New-York, was struck by Trolley Car No. 134 of the Steinway Railway about 9 o'clock to-night and demolished. The occupants, Miller, his wife and child, Mrs. Kuffe and her two children, and the driver, were violently thrown out.

JAMESPORT, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- United States Senator David B. Hill, with Chairman of the Democratic State Committee Hinkley and Perry Belmont, left Bay Ridge this morning on Mr. Belmont's yacht Satanella, and landed at Jamesport, the Summer home of Hugh McLaughlin and ex-Assemblyman Finnegan of Brooklyn.

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- All the towns in the northern part of Westchester County contributed their quota to swell the crowds at the Sing Sing Methodist Episcopal camp meeting to-day. They came here in buggies and carriages, stages and the big farm wagons with four seats, which accommodated the whole family.

WAGONER, Indian Territory, Aug. 11. -- The Indians who have committed a series of crimes since July 30 in the Territory were captured near Okmulgee Thursday after a desperate fight, and started for the Fort Smith (Ark.) jail to avoid being lynched.

BERLIN, Aug. 11. -- The war celebrations continue. The Third Brandenburg Artillery Regiment celebrated yesterday the anniversary of its going into field service. The veterans of the regiment took part in the celebration. Wreaths were placed on the graves of those members of the regiment who had been killed in battle, after which the regiment paraded.

Jesse Pomeroy, whose fiendish crimes startled the public over twenty years ago, is about to enjoy a relaxation, to a degree, of the rigorous life which he has led in the State prison at Charlestown since his sentence was commuted from death by hanging to solitary imprisonment for life. Pomeroy was found guilty of murdering two children by heinous methods and torturing another in a bloodthirsty manner.

M. De Cyon has in his possession the original letter which Queen Victoria wrote to the late Maharajah Dhuleep Singh, when the latter threatened to cast off his allegiance to England, and coquetted with Russia for its support in his mad project of raising an insurrection in India. Russia behaved with great loyalty on this occasion.
SARATOGA, Aug. 11. -- A heavy rainstorm that threatens to continue all night made its appearance early this evening. The weather this morning and afternoon was fine, but a trifle too warm.
A good story on the late Gen. Dan McCauley of Indiana is related by Judge John N. Scott, now of Port Townsend, Washington.

Three more bodies of workmen who perished in the collapse of the building being erected at West Broadway and West Third Street were recovered from the ruins between midnight Saturday and 6 P.M. yesterday.

Had some invading army swept down unexpectedly on New-York City yesterday afternoon and captured the town, it would have made a surprisingly small number of prisoners as compared with the population indicated by the Directory. All who could had gone out of town, and a majority left early in the day by boats and trains. Heat and humidity were jointly responsible for the exodus.

Whenever a freight train gets wrecked, anywhere from one to half a dozen tramps are almost invariably reported to have been killed. No account of such an accident is ever complete unless it includes a paragraph about the men who were stealing a ride at the time, and who, when the crash came, were scattered along the track in pieces of various size for a distance of anywhere from several rods to half a mile.

The Bell Telephone Company has brought suits against two independent telephone organizations for infringement of the Berliner patent, and with characteristic caution has brought them in Boston. These suits will involve, we suppose, the validity of the patent in question.

It was on the little lawn of a handsome house on New-Hampshire Avenue, the other day -- one of those hermetically sealed, deserted-looking mansions the fashionable quarter is crowded with Right in the midst of a velvety bit of turf there were four sticks stuck, and on their tops, a couple of feet from the ground, a newspaper was spread.

The great pineapple district of Florida lies along the lower part of the Indian River, extending to the most southern of the keys. In some other portions of the State much attention is being given to pineapple culture. In the neighborhood of Orlando this is notably so, and experience proves that the pineapple can be grown in nearly every southern county in the State.

The Syracuse News bids for the Democratic Convention, and suggests centrality, good hotels, and a "mascot" quality in the Democratic tickets made there as reasons for the guidance of the State Committee. But the Democrats will need no "mascot" assistance if they will see to it that the convention holds representatives of all the Democrats of the State.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12. -- A fire that threatened to destroy the block bounded by Franklin and Eighth Streets, and Callowhill and Buttonwood Streets, with Willow Street, a small thoroughfare running east and west through it, started at 8:30 o'clock this morning in the folding paper-box factory of Brown Bailey, 412 Franklin Street.

LONDON, Aug. 12. -- The fourteenth Parliament of Queen Victoria was opened today with the customary ceremonies. Prior to the formal opening of the House, there were the usual contests among the members for the seats they will occupy during the session.

The Directors of the Atlanta Exposition, which will open on Sept. 18 next, have become afraid that the State of New-York, including the biggest city on the continent, will be left out in the cold when the space for exhibits is finally allotted.
WINFIELD, L.I., Aug. 12. -- Nicholas Kipp, forty-nine years old, of Hyatt Heights, a suburb of this village, was struck by lightning early this morning and instantly killed.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Aug. 12. -- A full statement, of dividends paid by local mills the last quarter was issued to-day by G.M. Haffards Co. It shows larger earnings than those given out from other sources a few days ago.

Three dignified officers of the navy and one from the Marine Corps met in the Court-Martial Room of Building No. 7 at the New-York Navy Yard, in Brooklyn, yesterday. Individually, they are Capt. Winfield Scott Schley, Pay Inspector George A. Lyon. Commander James G. Green of the navy, and First Lieut. Littleton Waller of the United States Marine Corps.

The commerce destroyer Columbia, which recently arrived from Southampton on a natural draught speed trial, was placed in dry dock at the New-York Navy Yard yesterday. She has been put there to allow a Naval Board of Survey to examine and report on the amount of damage the vessel sustained when docked at Southampton preliminary to her trip across the Atlantic.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., Aug. 12. -- Reports from the country say that last night's storm was the severest of the Summer. Rain and hail fell, and the lightning was terrific. In Hanover Township lightning knocked down Annie Piscura while she was walking across a field carrying an open umbrella.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12. -- C.L. Magee came to the city to-day and had interviews with a number of the Philadelphia Republican leaders. Mr. Magee did not appear to be in the last affected by the results of the primaries held on Saturday.
NEWTOWN, L.I., Aug. 12. -- Mrs. Louis Zufall, wife of a jeweler of this town, was found dead in her house on Cook Avenue the night of July 29. Blood was upon the floor and upon her face and clothing.

It might easily have been hotter than it was last night in the Casino. This statement is not to be taken as an intimation that anybody complained of not being quite warm enough, but the surprisingly large number of people who went there to welcome "The Merry World" back from Chicago really did sit through the somewhat lengthy performance in what, during weather like the present, passes for "comparative comfort."

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 12. -- It was "dog days" weather to-day -- muggy, and, with the mercury running up to 82, but the rain last night had settled the dust, so that everybody was out this morning driving, including the Misses Ives, the Misses Parsons, Miss Kate Carry, and many of the older people in their victorias and various traps.

LYONS, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- This district was for several years represented in the Senate by Charles T. Saxton of Clyde, Wayne County, the present Lieutenant Governor, his place as Senator being filled at a special election last Fall by the selection of ex-Congressman and ex-State Senator John Raines. The Lieutenant Governor gave his indorsement to the selection of Senator Raines, and, in fact, contributed largely to his nomination.

Trouble is impending between business tenants and the resident landlord at the "sign of the big boot of Chatham Street," 72 and 72 1/2 Vesey Street, and 206 to 210 Greenwich Street, whose relations have become unpleasant, because, according to the story told by the tenants, the landlord is conservative and does not heed ample warning that the structure, which was put up as early as 1775, may collapse at any moment.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 12. -- This vicinity was visited this morning by a terrific electrical storm which did much damage.

If masculine greed and cruelty and feminine vanity and thoughtlessness are not in some manner restrained or punished it is only a question of time, and very short time at that, how soon the earth will lose its birds. Recently The Seattle Argus called attention to the danger of the utter extermination of game birds by the destruction of their eggs on the Alaska breeding grounds.

" I will not decide that a bowling alley is a nuisance," said Justice William J. Gaynor yesterday in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, on the application of Thomas D. Carpenter, Jr., for a preliminary injunction to restrain in the Irving Club from using its bowling alley until Fall, when the windows may be shut down.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug 12. -- It has been an extremely disagreeable day at Bar Harbor, the rain falling in torrents the whole day long.

Before the time when the campaign could open in the Spring of 1800, everything was running smoothly; but they were running by the inspiration and activity of a single man. The Council of State was Napoleon's greater self, the Senate his instrument of governing; the legislative body was as silent as the tribunate was noisy -- neither was a serious check on his plans.

Tammany Hall practically completed its reorganization last night, when it re-elected Henry D. Purroy Chairman of the Committee on Organization, and James J. Martin, Chairman of the Executive Committee. On Friday last, it re-elected Augustus W. Peters Chairman of the General Committee, so that the men at the head of affairs in the reorganized Tammany Hall, are precisely the same as those who were in control at the time of the last election.

ALBANY, Aug. 12. -- The membership of the Oneida Senatorial Convention will be pretty evenly divided between delegates favorable to Henry J. Coggeshall and those favoring Frederick G. Weaver. Both sides are claiming a majority of the delegates elected, but a little calculation will show that Senator Coggeshall has the best of it, and is likely to be renominated at the convention, which will be held within ten days.

LONDON, Aug. 12. -- Charles F. Crisp, ex-Speaker of the American House of Representatives: Edwin F. Uhl, American Assistant Secretary of State, and Henry Cabot Lodge, Senator from Massachusetts, were guests this evening at an entertainment given by Speaker Gully, at his residence in Westminister Palace.
Ex-Senator James W. Birkett was the principal witness called by Hugo Hirsh before the Assembly committee that is investigating the Charities Department affairs in Brooklyn yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Apprehension at the State and Navy Departments over the safety of American missionaries in China has been greatly allayed through the receipt of several official dispatches containing reassuring information, leading to the belief among those officially concerned that native outbreaks against foreigners have ceased for the present at least.

The Defender arrived off New-Rochelle at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. She had been towed down from Newport by the tug Wallace B. Flint. She left Newport on Sunday, accompanied by the tender Hattie Palmer. Everything went well until Faulkner's Island was reached on Sunday evening, and then a heavy thunderstorm was encountered. No damage was done, however.
Mr. Edward H. Kelly has sold, at about $26,000, the five -- story brick tenement 121 East Seventy-seventh Street, 25 by 86 by 100.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12. -- A morning of rain in torrents, a dry, sultry afternoon, and a wet, foggy evening were the remarkably varying meteorological features of the day. Cottagers remained in doors all the morning, drove in the afternoon, and attended numerous dinners, and later the Casino dance in the evening.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- August Willie, thirty-two years old, living at 226 Riverdale Avenue, attempted to strangle his wife, Dora, at Duencer's Hotel, on Warburton Avenue and Dock Street, this afternoon.

One of the most terrific thunderstorms of the season visited this city and Brooklyn and neighboring towns early yesterday morning, and for about an hour the heavens were bright with lightning in its various forms.

LONDON, Aug. 12. -- The Daily News will print to-morrow a dispatch from Hardanger, Norway, saying that the Odde Hotel was burned at midday, Aug. 9, and that forty of the guests, many of whom were foreigners, were absent on excursions to points in the neighborhood, and lost all of their property.

One has only to turn to the chemical textbooks of a few years back to see that there were three gases which were described as permanent, in that they had never been liquefied; these were nitrogen, oxygen, and hydrogen. The first two were liquefied some time ago, and hydrogen remained the one gas which could be described as obstinate.
" I have come this evening, Miss Mildred," began the youth, fingering his hat nervously and clearing his throat, "to ask you -- that is -- "
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 12. -- It continues hot in Long Branch. The mercury rose to eighty-four to-day. A heavy rain fell this morning, but it did not cool the air.

ALBANY, Aug. 12. -- Assemblyman Abell's legislative sub-committee continued its inquiry into the administration of affairs in the State Department of the Regents of the University to-day. Secretary Melville Dewey continued his denial of the charges published last week. He declared that he had never tried to bring about the removal of State Geologist James Hall.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Sixty wheelmen and five wheelwomen, members of the Select Few, completed a hundred-mile run, starting at 6 o'clock yesterday morning from Military Park, going to Princeton and returning last evening. This was their third annual century, and a more successful run has never been held. The pace was easy, the roads as a rule were in good condition, and all the arrangements were excellent.

" I have known New-York City to receive as high as 200 carloads of peaches a day from New-Jersey and Delaware, and to dispose of them without much trouble," a down-town commission merchant said yesterday. "This year the shipments may reach 150 carloads a day, though they will scarcely exceed that amount.

Mayor Schieren is the victim of several harmful delusions. He petulantly informed a reporter yesterday that he had more important matters to attend to than the reading of newspaper stories about Sunday liquor selling in Brooklyn. This attitude of mind is not merely unwise -- it is unsafe.

Howard S. Jeffrey, Augustus D. Juilliard, and James G. Cannon, receivers of E.S. Jeffrey Co., issued a statement yesterday to creditors of the firm, showing total receipts of $2,913,488.20, payments of $2,304,304.91, and a cash balance of $609,183.29. The statement covers business from March 25, when the receivers took charge, to July 31.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- A sensation was created in Greene County (Ohio) Democratic Convention last Saturday when a resolution was introduced calling upon the Post Office Department of Washington to investigate the alleged purchase of the Xenia Post Office by L.H. Whiteman. It was charged that Postmaster Whiteman had paid $500 for securing Senator Brice's influence, but rumor was not so definite in saying who got the money.
The twenty-eighth annual meeting of the Improved Order of Red Men in New-York State will be formally opened this morning in Tammany Hall with an address of welcome by Mayor Strong.

The protest against the proposed bullfight show at the Atlanta Exposition has elicited from President Collier a positive statement that "the performance will take place" and the opinion that "there is nothing worse in the bullfight under the conditions under which it is to be presented than the thrilling scenes of Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show."

EGG HARBOR CITY, N. J., Aug. 12. -- Congressman John J. Gardner, when asked to-day if he is a candidate for the Gubernatorial nomination, said: "I have not given the matter very serious consideration, but, of course, will not refuse the nomination if it comes my way." It is reported that United States Senator Sewell is favorable to Congressman Gardner's candidacy. Already the Atlantic County Republicans are in the field for Gardner.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- The lack of interest in the coming conference in this city of silver Democrats illustrates the disfavor in which the silver movement in held throughout the country.
Mayor Strong received a letter from L.D. Miller of Bradyville, Tenn., yesterday asking if there is not a lawsuit pending against the City of New-York in the interest of the estate of Robert Edwards.

Developments at the excavations in the Ireland Building, West Broadway and Third Street, which since Thursday last has stood as a monument to mark the tomb of many unfortunate laborers, took a new turn yesterday when Mr. Stevens, counsel for Joseph Guider, the boss plasterer, who was arrested Saturday, on a statement that he overweighted the building, attempted to show that the collapse was due to quicksand underneath the centre pillar.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 12. -- Mrs. Anna M. Carlysle of this city has received from the Rev. George E. White, a missionary at the Congregational School in Marsoven, Asiatic Turkey, news of the assassination of Garabed Agha, one of the ablest Protestants in the city, and head of the Armenian community there.

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- The Methodist Episcopal camp meeting, which is holding its sixty-fourth session here this Summer, is now in full blast, as they term it, and will continue with unabated fervor until next Sunday night, when it will close with the usual "march around Jerusalem," which has brought all its predecessors to a close.

Although the police authorities have announced that each succeeding Sunday in this city should be drier than the previous one, until a complete enforcement of the excise law was accomplished, there was certainly a relaxing of the effort last Sunday, and more liquor was sold than for several Sundays before.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- It has often been remarked as strange that the National City of Washington has been without a Democratic newspaper, a journal with a habit of indicating and approving the principles that hold that party together, rather than one ever seeking for individual departures from sound doctrine to find occasion for promoting Democratic heresy and Democratic division and defeat.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 12. -- When the heavy thunderstorm of this morning broke, one of the first flashes of lightning struck the stable of the Woodstock Lumber Company, at the foot of James Street, West End. In a few minutes the building was in flames.
Elections of Captains of a number of Republican election districts were held last night, to meet the changes caused by the reapportionment of the city into thirty-five Assembly districts.

The temperature yesterday did not approach Sunday's highest record by 4. The day was more uncomfortable, however, owing to the absence of the sea breeze and to the great amount of humidity in the air.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 12. -- The severe electrical and wind storm which visited this town at 4 o'clock this morning did a great amount of damage. In many places corn and other crops were blown down by the force of the wind, which swept over the county with great velocity. Lightning struck in several places.

An "Afro-American" writer complains that negroes are discriminated against "in the new mine, railroad, and factory work of the South," because Northern capitalists have a prejudice against black labor and "white labor refuses to work with black labor where white labor is strong enough to dictate terms."

SARATOGA, Aug. 12. -- The Executive Committee of the New-York State Hotel Men's Association met in executive session at the Grand Union Hotel at 9 o'clock to-night. The principal business transacted was the auditing of accounts and outlining a policy for the coming year. The association will hold its eighth annual session in the Convention Hall to-morrow, when an address of welcome will be made by Village President Charles H. Sturges.

I waited till night, and then, leaving the town, I detached a Captain with fifty troopers, with instructions to approach the enemy, but to retire as soon as he gave the alarm, toward a demilune on my left. My design was to cut off the pursuers between their camp and this demilune, where I lay in ambush.

WEST ISLIP, L.I., Aug. 12. -- Edward Miller Cameron, a millionaire resident of West Islip, a broker doing business at 26 Broad Street, New-York, President of the Hygeia Distilled Water Company, a well-known New-York clubman, accidentally shot himself through the heart with a pistol here last night. Death was instantaneous.

RICHFIELD, SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- The much-talked-of entertainment for the benefit of the road fund took place to-night and drew a very large and fashionable audience. The programme included a one-act comedy, "My Wife's Bonnet," and a capital little farce, "A Husband in Clover." The closing piece was "Her Revenge."

ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- A number of New-York people arrived this evening. Among them were Miss Theresa L. Atkinson, Mr. and Mrs. James Carson, Miss Carrie N. Carson, Miss Louise Probst, and Judah L. Taintor. The hotels here are now full.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- The naval ordnance people are favorably impressed with the new armor tested the other day at Indian Head, at the instance of the inventor, W.F. Lennard of Brooklyn. The official report shows that the plate selected for the test was 9 1/2 by 14 1/2 by 2 1/2 inches and had a weight of 24 pounds, or an equivalent of two pounds to the cubic foot.

It cannot be denied that shallow young men, whose acquaintance with Greek and Latin would not bear half an hour's examination, and whose passion for the fine arts is obviously affected, have learned their false Platonism from teachers no less cultivated than Symonds, and as reserved in style as Pater.
Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Devoe Sutton draw singularly vivid pen pictures of each other in divorce proceedings that they have just begun.

-- A sculptural prodigy in the person of a colored man named George R. Devane has been discovered in Charleston, S.C. Devane is an engineer by trade, and his art, which, if crude, shows undoubted signs of talent. His specialties are carvings on sticks, and they are exceedingly interesting and ingenious, and in some instances pretty.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- The Bureau of Statistics, Treasury Department, has issued its statement of finance, commerce, and immigration, for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1895, corrected to July 31. Compared with the figures of the previous year, the statement makes the following showing of the foreign business of the United States:
Rapid progress has recently been made with the concrete foundations of the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of St John the Divine, on Morningside Heights.

SARATOGA, Aug. 12. -- One hundred tourists from New-Haven, Springfield, and other places in Connecticut and Massachusetts reached here this morning. They will start Thursday on a trip through Lake George, Lake Champlain, and Au Sable Chasm, and return here Friday. They will leave Saratoga Springs the following day for their New-England homes.
Brooklyn people enjoyed their usual wet Sunday, the police making no attempt to interfere with the liquor traffic, which was carried on quietly.

The protest of the British and American residents of Tien-Tsin makes a renewed and forcible showing of the dissatisfaction with which foreign residents of China undoubtedly view the proceedings taken to obtain satisfaction for the murder of British subjects and the destruction of the property of American citizens.

WHITESTONE, L.I., Aug. 12. -- During the electric storm early this morning lightning struck a barn belonging to Patrick Reilly, a dairyman, and shattered one corner of the structure. Two workmen n Reilly's employ were asleep in the building at the time. Both were momentarily stunned, but neither sustained any injury.

The second part of the Summer meeting of the Queens County Jockey Club, which began at Aqueduct yesterday, was a thorough success. The attendance was unusually large, and the racing resulted in some fair-class sport. Favorites and outsiders divided honors.

When the Lake Superior liner Manitou left her dock at Rush Street Bridge yesterday morning she had on board four homing pigeons, which were to be liberated in mid-lake as an experiment to see whether their use was practicable in getting messages to the shore from a boat many miles away.

PETOSKEY, Mich., Aug. 12. -- On account of the absence of the Federal Judges from Chicago the matter of the application of Olmstead, one of the minority stockholders of the Whisky Trust, for an appeal from the decree of sale set for next Wednesday came up to-day for argument before Judge Woods.

After successfully weathering the perilous voyage from the mouth of the Columbia River to San Francisco Bay and getting inside the harbor without a mishap, the great raft of piles that recently came in from the north distinguished itself yesterday by running completely away with a tugboat and by cutting up capers quite at variance with its decorous behavior while being towed in the open ocean.

If any one desires to buy a church he will find some rare bargains these days. As in other commodities, the supply of churches for sale fluctuates considerably, but just at present, owing to the rapid westward push of business, the number for sale is larger than usual, and the would-be purchaser must be hard to please, indeed, who cannot find one according to his fancy in architecture and size.

NYACK, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- A skeleton, believed to be that of Dr. J.R. Crawford, a former prominent dentist of Haverstraw, a veteran officer in the late war, and a member of the Loyal Legion, was found in a small cave on top of the High Tor Mountain, at Haverstraw, yesterday, 1,000 feet above the village.
Mayor Charles A Schieren of Brooklyn several days ago said to a reporter for The New-York Times:

With an excursion party of three, and her master, the thirty-two-foot sloop Christine sailed from Ulmer Park early Sunday morning and has not been heard from since. The party consisted of Miss Baker of Hudson Street, Hoboken; Miss Homan of 11 West Sixty-third Street, this city, and Miss Provost of 463 Evergreen Avenue, Brooklyn. John Brown, the owner of the boat, accompanied the party and sailed the craft.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- The Ruisseaumont has never had such a prosperous season as the one this year. The hotel has been filled more than two weeks.

A young French explorer, M. Gaston Donnet, contributes to the Revue Bleue some vivid descriptions of the French colony of Senegal. The following happened at Saint Louis, the capital, a dull, unprogressive French colonial town, eaten up with red tape and officialism. M. Donnet tells us that he and a fellow traveler wanted to take a bath.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- A practical step toward assisting the construction department of the navy to decide important questions concerning the displacement of warships to be built has been taken by Chief Constructor Hichborn. He has ordered Constructor Ferguson to prepare an experimental tank at the Washington Navy Yard, in which models of vessels may be tested.

Our London correspondent sent us word a week or two ago that a letter of Queen Victoria's to Dhuleep Singh, which had just come to light, was regarded in England as the most remarkable of the royal writer's political and literary eccentricities. Yesterday The Times reprinted the letter itself, which fully bears out this description of it to persons who are versed in Anglo-Indian politics, but may need some elucidation to persons not so versed.

The upset price of $22,500 a year and 5 per cent. of the gross receipts on the New-York side for ten years was yesterday fixed by the Sinking Fund Commission for which the Controller should offer at public sale the franchise for a ferry the Pennsylvania Railroad is desirous of operating between Twenty-third Street and the North River and a point between Grand and Bay Streets, Jersey City.

WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 12. -- The Sheriff of Pratt County has attached the property of the Wichita and Western Railroad at Pratt and Cullison, the two principal stations of the road in that county. The Wichita and Western is a part of the Atchison system, and therefore under the control of the Federal Court, and it is certain that the Sheriff will soon discover himself in contempt with the court presided over by Judge Caldwell.
The total number of excise arrests made by the police Sunday was 136. There were 123 Sunday, Aug. 4. Acting Chief Conlin yesterday expressed himself as being satisfied that the law was well enforced.

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- A more delightful day for celebrating Children's Day in the Sing Sing Methodist Episcopal Camp Meeting could not have been desired than was had to-day. There was a clear sky and a deliciously cool, invigorating breeze from the west, which kept the children from getting out of humor, as the hot weather, such as prevailed Sunday and Monday, was calculated to do.

NORTH YAKIMA, Washington, Aug. 13. -- Charles McGonigle last night shot and killed his father, a ranch owner, near this city, and fatally wounded a blacksmith named Eaves. He surrendered and was brought here by the neighbors. The murderer had slandered Eaves's daughter, and that caused the tragedy. Eaves, his wife, and daughter, drove to McGonigle's ranch to force him to retract.

The thirteenth annual convention of the National Association of Newsdealers, Booksellers and Stationers was begun yesterday in Wilson's Hall, Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, with about 100 delegates in attendance

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Aug. 13. -- Beautiful weather and fine roads combined caused every person owning a horse or having money to hire one to go out driving or riding this afternoon. The hotel verandas, usually so well filled with ladies, seemed almost deserted in consequence.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Two naval officers left Washington to-night for Buffalo to take an interesting trip on the steamer North West. These officers are Chief Engineer J.H. Perry and Passed Assistant Engineer H.P. Norton, who are on duty at the Bureau of Steam Engineering, in the Navy Department.

PETSOKEY, Mich., Aug. 13. -- The hearing of the Whiskey Trust petition for leave to appeal, was concluded to-day before Judge Woods, who, after a brief study of the question as presented in the authorities offered, dismissed the application.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- Pugilism is Hamlin's last resort to swell the gate receipts at his Grand Circuit meeting. So many of the visiting horsemen went away last week and the local patronage was so small today that a big deficit will have to be made up unless the attendance can be materially increased during the next four days.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 13. -- At the meeting of the East Orange Township Committee last evening, several of the members took occasion to say a number of things in defense of the wheelmen of the vicinity, against whom some are inclined to think an unjust discrimination is being made by the police in the enforcement of local ordinances.

OCEAN GROVE, Aug. 13. -- The Summer school of theology continues with unabated zeal. This morning Prof. G.S. Burroughs, President of Wabash College, delivered his second lecture on the newly found Gospels. The subject was "The Apocryphal Gospel of Peter." Dr. Burroughs spoke of the discovery of the Akhmin fragment during the Winter of 1886 by the French archaeological mission.

At first sight, it seemed a bit remarkable that Mr. John C. New, reaching New-York from Europe on such an extremely sultry day as Monday undoubtedly was, should have felt it necessary, or even comfortable, to add an overcoat to his other apparel before marching down the Berlin's gangplank.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 13. -- After two weeks of investigation, during which innumerable witnesses were examined and public interest wrought to fever heat, the Grand Jury has indicted Maurice J. Hart, who is interested in the traction company, the garbage company, the electric light company, and other concerns which have received valuable franchises from the city, or which have fat contracts.
Messrs. L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for George P. Rowell, at $75,000, the four-story and basement brownstone dwelling, 4 West Fortyninth Street, 21.6 by 100.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Col. Henry L. Abbott of the Engineer Corps of the Army was placed on the retired list at noon to-day, having reached the age limit -sixty- four years.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 13. -- The Street and Water Commissioners this morning awarded a contract for a new water supply, with one supply main from the storage reservoirs near Boonton to high service at Belleville, to the Jersey City company, at $7,950,000.

ALBANY, Aug. 13. -- Secretary Melvil Dewey of the Regents of the University resumed the stand to-day before the Abell legislative investigating committee. Mr. Dewey explained in detail causes which he thought had occasioned the charges made against him during the last few years. He said he incurred the enmity of a certain official in the building and labor organizations.

WASHINGTON, Aug 13. -- The report of Indian Agent Teter of the Fort Hall Reservation upon the recent Bannock trouble was received at the Indian Bureau today. It confirms the heretofore published accounts of the killing of the Bannock Indians.

" I'm 'green' enough for the cows to eat," was the lament yesterday at Police Headquarters of James W. Callaghan, one of a band of thieves arrested on Monday by members of the Detective Bureau, through a stroke of luck which came to Acting Captain Stephen O'Brien.
Villa formerly meant a farm, not a house. Daisy was originally the eye of day, or day's eye.
A switching engine and a freight car wer6 precipitated Into the East River at the foot of North Fifth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, and a car coupler was drowned.

ALBANY, Aug. 13. -- If Levi P. Morton hopes to succeed in his ambition to follow his predecessors, Martin Van Buren and Grover Cleveland, from the Gubernatorial chair of New-York State into the Presidential chair at Washington, he will have to take no part in influencing the Senatorial and Judicial nominations of the Republicans.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 13. -- A local paper prints a story to-day to the effect that the real purpose of Gov. Morrill's trip East is to start a boom for himself for the Republican nomination for Vice President.
Many removals are expected to-day in the Water Register's Bureau of the Department of Public Works, and it is said that places will be made for a number of Republicans.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- On the eve of the conference of Democratic silver men the outlook is most discouraging to those who assumed that a call for such a meeting would attract a swarm of silver advocates from all over the country. Not fifteen Democrats of more than local prominence have arrived.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 13. -- The steamboat Pleasure Bay of the New-York and Long Branch Steamboat Company while on her way from New-York to this place and points on the Sherwsbury River this afternoon caught fire when off Sandy Hook. The fire started in the engine room and the first warning that the passengers had of its existence was when a cloud of smoke enveloped the steamboat.

The enforcement of the excise law and other enactments and the selection of election officers were the subjects of addresses made before the Patriotic Republican Club at 248 East Seventy-eighth Street last night by Joseph Murray, President of the Excise Board, and Theodore Roosevelt, President of the Board of Police.

The Washingtons defeated the Brooklyn baseball team yesterday at Eastern Park. President Byrne was vexed with the game his men put up, and, if black looks go for anything, there was a storm brewing at Eastern Park last evening.

Should the telegraphic dispatch from Madrid which reports that the Spanish Cabinet has resolved to pay the Mora claim in a lump sum in September, and without interest, prove to be true, it will unquestionably also be unsatisfactory to this Government, as it will not be responsive to the urgent request made to Spain by the State Department on June 6.

The Defender was at anchor off Mr. Iselin's home, at New-Rochelle, yesterday, and her crew were kept busy overhauling the yacht generally. The aluminum topsides of the boat, which were scraped yesterday, received a coat of the new paint which it is expected will protect them thoroughly from the effects of the salt water. Some of the sails were retrimmed and all the rigging was carefully examined to find any weak spots.
When Mayor Strong's new Charities Commissioners went into office they decided to get rid of John J. Blair, Supervising Engineer in the department.

One of the most serious accidents the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company has suffered, and which entailed more or less serious injuries upon a dozen passengers, happened at the City Hall terminus of the Third Avenue division at 9:40 A.M. yesterday, a train of four cars, in charge of Engineer Samuel Tower, running into the bumpers at the station.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 13. -- The long-expected tennis tournament for the Eastern championship in doubles began here this morning on the courts at the Casino. The weather was almost perfect for tennis, and later in the day a large crowd surrounded the courts and applauded the best strokes of the players.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13. -- Chairman Smith of Councils Committee on the Atlanta Exposition, came to Philadelphia to-day from his Summer home in Asbury Park expressly to attend to matters connected with the city's exhibit in the South. Mayor Warwick to-day received several letters of inquiry from intending exhibitors, and he referred them all to the Chairman.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 13. -- The hot weather that has prevailed here for several days has made the hotel business very good. The hotel proprietors say business could not be better. The mercury to-day here registered 85 degrees in the shade, but a good sea breeze was enjoyed in the afternoon.

Though the programme at Aqueduct yesterday promised but an ordinary day's sport, the attendance was large and the racing interesting. The opening event brought about a stirring contest between Lord Hawkstone and Austin, they finishing so close together that the Judges were unable to separate them, declaring it a dead heat.

SARATOGA, Aug. 13. -- The cottage of Mrs. J.T. Linthicum of New-York City was visited by burglars about 2 o'clock this morning. The burglars cut out a plate-glass window. The family gave an alarm and the burglars escaped.

Nobody but a liar can remember when there were better peaches to be had in New-York than there are to-day. It is equally true that no other kind of man can remember the year when the Delaware peach crop was not a failure. At this time last year we were relying exclusively upon the peaches of California.

SARATOGA, Aug. 13. -- The chief topic of conversation at the track to-day was the purchase of Henry of Navarre and Dorian by August Belmont, President of The Jockey Club. Both Mr. Belmont and Pierre Lorillard have been anxious to own Byron McClelland's crack racer, and as the flattering offers have been refused by McClelland time and time again, it was believed that he would not part with Navarre under any circumstances.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 13. -- The Newport Naval Reserve boat crew had a race tonight with the racing crew of the cruiser New-York. The latter crew, with two exceptions was the one that won the world's championship at Kiel. The Newport crew lost, but only by two and a half boat lengths in a row of a mile and an eighth.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 13. -- The mercury did not rise above 75 to-day, and a brisk wind from the west made delightful sailing on Mahkeenac Lake. Among the young ladies who went down to the lake to-day were the Misses Sands, Miss Barlow, and the Misses Parsons. New rowboats and canoes have been put on the lake this season, and many of the young ladies paddle a canoe, row a boat, or sail.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 13. -- Lloyd Lowndes will probably be nominated for Governor by the Republicans Thursday on the first ballot. The primary elections in Baltimore City gave him two districts of the three, and he had already enough from the counties to win.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13. -Philadelphia defeated New-York this afternoon in the most exciting game played here this season. The numerous exceptions taken to Umpire Burnham's decisions by both teams were more of a feature than were any of the plays made. The objections on the part of the visitors culminated, in the fourth inning, in Doyle's removal from the field.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 13. -Minneapolis has had trouble with Class B men for so many years that but few of them attended the meet of the present season. Barely a dozen were present to-day at the races of the Minneapolis Limited Cycling Club, held on the mile track at Minnehaha Driving Park. Barely 400 persons were present to see the contests.
HASTINGS, England, Aug. 13. -The seventh round in the international chess masters' tournament was played here to-day with the following results:
" Why they have not even combed out the tiger's ruffled fur," said a Tammany politician yesterday in commenting upon the so-called reorganization of Tammany Hall.

The theory that the collapse of the Ireland Building, at West Broadway and Third Street, last Thursday was due to the overloading of floors with tons of plaster was apparently confirmed late yesterday afternoon by the discovery that the iron plates under two side pillars were cracked in four parts, as was that under the central pillar which gave way.

The announcement of the formation at Shanghai of a joint British and American commission of inquiry into the massacre at Ku-Cheng entirely vindicates the conduct of our Government. It also has the effect of making the critics of the Government, who have been insisting that it should "do something," without having the slightest notion what it should do, appear very foolish.

The use of drugs to stupefy the inmates of flats and then pillage the places to their hearts' content is the latest trick of North Side burglars. A bold attempt to rob by this plan was made early yesterday morning on the building of Mrs. Kate Davis, 130 North State Street, but was barren of results for the burglars, as they were frightened away before they had gained an entrance.
LONDON, Aug. 13. -- The King of the Belgians has arrived in London on a brief pleasure visit. During his stay here he will preserve the strictest incognito.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- The open correspondence between Secretary Morton and ex-Congressman Abner Taylor of Illinois over the regulations of the Department of Agriculture intended to encourage the importation of Mexican cattle into the United States, which has been languishing recently by reason of the Secretary's absence from the city, was resumed to-day.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 13. -- Mrs. S. Weir Mitchell of Philadelphia gave a ball and supper to-night at the Kebo Valley Club. The walls of the ballroom were panelled with Egyptian embroideries and Oriental tapestries. The portieres were of silk velours, while the windows were curtained with delicate pink and yellow China silk.
Mayor Schieren has apparently made up his mind not to make the saloon keepers of Brooklyn close up on Sunday as long as he holds his present office.
LONDON, Aug. 13. -- A dispatch from Shanghai says that the commission appointed to inquire into the massacre of Christians will leave Foo-Choo this afternoon for Ku-Cheng.
PANAMA, via Galveston, Aug. 13. -- Guayaquil, Ecuador, is feverishly excited by the efforts of the city authorities to mobilize the reserve forces.
ALEXANDRIA BAY, Aug. 13. -- Excursionists from the West continue to come this way in large numbers. The hotels here for the past three or four days have been overrun with this class of visitors.

The second day's sitting of the twenty- eighth regular session of the Great Council of the State of New-York, Improved Order of Red Men, was opened at 10:30 o'clock A.M. yesterday in Tammany Hall. There were 500 delegates to the session present.

It is said that the Good Government Clubs are to investigate for the Police Board the character and qualifications of the candidates for election officers in this city whose names have been submitted by the regular party committees, and President Roosevelt is quoted as saying that a "full inquiry" will be made, and "the men will be put through a good, stiff examination, too, to test their mental qualifications."

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 13. -- The polo tournament for the Newport individual cups, open to teams of four, whose August handicap shall not exceed twenty goals, was opened here to-day by the Newport and the Freebooter team the latter a strong picked team from the country clubs near New-York. The Newports were: U.C. Eustis, Moses Taylor, Reginald Brooks, and Albert Francke.
Platt men in this city are asserting that all of the ninety-eight delegates so far elected to the Republican State Convention will obey ex-Senator Platt's orders.

Michael Donahoe, an expressman, of 217 East Twenty-sixth Street, was held in $1,000 bail in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday to await the result of the injuries received through his alleged negligence by Mrs. Shipman of 55 Lenox Avenue, wife of Andrew J. Shipman, of the law firm of Blandy, Mooney Shipman of 15 Wall Street.
The three Police Captains who have recently had charge of the old annexed district were shifted around yesterday by Acting Chief Conlin.

Transactions at the Sub-Treasury yesterday increased the gold reserve to $101,750,000. They consisted of the withdrawal of $900,000 and the deposit by the bond syndicate of $1,350,000. It had been thought that a larger amount might be taken.

Unless the Greenhut-Morris combination springs some new proceeding at the last moment out in Chicago, eighteen of the old Whisky Trust properties will be bought in to-day by the Reorganization Committee at the receiver's sale ordered by the Federal court.

Discussion of the international athletic contest, which is to take place in September, has brought out facts tending to show that the contestants will be very evenly matched. The American entries are young men who have established world's records in some instances, and in others have so closely approached the top figures that only the pressure of a hot contest was needed to make new marks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- While no official information is obtainable here regarding the negotiations looking to a new commercial treaty between Brazil and the United States, the fact is well known that Brazil has desired since the abolition of the reciprocity treaty to enter into more intimate commercial relations with this country.

RYDE, Isle of Wight, Aug. 13. -- The Royal Victoria Yacht Club had most disagreeable weather for the opening to-day of its regatta, which will last four days. In the early morning there was a moderate southeast breeze, but when the start was made it had shifted around to the southwest. Rain was falling heavily, and the weather was so thick that the markboats were invisible from here.

FIRE ISLAND, Aug. 13. -- A beautiful water pageant was witnessed to-day by a great crowd. The day was clear and a good breeze from the shore brought hundreds of boats from Bay Shore, Babylon, and many other places.

The Harlem Republican Club, which includes in its membership roll 275 prominent business men and politicians living in the upper part of the city, decided at its regular monthly meeting last evening not to open the club bar on Sundays and to buy a new Bible for the club library.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 13. -- It was oppressively hot here to-day, and cottagers generally remained at home till it was time for the afternoon drive.

Hugo Hirsh, counsel for the Assembly committee that is investigating the affairs of the Kings County Department of Charities, finds it hard work to get witnesses. He subpoenaed six yesterday, and only one appeared, and because of this there was no afternoon session.

LONDON, Aug. 13. -- The House of Lords assembled at noon to-day. Lord Halsbury, the Lord Chancellor, and Lords Coventry, Limerick, Cross, and Balfour of Burleigh, the commission appointed to read the royal proclamation opening the session of Parliament, announced that the Queen had approved the re-election of William Court Gully as Speaker of the House of Commons.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 14. -- The same two crack tennis teams will meet here to-morrow morning on the Casino courts that played in the finals for the Eastern championship a year ago. Howland and Foote and Chace and Wrenn both won their semi-final matches this morning, and a great contest is looked for between them in the finals to-morrow. Much interest is centred in the match.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14. -- The principal characteristic about to-day's local market was its apathy. The tendency was inclined to be reactionary, and fractionally lower prices were made in a few specialties, notably in the coalers. Reading sold off from 9 3/8 to 9, and Lehigh Valley from 38 1/8 to 37 1/2.

ELLENBURG, Washington Aug. 14. --Charles Vincent, who shot Mike Kohlopp in a drunken brawl Sunday, was lynched early this morning. A large mob gathered at midnight and attacked the jail about 1 o'clock. The Sheriff made resistance, but had a small force of men, and was overpowered.

RYDE, Aug. 14. -- The American schooner Yampa, owned by Mr. R.S. Palmer of NewYork, and the British schooner Amphitrite, the property of Mr. Frederick Wills, to-day sailed their match race over the Queen's Cup course of the Royal Yacht Squadron, from Cowes westward to the Lymington Spit, thence to the Bullock Patch buoy, southeast of the Nab Lightship, and back to the starting point, twice around, a distance of fifty miles.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14. -- The property of the Distilling and Cattle Feeding Company, commonly known as the Whisky Trust, was sold at auction on the Court House steps in this city at 11:30 o'clock this morning. The sale proved a mere formality, as there were no other bidders besides the Reorganization Committee, whose bid of $9,800,000, incorporated in the judicial decree of sale, was accepted.
PIERRE, S.D., Aug. 14. -- Ex-State Treasurer Taylor was this morning sentenced to five years in the penitentiary.

Lobsters are dear because they are scarce. They are scarce, it is said, because some who have thousands in pens at Portland, Me., know that rivals there have no more in their aquaria, and see a sure method of obtaining large profit by limiting the supply.

It was ascertained yesterday noon that there were no more bodies buried in the cellar of the Ireland Building at West Broadway and West Third Street. Every bit of debris had by that time been shovelled over. It had been expected more bodies would be found and three plain coffins were kept on hand.

NEWPORT, Aug. 14. -- Schuyler Hamilton, Jr., to-night received a special delivery letter from his father, Schuyler Hamilton, dated "Baltimore, Aug. 13," in which the writer said that by the time the letter should be received he would have been married to Jane Mercer of Baltimore.

BALTIMORE, Md., Aug. 14. -- Harry Williams, who is connected with the Washington Brewing Company, had a peculiar experience in Baltimore County, eighteen miles from this city, Sunday. At one time Mr. Williams considered his situation so unsafe that he readily gave up his $300 gold watch and chain to placate his captors, who, he said, threatened to lynch him.

NEWPORT. R.I., Aug. 14. -- The special event of this evening with society was the dance at the Breakers given by Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt in honor of her daughter, Miss Gertrude. There was a dinner to thirty young people at 8:30 o'clock, which was served in the large and elegantly appointed dining hall.

One of the excuses given for the failure to enforce the excise law in Brooklyn is the assumed fact that public opinion is so much opposed to the Sunday prohibition that juries will not convict the violators thereof. This is a singular excuse, when we consider that no attempt has been made to secure a conviction since a time whereof the memory of man runneth not to the contrary.

ELTINGVILLE, S.I., Aug. 14. -- There is a small war at the Woods of Arden, the beautiful property on the shores of the lower bay which Erastus Wiman formerly owned and named. The war is over a gate, passage through which is obstructed by planks fastened with heavy spikes and the stump of a tree fully two feet in diameter, which has been planted deep in the ground in the centre of the gateway.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Aug. 14. -- The town is baseball crazy to-night and the Summer visitors are as enthusiastic as the natives over the fact that the home club beat the Cuban Giants this afternoon in the best game ever played here. The grand stand was filled to overflowing, the majority of those present being ladies.
The National Association of Newsdealers, Booksellers and Stationers held the closing session of its thirteenth annual convention in Wilson's Hall in Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn yesterday afternoon.
LEIPSIC, Aug. 14. -- Baron Christian Bernard von Tauchnitz, the celebrated publisher of Greek and Latin classics, died today, aged seventy-nine years.

The Brooklyns met with another defeat yesterday at the hands of the Washingtons in the game of baseball at Eastern Park, Brooklyn. About 1,500 persons witnessed the contest, which was by no means exciting. The visitors were too strong at the bat for the home team.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- An address to the Democratic Party, urging that free coinage of silver be made the dominant issue in the next Presidential campaign, and the organization of a National Committee under instructions to advance as much as possible the interests of free silver in that campaign, will be the net results of the so-called conference of free silver Democrats which began here to-day.
Yesterday's transactions at the Sub-Treasury added $500,000 to the gold reserve, increasing it to $102,250,000.

RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 14. -- Marion Butler, the Populist Senator, appears to feel that the eyes of the nation are upon him. He seems to imagine that he is about to be martyred for bold expression of what he thinks are his principles. In a speech at Concord to-day, he said:

The Defender and the Vigilant will be floated into the dry docks in the Erie Basin at high tide, about 7 o'clock to-morrow morning. The Defender will occupy Dock No. 1 and the Vigilant Dock No. 2. These docks are side by side, and so any one who pays a visit to the basin will have a chance to compare the models of the two yachts.

The Great Council of New-York of the Improved Order of Red Men, who have been in session in Tammany Hall since Tuesday last, spent all yesterday afternoon in the election of officers. The contests for some of the offices were exciting. The following were elected officers of the Great Council of New-York:
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 14. -- This has been a most delightful day -- not too warm and not too cool, but just right for good bathing, driving, and sailing.

In the tennis tournament of the Marine and Field Club, which was finished yesterday on the Bath Beach courts, N.W. Garland, winner of Class B, defeated J.C. Chamberlain, winner of Class A. The latter played the steadier game of the two, but was unable to overcome the handicap of half thirty which he was obliged to give his opponent.

The Executive Committee of the New East River Bridge Commission had a secret session yesterday in its rooms in the Emigrant Savings Bank Building. A number of persons who were interested in the work of the commission were gathered in the outer office, waiting for the open session, although that there would be one was not assured.

Warden Patrick Hayes of the Kings County Penitentiary, when he arrived at the institution yesterday morning, learned with surprise that the Assembly committee that is investigating the affairs of the Department of Charities of Kings County had visited the penitentiary Tuesday night and had taken testimony.

The local Republican Conventions already held in different parts of the State, and the preparations for those soon to be held, afford indications of the Platt and anti-Platt division almost everywhere. The Platt men generally have control of the existing party machinery, and in most places they bid fair to retain control of it, but that is not an evidence of preponderance among the voters.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 14. -- The Northern Ohio Railway Companw was organized here to-day to take the place of the Pittsburg, Akron and Western. The capital stock is $4,260,000. H.L. Brice of Lima, brother of Senator Brice, who purchased the road, is President. The incorporators are A.L. Conger, Nelson Stone. Fred C. Smith, John W. Holloway, William P. Fulton, and John C. Frank.

Mayor Strong was a guest on board the floating hospital barge of St. John's Guild yesterday morning. The barge, with its big load of women and babies, was towed to the pier at the foot of Rector Street, in order to receive the Mayor and other members of the Board of Trustees of St. John's Guild.

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- This has been in a certain sense a day of rest between two busy ones at the Methodist Episcopal camp meeting, yesterday having been children's day, and to-morrow being old folks' day, when old-fashioned Methodism will prevail.

The large crowd that made the journey to the Queens County Jockey Club track yesterday were treated to another interesting afternoon's sport, notwithstanding that the programme was made up of a poor quality of horses. The first two events furnished a surprise, each being captured by outsiders.

It was, I think, at the little port of the Esquina in Corrientes that he came on board. A priest at first sight, yet not quite similar to other priests, at least to those whose mission is only for mass and meat. A Spaniard, too, at first sight, with the clean-cut features of Old Castille, the bony hands that mark the man of action, and feet as square as boxes.
Mrs. John Graham is not getting much alimony from her husband, but she is certainly keeping things lively for that gentleman, who is seventy-five years old.

The Mayor of Havana, Cuba, Senor Segundo Alvarez, who is at the Union Square Hotel, says there is danger ahead of trouble between Spain and the United States growing out of the action of our Government in pressing Spain to pay the Mora claim at this time, and of the aid that Americans are extending to Cuban agitators and filibusters.

Now and then the readers of Republican newspapers come across the editorial suggestion that in this "off year," when there is no great political issue to be discussed, due regard for the business interests of the State would be shown by postponing the campaigning as long as possible, so that the contest shall be brief and then be free from excitement or bitterness.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The Navy Department has determined to order a survey of the cruiser Atlanta on her arrival at New-York from Key West to determine her actual condition, which is believed to be bad.

Messrs. Hellner Wolf have purchased for S. Mehrbach the lot on the north side of Ninety-fourth street, 102 feet east of Third Avenue, 28 by 100 by 30 by irregular, and have sold the same at an advance to J. Farrekll, who will improve by the erection of an apartment house.

Ex-Mayor Thomas F. Gilroy defined his position very clearly yesterday as to his part in the organization politics of Tammany Hall, in an interview with a reporter for The New-York Times. At the same time he indicated clearly his belief that the hope of Democratic success this year lay in a union of all Democrats and a burial of all personal and factional differences.

ROTTERDAM, Aug. 14. -- Gustave Bingen, twenty-nine years old, a member of the banking firm of Bingen Brothers of Genoa, Italy, which recently failed with liabilities of $4,000,000, was arrested in this city last night as he was boarding the steamer Sparndam for New-York.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 14. -- Tom Cooper won a good race at the second day's meeting of the Minneapolis Cycle Club to-day. The mile open had a time limit of 2:30, and was ridden the first time, without pacemakers, in 2:31 2-5. On the second attempt, Gratoit Cabanne, a brother of the racing man, and A.W. Warren paced on a tandem and dropped out at the half mile.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- A bitter local fight is being waged between Mayor Lewis, who seeks renomination, and ex-Mayor Curran, who wants to succeed him, and their respective factions. The Lewis party represents the machine faction of the Republican Party, and is backed up by Superintendent of Public Works Aldridge. Curran represents the reform movement headed by John Van Voorhis.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 14. -- John Morris, a wealthy farmer, of Glendola, was last night awakened by a masked burglar, who ordered him to "keep your mouth shut and give up your cash." The burglar pointed a loaded revolver at the farmer.

The Drainage Will Receive Particular Attention -- A Greenhouse to be Erected in the Fall. Now that the Park Board has set aside a tract of 250 acres in Bronx Park as the site for the new Botanical Garden, work will be begun soon in laying out the ground.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- "If the American farmer would study the demands and condition of the foreign market, and devote less attention to politics, his condition would be greatly improved." Secretary Morton of the Agricultural Department advanced this proposition to-day as a result of his conversation a few hours earlier with Samuel Degean of Chicago.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Aug. 14. -- A dusty and weather-beaten traveler called at the office of Probate Judge Mason to-day and requested that official to place the impress of his official seal on a document which he presented to the Judge. It proved to be an affidavit to the effect that T.J. Warner had passed through this city.

BAR HARBOR. Me., Aug. 14. -- Social interest centred in two events to-day. The first was in the afternoon -- the annual lawn fete in aid of the Village Improvement Association. This year it was held on the grounds surrounding W.B. Rice's Summer residence, "The Tides." Flags and yachting insignia, loaned by the owners of the various yachts in the harbor, were draped effectively on the long piazzas.
Police Commissioner Roosevelt yesterday received the following from the Rev. A.P. Doyle, General Secretary of the Catholic Total Abstinence Union of America:

WEDNESDAY -- P.M. Having failed in all attempts to bring about liquidation in the stock market, the bears are now industriously circulating stories intended to create another gold scare. Thinking men, however, are not disturbed by the situation, for they realize that the absence of bills from the market at this time is readily accounted for by two well-known conditions -- the failure in part of Winter wheat and the lateness of the cotton crop.

Sir Charles Rivers Wilson of London, President of the Grand Trunk Railway and the special representative of British holders of Central Pacific Railway securities. arrived here yesterday on the steamship Majestic. He will proceed to Boston in a day or two; from there he will go to Portland, Me., and thence to Montreal.
Eugene F. Brooks, an old man-of-wars-man, sent an appeal to Recorder Goff yesterday, asking the Recorder to help him get out of Clinton Prison.

Several special committees of the late "reforra" Legislature are now on their pilgrimage .through the State, cn the ostensible mission of "investigating" something or other, but of which the only thing that can be afilrmed with vbsolute certainty is that they are piling up bills against the State which the taxpayers will have t.o pay.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- Ladies' Day at the Driving Park was also trotters' day, as all four classes in the Grand Circuit card this afternoon were for the diagonal-gaited fliers. The free admission for women, much as it is against the Hamlin policy, certainly helped to fill the grand stand, which had so many empty seats on Tuesday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14. -- The Executive Committee of the National Republican League met to-day. Thirtyseven States and Territories were represented. The presiding officer was Gen. E.A. McAlpin of New-York, who to-day gave $500 to assist in organizing a league in Arizona. When the matter of the sinews of war was being discussed, the Minnesota representatives contributed $1,000 on behalf of the Republicans of that State.

The Naval Court of Inquiry, which has been convened at the New-York Navy Yard to investigate allegations against Col. James Forney, while that officer was on duty at that post, resumed its labors yesterday.

The fact that an American and an English schooner yacht have been racing in British waters is more important and significant than the result of the race. The Yampa appears to have received a very exemplary beating, but that is a detail, and we need not even pause to inquire in how far she was a representative American yacht, or what chance she would have with our newer crack schooners.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14. -- Philadelphia again defeated New-York this afternoon by hitting Rusie hard in the seventh and eighth innings. Up to the seventh the big New-Yorker held the home team down to five singles and a triple, while the visitors batted Lucid, who made his debut as a Philadelphia twirler, rather freely, Davis making a home run in the sixth by sending the ball over the right-field wall.
HAVANA, Aug. 14. -- Capt. Gen. Martinez Campos started this morning for Santa Clara with 100 members of the Fire Brigade, who displayed much enthusiasm.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 14. -- When William C. Brockway, William E. Wagner, Sidney Smith, and Mrs. Libby L. Smith, arrested, charged by Chief William P. Hazen and his men with counterfeiting, were arraigned before United States Commissioner Isaac Romaine this morning, the Government was not ready to proceed.

SARATOGA, Aug. 14. -- A reception was given this evening at one of the hotels in honor of Mrs. J.T. Gibbons of Washington, a regular guest here for years. It was in celebration of her seventy-eighth birthday.

The Aldermen are going to have a flag of their own. They feel that they must provide themselves with a suitable emblem. They adopted a design for their official banner yesterday and they authorized the Committee on County Affairs to expend one hundred dollars in securing it.

Acts of heroism are by no means infrequent, yet they lose none of their appearance of novelty nor do they cease to excite admiration mingled with surprise. Whenever a human being risks life in noble effort, we are in some way startled by this discovery of qualities that lie concealed so that we practically forget their existence.
