Detective Sergeant Delahanty of the Bureau of Criminal Investigation and Information of Brooklyn returned to that city from Boston yesterday a sad man.

Aloyslus G. Molloy, twenty-four years old, of Boston Post Road, New-Rochelle, brother of Postmaster William Molloy of New-Rochelle, broke his back shortly after midnight Wednesday, while bathing at Rye Beach. He is in Bellevue Hospital, and will probably die.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 14. -- William Dovey, a prominent citizen of Delawanna, N.J., who was assaulted. Saturday night, July 28, by two foot pads, while on his way home, near the woods on Park, Avenue, is reported to be dying. One of the men struck him on the head with an iron bar knocking him unconscious. The thieves then rifled his pockets and robbed him of his gold watch and money.

BOSTON, Aug. 14. -- The twenty-eighth annual report of the Boston and Albany Railroad Company shows that there was a decrease of 430 in the number of passengers carried as compared with 1894, the total number being 12,151,670. The freight business, however, was largely increased, being 93,568 tons over that of last year, with a total of 3,994,340 tons.
Coroner Hoeber and a jury held an inquest yesterday into the death of Clara Newman, who died at 1,100 Third Avenue on Aug. 7.

SARATOGA, Aug. 14. -- The feature of the racing here this afternoon was the defeat of August Belmont's new purchase -- Dorian. He and Victorious were the only two starters in the Rancocas Stud Stakes. Dorian ran as if he was short of work, faltering in the last few yards, and was beaten a half length. The attendance was large and the weather delightful.

For some time past there has been a difference of opinion between the City Magistrates and the Commissioners of Charities and Correction as to the exact purpose and scope of the Wilds cumulative sentence law.

PANAMA, via Galveston, Aug. 14. -- Advices from Mapocho report that Quito, Ecuador, is guarded entirely by recruits, all the veterans, numbering about 1,500, having left the city Aug. 3 to reinforce the army of Gen. Sarasti, who holds the strategic positions around Riobamba.

New-York's premier long distance cycle rider, "Freddie" Titus, covered himself with glory at the Manhattan Beach track yesterday afternoon by making a show of Harry Maddox, the fisher lad, in their ten-mile match race, and very prettily adding two record gems to his brilliant diadem.

Commissioner of Public Works Brookfield reported at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment that the fumes from an ammonia factory near the southerly side of Calvary Cemetery were gradually destroying the bronze work on the Soldiers' Monument erected by the city in the cemetery.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- The fight which resulted in the defeat of Senator George W. Robertson at the caucus held in his own town last night was begun in the Town Committee a week ago, when a list of delegates presented by Senator Robertson was discarded by an overwhelming vote.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- H.T. Thurber, private secretary to President Cleveland, who suffered a slight attack of indigestion here yesterday, has recovered and left for Gray Gables this afternoon. A physician was summoned, but the illness was of no consequence.

Now that the Tilden money has become actually available for the New-York Public Library, the responsibility of the Trustees of that institution becomes operative. The question whether a library that is simply a repository of books, to which students and readers may resort, can fairly be called, in our time, a "public" library scarcely admits of any but a negative answer.

ALBANY, Aug. 14. -- James A. Roberts to-day announced definitely that he was a candidate before the Republican State Convention for the renomination for Controller. The announcement was not altogether a surprise to well-informed politicians. In their opinion Mr. Roberts has all along been coquetting with the subject.

NORRISTOWN, Penn., Aug. 14. -- Thomas Hovenden, the famous artist, was instantly killed by a railroad train near here this evening. Mr. Hovenden met with a hero's death. It was in attempting to save the life of a little girl that he lost his own. The sacrifice of Mr. Hovenden's life was useless, because the child that he attempted to save also met her death.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of The New-York Times.
BARBADOS, W.I., Aug. 2. -- Intelligence of a most stirring character has just been received here from Cayenne, the capital of French Guiana. War may shortly be declared between France and Brazil.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- A cable dispatch received at the State Department today from J. Courtney Hixson, United States Consul at Foo-Choo, reports the departure from that place of the mixed British and American commission to investigate the Ku-Cheng massacre Mr. Hixson is a member of the commission, and is accompanied by Ensign Waldo Evans of the Detroit as the other American representative.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 14. -- There were about fifty persons on the golf grounds this morning, who went around the links. It was a larger number than had played golf at any previous time this season. Among the young women who played were Miss Davis, the Misses Ives, Miss Shaw, Miss Barlow, and the Misses Parsons.

John J. Meade, a night watchman of 439 Hicks Street, has brought suit in this city against the City of Brooklyn to recover $100,000 for injuries which, he alleges, were inflicted on him by the soldiers under command of Major George Cochran of the Thirteenth Regiment, during the Brooklyn trolley strike.
The North German Lloyd steamship Stuttgart arrived yesterday morning with the American barkentine Eleanor M. Williams in tow. The barkentine was in a damaged condition.

Mrs. Leah Bernard, of 60 South Washington Square was locked up in the West Thirtieth Street Station last night, charged with disorderly conduct. At 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon Mrs. Bernard hired a cabman, Michael McGarry, at Thirty-second Street and Broadway, to drive her to the Stewart Building, Broadway and Chambers Street.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Aug. 15.-- In order to strengthen a charge of burglary two Red Antwerp pigeons were liberated from the police court in this city to-day. The birds were stolen from August Ermisch of 386 Ninth Avenue, this city, on the night of July 29, together with forty-eight others.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15. -- Chairman Gideon of the Racing Board of the League of American Wheelmen had a big budget of transfers, suspensions, and sanctions for race meets to send out to-day. Among the transfers to Class B were:

The Democratic State Convention will be held in Syracuse Tuesday, Sept. 24, beginning at noon. The State Committee will meet in that city on Monday evening, Sept. 23, at the Yates House. These matters were decided at yesterday's meeting of the committee, which was held at the Hoffman House, this city.

The Defender and the Vigilant will be put in the dry docks in the Erie Basin at 7 o'clock this morning to be thoroughly cleaned before meeting in the trial races next week. The two yachts will remain in the clocks until Saturday, and will then go to anchorage off the Atlantic Yacht Clubhouse at Bay Ridge.

A number of officers of the Seventy-first Regiment, connected with the publication of The American Guard Gazette, a regimental paper, held a conference yesterday afternoon to decide on what action should be taken on notice received from Lieut. Charles S. Clark of Company C that he intended bringing suit against The Gazette Association in the City Court for $50, which he says is due him for salary as its editor.
Samuel Cuperman is accused by Ludwig Wuestenberg of having played a very pretty confidence game, in which the stake was a corner saloon at Thirty-eighth Street and Ninth Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15. -- William Capps, the Fort Worth lawyer who represents the heirs of Minnie Williams, who it is alleged was murdered by H.H. Holmes, called upon District Attorney Graham to-day and secured permission to visit Holmes in the County Prison. The attorney's object was to get from the prisoner statements that might clear away the clouds now hanging over the title to the Fort Worth property owned by Minnie Williams and her sister.

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- There was a great influx of old people to the Sing Sing Methodist camp meeting to-day, as it had been given out that the day would be devoted to old-time Methodism and old-fashioned singing and prayer meetings.

The Association of Canalboat Owners is raising a cry of distress on account of what they claim to be an effort of the railroads to "annihilate the Erie Canal." They claim that two methods are employed during the season of navigation to strangle canal traffic, with a deliberate design of putting an end to it in time.

The work of framing an effective agreement for the maintenance of railroad rates, both freight and passenger, in trunk line territory, progressed satisfactorily yesterday. An adjourned meeting of the committee appointed by the Board of Presidents in June was held in the office of the Trunk Line Association. M.E. Ingalls presided.
SARATOGA, Aug. 15. -- The Presbyterian 100-mile trip through Lake Champlain today was enjoyed by several hundred persons, including many Summer visitors.

SWINEFIELD BRIDGE, N.J., Aug. 15. -- For fifteen years the farmers' granges of the townships of Union, Essex, and Morris Counties have united in a monster outing here in the middle of August. If times were bad, and things were not going the farmer's way, the outing lasted a single day.

No gold having been withdrawn from the Treasury reserve yesterday, the bond syndicate did not have occasion to add anything to it. It stood, accordingly, at the close of business, at $102,500,000, which were the figures after Wednesday's withdrawals. Since rates for foreign exchange remain as of late, it is expected that gold will be taken to-day for to-morrow's steamers.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 15. -- The international golf tournament will be held at Niagaraon-the-Lake, Ontario, Sept. 5, 6, and 7. St. Andrew's Club of Yonkers, N.Y., the oldest golf organization in the United States, will send a team captained by H.O. Tallmadge, Secretary of the United States Golf Association. L. B. Stoddard, the United States amateur champion, will be a member of the team.
The Brooklyns braced up yesterday, turned the tables, on the Washingtons, and placed a victory to their credit.

For the third time since the opening of the Spring meeting at Aqueduct a dead heat was run at the new track yesterday. The race in which the judges were unable to separate the horses was the fourth event, a dash of five and one-half furlongs for two-yar-olds. Crimea, on her good performance on the preceding day, was an even-money favorite, with Yankee Doodle a heavily backed second choice.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- The fact that Frederick W. Smith of this city, member of the Democratic State Committee from Monroe County, did not attend the meeting of the committee in New-York to-day has occasioned considerable surprise and speculation in political circles.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 15. -- A big excursion of colored people went out from this city this morning over the Camden and Atlantic Railroad. The excursion carried 1,600 persons, men, women, and children, from the city to Lake Side Park. The excursion was run in two sections. The first left the city twenty minutes before the other.

The members of the excursion party of Consolidated Railroad Engineers and Conductors who participated in the annual outing to Noyes Beach, off Watch Hill, Sunday, have every reason to believe that Engineer Charles Beattie of the Old Colony Road was the victim of a man-eating shark.

Democrats who earnestly desire the election of the Democratic candidates for State offices in New-York this Fall will not be fully reassured by the resolution in respect to primaries adopted by the State Committee yesterday. Mr. Mack's resolution undoubtedly represents an advance in candor and fairness over the resolution adopted at the committee's meeting a year ago.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 15. -- In its weekly review of Southern business interests, The Manufacturers' Record reports continued activity in railroad and industrial affairs. Notwithstanding the fact that there are over 100 cotton mills under construction, or companies organized to build in the South, new companies are constantly being formed.

Daniel C. Toal, who was Secretary of the Commissioners of Charities in Brooklyn prior to the Gott-Nolan-Murphy administration, was again called as a witness before the Assembly committee in the Brooklyn City Courtroom yesterday.

Fulton Market contributed its choicest turtles and fish, and Washington its best fruits and vegetables, to make a success of the second breakfast and dinner of the season of '95 of that ancient organization, the Hoboken Turtle Club.

BOSTON, Aug. 15. -- George Robie of the firm of Crowell, Robie Co., wool brokers, 520 Atlantic Avenue, committed suicide yesterday, presumably to test theosophy, by drowning in the Calumet River, near Chicago. He was only twenty-four years old, and had lived for some time in this city prior to his departure for Chicago, two years ago.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15. -- The papers for the transfer of the Whisky Trust to the American Spirits Manufacturing Company are being drawn up to-day, and as soon as they are completed, the transfer will be made. This will probably require several days.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Aug. 15. -- Mrs. Abigail Tuthill Smith, ninety-six years old, who was well known as "Aunt Abby," and who is supposed to have been the oldest inhabitant of Long Island, died at the home of her daughter, Mrs. J. Smith, in this village, Wednesday night.

BERLIN, Aug. 15. -- The battlefields of Colombey-Neuilly and Noisseville, to the eastward of Metz, the scenes of the engagements between the Germans and French Aug. 14, Aug. 31, and Sept. 1, 1870, were to-day visited by German veterans, who deposited wreaths on the graves of the fallen soldiers, German and French alike.

OCEAN GROVE, Aug. 15. -- The Summer School of Theology met this morning and adjourned for the day. The lectures were delivered by the Rev. Dr. C.H. Snedeker of Newburg, N.Y., and the Rev. Dr. Milton S. Terry of Evanston, Ill. The subjects were, respectively, "The Philosophy of the Incarnation Idea," and "The Exposition of Visions Five to Nine and Crowning of the Priest."
BLUFF POINT, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- Among the arrivals at the Canoe Camp here to-day were the following:

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 15. -- Founder James A. Bradley owns the shore front of Asbury Park, and formulates rules for the government of those who frequent the beach and boardwalk. The beach at the foot of Deal Lake at the end of the boardwalk, is the favorite after-dark rendezvous for love-struck maidens and youths, and is crowded nightly with the young people from the hotels.

Two South Portland fishermen performed a feat on Saturday which illustrates the hardihood and perils of their life. Charles Orr and a companion were out on what is called Trinidad Shoal, about eight miles southeast of Cape Elizabeth. They were in a small Hampton fishing boat, but had with them a harpoon and the other tackle needed in case they should run across a swordfish.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 15. -- Championship tennis began in earnest in the final round of the Eastern doubles at the Casino here this morning. Wrenn and Chace met Howland and Foote and beat them, after a most exciting five-set match. The champion and his partner will meet the Neel brothers to-morrow morning for the right to play Hobart and Hovey at Newport next week for the National Championship Challenge Cups held by them.
FLUSHING, L.I., Aug. 15 -- The ceremony of conferring the white veil on five postulants and the black veil on seventeen novices was concluded to-day in St. Joseph's Academy.

Charles B. Burt, who represents himself as a lumber merchant, and who formerly lived in West One Hundred and Thirty-sixth Street, was arrested yesterday morning at 35 Broadway on a charge of swindling Maxwell Sommerville of 69 University Place out of two sets of the Encyclopaedia Britannica.

The efforts of a small boy to disinfect a flea-ridden dog has led to the discovery of a new use for the mineral water now being pumped from the artesian well in the rear of the Union Depot Railway Company's power house, at Geyer and Missouri Avenues. There lives not far from the power house a small boy who rejoices in the name of Jimmy, and also in the possession of a dog.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- After repeated postponements on account of rain, the Wayontha Bicycle Club happened upon delightful weather this afternoon for its annual races. The hotels and boarding houses were decorated with flags and bunting in honor of the occasion, and every one seemed to have the day picked out for a festival.

NEWPORT, Aug. 15. -- Newport to-night is crowded with visitors. At some of the cottages there are as many as a dozen guests, and none is without at least one visitor. The hotels are filled, and still every train is bringing additional people.

Edward Warren Ball, who escaped from Detective Sergeant Delahanty when the Fall River steamer Puritan bumped into the pier at Newport, Tuesday night, has been heard from. Detective Delahanty believed Ball had committed suicide.

The friends of Mr. Charles W. Reed, the artist at 12 West Street, are congratulating him on his receiving a medal of honor for most distinguished gallantry in action at the battle of Gettysburg, July 2, 1863.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 15. -- The resolution of the Street and Water Board awarding a water contract to the Jersey City company was to-night sent to the Board of Finance for its concurrence. The board declined to act except after due deliberation, and referred the matter to the Committee of the Whole.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- The First Assembly District Republican Convention, held here to-day, elected the following delegates to the State Convention: George B. Sloan, John T. Mott, N.N. Stranahan, P.W. Cullinan, T.D. Lewis, and F.M. Bread; alternates, H.A. Wilcox, Rufus Day, W.H.M. Lymond, J.F. Hopkins, H.F. Parsons, and Edward Ward.

The arrest at Lynn, Mass., of Gen. Michael D. Fitzgerald, late of the late Coxey Army, and his summary incarceration in an insane asylum, look a good deal like monopolistic persecution. Only two charges were made against the General -- that he took a bath at Lynn Beach, and that he regarded some original poems which he had in a valise as valuable documents.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- The State Department has received a report from Minister Terrell at Constantinople, dated July 25, relating to the Armenian revolutionists at Marsovan, which is of great interest in connection with the press telegram published yesterday about a riot at that place, in which some American missionaries are said to have been injured.

The prompt conviction of Dennis Mullins, in the Court of General Sessions, for a violation of the excise law, seems to have had a salutary effect already in blocking the scheme that was begun to choke the General Sessions Court calendar with excises cases transferred from the Special Sessions Court.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15. -- The dropping of the indictment against C. P. Huntington by the United States District Attorney has raised a storm of indignation among the railroad employes. Last night a number of local lodges of the American Railway Union passed resolutions denouncing the action of the Federal officers and decided to participate in a mass meeting called for Saturday night.

If the building mover who signs the contract to move Immanuel Baptist Church, Michigan Avenue, near Twenty-third Street, successfully performs the work he will have done one of the most remarkable feats of building moving ever known. The contract calls for the moving of the church in its entirety fifty feet south and nine feet east, and it is an undertaking well covered with risks.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- The statement published this morning that the State Controller was compelled to borrow $2,000,000 on the part of the State, was news about the State Departments other than the Controller's. Mr. Roberts denied that he had borrowed $2,000,000 to carry on the Government to Oct. 1, the beginning of the fiscal year.

I spoke one day to a very distinguished literary Frenchman about the character of the Paris daily press, and he admitted it was bad; "but," he said, "you should not consider the journals you have mentioned as national papers, you should rather take the Petit Journal as a better specimen, and certainly it has a larger circulation that, any other two journals put together."

The Welsh of the Peninsula (it is called the Lleyn, which means the Peninsula) do not pretend to have many graces of manner. The majority of them are much like those very ugly chapels of theirs -- Salems, Zoars, Morians, Jerusalems, Bethels, -- which stare with their rectangular or polygonal faces at the Saxon stranger as if they thoroughly resented his intrusion into their domain of influence.

LONDON, Aug. 15. -- The House of Commons met at 2 o'clock this afternoon, and was at once summoned by the Usher of the Black Rod to the House of Lords to hear the reading of the Queen's speech, which was as follows:

BALTIMORE, Aug. 15. -- Alexander Brown of Alexander Brown Sons, who formed the sub-syndicate in Baltimore to co-operate with the Belmont-Morgan syndicate in furnishing the gold with which to pay the Government for the last issue of bonds, commenting to-day on the gold exports, said:...

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 15. -- Henry A. Barclay and family, who have been spending the last few weeks at Bar Harbor, will return to Bonnie Brae to-morrow. Mr. Barclay has some fine horses with him this year, and will have out his four-in-hand frequently. Mrs. Barclay will give a large dance Sept. 6.

Lower Fulton Street, Brooklyn, is at present in a very disturbed condition on account of the repairs under way there which necessitate the stoppage of trolley traffic below the bridge. A mistaken impression prevails in the public mind that the City Works Department is at fault, and a great deal of complaint has been made by residents of the side streets in that vicinity.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Aug. 15. -- The spinners of the Armory-Langdon corporation have received a raise of 8 per cent. in wages. They say this is a restoration of the old scale of wages before the cut-down. The spinners had determined on a strike unless an increase was granted.

To understand the relation of Mussulman rule to religious and intellectual freedom, we must note the influence of the conquest of Persia on the Arab mind. When the invaders took the capital city of Khosru, they did not know the value of booty. Some offered to exchange gold for silver, and others mistook camphor for sulphur.
Commissioner Parker tried delinquent policemen at Police Headquarters yesterday. There were sixty-seven complaints on the calendar.

Louis Marshall of Guggenheimer, Untermyer Marshall yesterday made the first move for continuing the Whisky Trust litigation that was temporarily stopped last Tuesday, when Justice O'Brien of the Supreme Court refused the request of Mr. Marshall's clients for an injunction restraining the Reorganization Committee from buying in the trust properties at the receiver's sale in Chicago.

RICHMOND, Ind., Aug. 8. -- My attention has just been called to the following communication, which was published in The Chronicle some days ago, and which, I am informed, has since been quite extensively copied by the Eastern press:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15. -- The game between Philadelphia and New-York to-day became a comedy before it was half over, and the principal role in the travesty on the National sport was assumed by the visitors. The home team won easily, making it three straight. No less than fourteen men participated for Philadelphia, a half dozen of them being pitchers and catchers. New-York had eleven men on the field, all told.

MADRID, Aug. 15. -- The men of the Princess Marie Christina de Monteda Regiment who were drafted for service in Cuba, proceeded last evening for Cadiz, where 100,000 persons witnessed their departure for the island.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug. 15. -- The cottagers and hotel gUests are enjoying themselves hugely, driving, bicycling, and bathing forming the three principal features that go to make up the day's enjoyment.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 15. -- An alleged "wild man" was caught in the woods near Elmora this evening by Officers Tucker and Decker of this city. He gave his name as Harman Lauterbach, aged seventy-seven, and appears to be an escaped lunatic. He raves and talks incoherently most of the time.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- The Secretary of Agriculture issued to-day a circular on the imports and exports of the United States for 1893 and 1894. It shows that, notwithstanding the depression of business, exports from the United States in 1894 were valued at $889,843,000, against $847,685,194 in 1893. Three-fourths of the total value was in farm products.

The Republican County Committee will meet to-night to issue the call for the primaries. It is not at all probable that any action will be taken on the excise question. Some of the members of the committee would like very much to get into a discussion on the advisability of running a straight Republican ticket, but they most likely will not call it up to-night.

ALBANY, Aug. 15. -- Numerous letters and petitions, some sent by telegraph, continue to arrive at the Executive Chamber invoking the clemency of the Governor in behalf of Maria Barbella. Some of these requests are simply for merciful consideration, others are for commutation of sentence to life imprisonment, and still others for unconditional pardon.

BEAUFORT, S.C., Aug. 15. -- The first official test of the big Government dry dock on Paris Island, two miles below Port Royal, was made to-day. The United States monitor Amphitrite was successfully docked in the presence of the official board, consisting of Capt. W.C. Wise of the Amphitrite, Engineer P.C. Asserson, and Naval Constructor J.F. Hanscom. Several thousand spectators were present.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- The harness racers drew a very fair patronage this afternoon, the expected attraction being the 2:11 trot. In this Beuzetta, Klamath, and six other noted campaigners were named. Onoqua and Nightingale were scratched last night, but all the others were supposed to start.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15. -- The North Atlantic squadron sailed from here this forenoon. Its next port will be Bar Harbor.

CARY, N.C., Aug. 15. -- J.C. Sibley of Pennsylvania talked on silver to-day to about 2,000 persons. "We have nine million votes," he said, "but partisanship weakens our forces. We must win in 1896 or we never will win. If we fail then the future offers only repudiation or revolution."

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- Passed Fast -- Steam yacht Satanella, Perry Belmont; Golden Rod, A.C. Hoagland; Marguerite, Guy Loomis; Vision, F.H. Benedict, and Theresa, Gustavus: Sidenberg. Sloop yacht Fanny Thomas, P Fiske.
" What station was that?" demanded the passenger in the rear seat, suddenly rousing himself, straightening up, and projecting his voice through the dimly lighted car.
The excise law, as was stated in The New-York Times of last Monday, was frequently violated in Brooklyn last Sunday, and the locations of many of the places that were open were also pointed out.

The Shepard Democrats met last night in Brooklyn and outlined, to a certain extent, their policy during the coming campaigns. Edward M. Shepard enunciated the policy and stated that, while he and his party were anxious to secure harmony, they could not consent to join the Willoughby Street organization unless the latter body agreed to accept the policy and conditions of the Shepard Democracy.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- Before Assemblyman Abell's legislative sub-committee, investigating the administration of affairs in the Department of the Regents of the University, Prof. Hall, the State Geologist, testified that he was in no way responsible for the published charges against the Regents or Secretary Melvil Dewey.
PANAMA, via Galveston, Aug. 15. -- Guayaquil, Ecuador, reports a superb victory gained yesterday by the patriots at Gatazo.

Six steel steam barges left Lorain, Ohio, last Sunday morning at 8 o'clock on their way to New-York City. They were laden with steel rails, manufactured by the Johnson Company to the order of a Brooklyn street car company.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 15. -- The Masonic fraternity of this city will soon be quartered in the finest and most complete temple in the State, and the building, which is now nearly completed, will be a credit to the city and to the Masonic bodies under whose direction it has been erected. The building stands at the head of Broad Street, opposite City Hall, in as central a location as could have been found.
Owners of high buildings in this city are beginning to lease or purchase adjoining properties in order to preserve for their tall structures the benefits of unimpeded air and light.

Before the "short campaign" proposed by some anxious Republicans for this Stare has advanced much further toward its close it is apparent that the Republican managers will find it difficult to avoid answering inquiries about the increase of 50 per cent. in the amount of State taxes over the tax of 1894.

The whole story of a mysterious story is told in the following note from Miss Perry. The case is, as Miss Perry says, a warning to literary people not to tell their stories by word of mouth if they want to print 'em:

President Theodore Roosevelt of the Police Board received a rousing ovation last night at a mass meeting of the members of the Charles Marks Republican Club, in their rooms, One Hundred and Seventh Street and Lexington Avenue. So eager to hear the Commissioner was the audience that it became demonstrative, and was only quieted down by the words of Charles B. Robinson, a prominent Republican of the Thirty-second District.

The Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott arrived from Europe on the steamship Spree Wednesday night, and yesterday morning started for his country home at Cornwall-on-the-Hudson. Speaking of his trip, Dr. Abbott said he had been greatly benefited by it. He sailed for Europe July 2. He staid ten days in London, and then spent a week in the Isle of Wight, which he considers a good place of rest for a tired man.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The conference of free-silver Democrats ended to-day without having accomplished results half so important as its friends had expected. A plan of organization was adopted and an address issued.

About five years ago a Mrs. Buzzard, residing on Maplewood Avenue, Germantown, purchased a second-hand piano on the installment plan from a firm on Chestnut Street. The cost of the piano was to be $250, and by agreement was to be paid for in monthly or quarterly payments, with a verbal understanding that the instrument should be kept in tune free of charge for the space of one year.

The Giglio brothers, who own the fishing boat Salvator, had a lively tussle with a big devilfish off the Farallone Islands last Tuesday. They crippled the monster at last and stuck him with a knife. Now what is left of him is hanging in front of the fish market on Merchant Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- By aiding and abetting three stowaways in their efforts to defeat the purpose of the immigration laws of this country, the British ship Kanawa, plying between Liverpool and Newport News, Va., has got into trouble, and at present is in a fair way to be mulcted in the sum of $600.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Aug. 15. -- A dishonorable discharge will be issued by Capt. Waring of the Fifteenth Separate Company, under directions of the State authorities, to Ferdinand Roesch, a private of the Fifteenth Separate Company, who was found guilty by court-martial of non-attendance at drills and fined $10, which he refused to pay, alleging that he was a native of Germany and not eligible to membership in or amenable to the rules of the National Guard.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 15. -- Jersey's Junior American Mechanics and their friends to the number of 13,000 came here to-day for their annual field day exercises and to celebrate American Day. Nineteen special trains transported the patriots. The town was gayly decorated, and the Ocean Grove authorities let down the bars and threw that religious resort open to the wearers of the red, white, and blue.

The Metropolitan Street Railway Company and the Third Avenue Railroad Company were given another hearing yesterday by the Railway Committee of the Board of Aldermen on their applications for consent to extend their cable lines over the King's Bridge Road.

Coroner Fitzpatrick and a number of experts visited the ruins of the Ireland Building at West Broadway and West Third Street yesterday and examined the soil under the foundations of the central pillar that was driven into the ground. Their investigation was not final, but it seemed to dispose of the quicksand theory.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 15. -- The annual bachelors' ball was given this evening at the Kebo Valley Club. It was a most enjoyable affair. The clubhouse was decorated artistically with hanging Oriental rugs, draperies, and placques. From the long windows floated silk gauzes, and the staircases were crowded with broad-leafed rubber plants.

The South and the West are both in the field for capital wherewith to develop their splendid natural resources. Capital is proverbially timid. Owing to exceptional circumstances the South is at a great disadvantage as compared with the West in overcoming this timidity. Two years ago there was a World's Fair at the West.

There has been much misrepresentation about the manner in which the act of 1873 was passed, and although the statements that the act was surreptitiously passed had been many times disproved, it is continually reiterated by the advocates of free coinage at a ratio of 16 to 1, and incorporated in the platforms (?) of the different State Silver Conventions.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., Aug. 15. -- The Republicans of Maryland to-day dodged the currency question with a cowardice that would have done credit to Harrison, Reed, or McKinley. The platform has not a word to say on the subject, furnishing in this respect a marked contrast to the utterance of the Democratic Convention, which pledged the party in unequivocal terms to sound money.

LONDON, Aug. 15. -- The Speaker read the Queen's speech in the House. Mr. Gavin Brown Clark (Radical) raised an objection to the passage referring to outrages on English missionaries, who, he said, were really Scotch and Irish.

The visitor to the London courts will not be impressed by any splendor of surroundings nor by any great dignity of proceedings. Entering the High Courts of Justice on the Strand the stranger must ascend a steep flight of circular stairs leading to long and dark corridors which open into small galleries in the rear of the courtrooms.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 16. -- The most elaborate production of Handel's oratorio of "The Messiah" ever seen in this country was given here this evening under the auspices of the Summer School of Theology.

George Comley, of the South Side, claims to have made the remarkable discovery. He is a steel worker, and says he ran across the secret while experimenting some months ago. Con Shay, formerly a steel worker, now one of the city's "finest," and John Ryan of the Keystone Rolling Mill, are helping Comley out in his schemes.
Howard P. Okie waxed exceedingly angry yesterday in a discussion before Recorder Goff, but his anger did him no good.

SARATOGA, Aug. 16. -- "Famous Men at Famous Dinners" was the subject of the lecture delivered this morning by William H. McElroy of New-York City. It concluded his series in the Saratoga Summer lectures. Prof. G. Frederick Wright of Oberlin College will be the lecturer next week.

Clinton Felder, special agent for the Cotton States and International Exposition, to be held at Atlanta, Ga., next Fall, is at the Gilsey House, where the New-York State Commission for the Exposition has its headquarters.

LONDON, Aug. 16. -- The House debated the address in reply to the Queen's speech. The amendment made last night by Mr. John Dillon to the amendment proposed by Mr. William Redmond was rejected by a vote of 257 to 123.

Courts-of-inquiry indications, like signs in dry weather, frequently fail. It was thought yesterday and the day before that the Forney court of inquiry, now in session at the New-York Navy Yard, would have finished its labors on those respective days; but new witnesses were introduced by the prosecution and new testimony brought forward by Lawyer Stayton in rebuttal, and so the case has dragged to an unexpected length.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- An unofficial statement has been received at the Navy Department denying the report telegraphed from San Diego to the effect that the Ward boilers of the monitor Monterey had "played out" on her trip home, and that the vessel had been reduced to the use of the Scotch boilers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16. -- As seemed inevitable, the General Passenger Agents of Western and other lines who have so long been unsuccessfully trying to form an association for the preservation of rates have at length referred the whole matter to the executive officers of their roads. This action was taken after an all-day meeting to-day. The proposition of forming an association from the Eastern gateways to and including Colorado common points was first taken up.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- At the third conference between the Madison and Oswego County Republicans held to-day to agree upon a basis of representation for the Senatorial Convention, the Madison County people weakened after a good fight and an agreement was reached by which Oswego County will have twelve delegates in the convention, and Madison County nine.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Aug. 16. -- The officials of the University of Pennsylvania were much surprised this morning when they read in the papers the allegation that the university had been duped into paying $15,000 for a collection of geological specimens belonging to the State of New-York.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 16. -- A plan for a wholesale delivery of prisoners from the county jail here was accidentally discovered yesterday afternoon. The leaders in the plot were Thomas Kelley, a burglar, and Michael F. Barry, who is awaiting trial for arson in this city. Everything was in readiness, and the men were to break jail to-morrow night, but one of the inmates weakened and informed the Sheriff.

The Tammany organization undoubtedly expects to participate in the approaching campaign and election. That has been made plain enough by the talk preceding and following the recent reorganization meeting. The leading men indulge in expressions of confidence that Tammany will contribute its share of assistance in securing a return of Democratic control in the city and the State.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16. -- The one thing that was needed to insure the success of the recently completed arrangements for the international cricket matches in Philadelphia this Fall was supplied to-day, when the management of the Germantown Cricket Club received a cablegram from Mr. Kenneth McAlpin, in which the latter expressed his willingness to cancel his engagement to bring a team to this city in September.

Attention was called in these columns a few days ago to the important part played by the bicycle in one of the contests during the late general election. In France, where the cycling fever rages even more fiercely than in this country, there is not a constituency where cyclists were not employed in the recent Councils General elections.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- Senor Zeballos, the Argentine Minister, is not in Washington and there is nobody connected with the Legation who can give any information with regard to the cable dispatch from Buenos Ayres announcing his resignation.
LONDON, Aug. 16. -- The Daily Telegraph to-morrow will announce that Gen. Sir Garnet Wolseley will succeed the Duke of Cambridge as Commander in Chief of the British Army, with limited powers.
That merry band of saloon keepers who have looked upon the excise law as a huge farce, and Mr. Roosevelt's enforcement of it as particularly humorous, do not now feel as gay as they did.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 16. -- The New-York and New-Jersey Telephone Company is about to make use of the bicycle as an aid to promote more rapid and economical work in the inspection and repair of its lines. A meeting of the different managers of the company was held in Brooklyn yesterday, and it was decided after next Monday to provide all inspectors and linemen with bicycles.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Aug. 16. -- Samuel L. Clemens, (Mark Twain,) who is about leaving for Australia, made a signed statement to-day concerning the purposes of his long trip and his business troubles, in part, as follows:

Warden Hayes of the Kings County Penitentiary received eight United States prisoners Thursday. Among them was Victor L. Ochoa, thirty years old, who is sentenced to two years and a half imprisonment for leading a military expedition against the Republic of Mexico.

Though the races at Aqueduct yesterday failed to bring about any close or exciting finishes, there was abundance of excitement for the crowd. The first race was run off twice, the favorite for the fifth event was disqualified for fouling, and Captain T., notwithstanding he seems to never have a liking for short odds, was the only favorite to reward his backers.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 16. -- For several weeks society here has been awaiting the arrival of the North Atlantic squadron, and was delighted to-day when the United States dispatch boat Dolphin, Capt. Buckingham, cast anchor in the harbor. She could not have asked for a heartier welcome. The whole fleet, consisting of the New-York, Montgomery, Minneapolis, and Raleigh, left Newport Thursday, and will arrive at Bar Harbor Monday morning.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 16. -- Wrenn and Chace beat the Neel brothers here this morning, after an exciting four-set match, and thus earned the right to challenge Hobart and Hovey for the National lawn tennis championship in doubles. An enormous crowd surrounded the Casino court to see the great match between the Eastern and the Western champion teams, and they were not disappointed, for a great match was the result of the encounter.

Mrs. Sarah M. Kopperman, thirty-nine years old, wife of M.M. Kopperman, a shoe manufacturer of 746 Flushing Avenue, Brooklyn, created a scene yesterday afternoon in the store of Louis Schaehne Brother, 10 Walker Street. She says the Schaehnes are her cousins.
LIMA, Peru, via Galveston, Aug. 16. -- The Chamber of Deputies verified to-day the returns of the elections, passed upon the credentials of the new members, and approved them.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Aug. 16. -- Consul General Williams has informed the State Department that the General Government has issued a circular to the principal Governors of the Island of Cuba prohibiting the hoisting of any foreign flag on private buildings, commercial establishments, and theatres, without previous authorization.

ROME, Aug. 16. -- The people of Ancona, a city of Central Italy, about 200 miles northeast of Rome, were thrown into a panic to-day by the explosion of a bomb on the stairway leading to the French Consulate.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- The morning exercises were devoted to the young people to-day. They attended in a body the closing and public session of the Young Men's Congress, presided over by George O. Reddington of Yale.

Ex-Gov. Flower's recent prediction that the Democrats will carry this State this Fall is being generally reproduced throughout the State, accompanied by the approving comment of Democratic editors. The ex-Governor's remarks appear to find the columns of the Republican papers too much crowded with reports of factional disturbances and bitter comment thereon to permit of the publication of Mr. Flower's opinions.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- The attendance to-day was large, the weather warm and clear, and the track fast. In the Merchants' Stakes, one mile and a furlong, Clifford met his Waterloo. Rey el Santa Anita not only beat him, but at the end was under a pull, while Griffin was whipping and spurring Clifford with his utmost energy.

The sentence of Dennis Mullins to imprisonment and fine for violation of the excise law should be taken as a warning by the liquor dealers of this city that the prohibition of Sunday selling in saloons is going to be rigorously enforced. They will gain nothing by insisting upon being indicted and tried by juries in the Court of General Sessions.

Here is the latest addition to the store of "traveling Emperor ovations." It comes from Stockholm. On the day on which the German Emperor paid a visit to Count and Countess Wedel at their castle Stora Sundby, the band of his yacht Hohenzollern had received permission to give a concert at the famous Hasselbacken restaurant.

The death of Mr. Samuel D. Thompson, which occurred at North Conway, N.H., on Wednesday, Aug. 7, brings up a flood of recollections of the early days of the White Mountain hotel business, with which he was long and intimately connected.

There is such an air of melancholy earnestness about the formal utterance of the "Democratic" silver conference in Washington that one has not the heart to treat it lightly. One ought rather to commiserate the venerable Senator Harris of Tennessee and his sad-eyed associates on the poor prospects of the undertaking they have voluntarily assumed of steering the Democratic Party of the Nation into the camp of the Populists.
John Blakely, proprietor of a cafe at 233 Broadway, and one of the best-known characters in the lower part of the city, died yesterday after an illness of a few hours.

After the famous Palmer poisoning case, the inhabitants of Rugeley waited on Lord Palmerston and begged him to sanction a change of name. "What do you suggest?" asked the genial Prime Minister. As the applicants failed to propound anything reasonable, the great Pam cheerfully added, "You can name it after me, if you like."

The Republicans in this city are varying the monotony of the hot weather by warmly discussing whether they shall run a straight ticket this Fall. The Republican County Committee met at its headquarters, in West Thirty-eighth Street, near Broadway, last night, but it was a special meeting called for the purpose of issuing the call for the primaries and to declare where and when the various conventions shall be held.

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- Samuel Acker, who lived with his brother about three miles from this village, was found dead in his barn this evening. There was a hole in his head, caused by the charge from a shotgun which lay broken in pieces beside him. On the floor, a few feet away from the body of Samuel lay William, his brother.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- A bicycle race meet was held here to-day at Rensselaer Park, under the auspices of the Troy Bicycle Club. There were about 1,500 persons present. There were several spills. W.J. Ainsworth of Albany fell in the half-mile open event and was run into by H.B. Mosher of Storm King, and Lewis L. Draper of Lansingburg. Ainsworth's left hand was ripped open, and Mosher's wheel was broken.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 16. -- It was very hot here to-day from early in the morning through the entire day. The mercury was as high as 85 in the shade, and there was little sea breeze.

We all know of the agricultural decline in England, and how the year 1877 marked the beginning of that collapse. Rents of land owners and profits of farmers have been "generally and largely reduced," and, above all, the wages of the rural laborers have made less advance than those of the lowest-paid town laborers."

BUFFALO N.Y., Aug. 16. -- Since the Grand Circuit meeting began here nine days ago the conditions for fast performances were never so favorable as this afternoon. The track was at its best, and the weather just warm enough to suit the horses, yet no effort was made to overtake any of the delayed programme, only two classes being on the card.

ALBANY, Aug. 16. -- Three of the public buildings in Albany owned and maintained by the State of New-York are used for public offices. These are the old State Hall, known in late years as Geological and Agricultural Hall, built in 1798-9; the new State Hall, erected in 1840-42, and the new Capitol, begun July 7, 1869, and to-day within $2,000,000 of completion.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16. -- The drawings for the national championship tennis tournament were given out this afternoon. The double championship game has been arranged for Tuesday next. The preliminary list is the largest on record for this association. It follows:

We republish in another column an editorial article from The New-York Times of this morning earnestly urging the Democrats of this city and New-York to get together with a view to sending harmonious delegations to the State Convention. The point of The Times is that the Democrats of the respective cities should by voluntary action at home relieve the convention from the unpleasant duty of passing upon the rival claims of regulars and independents.

ALBANY, Aug. 16. -- The Kings, Queens and Suffolk Railroad Company was incorporated to-day, to construct a narrow-gauge railroad about nine miles in length, with termini at the westerly line of the town of Jamaica, and in the village of Far Rockaway. The capital is $350,000, and the Directors are Carl Frederick Wilhelm Bodecker of New-York City, Frederick Fitter of Brooklyn, John N. Williamson of Ozone Park, George Pitkin Bergen of Freeport, and twenty-six others.

Consul General Li Yung Yen awoke yesterday morning to find himself in a worse predicament than for some time. Ever since the murder of Chang Yai, Li Yung Yen has shown a desire to have Mock Tai, the man accused of the murder, convicted, and, by doing so, has incurred the enmity of the See Yups, to which company Mock Tai belonged.

BEAUFORT, S.C., Aug. 16. -- The second test of the Port Royal dry dock was made this morning. The Amphitrite was left standing on the forward blocks until 1 o'clock, when the dock was again flooded until she floated free.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- The convention of Afro-Americans of the State to organize a Republican League opened in the Town Hall at noon to-day. C.W. Anderson of Albany, private secretary to State Treasurer Addison B. Colvin, called the convention to order. T. Thomas Fortune of New-York was chosen Temporary Chairman.

There was amazement combined with a little anger in the Department of Charities and Correction yesterday, concerning the publication by a trade paper of a statement that "the purchasing agent of the department had been removed and his place conferred upon a lawyer than whom it would be difficult to find one more unsuited to the duties."

SWINEFIELD BRIDGE, N.J., Aug. 16. -- Politicians' day at the grangers' picnic here did not come up to expectation. There was a big crowd present, but the only men mentioned in connection with the nomination for Governor were Augustus Cutler of Morristown and Elias Ward of Newark. John Kean was to have been present, but he had to attend a funeral.
Painters, carpenters, electricians, engineers, and scrubbers are at present making a very animated place of the Capitol.

Daniel C. Toal, who was Secretary of the Department of Charities in Kings County during the Gott-Nolan-Murphy administration, was again in the witness stand yesterday before the Assembly committee in the Brooklyn City Courtroom. He testified that he believed there was collusion in the awarding of contracts for county supplies.
Commissioner Waring has removed H.C. Corsa, a District Superintendent in the Street Cleaning Department, and Mr. Corsa says his dismissal was something past understanding.

Numerous inquiries have been received from Europe recently by Secretary George Wilson of the Chamber of Commerce concerning notices published in many of the German, French, Swiss, Austrian, and Hungarian papers, warning bookkeepers and others engaged in commercial pursuits against coming to America without first having obtained positions.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16. -- The murder of Lunatic George Pucik, at the County Insane Asylum, for which crime the attendants, George Gough and John P. Anderson, were to-day held to the Grand Jury without the option of bail, has brought to the light of investigation three cases which are said by the relatives of the victims to be similar to the Pucik horror.

PANAMA, via Galveston, Aug. 16. -- Gen. Eloy Alfaro personally addresses The New-York Times from Riobamba, Ecuador, in confirmation of the reports of the complete victory of his army over that of the Quito General, Sarasti.

CLAYTON, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- At Alexandria Bay to-night officials representing New-York State and officials from Canada met in conference to arrange the details in connection with the project for an international park at the Thousand Islands.

BERLIN, Aug. 16. -- The aniversary of the battle of Rezonville, during which several sanguinary cavalry engagements took place at Mars-la-Tour, was celebrated to-day by the First Dragoon Guards Regiment, which made a famous charge in that battle.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16. -- The Myopia polo team of Boston won the Newport Cups for teams of four this afternoon, defeating the Newports in a rattling game in the finals. By the official handicap the Myopias were allowed four goals, but they didn't need them, carrying off the cups on the result of the actual play. The teams, with positions and individual handicaps, were as follows:

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Aug. 16. -- The United States revenue cutter Grant has arrived at Sitka, Alaska, with mail from the patrol fleet in Bering Sea upto July 13. On board the Grant was Gov. Sheakley of Alaska, who took passage from Unalaska.

The Defender and Vigilant were admired by hundreds of yachtsmen and thousands of others who are interested in the coming international races as they stood in the dry dock in the Erie Basin yesterday. Both yachts were put in Dock 1, and there was an excellent opportunity to compare the two models.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- Gov. E.N. Morrill of Kansas is at the cottage of ex-Congressman Baker, at Charlotte, spending a few days with his old friend. The Governor is not averse to talking politics. When a reporter asked him, "Who is the favorite Republican for the Presidential nomination in Kansas?" he answered promptly:
At the meeting of the Police Board yesterday, on the recommendation of Col. Grant, the following was adopted:

The population of the Polish capital increases at the rate of about 20,000 souls a year. The annual census recently taken gives a total of 571,300, showing an increase of 20,314 during the twelve months. The Orthodox Russians form a comparatively small element of the whole population, numbering only 20,871, or very little more than the foreign residents, who are reckoned at 18,000.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. M. Orme Wilson returned to Lenox to-day after a trip to Newport and Bar Harbor, and will remain here for the rest of the season. They will entertain considerably.

Many persons who are deeply interested in the approaching contest for the America's Cup are needlessly alarmed by the fact that the Defender is not a centreboard yacht. The centreboard is in the minds of these persons a Yankee invention that in some mysterious way makes a yacht go faster and hence imposes defeat on Great Britain, the would-be haughty ruler of the seas.

Much speculation is afloat as to what is going to happen to that brilliant and accomplished advocate, Sir Edward Clarke. It is said that he is going to be made Master of the Rolls, and it is certain that as soon as Lord Esher has passed his seventieth birthday on the bench, which will happen this month, the veteran Judge will retire.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16. -- Mrs. August Belmont was out on the drive to-day and at the polo grounds with her French postilion turnout, the first ever seen in Newport. Two horses are attached to a low phaeton-shaped vehicle, and a rider seated on one of the animals drives both, while the occupants of the vehicle sit back and view the scenery.

An inquest on the bodies of the sixteen men who were killed by the collapse on Aug. 8 of the eight-story Ireland Building at West Broadway and West Third Street was begun yesterday by Coroner Fitzpatrick and a jury of nine architects and builders.

The statement made by Detective Sergeant Delahanty of the Bureau of Criminal Investigation and Information, Brooklyn, that his prisoner, Edward W. Ball, escaped from him on the Fall River steamboat Puritan Tuesday night, when the steamboat was in collision with the pier at Newport, has been denied by the officers of the vessel. Capt. Baylies Davis of the Puritan said yesterday:

The body found in the Hudson River at the foot of West One Hundred and Eighty-sixth Street early Thursday morning was identified yesterday as that of Gustav G. Kratz, a wealthy retired business man. The identification was made by William A. Smith of 59 Convent Avenue, with whom Mr. Kratz had lived for a number of years.
VOORHEESVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- The Prohibitionists of Albany County have nominated H.W. Elmendorf for Senator in the Twenty-ninth District.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- Matt W. Ransom of North Carolina is no longer Minister from the United States to Mexico. That office was practically declared vacant to-day, by a decision rendered by Holmes Conrad, Solicitor General of the United States and Acting Attorney General.

MARINETTE, Wis., Aug. 16. -- Favorites were bowled over in the races in this city to-day. It was the first day of the annual meet of the Wisconsin Division of the League of American Wheelmen. The track was fast and there was little or no wind to interfere with the riders.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Aug. 16. -- The ball nine again covered themselves with dust and glory this afternoon in beating a picked team from Norwich, three to two, in a very exciting game. The visiting club was made up of Develin, the old National League pitcher, and players selected from various nines of the defunct State League.

Some ten years ago a builder named Buddensiek was very deservedly sent to Sing Sing for the crime of putting up buildings too cheaply, more cheaply than they could be put up with a decent regard to the lives of those who were employed to erect them or were doomed to inhabit them.
SARATOGA, Aug. 17. -- An excellent card, with several good things, brought out a very good attendance at the Saratoga track to-day. The day was fair and the track fast.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 17. PICTURESQUE Hempstead is thronged with a large number of Summer residents and boarders. Bicycling, boating, and an early morning gallop across the Hempstead Plains to the Wheatley Hills form the principal amusements for the colony summering in this vicinity.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 17. -- Albert Ross Parsons, the nineteen-year-old son of H.S. Parsons of Garden City, L.I., was drowned about 5 o'clock this afternoon while bathing. About three hundred persons were on the beach, and about fifty other bathers were in the water at the time, but no one seems to have seen the young man sink.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 17. -- Charles J. Fredrickson, a saloon keeper of 431 Clinton Avenue, and his son caught one out of a gang of four burglars last night, and succeeded in shooting another, who escaped. Three places on Clinton Avenue were entered last night. One of these was Fredrickson's.

" On my first visit to England," says a man who is a persistent traveler, "I was given letters of introduction to a family living in the suburbs of Liverpool, which, on the day following my arrival in that city, I took occasion to present. I found the family, which consisted of a mother, her two daughters, and a young lady friend, most charming.

Although no sales of importance have been made public during the past week, it is known that several were made, one of them involving about $700,000, which the parties concerned deem it right to withhold for the time being. The continuance of the extremely hot weather has delayed the negotiations in some other transactions.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Aug. 17. -- Preparations are being made for the erection of a magnificent new hotel here. It will probably be built on the site now occupied by the Homestead Hotel. Ground will be broken early in September. For the last two weeks Mr. Fred Sterry, the manager, has been busily engaged consulting the architects.

CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 17. MOST important of the week's events was the East Bay Yacht Club ball last evening. It was a brilliant gathering. Everybody was there and had a good time, and the ball far surpassed last year's event.

MARINETTE, Wis., Aug. 17. -- The second day of the National Circuit race meeting of the Marinette Cycling Club provided some of the most exciting racing of the season. Cabanne made one of the greatest finishes ever seen, when he won the second mile open race on to-day's programme in 2:11. Cooper had won the first in 2:08, in State competition record time.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 17. ONE of the enjoyable events of the week was the excursion of the members of the Sunday school of the Watsessing Methodist Episcopal Church to Iona Island.

SHELTER ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 17. AUGUST has always been the best month of the Summer season at Shelter Island, and this year is no exception. The hotels have been filled to overflowing this week, and everything seems to indicate that they will remain so during the month. The cottages, too, are taxed to their utmost capacity.

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- The Sing Sing Methodist Episcopal camp meeting had its average number of attendants to-day, and a cool and refreshing breeze whistled through the big trees on the heights, while down in the village it was suffocatingly hot.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- With the exception of a hard shower, accompanied by thunder and lightning early in the week, the weather has been all that could be desired. The number of arrivals at the hotels has been far in excess of the preceding week.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 17. -- GOLF is becoming a universal sport here this season. There are quite as many devotees among the women as among the men, and scores of both sexes are occupying Newport links, pegging away at the little ball from 9 A.M. to quite sundown.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 17. As the end of the season draws near, social events continue to be more numerous, and the remaining few weeks will be crowded with pleasure. The beautiful tabieaus which were arranged Saturday evening by William M. Chase and J. Lawrence Breese, are still being praised. The title chosen was "An Evening with the Old Masters and Modern Painters."
OGUNQUIT, Me., Aug. 17. -- "Seems though things is gittin' a leetle onsartain agin', Silas," remarked Uncle Enoch Applebee to his old friend, Mr. Larrabee.

There are voices in the air that tell great tales of things to come early in the dramatic season of 1895-6. Theatrical activity is already beginning. We are actually to have two brand-new plays to-morrow night, one of them a comedy by a new author, with the promising title of "Other People's Money."

OLD ORCHARD CAMPGROUND, Me., Aug. 17. -- There never was a week of excitement like the past one since the Old Orchard Campground was purchased and occupied, twenty-three years ago, by the Methodist Episcopal Church of the State of Maine. People from San Francisco jostle against people from Canada, and every State in the Union is fully represented by officers of the Salvation Army from all sections of the country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- Commodore Selfridge, Naval Constructor Bowles, and Chief Engineer Farmer, the special board appointed to examine the hull of the cruiser Columbia, at the New-York Navy Yard, to determine the extent of damages she sustained by being docked at Southampton, has reported to the Navy Department. The board says:

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 17. -- By a score of 9 to 7 3/4 the Country Club of Westchester beat the Myopia team of Boston to-day, thus winning the Westchester individual cups for teams of four. It was a victory on the handicap, but nevertheless well earned. The teams, with position and individual handicaps, were as follows:

Kiretchjian, an Armenian graduate from Robert College, delegate to the World's Parliament of Religions in Chicago, and an eloquent orator who has been heard from many platforms in behalf of his unfortunate country.

War destroys, and at the same time is the incentive for the creation of new things. War and iron are inseparably linked together. The discovery of gunpowder caused a complete revolution in the manufacture of iron. The mixing of sulphur, saltpetre, and coal as a toy had been known for a long time.

SHELTER ISLAND HEIGHTS, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- The third club special race of the Shelter Island Yacht Club was sailed here this afternoon. More boats contested in to-day's race than have been entered for any previous race this season. The race was sailed over the usual twelve-mile course from the clubhouse to Greenport, to East Marion and Hay Beach Point, and down to the clubhouse, repeating the course.

HOTEL CHAMPLAIN, Clinton County, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- A stiff wind blew all day long from the southeast, and the sailing men in the camp of the American Canoe Association here, who were anxious to spend the day sailing over the course, were compelled to remain ashore. One or two went out with small rigs, but broke down before going very far.

The liquor dealers and saloon keepers of this city have been acting upon very bad legal and political advice in resisting the enforcement of the provision of the excise law against Sunday selling. They are thereby making the wrong issue before the people, one upon which they are sure to fail, while they are endangering the issue of more liberal legislation, which is the one that ought to be made.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- The forestry exhibit at the Atlanta Exposition promises to be the most complete and instructive ever made by a Government, excelling in excellence, though not in size, the exhibit at Chicago in 1893. The exhibits are now being shipped and the work of installation will proceed as rapidly as they arrive at Atlanta.

BOSTON, Aug. 17. -- Monday, Sept. 2, the 4,000 coatmakers of this city will demand of the 100 clothing contractors by whom they are employed the signing of an agreement regulating the hours of labor, wages, and other conditions for one year. If the contractors refuse to sign the agreement, the men and women will strike, and they say they will not return to work until their demands have been acceded to.
When Sanitary Inspector Frederick Springer strolled into the office of the Board of Health yesterday, President Charles G. Wilson asked him:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- A well-known army officer, recently promoted, promises to furnish an interesting case when the papers, now in the hands of the department commander, reach the War Department.

We had to make our way through a crowd occupying a large room or small hall in which business was conducted. This hall was filled with people, some of whom were there to look after their own or other people's affairs, and others of whom had obviously dropped in for a casual chat. Almost all were smoking cigarettes, an amusement which they shared with a good many of the bank clerks.

The Board of Health has a puzzling question to decide. Police Captain Pickett sent to it yesterday the body of a dog that had bitten two persons before it was finally killed, and asked it to determine whether the dog had been mad.

As far as the crack tennis players are concerned, this week -- championship week, as it is usually called -- is the wind-up of the tennis season. The contests at Narragansett Pier last week showed that the ranked men are in earnest, as only those who were interested in doubles did any playing at all.

ALBANY, Aug. 17. -- Secretary Smith of the new Capitol Commission one day this week gave his messenger, whom he styles his confidential clerk, an order for his pay on "Verplanck Colvin, State Treasurer." In the first place, Verplanck Colvin is Superintendent of the Adirondack Survey, and, in the second place, demands for pay must be made on the State Controller.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- The Surgeon General of the army will not make the recommendation that the former strength of the Medical Corps be restored.

Machines for transferring coal from cars to vessels more rapidly than can be done by any of the old processes are now receiving a great deal of attention at Lake Erie ports, and three new machines are soon to be put in operation at Cleveland. One of these is for the Erie Coal Transfer Company, and is on the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio dock.
ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 17. -- The members of St. John's Roman Catholic Church will enjoy their annual excursion to Laurelton Grove on Long Island Sound Wednesday.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 17. -- The regular Saturday evening dinner and dance at the Kebo proved, as usual, to be quite an enjoyable affair. After such a gay week, witnessing as it did three large balls and a host of smaller functions, a rather small attendance was looked for to-night, but society turned out in full force, especially the young people.

No doubt a great many people have noticed the recent extensively published criticisms of what is denominated by them the "crying scandal of the day," namely, the brewing of beer and the sale of the same by the Catholic monks of the famous Abbey of St. Vincent, in the County of Westmoreland, Penn.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- The decision of Solicitor General Conrad that Mr. Ransom's appointment as Minister to Mexico was unconstitutional may give rise to some curious complications. Mr. Ransom was appointed on Feb. 23, to fill a vacancy created by the death of Minister Gray on Feb. 14.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 17. -- Police and tramps had a desperate and bloody encounter in the stockyards district of East Toledo this morning. At 8 o'clock, Patrolman Steve Shafer came upon a party of tramps lounging under the Oak Street Bridge. He ordered them to disperse. Without warning, James Smith, one of the tramps, fired at the officer.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- LIVELY tennis playing characterized the tournament held here this week. It was pre-eminently the events of the last seven days.

BOSTON, Aug. 17. -- The reasons which induced ex-President Hudson of Chelsea to withdraw from the membership of the A.P.A. are now made public. Mr. Hudson was one of the most active persons in the order. He says:

North-Siders have no excuse now for wearing soiled linen. A complication of rates and cuts has brought the price of laundering a shirt -- plain, fancy, or neglige -- down from the prevailing prices of 10 and 15 cents to 4 cents a shirt. Collars, cuffs, and underwear have taken a corresponding drop.
Ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt and Mrs. Hewitt arrived in this city yesterday from Europe on the steamship Etruria.

LAKE RONKONKOMA, L.I., Aug. 17. IT IS the unwritten but strictly enforced law of this resort that everybody, young and old, must participate in every form of enjoyment suggested for their entertainment. So severe and lasting is the punishment for derelictions that there have been very few violations, even on Sundays.

We have just had a remarkable lesson in the eagerness which seems to be felt by States which are almost impotent for the orderly management of their own most important domestic affairs, to exclude other States, however distant and peaceful, from the possession of a single square mile of barren and miserable rock which might seem to be within the radius of their dominion.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 17. -- Rough water proved the only obstacle to the success of the Bayonne Rowing Association's eighteenth annual regatta held on the usually protected Bayonne cove of New-York Bay this afternoon. Only club members competed. Several hundred spectators enjoyed the races. Well-trained crews made close contests and interesting finishes.

In the absence of anything better to talk about, Wall Street has been worrying over the moderate exports of gold which are being made at this time, and, with a blind disregard of the fact that an outward movement of the metal just prior to crop reports comes as regularly as the Summer season, has attached undue importance to the incident.

The Seidl Society concerts at the Brighton Beach Music Hall are drawing to a close, this being the seventh week of the season. The society will give on Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday a grand Beethoven and Wagner festival, with seven soloists. Selections from "Egmont," "Fidelio," "Die Meistersinger," "Die Walkure," and four Wagner songs are the chief vocal features.

The keepers of French restaurants and of other restaurants where it is the custom to serve wines with meals need have no fear of police intrusion to-day as long as they confine the sale of wine to bona fide customers.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 17. MIDSUMMER finds no let up in the gayety here. The warm weather has increased the daily number of arrivals, and many new faces are seen on hotel plazzas and beach. Amityville is always sure of a satisfactory season, and each year finds it more popular with pleasure seekers.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 17. -- Cuyahoga County is entitled to 59 votes in the Democratic State Convention at Springfield. Twice that number will apply for admission Tuesday as a result of the exciting convention held here to-day at which the Brice men revolted against the action of their opponents, and set up a convention of their own.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Aug. 17. -- The Girard College Cadet Corps, numbering nearly 600, with a band of thirty pieces, will go into camp at Beaumont next Thursday. The boys will probably not break camp for about two weeks. The corps will be in command of Lieut. E.C. Brooks, United States Army.

Detective SergeS-hi' Lawrence ' Delahanty of the ,recently createqI Bureau of Criminal In.vestigation and Information, Brooklyn; who is regarded as the favorite detective of. Commissioner Welles, was suspended by Depdty Commissioner Crosby yesterday pending, the investigation of the charge-of gross neglect of duty in letting Edward W. Ball escape from him on the Fall River steamboat Puritan Tuesday night.

Excellent New-Jersey and Delaware peaches are now in market. There is a wide range in the prices. Very good white peaches could be purchased yesterday for $1.25 a basket, or for about $2.50 a bushel. Choice Crawfords Early, on the other hand, retailed as high as 40 cents a dozen. Excellent yellow peaches, highly colored and of delicate flavor, when sold by the quantity, brought $4 a bushel.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Aug. 17. -- The bicycle parade here to-day was a success. The avenues were lined with spectators. Prizes were awarded as follows: Murray Foster, a fountain pen; Will Sweeney, white wheel suit and white umbrella and flag; Frank Muir, National colors, cyclometer. The girls' prizes were: Miss Hazeltine, as Mercury, a china set; Carrie Brown, flower ornaments; Miss Leonard, white orange sash, tea set.

LYONS, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- The Republican District Convention to-day elected the following delegates, to the State Convention: Charles T. Saxton of Clyde, Barnet S. Davis of Palmyra, George S. Horton of Wolcott, John A. Munson of Savannah, John McGonigal of Lyons, Freeman Pintler of Palmyra, R.T. Ellison of Walworth, Prine Riggs of sodus.

LONDON, Aug. 17. -- [Copyright, 1895, by The New-York Times.] -- "It is an Irish session after all." I suppose I must have heard this remark in some form or other fall from fifty Sassenach mouths inside the precincts of Westminster the last two days. Most often it was uttered in tones of melancholy dejection, though some were angry, and here and there one grinned as he spoke.

The finance department has kept back the salary for the month of July of Miss Roone, whose name is on the pay roll as Street Cleaning Commissioner Waring's private secretary. Information has been filed, it is said, at the office of the Controller to the effect that no such person as Miss Roone is employed in the Department of Street Cleaning.
The steamship Furnessia of the Anchor Line, which sailed from this port for Glasgow yesterday, carried two bands of missionaries, numbering twenty-one persons, for East Africa, Siam, and Persia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- In the absence of a more attractive topic in these days of Political inactivity, the probable effect of the recent free-silver conference is being discussed here. Level-headed politicians say that the conference was a failure, and that the Democratic Party at large will not take any notice of it.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- WHAT is nothing more than a women's barroom, but is called a cafe, is in operation at one of the Broadway hotels.
RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- RICHFIELD has rarely in its long career as a resort known a greater week than the last. The hotels and boarding houses are full to overflowing.

EDGEMERE, L.I., Aug. 17. GUEST of the Hotel Edgemere are not backward in taking advantage of the many opportunities for amusement offerred here. The advantageous location of the hotel, situated at the head of the inlet known as Edgemere Bay, makes yachting one of the principal pastimes of the guests.
