PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17. -- The strike of 135 silk upholsterers' weavers, who left the mill of Hoyle, Harrison Kaye Tuesday, rather than accept a reduction of 10 per cent. in wages, was ended to-day. The weavers decided to return to work under the reduced scale Monday, after an unsuccessful attempt to induce the employes of Stead Miller to leave their looms.

STAPLETON, S.I., Aug. 17. -- An interesting story of legal irregularities was brought out in habeas corpus proceedings before County Judge Stephens to-day, and the question of ex-Assemblyman Michael McGuire's right to the office of Justice of the Peace, which he has held since January, 1893, has been raised.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 17. COTTAGERS who have been away at Bar Harbor, Newport, the Adirondacks, and other resorts, are beginning to return to Lenox, and by another week nearly half of them will be at their country places here.

LONDON, Aug. 17. -- The question of the future leadership of the Liberal Party is causing a good deal of excitement and talk in political circles. The Speaker to-day angrily denounces the action of irresponsible extremists in trying to force themselves into a position of supremacy in the party, and says it would be thought that these persons had already done enough mischief.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Aug. 17. -- Reports from Northern Labrador show an alarming number of deaths among the Eskimos at Nain, a Moravian missionary settlement on the northern coast. One-third of the entire population, eighty people, have died within the last two months.
BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 17. -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Youells of 1,005 Avenue D have been entertaining Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bushee of Northampton, Mass.

SARANAC LAKE, Aug. 17. -- NEW-YORK arrivals at Saranac Inn this week include William N. Elbert, Charles Pietzel, Dr. and Mrs. L.E. Holt, M.F. Cowperthwaite, Thomas E. Crowe, L.S. Worth and party, Mrs. Theodore Ralli and children.

The history of Belgium, since the elections of last year, in which the Clerical Party carried the country by an overwhelming majority, is full of matter for reproof and edification, not only in Europe, but in America also. The fact is, as we have before pointed out, that the Clericals had a plausible claim to plead that they had received a "mandate" to make public instruction religious instruction.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 17. -- The close of the second week in August finds the hotels between Seabright and Elberon enjoying a patronage unequaled in many years. Indications are favorable for the continuation of the Summer rush until late next month, as September, as a rule, is always the finest month in the year at this place.

ROME, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- Senator Coggeshall to-day bolted the regular Republican convention, which subsequently nominated F.C. Weaver to succeed him, and took a nomination for re-election from a "jump" convention.
STAMFORD, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- The Summer season in the Catskills promises to last later this year than for a long time. Many of the hotel proprietors have rooms leased as late as Nov. 15.

In reply to recent strictures upon the Park Commissioners for selecting a site in Bronx Park for the Botanical Garden, Secretary N.L. Britton of the Board of Managers of the garden sent out the following statement yesterday:

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 17. STRANGE monster of the deep have furnished a source of not a little amusement at the Prospect House during the past week. Fishing parties are popular at this picturesque watering place, and daily excursions to the favorite angling spots, within a half hour's sail from the hotel, are the order of the day.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- The baseball cranks are gloomy to-night, though the team played the best game of the season, fielding almost perfectly, and batting terrifically. J. Lee Taller is as gloomy as an iceberg. Robert Crawford, Jr., started for a drive as soon as the game was over.

Until the news came the other day that the British Government had annexed the Island of Trinidad, in the South Atlantic, probably not one Englishman in ten thousand knew that such a place existed. Even now I fear that the tidings of Brazil's grave resentment, and of the "growing excitement" in Rio Janeiro, will fail to stir up any profound interest in the subject.

The declarations of Mayor Strong, Chairman Edward Lauterbach, and Commissioner of Public Works William Brookfield on the question of a union or a "straight" Republican ticket this year, made it plain to most Republicans yesterday that there is a new and clearly defined issue in the local Republican row.
CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 17. LAST Saturday night the hotels turned away guests because of lack of accommodation, and most of the visitors have staid on during the week.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Aug. 17. -- Among recent additions to the New-York Summer colony are Mr. and Mrs. E.M. Grinnell, Mr. and Mrs. George J. Schermerhorn, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Talbot, Miss Vera Schuyler, Harold R. Talbot, Mr. and Mrs. C.C. Sargent, Miss Lilian P. Sargent, Miss J.E. Cannon, F.D. Stein, Mrs. E.L. Hawk, and Mrs. W.H. Davis.

If few readers of the latest work of Maarten Maartens are entirely satisfied with it, the fault is scarcely his, and, indeed, is not to be regarded as a fault at all. It would be too much to expect in all his books the thrilling power and the deft use of the uncanny and unusual that distinguish "God's Fool" and that were present in a smaller degree in "The Greater Glory.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 17. -- Asbury Park and Ocean Grove are crowded to-night as never before. The visitors began to arrive Monday, and the rush seaward was kept up all the week. The choice rooms at the hotels have been occupied for weeks by "season" guests, and the newcomers were stored away in "sky-floor" rooms, in the parlors, and in the corridors.

WHEELER'S FARMS, Conn., Aug. 17. -- A wildcat was killed in Farmer Ephraim Staynor's barn the other night in rather a remarkable way. Mr. Staynor has a family of nine pure Maltese cats, of which he has always been very proud. People from all over this region have heard of their rat-killing accomplishments, and tried to buy some of the kittens, but he would never part with one.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Aug. 17. HAPPY days at Sea Cliff are these Summer guest in large numbers are enjoying its beauties of scenery, healthfulness, and the various recreations and pleasures afforded by land, water, and social intercourse. There are more people than ever at Sea Cliff this season, as the travel by both boat and train demonstrates.

The novelty in the programme of professional bicycle races decided at the Manhattan Beach track yesterday afternoon was the contest between two "quad" teams, at a distance of one mile. This was announced as the first race of the kind ever held in this country. It was far from being a close race, yet it held the attention of the spectators from the beginning to the end.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- There was an abundance of wind for the yachtsmen who started their yachts in the first annual regatta of the Huguenot Yacht Club of New-Rochelle to-day, sailed over the club's four-sided courses. There were fifty-four starters, and plenty of excitement for the yachtsmen.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 17. -- The artists, Eastman Johnson, returned to Lenox to-night from a brief visit to New-York. Since finishing the portrait of ex-President Harrison, he has received a large number of orders for other portraits. He has just finished a portrait of George Cabot Ward for the Union League Club.

The unwelcome intelligence comes from Bar Harbor and Newport that the men in those Summer resorts wear black frock coats and high silk hats when they go to church on Sunday or attend social functions that occur before the dinner hour. A person given to hasty conclusions might infer this to be merely another proof of the prevalence of English fashions at Bar Harbor and Newport.
The strikes in the garment-making trades that have already been put in force are nearly all over, with a uniform record of success for the workers.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 17. -- Six prisoners walked out of the Lucas County Jail this morning. About 9 o'clock Turnkey Mosher went into the jail corridor to get shaved by the prison barber. He was no sooner seated and lathered than the prisoners pounced upon him, took away his keys and handcuffs, put the handcuffs on the turnkey's hands, and locked him in a cell.

Lists containing the names of thirty Maryland soldiers who were taken prisoners in the Battle of Long Island Aug. 27, 1776, are carefully treasured by Mr. William Ridgely Griffith, Chairman of the Maryland Committee which is preparing, to dedicate, in Brooklyn, N.Y., Aug. 27, the monument to the men who saved the American Army in that battle.

Although everybody was satisfied it was very hot yesterday, the mercury did not climb very high. The atmosphere was however, loaded with moisture, and the result was just as disagreeable with the thermometer at 80, and most of the time several degrees lower, as it would have been with a ninety-degree temperature and a reasonably dry air.
BLOCK ISLAND, Aug. 17. JULY was dull here owing to the rainy, disagreeable weather, but August thus far has been lively enough to make up for it.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 17. -- The United Presbyterian Church, in course of erection at the corner of Grand River and Alexandrine Avenues, was struck by a cyclone which accompanied a thunder storm about noon to-day and practically demolished.

Notwithstanding that the card at Aqueduct yesterday was anything but inviting, the fields being small and quality poor, the crowd was the largest of the meeting, fully 5,000 people being present. The racing was in keeping with the poor card, not one of the events bringing about a semblance of a contest, and, to make matters worse, only one favorite was successful throughout the afternoon.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 17. -- The week just ending has been one of many luncheons, dinners, balls, and receptions. The Summer here is but a continuation of the Winter's gayety. In the morning golf playing, in the afternoon luncheons and teas, and at night dances and receptions.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Aug. 17 -- The german given at the Town Hall Monday evening of this week was a great success. About twenty couples took part, and there was a large number of interested spectators. The floor was covered with crash and the stage banked with palms, goldenrod, and sprays of featherlike green.

ARVERNE-BY-THE-SEA, L.I., Aug. 17. -- The grand ball given in honor of Miss Frances Key, the granddaughter of the writer of "The Star-Spangled Banner," was held in the hotel this evening. Experienced decorators transformed the hotel into a veritable fairyland. Fancy Japanese and Chinese lanterns, bunting, and flags were arranged in tasteful order throughout the halls and parlors.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Aug. 17. ONG Beach becomes tractive as the season goes on. It has v . become a place for ' '~ _% rest and recreation. with just enough gayety in the so-,.C...-r -- a_- cial life to prevent its being dull.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 17. NO DECLINE in the popularity of Long Branch is to be noticed. While a number of the guests at hotels have gone to the mountains, the quarters they occupied have been quickly taken by those who, unable to secure accommodations before, have been waiting for vacant rooms.

The discussion which has lately sprung up regarding objections to the tall structures that are going up in this city, and the advisability of limiting the height of buildings in the interest of health and safety, naturally leads to reflection upon the cause of this anomalous projection of towers and spires into the air along our streets instead of solid and symmetrical products of genuine architecture.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 17. -- Ralph Tolles of Westervelt Avenue has been spending the week in New-England.

Major Gen. Edwin A. McAlpin, Adjutant General of the State of New-York, sailed for a six weeks' vacation in Europe on the steamship Lucania yesterday. He had a semi-military send off. The First Battery, under command of Capt. Wendel, paraded, and its band serenaded him.

CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 17. -- The annual regatta of the East Bay Yacht Club was sailed this afternoon over the club course off Hotel Brooklyn. There was a strong south wind blowing, and as the yachts were manned entirely by amateurs it made the most exciting race of the season. The course is triangular and requires seven rounds to make the ten miles.

Senator Hoar of Massachusetts has been gratifying a large number of his countrymen by the exhibition of good sense, good-will, and good temper in his letter to a wild goose who signs himself T.C. Evans and goes in great fear of the Pope. It is calculated to induce reflection upon the part of Senator Hoar that the exhibition has been surprising as well as gratifying.

NEWPORT, Aug. 17. -- This was the greatest day of the year, as the Saturday of the coaching parade always is. The ladies had out their most swagger gowns and their daintiest bonnets. A great crowd saw the procession form on East Narragansett Avenue. Col. Jay's coach, the first in line, being that of the President of the club, had Mrs. Jay on the box, gowned in white lawn, with lavender silk collar.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 17. -- Three thousand people turned out this afternoon to witness the bicycle races given at the athletic grounds under the auspices of the Asbury Park Athletic Association. The boxes were occupied by hotel guests and cottagers. There were seven races on the card -- one for novices, two for Class A men, two for Class B men, and two for professionals.
SUMMIT, N.J., Aug. 17. THE annual picnic of the Sunday school of the Springfield Presbyterian Church was held this afternoon on Baltus Roll Mountain.

Commissioned by the Hon. J.J. O'Donohue of the Catholic Club to paint a portrait of Archbishop Corrigan, Frank Fowler, the well-known New-York artist, has been working since the Spring upon a large canvas which is now almost completed, and which will be a truthful transcript of the form and face of the popular and much beloved prelate as he appeared in his fifty-sixth year, his birthday having occurred on the 13th of this month.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- The apothecaries in the navy are determined to better their condition if possible during the next session of Congress, and to that end have secured the co-operation of the American Pharmaceutical Association. It will be a surprise to most people to learn that the status of the naval apothecary has not changed since the war, with the exception of a slight increase of salary.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- Another controversy has sprung up in the Navy Department, which, although of a trifling nature, is destined to disrupt the Board of Construction, composed of the Chiefs of bureaus, whose majority vote is a recommendation to the Secretary of the type of all that enters into the modern man-of- war.
The search made by the police of the Tremont Station for Miss Lucretia Clark, who disappeared mysteriously from her home in Plainfield, N.J., Aug. 9, has so far proved fruitless.

ARVERNE-BY-THE-SEA, L.I., Aug. 17. THLETIC sports seem to occupy a large portion of the Summer girls' time at this resort. At the Hotel Arverne bicycling, tennis, bathing, and horse-back riding are the most popular amusements indulged in by the guests.
LONDON, Aug. 17. -- The new White Star Line freight steamer Georgic sailed on her first voyage from Liverpool for New-York yesterday. She is the largest cargo steamer afloat.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 17. -- An army of Knights, with drawn swords, will invade this city Aug. 26 and 27. The invasion will be a welcome one, however. In fact, Boston is already preparing to capitulate and receive the coming host. Like the Knights of old, these will bear aloft the red cross on their banner, with the motto "In hoc signo vinces."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- The new edifice now in course of erection for the Westchester Temporary Home for Destitute Children, in this town, will be an imposing and well-appointed building, an ornament to the locality, and will better meet the requirements than the old one, which was a private house remodeled to meet a demand, and which was burned to the ground last Winter.
There is fresh litigation in store for Napoleon J. Haines, senior member of the old firm of Haines Brother, piano manufacturers.
NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 17. -- NOT since the hot weather began have the resorts in this section been so largely patronized as during the last fortnight.

Crowds of visitors were all day yesterday at the Erie Basin to inspect the Defender and the Vigilant. Many climbed down the steep steps into the basin and got in the way of the men at work cleaning the yachts. Two men were kept busy all day long trying to keep them out of the basin.

IPSWICH, Mass., Aug. 17. -- Pilgrim Plymouth and Puritan Salem -- old colony aristocrats -- are fairly ostentatious in setting forth their claims to historic renown, and the visitor has guide book and reprinted annals with every famous locality and landmark plainly noted ready to hand -- colonial history on tap.

MADRID, Aug. 17. -- There has been a concerted rising of Republican bands in the Province of Valencia and the Province of Castellon de la Plana, immediately north of Valencia, and the Government is taking active measures to quell the rising in its incipiency.

Springfield's grand race meets of years past will be eclipsed, if that be possible, by the coming diamond tournament, booked for the 11th and 12th of September. Only the very upper crust of the racing world will show their paces there, and the finest crowd of spectators of the year will be on hand to watch and applaud the victors.

Late August and early September, the season par excellence for tours a-wheel, should not pass by without a ride over new routes. Wheel from modern New-York to rural New-England, across the broad Sound, and over the farmlands of Long Island, a panorama of a week's passing. Turn from New-York and its activity and heat.

Home was the chief resort of New-Yorkers yesterday. Comparatively few persons left their own residences during the day. The streets were deserted and the street cars comfortably empty. The steamboats on all the routes to Coney Island carried little more than half the number of passengers that went there on the previous Sunday.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18. -- Col. George E. Waring, Jr., Commissioner of Street Cleaning of New-York City, to-night gives out the following letter, which is self-explanatory:

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 18. -- Capt. W.N. Wells of the schooner Helen G. Wells, which arrived from Grand Banks to-day, reports that on Aug. 10, when thirty-six miles south and east of Cape Race, he passed within a short distance of the British yacht Valkyrie III. The Wells kept company with Valkyrie most of the day, but did not speak her, as she displayed no signals to be reported.

The demand for ice from New-York City has never been greater than at the present time, and all of the big ice dealers in this vicinity are scurrying about to secure barges, canalboats, or any other kind of a boat suitable to convey ice to the metropolis.

The exposures that have been made by The New-York Times of the Sunday violations of the excise law in Brooklyn were made the basis of an extensive report that was made at a meeting of the Christian Endeavor Union, held at the Grace Methodist Episcopal Church, on Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn, Saturday, by I.H. Edgar, Chairman of the Good Citizenship Committee.

I noticed a few days since, in a communication from Hanover to The Boston Journal, that the old pine which has made Dartmouth College famous and three Indians immortal, has gone where the moss cannot creep or the ivy twine. Time and the tornado have laid it low.

" I am in favor of closing saloons Sundays," said Mayor Charles A. Schieren of Brooklyn to a reporter for The New-York Times two weeks ago. "I have ordered the Police Commissioner to close them on Sunday, and he has reported that they have been closed."

ST. ANDREW'S BAY, Fla., Aug. 10. -- The Dr. Cliff-Allen party from Tennessee has had wonderful success fishing for tarpon in St. Andrew's Bay. The party numbered fifteen, including several ladies, and all enjoyed the exciting sport greatly. They go out on the water early every morning and return in the evening.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 18. -- A century run will be held by the Mohican Century Wheelmen on Sunday. Sept. 8, to Tuxedo Park. The course is over very fine macadam roads. The entrance fee is $1.50, which includes the cost of a handsome silver medal to all survivors.

One reason why the party in power in Pennsylvania, and especially in the City of Philadelphia, has such a tenacious hold and is so hard to turn out is the fact that it controls the election machinery, and the one thing in that State which is not "protected" is the conduct of elections.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 18. -- The mercury registered 84 in the shade the greater portion of the day, but a good, stiff sea breeze was enjoyed after 11 o'clock in the morning. More people have been here to-day than on any previous Sunday this season, and between 5 and 7 o'clock in the evening an unprecedented throng of people and vehicles was gathered on the famous Ocean Avenue drive.

While nearly all business men realize the value of advertising, there are yet some who have not learned that advertising is just as efficacious in the dull season of the year as when business is brisk, and more necessary.

President Charles G. Wilson of the Board of Health went to Riker's Island yesterday afternoon on the Health Department tug Franklin Edson, to determine for himself the extent of the crop of vegetables that Sanitary Inspector Frederick Springer said had sprung up on the island without the consent of the Commissioners of Charities and Correction, under whose jurisdiction the island is supposed to be.

MARSEILLES, Aug. 18. -- The steamer Yang Tse has arrived here from Madagascar. She had on board when she left Madagascar 136 French soldiers, who had been invalided home. Ninety-seven of these are now convalescent, thirteen show no improvement, and three died on the voyage. Ten of the sick soldiers remained at Zanzibar and thirteen at Port Said, their condition being such that they were unable to proceed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- It was learned to-day that Thomas Holcomb, Auditor of the Treasury for the State and other departments, did not content himself with merely raising the question as to the right of ex-Senator Ransom to draw the salary of Minister to Mexico, but, on the 13th of July last, decided that he was not entitled to the compensation which he claimed as such officer.

Dr. T. De Witt Taimage, who is at his home in Brooklyn, has not resumed his preaching and lecturing tour in the Western States, which was interrupted by the death of Mrs. Talmage, and his plans for the future are not as yet decided.

Mrs. James Brown Potter and Kyrle Bellew, who are to play the leading parts in de Courcil's "Le Collier de la Reine," which is to be produced at Daly's Theatre Sept. 3, were passengers by the French Line steamship La Gascogne which yesterday arrived from Havre. A rehearsal of the play, much of which has been recast, will be had to-day.

BERLIN, Aug. 18. -- Emperor William this afternoon reviewed the First Brigade of the Guards, infantry, on the Moltke Platz, which faces the new palace in Wildpark, the occasion being the twenty-fifth anniversary of the battle of Gravelotte. After the review his Majesty made a speech to the troops. He said that the heroism shown by the First and Third Regiments of Guards at Gravelotte was an ever imperishable example for the troops to follow.

HOTEL CHAMPLAIN, CLINTON COUNTY, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- The dance given at the American Canoe Association's camp near here last night was a very successful affair. The dance was held in the large "mess shed," which for the occasion was cleared of tables and chairs. A Plattsburg orchestra of five pieces furnished very good music. After the dance an entertainment was given in the Knickerbocker camp.

New-York was drier yesterday than on any other Sunday since the effort was made to impartially enforce the excise law. The aridity was general. Oases were not discovered, and the only successful subterfuge and evasion was by Oliver Sumner Teall's Girder Club, which, it was announced, had a membership of 500, and would open a down-town branch Aug. 25.

Tobacco growing in the Connecticut Valley for the past few years has been a game of chance. The early frosts, the high winds and the hailstorms which appear so frequently in the Summer months of these later years make the tobacco crop an uncertain quantity. There is, too, the great danger of pole sweat.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Aug. 18. -- William E. Hopkins, accused of aiding Oliver Curtis Perry to escape from the Matteawan Asylum for Insane Criminals is still in the Dutchess County Jail, notwithstanding the fact that a writ of habeas corpus was issued in his case by Judge Barnard Saturday night.

HAMMEL'S STATION, Rockaway Beach, L.I., Aug. 18. -- The Ocean View Hotel, situated at Surf and Chase Avenues, this place, was destroyed by fire to-night. The fire was discovered shortly after 9 o'clock.

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- The sixty-fourth annual Methodist Episcopal camp meeting here came to an end after a successful session to-night, and to-morrow those from out of town will depart for their various homes.

OCEAN GROVE, Aug. 18. -- Thousands of Methodists arrived yesterday to be present at the opening of the annual camp meeting to-morrow. To-day's services, held under the auspices of the Woman's Foreign Missionary Society, were largely attended. The sermon, at 10:30 A.M., was preached by Miss Mary A. Danforth, for many years a missionary to Japan.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 18. -- The day has been a rather quiet one, society taking advantage of the torrents of rain which have fallen most of the day, and resting at home after the whirl and excitement of the week just closed.

While rummaging among some old papers in the basement of the Court House at Louisville, Ky., about two weeks ago, Hubbard Bush and Theodore Diersen, janitors, found a number of exceedingly rare old stamps of the City of St. Louis, known as the "bear" variety.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18. -- Had it not been for the prompt action of Rear Admiral Richard W. Meade, Major A.L. Williams, and other members of the Union League yesterday, the handsome clubhouse of the league might now be a pile of ashes. At 3:30 o'clock it was discovered that the rear roof of the building was on fire.

Lefferts Place, in Brooklyn, between St. James Place and Franklin Avenue, has attracted the attention of the Good Roads Association. This means that it will very likely come to pass that Lefferts Place will be paved with asphalt, and that the wheelmen of Brooklyn will rejoice in consequence.

Some Democrats of prominence in this city are in favor of a conference of representatives of all the Democratic organizations, at which something may be done toward carrying out the proposition laid down in the resolution adopted last week by the State Democratic Committee.

So far as the trotting interest is concerned the most severe test of the new racing law of this State has been made during the last two weeks. Buffalo has, by reason of its thirty years as a central point for harness racing, and the success which has hitherto attended the annual visit of the Grand Circuit stables, come to be looked on as a place where the sulky could never diminish in favor.

The absence from his home of Frank A. Magowan, ex-Mayor of Trenton, N.J., one of New-Jersey's most prominent business men, who has been talked of as the probable Republican candidate next Fall for Governor of the State, has been explained. Mr. Magowan went to El Reno, Oklahoma Territory, where he began a suit for divorce.

Detective F.L. Odlin has returned from a visit to his old friend Sheriff W.W. Sewall of Island Pond, Me. Fifteen years ago Odlin and Sewall were passing the Summer with Mr. Roosevelt, the famous Police Commissioner of New-York, at his ranch in the Bad Lands of North Dakota. Roosevelt had a new boat on the river and one morning it was gone.

There is an excellent prospect now, brighter than there has been for at least forty years, that is to say, since New-York became a great capital, for making its Municipal Government a Government for the people. An honest and unhampered Police Commission, an honest and unhampered Commissioner of Street Cleaning, honest and unhampered Police Magistrates, these are great benefactions the value of which no past, present, or future mistakes of the Mayor can altogether destroy.

LONDON, Aug. 18. -- Lord Dunraven, the head of the syndicate which built the Valkyrie III.; his daughters, Ladies Rachel and Aileen, and Mr. Watson, the designer of the Valkyrie, will sail for New-York on the White Star Line steamer Teutonic, which is to leave Liverpool next Wednesday. Lord Alfred Paget will be a passenger on the same steamer, and perhaps the Dowager Duchess of Marlborough will go to New-York on her.
OCEAN CITY, Md., Aug. 18. -- Seven lives were lost by an accident to a fishing party on Isle of Wight Bay. Five bodies have been recovered. Those drowned are:

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 18. -- The Right Rev. J.S. Johnston, Bishop of West Texas, preached to-day in Trinity Church. There was a large congregation, including representatives from nearly all the cottages.

ALBANY, Aug. 18. -- The Third Judicial District is almost equally divided between the two great political parties. If there is any advantage it is on the side of the Democrats. For years past the Democrats have been successful in electing their candidates for Supreme Court Judge from the fact that they put up superior men rather than from any political advantage.
The officer at the desk in the police station at Coney Island stroked his mustache and slid his forefinger up and down the blotter early last evening and said:

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 18. -- A boy named Garcia, who twice placed stones on the track of the Hidalgo Railway, the second time causing the wreck of a train, was executed to-day at Pachuca, under the new law suspending constitutional guarantees in the case of persons obstructing the public mails or railway trains.

There is to be a conference at Saratoga this month for the discussion of "proportional representation." There is a National "League" and a number of State organizations devoted to this cause, and they have been trying to stimulate its agitation for two or three years past without making much apparent headway.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18. -- There were numerous visiting preachers in the local pulpits to-day, but a heavy downpour of rain all the morning kept nearly all the cottagers within doors. The week had been one of great social activity, and Summer residents, greatly fatigued, accepted the reasonable excuse to remain away from worship presented in the severe storm, and took the opportunity for rest.

TRENTON, Aug. 18. -- New-Jersey Republicans are experiencing the annoyance of having too many ambitious statesmen who would like to be Governor, and a number of leaders who would like to own a good amiable Governor.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 18. -- Cardinal Gibbons, who sailed from Queenstown on the Campania to-day, expects to reach Baltimore next Saturday afternoon. His Eminence and party will be met in New-York by a committee of prominent clergy and laity of this city, of which the Rev. John D. Boland of St. Vincent's Church is the Chairman.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- Controller Bowler has not yet begun the preparation of his decision on the sugar bounty claims of the Nebraska and Louisiana producers, counsel and other interested parties not having filed their briefs in the case. He expects to begin work this week, and will complete it by Sept. 1, when he will leave the city for the remainder of his vacation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- The War Department has received notification that Department commanders have approved sentences of courts-martial dishonorably discharging the following soldiers from the Army of the United States upon conviction of the offenses named, together with additional punishment as set forth:

Valkyrie III. is anchored off Liberty Island, in the upper bay. The cable rattled through the hawse hole at 10:25 o'clock last night, and it was the most pleasing sound that Capt. Cranfield and his merry crew of English sailors have heard for more than eighteen days.

When the new Capitol at Albany was begun it was estimated that it would cost $5,000,000 and would be completed in six years. It has cost several times $5,000,000 and its construction has occupied several times six years, and it is not finished yet. It is now said that $2,000,000 more will complete the structure, but nobody ventures to guess how long it will take.

BERLIN, Aug. 18. -- The foundation stone of the monument to Emperor William I. was laid to-day by his grandson, Emperor William II., with the most imposing ceremonies. The former Schloss Freiheit, where the monument is to be erected, was converted into a closed arena for the occupancy of the many guests who had been invited to attend the ceremony.

An adjourned meeting of the reorganized Southern Railway and Steamship Association will be held in the Hotel Waldorf today. It is expected that the new rate agreement, which was drawn up at Manhattan Beach last week, will be formally signed by all of the roads interested.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- The recent decision of the Acting Attorney General in the case of Minister Ransom is apt to have an important bearing upon the cases of several other persons holding important positions under the General Government, whose appointments were made under almost identical conditions.

The saloon forces have surrendered. The prompt justice meted out to them in Recorder Goff's court, and the consequent failure to overburden that tribunal, have broken the defiant spirit of the liquor sellers, and, through their counsel, they yesterday formally gave way and appealed for mercy.

The New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company proposes to make an example of the Hungarian brick maker, John Lascko, who flagged the Chicago express yesterday, and with a companion, boarded the train near Dutchess Junction.

Owing to the fact that college graduates and those who are interested in college athletics in the coming Cambridge-Yale games in October are anxious to secure reserved seats and boxes in advance, the managers of the Cambridge-Yale contest have decided to place the tickets on sale in advance and have adopted the application blank system, which has been so successful of late years in conjunction with the large football games.

The State Floral Society has decided to undertake the work of a complete classification of roses. This question was brought up before a meeting of the society by H.G. Pratt of Fruitville, who read a very interesting paper on the subject, and suggested the appointment of a classification committee. Mr. Pratt said:

-- Thomas Hovenden, the artist, whose tragic death was chronicled last week, was a man singularly modest, simple, and natural, who possessed to an eminent degree the respect, confidence, and hearty good will of his fellow-painters, and whose loss will be deeply regretted. Mr. Hovenden was a serious worker, and, to the very last, at earnest student.

Many circumstances of unusual interest attended the resumption of the inquest as to the deaths of the sixteen mechanics and laborers who lost their lives in the collapse of the Ireland Building, at West Third Street and West Broadway. Not the least of these was the announcement made by Coroner Fitzpatrick that he had issued a warrant for the arrest of John B. Ireland, the owner of the wrecked building.

Whenever the foes of Cuban independence have been driven from all their other argumentative strongholds, it is their invariable habit to fall back upon the assertion that the inhabitants of the island are incompetent to govern themselves, and that without the guiding hand of Spain they would soon fall into the condition of barbarism that characterizes Haiti.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Col. John M. Wilson, the engineer officer who was for a time Superintendent of the Military Academy, will not take Gen. Abbott's place in New-York City as has been reported. When Gen. Abbott retired his duties as Engineer of the Northeast Division of River and Harbor Work fell to Col. Wilson, who also gained a promotion.
LONDON, Aug. 19. -- The Hon. Charles A. Boutelle, a member of the American House of Representatives, was present in the Diplomatic Gallery during the debate in the House of Commons to-day.

BOSTON, Aug. 19. -- The American Board of Foreign Missions has received from some of its representatives in the Sassoun region of Eastern Turkey an account of the distribution of aid sent from England and America to the poor survivors of the terrible massacre. Crumbling walls scattered over the hillsides are said to show where once lived a well-to-do and happy population.

LONDON, Aug. 19. -- The Times will to-morrow publish a dispatch from Hongkong, confirming the report of the refusal of the Chinese Government to allow the British and American Consuls to inquire into the Ku-Cheng massacre.

Speculation to-day was confined largely to the industrials, with Tobacco the centre of interest. There was a rush to sell the stock at the opening, and the first sales on the tapis were reported at 102 3/4@101. The stock showed no rallying power, and within a very few minutes broke par. Before noon it was down to 95, from which point it recovered to 97, only to break sharply again.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 19. -The opening of the most vigorous political campaign ever known in the Commonwealth of Kentucky was made at the Auditorium to-night in the presence of 6,000 people, by a joint debate of three hours between Gen. P. Watt Hardin and Col. William O. Bradley, the Democratic and Republican candidates for Governor, respectively.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 19. -- It now looks as if the nomination for Governor would be forced upon ex-Gov. James E. Campbell at the Springfield convention to-morrow. A letter addressed to the Democrats of this county to-day by Col. James Kilbourne seems to be decisive, and takes him out of consideration for this office.

Robert S. Wilson, twenty-nine years old, of 94 Bridge Street, and William H. Crampton, forty-five years old, of 254 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, who represent themselves as being agents employed by the Law Enforcement Society, were arrested yesterday on a charge of extortion and were locked up in the Bath Beach Precinct.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19. -- The row of buildings at Sixty-third and Wallace Streets, Englewood, burned this morning. This row constituted the "Castle," in which H.H. Holmes, the confessed insurance swindler now awaiting sentence in Philadelphia, is popularly supposed to have concocted many of his crimes and committed numerous murders.

HAVANA, Aug. 19. -- Advices from Santa Clara are that Col. Plananca routed at Loma Siguaney, in the Sancti Spiritu District, several rebel bands, under the command of Roloff and Sanchez. Sixty rebels were killed, while the Government forces lost two killed and eight wounded. The rebels fled into the province of Puerto Principe and were pursued by the troops.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Aug. 19. -- Currency is given to a rumor here to-night that the A.P.A. order of the United States has formally tendered its support to Premier Greenway in his struggle for a National School system, and has offered to send armed men to assist him should there be any attempt on the part of the Dominion Government to enforce the order of the Governor General in Council for the re-establishment of separate schools.

There was no business transacted at the auction rooms yesterday, and a few only of the usual exchange and auction-room attendants were in evidence. For to-day there are nine sales scheduled, all of them in legal proceedings, and all to be held at 111 Broadway. They include the following:

The first practical step toward reclaiming wayward and friendless girls of that portion of the city lying between Fourteenth and Thirty-fourth Streets was made last night, when the New-York Rescue Band opened an establishment at 208 East Fourteenth Street, to be known as the Girls' Club and Industrial Home.

The election for delegates to a Constitutional Convention in South Carolina occurs to-day, after the most peculiar canvass in the history of American politics. A majority of the citizens nominally entitled to vote under both Federal and State Constitutions are negroes, and nearly all are Republicans, but for nearly twenty years that majority has by one device or another been prevented from ruling.

Severn R. Sharp of Kingston, N.Y., who was appointed by Gov. Morton to take testimony and investigate the condition of the office of Anthony Clinchy, the State Inspector of Gas Meters, held another session yesterday in the Superior Court. Deputy Attorney General Hasbrouk appeared for the State, and Congressman-elect William Sulzer was present in the interest of Mr. Clinchy, who was also present.
President Theodore Roosevelt of the Police Department was asked by a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday about his excise tour on Sunday. Mr. Roosevelt said:

BERLIN, Aug. 19. -- Fifteen thousand German veterans of the Franco-Prussian war celebrated the anniversary of the battle of Gravelotte, which was fought on Aug. 18, 1870, by a parade on the Tempelhofer Field to-day. The ceremonies attending the celebration were begun at noon with a religious service. The choral "Nun danket Alle Gott" was sung, and addresses were made by Dr. Woifing, an evangelical military pastor, and Dr. Vollmar, a Catholic ecclesiastic.

The bicycle riders of the Young Men's Christian Association of Brooklyn are going to have a big century run on Labor Day. This will be the very first affair of the kind engineered by the Y.M.C.A.'s and a full measure of success is predicted for it.
Acting Captain O'Brien of the Detective Bureau has under arrest at Police Headquarters "Jeff" Martin, alias the "Doctor," who is said to be well known as a sneak thief and blackmailer.

To be plaintiff in a divorce suit at 17, after two months of married life, is sufficiently remarkable in itself to make the case of Mrs. Augusta Peet of unusual interest. But this is only a minor item in this young woman's history, which is full of a tragic sort of romance.

The following interesting letter has been received from Buda-Pesth, Austria-Hungary. The writer is evidently confused in regard to localities, but manifests a proper desire to read The Independent Statesman, which, while not published at Concord, Mass., will be none the less interesting to him on that account:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- It is said here to-night that important developments may be expected in the case of Mrs. Haswell, whose name has been mentioned in connection with the bribing of the keeper William E. Hopkins, accused of aiding in the escape of Oliver Curtis Perry from the asylum at Matteawan.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19. -- A small riot and a number of broken heads distinguished a meeting of the Armenian National Union in North Clark Street yesterday.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 19. -- Reports of damage caused by the storm which swept over a portion of Pittsburg and Allegheny last evening continue. The numerous accounts of narrow escapes from flying wreckage render it remarkable that there were so few fatalities. The high wind and heavy rain were accompanied by hail.

The statement made by Col. George E. Waring, Jr., Commissioner of Street Cleaning, in a letter published in The New-York Times yesterday, to the effect that he had acted in accordance with a legal opinion received from the office of the Corporation Counsel in the matter of the pay of his private secretary, was confirmed by an official of the Law Department yesterday.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 19. -- The twenty-sixth annual camp meeting of the Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Association opened this morning with an unusually large attedance at all of the meetings. Much of the old-time Methodist fervor was shown among the zealots. Old friendships were renewed and many new ones made.
Considerable interest has been aroused among British authors and publishers by reason of the attempt to obtain proclamation of the Canadian copyright act of 1889.

PORTSMOUTH, Aug. 19 -- The cutters Ailsa and Britannia and the forty-raters Caress, Isolde, Carina, and Corsair started this morning in a race for the Albert Cup at the Royal Albert regatta. The course for the race was a distance of forty-six miles, the yachts going twice around the Nab Lightship and the West Middle Shoal.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of The New York Times.

That a jockey can be held responsible for a poor day's racing was fully demonstrated at Aqueduct yesterday. Had J. Horton, who is said to be a green boy, not been engaged to ride in the first events, the sport would have been enjoyable and the favorites would have carried off the honors.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- The attendance at the race track here to-day was very small, notwithstanding the fact that a fair card was offered. The weather was perfect for racing, and the track dry and fast. The feature of the day's sport was the race for the Hurricane Stud Selling Stakes. The event was robbed of all interest owing to the liberal use of the blue pencil.

There is an incident scheme on foot to make another non-partisan combination against Tammany Hall in the approaching election. It will not be the old Committee of Seventy, though some who were members of that body are in favor of it and would doubtless take a hand in the work. Some of the organizations which rallied under the Seventy's flag are in for another fight of the same sort.

From The Astoria (Oregon) Astorian, Aug. 10. At midnight the Spring salmon season of the Columbia for 1895 will be a thing of the past. The season now ending has been one of unusual happenings and fluctuating runs. From April 10 to 20 the fishermen made extraordinarily good catches, and it looked as if the year was going to show a very satisfactory advance over the pack of 1894.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19. -- It was a day of the gathering of crack lawn tennis players and their friends, as well as hundreds who are here to witness the tournament to be begun to-morrow. The Casino has a bonanza in its grand stand, as every one of its 5,000 seats will be taken before play opens to-morrow.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 19. -- John S. Barnes and family have returned to Lenox. Mr. Barnes, who has been at Bar Harbor and other resorts, returned yesterday, and the family came to Cold Brook to-day from Manchester-by-the-Sea. They will remain here for the Autumnal season, and will be a great accession to all of the Lenox society functions.
LOUISVILLE, Aug. 19. -- Is Kentucky a doubtful State? Will she break the "Soho South" and a Democratic record extending back half a century by electing a Republican ticket in November next?

September will be a specially lively month for athletic contests in this city. Not in years have such important meetings been scheduled. The pick of athletes in this country and Great Britain are to meet, and it will be a surprise if records are not broken. The principal meetings will be held on these dates:
HASTINGS, Aug. 19. -- The eleventh round of the international chess masters' tournament was played at Brassey Institute to-day, the results being as follows:

Washington Letter to The Philadelphia Ledger. There are two distinct branches of education which must be considered as factors of the development of our foreign commerce along broad, progressive lines. These are commercial education and industrial training. Europe has heretofore given greater prominence to the latter, owing to the eager rivalry in industrial production between the great manufacturing States.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 19. -- W.G. Nicoll, Supervisor and Justice of the Peace of this town, returned home at about 11 o'clock last night and discovered a ladder placed against the side of the house. It was resting against one of the windowsills on the second floor. His family knew nothing of the ladder being there, and said no one had been heard about the place.

A new three-act farce called "Other People's Money," written by Edward Owings Towne, was produced last evening at Hoyt's Theatre by Mr. Charles Dickson, who attempted, in its performance, a role which would well suit Mr. Crane or Mr. Nat Goodwin, and incidentally tried to sing a superfluous song.

COLOGNE, Aug. 19. -- In the International bicycle contests here to-day the one hundred kilometer race for amateurs was won by Cordang of Holland, Witteveen of Holland was second, and Heine of Norway third. Banker, the American rider, protested against Protin, the Belgian rider, being awarded the race he won yesterday, claiming that he was not entitled to compete in the final heat, as he had only third place in his heat.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- The local forecast official of the Weather Bureau at New-York City has been called upon by Chief Willis Moore of the Weather Bureau have been printed in the papers of the city have been printed in the papers of the city wherein he predicts the weather. Numerous reports have been published there and throughout the country that two months of hot and dry weather may be looked for.

DENVER, Aug. 19. -- Probably twenty-five men, women, and children lost their lives by the explosion of the boiler in the Gumry Hotel on Lawrence Street this morning. Half a dozen others are injured and at the hospital. Eight burned and crushed bodies are at the morgue. Ten more are known to be buried in the ruins, but seventeen persons are reported missing altogether.
George Parker, a professional nurse, died in the Brooklyn Hospital Sunday night. It has since been learned that his death was due in all probability to the proximity of a needle to the heart.

County Treasurer Hubert G. Taylor of Kings County yesterday presented a, communication to the Board of Supervisors regarding the financial condition of the county, and it is not a pleasing showing for the taxpayers.

Police Commissioner Parker yesterday appeared in the Tombs Police Court for George Howlett Davis, an inventor and manufacturer, living in Bayonne, N.J., who was examined on a charge of burglary, preferred by Emil H. Klaber of the Automaton Piano Company of 96 Church Street.

I am anchored on board a family canal boat in the wilderness of the Havel River, seeking to finish a book on the German struggle for liberty, which shall tell the truth from the standpoint of a plain American citizen. Pray help me to preserve some of this citizenship, which seems to give pain to some one on The Tribune and The Mail and Express.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 19. -- Edward W. Ball, Jr., of Woodhaven, L.I., has a Detroit record. About Nov. 3, 1894, Ball appeared in Detroit, accompanied by a wife, (which one, not known,) a baby, and a gigantic idea. He rented a flat on Cass Avenue, near Henry Street, and set up housekeeping.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 19. -- Contractor F.C. O'Reilly and a gang of about fifty workmen this morning continued the work of tunneling under the Pennsylvania Railroad Company's tracks at the Point of Woods, for the New-Jersey Junction Railway Company.
LONDON, Aug. 19. -- The Pall Mall Gazette has a dispatch from Shanghai, saying that a French gunboat has left Hankow for the purpose of opening up the province of Hou-Nan.

The comparative resistance which modern building materials offer to fire will form the subject of a long series of tests in specially-built chambers on the grounds of the Continental Iron Works, in Brooklyn.

Allow me to add a few words, by way of supplement, to the very important statements about Cuban matters made by a New-York merchant in an interview with one of your reporters, published in The New York Times of Aug. 15.
LONG BRANCH, Aug. 19. -- The Rev. William G. Russell of Camden is making a short stay with friends here.

LAKE MINNEWASKA, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- William Strong, ex-Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, died at 2:15 o'clock this afternoon. He yesterday suffered a stroke of paralysis which affected the left side of his body, and he also had a relapse of catarrhal fever. He had been ill for several weeks, and for the twenty-four hours preceding his death he was unconscious.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- A cool, bracing air and a clear sky has made driving the order of the day. A large party from the Spring House was out for a morning galop, and this afternoon every one who has a horse or could secure one was on the road. Mr. and Mrs. Robert Tailer appeared in a stylish trap behind a pair of steppers.

WEST POINT, Aug. 19. -- The detachment of Engineers from Willet's Point who have been practicing during the past week with the new Krag-Jorgenson army rifle will leave here to-morrow, and another company will take its place at once.

The-King County Board of Supervisors voted to give the contract to build the bridge across Newton Creek to the Kings County Bridge Company for $418,000, but yesterday Supervisor at Large Fitchie vetoed the resolution awarding the contract.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- The first shipment of the earliest variety of grapes has been made from the Southern Ulster fruit district. The price has been, in the main, satisfactory. The variety thus far shipped is known as the Champion, which, for quality, is not such as one delights to find in the old and reliable Concord.

It was Valkyrie Day yesterday. The arrival of the English champion had set every one talking, and it is doubtful if the wreck of the Defender would have changed the topic of conversation. The longshoremen and sailors along the river front gave their ideas of the powerful-looking craft that tugged at her anchor off Liberty Island.
Twenty-four defendants in excise cases were called to plead yesterday before Recorder Goff, under indictments found against them by the Grand Jury.

Justice Gaynor, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, on the application of Robert Crummey, issued a mandamus directing his reinstatement to the position of Assistant Warrant Clerk in the Controller's office by City Controller George W. Palmer, on the ground that Crummey is a veteran volunteer fireman, and his dismissal without cause, other than political reasons, was illegal.

Sixty carloads of peaches, with an average of 600 baskets to the car, reached this city yesterday morning from the orchards in Delaware, Maryland, and New-Jersey. As each basket contains at least 100 peaches, there will have been about 3,000,000 peaches either eaten, thrown away, or converted into preserves before the rise of to-day's sun.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, via Galveston, Aug. 20. -- Gen Alfaro's action in liberating the prisoners taken in battle before his entry in Riobamba has caused agreeable surprise and a favorable impression.

The only pleasing feature of the racing at Aqueduct yesterday was that a majority of the favorites were successful. From a racing standpoint the contests were a failure. Not in a single instance was there a close or exciting finish. The third event, a selling handicap, which promised to furnish the best race of the afternoon, was reduced to a walkover for Charade.
But for the action of the Morgan-Belmont syndicate in depositing $2,000,000 of gold with the Sub-Treasury yesterday the Treasury gold reserve would have been below $100,000,000 to-day.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 12. -- The historic little island of Barbados, at once one of the smallest and most pretentious of the West Indies, is now going through an extraordinary experience. Its population has overflowed, and the Government is facing one of the oddest crises recorded in history.

MADRID, Aug. 20. -- A dispatch to The Imparcial from Havana says that the death sentence passed upon the rebel chief Mujiga was confirmed by the authorities, and it is understood that the sentence was executed at Matanzas yesterday.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 20. -- Furnace "H" of the Edgar Thomson Steel Works, Carnegie's plant, at Bessemer, near Braddock, Penn., exploded between 4 and 5 o'clock this morning, killing eight men and badly burning six others -- not one of those employed about the furnace escaping. Some of the injured men have been brought to this city for treatment, and the dead are in the hands of the undertaker.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- Frederick Zimmerman, Mike George, and John Yonald, three barbers of this city, were arraigned before Judge Bard to-day upon a charge of violating the Sunday barber law. They were arrested upon the complaint of Policeman Gilroy. Last Sunday the barbers were caught shaving customers. George admitted to the Judge that he had shaved one of his employes. He was fined $5.

When the time comes for the next fat frying campaign by the American Protective Tariff League, there will be some pointed questions put to the officers of that league by men who have been in the habit of making liberal contributions.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20. -- W.A. Shoemaker, counsel for H.H. Holmes, to-day received a message purporting to come from Minnie R. Williams, dated Providence, R.I., which stated that the sender was alive and well. This is one of the women whom Holmes is accused of having murdered in the Chicago "castle."

SARATOGA RACE TRACK, Aug. 20. -- An excellent card, fair weather, and a fast track were the conditions which brought a very good crowd to the races here to-day. Most of the fields were large, and the sport was interesting throughout. The principal event down on the programme for decision was the race for the Okolona Hurdle Stakes, which was won easily by Kilkenny, a 5 to 1 shot.

A fair-sized audience, the time of year considered, confronted the six auction stands at No. 111 Broadway, where sales had been announced to take place yesterday noon. All were foreclosures sales save one -- an offering of the Astor leasehold of the four-story and basement brick tenement, with stores, 50 Avenue A.

BUFFALO, Aug. 20. -- The small steam yacht Rung Brothers, owned by the Burley Brothers of this city, with thirteen passengers and a crew of three, foundered early this evening between the inner Government lighthouse and the Reading coal trestle, and six of the passengers were drowned.
An interesting discussion regarding the affairs of the Swedish Baptist Church, at 138 East Twenty-seventh Street, took place yesterday before Judge Giegerich, in the Court of Common Pleas.

Emperor William is having the finest sort of a time in celebrating victories won over the French. It not only gives him daily opportunity to play with soldiers and to make resonant speeches to his heart's content, but it distracts public attention from the growth of Socialism in Germany, and really makes a few people believe that the empire exists to-day, not in spite of, but on account of, the Hohenzollern family.

The members of the "Horse Market Gang" now in Ludlow Street Jail awaiting trial on charges of counterfeiting are in rebellion because their ringleader is locked up in the only dark cell in the prison.

Wah Yue, a young Chinaman, appeared before Edward J. Newell, referee, in his office, in the Bennett Building, as a third party, to be examined in supplementary proceedings in a suit of Dong Fong against his cousin, Ho Cue.

MYSTIC, Conn., Aug. 20. -- The Connecticut Peace Society, with the Universal Peace Union, convened for its yearly meeting in Peace Grove to-day. Upon the platform were many delegates and speakers, among them being Mrs. Belva A. Lockwood of Washington, D.C.; John Branson, Dr. S.T. Evanson, John Collins, Oliver S. Fell of Philadelphia, M.R. Leverson of Staten Island, W.G. Brown of Toronto, Canada, and George Foster of Westerly.

The Board of Health is taking vigorous measures to bring the tenement houses of New-York up to the best sanitary condition. Yesterday thirty-two of these dwellings were ordered vacated by the tenants unless the buildings were at once put in proper condition. Last week sixty-four tenements were put under similar proscription.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 20. -- It has been an Autumn day in Lenox, with the mercury registering only 65. The women driving have worn their wraps, and the golf players have not found it uncomfortable going around the links. The trees are beginning to turn, and the goldenrod is in blossom, which reminds the cottagers that Autumn is near at hand.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- An open letter from ex-Commissioner of Pensions Corporal Tanner to the present Commissioner, Mr. Lochren, is published here. It causes comment, for the reason that it contains a warm eulogy of Judge Lochren's action as Commissioner, and that it demands the dismissal of an old Republican clerk upon the ground that he refuses to do justice to claimants.
HASTINGS, Aug. 20. -- Play in the international chess masters' tournament was resumed at Brassey Institute, in this city, to-day at 1 P.M., when the twelfth round was played. The results:

The State Democracy's occupation is by no means gone. Its organization should not only be kept up, it should be fortified. It ought to be better organized in future than it ever has been in the past, certainly better organized than it is at present. The State Democrats will have work to do.
The Commissioners of Accounts are very hard at work investigating certain of the city departments, with the aid of the $100,000 appropriation which was authorized by the Legislature.

The desire of the Regatta Committee of the New-York Yacht Club to make an exhaustive investigation of the comparative merits of the Vigilant and the Defender can only be commended, both in justice to each of the competing yachts and for the safety of the cup of which the club is the custodian.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 20. -- The bitter church war which has been waged for the last four months between the Presbytery of Monmouth and the congregation of the First Presbyterian Church of this place ended in a stormy meeting to-night, in which the Presbytery of Monmouth was ignored.

LONDON, Aug. 20.--The Attorney General moved in the House of Commons today that as John Daly, recently elected to Parliament for Limerick, was a convict serving a term of imprisonment for felony, his election be canceled. Timothy Harrington, Parnellite, moved an amendment referring the case to a committee.

Lawrence Dunphy, Superintendent of Blackwell's Island, and the technical prisoner in the case which the City Magistrates have caused to be made under the Wild Cumulative Sentence Law, was in the private examination room of the Jefferson Market Court yesterday afternoon. He was accompanied by Commissioner Wright of the Department of Charities and Correction and a number of other people who are interested in the case.

A new traffic agreement, which will practically control the Competitive freight business of all the railroads in the Southern States, was formally adopted at a largely attended meeting in the Hotel Waldorf yesterday. The new agreement forms the plan of action of the Southern States Freight Association, which is the successor of the old Southern Railway and Steamship Association.
Col. George E. Waring, Jr., Commissioner of Street Cleaning, returned to New-York yesterday from Newport, where he had been taking a vacation for a few days.

Special Policeman Charles Rogers, who is employed as watchman at Madison Street and Marcy Avenue, Brooklyn, effected the capture yesterday afternoon of a young man who is believed to be one of a gang of burglars and sneak thieves who have been operating successfully in Brooklyn.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 20. -- The ninth triennial session of the National Council of Congregational Churches will be held in this city Oct. 9 to 14 inclusive. It will be attended by 400 or more of the leading divines, educators, and business men of the country embraced in that denomination, as well as fraternal delegates from Great Britain, Canada, and Australia.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 20. -- The horrors of the Gumry Hotel catastrophe grow more pronounced as the work of recovering bodies proceeds. The scene to-day was sickening. Five bodies were taken from the ruins, making thirteen in all. It is supposed that thirteen more are still buried under tons of debris.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 20. -- The preliminary examination of William E. Brockway, the counterfeiter, ended to-day with a decision by United States Commissioner Isaac Romaine holding the prisoner for the action of the United States Grand Jury which meets in Trenton on Sept. 17.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- The President has granted a pardon to William T. Antley, convicted in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Alabama of illicit distilling, and sentenced April 16, 1895, to imprisonment for one year and one day in the Kings County Penitentiary, Brooklyn, and a fine of $500 and costs.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20. -- The long-looked-for yacht race between Cornelius Vanderbilt, Jr.'s, Ilderim, and August Belmont's Mineola was sailed to-day. Both are in the same sloop class and have been rival boats for several years. It was thought they would have it out in the late cruise of the New-York Yacht-Club, but Mr. Vanderbilt did not go in with Ilderim.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- This is the fourth week of the Saratoga Summer lectures, and the attendance to-day was very large. Prof. G. Frederick Wright delivered a lecture upon "Greenland, Its Scenery and People."

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 20. -Another beautiful day furnished opportunity for many driving parties to find enjoyment. Mr. and Mrs. David Wadsworth, Miss Wadsworth, Miss Gates, Miss Hollister, and Mrs. Evans, from the Spring House, drove over to Five-Mile Point for an Otsego bass dinner.
ALBANY, Aug. 20. -- The following appears in the published report of the proceedings of the Third Assembly District Convention of Oneida County held at Rome yesterday:

Mr. Ireland, the owner of the building that collapsed on West Broadway and killed fifteen people in its fall, was not in court yesterday, in spite of what was understood to be the assurance of his counsel the day before that he would be present. Yesterday the counsel explained that his client would be present when he was wanted.

Democratic State Committeeeman John W. Weber of Brooklyn is in favor of harmony in the Democratic ranks this Fall. He believes the two factions in Kings County should get together and unite upon a policy of action.
Ex-Congressman John Van Voorhis of Rochester was in this city yesterday. He will sail to-day on the New-York for London.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- As Grand Circuit meetings always begin quietly at this point, little was expected from the first card this afternoon. The big grand stand did not have a thousand occupants, and with the betting confined to private wagers with three bookmakers, the day was a dull one. There are plenty of good performers engaged later in the week, and on Thursday Alix is to be shown.
LONDON, Aug. 20. -- The United States cruiser San Francisco sailed from Gravesend for Havre to-day.

William J. Winberg, a prominent East New-York banker, a member of the banking firm of Edward F. Linton Co. of Brooklyn and a member of the Union League Club of that city, shot his wife, Susan, through the right side last evening at their home in Drew Avenue, just over the Kings County line, in Queens County.

SOUTHAMPTON, Aug. 20. -- The American Line's new steamer St. Louis had an official trial to-day, and maintained a speed of 22 3-10 knots per hour for over four hours, carrying the Stars and Stripes faster than any flag had ever been carried through the English Channel.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 20. -- The grand ball and reception which is being given tonight at the Kebo Valley Club to Secretary Herbert and the officers of the North Atlantic Squadron is, perhaps, the most brilliant affair of its kind ever held in Bar Harbor. Nearly a thousand invitations were sent out, and nearly as many persons are here to-night, crowding the clubhouse and theatre to overflowing.

The New-York's had a narrow escape from defeat at the hands of the St. Louis Club in the game of baseball yesterday at the Polo Grounds. There were scarcely 1,000 spectators present. The first part of the game dragged along slowly, and was monotonous. Neither side seemed to be able to do any batting except in the second inning, when the St. Louis team scored the first run of the game.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 20. -- The Chicago and West Michigan passenger train which left Chicago at 5 o'clock to-night was stopped by four robbers one and a half miles south of New-Richmond, at 9:40 this evening.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 20. -- A good stiff southwest breeze prevailed here nearly all day, which cooled the air splendidly, but it had a tendency to cause less bathing than in the last few days.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 20.--Notice of appeal from the General Term to the Court of Appeals has been filed by the defendants in the case of Harry Sneck against the Travelers' Insurance Company. This case involves an interesting question that has no precedent in this State, and has had a curious history in the courts.

SARANAC LAKE, Aug. 20. -- For a few days there has been no recital of "remarkable fish catches," for the Adirondack tourist is no longer fishing. He has taken his rifle and hunting knife and is camping out with friends in search of red deer. The hunting season opened on Thursday and hundreds have gone into camp from the hotels.

Inadequate foundations. These words sum up the opinion of H. Waller Brinckerhoff, an engineering expert, as to the probable cause of the collapse of the Ireland Building at West Third Street and West Broadway, whereby sixteen mechanics and laborers lost their lives. Contractor John H. Parker, the contractor for the erection of the building, appeared to be uneasy when Mr. Brinckerhoff thus expressed his belief to the Coroner's jury.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- Richard Crowley, who is in the field for the Republican nomination for Senator from the Forty-fifth District, has had a notable career in politics. He was elected to the Senate from the Niagara County district in 1865, when he was twenty-nine years old, and sat four years in that body.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- Consul Claude Meeker, at Bradford, in a report received at the Department of State, on the English Consular Service, says that it may appear strange, but it is nevertheless true, that the United States Consular Service, in a certain sense, is at present being held up to public view in England as a model after which the English Government should copy.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20. -- Society had a very busy day with a yacht race, lawn tennis, and polo on the programme. Attention had to be divided between the three, and neither received full justice. Cottagers gathered to-night at East Bourne Lodge, the Summer residence of Mrs. W. Fitzhugh Whitehouse, who gave a ball for her son, Harry Whitehouse.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 20. -- Ex-Senator William D. Edwards of Jersey City, and Alan Strong of New-Brunswick have made an application to Vice Chancellor Pitney on behalf of Attorney General Stockton, for an injunction to prevent the Brunswick Trolley Company, of which Gottfried Crueger is President, from building trolley lines in the townships of Middelsex County. W.P. Voorhees of New-Brunswick will represent the company.

LONDON, Aug. 20. -- The Morning Post to-morrow will say that it is learned that N.R. O'Conor, British Minister to China, has been fully authorized to demand that the Chinese Government issue any necessary directions to the local officials to insure a complete and satisfactory inquiry into the massacre of Christians at Ku-Cheng.

The scenes of Monday in the Court of General Sessions and the Court of Special Sessions may fairly be taken as evidence that the saloons have surrendered. It is to be hoped that the surrender will be followed by a compliance with the law hereafter in good faith, if not with cheerfulness.

Having taken account of his stock of heavy guns and mortars completed or under construction for the coastwise forts, Gen. Flagler finds that $48,000,000 more will be required to complete their armament, according to the present plans.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Aug. 20. -- Unless there is a sharp and sudden change in the political temperature, the nomination for Governor will be bestowed by the Democratic State Convention to-morrow upon ex-Gov. James E. Campbell by acclamation. All afternoon and evening the bands have been playing "The Campbells Are Coming," and the thousands in the streets have taken up the refrain.
LIMA, Peru, via Galveston, Aug. 20. -- The term allowed to the Bolivian Government for its reception of the Peruvian Minister, La Paz, or for the latter's return expires to-day.

COLLEGE POINT, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- Daniel S. Johnston, Jr., who keeps a bicycle store in this village, had a narrow escape from being killed this afternoon. Johnston and a friend named Albert Rubsamen decided to take a spin to Whitestone. While riding along Whiteside Avenue, Flushing, opposite Village Trustee Mitchell's residence, Johnston ran into two wagons.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 20. -- The announcement is made to-day that the Chambers-McKee Glass Company of New-Kensington will agree to the proposed wage scale of the window glass workers, and as this firm practically controls the situation the danger of a strike is thereby averted. In view of this fact it is probable that at the meeting to-morrow a general settlement on the basis of a 10 per cent. advance will be agreed upon.

The Directors of the Park National Bank, Broadway, near Fulton Street, met yesterday at the bank and elected Edward E. Poor President of the bank to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Ebenezer K. Wright.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- The friends of Miss Haswell have insisted from the start that as soon as she learned of the charges made against her in connection with the escape of Oliver Curtis Perry from the Matteawan Asylum she would clear herself, of any intentional wrongdoing in the transaction. The following was received to-day by H.O.H. Tucker from Miss Haswell, now at Ocean Grove:

NEWTON, Kan., Aug. 20. -- The most destructive hailstorm in the history of the county did great damage to crops and buildings about 6 o'clock last night. Hailstones larger than hens' eggs fell, and piled up until they resembled snow banks. The storm came from the northwest, and the velocity of the wind was very high.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 20. -- Wheelmen in this section are greatly incensed over the action of residents of Stratford, Fairfield, Milford, and Southport in sprinkling tacks along the main thoroughfares of those towns, and legal proceedings are talked of.

The potent "pull" of the Third Avenue Railroad Company with the present Board of Aldermen is apparently just as strong now as it was a few months ago, when, in the face of public opinion, the board granted the application of that company for the King's Bridge Road franchise. The Mayor vetoed this resolution, and then both the Metropolitan Traction Company and the Third Avenue Company renewed their applications.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20. -- The result of the election here to-night is a victory for Senator Quay and a defeat for the combination of politicians throughout the State who tried to overthrow him.
PANAMA, via Galveston, Aug. 20. -- Dr. Jacinto Castellano, Minister of Foreign Affairs of Salvador, asks that the following dispatch be published:

In preparing these otherwise excellent letters for publication, (or rather in not preparing them for publication, as they were not written for the public,) the author should have given them more careful preparation. The book should not contain so many colloquial abbreviations or contractions. So much by way of fault finding.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- The Indiana, the first of the three coast-line battleships to be launched, was authorized by act of Congress, approved June 30, 1890, appropriating for the construction of three battleships, at an individual cost not exceeding $4,000,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21. -- Conventions to nominate candidates for county offices and for delegates to the Republican State Convention at Harrisburg on Wednesday were held to-day. The county conventions excited little interest, as they were of the cut-and-dried order, and the delegate conventions absorbed all the attention, as, upon the result of their action there probably hung the mastery of the Republican Party leadership in Pennsylvania.

It would not be wise for those who are interested in the supremacy of the United States on the high seas to become panic-stricken because the Defender was overcome by stress of weather in Tuesday's race. But at the same time it would be very foolish to conclude that similar weather would be too much for the Valkyrie.

ALBANY, Aug. 21. -- The Von der Oudermeulen-Manning wedding at noon to-day was not only of interest because of the family connections of the bride and groom, but of international concern as well, because the bride will be the first American woman to be taken as a bride into the Court circles of Holland.

It is unfortunate for the cause of Ireland that John Daly should have allowed himself to become a candidate for the House of Commons while he was yet a convict serving a term of imprisonment for having been concerned in a dynamite plot. It is still more unfortunate that all the Nationalist members of the House should have voted to refer his case to a committee instead of acquiescing in the canceling of his election.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- This is Chautauqua Commencement Day, and is called "Recognition Day." The graduates of the class of '95 of the Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle went through the customary exercises of passing the "golden gate," marching up and down the avenues, afterward receiving their diplomas.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- Genuine Autumnal weather has prevailed to-day, and has been universally appreciated.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- Unless there is a much increased attendance at the driving park to-morrow, the local association is likely to follow the example of Buffalo and make this the last Grand Circuit meeting in this city. The cool weather, accompanied by a high wind, made it quite uncomfortable for the spectators and horses this afternoon, so it was a relief when ten heats cleared the card.

William Cullen Bryant is the candidate of Jacob Worth and his friends for the Republican Mayoralty nomination in Brooklyn. This information is not obtained personally from Mr. Worth or Sheriff Buttling, but it is reliable news.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- The army signal officers have equipped the service with an ingenious arrangement for distributing telegraph and telephone wires. It was found that in throwing insulated or naked wire on the ground preparatory to establishing communicating stations, the weight of the reel containing the wire was considerable, and it had to be carried in some sort of a handcart.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 21. -- Margaret Faulkner, fifteen years old, of 95 Pamrapo Avenue, was the victim of a frightful accident this morning. She was employed at Chadwick Brothers' thread mills.
