While crossing the room in which she works, her dress was caught in the belt of a big wheel, and in an instant she was whirling around the wheel between it and the belt.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 21. -- A rather quiet day was the result of last night's gayety. Even the golf links at Kebo were deserted. To-night, however, society has turned out in full force to attend the dinner and dance at Kebo.

SARATOGA, Aug. 21. -- The feature of the racing here to-day was the Spencer Handicap, J.W. Rogers's colt, Sir Excess, won in a big romp by four lengths from Saragosso, with the California crack, Rey el Santa Anita, a poor third.

Foreign exchange weakened perceptibly to-day, the posted rates being reduced 2 1/2 cent on the pound. This is the first official recognition of the change which is hovering over the market, and it was greeted with satisfaction by the bulls and corresponding alarm by the bears. The reduction induced active covering by the short interest, which, together with some buying for the advance, caused the railway list to be strong.

The annual Autumn meet of the New-York State Division of the League of American Wheelmen, to be held at Buffalo on Sept. 5 and 6, promises to be a much greater success than the State Division meet held at the Manhattan Beach track on June 15.

William E. Stillings, an attorney of 271 Broadway, sent a reply yesterday to the Police Board's recent request for an explanation as to why he did not withdraw his voucher for the good moral character of John F. McLaughlin, a candidate for appointment on the police.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- Passed East-Steam yachts Theresa Gustavus Sidenberg; Aquila, estate of George A. Thayer; Katrina, Henry F. Noyes; Ava. John H. Gourlie; Alicia, H.M. Flagler; Lorna, W.L. Stowe, and Orienta, E.R. Ladew.

An authoritative statement was issued yesterday in contradiction of the persistent rumors that the negotiations between J. Pierpont Morgan, James J. Hill, President of the Great Northern, and the Adams Committee of Northern Pacific bondholders had failed.

Walter P. Phillips, General Manager of The United Press, who is in town for a few days, talked freely with the editor of The Evening Post yesterday as to the outlook of The United Press and The Chicago Associated Press, which are at war with each other. Mr. Phillips said:

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 21. -- The Nashville, Chattanooga and St. Louis Railroad yesterday petitioned for the removal of S.M. Felton, receiver for the Cincinnati Southern Line. The latter road, by sharp manoeuvring and the use of a large force of men employed on Sunday, secured valuable right of way in Chattanooga that had previously been leased to the Nashville line, but was not yet in its possession.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- The reunion of the Seven County Veteran Association was held at Montrose, Penn., to-day, and it is estimated that 25,000 strangers attended. Armed escorts met the delegations at the station, and a salute of five guns announced the arrivals. They were then escorted through profusely decorated streets to the headquarters.

The performance of the St. Louis, under the official test to determine whether she was fast enough to be entitled to carry the United States mails, is a proper subject for National congratulation. Indeed, it should console us for the showing that the Columbia is not fast enough perfectly to fulfill her avowed mission as a "commerce destroyer."

The writ of habeas corpus sought by Foster L. Backus in the interest of William Starr Henry, who is accused of the murder of his father, Charles W. Henry, at 95 South Portland Avenue, Brooklyn, June 14, was returnable in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, before Justice Gaynor, yesterday. The alleged murderer was in court, as was also his brother, Walter, the "good son."

The East River Bridge Commissioners, after a two hours secret session in their rooms at the Emigrant Savings Bank Building yesterday, adopted a resolution rejecting the propositions made by Frederick Uhlmann, President of the East River Bridge Company and instructing Engineer Buck to survey a new line for the construction of a bridge between New-York and Brooklyn.

SHELTER ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 21. -- The Rev. Richard S. Storrs, pastor of the Church of the Pilgrims of Brooklyn, who is spending the Summer in his cottage, Sunset Ridge, on Divinity Hill, celebrated his seventy-fourth anniversary to-day. Many friends called at the cottage to congratulate him.
BERLIN, Aug. 21. -- Herr von Puttkamer, formerly Governor of the Fogo District, has been appointed Governor of the Cameroons.
The State Democracy will have nothing to do with Tammany at the primaries for the election of delegates to the State Convention. This was decided very positively at last night's meeting of the State

FLUSHING, L.I., Aug. 21. -- An express train, consisting of locomotive No. 75, one baggage car, and one coach, left Main Street station for Long Island City at 1:11 this afternoon. The train was in charge of Conductor David Williams. The engineer was Gus Ransford, and with him was a fireman named Schellinger. The drawbridge over Flushing Creek is not much over half a mile from the Main Street station.

Acting under the advice of the Tree Planting and Fountain Society, citizens of Brooklyn have begun to preserve their trees, but Lewis Collins, Secretary of the society, said yesterday that much still remains to be done.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- On the face of the returns, the Democratic caucuses held last evening settled nothing in the way of reorganization. According to all reports so far received, the Smith faction has carried the First and Third Assembly Districts, while the Page faction has carried the Second and Fourth, thus making the vote on State Committeeman a tie, unless some agreement between the leaders can be arrived at.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- The official figures issued to-day show that the general Treasury balance stands at $181,534,897. This includes $2,376,277, disbursed on account of bonds and interest this month, which will not appear until the statement for August appears on Sept. 1.
Mrs. Ira Lowe says she was wickedly deceived by her husband. She declares that he married her for her money.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 21. -- It has been a great day for sailing on Mahkeenac Lake, and of the three boats on the lake Miss Sands was the winner. The new Stokes yacht will be on the water next week. It is the finest, and it is believed will prove the fastest, boat on the lake.

Prof. Goldwin Smith writes to The London Times exhorting the English Conservatives and Unionists to reform the House of Lords. The upper house, he thinks, should be "reformed by its friends," as the high protectionists used to say about the tariff, and he points out to its friends that if they do not reform it, its enemies will.

GOTHENBURG, Neb., Aug. 21. -- The Union Pacific train No. 8, the east-bound overland flier, arrived here at 3:10 this morning with the passengers in a state of great excitement the express car shattered by dynamite, and riddled with bullets, and the trainmen badly scared. The train was stopped and robbed by bandits in a cut half way between Brady's Island and this place at 1 o'clock this morning.

The Metropolitan District Cricket League met at the Cricketers' Club Tuesday night. The coming visit of the Cambridge University team was the chief topic of discussion. It was definitely announced that all arrangements had been made to have the team play here on Labor Day and the following Tuesday and Wednesday, Sept. 3 and 4, and a committee was appointed to make all arrangements, and attend to all details of the game.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 21. -- Three Sunday schools were enjoying their annual excursion to-day. St. Luke's Methodist Episcopal, First Methodist Episcopal, and the Elberon Memorial, about 700 strong, journeyed to Asbury Park. The Elberon Memorial School, which is made up principally of city people summering here, will go on record as being the first excursion on the new trolley line.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- The Navy Department is the subject of some unjust criticism at present on account of its failure to hold extensive naval manoeuvres on the North Atlantic station. It has been asserted by the eager experts in such matters that the departmental officials have some covert reason for not ordering a fleet to play war in Long Island Sound, or attack imaginary foes in Boston Harbor.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 21. -- The fourth annual regatta of the Hempstead Bay Yacht Club was sailed to-day in a stiff southwesterly wind, over an eight-mile course opposite the clubhouse on Elder Island in the Great South Bay. The weather was all that could be desired for yachting. The sky was clear and the wind continued strong during the entire race.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 21. -- The general election for delegates to the Constitutional Convention, which will meet Sept. 10, was held in this State yesterday.
The regular meeting of the Park Board was held in the Arsenal yesterday morning, and the Commissioners had some odd questions to consider.

MONTREAL, Aug. 21. -- The forthcoming volume of the year book of Canada will contain an interesting chapter on the result of the late revision of the Dominion voters' lists, compared with the lists as they stood at the general elections of 1882, 1889, and 1891.
Frank L. Fisher Co. have sold for William Buhler, the four-story brownstone house, 20x60x100, 124 West Eightieth Street, to William Radham.

Whatever ground Senator Brice may have given for criticism of his course in the past, he is entitled to credit for his part in the successful effort to head the Democratic Party right on the currency question in Ohio this year. Yesterday's convention at Springfield reaffirmed the sound-money plank of the National platform on 1892 and commended the policy of the present Administration at Washington.

READING, Penn., Aug. 21. -- The body of ex-Justice William Strong arrived in Reading last night, and was taken to the chapel in Charles Evans Cemetery. This morning a plaster mask was taken of the face of the deceased by U.S.J. Dunbar of Washington.

ALBANY, Aug. 21. -- A letter has been received at the office of the Superintendent of Public Instruction, the writer of which, Deputy Superintendent Ainsworth thinks, has some of God's sunshine in his make-up. Aside from the poetical method employed, the sentiment expressed therein Mr. Ainsworth thinks laudable.
The German-American Reform Union has issued the following invitation to German-Americans to participate in the primaries for reorganization to be held to-night:

The use of aluminium plates in the construction of the yacht Defender has attracted unusual attention to that metal, while the report of the naval experts at Norfolk, Va., against its use on naval vessels, because of its corrosive tendencies, has raised a fear that it may lessen the chances of the American yacht in the international race with the Valkyrie III.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- Ainsworth R. Spofford, the Librarian of Congress, to-day transferred $22,000 from his private bank account to the Treasury of the United States.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Aug. 21. -- Sir Charles Rivers Wilson, President of the Grand Trunk Railway, has arrived in this city. Being asked what he thought of that part of the line which he had already inspected, he said:

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 21. -- The races of the Bridgeport Wheel Club took place at the Pleasure Beach track, this city, this afternoon. The track was slow on account of recent repairs, and, with a strong wind, prevented fast time. The races were:

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21. -- Another fine day favored the tennis players and the big field of would-be champions was cut down to seventeen, all but one of the second-round contests being decided. A big crowd flocked around the courts. As there were no specially prominent matches, the spectators were spread over the ground and hardly a court was without a fringe of Summer girls and their escorts.

Joseph G. Rampone was a very happy man last night as he led his Old Guard Band at the open-air concert in Abingdon Square, for his little daughter, Kitty was encored several times by the audience of about 15,000 people.
That the saloon men have been acting in concert in the fight against the Sunday excise laws, was made evident yesterday by Frederick B. House, counsel to the Central Association of Liquor Dealers.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Aug. 21. -- "Sound money" is the watchword of the Ohio Democracy this year. The advocates of free-silver coinage were overwhelmed in the State Convention to-day, being scarcely able to muster a total vote equal to the majority against them.

OLD ORCHARD CAMPGROUND, Me., Aug. 21 -- There are thousands here, and thousands are coming and going daily with as much precision as the flow of the water upon the velvety beach. There is something remarkable about these Maine Methodists that you do not find among the people of that denomination in the Southern and Middle States.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- County Judge Chester B. McLaughlin of Port Henry, Essex County, is the Fourth Judicial District Republican candidate for Justice of the Supreme Court. So largely Republican is the district that his election is substantially assured. The district covers eleven counties -- Warren, Saratoga, Washington, Essex, Franklin, St. Lawrence, Clinton, Montgomery, Hamilton, Fulton, and Schenectady.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- The case of John L. Waller, ex-Consul of the United States at Tamatave, Madagascar, and now in prison in France, has assumed a phase that justifies this Government in the belief that Wailer's days of confinement are nearly ended, and that he will soon be restored to liberty.

The Court of Special Sessions, Justice Jerome presiding, with Justices Jacob and Hayes, made a departure yesterday in meting out punishment to the dealers in adulterated milk. Instead of simply imposing fines ranging from $25 to $50 on dealers convicted of offering for sale impure or adulterated milk, as had been the custom, the Court fined Nathan Chasatsky, a "jobber" in milk, $100 and sentenced him to imprisonment in the Tombs for thirty days.
LONDON, Aug. 21. -- The following cable dispatch has been received at the London offices of the Wesleyan Missionary Society:

Again the Railroad Committee of the Aldermen has reported in favor of awarding the King's Bridge Road franchise to the corporation that runs the Third Avenue cars instead of to the Metropolitan Traction Company.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- In the course of the discussion of the Foreign Office estimates in the House of Commons to-day James Bryce, President of the Board of Trade in the Rosebery Ministry, said that the reforms which the Government asked to have instituted in Armenia were the least that could be accepted. The position of Christians throughout the East, he declared, was extremely perilous.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 21. -- Detectives Cosgrove, Carroll, and Jaekes went to 1%0selle this morning and arrested Gottlied Gedicke, aged twenty-nine years; Arthur Glassen, eighteen years, and Bertha Goff, aged twenty-one years, on the charge of being accomplices of Adam Wissel, now in the Essex County Jail for burglary.
TROY, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- At the second days' session of the State Firemen's Convention at the City Hall to-day, the following officers were elected:

NORWICH, Conn., Aug. 21. -- The games in the National Croquet Tournament went along smoothly to-day. President-elect Abner B. Holly of New-York has charge of the assigning of the grounds and players, and succeeded in pushing the games along so far in the first two days of the tournament that it was decided to have first-division players play two games with each other, instead of one as usual. Score:

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21. -- A terrible tempest in the early morning awakened society to a day of great social activity, and left the air clear and cool and the sky azure blue, without a cloud to mar it, conditions most auspicious for the unusually brilliant events of the day and evening.

Sidney S. Jacquelin, the young man who posed as the Count de La Rochelle, and was convicted in the Court of Special Sessions of larceny, for having pawned four rings which he had borrowed from Miss Marian Eyre, a telegraph operator of 240 East Thirty-third Street, was before Justices Jerome, Jacob, and Hayes yesterday for sentence.

NEW-RICHMOND, Mich., Aug. 21. -- The Sheriff and his posse, together with railroad detectives, are on the trail of the five robbers who held up the Chicago and West Michigan train near Fennville last night. They have tracked them four miles toward Allegan. The entire county has been aroused, and posses are out in every direction.

The man who returned a suit of clothes, complaining that there were moths in the coat, and was asked if he expected humming birds for $5.37, received about as much satisfaction as the average individual does nowadays who complains to his up-to-date laundryman that his linen has been rolled to the consistency of tissue paper. The laundryman complacently replies that the linen is at fault.

Edward S. Flow, colored, a delegate to the Republican County Committee from the old Eleventh Assembly District, was blackballed by the James G. Blaine Republican Club of the new Twenty-fifth Assembly District last night. This is the club that has been controlled by the Mayor's Secretary, Job E. Hedges. Mr. Hedges spoke in favor of Flow's admission.
TACOMA, Washington, Aug. 21. - The lynching of the Vinsons, father and son, at Ellensburg and the arrest of the lynchers are causing great excitement.

HOTEL CHAMPLAIN, Clinton County, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- The sailing races scheduled for to-day at the camp of the American Canoe Association here were postponed until to-morrow on account of a strong west wind, which kicked up a very, rough sea. Four paddling races were run off, beginning at noon.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21. -- Correspondence of The United Press, per Steamer Australia, Honolulu, Aug. 14: The Executive, Aug. 12, laid before both houses of the Legislature the expected contract made with Z.S. Spalding to grant a subsidy and exclusive franchise in return for laying and operating a cable from San Francisco to Honolulu.

ALBANY, Aug. 21. -- The Platt Republicans count upon securing twenty-eight of the thirty-one Senators to be elected outside of New-York and Kings Counties. The doubtful districts are the Twenty-ninth, Albany; the Fortieth, Tompkins, Schuyler, and Chemung, and the Thirty-fourth, Oneida.

John B. Ireland, the owner of the building at West Broadway and Third Street, whose presence has been much sought by the Coroner and the jury investigating the circumstances attending the deaths of fifteen persons who were killed when the structure collapsed, strolled into Part III. of General Sessions, where the inquest is being held, yesterday, and was seemingly an amused spectator of the proceedings.

In the party of Americans that made the trip to Blarney Castle this day was a handsome young Chicago girl. There was also a Chicago dentist in the party. The drive to the castle was delightful. It was through a magnificent country. And the road -- well, every tourist from the United States goes into ecstasy over the roads of Ireland.

John O'Brien's attempt to prevent the Aqueduct Board from letting the Jerome Park Reservoir contract to any one but himself has been defeated. Justice O'Brien, in the Supreme Court, handed down a decision yesterday, holding that, though O'Brien was the lowest bidder on the work by $174,000, the Aqueduct Commissioners were by no means bound to award to him the contract.
SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 22. -- Capt. Higgins of the steamer Excelsior, directly from St. Michael's and Unalaska, brings news of the wreck of the sealing schooner Walter Earle of Victoria.

WEEHAWKEN, N. J., Aug. 22. -- Three men were painting the house of Donald Smith, 10 Pleasant Avenue, this morning, when one of the ropes broke and they were thrown from the third story to the ground. John Strasser of 172 Palisade Avenue, Union Hill, had his collarbone and three ribs broken, and was taken to Christ Hospital. His injuries are probably fatal.
Justice Tighe in the Adams Street Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, held Policeman Thomas J. Donovan of the Clymer Street Precinct for the Grand Jury on the charge of felony.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The Acting Secretary of State, Mr. Adee, authorizes the statement that information has been received from Ambassador Eustis in response to urgent instructions cabled him some three weeks ago that the record of the proceedings and evidence in the court-martial of Mr. Waller at Tamatave is expected to reach Paris toward the end of this month.

The congregation of the Howard Avenue African Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, went, yesterday, on its annual excursion to Forest View Grove, on the Hudson. The conveyances were the steamer John Lenox and two barges, and the stopping point the foot of Dock Street.

The grounds of the Staten Island Cricket Club at Livingston yesterday afternoon were the scene of a unique and interesting exhibition of cricket. Several well-known ladies, who live in the vicinity played against the regular cricketers of the club, the men being allowed to use only their left hands, and baseball bats instead of the large cricket bat.

ASHFIELD, Mass., Aug. 22. -- The sixteenth annual dinner in aid of Sanderson Academy was given to-day in the Town Hall. Hundreds drove in from the surrounding towns, and many came a much longer distance.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- "I see that some of my critics suggest that I should have my salary paid in gold," said Secretary Morton this afternoon.

MOUNT CLEMENS, Mich., Aug. 22. -- "Charlie" Murphy, the veteran, won the mile open race on the programme of the national circuit meeting in this city, and made a good ride in 2:01 2-5, two-fifths of a second faster than his former record, which Bald took from him at Chicago, and the State competitive record, besides being the fastest mile ever made in competition with tandem pacing.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 22. -- A serious fire broke out in the Union Steamboat dock and warehouse, on the Menominee River, at 1 o'clock to-day. The dock and warehouse are leased by the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railway Company. The wind was blowing almost a gale, and the fire spread to the Anchor Warehouse, and then to the freight houses of the company.
Upon an order of arrest granted by Justice O'Brien of the Supreme Court, Deputy Sheriff Walgering yesterday arrested Henry Herzog of 203 East One Hundred and Fourteenth Street.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The closing business session of the twenty-third annual meeting of the State Firemen's Association was held this morning. Resolutions thanking the citizens of Troy for hospitality and entertainment and expressing thanks to Senators Lexow, McCarren, and Coggeshall for efforts to secure legislation favorable to firemen were adopted.

The question arising out of the seizure of Trinidad by England has been discussed in this country almost entirely as a joke. Indeed, the comic aspects of it are the most striking. There is, in the first place, the fact that the island is a barren rock, upon which nothing can support life but ravenous land crabs, and that does not even afford fresh water.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 22. -- The Democratic State Convention here to-day nominated for Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, Charles J. Phelps of Colfax County, and for Regents of the State University A.T. Blackburn of Holt County and Robert Kettle of Dodge County. A free-coinage resolution, offered by ex-Congressman W.J. Bryan, Chairman of the Committee on Resolutions, was adopted by an overwhelming majority, only six votes being cast against it.
BUFFALO, Aug. 22. -- Congressman M.W. Howard, (Pop.,) from the Seventh Alabama District, the author of "If Christ Came to Congress," lectured before the Crystal Beach Assembly last night.

Capt. C.P. Staubach of the Manhattan Bicycle Club is going to try for several long-distance records on Sunday. He has made careful preparations for the effort, and, weather permitting, expects to meet with success. His plan is to ride to Philadelphia and back again, paced, and, according to his schedule, he should perform the feat in sixteen hours.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The fight here among the Republicans over the Fall election, and especially over the nomination for Mayor, is now on in earnest, the City Convention having been called for Monday evening, Sept. 23, and the city caucuses, those not already held, for next Monday night.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 22. -- The Casino Theatre was crowded to-night for charity's sake, the tableaus for the benefit of Newport Hospital being in order. It was a gay gathering of wealth and beauty. Tickets sold at $4 each, and a hundred more could have been disposed of at the same rate. In fact, in the theatre, there was not even standing room to be had.
Fenton Rockwell and Albert Knittle are lawyers who do a large part of their business in the Gates Avenue Police Court, Brooklyn, over which Justice Harriman presides.

CROTON LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The Republican Convention of the Third Assembly District was held to-day at Croton Dam. There were seventy-four delegates present, representing nine towns. Ex-Collector William H. Robertson was present as the leader of the Republican Party of the county, and one of the delegates from the Town of Bedford.
Mrs. Julia Hanson, forty-six years old, of 141 Sands Street, Brooklyn, quarreled with her husband last night, and then drank laudanum from a bottle. She threw the bottle at her husband's feet.

BRISTOL, R.I., Aug. 22. -- The Defender arrived here this afternoon, but was unfortunate enough to go aground on the southwest point of Hog Island. She had only her staysail set at the time, and went on easily. It was low water, and the rising tide floated her off after she had been fast about an hour.

LONDON, Aug. 22. -- Sir John Leng, member for Dundee, in the House of Commons to-day asked Mr. A.J. Balfour, First Lord of the Treasury, whether in consonance with the views he had repeatedly expressed he would advise that the Government invite the assembling of an international conference in order to obtain an agreement in regard to the currency.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of The New-York Times.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Aug. 22. -- Senator Baker yesterday received an autograph letter from John Waller, ex-Consul at Tamatave, written in his cell in a French prison, touching upon his imprisonment. Waller says:

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The Broome County Republican Assembly and County Conventions were held here this afternoon and were managed by the Platt faction, without even a murmur from the anti-machine element. In fact, Broome County promises to remain as in the past, the Platt stronghold of the southern tier.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Aug. 22. -- There is every reason to believe that some compromise has been agreed upon between the Dominion authorities and the Manitoba Government in the schools difficulty, and that a peaceful settlement will be reached in the near future.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 22. -- Ex-Gov. Luzon B. Morris died at 3 o'clock to-day, at his residence in Prospect Street, from an apoplectic stroke which he suffered in his office this morning.

Through the persistent and untiring efforts of Bishop John F. Hurst of Washington and the energy of an efficient building committee, the proposed American University at Washington has now taken tangible form, and within a few weeks ground will be broken for the first of the buildings which, when erected, will far outrival anything of the kind in the Capital City.

HONGKONG, Aug. 22. -- Information has been received here that a large mob of infuriated natives, armed with weapons of every conceivable kind, made an attack a few days ago upon the American mission near Foo-Chow and wrecked the chapel and school attached to the mission.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- It was learned to-day that Mr. Hixson and the commission started for Ku-Cheng before the formalities preliminary to the inquiry had been arranged with the Chinese Government, and before the State Department had sent full instructions to him.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22. -- Another of H.H. Holmes's mysterious buildings has been discovered. It is ten miles from the "Castle," which is on Sixty-third Street. The latest find is on Sobieska Street, near the tracks of the Northwestern Railroad. The building is all boarded up and residents of the vicinity say nothing has been done there for some time.

If the Democrats of this State fully realize the importance of controlling the Legislature for the next three years, for which the election of a majority of the Senators this year is necessary, they will not fail to take advantage of every division among their opponents and every defection on account of Platt's bossism, and they will refrain from dissensions of their own and from bossism on their side.

EGG HARBOR CITY, N.J., Aug. 22. -The forest fire that has been burning throughout the pine belt of New-Jersey since last Wednesday is as fierce as ever. Fortunately for Absecom the fire is being carried in an easterly direction, and the immediate danger for that pretty place is not great.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 22. -- Ex-Mayor Frank A. Magowan, the rubber manufacturer, who has been in financial and domestic difficulties for some time, was arrested this forenoon on a bench warrant, charged with criminal relations with Helen Edith Barnes, wife of John Albert Barnes, the Superintendent of the Eastern Rubber Company, one of the concerns controlled by Magowan until it passed, two weeks ago, into the hands of a receiver.
The German-American Reform Union held primaries for the purpose of reorganization under the reapportionment in all but four of the Assembly districts last night. Marked interest was shown in them.

With clear weather and a good track there is every promise that the race for the Futurity Stakes, worth close of $67,000, will furnish a grand struggle at Sheepshead Bay to-morrow. All of the youngsters have had their final trials and with the exception of Applegate, who made a sorrowful exhibition in his trial yesterday morning, all satisfied their trainers.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The Republican Judicial Convention for the Seventh District will be held in this city Sept. 7, to nominate two Justices of the Supreme Court. The representation by counties in the coming convention will be as follows: Monroe, 12; Cayuga, 6; Steuben, 6; Wayne, 3; Ontario, 3; Seneca, 3, and Livingston, 3; and 20 votes will be required to nominate.

Mr. Justice Tighe of Brooklyn has a great aversion to officers of the law who secure evidence of lawbreaking without the knowledge and consent of the lawbreakers. He has personal reasons for this aversion, which are as notorious as his connection with prizefighting at Coney Island.

The minutes of the police court hearing in the Henry murder case submitted in the habeas corpus proceedings in the Supreme Court, before Justice Gaynor, Wednesday were the subject of much discussion yesterday. Foster L. Backus, counsel for William S. Henry, the alleged murderer, said:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Representative Bankhead of Alabama to-day said: "I am very much afraid that the Democrats are planning to let the Republicans elect Governors this year in both Maryland and Kentucky. Contrary to the general opinion, I am even more afraid of such a result in Maryland than I am in Kentucky.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Miss Nellie C. Rhodes last night made a bicycle record for ten miles Of 32:15. The best record for a male rider is a little more than 10 minutes better than this.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 22. -- The polo tournament for pairs was continued to-day with two matches, and the result is that to-morrow E.C. Potter and Lawrence Waterbury of the Country Club of Westchester, and F.B. Fay and R.G. Shaw (second) of the Myopias of Boston meet in the finals for the cups. Much money has been wagered on the result.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The American flag is to have a place on the revenue cutters, despite the remarkable prejudices of some of the older officers of that service, and contrary to a custom which, curiously enough, has survived for quite a hundred years. The cutters engaged in behalf of the Government, officered and manned by those in the employ of the public service, have hitherto displayed only an emblem of the Revenue Cutter Service.

There was plenty of excitement in Arlington Hall, 19 St. Mark's Place, last night, where members of the Good Government Clubs of the new Fourteenth Assembly District met to hear Police Commissioner Theodore Roosevelt explain the attitude of himself and his colleagues in the Police Board regarding the enforcement of the excise law on Sundays.

The following appeal for aid for the victims of Turkish outrages in Armenia was issued yesterday. The people there, it is said, are threatened with famine, and in one district alone 860 houseless people are living in the woods and in great need of the necessities of life:

The racing at Aqueduct yesterday furnished the best day's sport of the week. The attendance was considerably larger than on the two preceding days, many who had been at Saratoga being present. Backers of first choices were in great glee throughout the afternoon, they nearly sweeping the card.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22. -- The ingrain carpet weavers strike, which was inaugurated July 11 for an advance in wages of 7 1/2 per cent., ended to-day in a practical victory for the strikers. The result was accomplished when twenty-two of the manufacturers, whose employes were on strike, met at the Manufacturers' Club and reached a conclusion that each firm should induce its operatives to return to work.

Joseph Dexter Jones, accused of being the chief of a gang of "green-goods" swindlers who have been operating with impunity at Bound Brook, N.J., and at South Bethlehem, Penn., was arrested on Wednesday evening at the Pacific House, South Bethlehem, and is now detained in the Moyamensing Prison in Philadelphia, awaiting removal to this city for trial.

The Pittsburgs were outplayed by the Brooklyns in the baseball game at Eastern Park, Brooklyn, yesterday. They were evidently not used to the cool breeze from Jamaica Bay and got chilled as they faced it at the home plate, as they only made one base hit and did not score at all.

The emphatic denial, by a gentleman whose relations to the Defender syndicate make his words authoritative, that any serious injury was done to the yacht in the trial race of last Tuesday will be very gratifying to all patriotic Americans. In the course of time our English friends are bound to get their cup back, and their chances have never appeared to be more favorable than they are now.
ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- At the session of the Microscopical Society this morning Prof. Rowlee read a paper on "The Chlorophyl Bodies of Chara Coronata."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The Post Office Department to-day gave out a statement of the gross receipts of the leading Post Offices of the country for the month of July, and the increase at each over the receipts for the same month in 1894. It shows a continued improvement in the general business conditions of the country. The table follows:

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 22. -- The first regular meet of the Red Bank Wheelmen, held to-day at Byram's track, was a success in every way. The weather was bright and the track, though a trifle dusty, was in good shape. There was a large crowd of spectators. Six events, all for Class A riders, and sanctioned by the League of American Wheelmen, were run off.

SARATOGA, Aug. 22. -- To-day's card here was, if anything, of a poorer character than that offered yesterday. The events filled badly, and by vigorous scratching the card was made worse. The attendance was good and the track fast.
Recorder Goff will start in earnest to-day on the excise cases transferred from Special Sessions to General Sessions for trial. The day's grist of convictions promises to be an unusually large one.
The Good Government workers in Brooklyn are visibly discouraged over the recentrevelations of political corruption, and the bad management of the county finances.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 22. -- The clear, slightly warmer weather of to-day attracted every one out of doors, and there great deal of driving and golf playing. All the players were down at the links this morning and made the rounds. There were also many spectators in the tents, and on the piazza of the little clubhouse. J. Egmont Schermerhorn, Wright Barclay, John E. Alexandre, Parkman Shaw, and Mr. Cotting were among those who played.

In another column appears an appeal in behalf of the Armenian subjects of Turkey. It is issued by an American committee, which is acting in concert with that formed in England to raise funds and save these wretched victims of Moslem fanaticism from starving to death during the months that must intervene before the slowly acting powers can force the Porte to undertake long-needed reforms.

Five persons were arrested yesterday by direction of Coroner Edward T. Fitzpatrick, as a result of the testimony so far adduced in the investigation of the Ireland Building disaster, whereby sixteen lives were lost. This makes a total of seven persons now under arrest in connection with the case.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 22. -- The Iron Trade Review says advances in Bessemer pig iron, gray forge, steel billets, and wire rods have taken place in the past week, and in all lines of finished iron and steel the tendency is still upward, though with relatively less business than in raw materials.

More than usual interest will attend the arrival of the American Line steamship Paris, now on her way from Southampton, and due to arrive to-morrow. The vessel is fresh from a dry dock where she was cleaned and freshly painted, and it has been predicted that on this voyage she will establish a new speed record.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- A statement received at the State Department from Mayroyeni Bey, the Turkish Minister to this country, indicates that the reported attack on St. Paul's College, an American institution at Tarsus, Armenia, was erroneous.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- At the instigation of Mr. C. O'D. Iselin of this place a warrant was sworn out last Monday by William H. Shulte, a constable at Hudson Park, for the arrest of Capt. Charles Morss of the yacht J.S.N., owned by F.B. Van Derveer of 503 West End Avenue, New-York.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22. -- In the general political shaking up which will follow the overthrow of the Martin-Porter combine in this city, James McManes is to be sent to Congress.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 22. -- Interest in the camp meeting increases daily. The first service to-day, the consecration meeting, held at 5:45 A.M., found a goodly number of devout Methodists in the Tabernacle. The family devotions, held an hour later in the Auditorium, were also well attended. The Temple was crowded at the young people's meeting, and hundreds were unable to get inside the big building.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- According to a report to the Department of State, by Consul Eugene Germain, at Zurich, the destruction of vineyards in Italy by an insect commonly known as the vine louse has been enormous. Since the appearance of the insect in that country, it has totally ruined 282,529 acres of vineyards and 186,160 acres partly so.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The State Legislative Committeemen on Good Roads returned last night delighted with their drive. They pronounced the road around Canadarago Lake the finest in the State, and perhaps the fact that J. Lee Tailer took them the twelve miles, with twelve persons on the drag, in an hour and fifteen minutes without turning a hair on his horses, speaks more for the roadbed than they possibly could.

The dilatoriness of the proceedings that the Chinese Government has taken in satisfying the claims of England and the United States has borne its natural fruit in another outrage. Of this the American missionaries are the victims. By pure chance no American citizen has been done to death at Foo-Choo, for it seems that the victims of the mob have all been converts and Chinese subjects.
LIMA, Peru, via Galveston, Aug. 22. -American missionaries whom Cuzco would not welcome, threatening riot if the Government prevented their expulsion, are returning to Lima by way of Oroya.
MYSTIC, Conn., Aug. 22. -- The treasurer's report showed the receipts of the Universal Peace Union for the past year to have been $1,348; disbursements, $1,312.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The season is waning, but the hotels are filled to the doors. There was an unusually heavy arrival to-night. This season will go into history as the most successful ever enjoyed by the Thousand Islands resorts.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22. -- In an interview Father Barnham, S.J., who has just returned from Alaska, said regarding the boundary between British Columbia and Alaska:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22. -- A number of racing men have incurred the displeasure of the Racing Board by recently competing in unsanctioned events. In the weekly bulletin of the board, the names of the offenders, together with the terms of suspension imposed as penalties, are given as follows:

NYACK, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The Grand Rockland Hotel, on the hill overlooking Rockland Lake, was burned to the ground this morning. The guests escaped. The fire started on the first floor. The flames were first discovered in the northeast corner of the building. One theory of the origin of the fire is that a lamp was upset in the storeroom.

The annual regatta of the Horseshoe Harbor Club of Larchmont, N.Y., will be sailed to-morrow, the start to be made promptly at 12 o'clock noon. It will be open to yachts under thirty-six feet, enrolled in any recognized club, the committee reserving the right to reject any entry. All yachts are to be classified by their racing length and according to the recommendations of the Yacht Racing Union, Long Island Sound.
Mrs. Grace T Terry was married when she was fourteen years old, and her husband, Charles G. Terry, was only eighteen years old. This was in November, 1892, but they have never lived together.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Although the centre of political activity is at present far removed from Washington, there is great interest shown here in the contests in Kentucky, Ohio, Maryland, and other States, where various issues are to the fore. The fight in Kentucky attracts unusual attention for the reason that for the first time in many years the Republicans appear to have hopes of electing their State ticket.

In our previous letter we affirmed that the Sassoun troubles were brought about by the criminal efforts of Armenian revolutionary committees, and that no reliance whatever ought to be placed on Armenian testimony and assertions. We now propose to prove these two affirmations, not by Turkish -- that is to say, Mussulman -- testimony, but by American and European -- namely, Christian testimony.

The East River Bridge Commission was quite right in rejecting the offer of the franchise of the East River Bridge Company which was submitted, and in deciding to proceed with its work. The only authority it has to negotiate with the bridge company is to agree upon a price for the franchise, if it finds it desirable to acquire it.

New-York's baseball team batted in something of their old form in the game with the St. Louis team yesterday at the Polo Grounds. The miserable style in which the local team have been playing ball since their return from the West caused a small crowd to be present.

The American Spirits Manufacturing Company, the successor to the Whisky Trust, was yesterday incorporated with the Secretary of State in Albany and also in New-York County. Its object, as set forth in the articles of incorporation, is to carry on a general business of distilling spirits, including the distilling, redistilling, and rectifying of high wines, alcohol, spirits, gins, and whiskies of all kinds, with principal business office in New-York City.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23. -- The suit of Theodore Fox, a stockholder in the Consolidated California and Virginia Mining Company, against John W. Mackay, Senator J.P. Jones, the Comstock Mill and Mining Company, the Consolidated California and Virginia Mining Company, and others, which involves nearly $2,000,000, has been begun before Judge Seawell.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23. -- John Mallin, who was employed by the Brush Electric Light Company, ascended a pole at Vine and Eleventh Streets this noon for the purpose of stringing a new wire. He had been working but a few moments when a scream of terror directed the gaze of passers-by to the network of wires.

It ought to be good news that seven persons have actually been put under arrest to await the verdict of the Coroner's inquest into the fall of the Ireland building. It is not credible that without somebody's criminal incompetence or negligence a new building should have collapsed before it was done and killed fifteen people in its fall.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- The Saratoga Association's running meeting of twenty-eight days came to a close this afternoon. To-night a large proportion of the sporting fraternity disappeared in the direction of Sheepshead Bay, where tomorrow they will see the Futurity race. Very few horses are left at Horse Haven.

The expected tilt between Coroner Hoeber and Lawyer William F. Howe at the inquest on the body of little John Tracy, who was run over by John Lambritus in Washington Square, Aug. 14, did not take place yesterday. The hearing instead was conducted with the utmost decorum and there was not an incident to mar the dignity of the proceedings.

In Paris the first French temperance society has just been founded by Dr. Legrain, physician of the Paris lunatic asylums. The society's pledge, which English abstainers will remark dose not enjoin total abstinence, is as follows: "I promise, firstly, to abstain entirely except on medical advice from brandy and all liquors; secondly, to make use only in moderation of wine, beer, or cider."

FRANKLIN, N.J., Aug. 23. -- The burglars who visited a dozen or more houses here Wednesday night and created considerable excitement in this little town came back and continued their work last night in spite of the vigilance of the citizens.
A correspondent, whose sex we decline to divulge, sends us the following twenty-one answers to the above question, "Why I Hate Woman:"

It is significant of increased interest in the East that two publishing firms should have revived this book, for many years out of print, and it is to be hoped that the resurrection will prove permanent. We have already noticed the one-volume Macmillan edition, but the Chicago firm's enterprise gives opportunity for again commenting on a charming and vital book.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Commissioner of Indian Affairs Browning yesterday received a novel letter from four Mojave Indians, who are returning to their reservation after a tour of the country with one of the large circuses. The Indians want to take some souvenirs home to prove to their people that they have traveled extensively, among them photographs of the Commissioner and Assistant Commissioner Smith, whom they designate as the "big" and "little" Commissioner.

Commissioner Waring of the Street Cleaning Department yesterday reinstated H.C. Corsa as a District Superintendent, from which place Mr. Corsa, who is a war veteran, was removed last week. Col. Waring sent the following note to Mr. Corsa:

The plan for the reorganization of the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company was made public yesterday by the committee, which is composed of Alfred S. Heidelbach, W.L. Bull, George Coppell, Charles S. Fairchild, Arnold Marcus, John Crosby Brown, A.A.H. Boissevain, and Henry R. Reed.

Galena, Ill., was not much of a town at the outbreak of the rebellion. It was neither very populous nor generally known as a commercial or industrial centre. But there were brave hearts there, and scarcely had the call for troops been flashed over the wires from Washington until the little Illinois town was stirred to its four corners by a call for a public recruiting meeting.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 23. -- Senor Leopold Triran of Havana, one of Cuba's leading lawyers, with his family, is stopping at the United States Hotel.

This title is at least a quaint one. Pierrot, whimsical, side-splitting Pierrot, in the baggy white breeches, his face marble white, his grin painted crimson, called the child "Drumsticks." When you are eating a chicken, there is the breast, wings, and drumsticks, but nobody with common sense eats a drumstick.

ALBANY, Aug. 23. -- A conference which promises to continue for some time in deadlock was begun here this afternoon. Committees from Herkimer and Otsego Counties met on neutral ground to fix up a basis of representation in the Thirty-third Republican Senatorial Convention. The committees were composed of Deputy Secretary of State Andrew Davidson, Congressman David F. Wilber, and Assemblyman J.J. Rider for Otsego, and E.A. Brown, H.G. Munger, and Albert Story for Herkimer.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 23. -- Visitors at both the cottages and hotels seem to increase hourly, and the capacity of both is tested to the utmost. Many arrived to-night for the wedding of Miss Emily Tooker and J. Wadsworth Ritchie to-morrow at 3 P.M. at All Saints' Chapel. There will be no bridesmaids. Miss Cushing and Mrs. Whitney Warren were asked to be such, but it was decided yesterday to have none.

Among the rare and beautiful birds that recently arrived at the Philadelphia Zoological Garden is one that is puzzling the keepers very much. It is a small bird, whose plumage looked like a town that had been artistically daubed by a large crowd of sports. It has a peculiar beak, which, instead of being firm and bony, is flexible, like the reed of a church organ.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Clerk Kerr of the House of Representatives has begun the consideration of the contested election cases in the Fifty-fourth Congress remaining on his docket, but there is little probability of anything being done, owing to the expiration of the time limit within which proceedings in contest may be prosecuted.
HASTINGS, Aug. 23. -- The fourteenth round of the International Chess Masters' tournament was played to-day at Brassey Institute, the results being as follows:

We referred yesterday to the certainty that the Republican Party, should it regain complete control of the National Government, such as it possessed in 1890, would be compelled to undertake a change in the tariff in the direction of protection. We do not mean by this that there would be any serious attempt to restore the McKinley tariff as a whole, or even to advance rates to the McKinley level on any important schedule.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Reports received at the War Department from the commanding officers of companies who have tested the new army rifle -- the Krag-Jorgensen -- show that the arm is fully meeting expectations and giving satisfaction generally. The few complaints about the piece are confined to the sight.

The Piqua Club Association, the New Manhattan Athletic Club, and the administration of Jacob A. Cantor as receiver furnished a lively two hours' discussion yesterday before Judge Beekman, in the Supreme Court.

This little story has the charm of a finely-conceived, and well-executed "modern antique." It is a pleasing imitation. It would be perfect of its kind if the author had not thought it necessary, for the sake of "local color," to sprinkle common French phrases and expletives so freely through the text.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 23. -- Religious enthusiasm about the camp grounds is at fever heat. The camp meeting is attracting, large crowds. Dr. Stokes and his assistants are doing good work. The early meetings to-day were unusually spirited, and the worshippers were more numerous than usual. The helping hand meeting in Thornly Chapel at 9 A.M. was addressed by Sarah Williford, a colored woman from North Carolina.

Mr. Charles E. Hooker, Jr., in conversation, stated some interesting things about the material resources and industrial growth in his State of Mississippi. "My State," said he, "is attracting thrifty farmers, who come there uninfluenced by the extravagant rhetoric and imposing statistical totals of the immigrant and real estate agent.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 23. -- The island is still being favored with a steady stream of arrivals, every boat bringing a host of new faces to join the already large colony of Summer visitors now at this resort.

Serge de Savine, a Russian engineer, living now in Paris, hopes to make soon several long voyages in a balloon and montgolfier which he has invented. The first journey he intends to make from New-York to Paris, and then on the following June to cross the north pole. In these voyages he will be accompanied by the experienced aeronauts.

NYACK, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- The residents of Clarkstown and Haverstraw are excited over the finding of a beautifully dressed baby girl and the strange disappearance of its mother, who was richly attired and appeared to be refined and wealthy.

The likeness of this tale of Summer life to that dear old companion of our youth, "The Swiss Family Robinson," is not due to its form or its moral, but it is irresistible. Mr. Dole's family Merithew of Boston are not shipwrecked. Their voyage is neither long nor perilous, though it has its discomforts.
Sheriff Tamsen yesterday gave out the following statement, in connection with the recent disturbances in Ludlow Street Jail:

Mrs. Bates writes stories of the far West, with reminiscences of the early gold-seeking and ranching times. There are eight stories in the volume, of which "The Great Concern" and "The Mavericks on the Trail" are the most ambitious. A good example of Mrs. Bates's constructive power is found in "Resurrection of the Umpqua." What shall a poor little mining town be called?

The many friends of the family of the late ex-Gov. William T. Minor were pained and shocked by the news of Mrs. Minor's lamentable death. In an unfortunate accident last Tuesday, she sustained a fracture of the hip, which undoubtedly hastened, if it did not cause, her death. The deceased lady enjoyed the friendship and esteem of a wide circle of family connections, friends, and acquaintances, especially among the people of this, her native town.

Following closely upon its consideration of the much-disputed question as to whether entrance to the conning towers of our ships of war should be made large enough to permit the easy ingress and egress of the more rotund of our naval officers, comes discussion by the Navy Department as to the methods to be employed in removing to the "sick bay" such persons as may be wounded on the decks in action.

There is not the slightest room to doubt that "Warren" Ball, who was arrested in Boston Tuesday, in company with Samuel B. Ryles, for the bold robbery of Dr. George Drury at Brooklyn Saturday afternoon, July 27, in a vacant tenement house, where he had been called to attend to a phantom patient, and who escaped from the officer later, is E.W. Ball, Jr., formerly of this city, who has a record for crookedness here.

With engines "slambanging home "again, the old cruiser Atlanta, which has been on the verge of a dry dock and an appropriation for so long, made her way into harbor yesterday, and after resting a couple of hours in the lower bay limped past the Narrows, and stole wearily into a berth off Tompkinsville, S.I., and unless present orders are changed the footsore craft will be told to "move on" to-day.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 23. -- Carr Neel, the Western tennis champion, created a big sensation this morning by defeating one of the favorites, Malcolm Chace, in a great three-set match. Neel's game was a revelation to the Eastern critics. His headwork was remarkably good, and his clever volleying of Chace's hard drives brought out tempests of applause.

The Society for Improving the Condition of the Poor has conducted Summer sessions in six schools through the hot season, and five of them have now finished the Summer term. In these schools special attention is paid to manual training, both for boys and girls. These schools have all been well filled during the term, and many more pupils applied than could be received.

Coroner Fitzpatrick suspended taking testimony yesterday in the inquest respecting the Ireland Building disaster, and personally conducted the jury to the wrecked structure at West Broadway and West Third Street, where the entire day was spent in making an investigation of the central pillar, the stone upon which it rested, the concrete foundation, and the well upon the edge of which the column as raised.

Police Justice Tighe of Brooklyn may be impeached for his action Thursday in holding Policeman Thomas J. Donovan for the Grand Jury because the policeman had bought a pool ticket for the races from Bookmakers Charles Brown and "Tony" Jenkins.

Miss Alice Stone Blackwell and Mr. Frederick W. Peabody have been having a tilt over suffrage in the columns of a contemporary. This morning Miss Blackwell grows delightfully personal, and hits back at her argumentative opponent in this truly feminine but none the less logical fashion:

After hearing the evidence of Alice Wilson relating to the alleged disorderly house, 230 Thompson Street, Justice Jerome, in Special Sessions yesterday sent a messenger for Capt. Eakins of the Mercer Street Station, in whose precinct the house is.
OWEGO, N.Y., Aug. 23.--Thomas Collier Platt leads Tioga County's delegation to the Republican State Convention, and does it without a struggle, or even a ripple.

Superintendent Forbush of the Gypsy Moth Commission is an ardent lover of birds and has made a study of them for a number of years, occupying the position of ornithologist at Clark College at Worcester previous to his connection with the State Board of Agriculture five years ago. In conversation the other day, Mr. Forbush said:

The anti-Platt Republicans in this city have decided to make a fight for another union local ticket and against a straight Republican ticket. Thomas C. Platt and all of his followers desire to have a straight ticket.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Among the changes prophesied to appear in the forthcoming revised Army Regulations is one relating to the payment of the troops that has been urged upon the authorities for some time by those who have observed the extravagance and inconvenience of present methods.

A rumor was printed yesterday to the effect that the Rapid Transit Commissioners' plan for an underground railroad system might be abandoned, that Mayor Strong did not favor it, and that he was fearful that in the present condition of the city finances, owing to the increased city debt, the issue of any part of the $55,000,000 in bonds authorized for the construction would drive the city's bonds below par.
The Cunard Line and the Ellis Island officials are at odds. The relations became strained yesterday when the immigration people refused to land the steerage passengers of the Campania.

First the uncle tried literary society.

Mr. Charles R. Flint arrived from Europe yesterday on the Campania. His two months' quest of recreation and pleasure on the other side of the Atlantic was brought to an enjoyable termination by a week's grouse shooting in Scotland, where he and President Low of Columbia College, Charles A. Dana, and ex-Secretary of the Navy Tracy were the guests of Andrew Carnegie.
LONDON, Aug. 23. -- The Chronicle will to-morrow publish a dispatch from Shanghai saying that the French claims for indemnity for outrages on French missionaries at Szechuen have been settled.

A few days ago Mr. Harry H. Hodgson, one of the oldest cyclers in the city and the founder of the local division of the League of American Wheelmen, returned with his wife from quite an extended tour of Europe.

A reception was given last night, at St. Mark's Methodist Episcopal Church, in West Fifty-third Street, of which the Rev. Ernest Lyon is the minister, to the Rev. Dr. Edward Wilmot Blyden of Monrovia, Liberia, the representative of that republic at the Court of St. James.

The project to use a floor in the proposed new carriage house, planned by the Brooklyn Riding and Driving Club, for the storage of cycles and for indoor riding has aroused a storm of opposition from a certain element in the organization.

Clarence E. Moore of Anderson County has filed a suit for $25,000 damages against the International and Great Northern Railroad Company. He alleges that on Nov. 12, 1894, he was a brakeman on a freight train running between Palestine and Taylor. Between 8 and 9 o'clock that morning the engine was pulling a train of cars, going west, upon which he was working.

-- A new volume of Scottish stories, by Ian Maclaren, and relating to Drumtochty, will be published in October by Dodd, Mead Co., with the title "The Days of Auld Lang Syne." The same publishers have in preparation an illustrated edition of Maclaren's "Doctor of the Old School," the drawings to illustrate actual scenes.

As the clock in the Dockmaster's office at the foot of Christopher Street struck 3 yesterday afternoon the big Cunard liner Campania drew up to her pier, and, for the first time in her history, landed passengers in New-York early Friday afternoon.

In the presentation of the accompanying data concerning Educational Institutions, care has been taken to secure a brief, comprehensive statement about each, which will prove useful to parents and guardians. The material in every instance has been furnished over the signature of the responsible head of the institution or of some person authorized to speak for it -- having, in fact, been prepared for presentation in that form.
I respectfully call your attention to an anonymous letter from Constantinople, published in The New-York Times this morning under the heading of "The Sassoun Massacre."

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 23. -- The polo tournament for pairs closed to-day, and the handsome cup given by E.C. Potter goes to the pair composed of the donor and James M. Waterbury, Jr., representing the Country Club of Westchester. Their opponents were R.G. Shaw second and F.B. Fay of the Myopia Club of Boston.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 23. -- A disgraceful scene was enacted here yesterday at the funeral services held over the remains of John Lotz. While the family and friends were praying over the remains of the deceased, three brothers, who had followed the funeral cortege, got into a fight outside the church. Their cries and oaths could plainly be heard inside the edifice.

The text of Lord Salisbury's speech at the reassembling of Parliament shows a much more decided attitude toward the Government of Turkey than had been expected of him, and more aggressive than previous reports had indicated. Mr. Gladstone's speech on the Armenian question at Chester on the 6th of August was cautious compared with that of the Premier.

James Keir Hardie, President of the Independent Labor Party of Great Britain, who left England five days ago on the Cunard steamship Campania, reached New-York yesterday. He came in the second cabin and wore knee breeches of plaid tweed cloth and a blue outing shirt.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 23. -- It has been a breezy day at Mahkeenac Lake. The brisk wind from the southwest rolled up the white caps, so that the young women who drove down to-day were delighted, because they saw they were to have some fine sport sailing. When the canvas was spread they had about all they could do as they went skipping over the lake, to keep the boats right side up.

Not only every artist, but all to whom the arts are dear and true arts are the objects of admiration and respect, owe Dr. Spitzka a debt of gratitude for having turned the light of his knowledge and the sword of his indignation upon Max Nordau and his "Degeneration," -- the one, perhaps the worst caluminator since Titus Oates, and the other, perhaps the most abominable book printed in modern times.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

Last Tuesday delegates were elected in South Carolina to a convention to revise the Constitution of the State, and the purpose of the revision is to establish such regulation of the suffrage as to put an end to election frauds, and at the same time to maintain "white supremacy."

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Aug. 23. -- Frederick White, the Commissioner intrusted by the Dominion Government with completing the negotiations for a compromise on the parochial schools question, arrived in Winnipeg to-night. Premier Greenway also arrived in the city this evening. A full meeting of the Cabinet Council will be held to-morrow afternoon.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 23. -- The passing of the free-silver coinage craze is probably as evident in Missouri as in any other State or section of the Union. Perhaps the passing is more plainly perceptible here than elsewhere from the very fact that here the mania assumed, or was made to assume, the most violent phase.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 23. -- Col. Z.S. Spalding, who has obtained exclusive concession from the Hawaiian Government for a telegraph cable from the United States to Honolulu, had a conference with the Trustees of the Chamber of Commerce to-day. He explained his project in full, and the Trustees pledged themselves to give it all the aid in their power.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 23. -- John Healey, a painter, of 12 Godwin Street, was caught between the wheel and the shaft of a wagon to-day, and dragged some distance along the street. The reckless driver refused to stop to release him. A bystander finally seized the bridle of the horse, and brought it to a standstill.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23. -- Forty-one of the delegates elected from this city to support Gov. Hastings met this afternoon and pledged their support in writing to Gov. Hastings for Permanent Chairman of the convention, and to Col. B.F. Gilkeson for re-election as Chairman of the State Committee.

The attempt of the Prussian Government to McKinleyize the business of life insurance is a curious but perfectly logical application of the doctrine that Has made our Ohio Napoleon famous. The Prussian insurance companies, finding themselves hard pressed by the energetic methods of our New-York companies, have apparently succeeded in persuading the Government that they need protection.

The Summer meeting of the Queens County Jockey Club, which ended yesterday, proved a success, from a racing and financial standpoint. "Father Bill" Daly headed the list of winning owners with $3,400 to his credit, J. Delong came next with $3,050, and D. Higgins was third with $2,050.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 23. -- The college, the athletic, and the society world alike have begun to exhibit more interest in the Yale-Cambridge international track games than in any athletic event in years. The college graduates of all eastern institutions and the leading society people of the country have manifested the greatest earnestness to aid Yale all that is possible in making the affair a success which will reflect credit on American universities.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- The extensive plant of the Troy Steel and Iron Company, which was incorporated a few years since with a capital of $2,500,000, was sold yesterday to Frank S. Witherbee for $400,000.

MOUNT CLEMENS, Mich., Aug. 23. -- Good sport was had in the second day's racing of the national circuit meeting in this city. Cabanne, Titus, and Murphy were absent, but good fields were left for all the races. Cooper again showed good form, and Bliss came up in the fields and ran into second position in both the open contests. Kiser rode brilliantly in every race.

The attention of life insurance men throughout the country is at present directed toward the controversy in progress between the Government of Prussia and two of the leading New-York insurance companies.

The Pittsburgs did not do any experimenting with green pitchers at Eastern Park, Brooklyn, but their efforts were in vain, as the Brooklyns won. It was an interesting game all the way through, and the 3,000 spectators who were present were kept in a state of excitement for fear the home team would be beaten.

The rout of the saloon men was completed yesterday. Fifty-five of them pleaded guilty before Recorder Goff, in General Sessions, and paid fines ranging from $50 to $125. Not one of them dared to go to trial. They were fairly beaten at their own game.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- What will ever be considered a very unsatisfactory race meeting for the Saratoga Association closed to-day. The attendance was unusually good, the weather perfect, and the track fast. The programme offered was only of the ordinary kind, and was made up of very small fields, which were further reduced by scratching.
VIENNA, Aug. 23. -- An extensive conflagration has occurred at Tlone. Fifty houses were consumed, and 130 families were rendered homeless.

Mr. Saintsbury has written a preface for this volume of the new English edition of Balzac that may deter the purchaser of the edition from reading or re-reading the master's early romance of the Vendee, and that certainly will relieve him of the necessity of forming an opinion as to the merit of the work. "Le dernier Chouan" was published in 1829, but it was written two years earlier.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Secretary Morton's attention being called to a special telegram which declared that he had yesterday closed every sugar experimental station in the United States -- twenty in number -- and sold the property for what he could get, said that "the statement was very misleading, and only slightly tinctured with the facts."
ERIE, Penn., Aug. 24. -- The sunrise prayer meetings of the Christian Endeavor Convention this morning were largely attended, but before noon the rain descended in torrents.
NEWPORT, Aug. 24. -- Newport never was gayer than now, and society was never so much engaged Every hour in each day is taken up, and cottagers, therefore, are continually on the go.

PARIS, Aug. 2. -- Everything is supposed to be calm, everybody is going or has gone away, and Paris, at least, is left in tranquil solitude, in the elegant rustication of a city more enjoyable in Summer than in Winter, if one knows the ropes. Frankly speaking, the political exit has not been enthusiastic. "

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 24. -- A horseless carriage -- called so because it has power of locomotion independent of horse or any other beast -- is to be seen almost any day in Springfield's streets. That is the practicable and serviceable is shown by the fact that it has made long trips from one city to another. It is the invention of C.E. and J.F. Duryea.

An absurd idea has come into bloom, our colleagues say, in the mind of the Police Prefect -- the idea of regulating the costume of women who ride on bicycles -- or wish to look as if they did! Not that the idea is to select administratively the skirt dear to Americans or the trousers that are less dangerous to riders; true bicyclists would retain freedom in their preferences.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 24. MUCH interest has been taken in baseball this week, although tennis and boat racing have been indulged in to quite an extent. The Ampersand and Paul Smith nines, always considered the crack Adirondack ball clubs, met for the first time this season last Tuesday afternoon on the Ampersand diamond.

A party of lake yachtsmen, numbering 200 or more, will come to New-York to see the struggle between the Defender and Valkyrie III. for the International Cup. The party comprises representatives of the principal yacht clubs of the lakes, and will be a practical illustration of the growing interest in aquatic sports on the inland waters.

Some years ago I paid a visit to my nephew's vicarage in Buckinghamshire. He informed me that a new industry had sprung up in his parish -- there was a demand for humble bees, which could be sold for fourpence a head. He could not inform me what led to this demand, nor could the villagers who had sold the bees do so.

NYACK, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Great excitement was caused at West Nyack this afternoon by the careless and serious shooting of eight persons, who were present in a large throng to witness the annual meet of the Nyack Gun Club. The shoot took place a short distance from the West Shore Railroad, and several crack shots were there from several wll-known clubs in New-York and Brooklyn.

The recent celebration of the birthday (was it the eighty-sixth?) of the author of this volume gives to the work, first published though it was, many months ago, a kind of new and timely interest. It is the latest of the venerable librarian's books -- but we may sincerely hope it is some points removed from being the last.

Judge Horace Russell played the opening round of the team match between the St. Andrew's Golf Club and the Country Club of Brookline, on the St. Andrew's links, yesterday, and set the pace for the New-Yorkers by beating R.M. Appleton 3 up. Thirteen players were on each team, competing in pairs, as selected by the two Captains, A.L. Livermore and Lawrence Curtis.

The choir boys of the following churches will participate in the Seidl Society's children's festival on Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday afternoons in the Brighton Beach Music Hall: Grace Church, All Saints', Holy Nativity, Church of the Redeemer, St. Luke's, St. Clement's, St. George's, St. Bartholomew's, and St. Matthew's in Brooklyn, St. Paul's of Flatbush, and the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New-York.

LONDON, Aug. 24.--[Copyright, 1895, by The New-York Times.]--Usually this latter half of August finds Europe wrapped in complete holiday languor, with palaces and foreign offices locked and shuttered, and Kings and statesmen all off on innocuous vacation jaunts. This year there is a perceptible tendency on the part of men occupied in public affairs to keep near the telegraph office and maintain a careful watch over their neighbors' doings.
LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 24. LECTURES were given in the chapel this week. As has been the case in nearly all the lectures of the season, admission was free to the guests of the hotels.

Six tandems, with professionals astride of them, furnished a novelty at the regular Saturday afternoon cycle races at Manhattan Beach yesterday. No tandem race ever held in this country has had so many competitive teams, and this fact made the contest memorable.

HUDSON, Aug. 24. -- When the next campaign begins in this county the Democratic management will be in the hands of a new man. The announcement has been made that Samuel J. Tilden is to retire from the Chairmanship of the County Committee.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 24. -- Cottagers attended the Casino this morning for tennis, and this afternoon the wedding and golf were in order. Altogether, it was the busiest day of the season, and this evening Mrs. J. Watts Kearney, Mrs. James P. Kernochan, and Mrs. Thomas Hitchcock gave delightful dinners.
Good Government Club X, of the new Fourth Assembly District, has elected Messrs. Henry M. Cassen, and L.J. Frank as Trustees, to fill vacancies.

Previous to the racing at Sheepshead Bay yesterday W. Easton sold at auction in the sale paddock a draft of yearlings from the Fairview Stud. The fact that there was a good representation of prominent horse owners and trainers present made bidding brisk and good prices were obtained.

SAYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 24. BICYCLING continues to be the chief amusement here. A few nights ago a lantern parade was held. Every wheel in the village was brought out and the decorations were surprisingly original.

Only thirty carloads of peaches from Delaware and New-Jersey arrived in New York yesterday. There was consequently a decided advance in prices. Commission merchants easily obtained from $1.50 to $2 a basket for the best grade of fruit. There were not enough choice peaches to satisfy the demand.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 24. -- Kebo presented a gay scene to-night. It was the occasion of the regular Saturday evening dinner, which was an exceedingly enjoyable one. Covers were laid for seventy-five at the dinner. The long L-shaped table was tastefully decorated with wild flowers and Arbor Vitae.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 24. -- The result of the contest between the State Administration and Senator Quay for Chairman of the State Republican Committee is still in doubt. Both sides claim they will win, but neither is willing to give out figures to prove its claims.
BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 24. -- Company I of Bayonne, attached to the Fourth Regiment, will open its fair under canvas at the corner of Avenue C and West Thirty-fourth Street, Sept. 30.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 24. -- Mayor and Mrs. Alexander Gilbert of West Eighth Street have returned from a mouth's outing.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 24. -- There was a most enjoyable dance at the Montclair Club Monday evening.

ALBANY, Aug. 24. -- There is a rule in the office of the Superintendent of Public Buildings that any orderly who accepts "tip" will be discharged. This rule has never been rigidly enforced, but the tipping has heretofore been on the quiet. During the present Summer the rule has not only been ignored, but the orderlies in many instances have actually asked for money for showing visitors about the building.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., Aug. 24. LIVELIER than ever it was in its history is Upper Saranac Lake at present. The hotels are filled and engagements being into the made Fall, while every camp and cottage on the lake is occupied.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The property of The Washington News Publishing Company was sold at auction this afternoon under a deed of trust.
WARREN, R.I., Aug. 24. -- A petroleum launch, on which was a party of New-York people, struck a rock three miles from here yesterday, and those on board narrowly escaped drowning.

Admirers of cycle racing are looking for some of the best sport of the season in September. At Buffalo, on the 5th and 6th, the State Division's Fall meet will be the biggest thing in the way of race tournaments that any division of the League of American Wheelmen ever saw. At least this is what the managers of the meet say, and they are among the most reputable citizens of the Bison City.

" I am well pleased with my reception," said J. Keir Hardle, the British labor leader and ex-member of Parliament, yesterday, "and with the accurate reports, generally speaking, which the press has given of my opinions, I am doubly pleased, because of the wild character for exaggeration which has been given to the American press abroad."

Electrical men have always been inclined to regard the demand for wire as one of the best indications of the state of any and all of the electrical industries. When the demand is slack, it is evident that very few renewals are being made and that very little work is going on in the nature of extensions.
