ROCHESTER, Aug. 24. -- Chairman Hinkley of the Democratic State Committee, with Mr. Flanigan of Oneida County, Mr. Mack of Buffalo, and Clerk De Freest of Albany, arrived in the city this morning to take action on credentials and protests previous to the reorganization of the Monroe County Democratic Committee.

LONDON, Aug. 24. -- The Rev. William Bayard Hale of Middleborough, Mass., lestured to-night at the Examination School, Oxford University. His subject was "The Making of the American Constitution: A Genesis of Nationality." The lecture was attended by a large number of university extension students, who gave to Mr. Hale a good reception.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 24. -- Two thousand persons gathered at Camden station this afternoon to welcome home Cardinal Gibbons, after an absence in Europe of fifteen weeks.
SUMMIT, N.J., Aug. 24. -- The ladies of the Wyoming Presbyterian Church held an enjoyable apron sale last night in the chapel.
OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 24. -- The Ocean Grove Methodists rose early this morning, and the preliminary meetings were largely attended.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 24. -- Capt. Christensen of the schooner Maud M. Story, which arrived from the Banks to-day, tells of an attempt of a seaman to murder the crew on Aug. 19, while the vessel was at anchor on Brown's Bank.
I can pipe, too," he said.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The failure of Commander Thomas Perry of the United States gunboat Castine to salute the French flag at Tamatave, Madagascar, was accentuated by a subsequent incident of a semi-sensational character, knowledge of which became public to-day in a statement to the press at the Navy Department.

BERLIN, Aug. 24. -- The leaders of the German Bimetallic League, although to a considerable degree discouraged by the declaration of Mr. Balfour in the British House of Commons, that he had no right to pledge his colleagues in the ministry to a policy favorable to the calling of another International Monetary Conference, refuse to regard the British leader's statement as final in determining the action of Great Britain in the matter.

The Palisade Boat Club of Yonkers, whose junior eight-oared crew bore off the honors at the Middle States Regatta and won the medals presented by The New-York Times, was organized Oct. 16, 1866, and for nearly twenty-nine years it has maintained its high position in the aquatic circles of America.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 24 DELIGHTFUL weather has sent city folk to the shore in droves, and Asbury Park and her twin sister, Ocean Grove, are now accommodating the largest crowds they ever handled.

Most of you have read quotations of silver-fox skins and black-fox skins, but did you ever see one? The chances are that if you are not in the fur business you never did. Only 139 were taken in the whole world last season, and every year all of these go to Russia, where they are the fur of the royalty and the nobility.

SWARTHMORE, Penn., Aug. 24. -- "I take may pen in hand," was the trite beginning of letters a hundred years ago, and in a small room redolent and resonant with the witchery of long ago, the scribe takes the pen in hand, in the attic room which was the dreaming place by night and day of embryo art in America.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 24. -- The long-looked-for event of the season, the wedding of Miss Emily Montague Tooker, younger daughter of Gabriel Mead Tooker, and J. Wadsworth Ritchie took place this afternoon at All Saints' Chapel.

The refusal of the Sultan to accept general European superintendence of the reforms in Asiatic Turkey may be obstinacy or merely another move on the chessboard of Eastern European politics. His assertion that it will endanger the integrity and independence of his empire is plausible and has even more than a shadow of truth.

The original formation of the crust of the world consists of sterile volcanic rocks, only capable of supporting a very limited amount of plant life. By the action of water these rocks are worn away and degraded, and the debris being transported and deposited in layers of soil of more or less thickness, on which vegetation can flourish and produce food for human consumption.

Acting Inspector Brooks received information a few days ago that "The" Allen had opened another poolroom at 61 West Broadway. Allen had a poolroom at 22 West Broadway, which the police raided a month ago. He was arrested and has since been indicted. He is under $1,000 bail.
FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., Aug. 24. SOCIAL gayety among cottagers and hotel guests continues with unabating ardor.

ARVERNE-BY-THE-SEA, L.I., Aug. 24. PROBABLY there is more fun to the square inch at Arverne than at any other place of its size on the south shore. Surf bathing is a feature. For a thorough enjoyment of all the delights and benefits of a close and intimate contact with old Ocean, this place is unexcelled.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 24. ONE of the big social events of the week was the german Thursday evening. H.G. Lloyd, Jr., and H.B. Wilcox, both of New-York, had the affair in charge.
WESTFIELD, Mass., Aug. 24. -- There is little doubt that John Phelps Cowles of this place has met his death in South America.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 24. THE last week of camp is always the most exciting here. Excursion parties visit the post daily and friends of the cadets fill the hotels. New officers, with their families, have arrived, and until their quarters are in shape they stop at the hotels.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 24. THE season is passing rapidly here, and after the golf tournament on the hills next week sojourners will begin to leave for their city homes, though many of the cottagers will remain late into October, while a few keep their houses open through the entire year.

There was plenty of excitement before the running of the rich Futurity Stakes. The crowd was brought to its feet in the desperate finish in the Fail Handicap race between Rufino and The Butterflies. The two previous Futurity winners simply held the crowd spellbound.

This book was written "to reveal the religions of India by causing them to reveal themselves, and to elucidate them by commenting on them as they appear before the reader; traverse his field of vision, and finally leave his sight." It is the first volume of a series of manuals that may serve as textbooks for the historical study of religions in universities and seminaries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- There is cause for Democratic gratulation in the fact that Republican journals are denying that the Government intended to take aggressive action if Spain had refused to pay the Mora claim. For some reason not yet explained the Republican idea was that the Administration was engaged in a game of bluff with respect to this claim, and that nothing would come of it.

Women learning to ride wheels have been much in print; too often, however, blunt fact is made subservient to a picturesque story. The following essays to be a plain recital of actual experience, and as such may be helpful to some woman taking up bicycling for the first time.

LONDON, Aug. 24. -- That Lord Dunraven will agree to sailing the first race of the series for the America's Cup on Sept. 7, The Yachtsman says, gives the challenger a poor chance of getting in proper trim, although they are quite in accord with the spirit of the deed of gift, and Lord Dunraven has the reputation in America of being too good a sportsman not to be fair game.
HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 24. -- The will of Vicar General James Hughes, admitted to probate to-day, makes bequests as follows:

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- A rainy afternoon put a quietus on the ball game and stopped all the pleasure drives that were planned. The result was to make indoor sport the more attractive, and the grand ball at the Spring House is a scene of life and gayety. The veranda, as usual, is hung with lanterns and filled with couples promenading after the dances.

The largest and perhaps the only tunny ever caught on the Pacific coast was landed by C. Valancola and Capt. Gusti at Monterey Bay yesterday morning, after a desperate fight. The fish measures over 6 feet in length, and weighs 460 pounds.

The annual regatta of the Nonparell Rowing Club was held yesterday afternoon over a half-mile straightaway course on the Hudson River. The boathouse was bedecked with flags, bunting, and paper lanterns of variegated colors, while the balconies contained many pretty women. The results of the races are shown in the following summaries:
GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 24. -- The schooner Mary A. Clark, 79 tons burden, until recently owned at this port, sailed from here yesterday for New-York under circumstances that excite interest.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Pension Commissioner Lochren has replied to ex-Commissioner Corporal Tanner's letter of the 19th inst., demanding the discharge of Dr. W. Bell, an old Republican clerk in the bureau, because of his refusal to grant a pension to claimant Charles M. Knapp, the action of the clerk being reversed by the Commissioner when brought to his attention by Dr. Tanner.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 24. GOLF is the all-absorbing amusement here. Everybody has been practicing for the September tournament, which promises to be a great success. Many match games have been played between the club member. Among the men who have been playing nearly every day are S. Parkman Shaw, the champion of the course; John E. Alexandre, J. Egmont Schermerhorn, Wright Barclay, Jameson Cotting, Sanford Barnes, and M. Orme Wilson.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Aug. 24. -- The Girard College Cadets, 542 strong, marched down upon Island Heights Thursday, and went into camp at Beaumont, where they will remain ten days. There are six companies, besides a band of forty pieces, and six commissioned and non-commissioned officers. Lieut. E.C. Brooks is in command of the battalion, and has the following staff:

As anybody knows, there may be a plenty of mosquitoes on Fire Island Beach, above the sand, but under that sand are innumerable pots of gold. Whereas you easily find the mosquitoes, the gold is not so easily obtainable. Mr. Edward Richard Shaw has collected some of the legends of the Great South Bay and dressed them up in neat style.

The State Department has not been aroused any too soon to the importance and the urgency of the case of ex-Consul Waller, an American citizen, condemned by a French court-martial to imprisonment for twenty years. Nobody can impartially consider the proceedings had in the case without coming to the conclusion that our Government has been very patient and that the French Government has not been very civil.

Gutwillig Brothers have sold the southeast corner of West and Vestry Streets, 75.9 by 101.7 feet in areal extent, to John Kehoe, who will remove the old buildings and erect a storehouse to cover the plot.

The arrival of the Duke of Marlborough at Newport is likely to set gossip agoing. The question that the curious will try to decide is, Will Miss Consuelo Vanderbilt be the future Duchess of Marlborough? The rumor, started in London, that the announcement of their engagement might be expected at any time is thought by many people to have a better foundation than most rumors of the kind.

In the interview of Mr. Charles R. Flint published yesterday there were two points of great interest relating to the attitude of the investing public of England and the Continent toward American securities. It is needless to say that that attitude is not one of unreserved confidence, and it would be very strange if it were so.
VANCOUVER, B.C., Aug. 24. -- The Rev. Father Losi, Prefect Apostolic of the Roman Catholic Missions in Alaska, and his colleague, Father Barnett, are now here for a visit.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Gov. Levi P. Morton has accepted Village President Charles H. Sturges's invitation to attend and become a Patron of the floral fete, to be given on Thursday, Sept. 5. Mrs. Morton will accompany the Governor, and they will remain in town several days.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 24. WHEELING has reached the height of its popularity in Stockbridge. Everybody rides, and even the golf players divide their attention. Prof. Ogden Rood of Columbia College is enthusiastic over the sport, and is a skillful rider.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 24. Have found the week a busy one. There has been more transient business for them than at any time during the season. Many of the guests who have been spending the season here, and who generally take a short trip elsewhere before returning to their Winter homes, have gone, and people who have been summering at other resorts, and make Long Branch their winding-up point, have arrived in their places.
BELVIDERE, N.J., Aug. 24. -- There are cases of diphtheria at Independence, Warren County, and everything else is lost sight of in efforts to prevent the further spread of the disease.

KINGSTON, Aug. 24, (Special.) A PARTY, all members of the Happy Day Riding Club of New-York City, consisting of P.H. Pehlemann, John H. Loos, John S. Barth, Percy Von Goldstein, Miss L. Loos, Miss Stella Loos, Miss Bertha Barth, and Miss L. Barth, passed through this city yesterday on horseback, en route for a tour through the Catskill resorts.

The only league championship game played in the metropolitan district yesterday took place at Bergen Point, where the team of the New-Jersey Athletic Club scored an easy victory over the New-Yorks by 74 runs and 4 wickets to spare. For the winners W.H. Denzell played patiently and well for his innings of 28, not out, and J. Forbes, T.G. Clarke, and F.F. Kelly were also responsible for good work. The following is the score:

FIRE ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 24. FORMER habitues of this place have remarked that this year reminded them of the old days, when the best people of New-York City and State made Fire Island their Summer home.

Speculators have had the market pretty much to themselves during the week, and they have cut rather a wide swath in their specialties, the leading industries -- Sugar, Tobacco, and Chicago Gas. The tobacco trade situation, as explained in this column last Sunday, was ripe in speculative possibilities, and a prominent operator was not slow to take advantage of the opportunity presented.
PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Aug. 24. -- The recent sale of property at this place owned by the estate of the late P.T. Barnum, the showman, is to be reviewed in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, next Wednesday.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Aug. 24. AT the meeting of the Thursday Morning Club Aug. 29, Mrs. May Alden Ward of Boston will lecture. Her subject will be something pertaining to "Old New-England,'' but the exact title has not been announced.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 24. NEVER before has Bar Harbor had such a gay brilliant, and enjoyable week as the last. The officers of the naval squadron have been the lions. When the fleet drew out of the harbor Thursday afternoon, it seemed as if the season's death-knell had been rung.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Aug. 24. GOOD weather and fine roads continue to keep people here and to make driving and bicycling the great attractions. The Good Roads Committee went away satisfied that respectable dirt roads were feasible if they could be made intelligently.
ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 24. -- Mr. and Mrs. Ferdinand Gossweiler celebrated the twenty-fifth anniversary of their wedding with a reception at their home, in Freeman Street, Thursday evening.

EDGEMERE, L.I., Aug. 24. WHEN the capitalists erected the Hotel Edgemere they builded better than they knew. That the season so far has been an unqualified success has been evident to every one who has made a visit, however brief, to this spot.

A great deal of adverse comment has been created in Brooklyn Grand Army circles by the announcement of Col. Louis Finkelmeier of Metternich Post that that post will not participate in the celebration of the Battle of Long Island and the unveiling of the Maryland Monument Tuesday.

A celebrated operetta talks of people who say that they are Spaniards, and who are not Spaniards at all. If the public journals are to be believed, the bicycle, like Spain, has its imposters. There are on our boulevards, particularly the Saint-Michel Boulevard, persons who wear costumes of cyclists, and who are not cyclists. They are thus disguised "in order to attract attention."

If any of the Sundays since the enforcement of the excise law was commenced by the present Police Commissioners have been dry, it is entirely safe to predict that to-day will be the driest in the calendar. In bringing about this state of aridity the efforts of the police will be assisted and sustained by the respectable portion of the saloon keepers, who have announced their intention to in future obey the law without quibble.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 24. ONE of the most notable classes of visitors Cape May is entertaining this season is the theatrical colony. Sol. Smith Russell, leaving for Europe, sent his two children here for rest and recuperation, and on his return immediately joined them.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 24. -- As the time for the Master's sale of the property of the Atchison Company approaches, and for the reorganization of that great system under the plans of the committee, there is much speculation as to the disposition to be made of the large number of employes, many of whom have grown gray in the service of the old company.

Beer, all but unknown in France before 1870, now floods this country. Alcohol is poured from distilleries, where the refuse of beetroot, used in making sugar, is a substitute for grapes or malt. Beer saloons replace the cafes, where before the war Frenchmen sipped coffee and eau sucree, and met friends as in as informal drawing room.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Aug. 24. SEA Cliff's season is now at its height, and all the visitors are greatly enjoying themselves. They crowd as much pleasure as they possibly can into one day, beginning in the morning with boating, fishing, and bathing, followed by long drives in the afternoon, winding up the day with various games, entertainments, dancing, , until late in the evening.

DOVER, N.J., Aug. 24. -- Dissensions which have existed for some time among the employes of the Liberty Bicycle Works at Rockaway yesterday ended in a strike, and the factory is now closed, although operations may be resumed in a week or ten days.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 24. -- Gov. Charles T. O'Ferrall of this State, who is popularly supposed to be an opponent of John W. Daniel for the United States Senatorship, has written an open letter on the question of free silver. The significance of this letter is that it comes just at the opening of the campaign for the nomination of Democratic members of the General Assembly.
Blake -- What is called commercialism is often really merely self-preservation; it is not so much that the manager is over-anxious to make money as that he cannot afford to lose it.
ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 24. -- The Orange Athletic Club had things all its own way this afternoon with the Nutley Athletic Club in a game of baseball on the Orange Oval.

A new monthly magazine has lately been founded in this city, bearing on its cover the attractive title of The Bachelor of Arts. Its aim is to improve mankind by fostering university interests and looking after the welfare of general literature. It is an oblong but comely periodical. Its glazed white covers are neatly decorated in chocolate and raspberry tints.

The Brooklyns were on their muscle yesterday, and the style in which they made Von der Abe's St. Louis aggregation hunt the leather at Eastern Park proved a splendid afternoon's entertainment for about 4,000 of Brooklyn's baseball enthusiasts. Once more Manager Foutz's men played a perfect fielding game, not an error of any description being made by them, which, in addition to their heavy batting, made the visitors look like so many schoolboys.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 24. BLUE skies and bright sunshine have been thoroughly enjoyed by the guests of the popular Prospect House. The Altogether Club gave an outing this week which was voted a brilliant success by the members and their friends.

TORONTO, Ontaria, Aug. 24. -- The Canadian branch of the National Racing Circuit of the League of American Wheelmen opened very auspiciously in this city to-day and will continue every day next week in various places. The men leave Canada for Boston next Saturday night, where they will race on Labor Day. Twenty of the racing men from the States are following the circuit, with about the same number of Canadians.
The Lorelei beguiled me, and I went. There were twelve of us in the party, and then the skipper -- shall we count the skipper, or shall we no? That is a momentous question, for thereon hangs --

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 24. -- Hovey and Larned are the sole survivors of the eighty-two players who started in hopefully last Tuesday. Hovey was victorious over the Western champion, Neel, in a finely played contest, and Larned's wonderful driving beat Howland for the fourth time this season.
Ex-County Treasurer Henry H. Adams of Kings County yesterday made a statement in reply to County Treasurer Taylor's assertions that he left the county with an empty treasury and a large deficit.

ROMULUS, Aug. 24. -- The Republican Convention of Seneca County to-day elected as State delegates W.L. Sweet, J.B.H. Mangen, J.H.M. Glen, Charles Q. Vanlew; as Senatorial delegates -- O.G. Wheelock, D.C. McArthur, Millard Garnett, Patrick Galvin, Ogden Wheeler; as Judicial delegates -- L.G. Hoskins, Francis C. Allen, Henry Peterson, Resolutions indorsing the administration of Gov. Morton, Secretary of State, Controller, Treasurer, Attorney General, and State Engineer and Surveyor were adopted.

BRISTOL, R.I., Aug. 24. -- Work is being pushed on the new mast for the Defender, and it may be possible to have it ready for stepping to-morrow. However, there is yet considerable to be done on it, and the yacht may not be able to get away before Tuesday at the earliest.

LONDON, Aug. 24. -- As both the Executive Committees of the National Liberal Federation and the Central Liberal Association, which mainly holds the party purse, have hesitated to convene a general national conference, the political committee of the National Liberal Club has taken upon itself the responsibility of summoning a congress for Oct. 29.

LOURDES, Aug. 24. -- Fourteen railway trains loaded with sick, maimed, and otherwise incapacitated persons arrived here from Paris to-day, and their wretched occupants are lying helpless about the station, clamoring to be carried to the sacred grotto.

POMONA, Cal., Aug. 24. -- This town is famous for many things, but for nothing is it better known than for the fact that it receives its supply of electricity for commercial purposes from a plant at San Antonio Canon, thirty miles away -- an electric power transmission ten miles longer than that of Niagara, and in some respects the most remarkable in the world.

PARIS, Aug. 24. -- A heavy letter addressed to Baron Alphonse de Rothschild was delivered at the Baron's office this afternoon during his absence at Trouville. The Baron's confidential clerk, M. Jodkowsky, opened the bulky parcel with a knife, whereupon it exploded.

TRENTON, Aug. 24. -- There are not likely to be any new developments for the present in the Barnes-Magowan affair, as all the principals are out of town. The scandal continues to be the main topic discussed in political and social, circles in New-Jersey.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 24 -- The week just closed has been the most delightful one of the season. Clear and cool, just warm enough to make one feel comfortable, has been the record of the last seven days.

Der Deutsche Orden der Harugari has a larger number of members than any other German secret order in America. Its origin recalls the turbulent times in Germany and America-existing in the decade between 1840 and 1850. The liberty-loving Germans had to fight two foes at that period.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Dr. Salmon, Chief of the Bureau of Animal Inspection, Agricultural Department in regard to the threatened withdrawal by the English Government of the privilege given to American Inspectors to verify the diagnosis in regard to diseases discovered by the British Inspectors in American cattle, said:

If the Government may be safely intrusted with the transmission of our letters and papers, I see no reason why it may rot also be intrusted with the transmission of our telegrams and parcels, as is almost universally the case in Europe; or of our passengers and freight, through a State ownership of railways, as in Germany, France, Austria, Sweden, and Norway.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Racing under the auspices of the Saratoga Association ended yesterday, possibly never to be resumed. The race track speculators won a few lonesome dollars on the "Getaway Stakes," and last night witnessed a general exodus of the talent, who hurried southward to see the Futurity run to-day at Sheepshead Bay.

LAKE PLACID, Aug. 24. -- Whiteface Inn, under the management of Mrs. C.L. Child, is enjoying the most prosperous season in its history. Never before has the house filled up so early, and the booking for September already insures a full house well into that month.

William F. Harrity of Philadelphia, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, returned from Europe on the American Liner Paris yesterday. He appeared to be in robust health. Mrs. Harrity and her sister, with a party of friends, met him at the steamship's pier.

Annie Hill, twenty-three years old, of 71 West One Hundred and Seventh Street, pleaded guilty in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday to stealing jewelry and clothing, and was held in $1,000 bail for trial. Her excuse was that she was preparing for her marriage.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 24. -- The Second Presbyterian Church is one of the eight thriving religious institutions of the village of Huntington, and, aside from enjoying the distinction of owning the largest and most modern church edifice in the place, the society is said to combine more conflicting elements than any other.
SHELTER ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 24. COOLER weather has not made any appreciable difference in the life and gayety of the Summer visitors at this popular resort.
Mr. and Mrs. George J. Gould and their children arrived here from England yesterday on the steamship Paris, coming home browned by the sun and in excellent health.

OLEAN, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Here in the southwestern corner of the State the Republicans hold their caucuses earlier than is the rule in other portions of Western New-York. Thus it is that in Chautauqua, Cattauragus, Allegany, and Wyoming the battles at the party primaries have nearly all been fought, and the politicians have now turned their attention to the nominating conventions and the preliminary work of the campaign itself.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 24. -- The Democratic State Central Committee, pursuant to a call of Chairman Long and the Democratic candidates, had a conference this afternoon. Gen. Hardin reached the city at noon, and was present at the conference. All the committeemen and the party leaders are extremely reticent as to the course they will pursue.

Thomas J. Kenna, ex-Register of Kings County, who is one of the leading Democratic politicians in Brooklyn, has made some suggestions which he thinks, if adopted, would tend to harmonize the Democratic factions over there. Speaking to a reporter for The Brooklyn Daily Times, he said:
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 24. OF THE many attractive Summer resorts on Long Island, the pretty cathedral town of Garden City is undoubtedly one of the most prominent.

The meeting of a conference at Saratoga to-morrow for the discussion of "proportional representation" will doubtless excite sufficient interest to awaken a curiosity as to just what it is that this new breed of reformers propose and why they propose it, especially as they claim that it has an essential connection with civil service reform, municipal reform, and general political improvement, and is necessary to their success.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 25. -- John Smalley, who was shot and instantly killed by Deputy Sheriffs Spofford and McBain, at McBain, last night, was identified to-day by Detective Jake Way as the man who murdered Detective George W. Powers, aboard a Grand Rapids and Indiana train Wednesday night, while it was leaving this city.

Gaybert Barnes, the well-known author of educational text books, is dying in his home, 670 Tenth Street, Brooklyn, of apoplexy, of which he recently suffered a second attack. His physician, Dr. William F. Gardiner of Sixth Avenue and Lincoln Place, yesterday said that while Mr. Barnes might survive another week, the chances were against him.

BERLIN, Aug. 25. -- Misled by the exaggerations of the American newspapers, which represented that about 2,000 German-American veterans of the Franco-Prussian was of 1870 were coming here to take part in the fetes commemorative of that conflict, the German officials, acting under the orders of the Kaiser, prepared to give them a reception which should be of a national character.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- The latest mail from Central America brought files of The Bluefields (Nicaragua) Recorder, in an issue of which, that of July 27, appeared the following article, purporting to give the recommendations of the United States commission which recently inspected the canal:

Thomas C. Platt said yesterday at the Oriental Hotel that he had not made up his mind whether he was for a straight Republican local ticket next Fall, or for a combination ticket with all the anti-Tammany elements represented.

It was at the Manhattan Beach and other Coney Island hotels that the Coney Island Futurity, run on Saturday, was talked about yesterday more than in town. That was because every one who could possibly do so went out of the hot and dry city to get a breath of fresh air and a something to quench their thirst.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 25. -- Gov. McIntyre rested at his home to-day, after trying to stop the bull fight yesterday. He telephoned to Under Sheriff Brisbane on the scene today, but to appeals for militia he reiterated that he could not call them out until the Sheriff had exhausted his resources. The Sheriff replied that he had plenty of help, but no law to back him up.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 25. -- The first contest in the Gilchester serial handicap road race, promoted by the Gilbert Chester Company, in which points count and penalties are imposed in subsequent races, was run over the Rahway- Elizabeth course yesterday. Summary:

The first woman to climb to the summit of the Matterhorn was the daughter of a guide named Carrel. Then a New-York girl, Miss Brevoort, followed in her footsteps; that was twenty-four years ago. Now a Providence young woman, Miss Annie S. Peck, has emulated their exploit, and announces her success in a modest cablegram to The Boston Herald.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Aug. 25. -- Gov. Richards yesterday telegraphed orders to the Prosecuting Attorney of Natrona County to cause the arrest of the party of Princeton students who have just come in from a trip through the northern part of the State and report that they have killed a number of antelope.

BOSTON, Aug. 25. -- Never before in its history has the city taken such a holiday appearance on Sunday as to-day. The elaborate decorations, the constantly arriving delegations of Knights Templars in their rich trappings, and the crowds that have thronged the streets to view the everchanging scenes have combined to make the day one of bustle rather than one of rest.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- Passed East -Steam yachts Belle Hazen, H.L. Hoyt; Lorna, W.L. Storr; Forget Me Not, W.H. and G.P. Butler; Theresa, Gustavus Sidenberg; Judge, W. J. Arkell, and Stranger, Mrs. Mary Lewis, Schooner yacht Alsacienne, C.C. Bragg, and sloop yacht Bonnie Kate.

Mrs. Ella Stephens of Philadelphia is visiting friends at 34 East Ninth Street. Accompanied by two young women friends and a man, she spent yesterday in the country, returning at 8:30 o'clock last evening. The party entered O'Neill's restaurant, at 358 Sixth Avenue, and ordered a beefsteak for four, together with tomatoes and potatoes, and coffee for three.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 25. -- Judge Wilson yesterday dismissed the prosecution against Mrs. Noe, who was arrested Thursday for appearing on the streets in bloomers. In delivering his opinion, the Judge said:

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- George Gould's steam yacht Atlanta ran aground on Middle Grounds, in the Hudson River, off Haverstraw to-day. She was pulled off by the tug Sheffield after a short delay. The damage was slight.

NEW-HAVEN, Aug. 24. -- The traveler should approach this good old town through the broad, open door of its harbor. And here is the natural gateway -- the maps show this clearly enough -- where one who revisits Connecticut to freshen hazy memories and in his mind's eye to set the old beside the new of these end-of-the-century days, should pass in.

We have been much interested in a statistical table furnished to our neighbor The Tribune by a newspaper clipping bureau showing the number of items or articles clipped for its patrons by the bureau from the newspapers of this city for a period of ten weeks. We reproduce the table from the columns of The Tribune:

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 25. -- The happy ending on Saturday of the long-drawn-out fight between this city and the water works company continues to be the uppermost topic of conversation. The most general satisfaction is expressed on every band that the city has at last been enabled to acquire possession of the water works.

LONDON, Aug. 25. -- The Times to-morrow will publish a dispatch from Shanghai, saying that the inquiry into the massacre of missionaries at Ku-Cheng has been proceeding since Wednesday. All the members of the Consular commission have been present, but progress has been slow.
The Rev. Dr. George F. Pentecost of London preached twice yesterday in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 25. -- Next to the largest crowd of people here on any Sunday during the season was here today. One great feature of the day was a "dry one." Long Branch had not experienced such a dry day in many years. Not a place could be found open where a drink of liquor could be obtained. The majority of saloon keepers left their premises entirely, in order to avoid the annoyance.

OCEAN GROVE, Aug. 25. -- This has been a veritable "high day in Zion" for the many thousands of Methodists on the camp grounds. Fifteen religious meetings were held, and the services were attended by fully 100,000 worshippers, thousands coming from the near-by resorts. The first meeting opened at sunrise, and the last meeting was prolonged until nearly midnight.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 25. -- The semi-annual fair for the benefit of the Home for Friendless Children at Mineola is to be held on the Queens County Fair Grounds at this place, Sept. 4. Besides the attractions usually offered, there are several of popular interest. There will be eight Class A bicycle races for valuable prizes.

CRIPPLE CREEK, Col., Aug. 25. -- Manager Joseph Wolfe, in his knickerbockers, gaudy shirt, sash, big silver buttons, and mammoth Mexican hat, again carried out his promise to give the people a real bullfight, the performance to-day resulting in the slaughter of two bulls. He has probably made money out of the speculation, but he has not succeeded in making the miners of this camp believe that bullfighting is entertaining sport.

Sharp look out for thieves and other persons not desirable to have at large in the community is being kept by Capt. Stephen O'Brien, head of the Detective Bureau. Michael Kurtz found this out Saturday night. Kurtz, as Kurtz, is not widely known. By his more common name of "Sheeny Mike," he has become notorious. His number is 1,460 in the Rogues' Gallery.

BERLIN, Aug. 25. -- In the tennis matches played at Homburg yesterday, the gentlemen's single match was won by Forbes and the gentlemen's double by the brothers Turner. The single handicap was won by Turner. The ladies and gentlemen's double handicap was won by the Grand Duchess of Mecklenburg-Schwerin and Count Vosshonau.

Capt. Staubach of the Manhattan Bicycle Club made that 200-mile trip yesterday from this city to Philadelphia and return, and, although he slipped up on his carefully prepared schedule, he cracked an intermediate road record, and established a mark for the run between the two big cities.

It is reported that the German bimetallists are much discouraged at the declaration of Mr. Balfour last week as to an international conference. They are also deeply incensed at their English brothers for having led them to believe that, with Mr. Balfour as leader of the majority in the House of Commons, a conference was sure to come.

The independent Democratic organizations of New-York and Brooklyn having refused to participate in the regular primaries, the Democracy no longer is confronted by possibilities, but by facts. While it is to be regretted that these gentlemen are unwilling to pursue the course taken by the Rochester factionalists, it is too late for regrets.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- Half of the village of Rosendale, an enterprising cement trading point, is in ruins, as a result of a fire at that place to-day. The damage done cannot be covered by $125,000.

The visit of J. Keir Hardie, President of the British Independent Labor Party, continues to excite much interest among trades unions and organized labor in general. Mr. Hardie devoted Saturday afternoon to a visit to Staten Island, where he heard Prof. Daniel De Leon, editor of The People, speak to a large audience on "Socialism."

UNION HILL, N.J., Aug. 25. -- The twenty-first annual reunion of the Plattdeutsche of New-York was inaugurated at the Schuetzen Park here at noon to-day. The festival is under the auspices of the Plattdutsch Volksfest Vereen of New-York, which comprises the 116 different organizations of the Low Germans of the metropolis.

" I have issued orders to the Police Commissioner to close all saloons on Sunday, and he has reported that they were closed," said Mayor Charles A. Schieren of Brooklyn to a reporter for The New-York Times three weeks ago.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 25. -- A poolroom is in operation at the corner of First and Bergen Streets, Harrison, at which many Newark and New-York sports made bets yesterday on the Futurity and other races. The gambling was carried on in spite of the new and stringent law in New-Jersey, and it was not until to-day that Chief of Police Callagan of Harrison was apprised of the fact.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 25. -- The Rev. Sam Jones preached in Educational Hall this morning and evening. The hall was jammed at both services. His theme at the morning service was "Heres" Here are some of his remarks:
LENOX, Mass., Aug. 25. -- The air was greatly cooled and freshened by a heavy shower last night. The mercury only reached 72 to-day, while yesterday -- the warmest day in August -- it struck 85.

Last week there appeared in the Circuit Court of the United States, in Philadelphia, an applicant for naturalization who was, for a wonder, treated pretty much as the law provides and common sense and fidelity to the judicial oath require. Judge Butler subjected the applicant to a searching inquiry as to age, intended permanent residence, character, and, especially, knowledge of the Constitution of the United States.

State Committeeman Mack's newspaper, The Buffalo Times, misapprehended our position when it said the other day that we asserted that "the State Committee's resolution purging bolting Democrats of their disloyalty is merely specious"; and Mr. Mack's newspaper is also in error in assuming that we have intimated that the State Committee should have taken further action.

LONG ISLAND CITY, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- John Will, seventy-two years old, who lived alone at 562 Fourth Avenue, this city, shot himself in the head this evening with a pistol. The weapon is such a one as was in use a hundred years ago.
The dominating aspiration of police administration, the closing of every place where alcoholic beverages are sold, was not gratified yesterday.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 25. -- Cottagers had a much-needed restful day, and gave the city up almost entirely to excursionists, of whom there were thousands here. It was made a special day for such, and great boatloads came from points in the bay and along the Sound.

In view of hundreds of pleasure seekers at Coney Island yesterday, David O'Connor of this city lost his life while bathing off Balmer's Pavilion, at West Brighton. O'Connor dived, and those nearest him noticed he remained under the water a long time. When he came to the surface he was limp.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25. -- The Irish National Convention, which has been called to meet in Chicago Sept. 24, continues to stir up the fighting factions of the various Irish organizations in this country, and evoke the bitterest denunciation of those who have identified themselves with the "new-movement" convention.

For three weeks the sulkies employed in the Grand Circuit have been running the gantlet in this State, with a result that on the surface has little encouragement for the future success of light-harness sport under the existing legislation. Never was a prohibitory measure more thoroughly enforced than the one which forbids all forms of open betting on the race tracks of this Commonwealth.

NAPLES, Aug. 25. -- The representative here of The United Press learns that the settlement that has been arrived at between Prince and Princess Colonna, the latter the stepdaughter of John W. Mackay, gives the Princess the custody of the children, she paying the Prince the sum of 60,000f. yearly.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 25. -- The fight for Chairman of the State Republican Committee is now centred at the State capital. The leaders of both sides are here in great numbers to line up their forces for the struggle. The battle will open to-morrow, when a meeting of the State Committee will be held to prepare the roll of delegates to the State Convention.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- It is now definitely settled that Frank E. Rigby and Oliver P. Burnhardt, the members of the crack Cleveland team of Class B fliers, will be at the Autumn meet and tourney of the New-York State Division of the League of American Wheelmen at the Driving Park on Sept. 5 and 6.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 25. -- A good attendance again favored the Mutual Driving Club's trotting events at Waverley Park yesterday afternoon. Mr. Elisha B. Gaddis and other leading men of the New-Jersey Agricultural Society were present. An improvement was made in the Judges' stand, so that now the starter can stand out over the stretch and have a better view of the horses.

" Hol' up dah, mah son, hol' up dah!" excitedly exclaimed the Gen. Slocum's negro steward yesterday afternoon just as that vessel commenced to glide away from her landing at the Battery. The elderly darky was dancing about the rail, wildly gesticulating and pointing toward the water, where a kinky head had for a moment disappeared with a splutter and a splash.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25. -- Col. J.J. McCook, receiver of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe; Wheeler H. Peckham, counsel for the Union Trust Company; W.H. Rossington, Western counsel for the Atchison Reorganization Committee, and others interested in the Atchison reorganization, arrived here last evening.
In three widely distant parts of the globe American missionaries have been lately subjected to harassing, or are now exposed to perils that excite more or less anxiety for them.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- Hamilton Bonney and Fred Lyon, two young Rochester men, set out in a small sailboat from Charlotte, late Saturday afternoon, for Sodus. The breeze was twenty miles an hour, and they had to take a tow to get outside the piers. After sunset, when off Irondequolt Bay, their rudder was unshipped and they lost their centreboard, with the result that the boat was upset.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 25. -- Sunday, as usual, has been a quiet day, society attending church in the morning, driving on Corniche Road in the afternoon, and resting in the evening to prepare itself for the coming week, which promises to be one filled with gayety.
ROCKAWAY BEACH, L.I., Aug. 25. -- The chief feature at this place to-day was the free and unrestricted license which the gamblers enjoyed at the hands of Sheriff Doht's police.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 25. -- The eighteenth anniversary of the dedication of St. Patrick's Catholic Church was celebrated to-day, with impressive ceremonies, under the direction of the Rev. Father Patrick Hennessy, its venerable rector.

Some people noticed that it was very smoky about the city and bay yesterday, and some did not. The bluish haze that brooded everywhere, veiling the islands in the bay, was mixed with fog and helped the damp winds from the ocean chill the sunshine, and to many the trouble was just fog.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25. -- Those who do not believe that Matthew Stanley Quay is one of the best political organizers in the country may have their views regarding him changed by the news from Harrisburg next Wednesday. That day he will probably be elected Chairman of the Republican State Committee of Pennsylvania, and his victory will mean the defeat of every other conspicuous leader of his party in the State.
CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 26. -- The passengers in the stages on the way to the morning train to-day witnessed an unusual sight, and for a time feared they would have to deal with a maniac.
HASTINGS, Aug. 26. -- The sixteenth round of the International Chess Masters' tournament was played to-day, with these results:

BUFFALO, Aug. 26. -- If hard work will bring success to any venture, then the approaching State Division race tournament will be the cycling event par excellence in the history of the sport in western New-York.

The Times's special cable dispatch from Rio Janeiro published on Saturday brought the welcome news of peace in Rio Grande do Sul, and now a dispatch from Minister Thompson states that the Government of Brazil has signed an "agreement of peace" with the revolutionists.

There is no reason why there should be any difference on State issues, providing the machine does not pursue the bullhead policy which has resulted in party overthrow in the past. Certainly the lesson of the last two years ought to count for something. The importance of the State election this Fall ought especially to emphasize the folly of permitting local contentions to endanger the success of the State ticket.

A large and far-reaching amount of legitimate curiosity was satisfied yesterday when the remodeled plan for the reorganization of the Erie Railway was issued simultaneously in this city and in London through the medium of J.P. Morgan Co. and J.S. Morgan Co., respectively.

Frank Snyder, fourteen years old, of 164 Prospect Street, Brooklyn, was committed to jail for examination Friday on a charge of murder by Justice Welsh, in the Adams Street Police Court, yesterday morning.

" I've seen bear, deer, antelope, and Other animals in their native wilds. I've hunted and fished to satiety in a grand, happy hunting ground, marvelously stocked with all kinds of game of feather and fin, with prairie chicken, wild geese, and wild duck, salmon and trout, and nearly everything else that affords sport for a gunner or angler.

ALBANY, Aug. 26. -- Ex-Congressman Charles Tracey of this city believes that judicious selection of candidates by the Democratic State Convention, which meets in Syracuse Sept. 24, will bring victory to the party in November.

Bankers, both in and out of Wall Street, are rejoicing over the steadily accumulating evidences of improvement in the general financial situation. The movement of currency to the South and to the West has begun in earnest, and it promises to be particularly heavy this week.

BOSTON, Aug. 26. -- The busiest place in Boston to-day was the headquarters of the Triennial Conclave Committee of Knights Templars. Early in the morning the chief of each sub-committee was at his desk ready for the business of the day. The scene was decidedly suggestive of the headquarters of the Commander in Chief of an army that was about to be led into battle.

PARIS, Aug. 26. -- Thirty Anarchists, who were arrested on suspicion in connection with the infernal machine by the explosion of which M. Jacobsky, the confidential clerk of Baron Alphonse de Rothschild, was badly injured on Saturday, were released this morning for want of evidence.

John H. Buswell, clerk in the Department of Street Cleaning, who lives on the fourth floor of a flathouse at 223 West One Hundred and Fifteenth Street, was robbed of $500 worth of clothing and jewelry early on Friday morning last. The robbers used chloroform, and Mr. Buswell was awakened by the effects of the drug, but too late to catch the invaders.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- The committees representing the Counties of Otsego and Herkimer to fix upon the representation which each should have in the Thirty-third Republican Senatorial Convention made another miss to-day. Herkimer wants equal representation; Otsego demands eight to seven.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- If the outrages in China against foreign missionaries continue, and it becomes necessary to invoke the aid of the naval power in those waters to protect Americans, the United States will be capable of landing a larger body of sailors and marines than any other nation, with the possible exception of Great Britain.
BRANTFORD, Ontario, Aug. 26. -- Gardiner and Coulter, the bicyclists, returned to the track today prepared for a steady campaign. Gardiner had ridden twice before recently, but only for practice.

As a matter of fact, new insurance rates have not been promulgated in Vermont. Insurance men are now engaged in re-rating risks in various parts of the State, the work in Burlington having just been completed, and it is expected that the new rates will not be promulgated for several weeks yet. Moreover, there will not be a general increase in rates throughout Vermont, inas-much as some rates will be lower than before.

MONDAY -- P.M. Under the lead of the Grangers, the whole market advanced sharply to-day. St. Paul was in active demand, and advanced to 75 1/8 but closed at 75, a net gain of 1 5/8 points. The possibilities in Atchison pointed out in The Times on Sunday were recognized, and on good buying the stock advanced a point.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 26. -- The first thing of interest to cottage and hotel guests occurred at the Central Station this morning as the 9:30 train started for New-York. The occupants of handsome equipages, who had driven friends to the station, were horrified to see the bent form of an aged man, who proved to be J.A. Caldwell of New-York, thrown from the car platform to the ground.

The iron steamboat Perseus and the auxiliary steam sloop yacht Adelaide, owned by R.W. Inman, son of John H. Inman, were in collision last evening off Norton's Point, Coney Island. The Adelaide was thrown on her beam ends by the shock, and four of those on board were spilled into the water. No lives were lost.

Seventeen turtles, green of color and chagrined of feature, the delight of epicures and the prize of Southern fishermen, were brought to this port yesterday by the Ward Line steamship Vigilancia. They were caught off Tampico, Mexico, and came consigned to Eugene Blackford, ex-State Fish Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- In view of the constructions that have been placed upon Mr. Spofford's statement that he recently paid to the Treasury the sum of $22,400 on his accounts, the Librarian of Congress desires that the following explanation be made public:
YREKA, Cal., Aug. 26. -- Four men were taken from jail this morning by a mob and hanged to a rail which had been placed in the forks of two trees on the Court House square.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 26. -- The day has been an unusually gay one, the golf links at Kebo being crowded from early morning, the bay alive with yachting parties, and the evening taken up with several dinners and dances.

CENTRE ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 26. -- In a brisk southerly breeze that ruffled the waters of the Sound and tossed small craft about like cockleshells seven diminutive yachts competed today for the honor of defending the Seawanhaka international challenge cup for boats under fifteen feet in length. It was the first day of the trial races to select the boat that is to meet the English boat Spruce IV, in September.

LONDON, Aug. 26. -- The representative in this city of The United Press to-day had an interview with Montagu Sherman, who will accompany the Cambridge University and London Athletic Club teams, who sail to-morrow for New-York.

CHIVAGO, Aug. 26. -- A hundred horrified people saw Albert Golden tightly hugging his two-year-old child in his arms dragged half a block by a cable car yesterday afternoon. The cars were crowded with pleasure seekers, and Golden was obliged to stand. As the car shot around the curve at Cottage Grove Avenue the man was hurled from the platform.

There is no longer any occasion for doubt as to the attitude that will be assumed in the approaching political campaign by the Democratic Party in Kings County. Its General Committee met last night in the Athenaeum, corner of Atlantic Avenue and Clinton Street, Brooklyn, and declared unanimously for independent action at Syracuse and in the local conventions.

In the plan of reorganization submitted to the holders of the securities of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railway system, by J. Pierpont Morgan and his associates, there are many points that will undoubtedly meet with general approval, some points that will receive careful criticism, and some other points that will arouse antagonism.

HUDSON, Aug. 26. -- Twenty-five citizens and freeholders of the village of Chatham have petitioned the Board of Supervisors of Columbia County to change the site of the county buildings from Hudson to Chatham.

The Commissioners appointed by Gov. Morton, under the law of March 12, 1895, for the purpose of adopting measures to induce the United States Government to acquire the Palisades along the Hudson for a military reservation have been over the ground carefully, and secured the necessary maps and photographs.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- "The Ministers' Study of the Labor Problem" was the title of an interesting paper read by the Rev. Dr. Wilbur F. Crafts of Baltimore, Md., before the Ministers' Association this morning.

Judging by the splendid patronage accorded to the first appearance of the Grand Circuit cracks at Fleetwood Park, the Driving Club of New-York has succeeded in its efforts to arouse local interest in harness racing. There was not a vacant seat on the clubhouse stoop yesterday afternoon when the five days' meeting began, and the boxes on the balcony were all well filled.

If regular and contesting delegations are sent to the Syracuse Convention from this city and from Brooklyn there may be peace and there may be war. A contest is in itself an element of war. If the contestants win, peace commonly results. If they lose, war generally follows.

NYACK, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Senator Clarence Lexow yesterday visited an unoccupied house belonging to him. He found the door of an upper room locked. When he reached home he asked his wife if she had locked that door or ordered it locked. She had not.
UNION HILL, N.J., Aug. 26. -- The festivities of the second day of the twenty-first Plattdutsche Volksfest attracted as large an attendance as the previous day, and again the 35,000 mark was passed.

LA PORTE, Ind., Aug. 26. -- Three hundred persons in attendance at a Lutheran Church festival, at Tracy, yesterday were poisoned. One thousand communicants assembled at the village. Services were held in a large grove. At the conclusion of the morning services the people went to the tables for dinner.

A public hearing was begun yesterday before the New-York Harbor Lines Board, in the United States Army Building, in Whitehall Street, for the purpose of determining the location of the New-York City approaches to the proposed New-York and New-Jersey Bridge, and also to fix the terminus of the bridge on the New-York side of the North River.
The Police Board yesterday adopted the following, on motion of Commissioner Parker:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Miss Lucretia Clark, the school teacher who so mysteriously disappeared from Plainfield, N.J., Friday morning, Aug. 9, has been found. She was discovered at an early hour this morning at the home of ex-Mayor Charles S. Hayden, at 28 Holt Street, Fitchburg, Mass., by Detective Louis J. Beck of New-York, who has been at work on the case since last Friday.

GLARGOW, Aug. 14. -- Hopes are running very high here that Valkyrie will bring back the cup. Experts explain that the conditions of the coming contest are quite different from what they have been previously. It is no longer a centreboard cutter with deep draught versus a keel cutter, but two keel cutters.

WILLET'S POINT, L.I., Aug. 26. -- One of the most interesting characters among those that have come to this place in some time is an undersized, dark-complexioned man, who enlisted under the name of Peter Mentz in the Engineer Battalion about ten days ago.

Mrs. Ernest M. Munn, wife of the well-known coal shipper of the Produce Exchange, is determined to appeal from the decision of Lawrence Godkin, who, as referee, reported adversely to the Supreme Court on an application for a limited divorce brought by Mrs. Munn.
HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 26. -- Whether Senator Quay or the leaders arrayed against him will control the Republican organization in the State after next Wednesday remains yet to be determined.
" There will be no bossism from this office on the matter. If it is determined to nominate a union ticket again this year, very well, but I will not interfere in any way."

Holders of a majority of the consolidated mortgage bonds of the Savannah and Western Railroad Company met in the office of Simon Borg Co. yesterday to consider the proposition for participation in the reorganization of the Central Railroad and Banking Company of Georgia, submitted to the Mercantile Trust Company by Gen. Samuel Thomas and Thomas F. Ryan.

" We are suffering politically and commercially, not from revolution or fear of impending insurrection, but from false reports published in Panama and in the United States about a 'conspiracy' against the Government of San Salvador," said Manuel Parraga, a San Salvador merchant, just arrived from the capital of the smallest but most densely peopled and bustling of the Central American republics, yesterday.
WINFIELD, L.I., Aug. 26. -- William H. Mason, a stenographer of this village, lies dangerously ill at his home from the effects of nicotine poisoning. He is an inveterate cigarette smoker.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 26. -- Many driving parties have been in Lenox to-day. M.J. McEvoy of New-York arrived with a party of friends, including Mrs. M.A. McGlynn and Mr. and Mrs. M.H. Lawlor of Waterbury. Nathaniel Mann of Ballston Spa, and John E. Peck of Troy, were also here to-day, on their way through the country.

The United States Consul in Kingston. Jamaica, is Quincy Oliver Eckford of Mississippi. Mr. Eckford was one of Mr. Cleveland's first appointments in the present Administration, and I think that everybody who has been to Jamaica since he took possession of the office will agree with me that he is one of the best.

Solidarity Watch Case Company of. Brookl lyn, to acquire and continue ne i>uslness ox the Solidarity Watch Case Company (cooperative) and to engage in the manufactu'e of watch cases and other artieles of Jewelry, c.; cai. tal,_ $50,01. Directors.

OCEAN GROVE, Aug. 26. -- Interest in the great camp meeting continues unabated. The reaction feared after yesterday's tidal wave of enthusiasm did not materialize today, for every service was well attended, and a number of people professed religion.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 26. -- Southern New-Jersey is withering under the worst drought it has experienced in many years. No rain has fallen in over three weeks, and only two light showers have passed over the section in eight weeks. The damage to late crops can scarcely be estimated.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 26. -- Thomas M. King, Vice President of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company, will start to-day on a trip of inspection over the Roanoke and Southern and the Cape Fear and Yadkin Valley Railroad lines. Mr. King will be accompanied by Gen. John Gill, receiver of the last-named road, and Col. John A. Thompkins, expert accountant.

Recent reports of railway earnings show a gratifying condition of prosperity in every section of the country. The most favorable returns, however, have come from the West and Northwest. Some of the Granger roads, even in advance of the crop movement, are reporting remarkable increases in traffic receipts.
James Keir Hardie, the English labor leader and ex-Member of the British Parliament, was kept very busy yesterday.
LIMA, Peru, via Galveston, Aug. 26. -- The headless body of the Italian, Luis Guiffra, murdered a year ago by the Cacerist police, has been discovered and identified.

PARIS, Aug. 26. -- Newton B. Eustis, son of the American Ambassador and Second Secretary, and Mr. Alexander, counsel of the embassy, returned to-day from Clairvaux, whither they went to see John L. Waller, American ex-Consul to Madagascar, who was sentenced by a court-martial to a long term of imprisonment on conviction of having informed the Hovas, with whom the French are at war, of the movements of the French.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 26. -- The final match in the all-comers tennis tournament was decided this morning. As usual, the favorite was defeated, Larned falling again at the critical moment, just as he failed last year, when he had Goodbody beaten. Hovey won in straight sets.
" Tell the members of your constituency in the eastern section of the city that I am in favor of home rule and local option."

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 26. -- The Duke of Marlborough is the lion of the time here. He was out bright and early this morning, driving with Mrs. Alva Vanderbilt and Miss Consuelo. They made a few calls, Mrs. Vanderbilt introducing him to her more intimate friends, and then they drove to the Casino, where the tennis match between Hovey and Larned for the all-comers' prize was witnessed.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 26. -- Frederick Schamp is in the county jail awaiting the result of the Coroner's inquest into the killing of Farmer Samuel Clark, Sr., at Scotch Plains Saturday night. The inquest will be held Wednesday.

The contest for the Tammany Hall leadership in the Eleventh Assembly District between William Dalton, formerly an Excise Commissioner, the present leader of the district, and John J. Delany, was the subject of a long hearing before a sub-committee of Tammany's Committee on Contested Seats in Tammany Hall yesterday.

Ex-United States Senator Warner Miller of New-York talked with me for a few moments shortly after his arrival here. The Senator and Mrs. Miller have just returned from an extensive trip through Canada. "Our trip," he said, "was a thoroughly delightful one. With us were Gen. and Mrs. Horatio Alger, and a number of gentlemen who, like the General and myself, are largely interested in timber lands through the north of Canada.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 26. -- The special attraction here this afternoon was the open-air horse show, given at the Union Avenue Running Park, of the Saratoga Racing Association. It was held under the auspices of the Albany County Horse Show Association. The weather was perfect and there was a large and fashionable audience.

Just as evidences of reviving business all over the country are extremely annoying to those who believe a high tariff to be the only orthodox foundation for prosperity, so the remarkable decrease in the number of arrests for drunkenness and consequent disorderly and criminal conduct on Sunday must excite indignation in the people who have been bemoaning the enforcement of the excise law.

The Police Commissioners were jubilant yesterday over the manner in which the excise law was enforced throughout the city on Sunday. They were thoroughly satisfied with the work done by the police, which demonstrated that with the honest assistance of the reputable portion of the saloon keepers the law can be effectually enforced.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- David P. Williams, foreman of a gang of press riggers, from the Cottrell Printing Manufacturing Company, was crushed to death under a heavy printing frame in the Knickerbocker Press Company's building, at this place, this evening.

The ecclesiastical world will breathe more freely (or will it be disappointed?) to learn that it has just escaped a heresy trial. Among the younger professors in Andover Seminary, Andover, Mass., is a certain Prof. Ryder, who occupies the Chair of New Testament Exegesis. His duties require him to define very clearly the teaching as to the person of Christ, and his obligations to the creed require that those teachings be along certain well-defined lines.

WILLET'S POINT, L.I., Aug. 26. -- Much is being said and written at present on the merits and demerits of the new Krag-Jorgensen gun recently adopted by the United States Army, and as it is the weapon which would be used in defense of the Union, if one were necessary, it should interest every American to know whether it is the most desirable arm that can be had.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Aug. 26. -- President Clark, General Manager Dickinson, and other officials of the Union Pacific Railway, who are here, say that there is no truth in the charges made against them that they are in a "syndicate to freeze out private coal mining industries, and themselves reap the financial benefit of the monopoly thus formed."

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 26. -- W.W. Kettel of Washington, D.C., shot and instantly killed himself at the Hotel Willey, on Sixth Street, at 8:55 o'clock this morning. The suicide stood in front of the mirror in his room when he fired the bullet into the base of his brain, behind the right ear.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Aug. 26. -- The Mayor of this town is C.N. Arnold, a lumber dealer, a Republican, and a man who has not been known in recent years to tell a lie. He was nominated largely because Robert H. Hunter, formerly a State Committeeman, a Platt Republican ex-Collector of Internal Revenue, and county "boss," backed him for the office.
CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Passed East -- Steam yachts Reva, George L. Ronalds; Charlietta, W.B. Higgins; Orienta, E.R. Ladew; Helvetia, Columbus O'D. Iselin, and Lorna, W.L. Stow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Secretary of War Lamont to-day issued formal orders regarding the National dedication of the Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park, which will take place on the 19th and 20th of September. The exercises on the first day will be at Snodgrass Hill,. Chickamauga battlefield, when addresses will be delivered by Gen. John M. Palmer of Illinois and Gen. John B. Gordon of Georgia.

ALBANY, Aug. 26. -- State Controller Roberts returned to this city this morning and was at his desk about noon, looking as comfortable as if he had no idea that he was to be "thrown down" or thrown over by ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt when the Tioga chief makes up his list of State candidates.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 26. -- The Morning Herald, Baltimore's popular one-cent daily newspaper, moved into its new building, at the corner of St. Paul and Fayette Streets, to-day. The facilities of its old home, corner Baltimore and Charles Streets, were inadequate to meet the demands of its increasing business, and it was found necessary to seek new and more commodious quarters.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 26. -- There was a notable gathering of lawyers and jurists here this morning to attend a conference of members of the State Commissions for the Promotion of Uniformity of Legislation in the United States. Frederick H. Stimson of Boston called the meeting to order, and S.M. Cutcheon of this city was made Chairman.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 27. -- The annual contracts for bedding, clothing, and other necessaries at the National Home for Disabled Volunteer Soldiers were awarded to-day by Gen. Franklin, President, as follows:
HASTINGS, England, Aug. 27. -- The seventeenth round of the international chess master's tournament was played at Massey's Institute today, and the following are the results:

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 27. -- A grand concert was given to-night at the Brighton Hotel, under the direction of the Orpheus Male Quartet of New-York City. The leading parts were taken by Andrew Howard and John H. Van Arsdale, tenor singers, and Frederick D. Lincoln and J. Crawfurd, bassos, assisted by Louis Muniz, as pianist.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- In spite of the threatening weather, the Cadets gave the "color line" entertainment in the open air to-night. There was an unusually large audience present. No entertainment previously given here was so successful.

SARATOGA, Aug. 27. -- Members of the Proportional Representation Society of New-York and the American Proportional Representation League began a conference here to-day. The delegates do not exceed fifty in number. The conference is presided over by William Dudley Foulke of Richmond, Ind., President of the league, who made the opening address, stating the object of the gathering.

UNION HILL, N.J., Aug. 27. -- The third day of the Plattdeutsche Volksfest, now in progress here at the Schuetzen Park, was a typical old-fashioned German celebration of a bountiful harvest. In the Fatherland one of the liveliest periods is the time of the year when the harvest is gathered in. When the farmers have ended their labors for the Summer several days are devoted to a general jollification.

Delegates of the Wine, Beer and Liquor Dealers' Association of New-York County met at the Terrace Garden, Fifty-eighth Street and Third Avenue, yesterday afternoon. The purpose of the meeting was to take action on the resolution of the Excise Committee last week to the effect that all members of the association should, after Sept. 1, voluntarily close their places of business Sundays, and respect the excise law as it now exists.
Customs officers have arrested two men since Sunday on charges of smuggling, and both were held yesterday for examination to-morrow by United States Commissioner Alexander.
Westcott F. Zittel declares that he was intoxicated when he married Emma Richter, and he has begun a suit in the Court of Common Pleas for the annulment of his marriage.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Aug. 27. -- A crowd of angry boarders and a string of creditors stood around the piazzas and parlors of the Raulah House at sundown to-night vowing vengeance on the head of Manager Wallace McCutcheon, who had left the hotel in a mysterious way, and had later been joined by his wife. The creditors wanted McCutcheon because he owed them large sums, and the boarders wanted him because they were hungry.

At last London begins to understand that the affairs of this country are not in the hopeless condition represented by certain financial publications in that city. These papers for a year or more have been warning off European investors from American securities, telling them that there was nothing good in this country, and that money could only be placed here at imminent risk of loss.

On the 20th of July the Spanish Minister, from the shades of Swampscot, wrote a private letter which he allows to be published in the latest number of Harper's Weekly. It relates to the Cuban insurrection. He says: "The American press does not want the truth. * * *

ASHFIELD, Mass., Aug. 27. -- There was a charming wedding this afternoon at the Congregational Church at 5 o'clock, when Miss Julia Lincoln Ray of Chicago was married to James P. Andrews of Hartford, Conn. Miss Ray is the daughter of the widow of the late Dr. C.H. Ray, formerly editor in chief of The Chicago Tribune, and the granddaughter of the late Lincoln Clark of Chicago and Conway, Mass.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Via Galveston, Aug. 27. -- The war in Ecuador is virtually ended. Quite has pronounced in favor of Gen. Eloy Alfaro.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- A report was circulated about the State departments today, which gained credence as it spread, that Thomas C. Platt had thrown a sop to John E. Milholland, and that Mr. Milholland was awaiting a good opportunity to get within the fold again.

The shaft which was unveiled yesterday in Prospect Park is one of those memorials to the patriots of the Revolution that owe their origin to the societies of "Sons" and "Daughters," of late years so zealous in their work.

An Inquiry was begun yesterday afternoon at the New-York Navy Yard, Brooklyn, to ascertain who was responsible for the careless docking of the cruiser Columbia at Southampton, England, while that vessel was preparing for her test of speed across the Atlantic.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- The Saratoga Summer lectures were resumed this morning, the Saratoga Opera House being filled to its full capacity. The Rev. Dr. Wilbur F. Crafts of Pittsburg, Penn., delivered a carefully prepared and very interesting lecture on "Christian Sociology from the Church Standpoint."

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- One of the largest and most fashionable progressive euchre parties ever held here was given last evening at the Spring House, by T.R. Proctor. The prizes were a gold candlestick, a metal vase, silver scissors, a hand-painted clock, a silver pocket pencil, and a fan.

Considerable indignation is being expressed by the Cubans in this city who sympathize with the revolutionary movement now in progress in Cuba concerning a letter from E. Dupuy de Lorne, the Spanish Minister to this country, printed in Harper's Weekly, in which he asserts that the American press does not want the truth about the Cuban revolution.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Aug. 27. -- John I. Davenport, formerly Supervisor of Elections in New-York City, has been for two years or more the tenant of a fine house at 1448 Wyoming Avenue, Washington Heights, which has all the fittings and appointments of a luxurious home.

The position taken by the party in Brooklyn of which Mr. Edward M. Shepard is the recognized leader, as to the government of the city, is the only one which could be taken with honor or with any hope of carrying out the purpose of the party. That purpose has been clearly held from the first and firmly pursued.

OCEAN GROVE, Aug. 27. -- As the end of the camp meeting draws near, the interest in it increases. The twelve services to-day attracted large congregations. At the holiness meeting at 9 A.M., the Rev. Dr. McFarlane of Newark gave an account of his work in that city. The young people's meeting was unusually interesting, and scores of penitents in the audience asked for prayers.

The memory of Col. Smallwood's Marylanders who fell in the battle of Long Island Aug. 27, 1776, was honored and more deeply graven on the tablets of history by imposing ceremonies in Brooklyn yesterday.

Jockey Henry Griffin, who made such a phenomenal record by riding five successive winners at the Coney Island race track on Saturday last, was not so much in evidence yesterday. He had mounts in all six races that were run, but could not get any of his horses home as the winner of a race.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27. -- The tennis championship has changed hands again, and Fred Hovey, after years of hard struggle and bitter disappointment, is champion of the United States. The victory was a decisive one, Wrenn failing to win a single set.

The Aldermen yesterday by a vote of 22 to 8, in the face of public interest and against overwhelming arguments made in behalf of the Metropolitan Traction Company, granted the Third Avenue Railroad Company's application for the King's Bridge Road extensions.

Two sales were scheduled to take place at the Broadway salesroom, yesterday, both in foreclosure proceedings. The bidders were few in number, and were made up almost exclusively of auction room habitues. John A. Mapes offered the plot on West Sixty-eighth Street, north side, 400 feet west of West End Avenue, size 89.8 by 101.8 by 55.7 by 100.5, against which the judgment called for $10,585 and costs of foreclosure proceedings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Minister Denby telegraphs that, in response to a request made by him to the Tsung-li-Yamen, the Taotai, Hsu Hs Ing I, has been sent to cooperate with Consul Hixson in investigating the Ku-Cheng riots. The rank of this Commissioner, who is an Intendant of Circuit, is by treaty equal to that of the Consul.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The uncertainty concerning the case of Matt W. Ransom of North Carolina was ended to-day by the announcement of the ex-Senator's reappointment to the position of Minister to Mexico, which was declared vacant by the decision of Acting Attorney General Conrad that Mr. Ransom's nomination to the mission during his Senatorial term was unconstitutional.

ALBANY, Aug. 27. -- The contest in the Twenty-sixth Senatorial District -- Sullivan, Delaware, and Chenango -- between the Republicans has narrowed down to two men, James Ballantine of Delaware and J.W. Church of Chenango. The contest for Delaware's delegates was waged between Mr. Crosby and Mr. Ballantine.

If ever there was pomp in a title it is found in this exceedingly handsome volume, with its wealth of photogravures. Here are the actual sources of stories and legends which have come to us across seas from the mother land. You begin with Windsor Castle and you conclude with Lismore Castle, County Waterford, Ireland.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 27. -- Mrs. Frank Ellis gave a dinner this evening at Cleftstone cottage. Covers were laid for fifteen, and the affair was an exceedingly pleasant one. Among the guests were Mr. and Mrs. Edward Blair, Dr. and Mrs. W.W. Seely, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Bonner Bowler, Mr. and Mrs. A. Howard Hinkle, and Dr. and Mrs. Guy Fairfax Whiting.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27. -- The steel steam yacht Thespia, being completed at Cramps' ship yard for Mr. David Dows, Jr., of New-York, has just finished her speed trials. The trial ground was between League Island anl New-Castle, Del. The maximum indicated horse power developed was 830.8, with 155 revolutions, and the mean speed both ways, with and against tide, was 15.13 knots.

No news had been received up to a late hour last night of Robert W. Inman, the young cotton broker, and cousin of John H. Inman, who has been missing since Monday evening, when his auxiliary steam sloop yacht Adelaide was in collision with the Perseus of the Iron Steamboat Company off Bay Ridge, L.I.

James White, alias James Lee, alias Michael Kelly, thirty-seven years old, who says he lives at 37 Bowery, was held by Magistrate Crane, in the Tombs Police Court yesterday, on a charge of forgery to the amount of $308, preferred by Jeremiah Foley, a saloon keeper at Cherry and Roosevelt, Streets.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 27. -- Only the prompt action of the police to-day prevented a riot between the employes of the Pennsylvania and New-Jersey Junction Railroad Companies. The scene of the disturbance was Point of Rocks, at the foot of the heights where the Pennsylvania tracks enter the Bergen Cut from the east.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- The Albany County Horse Show Association this afternoon brought to a close its very successful first annual open-air show. The attendance fully equaled that of the opening day, and was composed principally of fashionable people. The awards made by the judges were as follows:
