The members of the Southern States Freight Association, which is to take the place of the Southern Railway and Steamship Association, met in the Hotel Waldorf yesterday. R.N. Erwin, Vice President of the Plant system, presided.

The Fourteenth Regiment of Brooklyn yesterday abandoned the old armory in North Portland Avenue, where its headquarters have been for the last seventeen years, and moved into the handsome new armory built for it at Eighth Avenue and Fourteenth Street.

Summer travel affords many interesting opportunities for the study of that most absorbing topic, human nature. It is a time when those of us who are inclined to be at all puffed up with self-esteem may find frequent opportunity for thanking Heaven that we are not as other persons are.

The Valkyrie stretched her sails yesterday afternoon and showed that she is a remarkably fast boat. She only set her mainsail, jib, and staysail, but with these she easily distanced a fleet of fast tugboats, and that apparently without any effort.
The will of Moritz Ertheiler, who was known as the "Honest Man of Maiden Lane," was admitted to probate yesterday in the Surrogate's Court, without opposition.

When Nancy Hanks was queen of trotters and made her debut before a metropolitan crowd the occasion drew the largest assembly that has been seen at Fleetwood Park in recent times. That was during the Grand Circuit meeting of 1893, and, though the swift-footed mare from Kentucky did not lower her record, she did a mile in 2:06 3/4 -- a very creditable feat.

The yachting season has already completely settled the question what yacht is to defend the America's Cup. There is no use of any further racing to decide that point. The Vigilant is not fast enough to dispute the representation.

If a couple of hundred coins are placed upon a tray and tossed on the table repeatedly, it is plain that at each throw any number of heads from none to 200 may turn up after each throw. If there were no trick in the business, none and 200 would very rarely appear. Most frequently the difference between heads and tails would be more or less even.

BOSTON, Aug. 27. -- The great parade of Knights Templars, a very prominent event in the great conclave, took place to-day. All conditions were auspicious for the demonstration. The sun's rays were obscured by a thick haze, and a refreshing westerly breeze tempered the Summer heat. The early morning scenes in the city streets were inspiring.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- A hearing today before Acting Secretary McAdoo of the Navy Department, with reference to amending the specifications for constructing the new naval dry dock at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, developed that the contractors, in driving piles, had struck some hard substance, which they could not penetrate, at a distance of thirty-nine feet, whereas they are required by the contract to extend the depth to forty-five feet.
HOBOKEN, N.J., Aug. 27. -- The police have for several days been investigating the reported interment of an infant before it was dead. The facts in the case were given out only to-day.

The resolutions adopted Monday night by the Democratic organization in Kings County, of which Mr. Edward M. Shepard is the leader, are regarded by Brooklyn Republican politicians as an effectual bar to Democratic harmony in the City of Churches, but this view is not entertained by some of the prominent members of the regular Democracy.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 27. -- The day was an ideal golfers' day, and it seemed as if all Lenox was down at the links, either as spectators or players. Among the players were J. Egmont Schermerhorn, S. Parkman Shaw, Joseph W. Burden, Miss Eunice Ives, Miss Grosvenor, Miss Edith Barnes, Miss Constance Parsons, Miss Grace Parsons, and Miss Carrie Webb.

City Works Commissioner White of Brooklyn yesterday appointed Miss Eva A. Weed, twenty-five years old, of 228 East Thirty-second Street, this city, an assistant in the draughting department of the Bureau of Sewers.

The investigation into the official record of Anthony Clinchy, State Inspector of Gas Meters, was resumed at 2 o'clock P.M. yesterday before Severn R. Sharp, who was appointed Commissioner by Gov. Morton to conduct the investigation.

Contrary to general expectation, the inquest to fix the responsibility for the loss of fifteen human lives when the Ireland Building collapsed, Aug. 8, was not concluded yesterday. All the testimony, however, is in, the last witness for the people. John B. Ireland, the owner of the building, having been called and having willingly testified yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 27. -- A small crowd of enthusiasts were present to witness the departure of the Cambridge University team and the remnant of the London Athletic Club team at 11 o'clock this forenoon from Euston Station. The special train which took them also carried the rest of the Aurania's passengers to Liverpool, whence they will embark for New-York.

Though the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst is at present in the peaceful town of Vevay, Switzerland, where he expects to remain for another month, he has already sounded the tocsin for the coming political campaign in a communication to the City Vigilance League.

Lieut. Gov. Saxton and Senator O'Connor, who were in town yesterday, had some things to say about politics. Senator O'Connor does not want to see another union ticket nominated in this city, even though he doesn't live here.

CENTER ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 27. -- Again today the Ethelwynn scored a victory over the other half-raters who are striving to attain the honor of defending the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club's trophy against the English boat Spruce IV. Although there yet remains one more day of the trial races, and the committee has not made its decision, the Ethelwynn's showing yesterday and to-day will no doubt entitle her to the distinction of meeting the English boat.

Excise Commissioner Julius Harburger is reported as calling those who support our Police Commissioners' Sunday policy "Puritanical, fanatical, and bigoted beings, who pride themselves on their blue-blooded ancestral lineage."

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 27. -- The American Bar Association convened in eighteenth annual session this morning. Among those who occupied the platform were Justices Brewer and Brown of the United States Supreme Court and Justice W.H. Taft of the United States Circuit Court.

Senator Lexow said some days ago that he had something better than "local option" to offer for the settlement of the Sunday excise question in this and other cities. It was a broader system of "home rule," under which "one of the items of local self-government might be the making of excise rules."
Is whisky a "necessary of life"? This is the burning issue in the latest phase of the Whisky Trust litigation instituted through Guggenheimer, Untermyer Marshall against the Reorganization Committee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- "If there is anything wrong going on in this department, I want it to be uncovered and a stop put to it. I want Congress, when it meets, to appoint an investigating committee of fifteen, and have 'em come down here and spend everyday with me."

John Bowe, member of the Democratic State Committee and Treasurer of Albany County, has been stopping at the United States Hotel, Far Rockaway, during the month of August. A reporter for The New-York Times called upon him yesterday afternoon to get his views on the prospects of Democratic success in New-York State this Fall.

NEW-HAVEN, Aug. 27. -- We have come down from the airy summit of East Rock to the old square Green, in the very heart of the town, asking the trolley to disclose some of the signs of change and growth which were hidden under the broad green cloak of the tree-tops. Here, at the busy corner where the town pump stands, is the starting point for all the electric lines.

The death of the nine-year-old boy, Benjamin Pincus, was looked into by Coroner O'Meagher and a jury yesterday. Solomon Pulka of 64 Willett Street was accused of causing the lad's death by a kick. Pauline Schaunbaet, eleven years old, testified that she saw a man kick the boy, but that it was not the defendant.

BREMEN, Aug. 27. -- The German-American veterans arrived here this afternoon. They visited the monument erected to the memory of the victims of the Franco-Prussian war, and placed wreaths around it. After listening to several addresses, the visitors, accompanied by military societies of Bremen, carrying banners, paraded through the streets to the Kaiser Wilhelm Monument, near the Rathhaus.

We remarked some weeks ago, in connection with the Cornell-Leander fiasco, that Americans approached matters of sport in quite another spirit from ourselves. Shortly afterward the father of one of the Cornell oarsmen came forward to accuse the coach of having practically sold the race with Trinity Hall.
ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- The first evidences of small politics in the State Civil Service Commission made their appearance a few weeks since, and to-day the game was begun in earnest.

A certain Chodric-Duclos, who was a stanch loyalist, found himself during the revolution of 1830 close to a barricade, from the top of which some boys were firing at the Swiss Guards. Of course they aimed badly, and their bullets went far beside the mark. Duclos, who was a magnificent shot, felt disgusted at the waste of powder and shot, quietly crept to the back of the structure, and clambered up.

BOSTON, Aug. 28. -- Routine business occupied the time of the Knights Templars at this morning's session of the Grand Encampment. Sir Hugh McCurdy, the Grand Master presided and delivered his triennial address. He said, in part:

It has long been known that the average ambulance surgeon could mistake the effects of almost any form of illness or of almost any accident for convincing evidences of "alcoholism," but it does seem as though a man who has been run over by a trolley car, and particularly by a Brooklyn trolley car, ought to be safe from the usual fate.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 28. -- Mrs. Potter Palmer gave another enjoyable luncheon party to-day at the Kebo Valley Club. Scarcely a day goes by but what some function, either large or small, is given by this cultured lady. To-day covers were laid for sixteen on a long table, beautifully decorated with hardy hydrangea, smilax, and maidenhair fern.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 28. -- After years of legal complications over numerous patents and experiments, with every type of foreign and domestic small arms, that have been submitted to the ordnance experts, the Navy Department has closed a contract with an American inventor for the purchase of his gun.

The Valkyrie had a good trial yesterday. At first she sailed about the bay and later in the day went outside the Hook. It was the intention of Capt. Cranfield on Tuesday to wait until Lord Dunraven arrived, but as the Teutonic had not been sighted yesterday morning, it was decided to get under way and possibly meet the Teutonic coming in.

LEADVILE, Col., Aug. 28. -- A serious accident occurred last evening on the Colorado Midland between this place and Granite. The California express, coming west, was struck by a huge rock that rolled down the mountain side, completely telescoping the bagage car and one end of the smoker.

Henry L. Wilson, associate editor of Puck, who lives at the Alpine apartment house, Broadway and Thirty-third Street, had an experience with a pickpocket yesterday afternoon which some persons might think funny, but in which Mr. Wilson could not see a joke.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- The Hunneman touring party of seventy-five ladies and gentlemen, who last night returned from the Adirondacks, left to-day for their homes at Plainfield, N.J.

The court of inquiry assembled at the New-York Navy Yard to inquire into the injuries sustained by the Columbia when that vessel was docked at Southampton, concluded the taking of testimony yesterday. The purpose of the Navy Department in assembling the court was to discover whether the damage to the commerce destroyer was due to improper docking or if the vessel was structurally weak.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 28. -- Newport's grandest ball was given to-night at Marble House by Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt in honor of her daughter, Miss Consuelo Vanderbilt, who is having her first Summer out. It was a function of magnificent and expensive details, and altogether cost a fortune. There were points relating to prepararation for the affair that tell of its extent and brilliancy.
The Court of Special Sessions was thronged with the members of the Central Association of the Wine, Liquor, and Beer Dealers of New-York yesterday morning.

CENTRE ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 28. -- After the third trial race of the half-raters to-day, which was largely a drifting match, the committee selected the winner, Ethelwynn, to defend the Seawanhaks Corinthian Yacht Club Trophy against Spruce IV. the English challenger. Ethelwynn's showing on this and the two previous days of the trials clearly entitled her to the distinction.

NEWARK, Aug, 28. -- Directly opposite the Pennsylvania station at Market Street, this city, to-night, a gang of toughs attacked a man and beat him almost to death, and would have done so had not the man attacked shot three of the mob and scattered the others. The attacked man ran away, fearing further violence, and was stopped by a private watchman.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 28. -- A white-winged angel of peace with pistols stuck in her belt and carrying a battle axe on her shoulder reigned at Point of Rocks to-day.

There is comfort for the lady cyclist in the dispatch this morning which says that in Paris a rumor was spread recently that the Prefect of Police intended to issue an order prohibiting women from wearing masculine attire within the fortifications. Hearing of this, the professors of the great teaching institutions have presented a petition to M. Lepine praying him not to make his order operative in the Latin Quarter.

By the signification of the royal approbation yesterday afternoon, the Speaker of the House of Commons was invested with the fullest powers for guiding and directing his new -- and let us hope happy -- family. He took the oath, signed the roll, and induced more than half his "pupils" to follow a necessary example.

George R. Rogers of Morristown, N.J., who deserted his five-year-old boy at the Continental Hotel, in this city, Aug. 8, subsequently admitted his crime, was extradited and brought to this city, where he was confined in the Tombs, was yesterday taken before Recorder Golf for sentence.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 28. -- The sessions of the societies affiliated with the American Association for the Advancement of Science were resumed this morning for the reading of papers, which were mostly technical. This was especially true of the mathematical and chemical societies. The latter spent the afternoon at the armory, and Hampden Paint Works.
PARIS, Aug. 28. -- lippolyte Raymond, the dramatist, committed suicide last eventrig by shooting himself with a revolver. .re had been suffering from melancholia for some time.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- The holding of Messrs. Streetor and Cox to the Federal Grand Jury in Chicago for the forging of the names of President Cleveland and Secretary Hoke Smith to a land grant recalls about as bungling a piece of work as has come to light in the Interior Department for a long time.

Annie Tuskolka was killed, after a desperate fight, by her husband, Charles Tuskolka, at their home in the tenement house at 515 East Thirteenth Street, at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning. Tuskolka was arrested soon afterward.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 28. -- Alexander Hutchinson shot James Getty, Jr., at the latter's office in his wholesale liquor establishment, at First Avenue and Cherry Alley, this morning. Hutchinson went directly to the county jail, and gave himself up.

WEDNESDAY -- P.M. The movement in to-day's market was a close repetition of that of yesterday. The foreigners were liberal buyers of their specialties, with the exception of St. Paul, of which they sold about 15,000 shares. The local buying, however, was so good that the offerings were easily absorbed, and the stock subsequently sold at its highest price of the year.
BOSTON, Aug. 28.--Secretary Herbert of the navy, who arrived in the dispatch boat Dolphin last evening, said to-day of the future movements of the North Atlantic Squadron:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- Frederick W. Vanderbilt of New-York, who has recently joined the little colony of millionaires up the river, is getting ready to make extensive improvements on his house and grounds. His house is on the "old Langdon place," which is said by some of the dwellers of Hyde Park -- where it is situated -- to be "the finest place on the Hudson between New-York and Albany."

Alexander E. Stevens has sold the five-story high-stoop dwelling and lot, 25 by 120.10, 10 East Fifty-seventh Street, to the Cass Realty Corporation. The price is not quoted. It was last conveyed in January, 1884, at $120,000. It will be converted into an apartment house.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 28. -- The marriage of Miss Grace Lippencott, daughter of Mrs. A.B. Lippencott, to William H. Wilson, Jr., a Brooklyn lawyer, was solemnized to-day at noon at the home of the bride. The Rev. A.B. Hermann of the First Reformed Church officiated. The young people left for Niagara Falls, where they will spend their honeymoon.

PATERSON, Aug. 28. -- A romantic story of the reuniting of a young girl with her father and brothers after a separation of eighteen years comes from Lake View, about a mile from this place. George Oliver, eighteen years ago, was a well-to-do resident of Morristown and had a family of young children. His wife died immediately after giving birth to twins, a boy and a girl.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- Secretary Carlisle will go to Kentucky in the latter part of the campaign and make several speeches in the interest of the Democratic Party. One who stands close to him said this afternoon that the Secretary had taken part in Kentucky campaigns for thirty years or more, and undoubtedly would be found in the thick of the fight not later than Oct. 15.

DETROIT, Aug. 28. -- Immediately upon the assembling of the American Bar Association this morning, Judge William H. Taft of the United States Circuit Court began the delivery of the annual address to the association.

ALBANY, Aug. 28. -- The conditions in both the great political parties are considerably mixed. In the Republican ranks in some localities, the Milholland anti-boss cry and the work he is doing are having their effect; in others the opposition cannot get a foothold. The State Democracy is successful in spots, and fails in others.

There was an interesting cricket match at Staten Island yesterday, the home club being opposed by a team of the Brooklyns, which included M.R. Cobb. Several other men who will take part in the game against Cambridge University were also present, and the match helped them to practice for the big event.

WILLET'S POINT, L.I., Aug. 28.--Amid a shower of bullets from a Krag-Jorgensen rifle in the hands of Sentry Herman Mart, Private Fred Moitz, a prisoner, escaped from this post to-day. Moitz is the man who enlisted in the Engineer Battalion two weeks ago, and was identified by his description in papers sent to Washington as a deserter from the First Cavalry.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- Passed East -- Steam yachts Ruby, A.J. Wise; Ava, John H. Gourlie; Lorna, W.L. Stow; Helvetia, Columbus O'D. Iselin; Orienta, E.R. Ladew; Halcyon, Howard C. Smith; Allegra, C.M. Pratt; Alicia, H.M. Flagler; Almy, Frederic Gallatin; Linta, Walter Luttgen; Charlotta, W.B. Higgins, and Whileaway; sloop yacht Nettie, W.H. Hathaway.

Several of the contractors who bid for the work of the new Jerome Park Reservier, and who deposited checks aggregating $544,000 as guarantees of good faith, have inquired as to what became of the interest due on these checks for the period during which they were deposited in the city's banks.

Leon Kahn and Benjamin Greil, who described themselves as merchants of Montgomery, Ala., and Max L. Weil, a lawyer, of Pensacola, Fla., called at Police Headquarters yesterday and told Acting Chief Conlin of the bad treatment they had received at the hands of two policemen and a Central Office detective.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- Josiah Quincy, once Assistant Secretary of State, but now a plain citizen of Boston, is in Washington, and has been interviewed on Massachusetts and National politics. Mr. Quincy, according to this interview, does not think the Democrats of Massachusetts have much chance of electing their candidate for Governor this Fall, whoever he may be.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- Harry W. Sherman, for fourteen years a lineman in the employ of the Rochester Gas and Electric Company, received a shock from a light wire this forenoon and was apparently dead for six minutes, when he recovered consciousness, after being subjected to the treatment similar to that used in cases of drowning, which is provided for in cases of electrical shocks.

No news of Robert W. Inman, who has been missing since his sloop yacht Adelaide was run down Monday evening off Bay Ridge by the Perseus of the Iron Steamboat Company, was received yesterday, and his friends are now almost certain he was drowned. If he is alive, they argued that there was no reason why he should not communicate with them.

Artist Edward W. Kemble of New-Rochelle was robbed the night of Aug. 12 in his home of about $300 worth of silverware by a burglar who left only the clue behind him of the imprint of his foot, which Mr. Kemble sketched and sent to the police. The man was caught yesterday at Amsterdam Avenue and One Hundred and Sixteenth Street.
There was but one stake race decided at the race meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club yesterday. That was the Flying Stakes for three-year-olds.

ALBANY, Aug. 28. -- The story published in The New-York Times this morning relative to the small politics which is being played in the State Civil Service Commission caused not a little talk about the Capitol to-day, especially about the rooms of the Civil Service Commission.

These are T.C. Platt's very busy days. He is putting the finishing touches on his Senatorial and Assembly plans. The fact that Chairman Charles W. Hackett of the State Committee and Congressman B.B. Odell, Jr., Chairman of the Executive Committee, were both summoned to the city yesterday, shows that the fine work is being done now.

The Executive Committee of the State Democrcy did not decide at its meeting last night whether to send a contesting delegation to the Democratic State Convention, to be held in Syracuse Sept. 24. Action was deferred until next Tuesday night.

EAST MORICHES, Aug. 28. -- The family of H.P. Shotwell of 72 and 74 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, was rudely disturbed by supposed burglars Monday night. Mr. Shotwell has rented a cottage here for the Summer, and spends his Sundays here, returning to town Monday, leaving the ladies without male protection.
The old Board of Police Justices received a severe blow yesterday under a decision handed down by Justice Stover in the Supreme Court.

NYACK, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- Capt. John Holley of Nyack may be selected to pilot the Valkyrie III. in the coming races. Capt. Holley is sailing master of the yacht Hildegard, owned by James C. Bergen of Brooklyn, and which always winters at Nyack, where she was built.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 28. -- Mrs. Abby L. Smith and Sidney Smith, the alleged accomplices of Forger William E. Brockway, who was held for trial last week, were arraigned before United States Commissioner Isaac Romaine to-day for examination. Most of the evidence merely a repetition of that given at the examination of Brockway and William Wagner. Sidney Smith's case was called first.

California and Kentucky have been in keen rivalry for a score of years as to the respective merits of their trotters. In that time the younger State secured one world's record, when Sunol won the championship in 2:08 1/4. Yesterday afternoon, at Fleetwood Park, the Sunny Slope had another triumph in a stirring contest between its latest marvel, Azote, and the four-year-old filly Beuzetta, from the heart of the bluegrass region.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- Minister Denby, at Pekin, has cabled a long explanation to the State Department with reference to events connected with the inquiry into the Ku-Cheng massacre.

The proposed new East River Bridge was discussed by the Commissioners yesterday behind closed doors for more than three hours, and whatever new steps were taken beyond those made known by Commissioner Sperry after adjournment remain locked in the minute book of the Secretary, from whom no information can be extracted.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 28. -- The three large charred chunks which were found last night in the chimney of the house in Irvington, where Holmes is supposed to have murdered Howard Pietzel, were examined this morning. The examination showed that one was the liver, part of the intestines, stomach, and spine of a human being.

The Good Government Clubs' Convention in the hall of the United Charities Building last night, resulted in the appointment of a permanena board of campaign officers, the adoption of a platform which evidences the policy of the organizations and declares their principles, and the appointment of an Executive Committee which, as circumstances dictate, will be a conference committee.
BUFFALO, Aug. 28. -- Henry D. Fitzgerald, a well-known attorney, and for many years United States Commissioner, was kidnapped last Saturday night and held until he paid for his liberty.

OCEAN GROVE. Aug. 28. -- The final sermons of the camp meeting were preached to-day, and the usual wind-up exercises take place to-morrow morning. The services to-day were unusually well attended. The interest manifested by the unconverted indicates that the sermons during the past ten days were effective.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- The struggle between the two counties of Herkimer and Otsego, which comprise the Thirty-fourth Senatorial District, over representation in the Republican Convention, presents one of the sharpest fights which has been seen in this State for many a day between the Platt and the Miller Republicans.

At present an immense proportion of the women throughout London never have been trained in proper household work, and so are quite incompetent to supervise and to direct the daily, monthly, yearly cleansing of their rooms. Among the working class, the mothers, mostly, are brought up in general neglect of things required for personal and family respect and comfort in their homes, and consequently are incapable of teaching what they do not know or practice.

Much interest was aroused in Cuban circles in this city yesterday by the publication in The New-York Times of a letter from E. Dupuy de Lome, the Spanish Minister to this country, in which he asserts that the Cuban army consists of only a few thousand adventurers.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- A wind and rain storm of terrific violence swept over this city at 5 o'clock this afternoon. Many chomneys were thrown down, buildings damaged, electric light and telegraph wires prostrated, and trees by the score torn up, roots and all. The steel liberty pole in Hanover Square snapped in two.

As John R. Walsh of Chicago came ashore from the Teutonic yesterday, he was served with a complaint in a suit for $200,000, brought against him by The United Press for betrayal of trust and violation of his fiduciary obligations, while acting as Director and Treasurer of that corporation.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 28. -- The Orange Athletic Club baseball players played all around their visitors, the Hollywood Baseball Club, this afternoon at the Orange Oval, and defeated them by heavy hitting. The visitors were all college players, and considered cracks, but their pitcher, J. Brokaw, was easily hit, and also gave eight men bases on balls.

The vast amount of engineering work that will be necessary to construct properly the rapid transit road cannot be imagined by a layman, or even by an engineer, unless he first makes himself familiar with the conditions as they exist in the streets under and over which the road is to be built.

A private century run for members only has been arranged by the Harlem Wheelmen for next Sunday. The objective points will be Astoria and East Islip, L.I. According to the schedule a little over ten hours will be spent in the saddle, and for resting three hours are calculated upon. The itinerary is as follows:

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- According to arrangements made to-night, Miss Amelia E. Haswell will surrender herself to-morrow to the police to answer the charge of aiding and abetting Oliver Curtis Perry, the train robber, in escaping from the Matteawan Asylum. Miss Haswell arrived in this city this morning, accompanied by her aunt, Mrs. C.E. King, and her brother-in-law, the Rev. Mr. Warren of Hoosick Falls. No one was allowed to see her.
Peter De Lacy has won another victory over the racing associations.

A hearing on the proposed changes in street grades was given by Commissioner Louis F. Haffen of the Department of Street Improvements in the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards yesterday at the department headquarters, 2,622 Third Avenue.

Recorder Goff made a practical application of the science of palmistry Tuesday, and as a result Thomas Jeblewsky was yesterday sentenced to four years and two months in prison. But for the test of the palm Thomas might now be at liberty.

LONDON, Ont., Aug. 25. -- On the fine third-of-a-mile track on the banks of the river Thames to-day the National circuit race meet of the London Bicycle Club was most successfully conducted. The attendance was over 5,000, and splendid racing was seen in every event. Last night the city turned out en masse to meet the circuit chasers upon their arrival.

Public interest has been so captivated by news of the occupation of the Brazilian Island of Trinidad by an English force that a historical sketch of the island may properly precede publication of the diplomatic correspondence which the incident provoked.

FORKED RIVER, N.J., Aug. 28. -- Ex-Police Justice Patrick Gavan Duffy of New-York City died at the Lafayette House, in this place, at 2:10 o'clock this morning. Had Judge Duffy lived until Sunday he would have been fifty-one years old.
RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- Gen. George H. Sharp of Kingston, N.Y., formerly on the staff of Gen. Grant, arrived at the Spring House to-day.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- While the nomination of H.H. Edgerton as the Republican candidate for Mayor is generally conceded, the defeated candidates at last Monday's caucuses -- Mayor Lewis and ex-Mayor Curran -- have not given up the fight. Lewis claims that some of the Edgerton delegates are such in name only, and that they are really Lewis men and will vote for him in the convention.

LONDON, Aug.28. -- In the course of the discussion of the estimates in the House of Commons to-day, the Irish and Scotch Radical members attempted to obtain a postponement of debate on the home votes. Mr. Balfour, First Lord of the Treasury and Government leader of the House, refused to consent to this, and the House proceeded with the discussion of the matter of salaries for the London University.

WEST POINT, Aug. 28. -- The furlough class arrived here by boat to-day. When the members reached the top of the hill, only their hat rims remained intact. Their joy was so great at being reunited that they almost hugged the clothes off each other.

We are informed by our Republican neighbor, The Tribune, that the Democratic Party is "trying to dodge" the tariff issue. No other journal has this news. Our neighbor also remarks that "the people" will "have something to say" about this "dodging," because they "are thinking and caring more about that question to-day than about any other that can be named."
SARATOGA, Aug. 28. -- The Proportional Representation League adjourned this afternoon after adopting the following:

" The Sporting Duchess" scarcely had a "first-night" success, but that prove nothing. It was a very hot night, and the house was full of blase folks who have seen everything. They did not expect to find much wit or humor or any evidences of keen observation of human nature in an Augustus Harris melodrama, and they were not disappointed.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29. -- Lawyer W.A. Shoemaker had another long conference in Moyamensing Prison with his client H.H. Holmes, during which the prisoner protested his innocence of complicity in the killing of Howard Pietzel, whose bones are said to have been found in a dwelling near Indianapolis.

English-speaking students of the French language are occasionally found who profess great delight in French poetry, even in the classics, but we think it is the experience of most that the charm of French verse, with rare and exquisite exceptions, is something to which the English mind is sealed.

James B. Elliott, the trolley motorman who ran over and killed John J. Read at Eighty-sixth Street and Twenty-second Avenue, Brooklyn, on the morning of Aug. 23, was admitted to bail 4n the sum of $1,500 yesterday, by Justice William J. Gaynor, in the Supreme Court.

HAMILTON, Ohio, Aug. 29. -- Local spiritualists and students of psychology are interested in a remarkable statement, sworn to by Miss Rena Leonard, a young lady of this city. She declares solemnly that one Jim Holly, a farmhand who works for her father, nine miles west of this city, is tormented with spirits, and that her home in the country is infested with spirits, who give mysterious rappings and knockings and other manifestations.

The general distrust of party platforms will not be dissipated by the one adopted by Mr. Quay's convention at Harrisburg on Tuesday. It is certainly, as a whole, far from a clear and strong statement of doctrine or policy, and parts of it are so elaborately obscure as to be simply unintelligible, and doubtless were meant to be so.
Commissioner Andrews tried the delinquent policemen at Police Headquarters yesterday. There were fifty-three complaints on the calendar, mostly for minor offenses.

WOODSTOCK, Ontario, Aug. 29. -- Five of the Class B men fell on a dangerous corner at the meet of the Woodstock Amateur Athletic Association to-day. Rigby slipped on the insufficiently banked corner in the mile open, and took Kennedy down with him. In a heat of the two-mile race Barnett slipped and fell and Decardy shot into space, landing fifteen yards away, Carman went over the two.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 29. -- There were 10,000 persons present to-day at the closing exercises of the great camp meeting, the most successful, so the leaders say, ever held on the camp grounds. The early morning meetings attracted their usual quota of worshippers. At the young people's meeting Leader Yatman made an address to the "true blue" Christians and "lukewarm" Christians, and the unsaved.

For the first time in the history of light-harness sport the papers have conquered the metropolis. The trotters long monopolized the attention of the patrons of the sulky in this vicinity, but they were forgotten yesterday.

James P. Archibald, the new Warden of Ludlow Street Jail, would like to have some repairs done to the jail, in order to improve the health of the debtor prisoners, as well as to add to the security of the Federal prisoners placed in his charge.

A curious holographic will, written on a half sheet of scented note paper and signed by Ellen Boden, was filed in the Surrogate's orifice yesterday by De Forest Brothers, lawyers for the Presbyterian Hospital, at Seventieth Street and Park Avenue. The will is as follows:

John T. Williams, the builder and owner, has sold the new ten-story fire-proof building, 50 feet square, on the northeast corner of Broome and Mercer Streets, for about $240,000. Hoffman Brothers were the brokers.
LONDON, Aug. 29. -- Concerning the forthcoming meeting between the athletic champions of the universities of the Old and New Worlds, a well-known writer on athletics says:

It is seldom in this country that twenty-two youngsters of American parentage and association are seen engaged in a contest on the cricket field. Such a game took place yesterday at Prospect Park, where the Juniors of the Manhattan Cricket Club defeated the boys of Staten Island by an innings and 14 runs.

The Defender and the Vigilant met in their second trial race yesterday, and, although the former won by 18 minutes and 8 seconds, over a triangular course of twenty-four miles, the America's Cup Committee decided to start them again to-day, chiefly because fluky breezes yesterday precluded the possibility of a beat to windward.

Col. Waring concluded some time ago that District Superintendent H.C. Corsa was not useful in the Street Cleaning Department, and asked him to resign. Corsa declined, and, as he is a veteran, defied Col. Waring to remove him.

Some colored Republican politicians who went last night to Adelphi Hall, at Fifty-second Street and Broadway, believe that they attended a conference under the auspices of the Colored Republican Association of the State of New-York.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- The Democratic County and District Conventions were held here to-day. They were harmonious in all their proceedings. A strong county ticket was put in nomination, and Democrats have strong hopes of carrying some of their candidates through in November.

Just before the return of Mr. Carlisle from his vacation it was reported that at the Treasury Department a plan had been much discussed and highly favored for preserving the stability of the currency. This plan was to secure authority from Congress for the issue of Treasury notes, bearing a low rate of interest, and redeemable at the pleasure of the Government.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 29. -- Acting Police Justice Maes received a surprise this morning. He had issued a warrant, on the representation of Mrs. Wilhelmina Lascell of 40 Bleecker Street, for the arrest of a man named William Martie, who, Mrs. Lascell charged, had cut down a tree on her property.

THURSDAY -- P.M. Increased activity and somewhat lower prices were the characteristics of to-day's stock market. The recession in the Granger group extended to a point in Burlington, 5/8 in Rock Island and Northwestern, 1/2 in St Paul, and 3/8 in Atchison. In other active stocks the decline was marked by small fractions. Some of the specialties showed decided strength.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 29. -- The Duke of Marlborough will remain here until next Thursday, and then go to New-York. This morning he took a drive again, and this afternoon he went to the Casino, where he hoped to have a go at Tom Pettitt at court tennis, which he plays a great deal at home.

Gratifying progress is reported from Berlin in the construction of the buildings for the Industrial Exposition. The structures have been so far advanced already that a promenade over the grounds will give the beholder even now a good idea what the exposition will be next year.

The first steel canalboats ever built in the United States arrived off the foot of One Hundred and Thirty-second Street, North River, late last night, from Lorain, Ohio, with a cargo of steel rails, consigned to the Metropolitan Traction Company, and the Staten Island Rapid Transit Company.

Without implying, or intending to imply, any disrespect to Judge Bischoff, it seems to us that his decision in the case of John Dudley against the Flushing Jockey Club is so remarkable that its confirmation by the higher courts is hardly to be contemplated among possibilities, much less among probabilities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Matt W. Ransom arrived in Washington last night, and bright and early this morning appeared at the State Department, where he took the oath of office before a notary public to enable him to reassume the duties of the Mexican Mission. Mr. Ransom's suspended salary will be continued from the date of the oath.
The ban has been put on Bernard Carney.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 29. -- Anson Phelps Stokes and family will arrive at Shadowbrook on Tuesday. They went from Point au Pic, where their son was married, to the Adirondacks. They will entertain largely this Autumn. Mrs. Stokes has already invited a carload of people to Shadowbrook for the next few weeks.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29. -- The victory of Senator Quay yesterday at Harrisburg over his opponent in the Republican Party may not be the absolute triumph that it appeared in the bout that followed the defeat of the Administration forces. In fact, yesterday's battle may be but the first of a long and desperate campaign.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Aug. 29. -- Miss Jessie Knox of New-York, who is summering at Patchogue, had a narrow escape from drowning this morning. Miss Knox is an expert swimmer and is in the habit of swimming sometimes a half mile from shore. She had gone about 700 feet when she screamed and sank.

BUFFALO, Aug. 29. -- It was learned late this afternoon, on authority which is considered absolutely reliable, that ex-Postmaster General Wilson S. Bissell had been offered the place on the United States Supreme Court Bench made vacant by the death of Justice Jackson.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29. -- If Parker Pearsons Valentine will take the chance of being hanged he can have $100,000. Valentine is wanted in Minnesota for murder and also to take a big estate bequeathed to him by his mother, Mrs. Lucy A. Valentine.

ALBANY, Aug. 29. -- Lieut. Gov. Charles T. Saxton, as Acting Governor, sat in the executive chair to-day at the Capitol and signed a number of unimportant papers, department vouchers, etc., requiring the Governor's signature.

OLD FORGE, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- Ex-President Harrison made a splendid shot last evening in East Marsh, First Lake. He killed a large dry doe. Guide Frank Sperry said Gen. Harrison made the best shot he has seen since he has been in the Adirondacks. One shot was sufficient to kill the deer.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 29. -- Ex-Gov. and ex-Senator William Pinckney Whyte says in an interview to-day that he cannot support John E. Hurst for Governor. This is the worst blow the ticket has received. Gov. Whyte was Controller, Governor, United States Senator, and then, when he was defeated by Gorman, was called unanimously by all parties to the Mayoralty of Baltimore.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- Frank Hough Osborn sang at the Congress Spring Park concert to-night. There was a very large attendance.
LONG BRANCH, Aug. 29. -- The Rev. Pennington Corson, pastor of the First Methodist Episcopal Church, left to-day for a sojourn in the Catskill Mountains.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, via Galveston, Aug. 29. -- Gen. Leonidas Plaza, commanding the Sixth Division of the Patriot Army, has entered Quito.

An automatic petroleum wagon of French make, and said to have cost $1,000, was used yesterday for the first time in this country. It went around and through Washington Square several times, and was apparently successful. There are 4,000 such vehicles in use in Paris.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 29. -- The meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science begn with a morning session. Prof. Edward W. Morley of Cleveland, te President of the association, occupied the chair. After addresses of welcome and response thereto, Edgar Frisbie was elected president of the section of astronomy, and Leland E. Howard of that of zoology, to fill vacancies.

Henry D. Wilson, associate editor of Puck, who was arrested Wednesday night on a Broadway cable car while trying to cause the arrest of a man who, he said, had stolen a gold watch and chain, was released by Magistrate Brann, in the Jefferson-Market Court, yesterday.

If it were simply a question of who wins a race and by how much, yesterday's contest between the Defender and the Vigilant might be regarded as a final triumph for the new yacht. But it was not a satisfactory day for yacht racing, and the question to be decided is how much faster than the Vigilant the Defender is when judged strictly on her merits.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29. -- Chairman Gideon of the Racing Board of the League of American Wheelmen has been very alert during the last week, and the result is an unusually large list of suspensions and transfers. He issued a bulletin to-day containing his rulings, supplemented by a string of sanctions for tournaments.

SUMMIT, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- Schoharie County is full of hills that reach so far up into the blue sky that they may well be dignified by the word mountains, as they are in instances by the New-York folks who come up here during the heated term, and are classified as "Summer boarders." The air is pure and invigorating, and the scenery is calculated to coax the lovers of nature to dwell here.

PARIS, Aug. 29. -- The corporation of the City of Lyons, following the example of other large cities and the General Council of the Rhone, have passed a resolution opposing the proposed exhibition in Paris in 1900, on the ground that it would derange the business of the country and unauly favor Parisian capita to the detriment of other cities.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- Tony Fanney, a cartman living at 173 Oak Street, is looking for a stranger who victimized him out of $59. The stranger offered to pay him $1 to move a trunk. The Italian was told that the trunk contained $59, and that he must give security for that amount before he could get the job.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 29. -- The pleasant weather of the last few days continues. For the many who are leaving, each steamer brings in a new crowd of visitors, who are booked for the month of September.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 29. -- Four violent earthquake shocks are reported from Pinotepa and Nacional, in Oaxaca, causing widespread terror. Each shock had a violent effect upon buildings. Walls were rent and roofs caved in.

BOSTON, Aug. 29. -- The third session of the twenty-sixth triennial conclave of Knights Templars opened at the Masonic Temple this morning. It was decided to vote for Grand Master by roll call, first calling the Grand Encampment, and then the States in alphabetical order.
HASTINGS, England, Aug. 29. -- To-day all the games, but one left unfinished in previous rounds of the International Chess Masters' Tournament were completed, the results being as follows:

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 29. -- The session of the American Bar Association this morning was principally taken up with reports of standing and special committees. The Committee on Expression and Classification had no report to offer.

CENTRAL CITY, Col., Aug. 29. -- Water broke through the walls separating the abandoned workings of the Bob Tail Tunnel property and the Sleepy Hollow and Americus Mines this afternoon and caught thirteen miners before they could be warned of their danger. Men have gone down to assist in recovering the bodies.

A Long Island Railroad train returning to Long Island City from Manhattan Beach last evening dashed into a hook and ladder truck going to a fire near Manhattan Crossing, East New-York, wrecked the truck, and injured three firemen, one of whom fell under a car. His arm and a foot were cut off, and he will probably die.

In deciding to submit to arbitration the disputed ownership of the region lying between the Oyapock and Araguari Rivers, north of the Amazon, France and Brazil have shown great good sense. They have set an example to other nations that are involved in similar controversies, and the example is the more striking from the difficulties that surround the subject.

ALBANY, Aug. 29. -- The annual report of the State Board of Regents exhibiting the examination statistics was issued to-day. It says that the growth of this department of the State University during the last five years has been phenomenal. This is due to the revised system adopted in 1891.

After two weeks' investigation and consideration, a Coroner's jury of architectural, engineering, and building experts, late yesterday afternoon, rendered a verdict, fixing the responsibility for the collapse of the Ireland Building at West Broadway and Third Street, whereby fifteen men lost their lives. John B. Ireland, the owner of the building, is not mentioned in the jury's findings.

WEST POINT, Aug. 29. -- The furlough hop was a brilliant affair. On account of the large number of people present there was not sufficient room for dancing. Friends of the cadets from all parts of the country arrived by trains and boats during the day. The rooms were cooled by cold air forced by fans from the basement.

Manager Augustus Pitou, under whose management the Grand Opera House will open to-morrow night, entertained a party of friends yesterday afternoon by lighting up the theatre and showing them the improvements he has made. The Grand Opera House is, to all intents, a new theatre for New-York.

The excise case against Thomas Durken, bartender for John J. Walsh at 1,066 Second Avenue, came up for hearing again before Magistrate Kudlich in time Yorkville Police Court yesterday, having been continued from Tuesday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 29. -- The special committee appointed a few days ago by the Democratic State Central Committee to find a way out of the difficulties caused by the declaration of P.W. Hardin, the nominee for Governor, in favor of free silver coinage, issued a rather remarkable address tonight to the Democratic voters of the State.

The crusade in behalf of another union ticket against Tammany, started by William Brookfield, Gen. Anson G. McCook, Cornelius N. Bliss, and others, is now in full swing. The action of the Good Government Club Convention in adjourning, subject to the call of the Chair, for the purposes of conferences with other anti-Tammany bodies, has set the politicians to figuring the chances of a union ticket as being excellent.

NYACK, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- The Board of Supervisiors of Rockland County to-day had a mandamus served upon it, signed by Justice Gaynor of the Supreme Court, in a matter which promises to be a very interesting one, not only to the people of this county, but also to other counties which raise money for publis purposes by bonds.

PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 30. -- The Women's Sanitary Association has decided thoroughly to cleanse the city. A Chairman has been appointed for each ward and three Inspectors for each precinct. They have been provided with copies of the city sanitary laws and will start out to-day.

Leonard Forbes Beckwith, who is at present in an asylum for the insane in Massachusetts, is charged by his sister, Mrs. Helen Beckwith Leigh, wife of Francis Dudley Leigh, of London, England, with being a defaulter for $150,000 to the estate of his brother, Arthur.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- At the Republican Assembly Judicial Conventions to-morrow, delegates will be chosen to the Judicial Nominating Convention. The candidates who have announced themselves are Nathaniel Foote of Rochester, Judge Nash of Avon, and John M. Dunwell of Lyons. In addition there are reports that Charles A. Hawley of Seneca Falls and Judge Robinson of Steuben may enter the race.

The visiting Knights Templars from Illinois, who have been attending the conclave at Boston, arrived in this city last evening, on the City of Lowell, and went to their headquarters at the Cosmopolitan Hotel. There were about 300 in the party.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 30. -- In the case of Albert Rushworth against the Common Pleas Court of Hudson County, to test the constitutionality of the naturalization law passed at the last session of the Legislature, Justice Van Syckel of the Supreme Court filed an opinion to-day in which the act is held to be constitutional.

The Directors of the Metropolitan Traction Company have resolved to extend the underground electric system, now in operation in Lenox Avenue to the Twenty-third Street cross-town line, then to the Ninth Avenue line, and ultimately to all the lines owned by the company in this city.

It is reported from Philadelphia that Senator Quay favors the nomination of Gov. McKinley for President next year, but is "not so far committed to him as to make an aggressive fight for him." We have little doubt that this correctly represents the attitude of Mr. Quay. It is now getting near the time when men who are in politics for business must be prepared to talk fairly definitely.

Prof. Holm has thus far adhered closely to his original plan of keeping clearly distinct that portion of Grecian history which bears the stamp of fact from that which rests on disputable ground. True to the instinct of German scholarship, he carries the sifting process almost to its furthest limits, and, instead of speculating idly over doubtful points, is often frank to acknowledge that it is impossible to draw satisfactory conclusions.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- It looked ten days ago as if Col. Timothy E. Ellsworth of this city would easily win the race for the Republican Senatorial nomination from this district. But Col. Ellsworth suffers for the sins of the Niagara County machine, of which he has long been a leader and a formidable opposition has arisen to him, Low, Hatch, and the others who follow Platt's bidding in local affairs.

It has been established that the excise law can be enforced in this city if the Commissioners of Police are in favor of enforcing it. The difficulties of getting evidence, of which so much used to be made by Police Captains who did not desire to get evidence, vanish when it is shown that the Police Captains will be held responsible for their failure to get evidence.

FRIEDRICHSRUH, Aug. 30. -- Thirty-six German-American veterans accompanied by twelve ladies and several children arrived at Friedrichsruh this forenoon. The veterans carried two banners, and the entire party marched to the castle gates. At noon Chief Ranger Lange came out and escorted the four veterans who had been selected to see Prince Bismarck into the presence of the ex-Chancellor.

STAPLETON, S.I., Aug. 30. -- Ex-Assemblyman Michael McGuire of this place, who for several years has been one of the leading Democratic politicians in Richmond County, was arrested to-night on two charges of grand larceny. The warrant was issued this afternoon by Justice of the Peace Peter Tiernan, upon complaints made by Frank D. Pommer, a New-York wine merchant, whose home is at this place, and by Louis Lichenstein.

DENVER. Col., Aug. 30. -- Edward T. Jeffery, President and General Manager of the Denver and Rio Grande Railway, is to be President of the reorganized Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Company. Mr. Jeffery was considered as the successor to J.W. Reinhart when he resigned the Presidency and senior receivership of the Santa Fe, a year ago.

La Vie Contemporaine is publishing a plea for Stambuloff, written by a Frenchman, who has lived at Sofia. The author, M. Albert Malet, defends his client in the close vivid style that appeals to his French readers. He boldly joins issue, our Paris correspondent says, with the whole French press, which out of Russomania has separated from other Western nations in its views on Bulgaria, and declares his admiration for Stambuloff's great qualities of statesmanship.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 30. -- The centre of gaiety to-day was on Bar Island, where the members of the Canoe Club were holding their regular Friday afternoon reception. The little island was alive with people, who sailed over from Bar Harbor and from the resorts across the bay. The Reception Committee to-day was composed of Mrs. Frank Ellis of Cincinnati, Mrs. Joseph Pulitzer, and Mrs. David Worden of New-York.

An excellent card is offered for the races at the Coney Island Jockey Club's track at Sheepshead Bay this afternoon. While none of the highest class of horses are engaged, those nominated are good enough to make lively sport a certainty.

William Berri, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Brooklyn Maryland Day Memorial Committee, has a gold medal, commemorative of the recent celebration in Brooklyn, and does not know how to dispose of it.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 30. -- Capt. John Hutchinson, one of the best-known residents of this city, and Superintendent of the West Jersey Ferry, went out on the porch, at his home, at Front and Linden Streets, this city, to get some fresh air last evening, and went to sleep in his chair.

BOSTON, Aug. 30. -- The long-expected and anxiously awaited North Atlantic Squadron arrived in Boston Harbor early this morning. The vessels were viewed from the wharves by hundreds of people who anxiously await an opportunity to visit them.

BUFFALO, Aug. 30. -- Two suits, one for divorce and the other for alienation of a wife's affections, have been begun, the first in this city and the second in Rochester, by William J. Willis. The defendant in the divorce case was born Miss Nellie Haines. The co-respondent is Col. J.H. Pennington, a Southerner, representing a South American syndicate, of which George Potter of Rochester is President.

There were 425 excise cases set down for trial yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions. There was a great crush in the court, caused by the announcement made by Justice Jerome on Wednesday that all the liquor dealers who would plead guilty would be let off with a fine of $25.

All doubt as to the fate of Robert W. Inman, the young cotton broker, was settled yesterday afternoon by the discovery of his body in the water off the lower end of South Beach, S.I. The body was first seen by F.H. Tobias, a boatman, and Fred Fisher, a boy, who attracted by the offered reward, were patrolling the beach.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 30. -- Sheriff Richard Serviss received a package through the mail delivery this morning, which created consternation because it was thought it contained dynamite.

We have received the report of the Executive Committee of the Sound Currency Committee of the Reform Club for the three months ending Aug. 29. It is a noteworthy document. It cites in a simple and direct fashion the history of an amount of skillful and honest work that, so far as we recall, is unprecedented in reform movements in this country, and a work that ought, on every account, steadily to be maintained.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 30. -- The sixth joint debate between the Republican and Democratic candidates for Governor of Kentucky, Col. William O. Bradley and P. Wat Hardin, which was to have taken place at the Henry County Fair Grounds, near Eminence, this afternoon, broke up in a row after a citizen had been killed by lightning.

LONDON, Aug. 30. -- During the debate on the Supply bill in the House of Commons to-day, Sir Charles Dilke criticised the giving of assistance to Newfoundland. He said that he believed a stronger case for State relief work might often be made in Great Britain. Bad government was largely answerable for the Colony's troubles.

This is an era of inspection in the City Government. President Roosevelt of the Police Department has led the way, and has become a famous inspector. Commissioners Andrews and Grant have also done some work of the kind. The latest addition to the list of volunteer inspectors is Mayor Strong himself.

Travel on the temporary bridge over the Harlem River at Third Avenue was interrupted from 7 until 8:30 o'clock yesterday morning, and, as a result, there was a long war of words between trolley men and sailors.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 30. -- Matthew Smith and wife, W.H. Park and wife, and M.G. Carroll, all of Cleveland, Ohio, are here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- The investigation which is being made into the methods of employing civilians at the Boston Navy Yard will probably result in an interesting report by the representative of Secretary Herbert, who has been spending some days at the Charlestown Station.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Acting Attorney General Whitney to-day made public two reports received by the Department of Justice, in response to inquiries regarding the Bannock troubles in Wyoming.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- The interest Secretary Lamont takes in the army was clearly shown yesterday when he offered to advance $50,000 to Paymaster General Stanton to pay the officers and men of the army who did not receive their June salaries owing to a deficiency in the appropriation for the pay of the army for the fiscal year, ending June 30 last.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- The Fall Regatta of the American Yacht Club was sailed to-day over the course from off Milton Point to and around a buoy off Parsonage Point, thence to and around the white spar buoy off Red Springs Point, Hempstead Harbor, thence to and around southwesterly stakeboat off Larchmont, thence to and across the finish line off Milton Point; distance of course, ten and three-quarters mile.

Mrs. Clara McArthur of 162 East One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street attempted to jump off the Brooklyn Bridge at 5:30 o'clock yesterday morning, but was prevented by the bridge policemen, who had been warned that a woman was going to take the risky leap and were keeping close watch.

BUFFALO, Aug. 30. -- R.T. Allen of 550 South Twenty-sixth Street, Omaha, Neb., shot himself on a New-York Central train a few miles out of Buffalo this morning. Mr. Allen went to the toilet room at the rear of the car and a moment later the passengers were startled by a pistol shot. Several men found Allen weltering in a pool of blood which oozed from a bullet wound in his left side.

BOSTON, Aug. 30. -- The Knights Templars, having nearly finished the "business of pleasure" that brought them from their homes, are now turning their attention away from the Atlantic shores, and are preparing for the return trips. Already a number of commanderies have departed and more are going on every regular long-distance train leaving Boston, and on special trains provided expressly for the transportation of the Knights.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30. -- The Evening Telegraph to-day says that the Democratic State Convention, which will meet Sept. 11 at Williamsport, will nominate six candidates for Judges of the new Superior Court. There are, it is said, at least thirty Democratic attorneys throughout the State who are anxious to be placed upon the ticket.

NEWPORT, Aug. 30. -- Lady Rachel and Lady Eileen Wyndham-Quinn, the daughters of Lord Dunraven, were at the Casino dance to-night, which was brilliant with gay gowns, precious jewels, and a large company of cottagers. Lord Dunraven's daughters came very late with Miss Grace Wilson, and they were at once the centre of attraction.
An official of the Brooklyn Bridge said yesterday that the new Brooklyn terminal station would be ready for use some time in September or October.

A rumor was printed in a newspaper yesterday morning to the effect that the Spanish steamship Villaverde, chartered by Gen. Campos, had been blown up at sea. The exciting tale had it that the Villaverde left New-York on Aug. 21, with a ton of dynamite aboard.

It is doubtful whether there will be any interference by the authorities with the racing at the track of the Coney Island Jockey Club to-day, growing out of the decision of Judge Bischoff of the Court of Common Pleas, in regard to the constitutionality of the Percy-Gray racing act.

An Anarchist of the ideal Reclus school, and a writer of indisputable originality and merit, H. Alexander Cohen, who is under a sentence of twenty years' hard labor, returned to France on Tuesday in order to give himself up and get a new trial. Several similar cases have ended in an acquittal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Minister Ransom had a long conference with Secretary Lamont to-day, presumably in connection with the question of using the water of the Rio Grande River, over which there have been disputes at various times. Mr. Ransom left for his home in North Carolina to-night and will go to Mexico soon.

Acting under instructions from the Navy Department, a board of navy officers yesterday made a test of a patent smoke respirator. The apparatus has been adopted by the English and German Navies, and it was to ascertain its utility for vessels of the United States Navy that the test was made.

STAPLETON, S.I., Aug. 80. -- The Richmond County police force received the greatest shake-up in its history to-night in the transfer from one to another of the three precincts in the county of thirty-nine out of the total force of fifty-seven. Two Sergeants commanding precincts and two Acting Sergeants were included in the number transferred.

WEST BABYLON L.I., Aug. 30. -- John S. Foster, President of the Forty-second Street Railway Company of New-York and son of the late William R. Foster, and Fred F.P.B. Sands, son-in-law of ex-Judge Alexander McCue, who was solicitor of the Treasury during President Cleveland's first term of office, are wrangling over the naming of a road which runs between their villas here.
The Matin publishes an interview with Zola, during which the latter expressed the following opinions about Rome:

As details of the massacre at Ku-Cheng continue to accumulate and grow more definite, the affair takes shape as one of the most hideous and atrocious that even the history of China, full as that history is of treachery and murder, has to offer for the civilized world's contemplation.
LONDON, Aug. 30. -- The Field says on the cabled reports of the yacht trials in connection with the coming race for the American's Cup:

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Aug. 30. -- The police and insurance men of this city are inclined to believe that the mysterious "Hatch" so frequently referred to by H.H. Holmes as being responsible for many of the crimes charged to the latter individual is not a myth.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- John Henry Barker, colored, living in "The Hills," a negro settlement two miles north of White Plains, murdered his wife to-day by shooting her with a double-barreled shotgun. Barker and his wife have had in the last year frequent quarrels, growing out of Barker's jealousy of his wife, who was a light, good-looking girl of 25, and was known as the "Queen of the Hills."

It seems to make a great deal of difference where a man sleeps. Some time ago there was a dispute as to whether the Wilkeswood stock farm was in the Kingston School District, and, by a resolution passed by the Board of Education, School Commissioner Moran was directed to have a survey made to determine the matter.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 30.--This afternoon United States Marshal Lannan of Delaware, with a posse of Wilmington policemen and two Pinkerton detectives, left this city on the tugboat Meteor and landed at Penn's Grove N. J., where they arrested twenty Cubans, who had been taken there from this city last night on the tug Taurus.

PETERBOROUGH, Ontario, Aug. 30. -- Dr. Brown, the Cleveland racing physician, won the mile open race at the National circuit meet in this city to-day. Coulter of Toledo rode a mile exhibition in 1:57 4-5, which is now the Canadian exhibition record, and took second to Brown in the mile open, after chasing him all the way down the stretch after the tandem dropped.

BUFFALO, Aug. 30. -- Tyler and Sanger, two of the professional wheelmen who will compete in the three-cornered race with "Johnny" Johnson, on Labor Day at the Driving Park, for a one-thousand-dollar purse, arrived in this city last night.

The fight between the anti-Platt and Platt factions of the Republican Party in this city will assume a very interesting phase at the primaries which will be held on Sept. These primaries will not only elect delegates to meet in the Assembly District Conventions and choose delegates to the Republican State Conventions, but they will also elect the delegates to the Republican County Convention and to all of the local conventions.

The police have suspected for some time that a poolroom and "bucket shop" was being run at 46 and 48 New Street, and at 12:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon Acting Captain King and eleven policemen of the Old Slip Station raided the place on the complaint of Arnold S. Polster of 311 Halliday Street, Jersey City, N.J.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 30. -- The members of the American Association for the Advancement of Science made an excursion to Forest Park, starting at 7 o'clock, and returning before the general session. Messrs, Barney, Lewis, and Orr escorted them.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 30. -- The Christian Citizenship Union or New-Jersey is an organization that was recently formed for the sole purpose of influencing Christians to vote for upright men for Sheriff and County Judge at the November election.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 80. -- An examination of Miss Amelia P. Haswell, the Troy missionary, who is accused of complicity in the escape of Oliver Curtis Perry from the Matteawan Asylum for the Criminal Insane, was held in the County Court House before Recorder Odell this morning. Calvin E. Keech and Walter Farrington represented Miss Haswell and District Attorney George Wood and Charles Morschauser the prosecution.
The New-Yorks gained another easy victory yesterday at the Polo Grounds, defeating the Cincinnatis by a score of 11 to 4. Two thousand spectators were present.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 30. -- The hat finishers of the C.B. Rutan Co. hat factory, who have been out on a strike, won the fight this morning by the company giving in to the demand of the strikers for an increase in pay of 25 cents a dozen in making all grades of hats. The firm is one of the largest hatting firms in the Oranges.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- A beautiful day was enjoyed by many of the guests in driving excursions. J. Lee Tailer tooled a party over to the head of Otsego Lake on his drag. There the steamer was chartered for a tour of the lake with a stop at Five-mile Point for an Otsego bass dinner and again at Cooperstown for the ball game.
DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 30. -- The American Bar Association elected officers this morning as follows:

Were it not for the fact that Forest and Stream is a journal intelligently conducted for intelligent readers, and devoted to the furtherance of legitimate ends and commendable purposes, it would not be a source of such painful surprise to find, as readers of this week's issue will in its leading editorial, the following very outrageous words: "The only excuse for such an attack is the truly journalistic one that it sells papers.
BRUSSELS, Aug. 30. -- The Independence Belge has dispatches saying that there has been severe fighting in the Congo country between troops and Mahdist forces.

The officials at the New-York Navy Yard were a bit startled yesterday when the dispatch boat Dolphin, with Secretary Herbert on board, unexpectedly appeared. The boat made fast to the ordnance pier, and at 9:30 o'clock the Secretary paid a visit to Commodore Sicard, the commandant of the yard. He remained closeted with that official for a half hour.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles Soteldo of New-York City were in a runaway accident while driving near Saratoga Lake to-day, and sustained painful injuries.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 31. -- A delegation representing the citizens of Minneapolis, Minn., made the formal presentation to the cruiser Minneapolis this morning of a testimonial in the shape of a handsome solid silver service of eight pieces, elegantly and suitably embossed and engraved, and a fine upright piano.

Proctor's Pleasure Palace, the new theatre in East Fifty-eighth Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, will throw open its doors for the first time at 12 o'clock noon to-morrow, Labor Day. Workmen are toiling day and night to hasten the completion of the big building, which is to communicate with the present structure, and which is to be devoted to the Garden of Palms and the Divan, fitted up in Oriental style.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 31. LONG Beach Hotel has been crowded during the sultry days and nights of the last week. The guests from distant points seem to be more numerous each week, and there is a probability of the hotel's remaining open until Oct. 1. Among the guests are the following:
ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 31. -- The Ladies' Aid Society of the Ferry Methodist Episcopal Church of East Orange gave an enjoyable penny sociable in the lecture room of the church Wednesday evening.

LONDON, Aug. 3. -- The Prince of Wales's cutter, the Britannia, has gone into Winter quarters at Cowes. The Prince has ordered that she be made ready for a cruise in the Mediterranean in the Spring, The yacht's record in British waters is remarkable, as she captured thirty-two prizes in the thirty-nine races in which she started.

Who shall presume, unless by rare chance he may have assisted at the ceremony, to name the day and place of birth of a wild red deer? Yet if the knowledge of the ways of deer be not vain, and all experience of teeth and head and slot be not at fault, our conjecture will not lead us very far from the truth.

As Leopold yon Ranke truly said. the exodus of the Jews from Egypt and their breaking with' the Egyptian theology of nature-worship marked the foundation of the civilization of mankind. Monotheism in its very inception placed man upon the highest pedestal of moral purity, spiritual elevation, and ideal aspiration.

People for whom the words "American sailor" still have a vague charm may hardly realize how important, as well as praiseworthy, have been the efforts of a few energetic and extremely practical philanthropists to remedy the manifold abuses from which seafarers have too long suffered in this and other United States ports.

The congratulations of Democrats throughout the State are due to the Democrats of Rochester, who have at last got together. Factions have weakened the party in Monroe County, until the Republicans practically directed the Democratic Party there. Irritation under this state of affairs produced agitation to remedy it, and the result was the intervention of the State Committe, which ordered caucuses to elect a new local organization.

The team of cricketers from Oxford and Cambridge Universities, who are to meet All New-York at Staten Island to-morrow, arrived here yesterday on board the American Liner St. Louis. They were expected to get in Friday afternoon, and a committee from Philadelphia came over early on that day to greet the visitors. It was not until 8 o'clock yesterday morning, however, that the St. Louis reached her dock.

" I notice that Nicola Tesla, the great electrician, says in The Century that he does not think it utterly impracticable to telegraph through the air without the use of wires," observed Gen. B.R. Cowen. "But he is not the first to think so by any means. During Grant's Administration a bill passed Congress chartering a company which proposed to telegraph from place to place through air strata.

The Larchmont Yacht Club held the third of its series of races for special classes yesterday over a triangular course on Long Island Sound. Thirteen boats started. The course for the larger ones was from the starting line off the clubhouse to a mark off Parsonage Point, Rye Neck, thence to a spar buoy off Red Spring Point, Hempstead Harbor, and thence to a stakeboat anchored southwest of the clubhouse.

While the team from Cambridge University that is now on its way to America is not one of world beaters in the opinion of the critics, it is still a good team of representative university athletes, and the Cambridge men expect that their representatives will make at least a creditable showing against the boys from Yale, whom they are to meet.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 31. -- Clement Morgan of East Ninth Street, left this week for a sojourn of a month at Dingman's Ferry.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 31. -- Cardinal Gibbons this morning closed the six days' retreat of the secular clergy at St. Mary's Seminary. His Eminence will to-morrow install his late private secretary, Father Whelan, as the pastor of St. Mary's Star of the Sea, South Baltimore.

Those who toil up the slopes of the Blue Ridge are often surprised at the wealth of floral luxuriance to be found in bare and desolate places. The upland pastures and high cliffsides are starred with golden elecampane, and wild rhododendrons, with great, showy blossoms of violet-purple, make gorgeous patches among the gray rocks.

Theodore N. Ely, Chief of Motive Power, Pennsylvania Railroad, who went abroad on June 12, as one of the company's representatives at the recent session of the International Railway Congress, arrived home on the Paris on Saturday. Mr. Ely visited England, Ireland, and Scotland, and a great portion of the Continent of Europe, and closely observed the workings of the different railroads in the various countries.

LONDON, Aug. 31. -- [Copyright, 1895, by The New-York Times.] -- There was a hurried Cabinet council at nearly mid-night a couple of days ago which people are still wondering about. The fact that George N. Curzon was sent for is taken to indicate that its subject was urgent foreign business.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 31. -- Yachting parties and the regular weekly golf handicap were the special features of the day, which wound up with a heavy downpour and a violent tempest.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 31. -- The Alabama-Bryce Insane Hospital is situated in the town of Tuscaloosa, on the Queen and Crescent Road, about sixty miles south of Birmingham. Under the management of Dr. Peter Bryce, who died last year, this Alabama State institution won a National reputation in the medical world. The institution bears the stamp of the genius of Dr. Bryce.

The important event of general interest in military circles, both in and out of New-York, at the present time is the week's rifle contests of the New-Jersey State Rifle Association, which commence at Sea Girt to-morrow. Aside from the best military marksmen from quite a number of States, there will be rifle teams from the District of Columbia, Pennsylvania, Georgia New-Jersey, and probably Connecticut and the United States Army.

FIRE ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 31. THIS little strip of land thrown up by the ocean waves ten miles from the mainland is becoming a favorite resort, not only for society people, who enjoy the surf bathing in the ocean as well as the still-water bathing in the bay, but for the people who are suffering with hay fever.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Aug. 31. SEA CLIFF life for the Summer visitor loses none of its charm as the fleeting days of August proclaim that only a few weeks remain before the season will be over. "I never tire of Sea Cliff," is an oft-repeated remark, and many who were new-comers this year have been charmed by its restfulness, healthfulness, and various attractions.

Starting with falsehood as the very basis and foundation of his character, Philip II. struck down free thought and honest belief wherever these were shown; and using the infamous Inquisition as his tool and vassal, he crowded the many prisons of that ascursed institution with multitudes of his suffering subjects; no less than six thousand five hundred of whom in Spain alone were at the lowest computation, burnt at tho stake in this reign!

BLOCK ISLAND, Aug. 31. NOBODY can deny that the present month has been one of the most remarkable in the history of the hotel business here. July was exasperatingly bad. There was every prospect before the opening of the season that it would be an unusually early one.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Aug. 31. PERFECT weather has been utilized for numerous driving trips to Cooperstown, Five Mile Point, Van Hernsville. Crugers -- almost anywhere as long as one could bowl over the smooth roads and breathe the invigorating air.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 31. -- The most interesting event of the week in Stockbridge was the meeting held in commemoration of the forty-first anniversary of the Laurel Hill Association Wednesday.
