The day was perfect, and everybody in Stockbridge was present, together with many from other towns in the county. H.D. Sedgwick, President of the association, was in charge of the exercises.

When the English pirates first swarmed over from the Continent to the land we now call England in the mythical "three keels" with Hengest and Horse, they brought this common -Teutonio word "thorpe" along with them. It was "thorpe," not "doff," in the old English fatherland. But they didn't use it much, for though they knew it,' it wasn't the usual English word for a house or village.
Mrs. Bertha Cassidy of 38 Macdougal Street had an exciting experience with a burglar Friday afternoon.

The Otsego Golf Club at the northern end of Otsego Lake is the athletic complement to the Cooperstown Athletic Association at the southern end of the lake. The links extend over the property of Henry L. Wardwell and Leslie Pell-Clarke, and throughout their entire extent command a fine view to the southward of the historic sheet of water, the scene of the adventures of the "Deer Slayer."

SYRACUSE, Aug. 31. -- Preparations are under way by the local Democrats for the State Convention, which will be held here on Sept. 27. The committee which went before the State Committee and urged that this city be chosen as the convention town made no mistake in representing that Democrats hereabout would turn out and give the delegates an enthusiastic reception.

The Armenian situation of to-day stands unique in the history of the world. It is at direct antipodes with the marvelous advancement of the great nineteenth century, and leaves far behind all the tales of horror that the victims of professional tyrants of all heathendom could tell from the days of Pharaoh to those of the infamous Nero.

John and Richard McGriff are twin brothers who were born in Preble County, Ohio, Aug. 31, 1804. Their father and mother died at the age of seventy-five years, leaving several children, four of whom are still living -- the twins and two other brothers, whose ages run from sixty-five to ninety-one years. All of them were married. The wives of the twins died about fifty years ago.

Robert A. Dobbin and Winfield S. Amoss, special auditors in the consolidated Baltimore and Ohio Relief Association cases, have filed their third report and final accounts in Circuit Court No. 2. The total amount to be distributed among the members of the relief association who were in good standing March 31, 1889, is $571,274.27. The amount of the contributions of such members was $1,360,147.03.
The funeral of ex-Police Justice Patrick G. Duffy was held yesterday morning, his fifty-first birthday, in the Roman Catholic Church of the Assumption, in West Forty-ninth Street.

There was a large crowd of tennis players on the lower courts in Central Park yesterday afternoon. Two contests were begun, a ladies' singles, with six entries, and a handicap men' s doubles, with ten teams. The crowd greatly interfered with the players in the former contest, pressing right into the courts, and probably causing the defeat of the plucky little Miss Gauthey, who is totally unused to tournament play.
BUFFALO, Sept. 1 -- 1:35 A.M. -- The Academy of Music, on Main Street, the oldest place of amusement in the city, is on fire and is threatened with total destruction.

Peaches continue to take the lead in the fruit market. Apples, pears, and grapes are in light-demand, while the market for good peaches remains unsated. The shipments of peaches to this market last week averaged about seventy carloads daily from Delaware and New-Jersey. The best ones are Crawford's Late, which retail at $2 and $2.50 a basket.

A considerable change has come over the spirit of the English press within the last few weeks regarding the situation in the United States. The advance in prices which has taken place in spite of the somewhat unexpected exports of gold and the undoubted improvement in the general trade situation has made a strong impression upon the minds of the financial writers.
A fire in the building of the Yorkville branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, at 153 and 155 East Eighty-sixth Street, yesterday morning caused damage to the amount of $5,000.

There are lamentably many persons, both men and women, to whom the words "habitual criminal," in their ordinary meaning, have been applied, but it was not until last week, when Recorder Golf had occasion to sentence a man named Bernard Carney, that general attention was called to the terrible significance which this often-used phrase has under the laws of New-York State.

DANVERS, Mass., Aug. 31. -- Salem and Danvers, of witchcraft distinction, centre all the enthusiasm of Summer visitors that is not expended on Hawthorne associations about those weird days of 1692. But there are two generations of years anterior, even to that early date, which make these old Colonial settlements notable and interesting.

Within an hour, the elephant Gypsy, belonging to a show which had a one day's stand at Sixty-fifth Street and Cottage Grove Avenue, yesterday afternoon was doing an act of politeness to an unknown youngster on the street and trying to stamp the life out of its keeper. But for the presence of the owner of the show, W.H. Harris, Barney Shea would to-day be the seventh trainer to be killed by old Gyp.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 31. -- The members of the Famous Fat Men's Convention held their twenty-ninth annual reunion and clambake this afternoon at Roton Point. The two or three hundred heavyweights, headed by the late H.D. Busch of Hoboken, 420 pounds, who were wont to attend these gatherings were sadly missed, but the few present bravely endeavored to fill the gap.

The winners in the international contests on Sept. 21 between the picked teams representing the New-York and the London Athletic Clubs will have cause to be proud of their trophies. Undoubtedly they are the finest ever stamped. They are made of 18 carat gold, and in design are the handsomest ever manufactured by Robert Stoll, the well-known dealer in medals of 19 John Street.

Chicago was visited by millions of cisco flies yesterday morning. They appeared suddenly at about 8 o'clock and disappeared as suddenly shortly before noon. They were most numerous within three or four blocks of the lake shore, between the river and Twelfth Street, but they were very thick all over the city.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Aug. 31. -- With the two firsts won by "Tom" Cooper to-day at the National Circuit race meet of the Montreal Bicycle Club, the seventh and last in the National Circuit of Canada, that rider advanced just two firsts to the good over "Eddie" Bald, who has been on the circuit two months longer. Cooper has won nine firsts in the last week -- a great week's work.

The familiar little poem entitled "Little Drops of Water, Little Grains of Sand," was written by Mrs. Julia Fietcher Carney, now residing in Holyoke, Mass. Though seventy-two years, old, Mrs. Carney is sprightly and full of vigor, and is the life and sunshine of the happy little household over which she presides.

BOSTON, Aug. 31. -- A dispatch from Colorado Springs, Col., states that it is the belief there that the Hatch who has been mentioned in conection with the Holmes murders is Holmes himself, and that he is the "Clark W. Hatch, Boston," who was tried at Breckinridge, Col., in April, 1890, for the murder of his miser uncle.

The American Line steamship St. Louis, which crossed the bar at 1 o'clock yesterday morning, landed her many passengers at the company's pier before 8:30 o'clock. The ship had broken no records except her own on the voyage; but there were many to exult at the showing made. Heavy gales beset the vessel at the start, and for three days and nights the ship was lurching and pitching over hills and valleys.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- The Navy Department is bent on a patriotic policy in relation to some of its prominent employes. It has been determined to no longer employ foreigners in the drafting rooms at the Navy Department and the various yards. Although this subject has been frequently referred to in times past, no active steps have been taken to limit the positions to American citizens.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 31. -- Alport Andrews asserts that he shot and killed State Senator Peter R. Morrissey. The authorities would not believe him until he had made an affidavit accusing himself of murder. Then they locked him up.

One of the first sermons the spectator heard on landing in England was preached in Westminster Abbey. The impressiveness of the Abbey service is, by the way, somewhat marred by the manner in which the crowd "crowds" the monuments, the women sitting on the pedestals and the men hanging their hats on the arms or any other projections in sight.

The lawsuit brought by Melvil Dewey, Secretary of the State Board of Regents, against Maria Whitney and Elizabeth Whitney, has been transferred from the Supreme Court, Essex County, to the Circuit Court of the United States for the Northern District of New-York. Hand, Kellogg Hale of Elizabethtown, N.Y., attorneys for Mr. Dewey, were notified of the transfer this morning by James W. Eaton of this city, who is attorney for the Whitneys.

Three routes offer their respective attractions to the wheelmen who are about to plan a trip from the metropolis to the City of Culture. These are entirely separated from each other, except that the third follows a part of the second for some distance.
The battle of Sedan was deplored and characterized as wholesale murder by 700 Anarchists in Clarendon Hall last night.

While the two most brilliant planets are lost to the evening skies, there are other beautiful heavenly bodies left for our enjoyment, as po month of all the year is more lavish in the bestowal of gifts than September. She sits like a queen enthroned, while heaped up before her are the abundant harvests, the fruits and flowers elaborated by the sovereign power of the great central star that rules the solar scheme.

Dr. Forbes Winslow of London, a well-known specialist on suicide and insanity, says that "Jack the Ripper," who by his crimes terrorized London a few years ago, is incarcerated in a county lunatic asylum in England.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 31. -- A picnic for the benefit of the Fresh Air Fund was held Thursday, in the Grove. It was in charge of Mrs. Leonard Fosdick.
District Attorney John R. Fellows is going in this week with a wish to clear the Tombs of prisoners awaiting trial.

ARVERNE-BY-THE-SEA, L.I., Aug. 31. AFTER all is said and done, Arverne remains, year after year, one of the gayest Summer resorts on Long Island. Two things contribute largely to this, the great hotel, delightfully situated within a few rods of the sea, and the social coterie formed by the cottagers who summer here each season.

The acessions to the collection of music have been more than usually important. The most valuable acquisition was a copy of the ".Motetti de Passione," printed by Petrucci at Venice in 1503. Of this work, the sixth printed by Petrucci with his newly' invented types, only one other copy is known to be in existence, and that wants the title page and one other leaf.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Aug. 31. NEARLY 100 invited guests assembled in the large music room at Kellogg Terrace Wednesday afternoon, to listen to a concert upon the great organ, given by Prof. Henry Dunham of the Boston Conservatory and Everett P. Truette of Boston.
An extensive scheme of fraud upon the Southern Pacific Railroad Company was made public yesterday by the arrest in this city by United States Marshals of Clarence Barnett, a commercial traveler.

At Prospect Park yesterday afternoon the local cricketers played several good games. The only contest brought to a conclusion was the Kings County Cricket Club and the New-Jersey Athletic Club second eleven match in the championship series of the New-York Cricket Association. The county men batted first, and were able to score only 52 runs, W.J. Pitcher taking 5 wickets for 13 runs.

UTICA., Aug. 31. -- There will be no contesting delegations from this county in the State Convention," said Railroad Commissioner Samuel A. Beardsley when a correspondent of The New-York Times asked him how the party in Oneida County is lining up as the campaign approaches. "There will be representatives in the delegation of both the Cleveland and the Hill Democrats.

Cable, horse, elevated, and electric cars and trucks were about the only locomotive things that stayed in the streets of New-York yesterday afternoon when the whole sky opened and sent a deluge on Manhattan Island and other abiding places.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 31. -- The arguments in the injunction suit of Thomas W. Pearsall to restrain the Great Northern Company from consummating the proposed deal to gain control of the Northern Pacific, were concluded yesterday. Speaking for the Great Northern, Attorney Grover said: "All that this matter amounts to in the eyes of a business man is greater assurance of credit, a greater assurance of solvency.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 31. -- In spite of threatening weather, many persons were at the golf links this morning to watch the game between Frank Amory and S. Parkman Shaw. They intended to go round the links twice, but on account of rain were obliged to stop after one round, in which Mr. Amory made a record of 56 to Mr. Shaw's 48.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I. Aug 31. HOTEL registers show a decided falling off in arrivals. Notwithstanding this, Far Rockaway has been anything but dull during the week. Although the hotels show signs of flagging interest, the cottagers continue to make merry with unabating ardor.

UTICA, Aug. 31. -- In addition to the very much mixed-up situation caused by Senator Coggeshall's bolt from the Republican Senatorial Convention, there is a little bit of the old-time "Half-Breed-Stalwart" row going on in this county. Possibly the fact that Roscoe Conkling once made his home here and has a good many very warm and personal friends has something to do with it.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 31. NO decrease in the number of social events is noticeable this week. Indeed, the week to follow gives promise of being one of the most brilliant of the season.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- Two facts stand out prominently in Monroe County politics as the result of the recent Democratic and Republican caucuses. One is that the Democratic factions have at last arrived at a basis of reorganization, which is something better than an armed truce. The other is that the control of the Republican Party by George W. Aldridge is more absolute than ever before.

-- Among the list of English painters who have recently died appear the names of John Evan Hodgson, R.A., whose historical works are little known outside of the British Isles; James Webb, a landscape artist of considerable talent; John Hayter, a brother of Sir George Hayter, the Court painter, and, at the age of eighty, John Absolon of the Royal Institute.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 31. -- There are race meets and race meets, but to the traveled lover of all that is best in speed cycling there remains but one Springfield, and consequently but one Hampden Park. The fame of the "diamond tournaments" is worldwide; it is not confined to a community, or a State, or a section of the country, but is spoken of wherever the wheels spin fast.

The condemnation of the Palisades by the Government for the purpose of converting them into a fortification and military reservation, in order to prevent their further destruction, is not approved by some military experts. John H. Stoddart of Alpine, N.J., wishing to get an expression of opinion upon this plan, wrote to Col. Loomis L. Langdon, retired, who was recently in command of Fort Hamilton. Col. Langdon said:

The 1st of August, according to the old style, the Russian Foreign Office and the Porte exchanged felicitations on the occasion of the four hundredth anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations betwwen the two empires. Michael Plestscheyeff was the first Muscovite Ambassador sent to the Ottoman Court, but his embassy was not very successful.
LIMA, Peru, Aug. 31. -- Congress was opened yesterday. Manuel Candano, President of the Government Junta and Minister of Foreign Relations, read the President's message.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 31. -- Society spent a quiet day indoors to-day, on account of the rain, which poured in torrents from early morning till nearly midnight. It turned out in full force to-night, however, to attend the regular Saturday evening dinner and dance at the Kebo Valley Club.

One day there was a traveler in the woods in California, in the dry season, when the trades were blowing strong. He had ridden a long way, and he was tircd and hungry, and dismounted from his horse, to smoke a pipe. But when he felt in his .Docket he found but two matches. He struck the first and it would not light.

Local politics are in a curious condition just now. Not many of the organizations know just where they are at. The anti-Platt Republicans want a union ticket. The Platt Republicans probably will not show their real hand until after the Republican primaries. Many of the members of the German-American Reform Union are in a rebellious mood against Mayor Strong's administration.

We trust that our Republican friends will set their faces like flint against the demand of the colored politicians for offices. Not that these men have not just as good a claim as white men to be paid for their votes and influence in that way, but no man, white or black or coffee-colored, has any decent claim of this sort, and the colored mercenaries are a peculiarly offensive type.
JAMAICA, L.I., Aug. 31. -- A local paper yesterday printed this unique letter:
There will be no relaxing of the efforts of the police to-day to enforce the provisions of the excise law, and the indications are that the day will be dry.

The Imparcial has been leading a chorus of Madrid newspapers in an eloquent protest against the utterances of "certain English journals" over the Cuban business. The Imparcial makes bold to say that these utterances show a want of appreciation of the "heroic efforts" the mother country is making to retain the island, which betokens the confirmed pessimist or the systematic bear of Spanish stock.
" Now, I don't reckon I ever tells you none about how near we all comes to hangin' Cherokee Hall, do I?"
Every large city, in its system of public parks, seems to present some feature wholly distinctive.

SATURDAY--P.M. Contrary to the general rule, there was good buying throughout the session, notwithstanding the half holiday and the approaching recess until Tuesday. The business was particularly well distributed, as only in two stocks -- St. Paul and Reading -- was there more than 10,000 shares done. All the Grangers closed at advances, the extreme gain being 3/4 in St. Paul. The coal stocks were notably strong, and the general list shared in the improvement.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 31. -- When Miss Kate Gannon, the leading soprano of the choir of St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church, became involved in a discussion with Miss Clara Belle Pruden, the leading alto, as to which had the smaller foot, she had no idea of breaking up the choir or creating a whirlwind of discussion like that which at present prevails in the congregation.

GRAND BEACH, Me., Aug. 24. -- A poem in white is what Maine's big Congressman. Thomas Brackett Reed, might be called when he is dressed in his snow white sweater, all ready for a ride on his glittering bicycle.

The weekly races at the Manhattan Beach track yesterday were devoted to Class A and professional events. Threatening weather resulted in a slim attendance, and a shower before the programme was half over made things disagreeable. The racing, however, was excellent throughout, despite the usual strong breeze blowing up the home stretch.

HAVANA, Aug. 31. -- A dispatch from Santa Clara says that Col. Palanca, with his command, has had sharp battles with the rebel bands under Suarez and Zayas at Cariblanca. The rebels were dispersed and their camp was captured. Their loss is unknown. The Government troops are pursuing the fleeing insurgents.

BAYONNE, Aug. 31. -- The Protection Engine Company fair was formally opened this evening and will continue until Sept. 7 in the handsome new firehouse on Avenue D, near East Fiftieth Street. During the coming week the fair will prove the social attraction in the upper section of Bayonne. With abundant attractive features the company hopes to engross the attention of the 500 local volunteer firemen after the Labor Day parade.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 31. OWING to the hot weather of the last week the Summer sojourners have been slow in returning to their city homes. As a rule, however, the city guests who summer in this locality do not go back until the latter part of September, and thus enjoy the pleasantest month of the season.

The attempt to settle the respective claims of France and England on the Mekong River by a joint commission on the spot has failed, and the negotiations will now have to be carried on in Paris and London.

August Belmont, Chairman of the State Racing Commission, of The Jockey Club, and of the National Steeplechase Association, came on from Newport yesterday and attended the racing at the track of the Coney Island Jockey Club. One of the first things he did was to call a meeting of the Stewards of The Jockey Club, which will be held at the track on Monday morning at 11 o'clock.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 31. -- A lawn tennis tournament for mixed doubles and ladies' singles is being played here on James J. Van Alen's lawn, and is proving very interesting to those who have been invited to witness the contests which are for valuable pieces of jewelry. The lawn is as smooth as a billiard table, and the courts are as fine as can be found in the country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- Among the cases docketed in the Supreme Court of the United States is one from the Kentucky Court of Appeals, which brings up for construction a provision of the Constitution of that State which forbids railroad companies which own, control, or operate competing lines of road from purchasing or otherwise securing control of the said competing lines.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 31. IT is safe to say that this has been one of the liveliest Summer resorts in the country this week. Events have crowded each other so closely that the cadets have had scarcely a breathing spell.

The "labor" question is a very old one in the State of New-York. On the 12th of December, 1809, the Grand Jury presented to the Court of General Sessions of the Peace, the Hon. De Witt Clinton, Mayor of the City of New-York, presiding, an indictment against James Melvin and others.
In to-day's issue of your paper I notice what seems to me an unintentional misleading statement of the proceedings on the Produce Exchange to charge Rule 35.

There are two subjects with which James W. Boyle is especially familiar -- city politics and oysters. He is paying more attention to oysters just now than to politics, as the time for making big shipments of the bivalves to the West has come, and his business as a wholesale oyster dealer requires most of his attention.

Disappointing is a glance beneath the haik of a Moorish maiden. The faces of the Moorish women are too broad to be beautiful. Their eyes are dark and lustrous, but every device of art is used to give them the appearance they present in the street to the curious stranger. Art also generally supplies the complexion.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 31. -- Mrs. J.M. Thornell has left her Monmouth cottage for the Adirondack Mountains.

Nearly a year ago Horace Geiger, a well-known business man, suddenly left his home, in the beautiful suburb St. David's, and was not again heard from until last evening, when he rang the doorbell of his mother's residence, 1842 North Thirteenth Street, and hurried into the house to greet her.
NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 31. WITH the waning of the season there seems to be greater social activity at the Summer resorts here and hereabout than prevailed the earlier and warmer days of the Summer.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 31. -- The twenty Cubans arrested at Pennsgrove, N.J., yesterday, were arraigned before Acting United States Commissioner MaCAllister this morning. The courtroom was crowded. The Commissioner read to each man separately the charge, and each pleaded not guilty. Ralph De Soto of this city, agent of the Cubans here, acted as interpreter.

Henry Rothkopf, senior member of the firm of S. Rothkopf, Son Co., which deals in trimmings, buttons, and veilings, at 477 Broadway and 50 Mercer Street, committed suicide in his office about 9:30 o'clock yesterday morning by shooting himself in the head.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31. -- The Cuban filibusters' expedition which came to grief at Penn's Grove, N.J., last night, was planned in Philadelphia, and the first hint the Government officials had of the movement came from Dr. J. Congesto, the Spanish Consul at this port.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 31. BY FAR the crowning feature of the week was Mrs. Alva Vanderbilt's ball at Marble House Wednesday evening. It was an occasion of splendor long to be remembered by those who beheld it.

The report of the New-Hampshire Forestry Commission contains some interesting matter from Prof. Flint of Winchester, N.H., concerning the distribution of the trees and shrubs composing the New-Hampshire forests, and also the bearing of certain problems in geological science on the researches made concerning the way in which the animals and plants of the State were distributed.

The crews on the Defender and Valkyrie had a busy day yesterday. Many radical changes were made on each boat. After the race on Friday the Defender was towed to Bay Ridge and her big mainsail was unbent at once. Then the boom and gaff were unslung, and in their places the new steel spars were shipped. The crew worked late to get the new spars on in order that they might be tried yesterday.

Few men have ever deserved so well of so many authors and so large a public as the great Leipsic publisher whose death we recorded in our later editions of yesterday. Baron Tauchnitz may be said to have founded an international conscience, to have introduced a literature, and to have invented a format.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 31. -- The twenty Cubans arrested at Pennsgrove, N.J., yesterday, were arraigned before Acting United States Commissioner MaCAllister this morning. The courtroom was crowded. The Commissioner read to each man separately the charge, and each pleaded not guilty. Ralph De Soto of this city, agent of the Cubans here, acted as interpreter.

Six thousand persons saw the Clevelands defeat the Brooklyns at Eastern Park yesterday. The Clevelands took advantage of every point, and by the close of the fifth inning they had 14 runs placed to their credit, while the home team had scored but 5 runs.

There was not a murmur of resistance to the Royal Commissioners when they arrive at the Priory of St. Swithin's in 1538. They found the prior and all the convent, they reported, very conformable. The ayor citizens, if we are to believe the Commissioners' report, were so enthusiastic in their support of the roya;1 intentions as to attend in person and give laud and praise to God and the King's Majesty.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- An excursion party of seventy-five Pennsylvania Railroad people, accompanied by their ladies, arrived at the Grand Union Hotel at a late hour last night and will remain over Sunday.

NEWARK, Aug. 31. -- Freeholder Reinhard of the Lunacy Committee of the Board of Freeholders has started a crusade to liberate several patients who are confined in the Hospital for the Insane that he believes are of sound mind. The release from the institution last Tuesday of Mrs. Jeralemon, he claims, is a victory for him.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- Republican Conventions were held to-day in the four Assembly districts of Monroe County, as were also the four Assembly District Judicial Conventions. The First and Fourth Assembly District Conventions met this morning at Pittsford and Spencerport, respectively, and elected delegates to the State Convention.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 31. BY SEPTEMBER 1 in other years few people were left at Lake Placid resorts to enjoy the delights of the early Autumn. But this year the big hostelries that overlook the beautiful Placid and Mirror Lakes are still filled with gay humanity.

CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- Frank Rice presided over the deliberations of the Ontario County Democratic Convention to-day, and in his usual energetic manner denounced the McKinley Tariff law and attributed the business adversity of the country to the enactment of Republican legislation. The following resolution was unanimously adopted:

The annual report of the Wabash Railroad, just issued, shows gross earnings for the year ended June 30, of $11,959,839, a decrease of $591,610 as compared with the previous year. The operating expenses were $8,921,030, and the net earnings were $3,038,809, an increase of $317,740. The total income for the year was $3,169,204, the fixed charges were $3,712,111, and the deficit $542,907.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 31. -- Elms and gambrel-roof houses, antedating the Revolutionary War by a generation or more, can be found without difficulty in the old town of Farmington, which is known throughout the country as the birthplace of President Noah Porter of Yale, and the scene of Nellie Grant's school days. One of these ancient dwellings, erected in the seventeenth century, and known as the Whitman house, is now occupied as a tenement.

News comes from Washington that the New-York Board of Aldermen has been snubbed -- cruelly, contemptuously, one is almost tempted to say effectually. The Aldermen are going on a trip down the bay, in a few days, and they decided that it would be a fine thing for the soldiers on Governors Island to fire a salute as the City Fathers sailed by.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 31. OF health and pleasure seekers still lingering in the mountains there are thousands, and nearly every house is still taxed to its utmost capacity, but it needs not the eye of a prophet to see that the end of the season is not far off.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 31. -- The sixth weekly golf handicap for one of the cups given by Theodore A. Havemeyer was played this afternoon, and won by J. Ellis Hoffman. The handicaps were not posted as usual to-day, consequently no one knew his standing until he had reported his score. The effect was to frighten some of the players, and they either did not enter or else quit before the course was half played over.
EAST ROCKAWAY, L.I., Aug. 31. -- The name-changing mania that is prevalent on Long Island has broken out here, and there is considerable hard feeling in consequence.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 31. -- The storm that passed over the eastern section of the State at 5 o'clock this afternoon did no damage here or in Hoboken, but it worked destruction in North Hudson.

On the evening before the great Buford ejectment suit. Jack Buford arrived at Weldon, the county town, mentally perturbed by exultation and dejection. On the one hand, there were his mother, his crippled brother, Swayne, his sister Blanche, all about to be restored to prosperity -- surely their interests must be pre-eminent, even if he would sacrifice his own.

Gen. Charles Adams, who was killed in the Gumry Hotel fire, in Denver, Col., Sunday night, was well known to the old-time Post Office Inspectors of Chicago, and to the Western country generally. He was a German by birth, his real name being Schwanbeck, but for some reason he requested one of the early Legislatures of Colorado to change his name to Adams.

In response to an article on the Brooklyn Water Supply in Harper's Weekly, in which it was stated that the authorities had made little effort to remove all dangerous accumulations in the horse brook draining into the Hempstead reservoir, Alfred T. White, the Brooklyn Commissioner of City Works, yesterday gave out a statement defending himself against the charge, which he declared to be unwarranted.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Aug. 31. -- The Department of State has received a dispatch by mail from Mr. Pringle, Charge d'Affaires at Guatemala, dated Aug. 14, giving particulars of the arrest of Robert J. Breckinridge and C.C. Goff, both citizens of the United States, on suspicion of being implicated in the murder, July 16, of P.O.D. Brooks, cashier of an agency company at Livingston, and described by Mr. Pringle as "a young American."
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 31. SECRETS seem to pervade every part of this resort. There are happy surprises in store for many, especially among those of the cottage colony.

SUMMIT, N.J., Aug. 31. -- A very pretty sale of cake and fancy articles was held on Thursday afternoon on the grounds of Mrs. G. Hodenpyl, in Waldron Avenue. It was for the benefit of the Fresh Air and Convalescent Home.

Gen. Ely S. Parker, Supply Clerk of the Police Department, died yesterday morning at his country home, at Fairfield, Conn. The news was not a surprise at Police Headquarters, as Gen. Parker had been seriously ill since he was stricken...

Mr. Sydney Buxton's bill, in the opinion of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Webb, Mr. Charles Booth, and other experts, contains the best proposals on the subject yet put into parliamentary form. It provides that the landlord shall register the address of ally premises let for a domestic workshop, together with the name and address of the occupier, and that he shall answer for their being kept in a proper sanitary condition.

The prevailing impression that the Plattdeutsche Volksfest Verein is an organization with purely social and jovial functions is erroneous. While this society has been brought into prominence mainly by the successful manner in which it manages the annual reunions of the Low Germans of New-York and vicinity, its chief object, nevertheless, is charity and benevolence.

Early last evening there was an exciting event that might have added a chapter of sadness to the convention of the American Bar Association, which has been marked by only the most happy experiences up to date. The Hon. James F. Joy fell into the river in a most dangerous place, but was quickly brought out by the efforts of Judge J.M. Dickinson of Nashville, Tenn.

Thirty arrests for violation of the excise law were made yesterday. This is believed to be the smallest number made on any Sunday in the last five years. Many precincts reported no arrests. In none were there more than six.

NOVI, Mich., Sept. 1. -- Mrs. Mary Ann Bush died last night at the residence of her daughter, Mrs. Alva Sage, aged 112 years and 2 months. These figures are based upon authentic records in possession of the family. She was the oldest person in Michigan.

We note a pretty widespread interest in the West as to the respective "booms" of Messrs. Allison of Iowa and Harrison of Indiana. There is no reasonable doubt that in the present state of Republican opinion either of these gentlemen stands a better chance for the nomination than any of the other reputed aspirants.

ROCKAWAY BEACH, L.I., Sept. 1. -- The fight by the residents and property owners of this place against the New York street cleaning authorities, who are said to be responsible for the heaps of garbage that float ashore on every tide, is to be carried into the Supreme Court by the Board of Health of the town of Hempstead, and the Citizens' Association of this place.

UNION HILL, N.J., Sept. 1. -- The twenty-first annual Plattdutsch Volksfest came to a successful close at a late hour to-night. The immense attendances of the previous days were again equaled, and at sundown at least 30,000 persons had passed the gates of the Union Hill Schuetzen Park. The crowd had evidently come with the sole intent of enjoying the day, and not a disagreeable incident occurred to mar the pleasures of the Volksfest.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 1. -- The seismic phenomena in New-Jersey were not violent or alarming, though well marked as to time, duration, direction, and oscillatory power. The quake came when the early morning was of crystalline purity and ideal temperature. The sky was cloudless, the atmosphere clear and serene, and the storm had brought a coolness that had Autumnal suggestions.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 1. -- The handsome new convent of St. Dominic, on the hillside at Caldwell, was dedicated this morning by Bishop Winand M. Wigger. It is one of the handsomest buildings of its kind in the State, and cost $115,000.

PARIS, Sept. 1. -- A series of great bull fights was fixed to begin at Bayonne today, and the celebrated Spanish bull fighter Mazzantini was specially engaged to appear. The police, however, refused to allow the fight to proceed, and they caused Mazzantini to be conducted to the Spanish frontier.

BOSTON, Sept. 1. -- At 12 o"clock midnight, Aug. 31, the New-York and New-England Railroad, the bone of so many corporation contests, became a thing of the past, and rose from its ashes as the New-England Railroad Company. The transfer was made by Thomas C. Platt and Marsden J. Perry, Receivers of the New-York and New-England, in pursuance of the decrees of the United States Circuit Court.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- Lizzie Halliday some time ago created a sensation by setting fire to her home in Sullivan County, causing thereby the death of a stepson. Later, she murdered Paul Halliday, her husband, at her home in Burlingham, Sullivan County, burying his body under the floor, and also two women whom she came to Newburg and got, and whose bodies she placed in a barn.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1. -- It looks as if the authorities of Philadelphia intend to try H.H. Holmes, the much-accused swindler and alleged multi-murderer, for the murder here of his partner. Benjamin F. Pietzel.

DULUTH, Minn., Sept. 1. -- The fight by Inman's Tug Line upon Singer's Tug Line, because the latter entered upon the towing business, resulted to-day in the sinking of Inman's tug Pathfinder in the harbor close to the docks, before thousands of people, and also in the death of Charles Scully, a Pathfinder fireman.

" No order to close saloons to-day was issued from Police Headquarters this week," said Capt. Dunn, who was in charge of the Police Department yesterday, to reporter for The New-York Times. "Why should such an order be issued? There is no necessity for one. Brooklyn saloons are all closed to-day. They never are open on Sunday."

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- R.T. Allen, who shot himself on a New-York Central train last Friday, while returning to his home in Omaha, Neb., after a visit to a college in New-Jersey, where he had left his daughter, succeeded in killing himself this evening. When he was brought to Buffalo he was taken to the Fitch Hospital, where he improved so much that the physicians assured him he would recover.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- The State Fair last week attracted a great many thousand people to this city from this and adjoining counties. The grounds were well filled nearly every day, the attractions were many, the exhibits excellent in quality and large in quantity, and on the whole the fair was a success.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 1. -- The circumstances attending the capture of the Cuban filibustering expedition at Penn's Grove, N.J., on Friday afternoon were the chief subject of discussion among the many local sympathizers with the revolutionary cause in Cuba. While deploring the fate of the expedition, there was an apparent feeling of exultation among the Cubans about the city over the mild manner in which the United States authorities treated the prisoners at the hearing.

MADRID, Sept. 1 -- Count de Benalua, who was an intimate friend of the late King Alfonzo XII., and Senor Martinez de Roda, who some time ago married in New York the widow of ex-President Barrios, of Guatemala, became involved in a quarrel recently, which resulted in the sending and acceptance of a challenge to fight a duel. The meeting took place on the French frontier, and both the duellists were wounded.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 1. -- The death of the Rev. James Hughes, Vicar General of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Hartford and rector of St. Patrick's Church, Hartford, has caused a number of changes in the clergy, some of which were announced to-day. The Rev. John A. Mulcahy, rector of the Church of the Immaculate Conception of Waterbury, has been transferred to the pastorate of St. Patrick's Church, Hartford.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- Whatever may be the effect on election day of the efforts of Democrats to bring about party union in Oswego County there remains the fact that for the last year in this county a unique spectacle in the political history of the State has been on exhibition.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Sept. 1. -- During the terrific storm Saturday evening lightning struck the house of John Hewlett, at Ocean Side, two miles south of this place, and literally wrecked the whole house.

The Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club are making extensive preparations for the cup races. They have chartered from the Old Dominion Steamship Company the seagoing steamship Roanoke, (or Guyandotte,) to enable members of the club and their guests to witness all of the races. The steamship will leave the Old Dominion Steamship Company's pier, No. 26 North River, foot of Beach Street, at 9:30 A.M. The attendance will be limited to 800.

Peter Gumry -- his birth and life of strange incident and adventure -- has been the subject of much interested discussion and some lively romancing during the past week. There has been current the captivating story that when a little infant he was picked up in midocean from a piece of wreckage, the sole surviving passenger of a lost vessel, and given the name of the rescuing craft.

ISHPEMING, Mich., Sept. 1. -- The citizens of this iron mining town and the neighboring one of the Negaunee to-night are alarmed at the labor situation. A hundred and fifty State soldiers are encamped in the vicinity of the Lake Ageline mine, where the steam shovels are to be operated by men who have been brought from Chicago to take the places of the strikers.

Jacquelin and Piette, the crack Parisian cyclists, did not arrive on the French Line steamer Bourgogne yesterday, as it was expected they would. George Boudier, a passenger on the boat, and himself a wheelman, said that the pair had mad all preparations to sail, but at the last moment decided to wait for the next steamer.

The present will be a brilliant week at the Sheepshead Bay track of the Coney Island Jockey Club, with racing every day except Friday. The week's sport will be ushered in with a most attractive programme this afternoon, the chief feature of which will be the running of the Twin City Handicap, at a mile and a quarter.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 1. -- Cottagers thronged old Trinity Church to-day to hear the Rev. Dr. C.H. Vibbert, vicar of Trinity Chapel, New-York. Every seat in the large auditorium was taken and chairs were placed in the aisles. The Duke of Marlborough was present. Dr. Vibbert is the guest of Sidney Webster. Bishop Leighton Coleman of Delaware preached at All Saints' Chapel.

BERLIN, Sept. 1. -- The inaugural ceremonies of the celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the battle of Sedan, the final engagement of the Franco-Prussian war, took place to-day. The programme in this city included the inauguration of the Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church, with the following details:
Mrs. Ballington Booth talked to a large audience in the Salvation Army Headquarters, Fourteenth Street, near Sixth Avenue, last evening, on the "New Woman."

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., Sept. 1. -- Staten Island felt the full force of the earthquake this morning. Tottenville appears to have been the most severely shaken. In that village the reports of broken ornaments and of dishes were numerous.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- Several hundred Hudson River fishermen met in Kingston yesterday and signed a long petition, in which they asked the State Fish Commission to set aside a new law, which goes into effect to-day and prohibits the using of fykes and seines in the fresh waters of the State. Deputy Attorney General G.D. B. Hasbrouck was engaged to carry their petition to the commission.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1. -- A local paper says that ex-Mayor Hopkins advised the great railroad strike of 1894, which ended in such disastrous loss of property and life, and confirms the statement by interviews with President Eugene V. Debs, of the American Railway Union, in Woodstock jail, and ex-Vice President George W. Howard, in this city.

STAPLETON, S.I., Sept. 1. -- Many Staten Island business men have been victimized by a man who came to Stapleton about two months ago with a wife and child, and gave his name as F.B. Patterson of Long Island. He was employed by the Rapid Transit Company as train dispatcher at South Beach, was very respectable in appearance, and talked of better days.

The local championship season of cricket is drawing to an end, and in the series of the Metropolitan District Cricket League but two games remain to be played. The result of the contest is already known, for Staten Island cannot now be prevented from coming out on top, even if defeated in the only game they have yet to play.

The Fifty-fourth Congress has the agreeable prospect of being able, at its first session, to make a splendid addition of new battleships and torpedo boats to the navy, while at the same time diminishing by perhaps five millions, or more if it likes, the annual naval appropriations, as compared with those of the current fiscal year.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 1. -- John Whewell, foreman in the Blickensderfer typewriter factory, took a sail in his catboat yesterday afternoon with his assistant foreman, Samuel A. Searle, the latter's son Samuel, aged nine, and Willie and Edward Burrett, aged five and twelve. They went bathing on Greenwich Point Beach, and subsequently got into the boat, letting it drift 400 feet from the shore.

The state of things in the Democratic Party in Maryland is eliciting much comment in all parts of the country. The declaration of ex-Gov. Whyte that the defeat of the German candidate is a duty that Democrats owe to their party -- a view that is apparently shared by a considerable number of Democrats in Maryland -- is variously received.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- The earthquake reported from New-Jersey, New-York, Pennsylvania, and Delaware this morning was not noticed here. The delicate seismic recorders at the Naval Observatory did not indicate the slightest disturbance here.

Among the arrivals from Paris yesterday on the French Line steamship La Bourgogne was Mme. Clementine de Vere Sapio, the well-known prima donna. It is two years since Mme. Sapio sang in the United States. At that time she was simply Mlle. Clementine de Vere, and attracted much favorable notice in concert and oratorio. She returns as Mme. Sapio and brings with her a sweet little baby.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- The Academy of Music, Buffalo's historic old playhouse, was gutted by a fierce fire early this morning. Besides the Academy proper, the liquor store of P.C. Millet, the saloon of Jacob Fried, the fur and hat store of George W. Comstock, and the variety store of the William Vaughn Company, all in the Academy of Music block, are damaged.

We recently pointed out that "the only way by which the stability of the currency can be absolutely secured is the gradual withdrawal of the demand notes." Commenting on this, The Times of Richmond, Va., says:
When the fleet of steel canalboats now discharging cargo from Lorain, Ohio, gets under way for its return trip there ,will be no little speculation as to the nature of the return cargo.

Thrice the earth trembled and New-York slept on. A Sunday morning earthquake could not arouse it -- a quake that first shook Jersey, caused sections of Pennsylvania to quiver and, going over to Long Island, jarred Brooklyn's tall buildings on the Heights, and ruthlessly tumbled country folks out of bed at 6 o'clock yesterday morning.

" The Chieftain" is the title of the sermon the Rev. Dr. T. De Witt Talmage has this week prepared for The New-York Times. The text chosen is from Canticles, v., 10: "The chiefest among ten thousand." The sermon is as follows:

WEST HAMPTON BEACH, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- The annual open regatta of the West Hampton Country Club was sailed yesterday afternoon. The wind was south and just a pleasant full-sail breeze. The bay was dotted with craft and the grounds and piazzas of the hotels and cottages were filled with spectators.
BERLIN, Sept. 1. -- Prince Bismarck, in receiving the German-American veterans on Friday last, said, after lamenting his old age and the condition of his health:

The great cricket match of the year will take place to-day at Staten Island, when the team representing the English Universities of Oxford and Cambridge will be opposed by a teals selected from All-New-York. The Englishmen form a very powerful team, with particularly good bowling, the quantity and variety both being there, and the representatives of the metropolis will require to put forth their strongest efforts to be saved from defeat.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 1. -- To-day was a delightful one at this place. To-morrow being Labor Day, many persons arrived here yesterday and to-day to spend Sunday and Monday. This was the last Sunday of the season for several of the hotels to keep their doors open, and they received a good patronage.

Questions as to what women may, can, will, or shall do in politics are interesting but vague. One explicit example of what women have done, for what purpose, and by what methods is worth any amount of discussion. Such an example is described, clearly and in detail, in a pamphlet (No. 150) published by the American Academy of Political and Social Science of Philadelphia.

WEST NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Sept. 2. -- Richmond County's first fair and horse show was opened at the grounds formerly owned by the Staten Island Athletic Club at this place to-day, and if the interest manifested on the opening day is continued throughout the week the fair will be an unqualified success.

The Defender was floated out of the Erie Basin yesterday morning before 9 o'clock. Many thought the famous yacht would remain there all day, and so paid a visit to the Basin to see her. Of course, they were disappointed. Half an hour after the yacht was floated a line was taken from the tug Wallace B. Flint, and the Defender was towed to New-Rochelle.

HASTINGS, England, Sept. 2. -- By 10 o'clock this evening 229 games of the international chess masters' tournament had been decided. Two games were left unfinished. Pillsbury takes the first prize, while Tschigorin and Lasker take the second and third prizes, respectively, or the amount of both prizes will be divided between those players, according to the issue of the unfinished game between Tschigorin and Schlechter.

It is announced in the Republican papers that Mr. Platt is now going over the names of the present incumbents of State offices to decide on which ones his favors shall fall. Two, at least, are likely to escape his indorsement -- one, Mr. Roberts, the Controller, and the other Mr. Hancock, the Attorney General. Exactly what grievance the astute ex-Senator has against these gentlemen we are not able in detail to describe.
The earthquake which occurred at 6 o'clock on Sunday morning was the subject of a good deal of comment yesterday.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 2. -- It has been quite lively to-day, although with the advent of the 1st of September, a number of visitors departed. Still a large colony of cottagers and hotel guests yet remain to make gay the closing days of the Summer season.

The importation of Asiatic cholera into the Hawaiian Islands and the culpable evasion of sanitary regulations at San Francisco by the steamer which had brought the disease to Honolulu direct attention to the possible exposure of the Pacific slope to infection proceeding from the Orient.

By a rear-end collision at the Woodlawn station of the Sea Beach Railway to Coney Island yesterday afternoon, at least fourscore persons of both sexes and all ages were injured. Some of them may die. None was killed outright.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- The opening session of the annual meeting of the American Social Science Association was held this evening. F.J. Kingsbury, LL. D., of Waterbury, Conn., President of the Association, delivered his annual address on "The Tendency of Men to Live in Cities." The only other event of importance was the presentation of the annual report of the Secretary, by F.B. Sanborn of Concord, Mass.

Those who are familiar with the excellent operetta called "Erminie" may remember that when Ravvy introduces Caddy as the Baron Bonny, he says: "And a bonny Baron the Baron Bonny is." With some slight change in orthography, the line may be applied to the latest invasion of Philadelphia operetta, and we may all say: "A bonny Princess the 'Princess Bonny' is."

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Sept. 2. -- Sir John Schultz, who for seven years has been Governor of Manitoba, to-night received an official dispatch that the Hon. J.C. Patterson, until recently Minister of Militia in the Dominion Cabinet, had been sworn in as his successor, and would proceed to Winnipeg at once.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Sept. 2. -- This afternoon the dead bodies of Dr. E.M. Remington and his mother, Mrs. Mary E. Remington, were discovered in their cottage, 150 Whitting Avenue. Mrs. Remington's skull was crushed in and her throat was cut.
CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- Passed East -- Steam yachts Emeline, Stephen J. Roach; Neaira, C.A. Gould, and Aquilo, estate of George A. Thayer, Schooner yacht Wayfarer, Adrian Iselin, Jr.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2. -- The waving of the red flag of anarchy during the formation of a Labor Day parade of Italians to-day led to a wild scene and the arrest of two men who attempted to incite a mob to riot. The police were informed yesterday that an organization of Italian Socialists was preparing for a celebration to-day and that the members had floated a red flag from the window of the meeting place.
WEST NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Sept. 2. -- The police and fire companies had a lively time because of firebugs who started five fires at Livingston and West Brighton Sunday night and this morning.

BERLIN, Sept. 2. -- The celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the fall of Sedan was continued to-day. The sun shone brightly. Immense crowds thronged the streets. At 8 o'clock this morning Emperor William reviewed the First Regiment of the Guards before the Schloss, and at the conclusion of the review personally decorated the standards of the troops with oak leaves.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 2. -- Oliver Belmont, having recovered from his illness, gave to-night the grand ball at Belcourt which he meant to give several days ago. He was able to receive his guests in person, and greeted them at the threshold of the magnificent ballroom. He was congratulated heartily upon his rapid recovery from a really serious illness.

BUFFALO, Sept. 2. -- Lake traffic during the month of August was not excessive, but showed quite an improvement over preceding months since the opening of the present navigation season. During the month of August 11,445,911 bushels of grain were received here, against 10,891,390 in August, 1894. But the receipts for the season thus far are nearly 6,000,000 bushels less than last year for the corresponding period.

SARATOGA, Sept. 2. -- Eighty Baltimore pilgrims reached Congress Hall this afternoon, and will remain until Wednesday. They are members of the Monumental and Baltimore Commanderies, and are returning from the Boston encampment of Knights Templars.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 2. -- The National Circuit meet of the Consolidated Cycling Clubs of Boston at Waltham track to-day was attended by the usual large Boston crowd. The entry list in Class B was the smallest by a large proportion of the season. Bald had everything his own way, Murphy having been notified through a member of the Racing Board that he was under suspension. Gardiner could not ride, owing to lameness.

The labor organizations in this city, with the exception of the Knights of Labor who are garment makers, refrained from parading yesterday, but observed the day by attending picnics, where they had music, dancing, and speaking.
It never had an equal in the annals of baseball.

BROCKTON, Mass., Sept. 2. -- Courtenay Thorpe's new drama, "The Story of a Sin," had a beautiful production here to-night before a large audience. The play is powerful, and is interesting in its development. Scenically, the production is very handsome and complete, a woodland scene being particularly notable for its picturesqueness.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Sept. 2. -- On Saturday 850 troops, commanded by Col. Canellas, had an engagement with 3,500 rebels, led by Maceo, at San Indio, south of Ramon de las Yaguas, some six leagues east of Santiago de Cuba. The fighting lasted eight hours, and resulted in the rout of the rebels.

We remember that in 1891, after The Times had published a list, in successive installments, of the many reductions of wages which had followed the enactment of the McKinley tariff, prominent Republican journals began, on a certain date, to deny that such reductions had taken place, although nearly all the very changes in question had been announced in their own news columns.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 2. -- Albert Schiffling, an expert instrument maker of this city, met H.H. Holmes Oct. 3, 1894. Holmes called at his place of business that day, with two cases of instruments. The cases were of brown morocco leather. One case contained two knives and a saw. The knives were quite sharp, pointed at the ends, and the blades bore a few dark spots.

CARDIFF, Wales, Sept. 2. -- The twenty-eighth annual Trades-Union Congress of Great Britain opened at noon to-day in the Town Hall here, with David Holmes, President of the Cotton Spinners' Association, in the chair. The Chairman announced that there were present 344 duly elected delegates, representing over a million members of various unions.

Five new plays were acted for the first time in this city last night; a new place of amusement, Proctor's Pleasure Palace, devoted to variety, was thrown open; several of the "combination" houses began their Fall terms with familiar pieces, and the customary Monday night changes were made in the theatres already in operation, the music halls, and roof gardens.
At a recent convention of silver men in Cleveland, Ohio, four men were arrested for trying to steal a diamond stud from one of the delegates.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2. -- The big event of the day in this city was the parade late this afternoon of the letter carriers of Philadelphia and neighboring cities, and the informal opening this evening of the Convention of the National Letter Carriers' Association. The letter carriers' parade included not less than 4,000 men.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2. -- Dissension marked the celebration of Labor Day in Chicago, and two rival organizations of labor marched in separate parades. This was the result of the long-pending dispute between the Labor Congress and the Trade and Labor Assembly.

DULUTH, Minn., Sept. 2. -- Living in the wilds or Northern Minnesota, fifty miles from a Post Office, with only a boy for a companion, Dr. George W. Fraker, who planned one of the most gigantic and successful insurance swindles of modern times, was to-day captured by officers who have been on his track for the last two years.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 2. -- A better doy for golfing than to-day could not have been chosen, and the members of the Morristown Golf Club had good cause to congratulate themselves on such typical weather for the opening of their Fall season.

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 2. -- Thomas Conneff of the New-York Athletic Club covered himself with glory this afternoon, breaking two American and one world's record during the New-Jersey Athletic Club's Labor Day carnival here. Conneff won his new laurels in the special race at one and one-half miles, scratch, pitted against George Orton of the same club, Charles Bean of Boston, and Andy Walsh of the Xaviers.
LONDON, Sept. 2. -- A dispatch has been received here from Archdeacon Wolfe, at Foo-Choo, denying the rumors that riots have taken place there.

The thorough enforcement of the excise law on Sunday was regarded by the Police Department as an indication that the liquor dealers, so defiant in the past in violating the law, had finally succumbed to the force of circumstances and had surrendered at discretion. Hereafter it is believed that the police will have little difficulty in carrying out the law.

One of the most interesting games of baseball that has been played in this city for some time was the contest at the Polo Grounds yesterday morning between the New-York and Cleveland Clubs. Dad Clarke pitched for the New-Yorks. He had perfect command of the ball, and gave only two men their bases on balls, while there were but three safe hits made off his delivery.

ROME, Sept. 2. -- Prime Minister Crispi presided at a meeting of the Cabinet to-day. Among the questions considered was that of granting amnesty to political and other prisoners on the occasion of the fetes that will be held Sept. 20 in celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the occupation of Rome by the Italian troops under Gen. Cadorna.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- Saturday's shower left the roads in fine condition, and to-day almost everybody has been riding, driving, and bicycling. The road around Canadarago Lake has been filled all day with fine turnouts and bicycles.

WHITESTONE LANDING, L.I., Sept. 2. -- The Cherokee Club, nearly 1,000 strong, visited Whitestone to-day. The occasion was the club's annual outing, Rhode Island clambake, and games. After breakfast the party spread itself over the grounds, and groups of men were gathered in shady places engaging in various games of amusement and discussing politics.
The Council of Administration of the New-York State Bankers' Association held two meetings at the Windsor Hotel yesterday, one in the afternoon and the other in the evening.

The Brooklyn police precinct commanders yesterday paid a glowing tribute to their own zeal in suppressing Sunday liquor traffic the day before when they reported to Police Commissioner Welles that, of a total of 160 arrests made between 6 A.M. Sunday and 6 A.M. Monday, 95 were for intoxication.

The Staten Island Club's ground at Livingston, S.I., was the scene yesterday of an interesting cricket match. A large crowd was present to see it, and the spectators were rewarded by witnessing some of the best plays seen hereabouts in years.

We regret that The Springfield Republican is disturbed about the motives of The Times in commenting on recent operations of negro Republicans. "What is it," says The Republican, "to a Democratic organ that a contingent of the Republican forces talks of bolting? Apparently the only motive The Times has is to show the worthlessness of negro voters -- which is singularly out of place.
BERLIN, Sept. 2. -- Emperor William has appointed his a, the Grand Duchess of Baden, Honorary Colonel of the Grenadier Guard, of which regiment the Empress is Colonel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- Robert Downing presented at the Grand Opera House to-night a play called "Helena," which is an adaptation by A.D. Hall of Sardou's "La Haine," which was produced at the Gaiety Theatre, in Paris, Dec. 4, 1874, and withdrawn after twenty-five performances. The scene is laid in Sienna and the play is a story of Italy at the time of the feuds between the Guelphs and the Ghibellines.

SING SING, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- The earthquake of Sunday morning was felt by many persons in this village, but as the place is often jarred at that hour in the morning by heavy dynamite blasts at the Rockland Lake stone crusher, on the opposite side of the Hudson River, nothing was thought of it until the nswapapers this morning informed the people that there had been an earthquake.
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 2. -- The State Convention of the People's Party was held today, with thirteen counties represented by about forty men and one woman.

In commenting on Henry M. Stanley's maiden speech in Parliament, The Saturday Review says: "The tinge of Americanism in his accent threw his individuality into a sort of relief." This is indeed amusing, considering, that Stanley was born in Wales and lived there until he was a well-grown lad. He did, it is true, come to America after a while.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 2. -- The day has been a perfect one in Lenox. Everybody has taken advantage of it, and the streets have had their old-time September appearance. Everybody but the Stokes family has returned, and they are expected to-morrow.

Taral came away from the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday afternoon with the honors of the day, he having won both of the stakes on the card with his mounts, taking the Pamridge Stakes, for two-year-olds, with One I Love and the Twin City Handicap with Rey El Santa Anita, one of the educated animals of the Santa Anita Stables.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 2. -- One man was killed and another injured by the collision of a locomotive and a trolley car at the Singac crossing of the Greenwood Lake Railroad this morning about 11 o'clock.

Brooklyn public schools will open to-day, and 118,000 pupils who have had two months of vacation will return to their books and slates. Two new schools and an extension to a third have been completed, affording accommodation to 4,100 pupils, but there yet remain about 8,000 children in Brooklyn who will be unable to gain admission to the schools for lack of room.
SAYVILLE, L.I., Sept. 3. -- Sayville will have a gala day to-morrow. Over 2,000 volunteer firemen, from the Suffolk County villages, with their friends, will be there to contest for prizes and glory.

7'he Tax Commissioners had arranged to give a hearing yesterday In the case of Assessors P. M. Haverty and Charles E. Vendt. Major Haverty, who is a veteran of the war, is charged by the Commissioners with being physically unable to do the work. Mr. V'endt wert to Europe seyeral weeks ago, and is charged with leaving his post without first having obtained the consent of the Tax Commissioners.

Bernard Ratkowsky, manufacturer of fur garments at 58 East Broadway, who failed on Aug. 26, was held for further examination in $3,000 bail in the Tombs Police Court, yesterday, on a charge of grand larceny, and in $2,500 on a charge of fraudulent concealment of property.
Democratic local politics was very interesting yesterday.

The various parties in interest, re-enforced by the usual auction room contingent, constituted quite a promising audience for the three auctioneers who were about to offer the several properties at auction in foreclosure proceedings yesterday at the Broadway salesroom. The outsiders, too, took a hand in the bidding, but did not succeed in buying anything at the prices they offered.

A large crowd traveled to Staten Island yesterday to see the Oxford and Cambridge cricketers in the match against All New-York. Monday night the Englishmen were well ahead, but their advantage did not detract public interest in the game. Their lead was greatly increased by the morning's play, the New-Yorks being 211 runs behind when they went in to bat.

The Farmers' Loan and Trust Company deposited $2,000,000 in gold coin in the Sub-Treasury yesterday. The deposit was announced simply as a special one, the trust company merely taking a receipt therefor.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 3. -- William K. Poinier, who died in Brooklyn to-day of the injuries received in the wreck at Woodlawn, was sixty-two years old. He was a son of ex-Mayor Poinier. He spent the Summer at Belmar, and returned to this city Saturday. After eating luncheon yesterday, he told his family he wanted to go out for an airing.

A number of things have occurred within the last fortnight which must convince the people of the City of New-York that there has been a very marked and healthy change in the operations of the police force. The most conspicuous of these is the dry Sunday of this week, due practically to the surrender of the liquor sellers in face of the resolute and implacable enforcement of the excise law.

The collision which took place on Monday upon the New-York and Sea Beach Railway is equally remarkable for the terrible danger involved and the small number of persons seriously injured, and for the circumstances from which it resulted. As one death has taken place, the investigation will be made to fix a more serious responsibility than was contemplated at the time of the arrest of the engineers and firemen of the respective trains.

People talk about hard times, but it is a fact that over 200,000 residents of New-York and Brooklyn took a vacation this Summer, either in the mountains or at the sea shore. This does not include 25,000 persons who went to Europe. The tide of Summer excursion travel has turned homeward. The rush is tremendous. It began Labor Day.
The New-Yorks beat the Chicago baseball nine at the Polo Grounds yesterday. "Tot" Murphy was given a rest and German covered third base. There were about 3,000 spectators present.

HARRISBURG, Sept. 3. -- The preliminaries of the campaign Senator Quay proposes to wage against his opposition were mapped out at a conference between the Senator and other anti-combine leaders before leaving this city after the recent State Convention. The conference was held at Senator Quay's headquarters.
LENOX, Mass., Sept. 3. -- The day has been devoted to out-door sports, and this evening there are several small dinner parties.
Matricide was the accusation implied in Coroner O'Meagher's warrant which yesterday consigned Mrs. Alice L. Fleming to a cell in the Tombs.

In the dispatch from Seattle, Washington, relative to the Northern Pacific receivers, which was printed in the New-York newspapers yesterday morning, an erroneous impression was conveyed. The dispatch said that United States Judges Hanford and Gilbert had decided that the Northern Pacific receivers had been illegally appointed and that the $5,000,000 of receivers' certificates already issued were not valid.

Prof. Hermann M. Biggs, pathologist and director of the Bacteriological Laboratory of the Health Department of this city, has just returned home from a two months' sojourn abroad. His principal object in visiting Europe was to attend the sixty-third annual meeting of the British Medical Association, which was held in London during July and August.

DUBLIN, Sept. 3. -- The Parliamentary election in St. Stephen's Green Division of Dublin, which took place yesterday in consequence of the appointment of the sitting member, William Kenny, Unionist, to the office of Solicitor General for Ireland, resulted in the return of Mr. Kenny by a vote of 3,325 to 2,893 cast for Mr. Mahoney, Parnellite.

There was a total eclipse of the moon last night. It began at 9:48 and ended at 2:54 this morning. Total obscuration began at six minutes after midnight, and lasted until 1:47. At that hour the moon began to emerge from the shadow, and gradually it crawled along until the full disk shone out again in brilliant splendor.

The burglars who confessed to looting the house of Lawyer August P. Wagener, 77 East One Hundred and Seventh Street, together with three alleged receivers of the goods stolen, were taken to the Tombs Police Court yesterday. The burglars are Jacob Baum, twenty-two years old, of 2,112 Third Avenue, and John Braham, twenty years old, of 517 East Eighty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- The official comparative statement of Government receipts and expenditures for the current fiscal year to date and for the month of August was issued from the Treasury today. It shows the receipts for the two months of the current fiscal year to have been $58,022,394, against $75,226,945 for the corresponding months of the last fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- The Navy Department officials who have charge of the Government dry docks, fear that they will be put to additional trouble concerning the new timber dock in course of construction at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The firm of Walsh Brothers of New-York is completing the dock, the original contractor, James Gillies of Brooklyn, having been notified to abandon his contract.

The James G. Blaine Club of the Tenth Senatorial District met last night at its rooms, 44 Henry Street, to hear Police Commissioner Roosevelt speak on "Civil Service Reform and its Effect on the Republican Party."

DENVER, Col., Sept. 3. -- The new plan of distributing proprietary medicines was revealed to-day at the afternoon session of the wholesale druggists, when G.A. Helley of Pittsburg submitted a report from the Committee on Proprietary Goods. This included a striking report from M.N. Kline, now abroad for his health, who has been Chairman of the committee during the year, and had the Cincinnati cut-price house to fight.
Controller Fitch, yesterday returned from his vacation and issued a statement regarding Col. Waring. The statement reads:

WAVERLY, N.J., Sept. 3. -- The State fair grounds were crowded all day. The judging of the exhibits began to-day and a good portion of the work was completed by nightfall, and by Wednesday evening the entire list of awards, with a few exceptions, will have been made.

ALBANY, Sept. 3. -- State Engineer Adams pleaded the baby act to-day, and wouldn't play. He failed to attend the meeting of the State Board of Equalization this forenoon, but got around to the afternoon session, at which the table of equalized values, based on the total assessed valuation of real and personal property in New-York State in 1894 was adopted.

AUBURN, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- The Democrats in the Thirty-ninth Senatorial District, which comprises the Counties of Cayuga and Seneca, are feeling very well satisfied as they look ahead to the approaching campaign. They are going to make a hard fight, and think they have a possibility of electing a Democrat in this district.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- The gold-mining industry of British Guiana, which is so closely involved in the territorial dispute between Great Britain and Venezuela, has not yet reached the point of assured success, according to the testimony of Sir Edward O'Malley, Chief Justice of that colony, who is now in Washington. Explaining his visit here as being entirely non-political, Sir Edward said:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3. -- Judge Dallas, in the United State Circuit Court, to-day extended until the 15th inst. the time for the filing of the answer of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad and Coal and Iron Companies to the suit instituted by the Pennsylvania Company for Insurance on Lives and Granting Annuities, as trustees, for the foreclosure of the Reading's general mortgage.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- The Prohibition State Convention to-day consumed a large amount of time and transacted a small amount of business. It was a lively political love feast, interspersed with oratory galore, applause, and Silver Lake Quartet selections, and some religious exercises.

CANANDAIGUA, Sept. 3. -- Senator Raines was one of the men to whom some members of the New-York Committee of Seventy made a half promise last Winter that they would invade his district this Autumn if he were a candidate for re-election.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- The Geological Survey has compiled a very interesting statement of the mineral products of the United States covering the calendar years 1885 to 1894. The largest production of pig iron was in 1890, when it aggregated 9,202,- 703 long tons, valued at $151,200,410. The product in 1894 aggregated 6,657,388 tons, valued at $65,007,247.

The not uncommon practice of corporations going into the hands of a receiver when creditors become too clamorous for their money and threaten attachments, promises to receive a check by a decision rendered yesterday by Judge Freedman, in the Superior Court.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3. -- The sixth annual convention of the National Association of Letter Carriers was formally begun in the Bourse Building this morning. It is the first gathering in the new structure, and George A. Bartel, President of the Bourse; John T. Bailey, the Vice President, and William R. Tucker, the Secretary, made addresses of welcome to the delegates, of whom there were about 500 present.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3. -- United States Senator Quay arrived in this city this morning. He came unattended, and his principal purpose in coming east was to take an outing. He was, however, prepared for work, and he transacted some important business in regard to the operations of the Republican State Committee with neatness and dispatch.

CARDIFF, Wales, Sept. 3. -- At to-day's session of the annual Trades Union Congress President Jenkins delivered his inaugural address. He denounced the independent labor organizations amid constant interruptions. He declared that the anti-labor and anti-trades union party had been privately subsidized by the opponents of organized labor, and challenged them to produce their accounts, showing where they got their funds.

There was the usual falling off in the attendance at the Sheepshead Bay race track yesterday that always follows a holiday's racing. There was more than a suggestion of Autumn in the air when the breezes blew in stiff from the ocean. The racing was fair, without any sensational features. Favorites were beaten in all of the races except the Flight Stakes, which was won by Dorian in the cleverest possible fashion.

ALBANY, Sept. 3. -- Assemblymen Gerst of Erie and Stephenson of Washington, of the Nixon special legislative committee, investigating street and elevated railroads, began an investigation to-day into the affairs of the Albany Railway. To-morrow the Troy City Railway will have an inning. Nothing of interest developed at the session to-day, mainly due, the committee's counsel, Arthur C. Wade, says, to the absence from town of officers of the railway, who are desired as witnesses.

From cable dispatches received in New-York it is learned that another American has distinguished himself in Europe in the musical world, and that his work has been successfully produced before critical Leipsic audiences.

BINGHAMTON, Sept. 3. -- The Good Government Clubs of Broome County promise to make matters interesting this Fall. A.N. Spierre is the leader of the reformers and his chief lieutenants are E.H. Titchener, Major McKenny, and Augustus Babcock. All are prominent lawyers and business men, and from the vigorous campaign they have begun it is safe to predict that they will cut into the vote of both Democrats and Republicans.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- Secretary Herbert to-day approved the proceedings and findings of the court of inquiry which met at the Brooklyn Navy Yard to investigate certain derogatory reports concerning Col. James Forney of the United States Marine Corps, and followed this action by directing the Judge Advocate General to draw an order convening a court-martial for his trial.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3. -- The Fall meeting of the Belmont Park Association began this afternoon, and, as is usual on first days, the racing was only fairly good. The track was very dusty, and for that reason about a second slow. The weather was pleasant, and a small crowd of people was on hand to witness the sport.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 3. -- A charming event this evening was the theatrical entertainment at the Breakers, given by Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt.
