Ever since they sent out their cards, about two weeks ago, society had been discussing the affair with peculiar interest, since it was a novelty in Newport. Thomas F. Cushing had been directing rehearsals for two weeks, and the actors and actresses had attained a remarkable degree of proficiency for amateurs.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 3. -- Yachts Sailed To-day -- Steamers Corsair. J. Pierpont Morgan; Wadena, J.H. Wade, and Restless, H. Silbey. Yachts Arrived To-day -- Steamer Valiant, William K. Vanderbilt, and sloop Navahoe, Royal Phelps Carroll:

ALBION, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- The war between the rival factions of the Republican Party of Orleans County becomes more and more threatening. Since the County Convention last Saturday, when the machine men played a trick on the other faction and froze them completely out of having any voice whatever in the proceedings, the feeling has become more bitter than before.
Fifteen more excise violators pleaded guilty in the Court of Special Sessions yesterday and were fined $25 each.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- Surgeon General Wyman of the Marine Hospital Service has instituted an original investigation into the facts in regard to the arrival of the steamer Belgic at San Francisco. This is the steamer that is supposed to have brought cholera-infected Chinese and Japanese to Honolulu and then to have proceeded to San Francisco, where her steerage passengers passed the quarantine officials and were landed.

WEST NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Sept. 3. -- The attendance at the Richmond County Fair and Horse Show this morning was light, and the opportunity was taken by the managers and exhibitors to clear up after the crowd of Monday for the reception of belated exhibits and the rearrangement of the displays. Everything was in order by noon, and during the afternoon more than a thousand persons were present.

Many doctors and lawyers arrived in the city last night to attend the International Medico-Legal Congress, which will begin its sessions in the United States Court, in the Federal Building, at 10 o'clock this morning.

Mrs. Elizabeth St. John, who is well known in Masonic circles in Brooklyn as a protege of the late Robert Macoy, who was Grand Recorder of the Knights Templars of this State, was arrested near her home in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon under circumstances that seem to indicate that she is insane.

For the first time in nearly forty years, and for the second time in history, the chess championship of the world has been obtained by an American. In the interval between the triumphal tour of Europe by Morphy in 1859 and the winning of the international tournament now just over by Pillsbury, residents of this country have attained the highest places in the chess world.

Mrs. Elizabeth St. John, who is well known in Masonic circles in Brooklyn as a protege of the late Robert Macoy, who was Grand Recorder of the Knights Templars of this State, was arrested near her home in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon under circumstances that seem to indicate that she is insane.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 3. -- Several sections of the Association for the Advancement of Science finished their work to-day and adjourned. The economic section had a paper on "Growth of Great Cities."
Investigation yesterday showed that the terrible collison on the Sea Beach Railroad at Woodlawn Station Labor Day was due to the following causes:

The small trial room at Police Headquarters was crowded from 9 to 11 o'clock yesterday morning with Election Inspectors and poll clerks chosen to serve at the coming election, who were summoned for examination as to their fitness to perform the duties required of them.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 3. -- Senator Calvin S. Brice has bought the Cleveland, Akron and Columbus Railway from G.W. Saul, its President, and Holland stockholders. An offer was made by Brice some time ago, but Saul resisted it, and he controlled a majority of the stock. Brice made another offer, and after a consultation of several hours with the Board of Directors of the road. Saul accepted it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- In view of the early admission of the Territory of Utah to Statehood, the last annual report of the Utah Commission, filed with the Secretary of the Interior to-day, becomes an interesting document, especially because of its review of the political history of the Territory.
ALBANY, Sept. 3. -- If the plans which have been formed by the lawyers in this section do not fail, the nominations for Supreme Court Justice in the Third Judicial District will come to Albany.

The Reform Club's Committee on Sound Currency has issued to the other members of the club an interesting report, in which is shown the work that has been done by the committee since May 29 in advancing conclusive arguments in opposition to the free-silver agitation, and in distributing sound-currency periodicals for educational purposes.

Only three days are left now before the first race for the America's Cup, and the managers of the two yachts, the Defender and Valkyrie, are doing all they can to have them as fit and as fast as it is possible to make them.
I have read with pleasure your editorial article of Thursday relative to the canal problem, and heartily congratulate you on the advanced and impregnable position you have taken on this subject.

Mayor Strong has doubtless acquired, since he soared from dry goods into the dizziest heights of municipal politics, knowledge of and facility in many and diverse phases of human activity. He has made especially notable progress, however, in the art of delivering short speeches. When he entered upon the Mayoralty campaign, Mr. Strong suffered agonies that were obviously of the keenest sort whenever he attempted to address his constituents.
ALBANY, Sept. 3. -- The following railroad reports for the year ended June 30 last were filed with the State Railroad Commissioners to-day:

The anxious consideration which the Police Commissioners have been giving to the rumored foundation of a great secret organization in the department designed to fight the efforts of the reform Commissioners to reorganize the force has resulted in decisive action on the part of the board.

BAR HARBOR, Sept. 3. -- Mrs. Henry C. Chapman gave a luncheon to-day at the Kebo Club, which was one of the most enjoyable affairs of its kind given at the club this season. The clubhouse, especially the dining room, was decorated artistically with flowers and plants. A round centrepiece of iris flowers was banked in by maidenhair ferns and smilax.

NEWARK, Sept. 3. -- John Nolan of 50 Lister Avenue is soon to be married, and according to the ethics of the social circles in which he moves, felt obliged to give all his friends a good time in celebration of the event. He did so last night.

What is the difference between the English and American accents as applied to the educated of each nation, or is there any such thing as an accent? A newly arrived Englishman is frequently greeted -- much to his astonishment -- with the remark that he cannot be an Englishman because he has not the English accent. The converse is true of the American on the other side of the Atlantic.

The letter of the Rev. Dr. G.H. Houghton of the Little Church Around the Corner to Henry Steinert, counsel of the Health Board, was read at the board's regular weekly meeting yesterday. Dr. Houghton claims that the marriage certificates on which he was late in making returns were mislaid in the absence of his secretary.
Dryden expressed the belief of everybody in the couplet that everybody knows:

WEST NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Sept. 4.-- The fair being held on the grounds of the old Staten Island Athletic Club continues to attract good sized crowds each day. There is much interest in the exhibits, which are creditable, considering that it is the first county fair ever held on the island, and that it was planned late in the season. The track and other contests also take up interest as the fair progresses.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 4. -- The forty-fourth annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, which opened in the "City of Homes" Thursday, filled Springfield not only with an army of clever men, but a large number of clever women as well -- women who have done and are doing valuable scientific work along most of the different lines represented in the association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- The Department of Agriculture has received from its agent in Berlin copies of the quarantine and prohibition regulations at present in force in the German Empire in regard to the importation of live stock and fresh meat. These regulations affect various countries, as follows:

OXFORD, Penn., Sept 4. -- The one hundred and seventy-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Upper Octorara Presbyterian Church was celebrated to-day. The Rev. T.R. McDowell, the pastor, presided. The Rev. J.L. Withrow, D.D., pastor of the Third Presbyterian Church of Chicago, Ill., made an address on "Some of the Relations of Religion to a Vigorous Vitality."

Politics of the "machine" order was indulged in liberally last night by Chairman Edward Lauterbach of the Republican County Committee. Ten members of the committee had signed a call for a special meeting to consider the question of the place for the Republican Assembly District Convention in the new Twentieth Assembly District, and also to consider such other business in reference to the primaries and conventions as might be brought up.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 4. -- This was the last day of the meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the anthropological section being the only one in which papers were read to-day. The Society for the Promotion of Engineering Education and the American Forestry Association also finished their meetings.
-- Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of The New-York Times.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4. -- The big special between Joe Patchen and John R. Gentry caused about 4,000 persons to journey out to Belmont Park this afternoon, and they got a dose of hippodroming that is likely to last them for several years to come. They witnessed one horse doing his best during the early part of the race, and the other being driven to win in the last two heats.

The action of Tammany Hall and the State Democracy in regard to representation at the State Convention on the 24th, if it were final, would certainly be extremely unfortunate. The proposition made by the former and rejected by the latter is precisely the one embodied in the resolutions of the State Committee; as a plan to secure a united representation it is impossible to concede either its good faith or its intelligence.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- Gov. and Mrs. Levi P. Morton arrived at the United States Hotel to-night, where they were called upon by a large number of prominent visitors and residents. The Governor will to-morrow take part in and review the great floral fete parade. Both the Governor and Mrs. Morton will attend the floral ball in the evening.

The fifth annual meeting of the New-Jersey Rifle Association is going on at the State range this week, and the fact that riflemen from several States are competing, some coming from as far away as Georgia, and that even regulars from the Department of the East have reappeared in these competitions, is especially gratifying.

LONDON, Sept. 4. -- The Post will tomorrow publish a dispatch from Paris saying that a Constantinople letter is published in Paris containing what purports to be the text of a dispatch sent by Rustem Pasha, the Turkish Ambassador to Great Britain, to the Turkish Foreign Minister, giving an account of an interview the Ambassador lately had with Prime Minister Salisbury. The letter says:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- The three-class race meet of the Rochester Athletic Club at the Driving Park to-day was a pronounced success, as far as the racing went, but was far from one in attendance, barely 3,000 persons being in the stand, instead of the 11,000 expected. The professionals put up some very interesting and exciting contests, and, in fact, rode well in every event.

Two bids for preliminary borings were submitted to the East River Bridge Commission at their regular weekly meeting yesterday, and after a brief consideration that of Contractor F.W. Millen was accepted. For all preliminary work he will receive $140.
PATCHOGUE, L. I., Sept. 4. -- A large crowd attended the firemen's tournament here to-day, and much interest was manifested in the several events. The result of the races was as follows: ...

Well browned with exposure to the sun and weather, the band of British athletes who are to uphold the colors of the London Athletic Club and Cambridge University in international contests with the New-York Athletic Club and the Yale University athletes, respectively, arrived in this city on the Cunard steamer Aurania, at seven o'clock last evening.

Mrs. Henrietta Reinhard, after establishing a fine reputation as an artful dodger of court decrees and edicts, ran plump against a snag yesterday in the person of Judge Giegerich of the Court of Common Pleas.
NEW-LONDON, Conn., Sept. 4. -- Arrived -- Steamers Restless, H.H. Silbey; Narwhal, C.H. Osgood; Huntress, F.C. Fowler; sloop Gossoon, L. Vaughn Clark.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 4. -- Henry Meinhard and family, who have been summering at West End, returned to New-York to-day.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Sept. 4. -- The Prohibitionists of Warren County to-day nominated J.C. Allen, a lawyer of Hackettstown, to be County Judge, J.H. Willever for County Clerk, and Dr. McKinstry and George Carter for the Assembly.

Herman Winter, an old resident of Brooklyn, died late yesterday afternoon in his home, 165 Taylor Street. Arrangements for the funeral have not yet been made, but it is expected that the services will be held Saturday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- Eight or nine thousand men in line in the Labor Day parade directed attention anew to the fact, which is not generally known, that Washington is fast taking rank among the chief manufacturing cities of the country. The last census reports conveyed the gratifying information that there were but twenty-six cities in the United States which exceeded Washington in the value of manufactured products.

SARATOGA, Sept. 4. -- Department of Health subjects were considered to-day by the American Social Science Association. The Chairman of the department, Dr. Frederick Peterson of New-York City, gave an interesting description of the Craig colony of epileptics. The establishment has a farm of 19,000 acres and will be able to care for almost 400 epileptics.

The impression conveyed by the dispatch from Seattle last Monday night, that the United States court Judges had rendered an opinion that the appointment of the Northern Pacific receivers was illegal, and that the issue of $5,000,000 of receivers' certificates was invalid, is now completely dissipated.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- The debt statement, issued to-day, shows a net increase in the public debt, less cash in the Treasury during August, of $2,815,418.08. The interest-bearing debt increased $210. The non-interest-bearing debt decreased $295,166, and cash in the Treasury decreased $3,110,374.08.

WESTFIELD, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- The news was sent out from this section May 17 last that the grape crop of Chautauqua County had been destroyed by frost. At that time it was believed to be true. The leaves and blossoms were frozen, and in a few days they withered, crumbled, and dropped to the ground as if it was Fall instead of Spring.

From a long article over the signature of the Loyal League's only spokesman we gather that those curious persons are much better satisfied with Brooklyn's financial condition than are Brooklyn's financial officers. Brooklyn, it seems, is really much easier in her finances than most persons think, and has, in fact, an increasing Constitutional margin of credit, while New York's is decreasing.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 4. -- It has been another typical Autumnal day in Lenox, although considerably warmer than yesterday. The various cottagers are constantly having additions to their house parties, and by the time Mrs. Barclay's ball takes place, Friday evening, nearly all the country houses will have their quota of guests.

ALBANY, Sept. 4. -- The figures on which the State Board of Equalization based its valuations of counties for the purposes of taxation for 1895 show that last year the real estate in New-York State increased in value $79,903,364, and the personal property $21,484,444. The increase in real values is due entirely to the cities, for farm lands have depreciated, with but few exceptions, in all parts of the State.

FLUSHING, L.I., Sept. 4. -- Miss Bessie Barnwell of this place and Alfred M. Coats of Providence, R.I., were married in St. George's Church at noon to-day. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Endicott Peabody of Boston.

According to a circular published in several newspapers along the Missouri Pacific system of railroads, Miss Helen Miller Gould has established two scholarships in the New-York University, in memory of her father, Jay Gould.

BUFFALO, Sept. 4. -- The hotels are filled with wheelmen to-night, and everything looks bright for the great two-days' division race meet, beginning to-morrow. Throughout the day the members of the Reception Committee were kept busy welcoming the visitors and directing them to the various hotels. The new Tifft House was League headquarters, and here the arrivals were registering all day long.
William Palette, who lives with his wife and five children at 235 West Twenty-fourth Street, attempted suicide yesterday morning by cutting his throat.
BUFFALO, Sept. 4. -- Lieut. Gov. Saxton, last night, in an interview on the political outlook in the State, said:

The Democratic General Committee of Kings County, which met last evening in the Athenaeum, Atlantic Avenue and Clinton Street, Brooklyn, ratified the action of the Executive Committee taken the previous night, looking toward harmony with the other Democratic organization, and authorized the Executive Committee to appoint a committee to confer with the other organization with a view to settling upon a basis of unity in the coming campaign.

No more important gathering of those who have we made forensic medicine a lifelong study was ever held in this or any other country than the Medico-Legal Congress, which was opened in this city yesterday. In fact, it is the first Medico-Legal Congress ever held in the history of the world, and it is under the management of the New-York Medico-Legal Society, the first to be established in the world.

The men who are accused of being responsible for the wreck on the Sea Beach Railroad at Woodlawn Park Monday were arraigned before Police Justice Cowenhoven at Fort Hamilton yesterday, and held without bail on charges of homicide.

The announcement which has been cabled from Constantinople, on the alleged authority of the Turkish Ambassador in England, as an official announcement, is not couched in official or in diplomatic language. Rustem Pasha is made to report Lord Salisbury as saying that "if the Porte persists in its refusal, the powers will themselves undertake the suggested reforms," but that "If the Porte continues to resist it will be a signal for the dismemberment of Turkey."

CARDIFF, Sept. 4. -- The Trades Union Congress at to-day's session approved the report of the Parliamentary Committee, with an addendum asking that Parliament pass legislation providing for the payment of union rates of wages to all workers in the Government depots.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 4. -- United States Marshal Walker returned from Erie to-day, where he went to arrest Assistant Postmaster Evisch of Erie for violation of the civil Service laws. Marshal Walker also took into custody two men named Leivie and Bruce, candidates for civil service examination.

LIMA, Peru, via Galveston, Sept. 4. -- A motion was made in the House of Deputies, yesterday, to declare invalid all the laws passed by Congress after May 1, 1894, when Col. Borgono usurped power, after the death of Gen. Bermudez.

DUBLIN, Sept. 4. -- The campaign in South Kerry is attracting much attention in Irish political circles. A new election in the district was rendered necessary by the decision of Denis Kilbride, (Anti-Parnellite,) who was returned from South Kerry and North Galway, to represent the latter constituency in the House of Commons.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Sept. 4. -- Charles Allen, one of the Springfield (Ill) Post Office robbers, who broke out of Ludlow Street Jail, in New-York, July 4, was caught here to-day. He was arrested on a telegram from Ozark, twenty-six miles south of here, where he had swindled the Postmaster and several bankers out of small sums.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 4. -- The session of the American Forestry Association, which was held to-day in the chapel of the Church of the Unity, was important, a large amount of ground being covered. The most important item of business transacted was the passage of resolutions regarding the forests of America. Among them were these:

Two Commodores and nine Captains of the United States Navy assembled in the court-martial room in the New-York Navy Yard yesterday to sit in judgement on a brother officer, Capt. George W. Sumner, who is being tried on three charges. They relate to the injuries received by the commerce-destroyer Columbia when that vessel was recently docked at Southampton.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- The convention of the State League of Republican Clubs began this evening with a mass meeting. Among the delegates there is much discussion of the attitude the party should take on the excise question. President George E. Green, in an interview on the subject, said:

At yesterday's meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apoprtionment Mayor Strong offered a resolution which is regarded as a partial revolution of the system now employed in the Street-Cleaning Department, in that it permits the making of contracts for the final disposition of garbage and other refuse. It reads:

The first race for the America's Cup between the Defender and the Valkyrie will be sailed next Saturday. The dates for the other races will be Tuesday, the 10th; Thursday, the 12th; Saturday, the 14th, and Tuesday, the 17th. If the Defender or the Valkyrie should win the first three races no others will be sailed.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4. -- At the session of the National Association of Letter Carriers to-day a resolution was presented from the Committee on Legislation which stated that the subject of increase of salaries was of most paramount importance to the convention, and recommended to the Legislative Committee the introduction of the bill known as House of Representatives Bill No. 6685, and urged its speedy passage by Congress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- Lawrence Gardner, Secretary of the League of Democratic Clubs and Secretary of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, says that the representation of the new State of Utah in the United States Senate will be equally divided between the so-called "Gentiles" and the Mormon Church -- one of each -- no matter whether the Democrats or Republicans are successful in the ensuing State campaign.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 4. -- Cottagers had a comparatively quiet day; yet there were several beautiful entertainments upon a scale much less extensive than the balls that have been absorbing their attention of late.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Sept. 4. -- Private telegrams from Labrador state that Newfoundland fishing vessels have been seized by a Canadian cruiser for a breach of the customs regulations. Particulars cannot be obtained until the arrival of the mail steamer, which is due to-morrow. But the probable cause is that the vessels were selling salt.

GYAYAQUIL, via Galveston, Sept. 4. -- Gen. Eloy Alfaro has arrived at Quito. A splendid reception had been prepared for him, and committees and delegations of citizens that went to meet him at Pambrillo, about five miles from the city, passed in a triumphant procession with him under arches erected in his honor.

Great interest continues to be manifested in commercial and engineering circles anent the proposition made by The New-York Times that it would be wiser to build a ship canal connecting Lake Erie and the Hudson rather than expend $9,000,000 upon improving and deepening the Erie, Oswego, and Champlain Canals.
HOBART TOWN, Tasmania, Sept. 4. -- The Legislative Council has rejected the Universal Suffrage bill, which was recently passed by the Assembly.

Abingdon Square was in gala dress last night on the occasion of the last open-air concert for the season given by Rampone's Old Guard Band, and the Ninth Warders turned out in full force to do honor to the event. These concerts have been a source of great enjoyment to the residents of old Greenwich Village, and regret was generally expressed last night that they had been brought to a close.

A pinch of humanity raised a fragile hand in Fourth Avenue late yesterday afternoon and a conductor rang for the stopping of a Madison and Fourth Avenue car. A four-foot man, with a package on which suspicious eyes would be cast in a prohibition town, made frantic clutches at the grab-rail of the car, and finally fell with his bundle across the feet of the conductor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- Solicitor Reeve of the Treasury has decided that the transfer of an employe of a firm doing business abroad to the American branch of the concern is a violation of the alien contract labor law. The case originated in Houston, Texas. A cotton firm doing business in Liverpool established a branch of the same firm at Houston.

The death from poisoning by tartar emetic at 397 St. Nicholas Avenue last Friday of Mrs. Henry H. Bliss has not been clearly established as due to her daughter, Alice L. Fleming, who was cast into the Tombs on Coroner O'Meagher's warrant.

Mr. Peter F. Meyer has sold for Catharine d'Anglemont to Herbert B. Turner, at about $36,000, the two lots, 50 by 98.9, at 136 and 138 West Twenty-eighth Street. It is understood that flats will be built on the lots.

ALBANY, Sept. 4. -- Lispenard Stewart's New Prison Commission is in a dead-lock over the appointment of a person to the three-thousand-dollar Secretaryship. There was a meeting of the board to-day, all the eight members being present. The names of three candidates for Secretary were presented. They were Augustus De Peyster of Bath, Augustus Sherman of New-Baltimore, and David J. Healey of Brooklyn. Mr. Healey was dropped after the informal ballot.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 4. -- To-day has been an exceedingly quiet one in Bar Harbor. The regular Wednesday evening dinner and dance was omitted to-night, the managers of the Kebo Valley Club reserving their efforts for the grand dinner and ball to be given there Saturday night, which will wind up the season's gayety at Kebo.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 4. -- Thomas Lloyd's charity bicycle races to-day and the accompanying fair and dance gave nearly a thousand people an opportunity to aid the Home for Destitute Children, at this place. Although the bicycle races were, of course, the star attraction, the fair was exceptionally well patronized, and netted a neat sum for the home. It was held in Agricultural Hall, on the fair grounds of the Queens County Agricultural Society.

The arrest in Baltimore, on a charge of swindling, of George L. Daly and Henry Balch, the alleged Dartmouth College students, has brought to light an interesting story of a visit, the men paid to this city before starting out on a career which has finally brought them to the doors of the penitentiary.

The Greeks have gone to war, and unless there is a speedy cessation of hostilities an epidemic of insanity is threatened among the clerks of the City Court, where the combatants have pitched their tents.

Mr. Sothern began his annual engagement at the Lyceum Theatre last evening with a new play that will live long enough to be called an old play. It is not too much to say of Edward Rose's dramatization of "The Prisoner of Zenda," that it is almost as charming as the story on which it is founded.

The presence of two Chinese boys in the Primary Department of the public school in Java Street, Brooklyn, has created excitement among the other pupils in that school, and a large proportion of them have arrayed themselves in hostility to the almond-eyed youngsters. The boys are Wonk Quong Chung, thirteen years old, and Wong Shing Chung, eleven years old, who live in Franklin Street, near Kent, where their uncle, Sam Ling, has a laundry.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 5. -- The stigma of defeat which the Washington National Guard suffered yesterday in the match for the inter-State Trophy was put in the shade to-day by their splendid victory in the contest for the Hilton Prize. Not only did they win this important match, but they beat by one point the best previous score made by the Massachusetts Guardsmen in 1887, scoring 1,097 points out of a possible 1,260.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 5. -- Chairman Henry D. McNaughton, who was selected by State Chairman Hinkley and his associates of the State organization to act as Chairman of the Democratic County Committee, is fully aware of the delicate and difficult task he has on hand in his capacity of leader of two factions which have been at violent odds for the last two years.

BUFFALO, Sept. 5. -- Three Justices of the Supreme Court are to be elected this year in this -- the Eighth Judicial District. A normal plurality of 8,000 to 10,000 in the counties composing the district makes the Republican nomination equivalent to an election. Therefore, this canvass has been marked by unbecoming strife among the candidates for nominations.

A venomous tirade against Gen. Nelson A. Miles, prepared at Washington and telegraphed to The St. Louis Republic, has been published in the columns of that paper. The absurdity of its statements, however, is so glaring that its main effect is simply to disclose the real motive that inspires it. It will be put at its proper value by those of Gen. Miles's countrymen who are aware of the eminent services he has rendered.

Mrs. Virginia H. Hallett has arisen to vindicate the rights of the tenant against the tyrant owners of fashionable flathouses. She is also doing legal battle for the privileges of bicycle owners and riders.

Mrs. Kate Collins started down town from her residence, 223 Willis Avenue, yesterday afternoon. She took the Suburban "L" train to One Hundred and Twentyninth Street, and there started across the platform to take another train. She sat down on a bench. Then she told her sister, Mrs. Lottie Morrison, who was with her, that she couldn't go any further.

The source of the poison which killed Mrs. Henry H. Bliss at 397 St. Nicholas Avenue Aug. 30 and the person who obtained or bought it were not discovered yesterday, but some active work in promising lines of inquiry was done by the police.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 5. -- A large number of matches were decided in the South Orange Field Club's tennis tournament this afternoon, but it is evident that the contest cannot be finished before Saturday. Carter was beaten in straight sets before little "Hokey" Ward, who lobbed with exasperating coolness and steadiness, practically forcing the ex-Princeton man to beat himself.

HAVANA, Sept. 5. -- The railway station at Sitio Grande, in the Sagua District, was set on fire at noon yesterday by rebel bands under the leadership of Masferrer and Betancourt. The insurgents also cut the telegraph wires. There were no troops at the place.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 5. -- The Duval divorce suit was before Vice Chancellor Reed, in Chancery Chambers, in this city, to-day. Through the action Caroline M. Duval seeks legal separation from her husband, Charles M., a New-York oil broker. Mrs. Duval was on the stand this morning, and continued the telling of her story.

The spectacle of a good man wrestling with adversity is dull and lifeless compared to the spectacle of a convention of the "party of moral ideas" struggling with the Sunday question. The latter is now presented at Binghamton in the session of the Convention of Republican Leagues.

BINGHAMPTON, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- The State League of Republican Clubs to-day declared against local option, though the delegates from New-York and Kings, under the leadership of Alfred R. Conkling, made a hard fight to secure an opposite expression. The struggle was confined to the Committee on Resolutions, which was in session several hours. As soon as the committee met, Mr. Conkling offered the following:

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- James B. Parker, a sewing-machine dealer, went to the Commercial Hotel here Tuesday evening, and half an hour after going to his room was found dead. Before going to the hotel he stopped at the office of Undertaker Weaver and said:

ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- Senator David B. Hill arrived in this city from Albany last evening, the guest of John B. Stanchfield and wife. Mr. Hill will attend the Democratic convention Saturday and make a speech. He spoke at the Chemung County Fair to a large gathering of farmers and his old friends this afternoon, being followed by Secretary of Agriculture Schraub.

The Platt and anti-Platt factions of the Republican Party had an opportunity before the County Organization Committee last night to reproach each other on the score of fraudulent election enrollments, and before the evening was over there were some surprising developments.

In respect to the magnificent scenery of Colorado and Utah, words, however glowingly written or earnestly spoken, to most eager listeners, can convey exceedingly little of what the eye can see and the heart can feel. I had the pleasure of several railroad journeys amid the finest of the mountain scenery.
Miss Daisy Virginia Meade, daughter of ex-Police Justice Clarence W. Meade, and ex-State Senator Frederick Seymour Gibbs were married last evening in Trinity Chapel, in West Twenty-fifth Street.

A one-sided, uninteresting game of baseball was played at the Polo Grounds yesterday between the Clevelands and New-Yorks. There were not over 2,000 spectators present, and many of them left long before the game was over, owing to the miserable manner in which the New-Yorks played ball. Their work was really so poor in the second and third innings that the visitors scored 9 unearned runs.

With her royal masts gone, most of her topgallant and royal yards carried away, and havoc wrought in her standing and running rigging, the largest sailing vessel in the world, the four-masted bark May Flint, entered port yesterday morning.

BERLIN, Sept. 5. -- The preparations for the coming military manoeuvres at Stettin cause the highroads converging to that town to take the appearance of a state of war. The roads are filled with troops, baggage, and ammunition wagons, and long, straggling trains of vehicles of all kinds. Many farm carts have been pressed into requisition, and the villages from Angermunde to Stettin are occupied by military in large numbers, with outposts and pickets.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5. -- The bulletin of the Racing Board this week, as issued by Chairman Gideon, contains the following items of general interest to wheelmen:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5. -- In the convention of the National Association of Letter Carriers this morning the proposition that proxies should not be permitted to vote at an election of officers was defeated after a warm protest from the smaller cities.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 5. -- Nebraska Democrats who are opposed to free silver and fusion with the Populists met in State Convention this afternoon. There was little canvassing among aspirants for places on the ticket, interest among the delegates centring more in the declaration of principles to be adopted. A telegram from Secretary Carlisle, regretting that he was not able to attend or write a letter, was read.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 5. -- Newport society was quite literary to-day. Mrs. Maude Howe-Elliott had a large audience of cottagers at Channing parlors, where she spoke on "An Artist's Life in Rome." She referred to her own apartments in an old Roman palace, from which she had a charming view of the Sabine and Alban hills.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- Prof. Francis Wayland, Dean of the Yale Law School, New-Haven, Conn., as Chairman of the jurisprudence department, opened the morning session of the American Social Science Association to-day. His address referred to habitual criminals, about 3,000,000 of whom, he said, were at large in this country, outlaws who were guilty of such crimes as highway robbery, train robbery, and train wrecking.

SING SING, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- Warden Sage of Sing Sing Prison received a visit to-day from the Prison Commission, which was created to act as a General Board of Supervision and Inspection over all the State prisons. The full commission was not here. Those who were present were Lispenard Stewart of New-York, Nelson Davenport of Troy, William R. Remington of Canton, George B. Hayes of Buffalo, and Mrs. John Davenport of Bath, Steuben County.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Sept. 5. -- The mail steamer from Labrador brings full news of the seizures of Newfoundland vessels. The seizures were made by L.A. Howard, a Canadian customs officer, who possesses some sort of authority to seize all Newfoundland craft found in Canadian waters. He will not accept duties, bonds, or securities. He has a schooner, a steam launch, and twenty-five armed men.

VINELAND, N.J., Sept. 5. -- This place is almost entirely surrounded by the forest fires, and is in great danger. To-night sparks from the fires carried by the wind are falling over the place, showing white beneath the glare of the lights, and people at first thought that it was snowing. Early this afternoon the sun was obscured entirely by the smoke, and lamps were lighted in all the stores and dwellings.
President Roosevelt of the Police Board tried the cases of delinquent policemen yesterday. There were fewer complaints than usual on the calendar, many being for minor offenses.

Interesting papers were read at yesterday's sessions of the Medico-Legal Congress, but none more interesting than the one by Gustave Boehm of this city, entitled, "Suicide, Legislation, and the Insanity Plea," in which the writer took the ground that under certain conditions a man was justified in taking his life.

ALBION, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- A meeting was held here Tuesday by some of the leading Democrats and Republicans of Orleans County, mainly for the purpose of talking over a ticket proposed to be placed in the held against the straight Republican ticket nominated at the County Convention Saturday.

CARDIFF, Sept. 5. -- The attendance of delegates, as well as that of the public, at to-day's sitting of the Trades Union Congress was very meagre. The resolution favoring the payment of salaries to members of Parliament, moved by Mr. E. Cowey of the Miners' Federation, was passed unanimously. It is as follows:

WAVERLY, N.J., Sept. 5. -- This was Governor's, President's, Politicians', the big day, or State Day, as it best suited the person wishing to refer to it at the State Fair. Governor's Day has become the most used term, but there was a time when President's Day was about all that could be heard when the next to the last day of the State Fair was spoken of.

HOLLY SPRINGS, Miss., Sept. 5. -- While the Board of Supervisors were in session in the Chancery Clerk's office to-day they discovered blood streaming down the wall from the courtroom. They rushed to the Sheriff's office up stairs, and, finding the door locked, broke it down. A revolting sight greeted them. Sheriff Robert A. McWilliams had committed suicide and lay prostrate upon the floor.

The Valkyrie and the Defender are ready for to-morrow's big race. The grooming and overhauling of the two yachts was finished yesterday. The British yacht is still in the Erie Basin. She will be floated out this morning at 10 o'clock, and shortly afterward measured by John Hyslop, the New-York Yacht Club official.

NEWTOWN, L.I., Sept. 5. -- Henry Beekman was arrested this evening charged with having threatened to shoot the members of the Board of Health and with maintaining a nuisance. Beekman keeps a piggery in this village, which the board considered a detriment to health and life.

A secret meeting of the plug tobacco manufacturers was held yesterday afternoon in the parlors of the Holland House, Thirtieth Street and Fifth Avenue, lasting from 4 o'clock until after 7. Col. M.C. Wetmore of the Liggatt Meyers Company of St. Louis presided, and H.I. Drummond of the Drummond Tobacco Company, also of St. Louis, was Secretary.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- An important examination is taking place at Leavenworth, Kan., before a board of army officers who are looking into the qualifications of fifteen enlisted men who have been recommended by their regimental commanders as possibly meriting commissions as second lieutenants.

The Brooklyns had an easy time of it yesterday in their baseball match with the Pittsburgs, as they drove Hart out of the box in the first inning and pounded Moran all over the field during the next three innings. It was ladies' day at Eastern Park and the usual large crowd of the fair sex were present.
LENOX, Mass., Sept. 5. -- The mercury reached 80 in the shade this afternoon, and so it was the warmest day for about two weeks.
" Rah ! Rah ! Rah ! Who are we? We are the boys of the G.I.C. Are we in it? Yes, we are; Freeville, fresh air. Rah ! Rah ! Rah !"

In due time we were driving over the prairies, which are always magnificent, but which on this day were magnificently beautiful, literally covered as they were with the prairie roses. Think of it! Acres upon acres thickly dotted with red, pink, and white roses, and the air laden with an aroma of the fresh-blown blossoms.

LONDON, Sept. 5. -- The Most Rev. Edward White Benson, Archbishop of Canterbury, Primate of all England, and Metropolitan, has issued a pastoral letter dealing with the Pope's recent letter to the people of England.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5. -- What is believed to be an important capture was made by city detectives to-day in the arrest of Robert Ritson, and it is thought an extensive swindle of National banks has been nipped in the bud. A firm of printers here notified Chief of Detectives Miller a few days ago that a stranger had given them an order for several hundred blank drafts, which were to be finished to-day.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 28. -- American agriculturists in the orange industry will be interested to learn that the Governor of Jamaica has just issued a proclamation prohibiting the importation of orange plants, cuttings, buds, or grafts from Louisiana and Florida. The reason is that information has reached the Government that the orange groves of those States are afflicted with a parasitic disease in an epidemic form, which ultimately destroys the tree.

LONDON, Sept. 5. -- W.T. Davis of Plymouth, Mass., who sailed to-day on the Fitamer Gallia for Boston, succeeded in accomplishing a mission confided to him by the Pilgrim Society of Plymouth, which has awakened considerable interest among historically inclined Englishmen.
SARATOGA, Sept. 5. -- Gov. Morton returned to New-York City to-night.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished application blanks wad necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of The New-York Times.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- Statement of the condition of the United States Treasury and t'he receipts and expenditures of the Government on the 5th day of September, 1S95:

DENVER, Col., Sept. 5. -- The National Convention of Wholesale Druggists and Proprietors of Patent Medicines discussed the new plan of handling proprietary articles to-day in executive session. After differences of opinion had been expressed, the plan was adopted by an almost unanimous vote. The sale of these articles is to be controlled exclusively by a general sales agent, under the supervision of a Committee of Fifteen.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 5. -Mr. and Mrs. D. Jones Crain gave a reception to a number of friends at their country place, Cullenwood, last evening. The guests were entertained with progressive euchre and other games, in which handsome prizes were distributed to the winners. After the games a supper was served.

PARIS, Sept. 5. -- The man who was arrested while attempting to explode a bomb in the Rothschild bank was taken to the police station in Rue de Provence. He is about twenty-five years old. He refused to give his name, but indulged in the usual Anarchist boasts, declaring that others would succeed where he had failed.

LANCASTER, Penn., Sept. 5. -- The seventh annual meeting of the Democratic Societies of Pennsylvania to-day gave hearty indorsement to President Cleveland's Administration and declared in favor of renominating Judge McCarthy for Superior Court Judge. McCarthy was the Democratic Judge appointed by Gov. Hastings under the law requiring that the seven Judges shall not be of the same political faith. The resolutions, in so far as they relate to National affairs, are as follows:

The London Spectator, which, though a strong Unionist paper, is generally trustworthy and candid, has recently made by correspondence an interesting investigation as to the way in which "illiterates" availed themselves of the law in the last election. Unlike the system usual in this country, the English law permits practically unrestricted aid to a voter declaring himself illiterate.

LIBERTY, Mo., Sept. 5. -- Surprising developments, it is rumored here, may be looked for in the Fraker insurance case before another twenty-four hours elapse. One officer of one of the insurance companies, who is here on the case, it is said on good authority, makes the statement that the man captured in Minnesota is not the doctor.

There exists in the navy a belief that court-martials are convened to convict. At any rate they very rarely fail to achieve that end. But there are indications that the one which is now in session at the New-York Navy Yard will prove an exception to the general rule.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The long-expected and much-anticipated decision of R.B. Bowler, Controller of the Treasury, in the sugar bounty cases, was made public this afternoon. As predicted in The United Press dispatches ten days ago, the Controller refers the whole matter to the Court of Claims for adjudication.

The most striking and suggestive contribution to the proceedings of the Medico-Legal Congress has doubtless been Mr. Albert Bach's criticism of the existing laws of the State of New-York upon the commitment of alleged lunatics. These laws are in effect the same which prevail in most English-speaking countries.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 5. -- The day has been quite a lively one at the golf links at the Kebo Club, reminding one of the days in August, when society made them their favorite rendezvous.
The way to Democratic harmony in Brooklyn now looks to be clear. The two organizations will come formally, through their representatives, into a conference Monday night or Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The United States Civil Service Commission has been notified of the arrest at Erie, Penn., of William C. Ebisch, chief mailing clerk, Edward J. Liebel, substitute letter carrier, and William J. Bruce, formerly general utility clerk in the Erie office, on charges of general conspiracy. Ebisch being also charged with violating the provisions of Section 5 of the Civil Service act of July 15, 1883.

Theodore Roosevelt, President of the Board of Police Comissioners, made an address last night before a large audience in the gymnasium of the Tee-To-Tum Club at 344 East Twenty-third Street. In the audience were many women. The Rev. Dr. Henry Y. Satterlee of Calvary Episcopal Church presided, and among others present were the Rev. Father Doyle, Secretary of the Catholic Total Abstinence Union; the Rev. G.H. McGrew, and John P. Faure Commissioner of Charities.

The Times is right in taking a broad view in considering the question of cost, which really is of secondary importance. The immense magnitude of our interior trade would be expanded enormously, beyond question, were proper facilities afforded shippers. The question of the comparative cost of the transportation of freight by water and by rail long since was settled in favor of the former method.
BUFFALO, Sept. 5. -- The Platt machine, which has long been the object of attack by prominent Republicans in this city, has adopted retaliatory measures.

It is a new fad that the Aldermen of the City of New-York should have an outing. They had it yesterday. It was a remarkable affair. It served to show that the Mayor and Commonalty of the City of New-York were together.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 5. -- Receiver Payne of the Northern Pacific arrived in town yesterday, and this afternoon held a conference at the Minnesota Club with Receiver Oakes. Judge Jenkins of the Federal court arrived in town about the same time.

WEST NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Sept. 5. -This was Brewers' Day at the Staten Island Fair and Horse Show, and the display of horses and wagons made by the four great brewery companies in Richmond County was pronounced by the many expert horsemen present to exceed anything in that class ever shown in New-York, while the competitive driving of four-in-hand teams aroused enthusiasm, the judges pronouncing it the finest exhibition they had ever seen.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- By far the best tennis ever seen in this part of the country was witnessed to-day at the courts of the Buffalo Tennis Club. Carr Neel, the Western champion, and Edward P. Fischer, the erratic New-York expert, were pitted against each other. Both had had easy work in the preliminary matches, and the meeting was keenly enjoyed by the large attendance of Buffalo society folks.

Sir Roderick William Cameron of Clifton, S.I., a Knight Bachelor of England, and Morris Hirsch, attorney at law, have declared themselves mortal enemies. Or, to be more exact, Sir Roderick made the declaration, when, standing close to the lawyer, he hissed in Mr. Hirsch's ear, with sundry introductory words for emphasis:

Henry M. Anthony, commission merchant at 100 and 102 Reade Street, made an assignment yesterday to Thornley Dickson of the law firm of Steele Dickson of 40 Wall Street, giving preferences to Charles Hathaway Co. for $58,836, for money loaned, and to the Chatham National Bank for $122,626.

Edward Lauterbach, Chairman of the Republican County Committee, called at the District Attorney's office yesterday as the harbinger of a movement that promises still further to augment the good will between Mr. Platt's faction of the Republican Party in this city and Mr. Bliss's faction.

BUENOS AYRES, via Galveston, Sept. 6. -- The new agreement about the boundaries between Chile and Argentine contains, beyond the statement already published, only details of delimitation. The relations between the two countries are most cordial.

ALBANY, Sept. 6. -- John E. Milholland seems to have no greater success in a business way than in bossing a political machine. Recently, on figures furnished by the Weed-Parsons Printing Company, he secured the contract for doing the State or Legislative printing. This was not accomplished until after the courts had passed upon questions raised by the Argus Company.

DEMMING, N.C., Aug. 19. -- Experts in mineralogy have long considered some parts of the South a most inviting field. Gem dealers, especially cutters, are cognizant of the fact that many of the best gems now cut in this country come from Southern localities. Take the States of Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, and Georgia, and about every known gem has been found in one or the other of them.

Prof. Otis Ashmore, the celebrated astronomer and educator, who resides in Savannah, has just returned from an extensive tour through the West, and relates an incident of the trip which outstrips fiction.
After the reading of the papers at the congress yesterday, Albert Bach, Vice President of the Medico-Legal Society, offered the following resolution, which was passed unanimously:

The Executive Committee appointed by the convention of Good Government Clubs to organize their work for the Fall campaign, held its first meeting yesterday in Room 303 of the Mutual Life Building, 32 Nassau Street, and appointed three committees to consider suitable candidates for County Clerk, Register, and judicial positions.

BUFFALO, Sept. 6. -- The importance to the Democrats of the State of some solution of the factional troubles in New-York and Kings Counties by which all Democrats of those counties may give unqualified support to the State ticket is recognized in no part of the State more than in Erie County.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 6. -- The plan for the rehabilitation of the Savannah, Americus and Montgomery Railroad has been unanimously approved by the Reorganization Committee, and to-day was promulgated by Gen. John Gill, Chairman of the committee. The plan provides for the raising of $1,675,000, which is deemed sufficient to wipe out the indebtedness of the company, extend the road from Lyons to Savannah, and provide a considerable amount for the improvement of the property.

BUFFALO, Sept. 6. -- Good weather, increased attendance, and fine racing marked the second and final day of the State Division meet. C.S. Werrick of the Parkside Wheelmen captured the banner offered by The New-York Times to the club having the largest number of Class A winners during the tournament.

Holders of certificates of deposit of the New-York Security and Trust Company for consolidated mortgage bonds of the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company met in the office of the trust company, in Wall Street, yesterday, for the purpose of approving a plan and agreement for the reorganization of the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 5. -- The Merchants' and Manufacturers' Association of this city is the largest business organization in the South, and one of the largest and richest in the United States. It is about the only business society that is alive to the interests of the city, and the only one willing to spend money for the city's good.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- It has been practically settled that Gen. Nelson A. Miles will assume command of the army, with headquarters in Washington, on the retirement of Gen. Schofield, Sept. 23. Although there has never been any official question regarding Gen. Schofield's successor and his station, there has been in military circles, a good deal of doubt expressed regarding the disposition of general officers on his retirement.

Already some of the English papers are worrying about the disagreeable things that may be said, and possibly done, over here if the London and Cambridge athletes should be successful in their competitions with those of New-York and Yale, and especially if Lord Dunraven should recapture the America's Cup.

A committee from the Institute Street Cleaning League called at the office of The New-York Times yesterday afternoon to urge the importance of resolutions addressed to Mayor Strong relating to the pushcart nuisance which were adopted at the meeting of the league held last Saturday evening at the Hebrew Institute, 197 East Broadway.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 6. -- Because of many rumors that have prevailed about the manner of work done upon, and material used in erecting, the new City Hall, the Grand Jury decided to employ an expert to inspect the work. Robert Maynicke of New-York was employed, and his report serves as the basis of a presentment made by the Grand Jury to-day.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 6. -- The exodus of cottagers who desire to witness the yacht races is by every boat and train, and many others have gone to New-York on yachts. Practically all will return by the close of next week, when the cottage colony once more will resume its social activity.

Ex-Mayor Hugh J. Grant, as receiver of the St. Nicholas Bank, made the announcement yesterday that the depositors in that unfortunate institution will probably be paid 100 cents on the dollar within a short time.

SULLIVAN, Ind., Sept. 6. -- James Ward murdered Aaron Hunter, his father-in-law, and John Hunter, his brother-in-law, near here last night with an axe and committed suicide by shooting when he was surrounded by a posse of miners and farmers, who were determined to lynch him. The double murderer decapitated his father-in-law's head and kicked it.

It was announced yesterday that the firm of Smyth Ryan, so tong and favorably known as real estate brokers and auctioneers, would dissolve partnership on Sept. 14, and regrets were expressed by the numerous friends of both members. The parting is a thoroughly amicable one. The firm came into existence in June, 1885.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 6. -- The Cotton States Exposition is in receipt of a letter from Senator John B. Gordon, Commander in Chief of the United Confederate Veterans, intimating that he has instructed the Adjutant General to issue general orders from the headquarters of the United Confederate Veterans, announcing Blue and Gray Day at the exposition Sept. 21.

SEA GIRT, N.J. Sept. 6. -- The New-Jersey Rifle Association can feel proud over the success of its fifth annual meeting, which commenced on Monday and closes to-morrow night. Several records have been broken. To-morrow the match for the Wimbledon Cup will take place.

Of political parodies some of the best and best known are contained in the "Anti-Jacobin," a publication too frequently polluted by political personality. Though such parodies are numerous, they are generally uninteresting. They soon become flat and ale after their occasion has passed away.

Judge Charles E. Phelps has returned to Baltimore after a trip over the battlefields of Virginia, on many of which he was engaged as a Federal officer in the civil war. He was accompanied on his visit by Major N.M. Rittenhouse of Baltimore.

Light to fresh southeasterly winds are predicted by the Government weather sharps for to-day. Last night a moderate breeze from the eastward was blowing off Sandy Hook. The chances are that there will be good yachting weather to-day for the first race between the Valkyrie and the Defender for the famous America's Cup.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 6. -- Mrs. Henry A. Barclay gave a ball this evening at Bonnie Brae, which was the first large society entertainment of the Autumn season. Mrs. Barclay and Miss Barclay received their guests in the large hall, which was decorated with flowers from the Barclays's own greenhouse.

TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 6. -- Lovely weather favored the international cricket match between Canada and Cambridge and Oxford played here to-day. The Englishmen were again unfortunate in losing the toss, and Parson Terry decided to bat first. The Varsity team, which trooped out to the field at 11:30 o'clock this morning, was practically the same team which beat New-York last week, with the exception of C.E.M. Wilson, who was replaced by H.H. Marriott.
A close game of baseball was played between the Cleveland and Brooklyn Clubs at Eastern Park, Brooklyn, which resulted in favor of the home team.
In an interview yesterday on the subject of State taxes, Controller Fitch said:

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.
LOVINGSTON, Va., Sept. 6. -- Miss Irene Langhorne, a daughter of C.D. Langhorne of Richmond, and the fiancee of Charles R. Dana Gibson of New-York, met with a painful accident near here yesterday.

STETTIN, Sept. 6. -- The Emperor arrived here at 4:10 o'clock P.M. to-day to review the troops and witness the manoeuvres. A dais covered with purple and profusely decorated with flags had been erected for his use at the quay, where his Majesty landed. The dais, as well as the entire quay, was guarded by grenadiers while the Emperor inspected the troops.

What a delightfully bantering manner had Henry Kingsley; and he was possessed, too, of that particular and rare talent of buttonholing you peculiar to Thackeray. Then, besides, he could write such pure English. Pray you, read that Page 203, where Laura sits at the organ and tries to play on it and cannot, and it concludes:
BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 6. -- "Off to Lenox!" is the cry here now, and it is being taken up by a large majority of the Summer guests at this place.

BUFFALO, Sept. 6. -- Conventions were held to-day in the two Assembly districts of Niagara County to elect delegates to the State Convention and to nominate candidates for the Assembly. The combined forces of Richard Crowley and Assemblyman John H. Clark dominated the First District Convention, while the Ellsworth-Low-Merritt Platt machine controlled the convention in the Second District. This leaves the Senatorial fight is still in doubt, with the chances in favor of Col. Ellsworth.

Some of our contemporaries, who comment upon the discussion by The New-York Times of the construction of a ship canal from Lake Erie to the Hudson River, appear to regard the proposition with the same sort of doubt as to its practicability and usefulness that was expressed by the opponents of the original Erie Canal.

Alexander R. Smith, the Secretary of the Executive Canal Committee which represents various commercial associations in the State in favor of deepening the canals two feet by the expenditure of $9,000,000, was asked yesterday by a reporter for The New-York Times whether the substitution of a ship canal from Troy to Buffalo would not be a much better scheme. Mr. Smith said in reply:

JAMAICA, L.I., Sept. 6. -- Julius Carrington was drowned in the aqueduct this afternoon. He took his son, twelve years old, out fishing in a rowboat. About the middle of the afternoon, after taking off all his clothing except a pair of bathing trunks, he threw his son overboard and then watched the struggles of the boy in the water.

A romantic paragraph has recently appeared in some of the American and English newspapers to the effect that an enormous fortune of $400,000,000, the accumulated property of one James Holmes, and the largest undivided estate in the world, is about to be distributed. It is alleged that Holmes was a South Sea trader and died in 1727, leaving his enormous wealth in the coffers of the Bank of England.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- Secretary Lamont issued the following order for the transfers of troops:

Prof. Roark has written his book in a manner that will cause it to commend itself to all teachers and students, and if it were not for the seeming impossibility of getting parents of young children to realize the important functions that they have to perform, they would read it, commend it, and enable their children to profit by the good advice that it contains.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 28. -- Jamaica has always been regarded as a favorable centre whence to launch expeditions against Cuba and Haiti during their periodical revolutions. The present Haitian Consul, however, has demonstrated how vigilance may make natural facilities for filibustering of no avail.

MALDEN, Mass., Sept. 6. -- H.A. Rallou and C.H. Rowe, agents of the State Board of Agriculture, to-day found eggs of the gypsy moth in process of hatching and the young caterpillars crawling from them. These eggs were laid only a few weeks ago, and their hatching before the end of the season verifies the worst fears of entomologists, who have predicted that the gypsy moth might some time have two broods in one season.

SARATOGA, Sept. 6. -- Est Callers Delos Olivas, a hotel guest, who suddenly became insane this morning, is being cared for at Police Headquarters to-night. He registered Monday, and, though he omitted to add his address, it is believed that his home is in the City of Mexico. The Mexican, who is a well-built man of middle age and striking appearance, was stricken with the mental malady while eating his breakfast.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 6. -- The State Fair, which has been in progress since Monday at Waverly, closed this afternoon. There was but a small attendance, and, with the exception of the trotting, there was little of interest going on. The exhibits had been their best, and many of them were removed during the day. The fair has been the most successful ever held by the association. The results of the trotting this afternoon were:

A goose is not what most people term it to be, for you hear it often spoken, when you doubt a fellow's wit, "You are a goose." On the contrary, I say that the goose is one of the sharpest game birds that ever cut the air, and it must be thoroughly understood to make the goose hunt a success. The weather must also be in your favor.

There will be more excursion steamers go outside Sandy Hook to-day to see the first of the series of five great international races for the America's Cup than have ever been known to attend any previous race for this much coveted trophy.

Mrs. M.A. Wilson of Philadelphia, who is touring Europe, in writing to a friend in this city speaks of an escape which she and others had from being blown up by dynamite. "We had taken passage on board the steamer Villam, Capt. Benedette," she says, "which was to leave Fiume for Ancona. This was Aug. 18, and we were told to be on board not later than 7 the next morning.

The President of one of the largest National banks, with particularly strong gold holdings, is reported as having said yesterday afternoon: "I am perfectly willing to turn into the Treasury, if necessary, as much gold proportionate to our holdings as the other associated banks." And he added that his bank "has always done its share in helping out the Treasury, and always will."

Although more than thirty year, have elapsed since the first and second battles of Manassas, interesting articles are still found by the relic seeker. Only a few days ago visitors found shells containing powder, pieces of canteens, and whole bayonets. A young man, Laws Spencer, living on the old Logan farm.

Nothing could be more unexpected than the letter of Emilio Castelar congratulating Gen. Martinez de Campos on his recent achievements in Cuba. In the first place, it does not appear what Gen. Campos is to be congratulated upon, except upon saving his own skin from the Cuban insurgents, in spite of the imminent peril to which it has been exposed.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- The people of the Seventh Judicial District are about to be given an instructive object lesson in the way Judges are made by Thomas C. Platt. The Republican Judicial Convention is called to meet in this city to-morrow to nominate two Justices of the Supreme Court.

Sellers in yesterday's market, counting on a weak closing to bring further concessions in prices, manoeuvred in early dealings to-day for openings for attack. They lacked courage for bold assault, having been warned against it by costly experience, but they seemed to feel that the chance to profit on a downward turn was at hand, and they stood ready to avail themselves of it.

BUFFALO, Sept. 6. -- The Democrats of Erie County have been making a hard struggle during the last week to reach some agreement which shall result in united action during the approaching campaign by all factions of the party. Meetings have been held almost daily, and sometimes at the rate of two or three a day, with this end in view.

Senor Segundo Alvarez, ex-alcalde of Havana by the grace of the Spanish Grandees, manufacturer of cigars and statesman of recent incubation, has condescended to write for The North American Review, a two-page article on the Cuban situation.

The season has arrived when the Post Office officials receive packages of fruit galore. Peaches and plums and berries have been pouring in upon the employes in the New-York Post Office ever since the vanguard of Summer travelers, reaching a place where such things actually grow, and with a kindness more generous than wise, immediately determine to share their newfound treasures with their friends at home.

SARATOGA, Sept. 6. -- The Ballston Hounds will open to-morrow the hunting season by a meet at a hamlet south of this place, called Dunning Street. There will be a large attendance of Saratoga cottagers.

Miss Florence Pullman, daughter of the head of the company, is said to draw a salary of $10,000 a year for naming cars. In the performance of her duties Miss Pullman evidences a decided preference for names which sound euphoniously, and which have a soft and musical quality.

MADRID, Sept. 6. -- Count Hobkirk, the Frenchman who was on board the American steamer Allianca at the time she was fired upon by a Spanish warship off Cape Maysi, Cuba, is now in this city. In an interview to-day he said that the Allianca was so close to the coast that he could see the inhabitants clearly.

Chemist W.T. Scheele yesterday completed his analysis of the contents of the stomach of Mrs. Henry H. Bliss, who died of poisoning Friday, Aug. 30, in her apartments, 397 St. Nicholas Avenue. The chemist also examined the dregs in the pitcher into which was poured the clam chowder sent to Mrs. Bliss, as alleged, by her daughter, Mrs. Fleming, who is now in the Tombs, charged with poisoning her mother.

The Sumner court-martial was brought to an end yesterday. Naval Constructor F. T. Bowles was the only witness, and he proved to be a good one for the defense. The court listened attentively to his words, as the officer has a high reputation and his statements carry weight.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- The medical fraternity of Peekskill is busy fighting an epidemic of measles and whooping cough at Verplanck's, a settlement four miles south of Peekskill. These two diseases appeared among the children of the place, (and there are three children to every adult in the hamlet,) about three weeks ago.

A decision of interest to bicycle owners was rendered by Justice Foster. It holds proprietors of public resorts responsible for bicycles checked by them. Last Saturday evening William A. Wilkins of 41 Aldine Square rode his wheel to the pavilion at Cottage Grove Avenue and Fifteenth Street and was given a numbered check for it by an employe.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, via Galveston, Sept. 6. -- Gen. Eloy Alfaro's reception at Quito was enthusiastic. The popular expression of feeling was intensely joyful. From the balconies young women of the leading circles of society cried "Viva Alfaro! Viva el Jefe Supremo!"

RICHMOND, Mo., Sept. 6. -- The county jail was visited to-day by many old friends and acquaintances of Dr. George W. Fraker, under arrest for swindling life insurance companies. There is not the slightest doubt of his identity. He was recognized by over a dozen prominent people, whose acquaintance with him extends over a period of ten years.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6. -- The interest of the delegates to the annual convention of the National Association of Letter Carriers was centred to-day in the election of officers. A report of the trustees of the benevolent association recommending an increase of 10 to 12 cents in the assessments was adopted.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 6. -- Railroad men who have heard the story are laughing at the expense of Charles P. Clark, President of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company. Mr. Clark did not return with the other delegates to the International Convention of Railroad Men, but prolonged his stay in Europe until early in August.
The new General Committee of the German-American Reform Union adopted resolutions at its meeting last night of a character decidedly unfriendly to Mayor Strong.

Bishop Charles E. McDonnell of the Catholic Diocese of Long Island returned yesterday to Brooklyn after an absence in Europe of eight months. The Bishop arrived on the steamship Britannic of the White Star Line, and was welcomed at the dock by delegations of clergymen and laymen who had chartered the steamer Black Bird with the intention of greeting him down the bay.
-- A volume of James Sully called "Studies of Childhood," and soon to be published, comprises papers dealing with the imagination, thoughts, language, and fears of children.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- Charles F. Jewett of Candor has been arrested for arson. During the last year about a dozen buildings have been burned in Candor and Owego, the fires being all of incendiary origin. The last fire was that in J.C. Taylor's creamery, involving a loss of about $30,000, a large number of cows and valuable machinery being burned.

From the statement of the cotton crop for the year ended Sept. 1, as compiled by The Commercial and Financial Chronicle, it appears that the total this year is 9,892,766 bales, while the exports are 6,719,713 bales, and the spinners' takings are 3,007,522 bales. The stock on hand at the close of the year is 280,063 bales. The crop in 1894 was 7,527,211 bales, and in 1893, 6,717,142 bales.

Tammany's Executive Committee met yesterday afternoon to arrange for the trip to the Democratic State Convention to be held at Syracuse Sept. 24, and to receive the reports from the Bureau of Elections showing how many of the candidates for Inspectors of Election had been rejected. Out of about 2,700 candidates for selection as Inspectors on the part of Tammany, 420 were rejected because their writing was poor or for other reasons.

The Medico-Legal Congress, atfer sessions lasting three days, brought its labors to a close in the Federal Building yesterday afternoon by passing resolutions to the effect that the subject of medical jurisprudence should be recognized in the various institutions of learning as well as in the medical and law schools of this country, and that every National and State medical society and bar association should appoint a standing committee upon medical jurisprudence.

London has no diplomatic "quartier." The foreign Ministers accredited to the Court of St. James's have availed themselves of a very wide latitude in their selection of abodes, so far as such choice has rested with them. "The Turk" is furthest away from Hyde Park corner, which is the centre and pivot of the world of fashion, though M. de Soveral in Gloucester Place, Portman Square, is near enough to keep him company occasionally.

The net result of the examination of the Democratic election officers is not quite so satisfactory as had been expected. Of the 2,782 who were notified to appear, only 2,397 responded to the summons. Of these, 12 filed their declinations, 15 had their time extended, and 358 remained absent.
Sir Henry Tyler, formerly President of the Grand Trunk Railway Company, arrived here from Europe yesterday on the steamship Lucania.
Democrats in all parts of New-York State are watching eagerly the attempts to bring about harmony in the party, particularly in Kings County and New-York.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- The Seventh District Republican Judicial Convention was held in this city to-day for the purpose of nominating two candidates for the Justiceships, one to succeed Judge Bradley of Steuben, who is to retire on account of age, the other to fill a vacancy caused by an additional Justice being apportioned to the district.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- The factional fight in the Republican Party in Dutchess County has been declared a drawn battle, and both sides have declared a truce. State Committeeman Lewis H. Vall and ex-Collector Robert H. Hunter have shaken hands, and ex-Congressman John Henry Ketcham is again in the saddle.

HOTEL CHAMPLAIN, N.Y., Sept. 7. HOTEL CHAMPLAIN is the centre about which the wheels of pleasure revolve. If you enjoy yachting, boating, or fishing, there is no finer water in the world for such sport than Lake Champlain.
" I should think she would be disgusting to have around," says the visitor, lingering at the door for the "few last words" that ladies like.

The battle of Tel-el-Kebir, if it be remembered thirty years from the present day, will be remembered solely because it was a notable instance in war of all the facts which Gen. Hamley attempted to ignore, and if it be forgotten it is because it was in reality the very reverse of all he attempted to invest it with.

FLUSHING, L.I., Sept. 7. -- The drizzling rain this afternoon interfered with the pleasure of the 1,500 wheelmen who gathered at the Flushing Driving Park to witness the races of the third annual meet of the Mercury Wheel Club of this place. The rain not only made it uncomfortable for the spectators, but it made the track heavy and fast time became an impossibility.

WEST POINT, Sept. 7. -- The cadets are again in harness and studies engage all their time. Rambles on "Flirtation" have been discontinued, and the Summer girl is no longer conspicuous on the hotel piazza or the plains. Grave professors and dashing tactical officers are everywhere.

" Typhoid fever," says The Boston Herald, "begins to figure prominently in the list of prevalent diseases, as it always does at this season of the year, when people are returning to the city from the mountains and seashore. There is apparently no logical connection between these two occurrences."
RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 7. -- The weather the last week has been delightful. Moonlight lawn parties, straw rides, and boating parties have been very popular.
PLAINFIELD, Sept. 7. -- John Honeyman has returned to his home at Knoxville, Tenn., after an extended visit at the home of his sister, Mrs. Carman Parse, of Grove Street.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Sept. 7. COOL weather and the advancing season have had the effect of diminishing the throng that has filled the Summer hotels here and hereabout. People have gone in crowds since the 1st.

The police had not last night found where the poisons came from which on Friday, Aug. 30, killed Mrs. Henry H. Bliss at 397 St. Nicholas Avenue, nor had they arrested any one as an accomplice in the crime of matricide, of which Mrs. Alice Fleming, or Mary Alice Almont Livingston, is accused.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L,I., Sept. 7. -- William Buchell, conductor on the Sag Harbor express train on the Long Island Railroad, and one of the oldest employes of the company, was dismissed to-day for declining to obey the orders of Mrs. Austin Corbin, wife of %he President of the road, because they conflicted with the orders he had already received.
The General Committee of the Democratic Party in Kings County will meet in the Athenaeum, Atlantic Avenue and Clinton Street, Brooklyn, to-morrow night.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 7. -- Unless present plans miscarry sadly, this city will see the greatest celebration in its history next Summer. The centennial anniversary of the founding of Cleveland by Gen. Moses Cleaveland, one of the Directors of the Connecticut Land Company, falls on July 22, 1896.
BAY SHORE, L.I., Sept. 7. THE last ball of the season was given last night at the Prospect House, and within a week Proprietor Rogers will have said "Goodbye" to the majority of his guests.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Sheridan P. Read. United States Consul at Tien-Tsin, and Commander Francis M. Barber, Naval Attache of the United States Legation at Tokio, have been selected as members of the independent commission which this Government will send to investigate the attacks on American missions at Cheng-Tu and its vicinity in June last.

Islam divides mankind into Dar-ul-Islam and Dar-ul-Harb -- the Home of Islam, and the Home of the Enemy.
