All that is not Islam is therefore an enemy, and must be warred against till it is subdued or exterminated. But Dar-ul-Harb is subdivided into infidels, pure and simple, whose only choice is the Koran or the sword, and Kitabi, or infidels, who possess inspired Scriptures, namely, Christians, Jews, and Zoroastrians.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 7. -- The Ladies' Aid Society of Grace Presbyterian Church held a birthday party Thursday, which was greatly enjoyed.

The situation of the Plaza Hotel, on Fifth Avenue, between Fifty-eighth and Fifty-ninth Streets, overlooking the Park, is one of the most beautiful in the city. Its convenience is increased by the Fifth Avenue stages, which pass its doors, and the cross-town cars near by. The Sixth Avenue elevated road is only a block away.

The wonderful tenacity with which the name of Aaron Burr holds fast to the memories of the American people who know anything of the Colonial times and the Revolutionary war is the most astonishing fact in the history of a man of questionable habits, whose old age was embittered by the ever-present recollection of one great crime, committed in the zenith of his fame.
Notwithstanding the brilliant card that was down for decision at Sheepshead Bay yesterday, the attendance fell far below the average, the crowd being the smallest of the meeting.
Society folk are talking now about little else except yacht. A large number of well-known people came on from Newport yesterday to see the first of the races for the America''s Cup.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 7. MORE people would have been in town on Thursday if the transportation companies had anticipated the rush and equipped their roads with sufficient cars to meet the sudden demand.

There were over 3,000 people in Eastern Park yesterday when the time arrived for calling the game between the Brooklyn and Cincinnati clubs, while 500 people were hanging around on the outside of the grounds, waiting to see if there would really be a game. The game was started in the rain, and seven innings were played despite the shower.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Sept. 7. -- Pedro Rovira Estevez, a deserter from the Spanish Army in Cuba, was captured and shot here to-day.

Ex-Speaker Crisp, accompanied by his son, returned yesterday on the New-York from a short trip to Europe. Mr. Crisp looked stronger and better than when he went away six weeks ago. He said that he had been in London, Paris, Edinburgh, and Dublin, but spent his time chiefly in London.

Histon's Hampden Park, in Springfield, will be the mecca toward which the wheeling world will turn this week for the cream of the season's racing. The feast of good things should be a glorious one, for every condiment known to the premier chefs in the cycle kitchen, has been sifted into the great dish, and its odors are very appetizing.

In a snug cottage at Woodmont, enjoying the delightful ocean breezes and the free and easy life by the shore, is Senator Joseph R. Hawley, who has for many years been a conspicuous figure in National affairs. Gen. Hawley has many souvenirs of the important public events in which he has participated.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 7. AS THE season draws to a close everybody is saying that it has been one of unusual gayety. The Summer has been an exceptionally brilliant one at the popular Kebo Valley Club.

TACOMA, Washington, Sept. 7. -- Elijah Smith, recently elected President of the Oregon Improvement Company, has commenced the effort of his life since he assumed the management of the company after the four years' incumbency of W.H. Starbuck as President.

The drill of the Santa Barbara Ice Company, which is boring a well in the lower part of town, has passed through a charred log some two feet in diameter at a depth of 340 feet. A careful examination of specimens obtained indicates that the long-buried tree is an oak similar to the species growing above ground to-day.

WEST NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Sept. 7. -- Between 3,000 and 4,000 persons filled the grand stand and bleacheries during the closing track and field events at the Richmond County Fair and Horse Show this afternoon. It was "Firemen's Day," and there were competitions for engine, hose, and fire companies.

The accusations against the moral character of the monk were made in order that men might welcome the dissolution of the monasteries. But the charges were for the most part baseless. The evidence of the visitors of Henry VIII. breaks down when carefully examined. The visitors themselves were men of far from unblemished character.

LONDON, Sept. 7. -- A match at draughts for u2 a side has been played here between J. P. Reed, the American champion, and the English champion, Alfred Jordan. The match was the best of twenty games, and resulted in a victory for Reed, who scored 5 wins to 1 for his opponent. Eleven games were drawn and three were not played.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

Considering that Saturday is a half-holiday anyhow, and the overwhelming interest in the yacht race, the fact that we had quite a busy market yesterday is pretty good evidence that Wall Street in these days is rather a lively place. The market now only gets dull when it sells off, or at least ceases to advance. It was chilled considerably on Thursday.

ROCHESTSER, Sept. 7. -- On a current of water and rum "Boss" Aldridge has floated to the Republican citadel in this county and captured it. The water is in the canals, which the ex-Mayor as Superintendent of Public Works has "worked" for all they are worth. The rum is sold by saloon keepers, who, to keep in the good graces of Mr. Aldridge when he was Mayor, gave support to him politically.

During the latter part of July, all of August, and the first week of September, the "barrens" of Eastern Maine present a scene of loveliness and industry that is in striking contrast to their desolate character for the remainder of the year, for this vast tract of land is the, birthplace and home of the luscious blueberry, and the harvesting season is then at its height.

In these days of minor poets, Richard Le Gallienne has pushed his way forward far enough to attract the attention of many literary critics, who would no doubt be glad to engage in the consideration of larger lyric personages. But large poets are not at all numerous at present, and therefore minor singers are not often treated with such curtness as Mr. Swinburne recently bestowed on Mr. Eric Mackay.
The funeral of Herman Winter was held at 165 Taylor Street, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon.

MERIDEN, Conn., Sept. 7. -- Cabanne pushed Bald uncomfortably close in both of the open races at the meet of the Meriden Whee: Club, The meet is not on the National circuit, but a number of the most prominent cracks came down from Springfield. Jenney was a close third in the half, and Earl Kiser, the Dayton boy, was third in the mile.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- The Chemung County Convention of the Democratic Party was held this afternoon in the village of Horseheads. The gathering was a most harmonious one, it being voted to seat a contested delegation. E.H. Collins, Mayor of the City of Elmira, was chosen Chairman.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- The Republicans of the First Assembly District of Westchester County held their district convention this afternoon in Wiggins's Hall, for the purpose of electing delegates to the State, Senatorial, and Judiciary Conventions. The district comprises the towns of Greenburg, Mount Pleasant, East Chester, and Yonkers.

LAKE KUSHAQUA-IN-THE-ADIRONDACKS, Sept. 7. KUSHAQUA Lodge has been the scene of much merry-making the past few days. The fourscore of guests at this cozy retreat practically form one harmonious and joyous family.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 7. -- The first week of September closed with a lively day at Bar Harbor. There were several social events of importance, all of which were largely attended.

KINGSTON, Sept. 7. -- Thousands of visitors are daily leaving the Catskills, but as yet none of the large hotels has closed The season is now nearly over, and, taking it altogether, it has been unusually prosperous.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 7. ICE GLEN'S annual torchlight parade will take place next Tuesday. The paraders, in fancy costumes, will start from the Soldiers' Monument promptly at 8 P.M., and upon their return from going through the Glen, will have their usual dance around the bonfire on the village green.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Col. Timothy E. Ellsworth of Niagara Falls will undoubtedly be nominated by the Republicans for Senator from the district composed of the Counties of Niagara, Orleans, and Genesee. He proved his claims to the County of Niagara to-day by defeating the Crowley-Clark forces in the County Convention in the election of delegates to the Senatorial Convention.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Sept. 7. -- With the end of August the season at the seashore is practically over, but as the season there wanes the mountain resorts of Virginia begin to take a new lease of life and gayety. Hot Springs is getting a large quota from the rush inland, for the Fall days in the mountains are most delightful.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Sept 7. ALTHOUGH the end of the season is not far off, thousands still linger at the various houses, cottages, and camps. Many of the smaller houses are already closed, but the big and fashionable resorts will remain open until Oct. 1, or even later.

The recent agitation of the question of using electricity on steam roads has been shrewdly taken advantage of by speculators for the purpose of influencing the quotations of the copper market. Should the suggested substitution come soon and suddenly, the demand for copper would be so great as to materially affect the markets, but, on the other hand, the dark horse which exists in the storage battery cannot be left out of the reckoning.

The margin by which the Defender defeated the Valkyrie in the first race for the America's Cup yesterday is, of course, extremely gratifying, for it tends to encourage the belief that the United States is not likely soon to lose that supremacy in the sport of the ocean which is so dear to the patriotic heart.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- The American Line steamship St. Louis has been accepted by the United States Government as a vessel of the first class for ocean mail service, on the basis of the report. made by Commander Royal B. Bradford, United States Navy, and Lieut. Richard T. Mulligan, United States Navy, who witnessed her recent speed trial in British waters.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 7. -- There is too much fire under the Republican kettle in New-Jersey, and not enough under that of the Democrats. The Republican political broth is likely to boil over before convention time, which is Sept. 19. while that of the Democrats may not get hot enough by the time the State Convention meets, on Sept. 26.

It is not Sir Edwin Arnold who describes the methods employed by the Japanese prima donna so that she may become the possessor of a proper voice. It is a native scribe who tells of the entire process, and in the most guileless manner. The aspirant for vocal distinction seeks the housetop on a particularly windy day.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 7. -- It has been a very busy day in Lenox, with golf, driving, afternoor teas, and dinners this evening. The day has been clear, with a little breeze. Throngs were about the bulletin board this afternoon, and there was much enthusiasm expressed when it was learned that the Defender had won.

TAYLOR'S-ON-SCHROON LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Although the height of the season is over. September promises to be as popular a month as ever, very many of the guests staying over for this, the most beautiful season of the year in the Adirondacks. More are coming each day, attracted by the fine fishing and hunting, which promises to be even better this year than usual.

Peaches were not plentiful last week. The shipments from Delaware were unusually light, and the best grades of fruit commanded fancy prices. The demand for Bartlett pears and apples was stronger, and the prices advanced somewhat. There was also a further advance last week in the price of lemons.

ALBANY, Sept. 7. -- Gov. Morton is a believer in good roads. One of the promoters of the projected bicycle cinder path between Albany and Schenectady waited upon him on Wednesday, and had no difficulty in securing a check for the improvement.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Sept. 7. -- The green of the surrounding hills is beginning to take a golden hue that indicates another Summer will soon be history, and the pockets of the local landlords are being tinged with both green and gold in a way that tells them better than nature how abundant the season has been in its harvest.

Mr. R.C. Kerens of Missouri is not exactly a model of moral excellence, but he is a shrewd and experienced politician, a member of the Republican National Committee from his State, and a boss who has made the greatest use of his opportunities. When he was in town the other day he expressed to a reporter of The Times an ardent desire for a short campaign for the Presidential election.

HAMILTON, Ontario, Sept. 7. -- The Hamilton Cricket Club began its Fall tournament to-day to decide the tennis championship of Ontario. Neel, Wrenn, and Fischer are among the prominent players entered, and the events will run over into next week.

The action of the German-American Reform Union, at its meeting Friday night, in denouncing Mayor Strong's policy is believed to be the forerunner of an arrangement whereby the union and Tammany Hall will work together this year. Since the last election many of the most prominent German-Americans in the city -- men like Carl Schurz, Arthur Von Briesen, Jacob H. Schiff, and Gustav H. Schwab -- have resigned from the union.

Mrs. Clara McArthur of 167 East One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street, the young woman who attempted to jump from the Brooklyn Bridge ten days ago, but was prevented from doing so by the police, dropped off quietly in the darkness at 3:30 o'clock yesterday morning, and she is now in the Hudson Street Hospital, a prisoner, charged with attempted suicide.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 7. -- The estate of Milton H. Sanford, the once famous turf-man, on Washington Street, was sold at auction to-day and brought only $16,000. The purchaser was William K. Covell of Newport. The owner of the estate was Mrs. Barger, wife of Samuel F. Barger of New-York and a niece of Mr. Sanford, who left the estate to her in his will.

FIRE ISLAND, Sept. 7. THE management of the Surf Hotel is congratulating itself on the extension of the season into September. The season is ending in a blaze of glory, reminding the old-time guests of former seasons, when Fire Island was the resort of New-York State.
Sir Henry Irving and Ellen Terry were among the passengers who arrived here from Europe yesterday in the steamship New-York.
GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Sept. 7. MRS. KATE TANnatt Woods of Boston gave a very interesting lecture before the Thursday Morning Club this week on "The Early Moravian Customs in America."

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 7. NEWPORT is bereft of most of its young men, who have gone to New-York to try to get a glimpse of the cup races. For the same cause Newport Harbor, a few days ago well filled with pleasure craft, is now occupied only by some fishermen and the few yachts that are never sailed into deep water.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- The Rev. Dr. Theodore L. Cuyler of Brooklyn and the Rev. Dr. M.H. Pogson of New-York City are included in to-morrow's pulpit appointments.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Interest in Washington in the international event was at the highest pitch, and was intensified when the three evening papers appeared giving directly opposite statements as to the progress of the race.

BUENOS AYRES, via Galveston, Sept. 7. -- Advices from La Paz, Bolivia, are to the effect that the results of the labors of the Mixed Boundary Commission show an Argentina gain of 600 leagues of territory in El Gran Chaco, formerly supposed to be the property of Bolivia.

Springfield, the homestead of Gov. Frank Brown, in Carroll County, near Sykesville, has been agreed upon by the Board of Managers of the second Hospital for the Insane of the State of Maryland as the site for the new hospital, to be erected under the act of 1894, appropriating $75,000 for a site and buildings and $25,000 as a maintenance fund.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 7. ONE of the most picturesque spots on Long Island is the Wheatley Hill region, situated on the northern shore of the island.

The pioneer Volksfest society is the Cannstatter association in the province of Wurtemberg, Germany. Our local Cannstatter Verein is the Nestor of these enjoyable reunions on this side of the Atlantic. Many theories have been advanced as to the origin of these festivities, but the authentic foundation of the Volksfest is known to very few persons.

It is the highest chimney in the world, (454 feet,) and one of the loftiest masonry structures in existence. It is, independent of its size, one of the best specimens of substantial, well-made brickwork in existence.

Mr. Emil Steffens, Jr., is twenty years old and the son of a rich man. Mrs. Emil Steffens, Jr., is twenty-four, and penniless. They were married in June, and now they are saying all manner of things of each other in the divorce courts.

The first of the series of races between the Defender and the Valkyrie for the America's Cup was sailed outside of Sandy Hook yesterday in a light breeze, and an "old sea" of considerable weight. The course was from a point off Seabright, N.J., fifteen miles to windward, east by south, and return.

The student rather believes that the missionary, having his particular calling of conversion most in his mind, if he does not distort the facts, at least gives them a coloring belonging to his particular creed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Secretary Herbert is determined, if possible, to have the new battleship Indiana, which has not yet been turned over to the Government, docked in the United States instead of at Halifax N.S., as proposed by the contractors, the Cramp Shipbuilding Company of Philadelphia, and with that object in view he to-day telegraphed Charles Cramp that the new naval dry dock at Port Royal, S.C., was in condition to receive the Indiana.

In the jail of Oroville is confined Thomas Laughty, alias Locklin, who is believed to be the murderer of Arthur Meyers. On the 30th of last October, Meyers was driving a stage near Nevada City, when a lone highwayman held up the stage and demanded the box. Meyers did not obey at once, and the highwayman fired, killing him instantly.

PARIS, Aug. 10. -- I have been spending a few days with an artist friend, far away from railroad and cable wire. Far away is a figure of speech, for Bizy-Vernon is only three kilometres from Vernon the town, and this is only one hour's express ride from the St. Lazare station. Guide books may tell you where the place is.

The recent retirement of the Duke of Cambridge as Commander in Chief of the British Army and the appointment of Lord Wolseley to the newly created office of Advisory Commander in Chief brings into prominent notice an eminent soldier, of whom little has been heard in these piping times of peace during the last decade.

BOSTON, Sept. 7. -- The American Board of Foreign Missions has received the annual report of the Constantinople station of its Turkish missions. This station covers the city, with its suburbs, the vilayet of Adrianople, 130 miles northwest, in European Turkey, and the sub province of Nicomedia, in Asia Minor.

Europe has sent us all sorts of attractions -- an Irving, Salvini, a Duse, and a Fitzgerald -- but there is now in the city a dashing soubrette who is certainly unique. Her name is Miss Boney, and she made her American debut at Proctor's Pleasure Palace Monday night last. Along with her companions, Waddy and Molly, she does all sorts of wonderful things with extraordinary celerity.

As announced some time ago in this column, there will be a new competition at Creedmoor this Fall, for a prize to be presented by Adjt. Gen. McAlpin, and, as predicted, it will be open to teams of three men. The match will be officially known as the Adjutant General's Match, and will prove a valuable addition to the usual programme.

It is difficult for him to resolve his several impressions distinctly and individually out of one, big, chaotic impression that burdens his mind.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- The Republicans of Rockland County held a largely attended convention in this city to-day. Gen. Ira M. Hedges of Haverstraw was Chairman. The following delegates to the State Convention were chosen: Senator Clarence Lexow of Nyack, Assemblyman Otis H. Cutler of Suffern, John D. Norris of Haverstraw, and Alexander Rose of Stony Point.

The beginning of September, which has been accompanied by the usual rush from country resorts to the city, has brought about a little activity in real estate offices. Most of the visitors thus far are, however, persons seeking dwellings or fiats for occupancy as tenants. The demand is growing with each succeeding day, and the evidences all point to a fair renting season, with rates maintained.

That the latest issue of the "Dictionary of National Biography" is the forty-third volume of the series, and yet only finishes up the names beginning with the letter "O" and starts in with those whose initial is "P," furnishes proof enough of the exhaustive and monumental character of the work, begun by Leslie Stephen, and which Mr. Sidney Lee, the present editor, is carrying out.
LENOX, Mass., Sept. 7. LENOX'S gay season has begun in earnest. All the wanderers have returned from the seaside and mountains and are glad to get back into their country houses.

Chief Hazen of the United States Secret Service captured four counterfeiters yesterday. The most important of these was Dr. Orlando E. Bradford, a dentist, who was arrested Aug. 3, and escaped the next day from Secret Service detectives at 514 Third Avenue, at that time his office.

LONDON, Sept. 7. -- The result of the election in the South Division of Kerry was announced yesterday. It was a victory for the McCarthyites, who naturally are jubilant over the success of their candidate, Mr. Farrell. Mr. William O' Brien, who some time ago was compelled to retire from Parliament owing to his having been declared a bankrupt, took an active part in the campaign, speaking and working for Mr. Farrell.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 8. -- A flattering list of entries has been received for the great "diamond tournament" on Tuesday Wednesday, and Thursday, and, unless all signs fail, the Springfield Bicycle Club's annual meet will be the best ever held at Hampden Park. Only trim heats will be decided on Tuesday, but these are always interesting, and will no doubt attract considerable attention.

ALBANY, Sept. 8. -- This year the certificates of nominations in but twenty of the fifty Senatorial districts must by law be filed with the Secretary of State. Under the old apportionment the only counties whose Senatorial districts were entirely within their boundaries were New-York, Kings, Albany, Monroe, and Erie.

HAMILTON, Ont., Sept. 8. -- The bulletins posted by The Associated Press here yesterday afternoon informed the public that the Valkyrie was winning the big yacht race with ease, and that the Defender was far in the rear. Fortunately the three newspapers were supplied with The United Press service.

GLASGOW, Sept. 8. -- The Herald of this city will say to-morrow, in an article on the defeat of Valkyrie Ill., that the result is exceedingly disappointing, as it looks so like a repetition of the old disheartening story. It will add: "The Defender won the first race in a breeze that, on the whole, presumably suited her less than it did the challenger.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 8. -- Interest in the novel Gilchester serial handicap ten-mile road races has increased and the closeness and excitement of the races have grown with each contest. The originality of the conditions have brought about this result. The series consists of four races, the handicap and time prizes going to the makers of the largest number of points on the basis of 5 for first, 3 for second, and 1 for third.

The announcement that Secretary Herbert is in favor of making canvas the principal, if not the entire, propelling power of the new training ships proposed for the Naval Academy has naturally caused a good deal of discussion. That the advance of ship building and handling is toward the complete abolition of spars and sails is not to be denied.

The annual championship meeting of the Amateur Athletic Union that is to be held at Manhattan Field Saturday, Sept. 14, promises to eclipse any previous meeting held by the union. A thoroughly representative entry list has been received by Secretary Sullivan, and nearly all the associations of the union will send on their representative champions.

The German-American Reform Union held a social gathering yesterday in Ulmer Park. Four thousand tickets were sold by Saturday morning, and about 5,000 persons passed through the gates before the close of the day.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Sept. 8. -- Four large packing boxes and two trunks filled with articles stolen from the Prospect Hotel, at Hammel's Station, Rockaway Beach, were found in this city last night by Detective Peter Kelly, who later arrested Louis Routte, the hotel porter, on a charge of being the thief.

SANDY HOOK, N.J., Sept. 8. -- The bay has seldom held such a mangnificent fleet of pleasure craft as that which rode at anchor to-day. There were big, graceful white schooners and any number of single-stickers, all looking their very best. There were jovial parties aboard most of them, upon whom the Defender's decisive triumph had apparently acted as a tonic.

Mr. Platt had his hands full yesterday at the Oriental Hotel, at Manhattan Beach. It was his last Sunday there this season, as the hotel closes Wednesday, and several prominent Republicans sought his advice or aid in their local factional fights.
