A "dryer" Sunday then yesterday never was known in this city. From the Battery to Spuyten Duyvil, and from Grand Street Ferry to the North River the law against the Sunday sale of liquors was so strictly enforced that, with a few exceptions, the saloons may be said to have been hermetically sealed. The result was that scarcely an arrest for a serious offense was made in the entire city.

CHAMBERLAIN, S.D., Sept. 8. -- The Sioux at Rosebud Agency, under the leadership of Hollow Horn Bear, a powerful and influential chief, have warned Indian Agent Wright and his employes to vacate the agency within twenty-one days. They threaten to burn the agency buildings.

When the light-harness steppers complete their engagements at Philadelphia this week, another Grand Circuit campaign will have ended. So far as the horses are concerned, the series has been a most brilliant one. At every point, with the exception of Rochester, track records have been lowered or miles covered in exhibitions that surpassed those of former years.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment will hold a special meeting to-day to consider what shall be done to place the towns of William's Bridge and Wakefield in a condition satisfactory to the Board of Health.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 8. -- The season at the Kebo Valley Club closed last night. That there was still quite a colony of Summer visitors on the island was shown by the large crowd which turned out to enjoy the last social event of the year at the popular clubhouse.

The first day of the thirty-third annual Harvest Home Festival of the Canstatter Volks Fest Verein was enjoyed by a throng of Germans that uncomfortably filled Sulzer's Harlem River Park yesterday. Shortly after noon the crowds kept streaming into the gates, and long before the festivities began fully 10,000 persons had entered the picnic grounds.

Among our modern surnames, Toft and Croft are but fairly well represented. Burghman, or Burman, is a good, old English name, recorded in the "Hundred Rolls" ; and one such Burman, no doubt. gave his patronymic to some upland toft, which was thenceforth known among his neighbors as Burmantoft.

CORONA, L.I., Sept. 8. -- The Michael J. Sullivan Association of Long Island City came here to-day for its second annual chowder. Just before reaching Corona William Haggerty, a stonecutter, of 97 Greenpoint Avenue, Long Island City, was run over by one of the stages, and died fifteen minutes afterward.

ALBANY, Sept. 8. -- George W. Aldridge, State Superintendent of Public Works, is critically ill at his temporary residence in this city. Mr. Aldridge spent last Sunday with his family at Lake Placid, in the Adirondacks, returning to Albany early in the week.

CLIFTON, S.I., Sept. 8. -- A tally-ho coach containing about forty members of the Timothy J. Foley Association of New-York was overturned while descending the Vanderbilt Avenue Hill about 9 o'clock tonight. A boy was killed, and nearly all of the party sustained slight injuries. Nine were taken to the Staten Island Hospital.

The neutrality laws of the United States have stood on the statute books for three-quarters of a century unchanged. They grew out of the troubles which arose from time to time subsequent to the Revolution, the searching of American ships, and more especially after the close of the war of 1812, in the fitting out of privateers and buccaneering adventures which frequently threatened to disturb our foreign relations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Secretary Herbert to-day stated that the published statements that he had ordered work on vessels under construction to be expedited were entirely correct.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Sept. 8. -- Five persons were blown to instant death and three injured by an explosion of dynamite at Specht's Ferry, ten miles from this city, on the river side, at 7 o'clock this morning. The dead are:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- The Standard of to-morrow, in an editorial on The Associated Press report of the yacht race, after quoting from The Syracuse Herald The Associated Press's boastful account of its preparations to cover the race, will say:

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 7. -- Alexander Porter Morse, the well-known international lawyer of Washington, D.C., delivered an address before the Naval War College on Wednesday last, on "Some Phases of International Relations," in response to an invitation extended by the President of the college.

HORNELLSVILLE, Sept. 8. -- After fighting among themselves for a number of years and sending contesting delegations to the State Conventions, the Democrats of Steuben County have united this year, and there will be but one delegation, on which there will be representatives of both factions.

These coal-carrying vessels, or "colliers," have played a very important part in English national development. For generations they formed the nursery of British seamen, and the "Geordies" of the coal-brigs sailing out of the Tyne and Wear used to be accounted among the nimblest and boldest seamen afloat. There was not, perhaps, much "book learning" among them, and more of rule-of-thumb than of scientific navigation about the management of their vessels.

The earlier half of the eighteenth century was remarkable for its coarseness and the strange incongruities of its mixtures, for "pyes" and "olios" in which savories and sweets were blended in artless confusion, for food, in fact, but little more refined than that propounded in the Forme of Cury at the end of the fourteenth century.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- The Government exhibit at the Cotton States and International Exposition at Atlanta has been shipped, and agents are in that city actively at work setting up the cases and models. The Interior Department has sent many interesting models from its Patent Office model room, and has had them arranged so as to show the progress of invention in important lines.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- "It is not generally known, but nevertheless it is true," said Secretary Morton, "that the silver dollar advocated by the free-silver men and popularly styled 'the dollar of the daddies' was evolved on and from a gold basis.

PANAMA, via Galveston, Sept. 8. -- Lima advices give the details of Pierola's inauguration as legal President of Peru. The streets were thronged, and all classes had joyful faces and were full of enthusiasm. On the route to the palace and to Congress, and in other streets, flags and arches were displayed, and houses were decorated with garlands of flowers.

I desire to express my thanks for the broadminded and well-informed editorial you recently published on the "Deep Waterways Movement." It is the first article I have seen in a New-York paper which takes a National view of the movement, and displays a knowledge of its great importance to the future development of the West and to the commerce of this city.
A bronze memorial tablet in memory of the Rev. Daniel J. Sheehy was unveiled in St. Ambrose's Roman Catholic Church, De Kalb and Tompkins Avenues, Brooklyn, last night.

Much confusion prevails in the public mind as to the duties and rights of the citizens and residents of this country under the laws which regulate international neutrality, and there has been a tendency in certain directions to criticise the action of the Administration in connection with the present Cuban revolution.

Geregino Vegillo, twenty-three years old, a knife grinder of 201 Bleecker Street, was stabbed under the left arm and in the right shoulder in a saloon at 549 West Broadway at midnight last night, and was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital by Dr. Chandler in an ambulance. There the surgeon said that his chance for life was small.

PANAMA, via Galveston, Sept. 8. -- Official details of the murder of C.H. Simmonds at Cali, Department of Canca, Colombia, show that Col. Charles Radford of Virginia went into Mr. Simmonds's private office on the evening of Sept. 5. He found his victim alone, and, without any dispute or quarrel, with perfect calmness, committed the crime.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- All Washington to-day is laughing over the ludicrous position in which the once discreet and careful Washington Star yesterday placed itself by accepting and indorsing with ready gullibility The Associated Press faked story of the yacht race.

Dr. Forbes Winslow, the well-known alienist, of London, gave to The New-York Times recently an interview in which he expressed his views on "The Madness of Genius." He gave a categorical list of poetical and other geniuses who had died of insanity. His statements have given rise to much discussion.

In harvesting the prune crop it is important that the fruit should be thoroughly ripe before it is gathered, otherwise it will lack the rich flavor essential to a good marketable fruit. The principal varieties of prune grown in California are the Petite prune or Agen, or California prune; the Bulgarian, the Fellenberg, the Hungarian, the Robe de Sergent, the Silver prune, and the Tragedy. The California prune is by far the most common.

The origin of "croft" itself, even more than of its sister words, is "wrop in mystery." It is a very old English term, appearing in the charters or title deeds of estates as long ago as the reign of Edgar, where the phrase "at the croft's head" is quoted by Dr. Murray; but it remained long unrecognized in the literary language.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 8. -- Cardinal Gibbons talked to a large congregation to-day at the Cathedral of impressions made upon him during his recent European trip.

David Rodriguez, a switchman in the employ of the Forty-second Street Surface Railroad, who lived at 345 East Thirty-fourth Street, died yesterday from concussion of the brain. He was run over by a milk wagon Saturday morning, at Seventy-first Street and the Boulevard.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 8. -- Chief Post Office Inspector Johnson, Deputy Inspector Sutten, Postmaster Ridgley of Springfield, Ill., and Assistant United States Attorney Draffener of the Western District of Missouri held a conference at the Federal Building in this city this evening as to what disposition to make of the man under arrest at Springfield, Mo., now identified as Post Office Robber Allen, who recently escaped from the Ludlow Street Jail, in New-York.

MONMOUTH, Kan., Sept. 8. -- There were twenty-five persons hurt in the wreck of the Kansas City, Fort Scott and Memphis passenger train near Monmouth yesterday afternoon, several seriously. As the train neared the bridge over Indian Creek, one mile west of Modmouth, an axle on the rear coach broke, and when the train had reached the bridge the baggage car tipped and crashed into the side timbers of the bridge.

The Western Union Company is having considerable trouble on one of its lines in the northern part of the State. Thirty-eight new insulators had to be put in last week on a comparatively short stretch of line, and the juvenile epidemic which is presumably the cause of the mischief shows no signs of abatement.

The delegates appointed by Gov. Stone of Missouri and Gov. Holcomb of Nebraska to represent those States at the Topeka Western States Conference, Oct. 1, include the four United States Senators, all the members of Congress, and a score of the most prominent business men in the two States. Other States will be equally well represented, and the conference now promises to be the largest and most representative gathering of leading Western men ever assembled.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Sept. 9. -- More smuggling seizures were made to-day. The ramifications of the smuggling syndicate are proving to be vast. The whole city is honeycombed. Many leading citizens are involved, including several prominent supporters of the Government.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9. -- Kier Hardie, English Socialist and member of Parliament, had an exciting session with the Methodist ministers to-day. Mr. Hardie had been invited by the Chicago Methodist Episcopal preachers to speak before them. After a mildly spoken denunciation of the Church and clergy, Mr. Hardie said:

The conference that is to last through the week was begun yesterday in the Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street. The announcement that Dwight L. Moody would speak drew an audience that completely filled the church last night. Mr. Moody, however, only presided, the principal speaker being the Rev. Andrew Murray, the pastor of the largest church in Cape Colony, South Africa, and the author of a number of well known devotional works.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 9. -- The Board of Trade this evening adopted resolutions condemning the water contract about to be made with the Jersey City company, but approving the plan for getting a temporary supply from the East Jersey company.

The Executive Committee and district organizations of the Anti-Tammany-O'Brien Democracy met last night at their headquarter, 144 West Forty-second Street, adopted a declaration of principles, made arrangements for campaign conventions and work, and roundly abused Tammany Hall, Mayor Strong, and certain officers of the municipal administration.
Three burglars a plucky little tailor, Charles Scheele by name, and an auger belonging to the burglars' kit, figured in an early morning drama yesterday, at 136 Essex Street.

At a special meeting of the Stewards of The Jockey Club, held yesterday afternoon, Messrs. August Belmont, J.O. Donner, G. Lee Knapp, James R. Keene, W.P. Thompson, and F.K. Sturgis being present, the following resolutions were adopted:

The attempts made in the New-England States and in this State during the last three or four years to prevent the sale of milk taken from consumptive cows have excited much interest in certain parts of the West, and now we see the sanitary authorities of several Western States and cities striving to protect consumers of dairy products by stamping out the disease in their local dairy herds.

New-York's aggregation of ball players put another victory to their credit yesterday at the Polo Grounds, to the great delight of the cranks who had assembled to see the game. It was by no means a phenomenal exhibition of ball playing on either side, but the home nine played a much steadier game than did the Cincinnatis, who were pitted against them.

The second day of the Canstatter Volksfest attracted large crowds to Sulzer's Harlem River Park yesterday. The promised novelties in abundance were presented, and the visitors were kept busy from noon until midnight taking in the sights and witnessing the laughable amusements carried on continually.

Henry L. Carville of Houlton, candidate for Governor of the proposed Anti-Dog License Party, has been in town this week and has been putting in the time campaigning for his new party. Friday evening he held forth at the office of Ludden Ludden, the Auburn attorneys, where he met a number of lawyers and prominent citizens.
Below will be found a series of brief interviews with advertising agents in this city which point toward an era of business prosperity greater than any which this country has enjoyed for many years.
The way is entirely cleared, at last, for Democratic harmony in Brooklyn.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 9. -- J.F. Taintor of New-York said to The United Press reporter last night: "I don't know of any movement to attempt a consolidation of the street railway systems of Denver. I am here to attend the foreclosure sale of the Denver City Cable Companay next Tuesday. I represent the bondholders, who have $3,500,000 invested in the property.

Among the pessengers on the steamship Fulda, which arrived at her dock in Hoboken at 3 P.M. yesterday, was Mr. J. Arthur Brand, who has come to New-York to race for the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club's new international challenge cup for small yachts. On the forward deck of the Fulda was Mr. Brand's new racing half-rater Spruce IV., which will meet Mr. Cornelius J. Field's Ethelwynn on Oyster Bay within the next fortnight.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 9. -- Ex-Congressman William D. Bynum has finished his sound-money campaigning in Indiana, which he made under the auspices of the sound-money branch of the Reform Club of New-York. During the last three months Mr. Bynum has made fifty speeches in the State.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- The Department of State has received a report from Consul General McIvor, stationed at Kanagawa, Japan, on the foreign trade of that country for the year 1894.

Patrick H. Flynn, President of the Nassau Electric Railroad Company of Brooklyn, intends to sue Park Commissioner Squier to prevent him purchasing land adjoining Cypress Hills Cemetery, for a new park.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 9. -- Twenty years ago the people of Connecticut had discovered their shore but had scarcely begun to use it. There were a few isolated Summer hotels at points on the coast, and to these came a few of the well-to-do residents of the cities and inland villages in the hot months.
Commissioner Waring of the Street Cleaning Department gave out the following address to the public yesterday:

Sensational stories were printed in several of the afternoon papers yesterday to the effect that Mrs. Fleming, who is a prisoner in the Tombs, suspected of having administered poison to her mother, Mrs. M. Evelina Bliss, was breaking down. It was further asserted that Mrs. Fleming had fainting spells, and was unable to leave her cot, and that it had been deemed necessary to have the prison physician attend to her.

The Americus Athletic Association of West Hoboken, an organization of volunteer firemen, banded together to save the lives and property of residents on "the Hill," has added cricket to its other outdoor sports and pastimes, of which football is the chief one. They played the Hoboken Club yesterday and suffered defeat by 87 runs.

A Summer of naval manoeuvres in which there are no "Red" fleets contending With "Blue," no supposed enemy called Achill, and not even a simulated battle or a pursuit, is a novel experience of late years to England. Doubtless it was because there was a total absence of strategical problems to be solved, and of any supposed hostilities, that the Admiralty gave to this year's evolutions the title of "tactical exercises."
BERLIN, Sept. 9. -- The Kaiser has issued a rescript, which is published in the official Reichsanzeiger, expressing his thanks for the loyal greetings he met with during the Sedan Day celebration.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- Francis Hendricks is magnanimous and astute. By a clever play in the Republican County Convention to-day he satisfied his own faction, conciliated the Beldenites, and paved the way to a nearer approach to harmony in his party than has been reached in many years past.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

" I don't think you could go into any part of the city now," says Gen. Emmons Clark, Secretary of the Health Department of New-York, "and find meat of any kind exposed outside, or at the open doors or windows of the markets."

CALUMET, Mich., Sept. 9. -- Ten miners went down the southernmost shaft of the Osceola mine this morning. The men were especially selected from among the fearless and experienced workmen, habituated to breathing powder, smoke, and foul air.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- Mr. and Mrs. J.R. McKee have rented for three months the William H. McCall cottage, on Circular Street, and it is understood that ex-President Harrison will be their guest. They will take possession Sept. 15.

MEDINA, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- The key to the situation of the Thirty-first District Republican Senatorial Convention will be carried to Albion to-morrow by Judge North of Genesee County. So far as appears on the surface, there are only two candidates to-night -- Elsworth of Lockport, who controls Niagara County's seven delegates, and ex-Senator Pitts of this place, controlling Orleans County's seven votes.
Alcoholic liquors can no more be sold on Sunday in a club than in a licensed saloon, according to a decision made yesterday afternoon by the Board of Police Commissioners.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 9. -- Newport continues very quiet, because all the men are in New-York, and the cottage colony is composed almost solely of women.

HAMMONTON, N.J., Sept. 9. -- Samuel L. Lukers, a brakeman on the South Jersey Railroad, was killed at Folsom, two miles from this place, on Friday night. Until this afternoon it was understood here that he was killed while coupling cars. The train crew to-day, when they were here, told a different story, and it is being investigated by the authorities.
At least 250,000 girls and boys began their year's work yesterday in the public schools of the city, under the guidance of about 4,000 teachers.

A great deal of comment has been indulged in by the press throughout the State in regard to the recent building of a fleet of boats capable of navigating Lake Erie as well as the Erie Canal, a new departure in building. The credit is given to The Globe Iron Works of Cleveland, Ohio, and the Johnson Steel Company of Loraine, Ohio, as being the originators of the scheme.

ALBANY, Sept. 9. -- The affairs of the National Wall Paper Company received attention at the hands of Deputy Attorney General Gilbert D. Hasbrouck this afternoon, on application for its dissolution. The company represents a combination of thirty-eight wall paper manufactories throughout the United States, which was formed in July, 1892, with a capital of $30,000,000 common stock, and $8,000,000 debentures.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9. -- The Inter Ocean, in attempting to explain the ridiculous reports sent out on Saturday by The Chicago Associated Press on the yacht race, puts all the blame on the Postal Telegraph Company. It says:

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Hall, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Clinton and Montague Streets, and who lives at 157 Montague Street, Brooklyn, adjoining the church, is seriously ill.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 9. -- The political situation in Mississippi is peculiar. There are two State tickets in the field -- Democratic and Populist. The platform of each of these parties favors the free and unlimited coinage of silver at the ratio of 16 to 1, without international agreement. The financial plank of the Democratic platform is a literal copy of the Pertle Spring (Mo.) deliverance.

Votaries of upland and big game shooting, anglers and fishermen, all who uphold bicycling, and outdoor recreations, naturalists, canoeists, campers, ethnologists, and the general public who appreciate wholesome novelty in rational amusement, will learn with satisfaction that the holding of a Sportsmen's Exposition at the Madison Square Garden next year is more than a probability.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 9. -- Judge Van Syckel of the Supreme Court has filed the Court's opinion in the case testing the constitutionality of the Voorhees elective judiciary act, and he pronounces the law unconstitutional. The syllabus of the opinion is as follows:

HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- Word has been received here of the brutal murder of James B. De Groff, a resident of the town of Hillsdale, who lived about three miles from Hillsdale Village. De Groff, who was seventy-four years old, was found dead by the roadside, by his wife, with his head crushed, and an iron bar, covered with blood, lying by his side.

The weird, sweet, annual mystery of the night-migrating birds has begun. Last night, sitting in a canoe on the lake, the listener heard for a long time the soft, aerial twitterings and calls which mean to the birds, bound on their long journey, perhaps from Canada to Florida, what "keeping hold of hands" means to human beings.

The Roman Catholic Church in the Northwest accepted, a few days ago, the gift from James J. Hill, the President of the Great Northern Railway, of the Seminary of St. Paul, the completed buildings representing an expenditure of $500,000, while the deed of gift assures to the institution an indefinite extension of liberal assistance.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- The Alhambra, in which the Democratic State Convention is to be held, has been the scene of many stirring political gatherings, and of not a few important conventions. It will be a long time before the memory of that remarkable gathering of May 30, 1892 -- the "dandelion convention" -- fades away.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 9. -- Several large dinner parties and a grand hop were given to-day. Society, and especially the young people, turned out in full force tonight to attend the last Monday evening hop of the season. A supper was served to the dancers about 11 o'clock.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- A battle royal between the Platt and the anti-Platt forces in the convention to choose the Republican candidate for State Senator from the Twenty-seventh District is expected when the delegates convene in this city at 1 P.M. to-morrow.

A long-promised, often-deferred play by Augustus Thomas, who is still the foremost American dramatist, in spite of some recent failures, in the minds of many good judges, and who certainly stands next to Bronson Howard among our playmakers, was produced at the Standard Theatre last night. The play is called "The Capitol," and is in four acts.

Light to fresh southerly breezes are predicted for to-day off Sandy Hook by the Government forecaster. It is said that it may be hazy, but there are no storms in sight, and nothing to indicate any disturbance.
ELMIRA, Sept. 9. -- The fight which Jacob Sloat Fassett is making against the Platt forces in Chemung County surpasses anything that has been seen in the way of politics here in recent years.

An interesting case, illustrating a new source of danger from electric wires, was recently brought to the notice of the Boston Board of Fire Underwriters by the accidental sounding of an automatic fire alarm in one of the Washington Street buildings.
LONDON, Sept. 9. -- The Daily News will to-morrow publish a dispatch from Kars, stating that fresh outrages have been perpetrated in the Erzinzian district.

The Police Board held an executive session yesterday after the regular meeting. It was learned that Col. Grant, as Chairman of the Committee on Repairs and Supplies, had told Spellman, the hatter, to go ahead and make the Winter helmets for the force. Spellman had the contract for years, and it was only last Spring that Knox the hatter succeeded in getting his samples before the Commissioners, and had the contract awarded to him.
Congressman Lemuel E. Quigg sent his resignation to Gov. Morton last night as member of the House of Representatives from the Fourteenth Congressional District of this city.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 9. -- A number of men who bet on the strength of Western Associated Press bulletins Saturday, feel very sore against The Post Express, and say they will hereafter place no dependence on the paper. One man, who claims to have lost $100, said this morning: "I think something ought to be done to wipe that association out of existence.

The Republicans will hold their primaries to-night for the election of delegates to the Assembly district conventions, which will be held on Thursday night, and which will elect delegates to State, county, and all other conventions.

The cotton crop of 1894-5 in this country was the largest ever produced on earth. Statistics gathered and published some days since by Secretary Hester of the New-Orleans Cotton Exchange show that the total crop of the United States was 9,901,251 bales, and was therefore 865,862 bales larger than the crop of 1891-2, which was 9,035,379 bales, the largest ever marketed prior to that of the last year.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9. -- Sydney R. Ellis's romantic, picturesque drama, "Bonnie Scotland," was given its first production at the Chestnut Street Theatre to-night. The play is in four acts and seven scenes, all of which were elaborately presented. The scenes and all the characters are Scottish, and the story is one of Scottish life.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- The result of to-night's caucuses in Erie County will be a solid anti-Platt delegation to the State Convention. The organization which is opposed to Platt won easily in the eight Assembly Districts and not a Platt man will be elected as a delegate to the convention to-morrow.

In our Washington dispatches of yesterday occurred the following statement: "It seems probable that a bond issue will be required when the season of gold exports sets in, unless the currency laws shall have been changed in the meantime so as to provide for the retirement of the greenbacks or for some control over their constant reissue by the Secretary of the Treasury.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 9. -- The defense in the suit brought by Mrs. Celine Duval against her husband, Charles L. Duval, a New-York broker, held forth before Vice Chancellor Reed, who is hearing the case in this city to-day. This was the fourth day the case has engrossed the Court, to the exclusion of other business.

The trouble with any scheme less than a ship canal is that it leaves the Buffalo elevator monopoly master of the situation. The transfer of grain from the lake vessels to the canalboats has been and will continue to be the great drawback to the profitable operation of the canals, until a ship canal solves the problem.

A collision took place on the East River early yesterday between a small sailboat and Transfer Boat No. 3 of the New-York, New-Haven Hartford Railroad. A Mrs. Marsh of 131 Thirty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, was drowned. Her husband, and child, and a man whose name the police do not know, were saved by the deck hands on the transfer boat, and landed in Jersey City.

The work of sorting and examining the big batch of old indictments found last week in the brownstone Court House attic was continued yesterday in the District Attorney's office. The indictments, of which there are over 2,000, have all been listed, and District Attorney Fellows yesterday gave out the names contained in the indictments and the crimes for which they were found.

The roof gardens are closed. Their lanterns had lights of burning gold and aurora, their tall, exotic plants were neat and polished like the morning faces of schoolgirls, and you were among them -- lithe towers, swelled cupolas, and acute steeples made fantastic designs in the dark blue air -- as in a city of palaces wherein were given royal festivals.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 9. -- The thirteen Cambridge athletes who are to meet the Yale team in New-York on Oct. 5 are practicing two hours every afternoon at the Yale Field in this city. A few of the Englishmen indulge in brief practice each forenoon at the field.

A more contented, well-satisfied appearing set of athletes than the seven members of the London Athletic Club, as they sat out on the veranda of the Berkeley Oval clubhouse after lunch yesterday, could not well be found. Every man of them is the picture of health and vigor, and they made a very picturesque appearance yesterday, attired in white trousers, flannel coats, soft hats, sweaters, and other articles of neglige apparel.

Caithness, (Gaelic "Gollabh,") Catteynes, the Land of the Stranger, and Suderland, the South Land, are steeped in strange superstitions, some traceable to Norse, others to Celtic, influence. The lone, windswept home of the Clan of the Carts, with its miles of moorland and peat fields, its bold, rocky coast, this county, with Sutherland, and the groups of islands to the north, are in a peculiar sense the home of folk-lore, legend, myth, and peasant wisdom.

Our London correspondent has told our readers of the swarms of Americans in Europe who hold return tickets by the various lines, but who neglected to secure in time their accommodations for the westward passage, desiring, naturally, to prolong their travels to the last possible day.

There is every indication that in the near future there will be a consolidation of all the gas companies in Brooklyn with the view of controlling the gas supply in that city. As a preliminary step in this direction there was filed in the office of the Secretary of State in Albany yesterday the certificate of incorporation of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, to supply gas and electricity for private purposes, capitalized at $15,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- The President has granted pardons in the following cases:

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Sept. 9. -- Reform -- that is, Long Island City's kind of "reform" -- has almost emptied Long Island City's Treasury. Several of the department funds have become exhausted through the alleged extravagance of the City Government, and a number of city officers, including the members of the Board of Aldermen, the firemen, and the police, may have to go without their salaries for the remainder of this year.

Representative Morse of Massachusetts appears to be about the only vehement or even audible opponent of the policy adopted by Secretary of Agriculture Morton, by which the annual mailing of 400 tons of seeds, at a cost of $168,000 to the Government, and with no real benefit to anybody except a few dealers in seeds, has been abandoned.

The withdrawals of gold from the Sub-Treasury yesterday for export to Europe amounted to $1,200,000, of which W.H. Crossman Bro. took $1,000,000, Oelrichs Co., $100,000, and Nesslage Fuller $100,000. The gold reserve was reported yesterday morning before the withdrawals at $98,910,772, leaving the balance at the close of business yesterday at $97,710,772.
A queer release, in the shape of a letter, was put in as evidence yesterday in the suit of Cable against Smith, in the Supreme Court.
The United Hebrew Charities received $10,702.66 last month, and the disbursements were $7,513.12, divided as follows:
Sir Roderick W. Cameron was examined yesterday as a witness in supplementary proceedings begun in the City Court against his son, Duncan E. Cameron.

NIAGARA FALLS, Sept. 10. -- The eighty-second annual Grand Conclave of the Grand Commandery Knights Templars of the State of New-York opened here this morning, when a large number of commanderies arrived. The city is gayly decorated with flags and bunting, and there are bands of music everywhere.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- The following applications for pardons, acted upon by the President, have been received at the White House:

Mrs. Alice Mary Fleming, after being practically exonerated by a Coroner's jury of any participation in the alleged poisoning of her mother, Mrs. Evalina Mathilda Bliss, was yesterday rearrested upon a bench warrant issued by Judge Fitzgerald, sitting in Part I., General Sessions, upon an affidavit made and presented by Assistant District Attorney McIntyre.
A spare, nervous-looking man, arrayed in a rusty suit of black and carrying a small valise in his hand, went into one of the leading hotels the other day and addressed himself to the clerk:

ALBANY, Sept. 10. -- Albany and Rensselaer County politics is bady mixed. In Rensselaer, as in Albany, the indications point to three tickets for county officers. These will be made up of regular Democratic and Republican nominees and independent candidates nominated by petition. If Mayor Wilson is not taken up by the Albany City Republican Convention for renomination, he can file a certificate as a candidate of the Honest Elections Party.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 10. -- The September term of the Hudson County courts began yesterday. Judge Lippincott's charge was brief, but in some respects pointed. The frequent leaks that occurred during the last term, that made Grand Jury matters public property, before they became known to the Court, caused Judge Lippincott to "recommended the jurors to observe closely the oath they had taken as to the secrecy of their work."

BUFFALO, Sept. 10. -- Theodore Roosevelt addressed the Liberal Club to-night. Among those present were Father Sylvester Malone of Brooklyn, Prof. Lounsbury of Yale, the Rev. Mr. Appleberry of Boston, Col. McGruder, United States Army, and Carroll D. Wright, United States Commissioner of Labor.

LYONS, Sept. 10. -- The Republican convention of the Forty-second District, which includes the counties of Wayne and Ontario, to-day nominated John Raines for Senator by a unanimous vote. The orders of the Republican machine were obeyed to the letter. The lack of opposition to the renomination of the Senator, taken in connection with the recent fight made by Hamlin and his friends, indicates how complete is the control of the machine.

The final match in the Central Park handicap contest in mixed doubles was played on the lower courts in the Park yesterday afternoon. Heywood and Miss Hart had to concede good odds to Moore and Miss Howard, and the result was a remarkably pretty fight, the odds receivers winning by only four points.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 10. -- The day has been a very quiet one, and the season practically may be said to be ended. Nearly all the hotel guests have departed, and the cottagers who remain have settled down to take a much-needed rest after one of the gayest seasons Bar Harbor ever has experienced.

J. Sloat Fassett in his fight against Platt in Chemung County is hampered, somewhat as Coggeshall was hampered in Oneida, by the selfish personal element in the contest. Fassett has by no means the unsavory record of Coggeshall, but he employed what are known as "machine methods" and was subservient to the bossism of Platt so long as it served his own ends.

The failure of Mayor Schieren to accept an invitation of the Bushwick Democratic Club of Brooklyn to meet its members in a social way after his review of the Sedan Day parade, Monday, Sept. 2, has resulted in the resignations of two prominent members from that club, and the threatened resignations of several leaders in the Arion Society.

Mr. A.T. Hartwell has sold, at about $45,000 each, the three five-story brick apartment houses 28 to 32 West Sixty-fourth Street, south side, beginning 225 feet west of Central Park West, each 25 by 100.5.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Sept. 10. -- Ohio Republicans formally opened their State campaign here to-day in the home town of Gen. Bushnell, the candidate for Governor. The weather was propitious though hot, and fully 10,000 Republicans from other Ohio counties came in during the forenoon. The early morning demonstrations of to-day were on the arrival of ex-Gov. Foraker from Cincinnati and of Senator Sherman, who came over from Columbus on a special train with Gov. McKinley.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 10. -- Thursday will see the wind-up of the great tournament at Hampden Park, and, if the weather holds good, the last day's programme will be the best of the meet. In the three classes will be seen many in the following list, all having been duly entered:

The members of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, which is the leader in the movement to consolidate the gas interests of Brooklyn, had a conference yesterday afternoon, but there was no practical result.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- The story of Platt's manipulation to secure the delegates in the Twenty-seventh District Senatorial contest from Montgomery County in spite of the Arkells and their friends, which The New-York Times published this morning, created a profound sensation. Outside of the delegates present there were four or five hundred politicians from all parts of the district fluttering about the convention hall and the revelations made by The Times astounded them all.

The fleet of canalboats, whose advent into this port Aug. 29 caused widespread comment and interest in shipping circles and among persons concerned in commerce generally, after a twelve days' sojourn in the harbor, began their return trip yesterday. They left the docks of the American Sugar Refinery, in Williamsburg, about twilight, loaded to their full capacity with sugar consigned to Cleveland, Ohio.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- The opening session of the thirteenth annual convention of the New-York State Wine, Beer, and Liquor Dealers' Association was held in this city to-day. The attendance was very large, delegates being present from different parts of the State.

Mrs. Marshall of Kent Street, Brooklyn, returned last Saturday to her home from Ocean Grove, N.J., where she had spent the Summer. Her trunks followed her and a good part of Monday was spent in opening the trunks and storing their contents away.

It seems likely that the British Government has made a costly mistake, and something worse, in reversing the avowed intention of its predecessor and in deciding to keep possession of Chitral. The march upon Chitral was worth making, one is inclined to say, as a gallant and inspiring feat of arms, even though the relief of the beleaguered Britons had not been an act of duty on the part of the nation.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept 10. -- The Republicans of the Third Assembly District of Queens County, which comprises the towns of Hempstead, Oyster Bay, and North Hempstead, to-day elected the following delegates:

Though Requital, Ben Brush, and Crescendo, the crack two-year-olds of the year, representing the East, West, and the Pacific slope, were to meet in the Flatbush Stakes at Sheepshead Bay yesterday, they failed to prove a drawing card against the international yacht contest, the attendance being the smallest of the meeting.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 10. -- William R. Palmer, traveling manager of A.M. Palmer's "Trilby" company, committed suicide early this morning in his room in the Southern Hotel by shooting himself through the head. Mr. Palmer was a brother of A.M. Palmer, and has managed the "Trilby" company ever since it started on the road. He reached St. Louis a week ago last Monday.

One of the most notable news victories scored in recent years was won by The United Press Saturday in giving to the reading public the earliest and only authentic account of the Defender's great triumph over the English racer Valkyrie III.

Bernard J. York, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the General Committee of the Democratic Party of Kings County -- the regular organization -- yesterday announced the names of the conference committee, the appointment of which was authorized by the Executive Committee last Friday night.

We publish in another column the substance of a letter sent by Senator Roger Q. Mills of Texas to the Chairman of the Democratic Committee of that State. It is an extremely important, interesting, and timely document. Senator Mills has been heretofore classed in a general way with the friends of silver, although his position in regard to the currency has been by no means so extreme as that of some other Southern leaders.

James Donohue, twenty-eight years old of 344 West Seventeenth Street, was shot in the left side at Twenty-third Street and Ninth Avenue yesterday morning by Patrick Coyle of 337 West Seventeenth Street during a quarrel. Donohue will probably die. The police of the West Twentieth Street Station have arrested Coyle and two men who, they say, were witness to the shooting.

The new building of Fire Patrol No. 3 of the New-York Board of Fire Underwriters, at 240 West Thirtieth Street, was opened for inspection yesterday, and will to-morrow be opened for service. The building is four stories in height, of Flemish architecture, the first floor being of Indiana limestone and the upper floors of light brick.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 10. -- The eighth Constitutional Convention of South Carolint met here to-day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- The waning cause of free silver has received another blow which is certain to hasten its utter collapse. Senator Mills of Texas, who until recently was classed among the supporters of the free-coinage doctrine, has become convinced, after patient study, that this doctrine, if put into operation, would result in untold harin to the country.

SARATOGA, Sept. 10. -- The 920 members of the International Association of Ticket Agents, after passing the day at Lake George, returned here this evening for supper. The party, filling four trains of sleeping coaches, left for Boston to-night. They will remain in Boston two days. As guests of the Boston and Maine Road they will visit Bar Harbor, after which they will depart for their respective homes.

The fact that the Valkyrie yesterday crossed the finish line ahead of the Defender by 47 seconds, corrected time, may be historically interesting, but it has little bearing on the questions which must be decided in order that yacht designing may make progress. It is true that it was the second time in the history of the America's Cup that an English yacht crossed the finish line ahead of the native defender.

The bulletins of the race between the Defender and the Valkyrie III, posted in this city on Saturday by The Morning News and The Every Evening respectively were as different as it was possible to make them. The Morning News, which is served by The United Press, posted but few bulletins, yet they were accurate.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- Another bright day favored the tennis players here to-day, and the big open tournament of the Sleepy Hollow Tennis Club was continued under most favorable circumstances. All of the club courts were kept in constant use throughout the day, and a great many matches were finished before darkness stopped play.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 10. -- The largest and best-conducted race meet of the year began here at Hampden Park this afternoon under auspices which foreshadow a flattering success. The racing will continue to-morrow and Thursday, and the very pick of America's speed cyclists will participate.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 10. -- Mrs. Pietzel and her daughter Dessa, the only child who escaped H.H. Holmes, went before Coroner Castor this morning. Mrs. Pietzel, while looking upon the trinkets found in the chimney of the Irvington house where Howard Pietzel's charred remains were found, went into hysterics, and sobbed almost continuously during her testimony.
For the first time in several years a resolution was passed over the Mayor's veto yesterday by the Board of Aldermen.

It was a sorry spectacle, indeed, that the self-styled Associated Press made of itself in reporting the international yacht race on Saturday. After having vaunted and boasted of its superior facilities for news-gathering and news-spreading, it dished up to its representatives all over the country the poorest, most inaccurate account of a nautical event or, in fact, any other incident of public interest, that has ever appeared in the public prints.

Have any of those hysterical persons who made a short-lived clamor some weeks ago about a now forgotten heroine named Barbella taken due note of the fact that Filippo Giampata has just been sentenced to five years in prison for stabbing, but not seriously injuring, a woman against whom he really had exactly the grievance which the Barbella only says she had against the man whom she murdered?

Edward C. O'Brien, President of the Dock Board, will send to Mayor Strong to-day his yearly report. One of its main features will be a denunciation of a "ring" of dredging companies who have combined, as alleged, to keep all dredging contracts among themselves. Commissioner O'Brien said yesterday:

Two championship games were played at the Polo Grounds yesterday between the New-York and Chicago Baseball Clubs, and the event attracted over 6,000 persons. There had been postponements the last two Saturdays.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 10. -- A sensation was caused in New-York and New-Haven on the morning of May 31 of last year, when it was discovered that James Low of this city, who had occupied a stateroom on the C.H. Northam on the trip between those cities, the night previous had disappeared during the night without anybody seeing him.
Mayor Strong has signed the resolution of the Board of Aldermen granting the application of the Third Avenue Railroad Company for the King's Bridge Road franchise.

The last of the celebration of the Constatter Volksfest for the present week took place yesterday at Sulzer's Harlem River Park, in the presence of another large assemblage. The final day of this popular harvest home festival will be next Sunday, and special preparations are being made to make this a fitting finish of one of the most enjoyable and successful celebrations in the long list of Constatter VolKsfeste.
DENVER, Col., Sept. 10. -- The following extract from The Republican shows how that paper tried to hedge upon the misleading report of the yacht race made by The Western Press Association:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- Secretary Herbert to-day opened bids for the construction of the three seagoing torpedo boats authorized by the last Naval Appropriation bill. The cost of the vessels was limited to $175,000 each, and the act provided for the construction of one of them on the Mississippi River, one on the Pacific coast, and one on the Gulf.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10. -- Here, where The Associated Press has its home, there is expressed much disgust at the failure Saturday of its already lame service.

STETTIN, Sept. 10. -- Emperor William, Emperor Francis Joseph of Austria, the King of Saxony, and the Bavarian and other Princes started early this morning for Kolbitzow, where an engagement was opened between the Guards Corps and the Second and Third Army Corps.

The Police Commissioners, having given their construction of the Sunday clause of the excise law so far as it relates to clubs, have stopped at that point, and will make no special effort to enforce the law against them any more than it attempts to enforce the law against French restaurant keepers who sell wine with meals Sundays.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- Nothing official, so far as can be ascertained, was received at the Treasury Department to-day from representatives of the Belmont-Morgan syndicate indicating whether or not they intended to make good the Treasury's depleted gold reserve. At the close of business to-day the reserve stood, all withdrawals deducted, at $97,544,666, or nearly $2,500,000 below what is usually regarded as the reserve limit.

The street stands have got to go. The Acting Chief of Police announced yesterday that after Oct. 1 no stands except those for the sale of newspapers, periodicals, fruit, and soda water will be permitted in the streets. Bootblack stands will be banished. Grocers, butchers, and other dealers will not be permitted to use more than three feet of the sidewalk, from the house line, to exhibit goods.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 10. -- The annual torchlight procession which passed through Ice Glen to-night was the largest and most picturesque that has ever been through this mountain gorge. There were more than 1,000 torch bearers. They assembled on the green in the centre of the town, near the Soldiers' Monument, and, led by the Stockbridge Band, marched through the main street to the railroad station, and thence by the path up to the glen.

Almost a model game of baseball was played at Eastern Park, Brooklyn, yesterday, between the Cincinnati and Brooklyn clubs, but, owing to the intense interest in the international yacht race, there were not over 1,700 spectators present.

That ex-Senator Platt will control the Republican County Convention, as well as a large majority of the delegates to the Republican State Convention, appears to be certain as a result of the Republican primaries last night.

The figures compiled in Poor's Manual for 1895 relating to the construction and earnings of railroads in this country present an interesting study. So far as they relate only to the construction of new lines within the past twenty years they are especially significant.
Permit me to call your attention, and, through your columns, the attention of the people of this State to the condition of the law relative to the taxation of corporations.
TOLEDO, Sept. 10. -- The Blade, the local organ of The Chicago Associated Press, 1 an editorial on The Associated Press report of Saturday's yacht race, says: "

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 10. -- Oliver H.P. Belmont to-day created no little excitement and enthusiasm by his celebration of the anniversary of Perry's victory. Lake Erie's hero was Mr. Belmont's great-uncle, and Mr. Belmont is named after the famous Commodore, who sent out to the world the message, "We have met the enemy and they are ours."
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 10. -- Landlord Leland of the Ocean House to-day treated his guests and many friends to a genuine Rhode Island clambake, on the grounds of the hotel. There were no formalities.

A most unfortunate occurence marred the second contest for the America's Cup, which took place off Sandy Hook yesterday. All the conditions were favorable for a close and beautiful struggle between Defender and Valkyrie III.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- The news which comes from Panama of the taking of Florencio Bustamente, one of ex-President Carlos Ezeta's stanchest supporters, from the Pacific mail steamer City of Sydney, at Libertad, by officers from Salvador, has excited much interest here. The charge on which he was removed from the steamer was that he had committed crimes during the time that Ezeta was in power.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 10. -- Louisville seemed to be full to overflowing this morning.
Senator Lexow, Chairman of the famous Senate investigating committee, was a witness yesterday against Patrick Sarsneld Cassidy in the Court of General Sessions, Judge Allison presiding.

One of the greatest of the difficulties that face poor women during the Summertime in New-York -- women who are either responsible for the support of their families or find it necessary to supplement the wages of the principal breadwinner -- is that of finding any kind of work to do.

CORNING, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- The Forty-first Senatorial District is one of the few in the State where the Republican nomination is still unsettled. The convention is called to meet in Bath September 24, and unless some candidate drops out before that time the first ballot will show six votes for each of three men.

Col. Varigault, the head of the Paris Fire Department, seems to have a good idea of the effectiveness of the New-York Fire Department and its accessories, and has expressed himself as greatly pleased with what he has seen.
The three days' reunion of the United States Military Telegraph Corps and the Old-Time Telegraphers and Historical Association was begun yesterday morning in the Broadway Central Hotel.

Never since Columbus sailed away from Palos and discovered America, while all the coastwise prophets were telling everybody what a crazy man he was, has anybody made such a bungle of the news of a nautical event as the so-called Associated Press made of the international yacht race on Saturday.
Charles E. Anthony's one meeting with Lincoln presents an interesting contrast to those of the men who shared the emancipator's interest in public affairs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- If the people who attend the opening ceremonies of the Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park on Sept. 19 and 20 fail to secure good accommodations the fault will be their own. There is a popular impression that the Government will provide food and lodging for all who may take part in the opening of the park.
GLASGOW, Sept. 11. -- The Mail to-morrow will say:

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 11. -- Robert T. Herrick, the insurance lawyer, who captured Dr. G.W. Fraker, the insurance swindler, will file with the Clerk of the United States Circuit Court an amendment to the bill in equity which the Insurance companies filed last week to recover the money paid to the Fraker heirs.

The New-Yorks, after their two defeats at the hands of the Chicago Club, pulled themselves together sufficiently yesterday to win a game of baseball from the Boston Club. The two straight to Chicago evidently had an effect upon the attendance, as there were not over 1,500 people present at the Polo Grounds, but they managed to entertain themselves by finding fault with the umpire.
Mrs. Frankie J. Lewis, thirty-five years old, of 52 Morris Street, Jersey City, called at the Lorena House, 386 Third Avenue, Tuesday night and asked for Oscar McCullough.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- The Grand Legion of Select Knights passed the second day of its seventeenth annual meeting in executive session. The question of the reserve fund was laid over for one year by unanimous consent.

The sale of G.J. Harley's trotting stock at Fleetwood yesterday was much more successful than anticipated. Horsemen generally considered it a mistake to offer fine animals at this season of the year, but Mr. Harley's business takes him at once to the Pacific coast for a prolonged stay, and the sale could not, therefore, be postponed to a more convenient season.

Much of the time yesterday at the first meeting of the Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange since the Summer recess was taken up with the discussion of the proposition of a member of the committee to require the American Sugar Refining Company to make a public report of its financial condition.

The New-York Times recently called attention to the necessity for a high-pressure water supply in the lower part of the city. This improvement has been urgently advocated by the Board of Fire Underwriters and other associations. The matter was brought to the attention of the Sinking Fund Commissioners yesterday. Representatives of the various interested bodies were present.

Some fake reports, that looked as if they might have been prepared by somebody who could not tell a yacht from the State scow Tom Wheeler, crept into town: Saturday, alleging that the British boat, the Valkyrie, was ahead, and the fake was kept up all the afternoon, getting worse as time went on, so that people unfamiliar with the source of the canards were in doubt as to the true situation.

We have already stated the reasons why the excise law can have no application to social clubs and was intended to have none, but it may be worth while to enlarge a little upon one of these, which does not seem to be fully understood by the Police Commissioners. Clubs cannot under the present law be licensed to "sell liquor."

C.C. Taylor, engineer of the Pablo Railroad, has pulled a throttle for thirty-six years, and during that time has had many novel experiences, but Sunday he had one that has no parallel in his life's history.

Park Commissioner Squier of Brooklyn was served yesterday with the temporary injunction issued by Justice Osborne of the Brooklyn City Court, restraining him from the further purchase of land at Richmond Hill for park purposes.

The protest of C. Oliver Iselin against the Valkyrie was sustained by the Regatta Committee, and the race sailed on Tuesday, in which the Valkyrie finished first, has been awarded to the Defender. It was late yesterday afternoon when the Regatta-Committee rendered its decision, and the result pleased some and was criticised by others.

BUFFALO, Sept. 11. -- Police Commissioner Theodore Roosevelt of New-York delivered an address before a mass meeting held at Music Hall to-night under the auspices of the Catholic Abstinence Union. He gave his whole attention to Senator Hill's recent criticisms of his method of enforcing the Sunday closing laws in New-York, speaking of the Senator in vigorous terms. He said, in part:

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- An interesting and lively strife is anticipated at the Democratic County Convention to be held at New City Saturday to select delegates to the coming Senatorial Convention which will nominate Senator Lexow's opponent. There are two factions, each headed by prominent members of the party in the county, and two separate calls for the County Convention, one by each faction, have been issued.

It was not many years ago that the superiority in railroad speed was conceded to lie on the other side of the Atlantic and with the British Islands. There were three or four British trains that were faster than any trains on the Continent either of Europe or of America. This was the result mainly of the more careful and more costly construction of the British roads, not of the superiority of the engines.

ALEXANDRIA, Minn., Sept. 11. -- Five persons were killed and a dozen injured this morning in a collision between passenger trains on the Great Northern Railroad, near Melby, a flag station between Ashton and Evansville. Somebody blundered. The eastbound passenger train, while running at a comparatively high rate of speed, met the coastbound train on a heavy grade, wrecking the engine and several cars.
Mrs. Mary Alice Almost Fleming was indicted yesterday by the Grand Jury on the charge of murder in the first degree.
LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Sept. 11. -- An appeal to the courts will probably be the result of Long Island City's empty Treasury.

There are all sorts of disputes about the results of the Republican primaries in this city and the means by which those results were obtained, but there is no doubt that Platt secured control of the delegates in a majority of the Assembly districts and will dominate the local conventions.

It is not difficult to believe that the German Emperor was both "surprised" and "greatly irritated" when Gen. von Waldersee made that forced march, early Tuesday morning, and inconsiderately opposed so many troops to those commanded by the young Kaiser that the latter had to scuttle away in great haste to avoid capture as well as defeat.

The Democratic organizations in this city are pushing along their preparations for this Fall's campaign. A determined effort is to be made to get the State Democracy and the Tammany Hall Democracy together, but no definite steps have been taken in that direction as yet. Both organizations held meetings last night.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 11. -- But for Kennedy's passes to first to-day, Brooklyn would have shut the champions out without a run. He held the home team down to 9 scattered singles, and pitched winning ball, except in the second and eighth innings. The visitors solved Hemming's delivery in the first and ninth rounds, and earned their three runs.

HAVANA, Sept. 5. -- Since Aug. 1, 9,300 officers and men of the Spanish Army have landed in Cuba, the majority of them in this city. They include all arms of Spain's best regiments, artillery, cavalry, engineers, and infantry; also a heliograph corps.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 11. -- Mayor Wanser to-day decided not to cause the arrest of Edward T. McLaughlin for criminal libel in asserting at a public meeting that his action on the water contract was swayed by money, but to bring a civil suit for $50,000. He has retained Charles Thompson, of the firm of Dickinson, Thompson McMasters.

LANCASTER, Penn., Sept. 11. -- The most disastrous leaf tobacco fire in the history of this city started at 3 o'clock this morning in the warehouse of John F. Brimmer on Tobacco Avenue, and communicated to the warehouse owned by R.H. Brubaker, both of which were entirely destroyed with their contents.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., Sept. 11. -- The Democratic State Convention to-day nominated a candidate for State Treasurer and a full judicial ticket. The platform adopted includes an unqualified indorsement of the National Administration, a square declaration against the free coinage of silver, and a pledge of continued opposition to the doctrine of protection.

AQUEBOGUE, L.I., Sept. 11. -- If there is a competent school teacher anywhere in the United States who is without employment and without relatives a vacancy awaits such an individual here. Aquebogue wants a school teacher, but the teacher must be alone in the world.

Our Paris correspondent writes: "A letter of the Prussian General Verdy du Vernois, dated September, 1870, and given in some of the papers, describes the day spent by the Emperor William and his staff at Ferrieres, and reminds one that truth is stranger than fiction. The writer owes his French name to his Huguenot origin. He says:

Wall Street and society forgot about rachting yesterday long enough to go down to the Coney Island Jockey Club's track. It was the running of the first of a series of three races between Henry of Navarre, Domino, and Rey El Santa Anita that was the magnet that filled the boxes in the second tier for the first time since the Futurity was run, and brought altogether about 8,000 persons to the track.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11. -- The following communication appears in this morning's Inter-Ocean, a local organ of The Chicago Associated Press:
The Department of Docks submitted to Major Strong yesterday the report of the transactions of the department for the quarter ending July 31.

The entries for the coming championship meeting of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States to be held Saturday next at Manhattan Field, commencing at 2 P.M., were made public yesterday by Secretary Sullivan, and the list is the most representative one ever received by an Amateur Athletic Union committee for a track and field championships.

In answer to a call from the Superior Council of New-York, a convention of Presidents and Vice Presidents of Central and Particular Councils of the St. Vincent de Paul Society was begun yesterday morning at the Mission of the Immaculate Virgin, Lafayette Place and Great Jones Street. The convention will continue until to-morrow evening.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 11. -- The metropolis of Kentucky was ablaze with patriotic enthusiasm this morning. Through her wide streets and over her boulevards marched as her guests 30,000 of those who once came to conquer. Their pathway was banked by over a third of a million people, who gave the boys in blue a reception that will never be forgotten by the veterans from abroad.

Edward M. Shepard, Chairman of the Harmony Committee of the Democratic Party in Kings County -- the independent organization -- said last night at his home that in all probability the first conference between the Harmony Committees of the two wings of the party in Brooklyn would be held this evening.

Park Policeman John Flaherty was assaulted by a mob of nearly 200 persons in Bryant Park, Fortieth Street and Sixth Avenue, last night. During a fight the mob stripped the officer of his shield, helmet, coat, club, and revolver. His hand was broken, both eyes badly blackened, and he sustained a severe scalp wound.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Sept. 11. -- Republicans in Washington whose vision extends beyond their noses are criticising the speeches delivered yesterday at Springfield, Ohio, by McKinley, Sherman, Foraker, and Bushnell in opening the campaign in that State.
PATCHOGUE, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- The Republican County Convention of Suffolk County, met here to-day, and elected delegates to the State Convention and Judicial Convention.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- The triennial session of the National Council of United Chapters of the Phi Beta Kappa Society has occupied substantially the entire day. The President, Col. T.W. Higginson of Cambridge, Mass., occupied the chair. The greater portion of the time was devoted to considering applications for chapters.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 11. -- The large contingent of Summer residents who went to New-York for the yacht races began to return to-day. Perry Belmont returned on the Satanella and Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Fish Webster, Mr. and Mrs. William F. Burden, and the Messrs. D'Hauteville returned by rail.

Louis S. Newman and Samuel Lustbader, butchers, have been close rivals for the trade and good wills of the dwellers in and about West Thirty-eighth Street, who believe in the tenets of the Orthodox Hebrew church.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11. -- The National Council, Order of United American Mechanics, to-day elected officers. National Councillor Simon gave up his seat, and Vice Councillor Dittess, according to the usual custom, was elected to fill his place.

Henry M. Stanley, the African explorer, and at present a member of the British Parliament, was a passenger by the White Star Line steamship Majestic, which arrived yesterday from Europe. He was met at the wharf by Major Pond, who acted as his manager during his lecture tours.

We regret to say that it is becoming extremely difficult to avoid taking Judge Gaynor seriously. Of course in his capacity as Judge he is entitled to the utmost seriousness of treatment at the hands of all outsiders, and this The Times, at the expense of considerable self-restraint, has uniformly accorded to him.

There was joy yesterday in the ranks of the Republicans of this city and county who train with Thomas Collier Platt, and corresponding dismay among those who have stood by William Brookfield and the administration of Mayor Strong. This was all brought about by the result of the primaries on Tuesday evening.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 11.--Four members of the Louisville Legion were instantly killed this morning by the explosion of ammunition in the caisson of the gun which was being driven to Phoenix Hill for service in connection with the Grand Army of the Republic parade. The victims were:...

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- Platt stands in the Twenty-seventh Senatorial District to-night in the guise of a mendicant, with his arms outstretched, begging for one more chance. His followers are making every sort of promise to stay defeat. Krum is confident of the nomination, and Mosher hangs on tenaciously, waging an up-hill fight.

TROY, Sept. 11. -- About 200 delegates were present at the closing session of the Liquor Dealers' Convention to-day. Glens Falls was selected as the place for the next convention. The Executive Committee will select the time. The officers were re-elected, as follows:

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 11. -- The Constitutional Convention began its business session this morning. President Evans announced his standing committees. Senator Irby is Chairman of the Committee on Declaration of Rights, and Senator Tillman is in charge of the Committee on Rights of Suffrage, which means, of course, the reporting of the Mississippi plan with modifications.

R.C. Meade, formerly an insurance agent at Atchison, Kan., who disappeared three years ago with $30,000, the interest on mortgages held by widows and orphans of that city, was arrested in this city yesterday by Central Office detectives at the request of M.G. Larken, Sheriff of Atchison County, Kan.
Commissioner Waring of the Street-Cleaning Department gave out the following communications yesterday:...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- The weather has become distressingly hot again, and the people who have returned from their vacations are likely to lose the good effects of their outing. In the early Summer the temperature here was delightful, and stay-at-homes had a good deal to say about the advantages of Washington as a Summer resort.
Hannah Downey, spinster, is afraid of no court, Judge, or jury.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- In dispatches to the Department of State, dated Aug. 23 and 24, Consul O'Hara of San Juan del Norte, Nicaragua, announces the distribution of the indemnity of 15,030 paid by the Government of Nicaragua, in response to the British demand for damages because of the Bluefields affair.

The general court-martial convened to try the charges found against Col. Forney, United States Marine Corps, by the Court of Inquiry recently held at the New-York Navy Yard, began its second session at the same place yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 11. -- Additional prestige was acquired by the Springfield Bicycle Club this afternoon through the great success of the second day's programme in the annual "Diamond Tournament" at Hampden Park. Records fell, and there were such fighting finishes as are seldom seen on the National Circuit. At the close of the contests the general verdict was, "There's only one Springfield and but one Hampden Park."

Mr. George R. Read has sold for the Clearing House Association to Donald Mackay, at $725,000, the northwest corner of Nassau and Pine Streets, 36.7 by 80.3 by 37.1 by 80.5. The plot contains about 2,970 square feet, and the price is therefore at the rate of more than $244 per square foot. There is a substantial five-story and basement brownstone bank building on the lot.

President Jackson Wallace of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen, who has aspirations for higher political honors, allowed himself yesterday to be made the cat's-paw of the Aldermen in signing a resolution adopted by that body on Tuesday.

WESTBROOK, Sept. 11. -- Sometimes a native of one of these rugged New-England towns, having accumulated wealth elsewhere, returns to set up at his birthplace a monument that shall not only commemorate his family name but at the same time be an enduring agency for the promotion of intelligence.

LONDON, Sept. 11. -- The sixty-fifth annual meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science opened this evening at Ipswich. It is customary for the retiring President to introduce his successor, but Lord Salisbury, who was President last year, telegraphed from the Chateau Cecil, near Dieppe, France, that he required rest, and was unable to attend the meeting.

The first stated meeting of the Board of Education since vacation was held yesterday afternoon, Chairman Maclay presiding. School affairs in the newly acquired annexed district and the budget for next year occupied most of the board's attention.

WILLIMANTIC, Conn., Sept. 11. -- State Attorney John L. Hunter has made application to the Superior Court in Windham County for an order to examine the books and papers of the Natchaug Silk Company. His application contains the assertion that the stockholders of the company have reason to believe that certain crimes have been committed by the officers and employes of the company, which the books will disclose.

LONDON, Sept. 11. -- The decision of the America's Cup Committee to give Tuesday's yacht race to the Defender was known in the London clubs and newspaper offices at about 10 o'clock this evening. The general public will know nothing about it until the papers appear in the morning. Clubmen and the London agents of provincial papers stood about in groups to-night discussing the matter.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 12. -- The house and barn of T.S. Jones, at Cove Neck, near East Norwich, were struck by lightning during the storm late this afternoon. Two horses were killed.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- In General Term of the Supreme Court in session here, Judge Charles, F. Brown presiding, the law of April 1, 1895, known as the civil service aid for old soldiers, Chapter 344, was pronounced unconstitutional, all the Judges concurring.

LONDON, Sept. 12. -- Sir Douglas Galton, who was seized with a fainting fit at Ipswich last night, while reading an address before the British Association for the Advancement of Science, of which he is President, is much better, and was able to appear at this morning's sitting of the association.

Thomas C. Platt walked leisurely up Broadway about 9:30 last night in a full dress suit. He looked as cool as any man on Broadway. At the same hour, in various Assembly districts of the city, Platt followers were sweltering in cellars and small halls, struggling and fighting in the ugliest, liveliest, and altogether most exciting Assembly district conventions ever held.

An interesting visitor to New-York yesterday was the Rev. S.D. Ferguson, who is the Bishop of Liberia, of the African Methodist Episcopal Church. The Bishop is on his way to attend the triennial conference of the African Methodist Episcopal Church of this country, which is to be held next month at Minneapolis.
LIMA, Peru, via Galveston, Sept. 12. -- The Minister of War has issued orders, the tendency of which is to enforce discipline and prevent rowdyism in the army.

STETTIN, Sept. 12. -- The military manoeuvres were renewed this morning. The Northern Army, commanded by the Emperor in person, stormed and captured Sparenfelde Height. The Third Army Corps was checked from outflanking the Second Corps by the strong intrenchments of the latter.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 12. -- Mrs. Margaret Bottome of New-York, President of the King's Daughters, held an informal reception this afternoon at Rough Point, the residence of Mrs. Frederick W. Vanderbilt, whose guest she is. The affair was in the hands of When-so-ever Circle, of which Mrs. Vanderbilt is a member and a patron.

QUEBEC, Sept. 12. -- At the banquet of the Canadian Bankers' Association this evening, an impressive address was made by William C. Cornwell, President of the City Bank of Buffalo, and delegate to the association's convention from the New-York Bankers' Association. Responding to the toast. "The President of the United States," Mr. Cornwell said:

MOUNTAIN STATION, N.J., Sept. 12. -- The play this afternoon in the championship tennis tournament of the Orange Tennis Club was marked by a wonderfully plucky up-hill fight, George Miles drawing his match with Holcombe Ward, when the latter had but one point to go to score a victory, in straight sets by a 0 -- 0, 6 -- 1 score.

LONDON, Sept. 12. -- The Daily Telegraph will say: "If the American public will not submit to the dictates of good order and self-restraint, which elsewhere are stronger than any police, they cannot blame an English gentleman for refusing to risk his crew and vessel in the hubbub of such a scene."
September is not wont to annoy the public as she did yesterday, and it is seldom that she allows herself to be seen in company with that most heart-breaking General Humidity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The Caroline incident, as it is known in diplomatic annalS, has again absorbed the attention of the State Department people. The latest information on the subject promises that there will be no speedy termination of the controversy. Our representative at Madrid reports that the Spanish Government has declined to accede to the demand of the State Department to permit the return of the American Protestant missionaries to the Caroline Islands.

H. Walter Webb, Third Vice President of the New-York Central, spoke with much satisfaction yesterday of the record-breaking achievement of his special train, which ran from New-York to Buffalo last Wednesday in 407 minutes. He said: "We have not yet reached the, limit of our capabilities.

After long probing by Secretary George Terry and Treasurer Edwin Einstein of the Dock Board, the former was able to read yesterday at the weekly meeting of the board, at the request of President O'Brien, a report concerning the granting of leases of certain property under water, which shows a loss to the city in ten years of $129,591.95.
YETAPAN, Honduras, Sept. 12. -- A courier arrived yesterday from Yetapan and announced the most terrible earthquake ever known in that section. The loss of life and property is enormous.
With the completion of its new Twenty-second Street Ferry the Pennsylvania Railroad Company will start a cab and hansom service similar to that which it now has in Philadelphia.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 12. -- Ex-Gov. John M. Thayer of Nebraska was almost hooted from the platform at the Grand Army Camp Fire at Phoenix Hill last night, which was participated in by a crowd of over 10,000. Early in the evening addresses were delivered by Congressman-elect Evans and Ex-Gov. Buckner, and it was close on to 11 o'clock when the Nebraskan was introduced.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 12. -- Edward T. McLaughlin, against whom Mayor Wanser proposes to bring a suit for damages for alleged slander in connection with the water contract, called on the Mayor today and made an apology. He said he had been misunderstood. He admitted having said that Mayor Wanser was swayed by money, but he did not mean that the Mayor had been bribed.

Ludlow Street Jail has lost one of its oldest and most esteemed prisoners, William Stitt.
