The racing at Sheepshead Bay yesterday resulted in the poorest day's sport of the meeting, and was witnessed by an exceptionally small crowd, less than 1,500 people being present. There was but one stake event down for decision, the Golden Rod, for two-year-olds, a run of seven-eights of a mile, over the turf track, which resulted in an easy win for the Brookdale Stable's candidate, One I Love.

ALBANY, Sept. 12. -- The State Lunacy Commission expects that the recent decision of the General Term, compelling New-York to pay its quota, of tax for State care, will result in New-York County turning over its pauper insane to the State as soon as necessary legislation can be secured, and it is accordingly interesting itself in the disposition of cases of alien paupers reported from New-York City.

The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals will, in the October number of Our Animal Friends, which it publishes, "modestly disclaim any credit whatever" for any part of the exploits of W. Hosea Ballou in the matter of the bullfights in the Mexican village at the Atlanta Exposition.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 12. -- The Republican Senatorial Convention for the Twenty-seventh District to-day, after two half-hour sessions, took a recess until 11:30 to-morrow. The four hundred and thirty-second ballot showed no change in the standing of the candidates. Keck's people are making every effort to prolong the balloting until the State Convention meets.

The American champion yacht Defender sailed alone yesterday in the last of three races for the America's Cup. She had what is known to sporting men as a walk-over, and in all human probability no one ever saw a more disgusted set of sportsmen than those who went out yesterday in the hope of seeing a yacht race.

The Normal College was opened yesterday morning with an attendance of 2,070 girls. This is the largest attendance known in the history of the college. This number will be augmented by about thirty more pupils, making a total of 2,100 in the college.

Some things have come to the surface in Brooklyn within a week which indicate conclusively to the practical Republican politicians that Mayor Schieren has not abandoned the hope of being renominated. It will be remembered that Mr. Schieren, some weeks ago, publicly announced that under no circumstances would he run again.

The Chief Justice and Mrs. Fuller have concluded not to renew the lease of the house on the corner of Massachusetts Avenue and Eighteenth Street, in which they have resided for the past few years, since moving from the Barber house, on Fourteenth Street and the Boundary. The Chief Justice, early in the Summer, purchased a Summer home at Sorrento, Me., and, with his family, has been spending the Summer at that place.

Considerable amusements was created by some of the members of the squadron who operated the blackboard upon which they chalked the latest news of the great race at New-York. The bulletins displayed by our yachtsmen for their visitors at the clubhouse, among whom were many Americans, were obtained from the rival telegraph lines, and as the race progressed proved to be of the most bewildering character.

LONDON, Sept. 12. -- The Daily Chronicle to-morrow will print a dispatch from Shanghai to a news agency of this city, saying that a native mob recently attacked the British Consul at Wenchow, in the Province of Che-Kiang, pelting him with stones and other missiles.
John May, a truck driver, of 183 Hudson Street, was stabbed in the side Wednesday night somewhere near Desbrosses and Hudson Streets, but he refuses to disclose the identity of his assailant.

ATTLEBOROUGH, Mass., Sept. 12. -- One of the worst thunderstorms that ever visited this place struck here at 1:10 o'clock this morning. The wind blew in fearful gusts. Trees were prostrated, blinds wrenched from houses, and chimneys blown down. The velocity of the wind was eighty miles an hour, and the lightning was incessant.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Eugene T. Chamberlain, Commissioner of Navigation, has prepared as Part 2 of his report for 1895 a compendium of the laws of the United States relating to navigation and the merchant marine, which makes a bound volume of nearly 500 pages, with a comprehensive and analytical and alphabetical index.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 12. -- The forerunners of the dedication crowds arrived this morning from Louisville, about 150 strong. Fully 1,000 visitors are already en route from the Grand Army of the Republic encampment. A sham battle at the park will in all probability be added to the list of attractions.
DENVER, Col., Sept. 12. -- Troops at Fort Logan have made the first test of the new emergency ration prescribed by the War Department.

The trial of Patrick Sarsfield Cassidy for criminal libel was for a time yesterday exceedingly lively, when ex-Judge George M. Curtis, counsel for the defendant, narrowly escaped being fined for contempt of court.

There was a hesitancy yesterday on the part of interested city official in talking about the State's suit against the city to recover New-York's quota of back taxes for the care of the State's insane, amounting to $1,400,000. This suit was decided by the General Term, at Saratoga, on Wednesday, in favor of the State.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 12. -- The champions had a batting matinee at the expense of the Brooklyn twirlers to-day. Gumbert was sent to the bench after seven runs had been made off his delivery in three innings. Abbey fared little better. Twelve hits for sixteen bases, three bases on balls, two hit batsmen for a total of twelve runs was the record made against him during the five innings he officiated.

They suffered assimilation in the cast-iron interior of the gull merely as a punishment for their temerity in coming to steal his dinner. We gave him a daily dinner of scraps, besides occasional delicate morsels such as worms and fishes.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- J. Sloat Fassett has caused the Platt forces in this county to suffer an ignominious defeat.

It was announced a few days ago that the American Wire Nail Company, at Anderson, Ind., operating the largest plant of its kind in the country, and employing 1,000 men, had given notice that it would reduce its force of workmen in the wire-nail department by one-half. "This means," said the press dispatch, "that the company is unable to place all the nails which it is making."

The Rev. Andrew Murray of Wellington, South Africa, who has been conducting a series of Christian conference meetings this week in the Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, will speak for the last times this afternoon and evening. He and his wife will sail for England to-morrow on the steamship Lucania.

The convention of presidents and vice presidents of Central and Particular Councils of the St. Vincent de Paul Society was resumed yesterday morning at the Mission of the Immaculate Virgin, Lafayette Place and Great Jones Street. Jeremiah Fitzpatrick presided.

Mrs. Mary Alice Almont Fleming appeared yesterday in the Court of General Sessions before Judge Fitzgerald, to plead to the indictment found against her for the alleged murder of her mother, Mrs. Evelina M. Bliss. She was accompanied by her attorneys, Charles W. Brooke, John C. Shaw, and Gratz Nathan.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- A party of distinguished Georgians reached the city this morning, and extended a hearty invitation to the people of Chicago to attend the Cotton States and International Exposition. A large delegation of representative Chicago men met the visitors at Glenwood, twenty-five miles distant, in a special train, and tendered them the freedom of the city.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 12. -- An evening paper publishes a long account of the capture of Gen. Florencio Bustamente at La Libertad. It says that Bustamente probably met a fearful death at La Libertad soon after he was landed from the Pacific Mail steamer City of Sydney.
LOUISVILLE, Sept. 12. -- A scene of a very peculiar nature was enacted at the opening session of the National Convention of the Woman's Relief Corps.

Policeman Cragen, of the West Thirtieth Street Station, at the risk of his life, stopped a runaway team of horses attached to a landau, at Broadway and Thirtieth Street, last night. Had it not been for his act many persons might have been injured, for at the time Broadway was thronged with vehicles and pedestrians.

The Pulitzer Building was set on fire shortly after 10 o'clock last night by an electric light wire, which in the delivery room under the sidewalk at Frankfort Street and Park Row, ignited waste paper, and before aid came the disaster had assumed such gravity that three alarms were struck, and every apparatus summoned was needed.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Hall, pastor of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn, died at 11 o'clock last night at his home, 157 Montague Street, Brooklyn, after a long illness, of paralysis. At his bedside were his wife and daughters, Dr. Bierwirth, who attended him in all his illness, and a few intimate friends.

Alexander E. Orr, the President of the Chamber of Commerce, has returned to the city after a vacation, and yesterday talked with a reporter for The New-York Times concerning the editorial that recently appeared in The Times deprecating the proposed expenditure of $9,000,000 for deepening and improving the Erie, Oswege and Champlain Canals, and suggesting that the time was now ripe for the construction of a ship canal from Lake Erie to the Hudson.

The German clubs and societies of this city do not apprehend any trouble so far as the police are concerned with reference to the Commissioners' ruling on Sunday liquor selling. While this subject furnishes one of the principal topics for discussion at the leading German clubs, the consensus of opinion seems to be that private clubs do not come within the pale of the excise law, hence the Police Department has no jurisdiction over them.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- A terrific storm swept over this section at about 9 o'clock last night, causing much damage to property generally and culminating in serious disaster and fatality at Cape Vincent, at the foot of Lake Ontario.

BOSTON, Sept. 13. -- Ed Lawley, the South Boston yacht builder, was seen by a reporter to-day and expressed his opinion that the Regatta Committee was entirely justified in giving the cup to the Defender. He did not believe that the collision on Tuesday was intentional, but he could see only one course for the committee to pursue, and that was to award the race to the Defender.

Patience Penfold, the little gypsy Princess who died suddenly in her mother's arms Wednesday afternoon, was buried in the Presbyterian Cemetery at West Farms yesterday. The funeral services were held at the camp at 1 o'clock, in the presence of the whole tribe. The simple ritual of the Protestant Episcopal Church was read over the body by the Rev. Benjamin H. Burch, rector of St. Stephen's Church, King's Bridge.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- A proposition from a mysterious source has been under consideration in the Navy Department. It is suggested that the administration of affairs in that department be aided by a naval board of control, although those who have had any business with the Navy Department must feel that there are sufficient boards, and committees already organized to meet all the demands of the service.

At the election in New-York State next November the voters will be called on to pronounce for or against the issue of $9,000,000 of State bonds, the proceeds of which are to be devoted to deepening the Erie, Oswego, and Champlain Canals. This proposition was authorized by the last Legislature, and has to be submitted to popular vote in accordance with the requirements of the State Constitution.

It was reported in Newark and this city last evening that William J. Thompson, the owner of Washington Park, and known as the Duke of Gloucester, on account of his connection with that place, had secured a foothold in Delaware and Maryland as well by purchasing a piece of land near Newark.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- According to present appearances the Fifty-fourth Congress will assemble next December with nearly every question in regard to our foreign relations either settled or in process of satisfactory adjustment.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- More pleasant weather favored the Sleepy Hollow Tennis Club here to-day, and the club's big tournament was continued. Considerable progress was made in all five of the events, and three finals were finished and a fourth started. The final in mixed doubles will be played to-morrow and the tournament ended.

BOSTON, Sept. 13. -- Rear Admiral George E. Belknap, United States Navy, is of the opinion that the fouling of the Defender on Tuesday was not altogether accidental. "On the occasion of both races there seemed to be," said he to-day, "needless jockeying at the start on the part of the Valkyrie.

ALBANY, Sept. 13. -- Ex-Senator Hiscock of Syracuse, representing the Manufacturers' Lloyds; Bainbridge Colby of New-York, representing the Mutual Lloyds, the Mercantile Lloyds, and the Hudson Fire Lloyds, all of New-York, and William B. Ellison of New-York, representing the American Lloyds and the Great Western Lloyds, met with State Controller Roberts by appointment at the latter's office this afternoon, to discuss the State taxes, if any, their companies should pay.

This is the first week of the season for the pumpkin pie. The cranberry pie is also in its first days, and the pie industry in general is beginning to look forward to the increased proportions of Fall and Winter trade, and the mammoth Christmas mince pies, which crown the holiday season.

Kendrick, the Third Vice President of the New-Haven Road, concerning the proposed extension of electrical equipment on the Old Colony division, he said: "We are entirely satisfied with our experiment on the Nantasket Beach business, the season having demonstrated the fact that the cheap and frequent trains create traffic.

In view of the remarkable record made by Vice President Webb's special flier on the New-York Central Railroad, from New-York to Buffalo, last Wednesday, an analysis of the best achievements of British railways in the matter of speed presents interesting material for comparisons.

Piget Sound timber goes everywhere, even into the masts of the fleet yachts made by both America and England to race for the America's Cup. But the point of most interest to the people of this region is that the great spars of noble Douglas fir shipped from this region as soon as they pass beyond the State line have fastened upon them the name of "Oregon pine."

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Sept. 13. -- The story of a narrow escape from drowning in Hog Island Inlet last night, in which thirteen persons returning from the yacht race were concerned, was told this morning, and its hero is Alfred Hill of Oceanside.

Edwin A. Martin, Chief Chemist of the New-York Board of Health, and head of the division of food and offensive trades of the department, spent his vacation this Summer near Goshen, Orange County, this State, in the centre of the great dairy district. Mr. Martin was for many years a State Milk Inspector, and while rusticating last month he made a tour among the milk farms near Goshen, renewing old acquaintanceships.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 11. -- The campaign in Maryland has already gotten beyond the first stages, and the forces are being lined up for the real fight on the stump and at the polls. When Senator Gorman arrived on the scene a few days ago he found his organization considerably demoralized, and many of the leaders discouraged.

The yachting fiasco was a general topic of conversation all over town yesterday. Every one was disappointed that after talking and working a year to arrange races for the America's Cup that the series of races should end in a burlesque.

Mr. A. J. Johnson, agent of the State Forestry Department, is in the city again. For the past two months he has been roaming the country from California to British Columbia. He has not stayed long in any one place, and has been looking to see in what localities the forest trees are bearing seeds, principally of the coniferae.

Shippers of fresh, salted, canned, corned, and packed beef were greatly excited yesterday over the order from the Secretary of Agriculture requiring that all such beef offered for exportation after Sept. 16 must be accompanied by a certificate showing that the cattle from which it was produced were free from disease, and the meat sound and wholesome, and also announcing that no clearance would be granted any vessel having on board meat without such certificate.

The convention of the St. Vincent de Paul Society was resumed yesterday morning at the Mission of the Immaculate Virgin, at Lafayette Place and Great Jones Street. There was a full attendance of delegates.

Additional experiments of an interesting nature were made a few days ago with the electric motors on the Nantasket Branch of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company, and at the conclusion of them some significant remarks were given to the press for publication by President Clark, who has recently returned from Europe and had not been present during the earlier experiments on the same road, to which we have referred heretofore.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 13. -- The contests at the Republican primaries in Elizabeth and Rahway to-night for delegates to the State Convention were the most bitterly contested ever known, and the greatest vote ever cast was polled.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- At the Otsego Republican County Convention to-day the following delegates were chosen to the State Convention: D. Forest Wilber, Andrew Davidson, James W. Barnum, C. Porter Root, E. Reed Ford, Menzo H. Nichols, John S. Kidder, and D.C. Johnson.
A feeling of gratification prevailed among Democrats in Brooklyn yesterday when it became known that, after considerable discussion, harmony in the party in Kings County was a last assured.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Washington won two games from Brooklyn to-day owing to the failure of the latter to connect successfully with the pitching of the home team twirlers, Mercer and Anderson. Mercer pitched the first game, and with proper support would have shut out the visitors. Anderson's work in the second was nearly as good.

LONDON, Sept. 13. -- The feeling throughout England over the failure of the match between the Valkyrie III. and the Defender, though embodying many shades of opinion, generally upholds Lord Dunraven, who is considered to have had just cause for abandoning yesterday's race. The opinion most generally held is that he was beset with difficulties especially abhorred by him, though in some quarters it is thought that he was possibly hasty.

Riley Grannan's alternate winnings and losses at the Sheepshead Bay track have been the principal sensations of the Coney Island Jockey Club's Fall race meeting. His "plunges" and successes have been chronicled and commented upon locally and telegraphed over the country. But he is not the only big operator at Sheepshead Bay, neither is he the star "plunger."

It would be a cause for general congratulation if the outcome of the international yacht races, could be accepted as a huge joke. Surely, when all the preparations which were under way in two countries for many months are considered, the net result is ludicrous enough. We have succeeded in "keeping the cup" under conditions which are satisfactory to nobody.

Some interesting facts about the revolution in Cuba were obtained yesterday by a reporter for The New-York Times from a Cuban gentleman whose name is not made public for obvious reasons. This gentleman, although not taking an active part in the present revolution, is accurately informed in regard to the state of things in Cuba, having relatives in Havana, Matanzas, Santiago, and other cities, and friends all over the island, with whom he corresponds extensively.

If any of the returning residents of Brooklyn desire to add to their manages for the coming Winter a cat or a dog, they will have a large and varied collection to choose from by applying at the Shelter of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, Nostrand Avenue and Malbone Street.

We publish in to-day's Eagle an important letter from the Hon. Elnathan Sweet, former State Engineer and Surveyor, to The New-York Times on the proposal to bond the State for nine millions to begin a new enlargement of the Erie Canal. Mr. Sweet is an engineer of long experience, and his knowledge of the subject is complete, as he has had personal charge of canal engineering while in office.

KINGSTON, Sept. 13. -- The Republican machine has selected Charles Davis of Saugerties as the candidate for the Senate in the district which includes Ulster and Greene Counties. Mr. Davis is a lawyer. He has the backing of Republican State Committeeman W.S.C. Wiley of Catskill. Mr. Davis will not have the entire backing of the Republicans of the county, inasmuch as Capt. J.H. Everett of this city is the choice of some.

JERSEY, N.J., Sept. 13. -- Friction caused a fire to-day that destroyed $30,000 worth of property and threw sixty men and girls out of work. The scene of the disaster was the mattress factory of the Runyon Manufacturing Company, 190 and 192 First Street -- a four-story brick structure, 50 by 100 feet.

William E. Cleary of the Lake Erie and Champlain Canals Transportation Company gave a reporter for The New-York Times an interesting interview yesterday respecting the suggestions made recently by The Times on the proposed nine-million-dollar improvement to the canals and the advisability of the construction of a great ship canal from Lake Erie to the Hudson.

The letter in another part of this paper from A.L. Crocker, President of the Minneapolis Board of Trade and Chairman of the Executive Committee of the International Deep Waterways Association, is only one of many prompt responses heard from the Northwest and the West to the proposition recently made by The New-York Times for a ship canal across the State of New-York to connect the Atlantic Ocean and the great lakes.

Next November the people of the State of New-York will vote upon the proposition to issue State bonds to the amount of $9,000,000, the proceeds of which are to be employed in improving the Erie, the Champlain, and the Oswego Canals. It is intended to deepen the Erie Canal to nine feet, and the Champlain Canal to the uniform depth of seven feet.

BOSTON, Sept. 13. -- The American Board of Foreign Missions has received a detailed report from a missionary member of the Relief Commission in Eastern Turkey, which is operating behalf of the Armenians who have survived the massacres there.

The meeting at Manhattan Field this afternoon of America's crack athletes in contests for the championships of the Amateur Athletic Union will be an important event. A number of the men who will face the Britishers in the international games a week from to-day will take part, and the English athletes themselves will look on, having accepted an invitation to witness the sport.

The result of the Assembly District Republican Conventions on Thursday night was variously accepted by Republicans yesterday. All conceded that ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt was the controller of a very large proportion of the delegates to the State Convention. The Platt people themselves were claiming that they would have about 99 of the 135 delegates elected. That they would have from 90 to 100 was generally accepted.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 13. -- The Associated Cycling Clubs of New-Jersey held their monthly meeting at the clubhouse of the Atalanta Wheelmen, 37 Rector Street, last night. Progress was reported by the Committee on Social Intercourse as regards bowling, billiards, and pool. Plans for a stag theatre party in the near future were also discussed.

This is a truly remarkable book, and, in its way, a great one, worthy of instant reading by all to whom the delicately subtile imaginings of a real poet, expressed in a style of picturesque, simplicity and surpassing beauty, have either value or interest.

One of the most mutually surprising things to the Californian in earthquake shocks has been the calmness of the stranger; to the stranger it has been the terror of the Californian. Both were right. For to the stranger the terror of the Californian over a slight jar, a gentle oscillation, and the swaying of the chandelier has been inexplicable.

The jury in the libel suit of President Jeroloman of the Board of Aldermen against Patrick Sarsfield Cassidy failed to agree yesterday. It is said that the members stood seven to five for acquittal. The case will probably soon be tried again.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 13. -- The Republican Senatorial Convention for the Twenty-seventh District adjourned this afternoon after the four hundred and thirty-fourth ballot, to reconvene next Wednesday, no place being named, but with an understanding that it will probably be in Amsterdam.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 13. -- The twenty-ninth annual encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic ended to-night with a ball. Thousands of visitors left the city to-day, but other thousands remained, intending to go to Chattanooga early next week. During the day there was a great barbecue at Wilder Park.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- A large number of spectators was present this afternoon at the Columbian Tennis Club courts to see the finals in men's singles and doubles. In the morning the semi-final matches in both events were played, and Wrenn and Fischer are left to fight it out in the singles. In the doubles the remaining teams were Fischer and Wrenn and Hawes and Pope.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 13. -- The Constitutional Convention's session to-day was one of debate from first to last, practically nothing being accomplished. When the convention met at noon it took up the report of the Committee on Rules. After several chapters had been adopted, the fight came as to whether all resolutions and ordinances presented to the convention should be printed upon introduction or not.

HONOLULU, Sept. 5. -- Owing to the cholera epidemic the catching and sale of fish on this part of the coast ha been prohibited. This has greatly grieved the natives. The old fish market has been demolished for sanitary reasons. All the crowded tenements encroaching on the stream are to be demolished.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- Passed East -Steam yachts Nourmahal, John Jacob Astor; Lorna, W.L. Stow; Shearwater, Edwin D. Morgan; Theresa, Gustavus Sidenburg; Forget-Me-Not, W.H. and G.P. Butler; Helvetia, Columbus O'D. Iselin; Alicia, H.M. Flagler; Orienta, E.R. Ladew; Judy, W.H. Watrous; Columbia, W.C. Whitney; Radha, J. Burke Wolfe; Neckan, Gretchen, John E. Reyburn; Zara, F.G. d'Hauteville; Eugina, John B. Herreshoff; Hermione, Robert Goelet; Ozhester, Charles Bradley; Reverie, F.G. Bourne, and Amadis.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- If ex-Congressman Richard Crowley of Lockport had arrived in Buffalo half an hour earlier this afternoon he might have made a Justice of the Supreme Court.

CORONA, L.I., Sept. 13. -- The Citizens' Club of this village, organized for the purpose of enforcing the Sabbath laws, attempted to hold a mass meeting to-night in Firemen's Hall. The hall was packed to suffocation. The majority of those present indicated by their action that they had gathered for the sole purpose of preventing a meeting, and they succeeded in their purpose.

STAPLETON, S.I., Sept. 13. -- One of the thieves who have recently been operating at Atlantic Highlands was captured at South Beach this morning. Henry Ocherhausen, the proprietor of a hotel at the upper end of the beach, saw two men wading ashore about 6 o'clock from a large catboat that had been run upon the beach.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- It was a matter of common report at the close of the last session of the Legislature that Speaker Fish and the Republican leaders on the floor had arranged junketing trips for an unusually large number of members during the hot weather. Investigations into all manner of topics, from the sweat shops of New-York to the forests of the Adirondacks, were ordered.

The London Athletic Club team was increased by three members yesterday at Berkeley Oval. The new arrivals came down from New-Haven, where they have been training recently with the other members of the Cambridge team. They are Fitzherbert, quarter-mile; Horan, half and three miles; and Mendelsohn, long jump. W.E. Lutyens came down from Yale Thursday, so that the English contingent now at the Oval is a very respectable and vigorous looking lot of athletes.

Your editorial, "Victory -- A Yellow Dog," sets forth, with the vim, snap, and point characteristic of The Times, the yachting status quo. That pesky excursion fleet seems to have caused this undesirable snarl. Although its antics had been foreseen to the fullest extent, no comprehensive provisions for their restraint had, so far as appears, been made.
Republican Assembly District Conventions were held in Kings County last night for the purpose of electing delegates to the Republican State Convention, which is to meet in Saratoga.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13. -- Philadelphia easily defeated New-York this afternoon in a postponed game due in the metropolis. Clarke was knocked out of the box in the fourth inning. Taylor had the visitors guessing in every inning except the fourth. Owing to the uncertainty about playing the game, the attendance was kept down to 4,817. The score:

Mr. Nathan Straus has sold to a Boston firm the old Scotch Presbyterian Church property, at 53 to 59 West Fourteenth Street and 54 and 56 West Fifteenth Street, 95.11 feet on the former and 50 feet on the latter street. The church edifice and a small business building are on the Fourteenth Street front, and a school building is on the Fifteenth Street one.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- A more barefaced steal was never perpetrated upon the Government than that involved in the so-called sugar experiments, which began in 1885. Senator Peffer, unwittingly, was the direct cause of bringing to light all the facts in connection with this fraud upon the public Treasury.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- Clarence Lexow will be renominated for another term. There is opposition to him in this district, comprising the Counties of Rockland and Orange, which is strong in some sections. His record last Winter in the Senate on the New-York Reform bills, when he deliberately tumbled off the high perch which free advertising in the New-York City police investigation had given him, has disgusted many Republicans in the two counties.

Probably there are very few if any towns in Arizona that can boast of the interesting surroundings of Flagstaff. Within a radius of ten miles are to be found the famous cliff dwellings, the beautiful San Francisco peaks, the ancient cave dwellings, and the well-known bottomless pits. Here the every whim of the geologist and philologist can be satisfied.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- The Marine Hospital Service has official information of the progress of the cholera in Japan, 1,076 cases and 717 deaths at Osaka, and 246 cases and 193 deaths at Hiogo being recorded.

YORK, Penn., Sept. 13. -- The convention of the State League of Republican Clubs today expressed unbounded and unflinching loyalty to Senator Quay. This loyalty was expressed in all the speeches. Nobody seemed to think of Gov. Hastings until just before the hour for adjournment, when a resolution indorsing the State administration was declared adopted, though there had been many votes against it.

It happened that to get accurate news of the race between the Defender and the Malkyrie on Saturday put to a supreme test every resource known to journalistic enterprise and skill. The whole world called on the newspaper to follow the yachts thoughout their course, marking their movements minute by minute with the same precision that would be expected in reporting a horse race in progress on land.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 13. -- Forest fires are raging again in this vicinity, consuming everything in their course. A vast amount of valuable timber and game lands have been devastated by the flames. The fire began burning yesterday afternoon at Reega, a short distance from here, and the site of the Hebrew colony recently established by Baron Hirsh of England.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 13. -- A pretty dance took place to-night at Coldbrooke, the country house of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Barnes. It was given for their three daughters, Miss Barnes, Miss Nellie Barnes, and Miss Charlotte Barnes. The dance was the second large dance of the season in Lenox, the first having been given by Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Barclay at Bonnie Brae, last Friday.

The disgraceful contests in some of the Republican Assembly District Conventions in this city and the bitter dissensions in the party in various parts of the State have but one cause -- the "bossism" of Plait. Whatever differences of opinion there may be in the party on questions of policy, local, State, or National, they have nothing to do with these squabbles.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Sept. 13. -- Gen. Eloy Alfaro is to leave Quito in the latter part of September in order to be present at Guayaquil's celebration, Oct. 9, of the victory gained by the patriots for La Honra National. The Government has appropriated 10,000 sucres for the expenses of a public festival.

There was withdrawn from the Sub-Treasury yesterday $4,300,000 in gold coin for shipment to Europe to-day. This makes the total amount withdrawn during the week $7,200,000, the largest sum sent to Europe in one week since the exporting of gold coin assumed an important phase last Winter.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- With all the system which has been established by the Navy Department for ascertaining the fitness of officers and their conduct in the discharge of their duties, it is discovered that an important omission has been made in the method of acquiring this information.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 13. -- Many taxpayers visited Mayor Wanser to-day to explain their views in relation to the water contract. Whether they favored or opposed the project, they had a courteous hearing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- The Navy Department to-day made public its action in the case of Capt. George W. Sumner, late in command of the United States cruiser Columbia. This officer was recently tried by court-martial at the Brooklyn Navy Yard on charges growing out of the injury sustained by his vessel in docking at Southampton in July last.

It was made public yesterday that for some time past some of the New-York banks have been paying gold into the Treasury in exchange for legal-tender notes. Some $900,000 was paid in this way yesterday, while at the same time propositions were received at the Sub-Treasury from banks in Rochester, N.Y., Pittsburg, Penn., and other cities to exchange a million of gold for small notes.

RIO GRANDE, N.J., Sept. 13. -- Of the two abandoned sugar mills here, one was a private affair fostered by the State of New-Jersey and the other was supported by the United States Government as an experiment station for trials in sorghum cane. The Rio Grande Sugar Company was started in 1881 or 1882, and hundreds of acres of farm land were turned into sugar plantations.

Peffer has spoken. If any more bonds are issued by the Secretary of the Treasury, the Kansas statesman is going to advise their repudiation. This is, indeed, a most terrible threat for there call be no doubt that any advice given by Senator Peffer would be followed without hesitation by everybody within hearing distance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- " The war in Cuba will be prosecuted by the Spanish Government to the bitter end. Our national honor demands it. We must protect our subjects in the island who have been loyal to the Crown, who represent nearly all the material interests in Cuba, and to whom the success of the rebels would mean ruination.''
The Engineering and Mining Journal (New-York, July 20) contains the following account of the life of the late John Heard, Jr.:

Written, probably, in a great measure -- though published of course anonymously -- by Ulrich von Hutten, it was at first supposed that the "Epistolae" supported the cause of the monks, and they were received by the Dominicans, the obscuri viri, with great applause. To one who criticised their style they answered, "You should not consider the mere husk of expression, but the energy of the thought."

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 14. -- Miss Ethel Kenny and Miss Bessie Walker of West Orange held a fair this afternoon at the home of Mrs. J.S. Birdsall of Main Street, East Orange, for the benefit of the Home for the Crippled Children of Newark.

French and English yachtsmen will have all the sport they want next season, and the chances are that before it is over several more yachting trophies will keep the America's Cup company at the New-York Yacht Clubhouse.
SING SING, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- The political situation in Westchester County has begun to assume a more definite shape, now that conventions have been held and others are near at hand.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 14. -- Mayor Wanser gave another hearing on the water question to-day. Henry Lembeck of Greenville made an earnest appeal for pure water. He said he had cut short his stay in the country in order to come home and speak on the subject, because he had made up his mind not to build any more houses until the city has a new water supply.

JAMESTOWN, Sept. 14. -- The bitterness which was stirred up when the Republicans held their convention to nominate an Assemblyman in this district may result in an independent candidate taking the field. The convention resulted in the nomination of Jerome Babcock as the Republican candidate. He is running on a free-silver platform.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- Time does not soften the keenness of British chagrin over the outcome of the America's Cup contest. The Field has a few choice expressions which purport to represent the sporting spirit of Great Britain: "Excursion steamers laden with frantic Irish-Americans who do not know a yacht from an oyster boat," and "The New-York press, representing the rabble of excursion steamers."

" Bein' single myself that away," observed the old cattleman, breaking what had been a long period of silence, "females is ondoubted what Doc Peets calls a theery with me. But nevertheless, in an onpresumin', lowly way I gives it as my meager jedgment, an I gives it cold, as how a jealous woman is worse than trantlers.

Prof. Skidmore of Philadelphia, in a course of laboratory lessons to supervising Principals and teachers of the Philadelphia public schools, took up the subject of metals recently. In the course of his lecture he made some interesting remarks in regard to the distinction between minerals and metals. It is not possible, he observed, to define exactly what a metal is, yet there is little liability of mistake in distinguishing a metal from a non-metal.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 14. -- Miss Ella Hobart, who has been appointed by the Connecticut Woman's Union as its missionary representative among the Poles of the West, is a native of Cleveland, Ohio, and was a teacher in the public schools of that city, when she decided to enter the Home' Mission field six years ago.

Bona fide clubs -- social organizations that have not sprung into existence since the enforcement of the excise law -- are not likely to be subjected to inconvenience or surveillance by the police to-day.

The Fall meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club, which was brought to a close with yesterday's racing, furnished a capital afternoon's sport. The Great Eastern Handicap, for two-year-olds, the feature of the card, brought about an exceptionally brilliant contest, four of the thirteen youngsters being heads apart at the finish.
IPSWICH, Sept. 14. -- At to-day's meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science Prof. March of Yale University read a paper in the geological section.

PANAMA, via Galveston, Sept. 14. -- A. C. Love, the alleged defaulter of Texas, whose extradition is the first case under the new treaty between the United States and Colombia, is in custody on board the Colombian Line steamer Advance, which leaves Colon to-morrow.

Ex-Naval Officer Theodore B. Willis, leader of the anti-Worth faction in Brooklyn, is of the opinion that no condition of affairs could exist whereby Mayor Schieren could be induced to take a renomination.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 14. -- A pleasant lawn party was held by the ladies of Montclair Heights on the grounds at Valley Road and Mount Hebron Road, Thursday afternoon, for the benefit of the building fund of the proposed church which is to be built on that site.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- The most important event of the year in the army, aside from administrative acts, affecting the military establishment, is the retirement, on Sept. 29, of Lieut. Gen. John McAllister Schofield, the head of the army. Gen. Schofield's retirement is for age, and is compulsory, as it is with all officers who reach their sixty-fourth year.

The yachting contest for the America's Cup is probably exciting more general interest and enthusiasm, and being given a wider publicity by the press, than any other similar event in the history of navigation. Every detail in the construction and arrangement of both competing yachts is described with all its possible bearing, and innumerable views illustrate the graceful proportions of these boats.

Though I never met Mrs. Gaskell, I have known the original of at least one of her characters, and heard my mother speak of others. The sturdy, upright figure of Capt. Brown stands vividly before me. He was of middle height, with a large head and bull neck, and what an American would call a "chunky" figure, somewhat like a marmot when he goes to sleep for the Winter.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- Passed East -- Steam yachts Sultana, J.R. Drexel; Hirondelle, C.G. Evans; Forget-Me-Not, W.H. and G.P. Butler; Therese, Gustavus Sidenberg; Alicia, H.M. Flagler; Helvetia, Columbus O'D. Iselin; Orienta, E.R. Ladew; Sylvia, Edward M. Brown; Scionda, Alfred W. Booth; Ozhester, Charles Bradley; Marguerite, Guy Loomis; Marion, Edwin D. Fox; Countess, G.H. Stover; Linta, Walter Luttgen: Intrepid, Lloyd Phoenix, and Calypso.

Edward A. Scannell, brother of John J. Scannell, the Tammany leader, and ex-Fire Commissioner, feels badly over the discovery of the box full of old indictments, found a week ago yesterday by attaches of the District Attorney's office. It developed yesterday that among the indictments was one against Scannell for a deadly assault committed Christmas Eve, 1875, on an inoffensive stranger named Henry Wilson.

Philadelphia is making a move toward the correction of a glaring abuse. An ordinance is being introduced in the City Council to prevent the obstruction of street-car lines by coal carts, and probably an amendment will be added to provide that where coal is emptied on the street preliminary to its being taken into the house a clear pathway shall be left on the sidewalk for pedestrians.

Balzac, who knew every phase of Parisian life, begins the longest story of the four found in this volume with a description of the different modes of transportation. The word "coucou," for a vehicle, common in the thirties, is scarcely in use to-day. Once, too, the "grandes messagerie" took under their charge traveling France, but the diligence is even as rare to-day in that country as is the stage coach in the United States.
" Ha, ha! Ha, ha! Ha, ha, ha! Don' you tell a tale like dat, fo' I neber."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 14. -- John Kingdom, thirty-seven years old, arrived here yesterday morning from Indianapolis, en route to his old home in England. He is paralyzed, and the hotels refused to receive him. He was taken to the City Hospital.
BOSTON, Sept. 14. -- Col. John Warren, who was injured by the falling of a piece of stone from the Masonic Temple a few days ago, died to-day.

MOUNTAIN STATION, N.J., Sept. 14. -- Rob Miles beat his younger brother, George, here this afternoon in the closest tennis match played in the Oranges this season. The contest was the final round in the championship tournament of the Orange Tennis Club, and Miles's victory gives him the right to play Duncan Candler for the new Orange Cup.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 14. -- The weather was cold here to-day when play was resumed in the first international inter-university cricket match, which the Philadelphia Cricket Club is managing with considerable success. It did not prevent a good attendance, however, and a large and fashionable gathering was on hand, and many ladies braved the sharp wind which swept across the ground in order to watch the play of their favorites.

CARMEL, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- The Putnam County Republican Convention was held here this afternoon. It was as harmonious as a Quaker meeting. Speaker Hamilton Fish had a field day. He was nominated for the Assembly, selected as a delegate to the Saratoga Convention, chosen a member of the Putnam County Republican Committee, and elected as its Chairman.

The south branch of the Raritan River runs through Clinton, N.J., and along the picturesque Lehigh Valley Railroad. It is famous for its black bass, turtle, and water pilots; and its wooded shores are great resorts for fishing and picnic parties. At Kershaw's Mills there is a large dam, over which superfluous water empties into a sort of raceway.

Within the limits of a peer's electoral possibilities his peerage is, speaking broadly, in his favor. Provincial municipal elections are, perhaps, hardly a goad test. A peer who stands for his County Council almost invariably resides in the county. He spends money there, employs labor, and more or less identifies himself with its interests and doings, especially at Christmas time, and in the matter of coals, blankets, and port wine.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- A dispatch was received at the Navy Department to-day stating that the cruiser Olympia had arrived at Honolulu on the 2d inst., and, finding cholera there, had left for Lahaina, where she will remain for about twenty days to repair her condenser tubes.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Sept. 14. -- Under the leadership of State Chairman James W. Hinkley the Democratic Party in Dutchess County is united and enthusiastic, and there is a hopeful feeling of a favorable result to the campaign this Fall. Two harmonious district conventions were held to-day, at both of which the delegates elected were friends of the Chairman of the State Committee.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 14. -- The official programme of encampment week has exhausted itself, and the visitors from out of town are leaving as fast as the trains can get them away. The great majority is homeward bound, but thousands are going on to Chattanooga for next week's celebration. The Commander in Chief and his predecessor, with their staffs, will pay a visit to Lincoln's birthplace to-morrow.

The members of the St. Andrew's Golf Club held their fifth monthly handicap tournament yesterday, over their club course, near Yonkers, and in number of entries it was one of the largest and best tournament of the handicap series. The scores, however, were not quite up to the usual style of play, although in some individual cases good records were made.

SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 14. -- The annual fair for the benefit of St. Teresa's Church opened in the parochial schoolhouse, Short Hills, this evening, with a large attendance. It will continue for one week.

The Democratic General Committee of Kings County has ratified the agreement formulated by their representatives and those of the Shepard organization. This agreement was that the Shepard organization was to be entitled to one-third representation in the State Convention, two out of the five State Committeemen, and two members on each committee appointed by the State Convention.

WILLET'S POINT, L.I., Sept. 14. -- The United States Engineer Battalion is justly proud of its many possessions. Not the least of these is the big Drum Major who leads the battalion band. Since 1886, when he enlisted in the Engineer Band, the Drum Major has been probably the most conspicuous figure in all the great National parades in New-York City.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- After more than twenty years of controversy, which several times threatened to bring about strained relations between Spain and the United States, a draft for the amount of the indemnity demanded by this Government for the confiscation of the Cuban estates of Antonio Maxima Mora, a naturalized American citizen, was delivered to-day by Senor Dupuy de Lome, the Spanish Minister, to Mr. Adee, the Acting Secretary of State.

The Order B'rith Abraham would furnish much material for an article about the early hardships Jewish secret societies had to encounter here in ante-bellum days, if the early records of the institution could be found; but very little can be ascertained further than that its birth was fraught with struggles that continued for many years thereafter.

One fine day in 1857 the clipper ship Aline, with Reuben Reade as master, sailed into the harbor of New-York, bearing, besides a valuable cargo of Eastern stuffs and wares, the unique assignment of a little Japanese boy, named Togoora, to the owner, James Stuyvesant, a merchant conspicuous for wealth, integrity, and benevolence.

As Mounted Policeman McIver of the West One Hundred and Fifty-second Street Station was riding along Depot Lane, Fort Washington, early yesterday morning, he was surprised to see a lightly-clad man stretched out on the narrow cornice on the fourth story of Raimund von H. Schramm's house.

The question of protecting the picturesque Palisades on the Hudson River from the encroachments of private enterprise which would mar their attractions is in the hands of a joint commission representing the States of New-York and New-Jersey, and suggestions come from various quarters as to the best means of accomplishing the purpose.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Sept. 14. -- Hot Springs is unsurpassed as a Fall resort. Situated at a high elevation, with pure, bracing mountain air and unequaled opportunities offered for mountain climbing and other outdoor exercises, it forms an ideal place for the busy man who has a few weeks' relaxation from his desk.

This life we live is Mr. Pearce's masque. He is a young English writer, who has received a great deal of praise because of his fine imaginative gift and his simple, clear, and correct literary style, but the shadow of pessimism is upon him heavily. Everything that is, is wrong -- that seems to be Mr. Pearce's motto, and the motto of hundreds of young contemporary writers of whom the world takes note.

BERLIN, Sept. 14. -- Herr von Koeller, Prussian Minister of the Interior, returned to Berlin on Thursday from Stettin, where he spent some time in consulting the Kaiser in regard to the formulation of anti-Socialist measures for presentation to the Reichstag at the next session of that body.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- The Catholic conference that is annually held in England under the auspices of the Catholic Truth Society, has hitherto been treated by the press as unworthy of mention. It has this year suddenly assumed the importance of a leading congress. The conference began at Bristol on Monday and terminated on Thursday.

PLAINFIELD, Sept. 14. -- South Avenue, in the direction of Westfield, seems to be the stamping ground of footpads, and they are getting very bold of late, two men, residents of this place, having been stopped last night. In neither case did the highwaymen get any booty.

The merits of Mr. Frederick Breton's romance are unmistakable, though the topics he treats are not pleasing ones, and the story is very much extended. The refrain in the novel, like a leit motif, is a Welsh inscription on a cross: "Heb Dhuw; Heb Dhim. Dhuw; a digon," meaning "Without God, with nothing; with God, with everything," and this saying is constantly repeated.

Here are a baker's dozen and one over of the most refreshing yarns. Colonel Bowlong is a veritable Munchausen. Everybody admires a good liar whose mendacity is free from malice. In the case of Bowlong, one fairly loves him before his second tale is half finished. At first one is inclined to shy at a new volume of East Indian tales.

The making of a new record for long-distance speed on railways by the New-York Central directs attention to the general conditions of railway travel. The record is likely to stand for some time, since it is announced that the Scotch roads, the competition between which gave occasion for the record which has been broken upon the Central, have abandoned racing.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 14. -- It has been so cool here to-day the grate fires are burning in all the cottages and hotels.

The peaches displayed in the markets and on fruit stands yesterday were unusually fine. The cool weather prevented the fruit from becoming too soft and from decaying, and the peaches looked as though they had just been gathered from the trees.

The fact is plain now that while Augustus Thomas's new comedy, or drama, as he prefers to call it; is a very good play, as plays go -- far above the average, indeed, in certain qualities that do not count much in securing the popularity of a play -- yet, it is not quite good enough to outbalance a bad performance.

As an American of 240 years descent, and as an admirer of American fair play and of that British fair play from which it springs, I wish to express my thanks for your editorial, "Victory -- A Yellow Dog," and my admiration for the just, honorable, and impartial attitude of The Times in relation to the outcome of the America's Cup races.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 14. -- Mrs. Dudley S. Miller of Orchard Place went to Asbury Park for a week on Tuesday.

Col. J. Thomas Scharf, who for the last two years has been Inspector of Chinese Immigration at this port, has been transferred by the Secretary of the Treasury to the New-England district. He will be succeeded by Inspector John Finley of Brooklyn, who was Scharf's predecessor. Inspector Finley took charge of the office yesterday.

Peter Styers, whose claim of being the oldest running locomotive engineer in the United States was not disputed, died early Thursday morning at his home in West Bethlehem, of gangrene, hastened by paralysis. He railroaded for nearly half a century, and ran a locomotive for nearly forty-six years. In all this time he was never in collision, and was the cause of no accident.

Mrs. Maggie Hamilton, the woman in whose house at 336 East Sixty-sixth Street, thousands of dollars worth of household goods, , were found, with Thomas, her husband, was arraigned in Yorkville Court yesterday morning.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- Although arrivals are still quite numerous, the end of the season is close at hand. It will long be remembered as the most prosperous season in the history of Adirondack resorts.

A family whose head is a citizen of the United States and who claim that they were despoiled by Spanish officials of all their property in Havana, and were brutally treated, are living at 201 East Fifty-sixth Street, this city.
I shall never forget the dismay with which many of us heard Huxley's paper on the question, "Has the frog a soul, and of what nature is that soul, supposing it to exist?"
Litigation in the case of the defunct Madison Square Bank promises to be resumed on an extensive scale.

All manner of extravagant ideas were contemplated at what would be in store when the train reached Loveland. Extravagant as they were, all of them were short of realization. The people of that town had gone to no end of trouble. Within a hundred yards of the station. In the shade of long rows of cottonwood trees, tables had been constructed, and along these were arrayed great heaps of eatables.

Much has been said and written about Boston's new Public Library, but much more remains to be described. The beautiful structure and its valuable and artistic contents will doubtless furnish many a theme for years to come to discuss and to write about. The local pride of the true son of Massachusetts is great, but in this case it is most pardonable.

The possession of the ballot has not purified the male voter from the heinous sin of a sold vote. Why should it purify the woman? It is a well-known fact that, in all our large cities, there is a great body of women who sell themselves, soul and body. It is idle to stop and say that men are responsible for this horror. I have no desire to screen men.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 14. -- It has been an exceedingly pleasant week in Lenox, the only drawback being the excessive heat of the early part of the week, which made it rather too warm for outdoor sports. This was especially the case on Wednesday, when the mercury approached 90. It cooled off a little on Thursday, however, and the rest of the week has been delightful.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- The naval Surgeons have perfected the rules which will govern the treatment and care of the disabled in time of action on board ship. The method of transporting those who are disabled is a matter of great importance, and cannot always be easily and rapidly done in times of excitement.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- The Republican Convention of Chemung County was held in the village of Horseheads this afternoon, and resulted in a genuine love feast. This probably was due largely to the overwhelming victory of ex-Senator J. Sloat Fassett in the Republican primaries Friday night.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- The execution of Mr. Stokes, the British African trader, who was hanged by Major Lothaire, an officer of the Congo Free State, on the charge of selling arms and ammunition to the natives, continues to occupy considerable space in the newspapers. It is probable that on his return to Brussels Major Lothaire will be tried for the murder of Mr. Stokes.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Sept. 14. -- A chronicle of events in this village these September days reads very much the same from day to day. The weather is simply perfection, and the roads seem to grow better with the constant use. Mr. and Mrs. J. Lee Tailer, Mr. and Mrs. John Townsend, and Dr. and Mrs. Charles C. Ransom find something to do in driving over to the Otsego Golf Club and practicing upon the links.

Frank Sorowowsky, who killed John Kospercikofsky ten days ago in the former's saloon, at 18 Meadow Street, Bayonne, N.J., was arrested in Flatlands yesterday morning. He was committed to Raymond Street Jail by Justice Ford.

A famous trial for murder will be held this Fall at Caldwell, Kan., and all the old-timers of the border who have escaped death at the hands of adversaries or the hangman will be there either as witnesses or as spectators. Thereby hangs a record of killings that has few equals in Western history. In 1881 Jim Talbet was the dashing king of the Kansas and Indian Territory outlaws.
President Wilson of the Health Board said yesterday, in reference to the discovery of diluted milk in the Straus depots, that the analyses by Chief Chemist Martin had not been completed.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 14. -- The prophecy made in June that the season at Bar Harbor would be a brilliant one has certainly been fulfilled. In spite of the fact that a large number of society people who Summer regularly at this fashionable resort spent the warm season in Europe this year, Bar Harbor was full of life and gayety, and was favored with one of the most successful seasons in its history.

KINGSTON, Sept. 14. -- The Republican convention for the First Assembly District of Ulster County, held in Kingston to-day, resulted disastrously to the present political prospects of Deputy Attorney General G.D.B. Hasbrouck. Of the thirty or more delegates present, only about nine were Hasbrouck men.

Favorable reports are being received by members of the Inter-State Commission regarding the condition of Judge Veazey of Vermont, and it is expected that he will be back at his desk within a month, or at least by the 1st of November. He is now at Springfield, Vt., where he is greatly enjoying the country air, after the beneficial effects of several weeks at the Isle of Shoals.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- If money constitutes the modern sinews of war, the Spanish monarchy is in a poor condition to accomplish the subjugation of Cuba. Spanish finances have shown a constantly recurring deficit for a long period of years; the currency is upon a depreciated paper basis, and the Government suffers a heavy loss in the payment of interest on its obligations held abroad because of the unfavorable exchanges.

WEST POINT, Sept. 14. -- It has been a quiet week here. The death of Cadet Butterly cast a gloom over the whole corps. He stood well in his class, and was very popular. A soldier's funeral was given him.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- The Tompkins County Republican Convention to-day nominated Frederick E. Bates of Caroline for member of the Assembly, W.E. Brown of Dryden for School Commissioner, Second District; John W. Brown of Ithaca and Ransom Johnson of Caroline for Coroners.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- The first week in October will witness a gathering in Washington that will mark the most important epoch that Roman Catholic educational interests in this country have ever known. During this week the largest Eucharistic Congress ever held in the United States will be convened in the new St. Matthew's Church.

WEST ISLIP, L.I., Sept. 14. -- The wealth and fashion of the Summer colony of the south side of Long Island were never seen to better advantage than at the first carnival of the South Shore Country Club, held at the new grounds this afternoon, when about 1,000 of the members of the first families of New-York and Brooklyn society gathered there to witness a programme of athletic sports.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 14. -- The smallest attendance of the year was that at the Waltham meet in the National Circuit. Cabanne defeated Bald in the half-mile open race, the most exciting event of the day. Rain fell during the afternoon, and the mile open race in Class B was run in a storm of small proportions. Owing to the cold, the men appeared in full racing suits.
COLON, Colombia, Sept. 14. -- The freight traffic of the Panama Railroad has increased to 30,000 tons a month.
ALBANY, Sept. 14. -- Catechism of the State Civil Service Oounisslon:

The man -- you knew him by his first name only -- was Evelyn, and he was on a Peninsular and Oriental steamer on the way to Marseilles.

LONDON, Sept. 7. -- Hall Caine's forthcoming visit across the Atlantic will introduce to Americans by far the most striking and interesting personality to be found among British men of letters. The craft of writing, as it is followed in these islands, does not, somehow, tend to promote individual characteristics and markings.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 14. -- Any one who has visited New-Haven during the last ten days could hardly have failed to be impressed with the fact that something unusual was on foot, and if he had a photographic camera with him when he boarded the first street car there are ten chances to one that the conductor would have asked him: "Are you looking for the Englishmen?"
" Oh, teacher, I forgot. I thought I was home."

When Mr. Hubert Besils came down to Culverly in North Kent for recreation, having had his health broken down by overwork, he had hoped to find rest in the house rented of the vicar.
All schools in the city which give either academic or graduate instruction to women report increased registration and a bright outlook for the approaching collegiate year.

EGG HARBOR CITY, Sept. 14. -- The forest fires are still raging in the vicinity of this place, but there has not been as much headway made by the flames as was feared last night, owing to the heoric efforts of the volunteers in fighting them. However, the danger is by no means past, and the firemen continue back-firing.

Later on the conversation around me reached my understanding, charged with droll significance.

It may be fairly stated that Cuba has been in a state of more or less active or constant slumbering revolution ever since the period during which the Spanish-American Colonies achieved their independence. The first serious effort was made in the year 1822, when the aid of Simon Bolivar was sought by the Cubans.

Renting has been the most conspicuous feature in real estate dealings during the last week. The business in it has been on the whole most encouraging. The demand for dwellings, especially in the central part of the city, between Madison Square and the Central Park, has been greater than the supply.

STAPLETON, S.I., Sept. 14. -- The Richmond County Republican Convention was held here this afternoon, and delegates were elected to the State Senatorial and Judicial District Conventions. There is a very small anti-Platt contingent in the county, and with but one exception the delegates to the State Convention are avowed Platt men.

The breaking of ground for the new Brooklyn Museum of Art and Sciences, on Prospect Hill, took place yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock, under the auspices of officials of the city and the institution, and in the presence of many prominent citizens.

We published on the 7th inst. a letter from Mr. Sidney H. Preston of London, in which he referred to a "romantic paragraph" which had recently appeared in certain American newspapers to the effect that "an enormous fortune of $400,000,000, the accumulated property of one James Holmes, and the largest undivided estate in the world," is about to be distributed.

SARATOGA, Sept. 14. -- Thomas C. Platt did not reach his hotel until after 9 o'clock to-night. He went at once to his cottage and afterward to the dining room, from which he did not emerge till about 10 o'clock. On the same train that brought Platt were others of the advance guard of the Republican State Convention.

One of the arguments in favor of international sporting contests of any kind is that they promote international good feeling. We are at present in possession of a curious and interesting commentary upon that view.

A sharp September wind, that had a suggestion of nettles in it when it hit the faces of people in the grand stands, blew across the Manhattan Field yesterday during the time that the annual games of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States were in progress.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 14, -- Society has had a very monotonous week of it, with little to do but to drive, attend French lectures, and talk. A dearth of men has been the secret of the very tedious conditions, which will greatly improve now that the yacht races, the magnet that drew them all to New-York, are over. The week's festivities consisted only of ladies' luncheons and children's parties.

Some months ago we referred to the preparations made for the collection throughout Germany of statistics relating to the use and effect of diphtheria antitoxine. The statistics available up to that time had been, with few exceptions, those furnished by hospitals in Berlin and two or three other German cities, Vienna, Paris, and New-York.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- A convention of Republican delegates from the First Assembly District of Orange County was called to meet in this city to-day for the purpose of electing delegates to the State and Judicial Conventions. It proved to be a Presidential nominating convention, and B.B. Odell, Jr., Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Republican State Committee, named Levi P. Morton as the Presidential nominee.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 15. -- Late to-night it was said at the Casino that it had been arranged that the Defender and the Valkyrie should race over the Newport course, and that Lord Dunraven had telegraphed Capt. Cranfield to stop the work of preparing the Valkyrie for sea.

A deposition was received Saturday by Herant M. Kiretchjian, General Secretary of the Armenian Relief Association, from Mrs. Mariam Haroyan, a well-connected Armenian lady from a city of Upper Armenia, concerning the security of Armenians in the cities, as compared with the villages. She said:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- It is believed at the Treasury Department that the receipts this month will surpass those of August, and that the Government will very soon be upon a self-supporting basis. The receipts for the first fourteen days of September have reached $13,197,176, and this is a more favorable showing than appears on its face.

While the band was playing on the Mall in Central Park yesterday Thomas Smiley, a bookkeeper of 322 Fifth Street, suddenly turned to W.S. Scossel of 629 Garden Street, Hoboken, who stood behind him, and said:

The full story of how a gang of six professional thieves have robbed this city of upward of $5,000, and throughout the Union have secured nearly $25,000 within two years, by pillaging mail boxes, became known to Acting Chief of Detectives O'Brien yesterday by the confession of one of the members of the gang who was arrested Saturday after a long and anxious search.

The editorial comments on the cup races in your issue of yesterday and the reportorial remarks of to-day lead me to give you the expression of my views of the situation as briefly as possible. There seems to me to be a very general misunderstanding of the rights of the contestants and the powers of the committees in the minds of newspaper men.

At the celebration of Winthrop's landing, at Beverly, the fire needed for the clambake was produced by skillful artists who rubbed sticks against each other, as is said to be the manner of savages. There is no doubt that the gentlemen who planned the entertainment had excellent historical authority for reproduucing this process.
A drop of 49 in 48 hours is the newest local event.

Ex-President Harrison had a very quiet time yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. In the afternoon he went out for a drive, and after dinner he called on his daughter-in-law, Mrs. Russell B. Harrison, who is at the Windsor. He remained with her until after 10 o'clock, when he returned to the Fifth Avenue.

SARATOGA, Sept. 15. -- The sentiment of the most prominent Republicans who have come here to attend the State Convention is in favor of taking the cowardly position of dodging on the excise question. The problems created by Commissioner Roosevelt are too much for the statesmen who are here. They would like to make a declaration which would satisfy both the cities and the country, but cannot do it.

ANNAPOLIS, Sept. 15. -- The Naval Academy, which has the only system of salt-water supply in this country, if there be any other in the world, is enlarging its plant by placing in the power house an engine and pump capable of giving 1,000 gallons of water a minute. This doubles the capacity of the plant, and enables the supply to continue in ease of accident to one set of pumps.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.J., Sept. 15. -- The villages of Bakersville and Bargaintown, which were threatened by extensive forest fires last night, have been saved by gangs of men working all night and to-day setting back fires. Some valuable cranberry bogs were burned. Another fire started at 4 o'clock this afternoon four miles above here, and is now sweeping toward McKee City, which seems to be in imminent danger.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 14. -- The demand of The New-York Times for a ship canal from Lake Erie to the Hudson has excited a great deal of attention here, and the successive articles on the subject have been widely read and discussed. Perhaps nowhere on the lakes are the questions affecting the improvement of the outlet to the sea so thoroughly comprehended and so broadly treated as in Cleveland.

It is a pity to have a beautiful lyric tampered with for the sake of a song, and yet we would have lost cue of the loveliest songs that was ever sung if Burns had not tinkered with "Ye Banks and Braes o' Bonnie Doon." The two syllables added to each alternate line are printed in parentheses:

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- Lord Dunraven yesterday cabled to Mr. Grant, Secretary if the Royal Yacht Squadron, the correspondence between himself and the New-York Yacht Club on the events in connection with the contests for the America's Cup, at the same time expressing a desire that the correspondence be published in England.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 15. -- Yachts sailing to-day are: Steamers Valiant, William K. Vanderbilt, and schooner Intrepid, George W. Weld.
HAVANA, Sept. 15. -- The steamer Colon arrived here this morning with reinforcements for the troops. The newly arrived soldiers were given an enthusiastic reception.

BERLIN, Sept. 15. -- The military experts who have just returned from participation in the annual manoeuvres at Stettin are unanimous in their praise of the masterly Generalship of Count von Waldersee, who reversed the whole programme and snatched unforeseen advantages from the Kaiser himself.
PORT RICHMOND, S.I., Sept. 15. -- Five hundred persons assembled in the Prohibition Park auditorium this afternoon to hear an address by Terence V. Powderly on "The Gospel and the Labor Problem."

There is a soldier in Troop G of the Second Cavalry, at Fort Vlngate, who bears the distinction of being the best shot in the United States Army. I-r is sergt. Henry Henser, and, not only is he a thorough cavalryman in every sense of the word, a perfect carbine and pistol shot, but he has had some adventures that few men would have lived through.

WATERFORD, N.J., Sept. 15. -- A terrific fire is destroying thousands of acres of cedar swamps near here to-night. This is the fire that has been burning in the Jackson meadows for the past two weeks, and which has destroyed at least $60,000 worth of property.

Flames shot out of a window in the second floor of Marsh, White Co.'s big grain elevator, on Quay Street and the East River, Greenpoint, shortly before 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Day Watchman Patrick Lennon and Night Watchman Peter Smith were standing together outside of the building.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- Fire early this morning destroyed the magnificent barn and outbuildings owned by John D. Rockefeller, the Standard Oil magnate, which were situated on the Bedford Road, near Pocantico Hills.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 15. -- The churches were filled to overflowing to-day, but the congregations found them almost too cool for comfort. Doubtless some attended Divine worship expecting to catch a glimpse of Lord Dunraven, but he came not, spending the morning driving with his host, Frederick W. Vanderbilt was in her pew at Old Trinity, with Lady Boyd, her guest. They took a drive this afternoon.

The American Line steamship Paris, which reached Quarantine Saturday night, many hours behind her usual time, came up to her pier early yesterday morning. Leaky boiler tubes had been the principal cause of delay, and a heavy southwest gale of thirty-two hours' duration had done its share to extend the journey of the ship.

TRENTON, Sept. 15. -- The Republican camp has been turned into a Donnybraok Fair. Many ordinarily peaceful Republicans are going about banging heads in the most belligerent sort of way. The fight is the most intense that New-Jersey Republicans have ever had, and the grand finale will take place next Thursday, when the State Convention is held.

We may be pardoned for some impatience over the lapse of time since our Government has called for the detailed account of the trial of an American citizen and ex-Consul in Madagascar which it has not yet received. Nothing is clearer in international law than the right of a Government to satisfy itself, when one of its citizens has been condemned and punished in a foreign country, that he has had a fair trial.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- Pew men o importance o-ame to the city to-day. Trains were infrequent. Those who came last night, however, were a busy lot. tir. Fiatt's rooms were occupied all day by men prominent in the party, who came to windLup what he wanted done.

The funeral of Edwin C. Odell, from his late home 159 Eleventh Street, Brooklyn, was interrupted twice yesterday afternoon through the agency of Mrs. Rose Dowling of 265 Seventeenth Street, who secured a divorce from Mr. Odell twelve years ago.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Sept. 15. -- Peter N. Dow found the body of a young mulatto woman lying in a clump of bushes twenty feet from the river road this morning. Dow at once notified County Physician Wagoner, and a large crowd went to the scene of the tragedy.

The thirty-third annual Cannstatter Volksfest came to a successful close yesterday at Sulzer's Harlem River Park. There were no indications of the excise drought at the Fest, for all who had the desire could have their thirst quenched without any trouble. The attendance was at least 8,000.

Two youthful highwaymen were arrested last evening on Pier No. 7 East River, where they were engaged in robbing three smaller boys who stood with their hands held high while their pockets were being rifled.

EGG HARBOR CITY, N.J., Sept. 15. -- The situation at this place is practically unchanged. The forest fire which has been threatening the town for days stills hovers around it, and a shift of the wind may drive the flames from the forest and the swamps to the town. The fire bell rang at frequent intervals last night, and several times today the men were called on to gather to fight the threatening flames.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 15. -- The end of the first week of the session of the Constitutional Convention has come. Five days' work has been done in complete harmony, and with absolute freedom from utterances of a political savor. It is remarkable that 160 South Carolina political leaders should be together in the same hall for a whole week, discussing all kinds of political matters, without letting politics come into the proceedings in any way.

During the fourteen days' racing of the Coney Island Jockey Club, 84 races were run, in which 286 horses competed. The total amount divided among horse owners was $153,875, of which sum Col. W.P. Thompson Sons of the Brookdale Stable received $4,000, J. Nagler Burke of the Pueblo Stable $2,500, and J.B. Haggin of Rancho del Paso $1,000, as the breeders of the horses that were placed in the Futurity.
The Democrats of Kings County were jubilant yesterday over the result of the conference that brought around harmony between the regular and reform organizations.
Patrolman Rose of the Gates Avenue Station, Brooklyn, is a rash man. What he did yesterday may get him into trouble with his superiors.

During the last two weeks the crude-iron market, especially in the Pittsburg district, has been in a condition of great excitement, and the price of Bessemer pig at Pittsburg and the valley furnaces has advanced about $2.50 per ton, or nearly 17 per cent. The entire advance since the end of March has been 70 per cent., and the price of Bessemer pig has not been so high since 1890.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Sept. 15. -- The following Australian advices to The United Press have been received per steamship Miowera:

The funeral services over the body of the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Hall, who, for twenty-six years, was rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn, which were held yesterday afternoon and evening, were largely attended, as the Rev. Dr. Hall was one of the leading clergymen in Brooklyn.
