Spruce IV. had more distinguished visitors yesterday than she had ever dreamed of in the seclusion of her Solent home. She lay on the ways at Abram's yard, at Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., shining in two coats of varnish and a new rubbing of the best English potlead, and "Tom" Wade, her crew and keeper, stood by to do the honors.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14. -- The pardon of a large number of prominent exiles by the Hawaiian Government, and the probable release of ex-Queen Liliuokalani from her prison in the royal palace, has led some to believe that the population of Hawaii is not so strongly in favor of the republic now as it was.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 15. -- Twenty thousand dollars' worth of diamonds and jewelry set with other precious stones is missing from the cottage of II. Victor Newcombe, a quarter of a mile below the Elberon Hotel. It is uncertain how the stuff was taken. It was there on Saturday evening at 5 o'clock, when Mrs. Newcombe had occasion to go to her jewel casket to take out an ornament she wished to wear.

Alfred S. Jaffe, forty-five years old and a widower, killed himself with carbolic acid yesterday at 142 Lexington Avenue, while a policeman who had arrested him on a warrant which charged grand larceny waited for him to dress and go away with him.

The ride to Boston via Albany, Williamstown, and Fitchburg is in every way the most picturesque of any of the routes which it is possible to take, but it is at the same time, more difficult, owing to the character of the road surface as well as to the many hills which have to be surmounted.
Col. George E. Waring, Jr., Commissioner of Street Cleaning, has taken apartments for the Fall and Winter in Rutherfurd House, at Eleventh Street and Second Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- The death of Prof. C.V. Riley, late Entomologist of the Agricultural Department, which occurred at a late hour last night as the result of a fall from his bicycle, as previously mentioned in these dispatches, not only closed the career of a scientist of international reputation, but completed a triad of fatal accidents which this city has unfortunately suffered in connection with the three most popular athletic sports of America.

Racegoers generally regret that the racing at the Sheepshead Bay track is at an end for the year. The course is probably the most popular in America. The sport is always of the best. as the management makes it a point to cater only for the best of the horses in training, leaving the riffraff among the racers to look out for themselves and eat oats if they cannot win races.

It is lamentable that the decent people of Corona, the people who object to having that pleasant little Long Island village made a Sunday resort for gangs of drunken ward heelers and other howling ruffians and criminals, should have allowed their mass meeting to be broken up Friday night by the resident thugs over whom, only a week ago, they gained such a signal victory.

The assemblage which is gathering at Saratoga, and which will to-morrow resolve itself into a convention to nominate candidates for State offices and to declare the principles of a political party, will be made up of delegates nominally representing the Republican voters of this State.

Dr. Chauncey M. Depew, who was a passenger on the American Liner Paris, which arrived at Quarantine late Saturday night, was brought to the city early yesterday morning on the steamer Edgerton. He landed at the foot of West Forty-second Street, where he was met by his carriage, went to the Grand Central Station, and was conveyed thence by a special train to Dobbs Ferry.

Madagascar's Queen, was brought up in poverty, in an unknown village, by a country butcher, her uncle, who sold to peasants third grade meats. Yet she was the niece of the reigning Queen, Ranavalo II. Her aunt detested her and would do nothing for her. The only service that she even rendered eo her was to die.

Much interest has been aroused among the members of the Maritime Association of the Port of New-York, more familiarly known as the Maritime Exchange, concerning the editorial article that recently appeared in the columns of The New-York Times advocating the construction of a ship canal between Lake Erie and the Hudson, rather than the proposed immediate expenditure of $9,000,000 on lengthening the locks and deepening the Erie, Champlain, and Oswego Canals.

Marcus R. Mayer, the theatrical agent and business representative in this country for George Edwardes, arrived on the Paris yesterday. He comes back with some fresh importations. The George Edwardes's attractions, which Mr. Mayer will represent, will be given here under the exclusive management of Charles Frohman and Al Hayman.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 15. -- Thomas Larkins, fourteen years old, a brother of James Larkins, the ex-champion of the Scottish-American Athletic Club, was found dead this morning in a cave in a vacant lot on Montgomery Street, near Monmouth Street.
Interest in the enforcement of the Sunday clause of the excise law was yesterday shifted by common consent from the saloons to the clubs.

The "regular," or "machine," Democratic Committee of Kings County on Saturday evening ratified, with only two dissenting votes, the agreement with the committee of the "Shepard" Democrats as to representation in the State Convention. This agreement is in complete accord with the suggestion made by The Times immediately after the meeting of the State Committee last month.

" The Ethics of a Yacht Race" was the subject of a prelude to the sermon of the Rev. Cortland Myers, in the basement of the new First Baptist Church, Third Avenue and Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, last night. Probably 1,000 persons were present.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 15. -- Wallace Brothers of Statesville, the largest dealers in medicinal herbs in the world, have assigned. They have been in business thirty-six years. Pressure by certain creditors caused the assignment. The indebtedness approximates $200,000, and is said to be fully covered by assets.

SARATOGA, Sept. 16. -- Nearly all the details of the convention's routine have been agreed upon. The arrangements at the convention hall have been completed. Tickets were issued to-night by Chief Clerk Reuben Fox of the State Committee. There will be plenty of room for all, far there is not much of a crowd outside of delegates and alternates.

ELBERON, N.J., Sept. 16. -- The robbery of $20,000 worth of diamonds, rubies, and emeralds from the cottage of H. Victor Newcomb on Saturday afternoon is almost the sole topic of discussion here. The robbery is still a mystery as to who committed it. The robbery was committed on Saturday afternoon, between probably 3 and 5 o'clock.

SARATOGA, Sept. 16. -- A most striking feature in many of the groups that crowded the lobby of the United States Hotel to-day was Edward Lauterbach. He was illuminated beautifully. On the background of the sombrely clad groups of chatting statesmen, he looked like a patch of rainbow on a bank of storm clouds.

SARATOGA, Sept. 10. -- One of the side issues of the day developed in the Fassett headquarters. It has been known for some time that it is the wish of T. B. Platt that E. C. Stewart of Tompkins be nominated in the Fortieth (Tompkins, Broome, and Chemung) District, for the Senate. This district adjoins Mr. Platt's stamping ground, and he has been desirous of conferring some political favors upon Mr. Stewart.

The New-York State Democracy held its primary elections last night in the various Assembly districts. The elections were to select members of the Assembly District Committees, and also delegates to the following conventions: Assembly District Convention, to nominate a candidate for Assembly; Senatorial Convention, County Convention; Congressional (Tenth and Fourteenth Districts), and Assembly District Convention, next Thursday night, to elect delegates to the State Democratic Convention at Syracuse.

The Brighton Beach Association race meeting, which began yesterday, is as yet anything but a success. The attendance was very small, and the racing tame, there being but one close finish. The only pleasing feature of the sport was that four of the favorites were returned winners.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16. -- An unlooked for and totally unexpected result was reached here to-day at the conclusion of the International Intercollegiate cricket game on the grounds of the Philadelphia Cricket Club. The University of Pennsylvania team scored a victory over the Cambridge and Oxford team by 100 runs.

John Jeroloman, President of the Board of Aldermen, appeared before the Board of Excise yesterday as prosecuting counsel in the case against John S. Tekulsky, brother of Morris Tekulsky, against whom a complaint for the revocation of his license is pending.

CITY ISLAND, Sept. 16. -- Passed East -- Steam yachts Oneida, E.C. Benedict; Helvetia, Columbus O'D. Iselin; Lorna, W.L. Stow; Cosette, F.L. Osgood; Formosa, George F. Fabyan; Alicia, H.M. Flagler, and Orienta, E.R. Ladew; schooner yacht Elsemarie, J.B. King.

MONTREAL, Sept. 16. -Sir Henry Irving opened his American tour at the Academy of Music, in this city, to-night. The opening production was "Faust," in live acts, adapted from the first part of Goethe's tragedy, by W. G. Wills. It met with a flattering reception.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Sept. 16. -- There has been trouble for some time between the officials of the Central Railroad and the oyster shippers at Bivalve, a small place near here, and the result is that a boycott has been declared against the railroad company. There are twenty-two shippers of oysters at Bivalve, and all but three have withdrawn their patronage from the Central Road.

ALBANY, Sept. 16. -- The American Fire Insurance Company of New-York to-day certified to the Secretary of State that it had increased its capital stock from $200,000 to $400,000. The amount of the company's capital paid in is $200,000, and the whole amount of the company's debts and liabilities is $326,517.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 16. -- The primaries for the election of delegates from Essex County to the Republican Gubernatorial Convention, to be held at Trenton next Thursday, took place to-night, and were the most exciting held in years. Only three of the candidates, Elias S. Ward, John Kean, and John W. Griggs, figured here, and in the order named. Griggs carried all the temperance strongholds, and Ward carried everything else in the county.

-- Bellows-Litchfield Wedding. -- Miss Elizabeth Litchfield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Backus Litchfield of this city, will be married to-morrow at Blythebourne, L.I., to Charles Bellows. The ceremony is to take place at 4:30 o'clock P.M., in the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. John, the Rev. Robert B. Snowden officiating.

LONDON, Sept. 16. -- Admiral Montagu, a noted yachtsman, owner of the Carina, has written a letter which The Times will publish to-morrow, approving Lord Dunraven's conduct throughout. He admits that the New-York Yacht Club did all it could to insure fair sailing, but it was powerless.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Two poor exhibitions of baseball were given here to-day. The home team fielded like amateurs all the way through, but managed to win the first game by heavy batting. Brooklyn won the second game on account of the ineffective twirling of Anderson, Malarky, and Boswell. The fielding of the visitors was brilliant. The scores:

The Valkyrie and Defender, the owners of these two yachts, and the committees of the New-York Yacht Club are still discussed in yachting circles, and, in fact, all over the town. The last letter issued by Lord Dunraven to the America's Cup Committee threw a little more light on the whole trouble, and the feeling now is stronger than ever that a little tact and good judgment would have averted the whole trouble.
Mr. Max Marx has sold, to D. Lewi, the three-story and basement dwelling 534 West One Hundred and Forty-eighth Street, 17 by 55 by 100.

A recent construction of the provisions of the alien contract labor law has caused some excitement among the representatives of the foreign insurance companies doing business in this city. The decision was made in response to a letter written to the Secretary of the Treasury, in which the following questions were asked:

The football season at Manhattan College was formally opened yesterday by thirty-five candidates reporting for active training. With the majority of last year's team back, and some promising new material to select from, a strong team will be put in the field. The enclosed full field is being leveled and put into regular football trim.

The General Committee of the Democratic Party in Kings County met at the Athenaeum in Brooklyn, last night, and ratified unanimously the agreement reached by their conference committee last Thursday with the conference committee of the regulars, in reference to representation in the State Convention and in the State Committee.

SARATOGA, Sept. 16. -- The Assembly Judiciary Committee engaged in investigating the charges brought by certain residents of Mount Vernon against George C. Appell, Judge of the City Court of that place, met at the United States Hotel this afternoon.

LONDON, Sept. 16. -- The London and Edinburgh Steamship Company's steamer Iona, plying between Leith and London, caught fire on her trip to Gravesend this morning. The fire started in the cabin. Five women and one child, passengers, and the stewardess were burned to death. A number of others were badly burned and otherwise injured.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16. -- The steamer City of Rio Janeiro arrived from the Orient via Honolulu this morning. She is now in quarantine, no communication whatever being allowed with the shore. She brings only one passenger, a Mrs. Bacon, from Honolulu. It is believed the steamer will be promptly released from quarantine, as she has been out from Honolulu eight days, with no sickness aboard.

Our Paris correspondent telegraphs: The Gaulois, having repeated the charge against Count Nigra of having urged the Empress Eugenie to fly from Paris on the 4th of September, is thus corrected by the Count: "The part I played was simple. Knowing the Government of Napoleon III. was going to be overthrown, I went early on the 4th of September to the Tuileries to be at the orders of the Empress.

SARATOGA, Sept. 16. -- The leaders of the Republican Party in this State to-day decided to dodge the excise issue. These leaders made this record because of the cowardice of Thomas Platt or his lack of ability to grapple with the question. The record was made at the dictation of a "boss" ever ready to subordinate the moral ideas of his party to the policy of a politician.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16. -- The narrow-loom rug weavers employed on piece work in John Bromley Son's mill, on Lehigh Avenue, announce that an increase of 10 per cent. in wages has been voluntarily granted them by the firm, to go into effect on Wednesday. The amount of the increase was taken from the wages of the weavers about a year ago.

Christian Fuers, sixteen yeaxs old, escaped from the New York Juvenile Asylum, One Hundred and Seventieth Street and Tenth Avenue, nearly a year ago, and since then has worked for a lithographer at 138 Centre Street.

A delegation of the North Side Board of Trade, headed by Senator Charles L. Guy and Tax Commissioner Wells, called upon Mayor Strong yesterday to protest against a resumption of the use of Riker's Island as a common dumping ground for the refuse of the city.

It was rumored in Brooklyn cycling circles yesterday that Chairman Gideon of the Racing Board of the League of American Wheelmen would reach that city today and immediately start gunning for Class A men who ought to figure in Class B. The statement is said to have caused considerable uneasiness among the racing men, particularly those who are alleged to have had incidental expenses paid by their clubs.
SARATOGA, Sept. 16. -- One of the conceits of Addison B. Colvin --

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 16. -- The marriage was announced here this evening of ex-Freeholder Justus Morris, aged seventy-four, to his housekeeper, Miss Annie Hergert, aged twenty-two. Justus Morris is a prominent Republican and a large real estate owner in Elizabeth. He is estimated to be worth $150,000.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 16. -- Congressman Josiah Patterson has returned from another tour of sound-money speechmaking that carried him as far east as Saratoga, returning by way of Washington. He was in the latter city last Thursday. Referring to an interview with Secretary Carlisle, the Congressman said to-day:

The letter published yesterday in which Lord Dunraven justifies his withdrawal from further competition for the America's Cup, after losing one race by a clear defeat and one by an adverse decision after a foul in which the American boat was crippled, has less weight of matter in it than was fairly to be expected.

Every morning for more than a week a little band of athletes has issued from the Berkeley Oval cottage at Morris Heights at about 11 o'clock and made its way to the dressing-rooms near the cinder track. It represents that body of the London Athletic Club team which does not also belong to the Cambridge University team, and contains some of the best-known men in English athletic circles.

We have more than once presented reasons which seemed to us conclusive why the excise law of this State has no sort of application to clubs, but the subject continues to excite interest and to invite discussion, and some persons go so far as to rake up judicial decisions under some other law or in relation to some other point, in order to bolster up an untenable position.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 16. -- Justice Magle of the Supreme Court filed his opinion in the case to-day testing the constitutionality of the Voorhees elective judiciary law. He dissents radically from the opinion of Justices Van Syckel and Lippincott, who, in their decision a few days ago, pronounced the act unconstitutional.

SARATOGA, Sept. 16. -- There has been a scurrying all day among the friends of four or five men, each of whom wants to be the candidate for the place on the Court of Appeals bench. This has been the only place for which any canvass has been made.

SARATOGA, Sept. 16. -- Controller James W. Roberts, who is enough of an anti-Platt man to have been the cause of the original talk of "smashing the slate," reached this town about noon. His advance guard and manager of his boom, Deputy Controller Morgan, came Sunday night and had surveyed the field a few hours when his chief arrived.

A large meeting of the creditors of the firm of Bernheim, Bauer Co., which deals in clothing at 6 to 12 West Third Street, was held yesterday at the Broadway Central Hotel, with Walter Stanton as Chairman and Harry Dun as Secretary.

The fine question whether or not a husband is justified in getting drunk when his wife makes things unpleasant for him and her sister insists on staying at his house as a permanent guest, against his will, was submitted yesterday to Judge Beekman, in the Supreme Court.

SARATOGA, Sept. 16. -- Some of the Republicans in this camp refuse to take to the woods on the excise question. While the action of Mr. Platt's conference last night is bolstered up by a host of warriors who declare that it will spoil the party's chances in November to make any declaration, there are others who insist that there must be some action taken.

The fourth and final contest in the Gilchester serial Handicap ten-mile road race was run over the Elizabeth-Rahway course on Saturday afternoon, and resulted in an entirely new set Of placed men by reason of the novel conditions of the race, which penalize winners of places in each succeeding race and award the prizes by points gained in all.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- The arrangements for the Democratic State Convention, which will meet in this city a week from to-morrow, are nearing completion, and the indications are that Syracuse will have the biggest crowd in the city that has been gathered at a State Convention in many years.

A conference in regard to the alleged adulteration of the milk sold at one of Nathan Straus's sterilized milk depots was held yesterday morning in the office of Henry Steinert, the counsel for the Board of Health.

The Army and Navy Journal remarks that "there appears to be located somewhere in Washington a bureau of defamation who have on several occasions made the senior Major General of the army the object of their attacks." The St. Louis Republic has been made the medium of their last attack."

Four vessels of the North Atlantic squadron, known as the squadron of evolution, or the white squadron, yesterday joined a fifth at anchor off Tompkinsville, S.I. The five white-hulled, trim-looking men-of-war made a fine appearance as they swung to their anchors off the Staten Island shores.

The New-York baseball team had a very much patched-up appearance in the game with the Quakers at the Polo Grounds yesterday, and perhaps this had something to do with their defeat. Burns played at first, German at third, Davis at second, and "Aunt Agnes" Stafford in left field. The local team also had a new face in the pitcher's box -- young Doheny, the upcountry twirler, making his first appearance in this game.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 16. -- Col. Frederick D. Grant of New-York was the principal speaker at the reunion of the Army of the Tennessee this evening. He devoted himself almost entirely to explaining his father's last military campaign. In the course of his address he said:

The Bijou Theatre, which was opened last night for a new season, under the management of Rudolph Aronson, seems really to have begun a new term of prosperity. The decorations and furniture of the house have been entirely changed, and the mural paintings by Totjetti, the curtains, draperies, chairs, and lighting apparatus are all handsome and modern.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Sept. 16. -- Jacob S. Johnson, the colored man with whom Annie Rogers of Newark, whose dead body was found on She banks of the Raritan River yesterday with marks on her throat showing she had been murdered was last seen, was placed under arrest at noon today, and committed to jail without bail.

Let us suppose that at the opening of Congress Mr. Carlisle and the President should recommend the funding of demand notes in bonds bearing not more than 3 per cent. interest; what would be the result? We put to one side, for the present, what the action of Congress on such a proposition would be, because it is quite impracticable to predict it with any certainty.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 16. -- With Lord Dunraven here, as well as half the members of the Cup Committee of the New-York Yacht Club with the former's last letter to them in their custody, Newport is really the world's yachting centre just now. Interest, however, is fast dying out, and society is slowly settling down to its daily routine.
The Methodist ministers held their first meeting after the vacation season at 150 Fifth Avenue yesterday. There was a very large attendance of members.
In presenting the annual report of the Louisville, New-Albany and Chicago Railroad, President Samuel Thomas says:

What is styled "the Home Rule Democracy" was formally organized last night at the Morton House. Of the twenty-three members of the Executive Committee present last night none is especially prominent in politics. The Chairman of the committee was William Churchill, a boss truckman, formerly one of ex-Sheriff O'Brien's followers.

The construction of the excise law in regard to clubs seems to have got into a regular muddle at Police Headquarters. Acting Chief of Police Conlin told a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday that the decision of the police authorities in regard to the Girder Club would be known by noon to-day.

Wall Street was flooded with rumors yesterday about the gold reserve, the action of the members of the syndicate and the banks holding gold, and a projected new issue of bonds by the Government. There was very little foundation for the rumors.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 16. -- Mrs. William B. Shattuck gave a very large afternoon entertainment at 4 o'clock to-day, which took the form of a musicale, with selections by a number of amateurs, including Mr. Gasquet of New-Orleans and Mr. Pegram of New-York. Nearly all the cottagers were present, including Mr. and Mrs. Henry Barclay, Miss Gertrude Barclay, and a number of New-York guests of their house party.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 16. -- James J. Van Alen gave a grand banquet to-night in honor of Lord Dunraven, H. Maitland Kersey, Lady Boughey, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Vanderbilt, Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Fernando Yznaga, Lady Eileen, and Lady Rachel Wyndham-Quin, and Miss Grace Wilson were among those present.

A private detective in a dry goods store in Sixth Avenue yesterday saw a woman pick up a Russian leather pocketbook from a counter and leave the store without paying for it. The detective followed the woman and had her arrested.

The conference of the United Rescue Workers of New-York City and vicinity, under the auspices of the National Christian Men's Union for Total Abstinence and Rescue Work, was begun yesterday in St. Bartholomew's Parish House, and will be continued until Saturday night.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 16. -- Harvard's football season began to-day, and about forty candidates presented themselves. Several of the members of last year's eleven did not appear, but are expected tomorrow. The squad went through the usual first day's practice, punting, starting, falling on the ball, catching, and finally a short run.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 16. -- The Orange Athletic Club football team went into out-door training to-day and hereafter will practice on the Orange Oval three nights a week, the electric are lights used last year affording ample illumination.

The price of anthracite coal has been advanced about 25 cents a ton by the wholesale dealers during the last few days, and consequently a general advance by the retailers throughout the city has been made.

SARATOGA, Sept. 16. -- Chauncey M. Depew spoke words of encouragement to the members of the Republican Editorial Association of the State of New-York, which held a meeting to-night in the United States Hotel. William J. Arkell presided, and A.O. Bunnell of Dansville acted as Secretary. About fifty members of the association were present.

The first New-York performance of "Black America" was given at the Madison Square Garden last night, and the audience much enjoyed the entertainment afforded by 300 negroes, who come here under the management of Nate Salsbury.

Thomas Smiley of 323 Fifth Street, who is forty-one years old and a clerk, and who drew a pistol on the crowded Central Park mall on Sunday afternoon, was arraigned in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 16. -- Mayor Wanser to-day approved the resolutions ordering contracts for a new water supply -- the contract with the Jersey City Company for a permanent supply, and that with the East Jersey Company to be temporary, or until the Jersey City Company is ready to deliver water, which may be two years.
Senor Dupuy de Lome, the Spanish Minister at Washington, said yesterday that he believes the revolt in Cuba will be crushed within six months.

The convention which meets at Saratoga to-day is likely to be silent or to execute a clumsy dodge on the excise question, but, whatever it does, that phase of the question which has been exciting interest in this city for several months will not fail to be an issue in the coming election of members of the Legislature.
WELLSVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- Wellsville is a thriving little place on the line of the Erie Road in Allegany County.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 17. -- The dismissal of the Rev. John J. O'Donnell from his parish by the Rev. J.J. Crowley adds another interesting chapter to the story of dissension that has kept St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in this village prominently before the public of late.

Any person, whether club member or club waiter, whether saloon keeper or ordinary citizen, will be held to answer a violation of the excise law by Magistrate Cornell if proof is adduced that he has either sold or given away intoxicating liquor on Sunday.

WEST NEW BRIGHTON, S.I., Sept. 17. -- Bystanders in the vicinity of the railroad station at this place were treated to an exciting scene at 4 o'clock this afternoon. A man and woman appeared with a boy of eight years, who was screaming and making every effort to escape. The man was Lawyer E.J. Powers.

Another chapter revealing the inside history of the recent yachting fiasco was laid bare yesterday by ex-Commodore James D. Smith, Chairman of the America's Cup Committee. He made public two letters addressed to C. Oliver Iselin By Lord Dunraven and a letter from Mr. Iselin to Mr. Smith.

In 1823 John Brooks, the first permanent white settler in Jay County, Ind., settled on the creek that now bears his name. In June of the following year, he started for Stillwater, Ohio, for provisions, expecting to be gone several days. His wife and child were left alone, as was usual. She saw no one for several days, except a traveler on his way to Fort Wayne.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 17. -- Congress opened last night. The President's message says the arrangements with Guatemala have been duly ratified. The prevalence of yellow fever in Salvador and Guatemala rendered precautions necessary on the Mexican Pacific coast. On the invitation of the United States Government, Mexico nominated a delegate to the Irrigation Congress at Albuquerque, N.M.

By a majority opinion, the full bench of the Massachusetts Supreme Court to-day sustained the defendant's exception in the case of William A. Perry against the Old Colony Railroad Company by holding that the Employer's Liability act does not contemplate that a railroad company shall be liable to its employes for injury sustained from a locomotive stalled in a roundhouse undergoing repairs.

ALBANY, Sept. 17. -- For the first time in the history of the Court of Appeals it convened to-day in extraordinary session at the Capitol for the purpose of determining the constitutionality of the annexation of a certain portion of Westchester County to New-York City.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 17. -- To-morrow is the day appointed for the formal opening of the most important and progressive exposition ever held in the South. For two years the work of preparation has gone on unceasingly, and most of the thousands of exhibits are in place and ready for inspection.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 17. -- The indications are that the celebration beginning here to-morrow will be of greater magnitude than was at first anticipated. Twenty-two Governors will be in attendance, with their staffs, and will take part in the dedication of various State monuments. Gen. Schofield will arrive on Wednesday from Cincinnati, and address the Army of the Cumberland at its reunion on Wednesday evening.
The armored cruiser Maine, whose construction was authorized nine years ago, was placed in commission yesterday at the New-York Navy Yard.

" Certain chance sentences," in an address by Mr. Crockett before the Edinburgh Philosophical Institution, "expressing admiration and appreciation of Galt, fell upon the wayside of a publisher's mind, where, not being instantly devoured by the birds of the air, they sprang up, and, in due course, they brought forth the excellent fruit of this new edition."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17. -- Unless all signs fail, Philadelphia will have a big athletic meeting this Fall. When the University of Pennsylvania first suggested that the intercollegiate Athletic Association should invite a team of English collegians to compete in this country. Yale managed to quash the suggestion.

HAVANA, Sept. 12. -- Madrid cable dispatches of Sept. 10 are published in this city. They give the official views of Senor Canovas del Castillo of Madrid, acting for the Government of Spain, concerning the rebellion in this island.

The knowledge of a criminal physiognomic type, which at first appeared most novel, and was most generally denied by the savants, is often instinctive among the common people. There are often persons, especially among women, who are far from suspecting even the existence of criminal anthropology, and who yet, at the sight of those who bear criminal characteristics, instantly experience a lively repulsion and know that they are in the presence of a malefactor.
SARATOGA, Sept. 17. -- After the platform had been disposed of, Speaker Fish, on a nod from Platt, moved that the convention proceed to make its nominations. This was carried.

The second conference between committees of the regular and independent Democratic organizations of Kings County was held in the Hamilton Club, Brooklyn, last night and lasted nearly an hour after midnight.

SARATOGA, Sept. 17. -- The Committee on Resolutions was ready to report when Mr. Lexow concluded and Speaker Fish at once sent up the report. The reading by Secretary Kenyon was scarcely interrupted by applause. Everybody listened for a reference to the excise question and nobody heard it. Mr. Platt appeared to have had his way with a majority of the committee.

The expedition to Madagascar was undertaken, like another and much more famous enterprise, in gayety of heart, but it is not conducted, and still less is it in the way to be finished, in the same festive spirit. At present there is an active discussion going on in the French press about the responsibility for the expedition.

The Board of Aldermen yesterday received two applications from the Metropolitan Traction Company for permission to extend its lines. One application is said to be designed to secure a route that will parallel the King's Bridge Road route, which the board gave to the Third Avenue company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- Secretary Lamont has earned the gratitude of the officers of the army by directing Paymaster General Stanton to notify all officers that on the receipt of their unpaid salary accounts for the month of June, properly certified and receipted, checks on the National City Bank of 52 Wall Street, New-York, will be forwarded for the amounts in full.

Our neighbor The Tribune appears to have ascertained that the Whisky Trust did not receive the $12,000,000 "given" to it, as The Tribune has repeatedly asserted, "by a Democratic Congress." We remarked some time ago that we could not understand why a Trust or a corporation which had received $12,000,000 from Congress should a short time afterward go into bankruptcy.

The present month is likely to prove notable for its displays of fraternal sentiment among the survivors of the two great armies that thirty-odd years ago were in deadly conflict. The meeting of the Grand Army of the Republic at Louisville offered the first of these displays, and the voting down there of a resolution of protest against the dedication of the Confederate Monument in Chicago on Decoration Day was most significant.

Mme. Ottille S. Carre, Col. Waring's private secretary, was complainant in Yorkville Police Court, yesterday, against Edward von Hofmeister, twenty-three years old, of 139 East Forty-ninth Street. She charged him with the larceny of a pair of opera glasses worth $20. He admitted his guilt.

On the pier of the North German Lloyd Line at Hoboken, during the landing of the passengers from the steamship Ems yesterday. Alberto Bostamente, who had come from Southampton as a first cabin passenger, excited suspicion. Custom House officers searched him, and found he had secreted the following articles to evade payment of duty:

LONDON, Sept. 17. -- A dispatch from Sandefiord, Norway, says: "Advices have been received from Angmaggsalik, on the east coast of Greenland, that about the end of July a vessel, believed to be the Fram, which conveyed Dr. Nansen and his expedition from Norway in search of the North Pole, was seen imbedded in a drift of ice off Sermilik Fiord, on the east coast of Greenland."

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- Herman Sprouse, a baker employed in the shop of Karl Eberle, in Mount Vernon Avenue, was attacked to-day with what appears to be a clear case of hydrophobia, while at work in the shop. He suddenly became excited and began to act strangely. The men in the shop with him became frightened. They sent for their employer, but before he arrived the man became violent.

There was a double tragedy in Brooklyn yesterday. Mrs. Jessie Curtis, twenty years old, the wife of Charles Curtis of 452 Ninth Street, foreman in the Ansonia clock factory, was shot in the left breast and fatally wounded by Charles A. Poole, who then killed himself.

PANAMA, via Galveston, Sept. 17. -- San Jose, Costa Rica, has given three days to enthusiastic celebration of Central American independence, and to the unveiling, by President Rafael Iglesias, of an allegorical monument in commemoration of the victory obtained in 1856 and 1857 against Walker's filibusters.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- Senior Fombona, the attache of the Venezuelan Legation who was convicted and fined in New-York for insulting a woman on the street, has returned to Washington, and there is now talk of a protest to the State Department by the Venezuelan Minister, Senior Andrade, based on the arrest of the attache.

The only withdrawal of gold from the Sub-Treasury yesterday was $250,000, which was taken by Haskier, Wood Co. for shipment to-day. Handy Harman will ship $150,000 to Europe to-day, but this gold will not be taken from the Treasury, and therefore will not affect the gold reserve.

Andrew J. Wightman, the disbarred lawyer who has served several terms in State prison, bobbed up again yesterday as a party to an alleged conspiracy by which the heirs of John Brennan were swindled out of an award for condemned property.
Plans have been filed for the following new buildings in Brooklyn:

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 17. -- Slowly the prosecution is taking Theodore Durrant up to the Emmanuel Baptist Church door with Blanche Lamont. Another long step was taken yesterday, and the two traced to the "Mission" -- to the corner of either Valencia and Twenty-first Streets or Valencia and Twenty-second Streets.

SARATOGA, Sept. 17. -- Platt threw the throttle of his nicely oiled machine wide open at the opening session of the convention, and with what Du Maurier would call his prehensile eyes, he closely watched the operations from a front seat. All its bearings were oiled to a nicety. Dr. Depew, from his seat in the New-York delegation, got pointers from it as to how to run the fast train over the New-York Central.

SARATOGA, Sept. 17. -- The Junketing Committees of the late Assembly have been enjoying the convention. Saratoga is a delightful place at this season of the year, and the thoughtfulness of the men who engineered the resolutions through the Assembly last Winter, by which many members were turned loose in the State to travel at the State's expense, makes it possible for many members who might not otherwise be able to attend to do so.

LOWVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- The Lewis County Democratic Convention was called to order at the Court House in this village at 2 o'clock this afternoon. James P. Lewis of Croghan was elected Chairman and Philander Blodgett of Denmark and Charles Nelbergali of Montague were made Secretaries.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 17. -- Another class, exclusively for literary purposes, has been organized here. Miss Georgia Roberts of New-York is to deliver five lectures to them upon the subject of Japan and the woman question. The meetings are to be on Monday and Thursday mornings, successively, at the villas of Mrs. Frederick W. Vanderbilt, Mrs. N. Devereaux Clapp, Mrs. William H. Osgood, Mrs. E.J. Berwind, and Mrs. William Post.

Charles A. Hess and ex-Senator McClelland, counsel for Capt. Joseph B. Eakins of the Mercer Street Station, who was tried not long ago on charges made by the Parkhurst society for alleged failure to suppress disorderly houses in his precinct, and Lawyer Moss of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, appeared before Commissioner Andrews at Police Headquarters yesterday afternoon at an adjourned hearing of the Eakins case.

In regard to the crusade now going on against the selling of alleged adulterated milk and candies in the small stores which cluster around some of the public schools, E.W. Martin, chief of the Department of Food Inspection and Offensive Trades, said yesterday:

AURORA, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- The death of Mrs. Henry A. Morgan of this place is a loss that will be felt very keenly, not only in Aurora, but in other cities where she was known. Mrs. Morgan had been traveling abroad for the last year. Very recently she had gone to Hamburg, and was receiving treatment there. Her death in that place on Sunday was very sudden.
Cyclist wishing to Join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of The New-York Times.

Mr. Platt has renominated his "old ticket," without opposition. He has been compelled, however, to place them on a platform which, as to the only living issue in the State, he had deliberately rejected. There was profound indifference in the convention as to the nominations, with the exception of that for the Court of Appeals, for which Kings County had a candidate, who was ignored.
A meeting of the Board of Trustees of the Sportsmen's Exposition Association was held yesterday afternoon at the office of the Winchester Repeating Arms Company.

Charles S. Gleed of Kansas, one of the most active of the Directors of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe system, is now at the Holland House, in this city. He has but recently completed a careful inspection of about 4,000 of the 9,000 miles in the Atchison system, and the 4,000 miles which he saw, all by daylight, include the main line from Chicago to San-Diego.

The only French horseless pleasure carriages to be seen in this country are at present on exhibition in Fourteenth Street. For several days past large crowds of people have been attracted on the north side of Fourteenth Street by these novelties. A great deal has been said and written about horseless carriages, and some enterprising firms have designedly confused the public mind as to what they are.
Mr. O.T. Mackey has sold to J.S. Ferguson the four-story brownstone dwelling 7 West Ninetieth Street, 18 by 100 1/2.

SARATOGA, Sept. 17. -- The report of the Committee on Resolutions caused the only real fight of the convention. The battle had begun at the meeting of the Committee on Resolutions. The excise question was as troublesome there as it has been at any time since the statesmen came together early in the week.
LONDON, Sept. 17. -- Sims Reeves, the celebrated English tenor, has remarried. His new wife is young and handsome. He is seventy-three years of age.

Electricity as a motive power and its practical use in handling freight on railroads were tested yesterday on the Nantasket Beach electric system of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railway. The experiments were made with motor cars and flat cars heavily freighted with Quincy granite, and were witnessed by a large number of railroad officials, who regarded the tests as satisfactory and indicative of a revolution in railroad traffic within a few years.

Almost every group of mammals has some members conspicuously striped, others spotted or covered with rosettes. Even those that are plain or self-colored exhibit stripings or stars as a frequent abnormality. Thus, most donkeys and horses show some trace of stars, of dapplings, or, in rarer though common cases, of zebra markings. Most lions show here and there on their sides rosette-like markings recalling the spots of the leopard.
SARATOGA, Sept. 17. -- The State machine has virtually posted up a placard bearing the words, "No Brookfield men need apply."

Two hundred and twenty-six Chinese passed through this city yesterday. They came from Hongkong by steamer to Vancouver, and across British America by the Canadian Pacific Railroad. With the exception of nineteen laborers, who were en route to Cuba, and who occupied a separate car, the Chinese were on their way to the Cotton States Exposition, at Atlanta, Ga.

BOSTON, Sept. 17. -- The Spaniards have evacuated Banes, the most important fruit port on the northern coast of Cuba. It is the port from which nearly all the bananas which come to Boston are shipped. The Spanish soldiers made a feeble attempt to defend the place, but the rebels were too many for them.

The public is in danger of forgetting that a commission was provided for by law and duly appointed by the Governor months ago to devise improved methods of procedure in the Legislature. We are not sure that the commission has not forgotten that it has any duty to perform, for it has not yet taken any action and we have not heard of its holding any meeting.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Sept. 17. -- F.V. Linden, father of F.V. Linden, Jr., the Brooklyn jeweler, of 62 Bond Street, who has a Summer home at this place, fell dead near the railroad station this evening. The cause of death was heart disease.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- Warner Miller's friends are already so impressed with the significance of his victory in securing the "morality" amendment to the platform that they have begun predicting that his action to-day will make him the natural leader of his party in the State and will re-elect him to the Senate as the successor to Senator Hill.
While Rudyard Kipling is preserving the brogue of Sergt. Mulvany, his father is preserving the original art of India with the same care and patience that his son operates on his favorite Irishman.

KEY WEST, Fla., Sept. 17. -- Pilotboats arriving here this evening report the Spanish corvette Conde de Venadito to be cruising inside the Florida reefs between Key West and Indian Key. This vessel arrived from Havana yesterday and sailed in the afternoon. The people of this city denounce the invasion of our inland waters by a foreign war vessel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- It is quite evident that the State Department has taken the precaution to fortify itself against any attempt on the part of the French Government to submit an expurgated edition of the record of the court-martial that convicted Waller, or one that does not fully and fairly set forth all the facts.

Blake -- I can give you my word as an artist that in any art that deals with special conditions -- as the art of writing for the stage undoubtedly does -- there must inevitably be a great deal of technique involved that it is important and essential to master. I can give you an instance in another material.

A case of unmitigated cruelty to a child came to public notice yesterday in Brooklyn. According to the story told in the Ewen Street Police Court, Burrell Bayar, Jr., eight years old, had been chained like a dog for three days and nights by his stepmother to the grape arbor in the garden in the rear of the premises, 83 Devoe Street.

Collector Kilbreth and Special Deputy Collector Couch went to Washington yesterday afternoon to consult with the Secretary of the Treasury about certain changes which are contemplated in the methods of the Custom House in this city.

SARATOGA, Sept. 17. -- Chairman Hackett called the meeting to order at 12:25 o'clock, and requested the Rev. Dr. Carey of the Bethesda Episcopal Church of this village to make the opening prayer. So suspicious are some politicians that they listened with great attention to the prayer, fearful that something might be said in it relative to the excise question.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17. -- A handsome steam yacht has been designed for Mr. A.J. Drexel of this city by G.L. Watson, the man who planned the Valkyrie. Mr. Drexel, who sailed 18.000 miles in the Margarita this Summer without the sign of an accident, came to the conclusion that handsome and swift as the dainty vessel was it did not afford him sufficient room, and he decided to sell it. There are several prospective purchasers.

Yesterday was the thirty-first anniversary of the installment of Dr. Horatio Stebbins as pastor of the First Unitarian Church in this city, and the ladies, in kindly remembrance of long and fruitful service, had planned to make the occasion notable by presenting to the church a portrait of their pastor in oil by Miss Eva Withrow.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 17. -- The papers in the certiorari proceedings begun Monday afternoon by John Wheelihan for a review of the award of the water contracts to the Jersey City Water Company were served to-day on Corporation Counsel John A. Blair and Corporation Attorney Spencer Weart. The writs are returnable Saturday morning before Justice Lippincott.

There are thousands of horsemen and lovers of racing who are now regretting that they did not go to the Brooklyn Jockey Club track yesterday. It was the opening day of the Fall meeting there. The First Special, at a mile and a quarter, was down on the card for decision. In it were entered the best of the handicap horses of the year.

The art of the biographer has vastly improved within the last quarter of a century. The time when the writer of a man's life was either a blind advocate or an equally blind assailant appears to have gone by, and in these days biography has assumed the calm and judicial tone of critical history.

A Vermont veteran tells a good story of the fight of Burkittsville, Va., just before the battle of Sharpsburg: "The Confederates, overpowered, fell back up the hill, firing upon Our men from behind rocks and the natural defensive positions presented by the ground until they reached their artillery, where they made a more decided stand.

New-York has now a Manual Training High School that promises to be of great value to the city and the country. There have been, and are, schools in the city for teaching the young the first principles of various trades, but the school connected with the Teachers College is the first in this city to offer a complete training in handicraft of many kinds.
The Police Alarm and Intercommunication System, in use in Boston and other cities, was tested in the Nineteenth Precinct yesterday.

The citizens of Brooklyn and the public-school children are going to give the new Government cruiser Brooklyn a splendid silver service, to cost not less than $10,000. The project took final and definite shape yesterday.

An enthusiastic mass-meeting under the auspices of the Thirty-fourth Assembly District Organization of the City Vigilance League was held last night in Bethany Presbyterian Church, One Hundred and Thirty-seventh Street and Willis Avenue.

Health Officer Woodward has submitted to the Commissioners a chart and table showing the variations in the death rate from typhoid fever for the seventeen weeks ending Sept. 14, with a comparison with the death rate from the same diseases during corresponding weeks in 1891, 1892, 1893, and 1894.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18. -- The Pennsylvania Railroad to-day, in testing a new engine from the company's shops, made a remarkably quick run between Jersey City and Philadelphia. The distance between the two cities is 89.76 miles, and to-day's run was made in ninety-nine minutes. Although this is exceedingly fast railroading, it is still ten minutes behind the record made two years ago between Jersey City and Philadelphia.

At various times this State has been ruled by the monarchs of Spain, France, and England; that is, they have ruled it to the extent of giving it away to various people whom they didn't dislike enough to behead. The State of Iowa has been passed around like a municipal franchise among people who didn't appreciate it, and at last had to develop itself without any foreign aid.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 18. -- Arthur E. Marsh, financial manager of the clothing firm of Charles E. Lynch of this city, and a humble-appearing man of rare intellectuality, has left this city under a cloud, and an expert is examining his books. The firm by which he was employed declines to state the amount of the alleged shortage.

EAST TAWAS, Mich., Sept. 18. -- The most disastrous storm of recent years passed over this locality at midnight last night, disabling vessels, wrecking buildings, and leaving general destruction in its wake.

Mr. Henry Labouchere, who is neither a maniac nor an imbecile, writes in this week's issue of Truth as though he were a combination of both. "It is simply false," he declares, "to say that the Defender was hampered equally with the Valkyrie III. The Captains of the steamboats took care that that was not the case."

The corporation of the University of the City of New-York held its first meeting of the academic year in the new University Building, Washington Square, yesterday afternoon. The object of the meeting was to decide as to the formal opening of the new building at University Heights and the new halls for the law, pedagogy, and graduate classes in Washington Square.

The statements that were published in several of the morning newspapers yesterday by which it was made to appear that the German-American Reform Union had made an alliance with Tammany, and would support its candidates at the coming election, caused much surprise among the members of the union, as well as among others who were members of the combination that defeated Tammany last Fall.

LONDON, Sept. 18. -- The Morning Post to-morrow will print a dispatch to a news agency saying that American planters have secured a concession from the Hawaiian Government and a contract has been signed granting an annual subsidy of $40,000, with exclusive rights for twenty years, to lay a cable from the American continent which shall extend only to Hawaii.
NEWBURG, Sept. 18. -- Hudson River fishermen met here to-day to organize for self-protection against laws which, they claim, affect them.

On July 25, 1813, an unsuccessful attempt was made to carry San Sebastian itself by assault. Colin Campbell, with twenty men of the light company of his regiment, constituted the forlorn hope at the great breach, and on reaching the top he was shot through the right hip and fell to the bottom.
The junior championship tennis tournament was finished yesterday afternoon on the Central Park courts. The results follow:

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 18. -- President Cleveland, at 6:54 o'clock this afternoon, touched a golden button at Buzzard's Bay, and instantly the wheels of the machinery at the Cotton States and International Exposition, 1,000 miles away, leaped into life. Cannon blazed and thundered, 60,000 people cheered, a thousand flags fluttered from the tops of the many buildings, and the great South's industrial exposition was officially opened.

FLUSHING, L.I., Sept. 18. -- The Democratic Convention for the election of three delegates and alternates to the State Convention, and one delegate and alternate to the Judiciary Convention, was held in the Town Hall here this afternoon. A large number of Democrats were present, and harmony was the most noticeable feature of the gathering.

In the wonderful progress made by medical science of the world successful treatment for most diseases has been discovered, and diseases which were at one time considered incurable are now easily conquered. Among the most difficult and obstinate of diseases which has baffled the skill of our most noted Physicians up to the present time, Asthma ranks first.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- The German Roman Catholic Central Verein to-day elected the following officers: President -- Adolph Weber, Racine, Wis.; First Vice President -- Michael Beck, Albany; Second Vice President -- Henry W. Wolf, New-York City; Recording Secretary -- Alfred Steckel, Milwaukee, Wis.; Corresponding Secretary -- Anton Bickel, Milwaukee, Wis.; Treasurer -- John F. Brinkman, Terre Haute, Ind.; Executive Committee -- Frederick Arendas, Jacob Miller, J.A. Schiffer, and G.E. Scherer.

Lawyer Thomas W. Murray of 338 Broadway, who occasionally practices in the police courts of the city, entered the Yorkville courtroom shortly after 8 o'clock yesterday morning. Chief Clerk Tebbetts ordered him to remove his hat.

It is impossible to read the Bengali newspapers without seeing that abuse of the Englishman and the Government has been adopted as a deliberate policy. Whether this arises from the hope of obtaining political concessions, or from sheer malice, it is difficult to say. But often these papers will be full, from beginning to end, of nothing but the most outrageous attacks on the Government and its officials.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18. -- Notwithstanding the endeavors of Japanese and Chinese authorities to suppress news concerning the cholera, the truth has at last come to light concerning the plague. Japan and North China are fairly alive with cholera germs.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 18. -- The double-front block occupied by Eastman, Schleicher Lee, retail furniture and china dealers, was destroyed by fire early this morning, together with the entire stock. Loss, $200,000; insurance, $100,000. The Indiana National Bank was destroyed also, together with all the contents, except the safe and its valuables.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- For the first time in its history the Supreme Court of the United States now has pending before it two appeals by one person from judgments sentencing him to be hanged for murder, the two crimes having been committed on different days and at places separated by many miles.
Mr. J. Bruckmeyer has sold to S. Greenfield the four-story brick tenement 613 East Sixth Street, 25 by 92, at $14,000, a slight advance on the price paid by the seller.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- The Treasury gold reserve stood at the close of business to-day at $95,706,954, a gain for the day of $324,000. The gains were made as follows: From National Bank of America, Chicago, $50,000; from People's National Bank of Pittsburg, Penn., $100,000; from First National Bank of Brooklyn, N.Y., $250,000; small deposits of gold at various Sub-Treasuries for currency, $74,000.

Members of Good Government Clubs who live in the Fifteenth Senatorial District held a convention last night in the clubhouse of Good Government Club A, 722 Lexington Avenue, and organized committees to conduct the Fall campaign.

MILLBURN, L.I., Sept. 18.--The prevalence of diphtheria in this village has become so marked as to be regarded as almost epidemic. The dread disease has been on the increase for several months, and, although the people of the village tried at the outset to make light of the matter, the disease has spread so that there is a condition of affairs little short of panic among parents having young children.
Premiums aggregating $30,000 are offered this year by the National Horse Show Association for its eleventh annual show, which is to be held in Madison Square Garden Nov. 11 to 16, inclusive.

There are a great many persons at all times engaged in writing songs for the people, but the people refuse to sing them. It is not at all necessary to the success of a song that it should have any sense in it. Some of our most popular songs are the veriest drivel. But, on the other hand, sense does not always kill a song.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- Frank Dominick, an Italian hand-organ man, was murdered in this city this evening by Pulis Colden, a colored youth, employed as cook on the steamer John L. Hasbrouck of the Poughkeepsie Transportation Company's line. Dominick and another Italian named Sartori Carlos were drinking beer on the Main Street wharf most of the afternoon.

The decision which the Court of Appeals has promised to file on the 27th, Friday of next week, will settle the question of the validity of the annexation of a part of Westchester County to this city, and with it the question of putting the annexed area into an Assembly district.

The act regarding "The Right Packing of Salmond," and "Against Clandestine and Unlawful Marriages," are fair specimens of the paternal legislation of the time. The latter act makes the contracting of such marriages punishable by "stocks and irons," which "pains corporal shall no ways be prejudicial to or derogat from the Orders and Censures of the Kirke to be inflicted against the Delinquents."

The announcement made by City Magistrate Cornell on Tuesday that any person who even in his own home sold or gave away beer or intoxicating liquor on Sunday was guilty of an offense, and if brought before him, and proof was adduced, he would hold the accused person to answer for a violation of the excise law, caused a great deal of comment, and was widely discussed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- If the present rate of influx keeps up for any considerable time the various assignments of the Mora claim promise to keep a score of clerks in the State Department busy. Now that the money is certain to be in the hands of the State Department within a few days every one who has a claim, immediate or remote, is hastening to place it on file.

Ude was an accomplished cook, probably of the school of Beauvilliers, and achieved a great reputation in the land of his adoption as chef to Lord Sefton, as steward of the United Service Club, and maitre d'hotel, or director of the kitchen, at Crockford's. The first edition of his book came out in 1813, but it was a later one, in 1822, that attracted the greater attention.

The baseball match which was to have been Dlayed at the Polo Grounds yesterday bet-een the Ne-York and Philadelphia Clubs was postDoned on account of wet grounds. The Came may possibly be Dlayed Thursday next.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 18. -- The quarter centennial reunion of the Society of the Army of the Cumberland, meeting in conjunction with the dedication of the Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Park, was held to-night in the monster tent erected to accommodate the several gatherings of the week, which convenience required should be in the city.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 18.--Mrs. Edward Stevens and Mrs. Alexander H. Stevens, whose home is Sea Change, Far Rockaway, and who are well-known in New-York society; Dr. Blake White of 1,013 Madison Avenue, New-York, and a woman who would not give her name, were arrested last night by Policeman Robert Vandewater, in Fulton Street, for riding their bicycles on the sidewalk.

Most people who have any notion at all of the great work that has been done in utilizing for industrial purposes the water power of Niagara have been of the opinion that for the accomplishment of that result there was necessary and there was obtained a singular and unprecedented combination of capital, enterprise, scientific knowledge, and technical skill, and that these were gathered from all parts of the civilized world.

JAMESTOWN, Sept. 18. -- At the Democratic Convention for the Second Assembly District of Chautauqua County to-day, U.S. Ladue was nominated for member of the Assembly. C.H. Corbett and C.R. Crosby were elected delegates to the State Convention. They belong to the Cleveland wing of the party.
HAVANA, Sept. 18. -- Seventeen persons who, it is believed, are accused of political offenses, were arrested in this city this morning.

The ignorance in regard to the higher branches of cookery, which certainly prevailed at this period in England, is to be accounted for, I think. Throughout the eighteenth century there seems to have been a deeply rooted prejudice among those who wrote on the subject against anything French.

The longest way around is often the shortest way to a vessel's destination. Sailingship routes on the United States North Atlantic pilot charts clearly show, for example, how unadvisable it would be for a navigator bound to England from the equator to make directly for his destined haven.

Andrew Collins, who lives in a Bowery lodging house, was arrested on Tuesday night on suspicion of being the accomplice of Harry Robinson, who a few weeks ago got Editor Wilson of Puck into trouble by slipping a stolen watch into his pocket on a Broadway car. James Wallace, whose picture ornaments the Rogues' Gallery, was arrested with Collins.

Allegations of fraud were made in court yesterday against the persons who are engaged in winding up the affairs of the Old Staten Island Dyeing Establishment in proceedings for a voluntary dissolution.

It is said that you do not really know a man until you have joined him in a carouse. I have shared two with M. Stambuloff. The first was at Bourgas Monastery, whither a whole crowd of visitors, journalists, and commercial people had repaired from Sofia for a three days' picnic and a sight of the peasants dancing the choro.
The twenty-fifth annual picnic of the Yorkville Brewers' Battalion attracted an attendance of about 10,000 persons at Sulzer's Harlem River Park yesterday.

In extent, variety of natural features, multitude of monuments and historical tablets, facilities afforded to visitors, and, finally, in the importance of the events which it commemorates, the Chickamauga and Chattanooga Park, formally dedicated this week, is fully worthy of the imposing ceremonies prepared for it.

It appears that under the English treaty of extradition with France an examination of an accused can only take place in Bow Street. Now, Dr. Herz was at Bournemouth in bed, too ill to be removed to London. The English Government was naturally not content with the testimony of a single private practitioner.

The official statement of Mr. Daniels of the New-York Central confirms the accounts already given by The Times, and makes it quite clear that the superiority in railroad speed has passed to this side of the Atlantic. He shows that the claim of certain English roads to run regular trains faster than the Empire State Express is not borne out by the latest time tables of these roads.

Gold operations at the Sub-Treasury yesterday resulted in the addition of $150,000 to the reserve. The First National Bank of Brooklyn deposited $250,000, taking legal tender notes of large denomination in exchange, and $50,000 was given for small notes, to be shipped West. Against these gains, Oelrichs Co. withdrew $150,000 for shipment by steamer to-day.

More letters relating to the yachting fiasco were published yesterday, but instead of clearing up the trouble it is making the muddle worse. Mr. Kersey gave out Mr. Iselin's letter to Lord Dunraven offering to resail the second race. He also made a statement on behalf of Lord Dunraven answering a letter of Mr. Iselin to Mr. James D. Smith.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Sept. 18. -- The Democratic Convention for the First Assembly District of Queens County, composed of this city and the town of Newtown, met in the Court House here this afternoon to elect three delegates to the State Convention and one delegate to the Judiciary Convention.

Within fifty yards from the house we found a large wooden platform, covered by a roof of atap, (leaves of a palm, and similar to those of the cocoanut tree,) and resting, at about four feet distance above the ground, upon strong piles, that had been driven into the soft soil of the plantation which encircled the residence.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- The Herreshoffs, the great yacht builders, may be given a chance to show what they can do in the way of naval architecture. When bids were opened at the Navy Department for the construction of the three seagoing torpedo boats authorized by Congress the Herreshoffs were found to be the lowest bidders.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 18.--Preliminary to the formal dedication of the Chickamauga National Park, a number of State monuments were dedicated to-day. An immense number of visitors are already here, and tens of thousands more are expected to arrive to-morrow, when the principal exercises will be held.

The English athletes put in two good sessions of practice on the Berkeley Oval track yesterday. The track in the morning was a trifle heavy, as a result of the early morning rain, and the shower later in the day did not improve it for the 5 o'clock afternoon practice.

GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- The Fulton-Hamilton County District Convention at Johnstown to-day was a harmonious affair. It was wholly under the control of the Hill wing of the party, the Cleveland men having offered no opposition in the primaries in deference to the candidacy of John B. Judson for State Treasurer.

John V. Coffey, a grocer at 61 Seventh Avenue, was sentenced in the Court of Special Sessions yesterday to pay a fine of $300 and serve three months in the City Prison for selling milk which was 7 per cent. water and 29 per cent. skim milk.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 18. -- Judge Lippincott to-day authorized the statement that he has no desire to be the Democratic candidate for Governor. He is satisfied with his present position, and wishes to keep aloof from politics.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 18. -- For September it was socially unusually busy to-day.

SARATOGA, Sept. 18. -- Three of the five State officers renominated by the omnibus ballot cast by the Assistant Secretary of the Republican State Convention yesterday were behind their big desks to-day. They were Secretary Palmer and Controller Roberts, who never speak a they pass by, and Attorney General Hancock.

POMONA, Cal., Sept. 18. -- The grizzly bears found all through the canons of the Rocky and Coast Mountains and spurs of the great Sierra Nevada range seldom descend from lofty altitudes where they manage year in and year out to eke out a subsistence near he perpetual snow line. An old and experienced hunter has said that "any man's a fool to go in arter bear alone."

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Sept. 18. -- A delightful german was given in the Hotel Castleton this evening. The great dining room, which is considered one of the best dancing floors on Staten Island, was in excellent condition, and nearly 300 ladies and gentlemen were present.

Acting Captain Steinkamp, with two detectives, went to Thirty-ninth Street and Eleventh Avenue yesterday afternoon to watch for a man whom they supposed was stealing oats from the meat firm of Schwarzschild Sulzberger, at Forty-fifth Street and First Avenue. For three months past the firm has been missing hundreds of dollars' worth of feed while in transport from freight cars to its place of business.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- The American Bimetallic Union, formed of the three bimetallic leagues, is the outcome of the conference of silver leaders which was concluded here this afternoon. The headquarters of the union will be in Chicago. Gen. A.J. Warner of Marietta, Ohio, is the President, and E.B. Light of Denver, Secretary.

The New-York State Board of Health met yesterday at the Murray Hill Hotel. Dr. Daniel Lewis presided. The other members present were Dr. Alvah H. Doty, Health Officer of the Port of New-York; Dr. S. Case Jones of Rochester, Dr. F.W. Smith of Syracuse, State Engineer Adams of Watertown, Dr. Fowler of New-York, Owen Cassidy of Montaur Falls, and Dr. Baxter T. Smelzer.

I had looked in late after dinner at the British Agency, expecting only to find the usual skittle billiards and backgammon in progress. To my surprise I found the card-room more crowded than I had ever seen it before. Not only the usual attaches, but a bevy of Ministers and officers were crowded around the table.

Besides the 2,000 untried indictments recently unearthed in the attic of the old brownstone Court House, in City Hall Park, it developed yesterday that a batch of about 1,000 old police court complaints was also found in the same box. Assistant District Attorney Unger, speaking of this latest find, yesterday, sold:

Despite the disadvantages of comparative newness, railroads running westward from Chicago are credited with some excellent races against time, and run regularly fast trains, which carry the mails in as good time as is attempted in the East. From this city to the Mississippi the conditions are nearly as favorable as in New-York, and over that distance fast runs are continually made.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 18. -- On the eve of the New-Jersey Republican State Convention it is utterly impossible to predict with any degree of certainty who will win the hot fight that has been waged in the primaries. All sides agree now that the first or informal ballot will show that Senator Griggs of Passaic has a greater following in the convention than any other man.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 18. -- "Uncle Josey" Field of Middletown will have reached his one hundred and third birthday if he lives until next Sunday. He has been written about, perhaps, more than any other centenarian in this country. He continues to live on his immense farm along the Middletown Turnpike, about one mile from this place.

What ought to be done by the Swiss authorities, we wonder, to Prof. Heim, the savant, for his speech at the Alpine Club in Zurich? Only a week or two ago it was decreed that the Swiss press should be silent concerning suicides, for newspaper reports of suicides gave a stimulus to some people go and do likewise.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 18. -- Rutgers College opened to-day, entrance examinations having been held yesterday. The freshman class is about the same in number as last year.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., Sept. 18. -- The vast machinery of the Atlanta Exposition was successfully set in motion this evening from the President's Summer home, Gray Gables, a little before 7 o'clock. The weather has been rather unpropitious, for it rained nearly half the day. About noon it cleared somewhat, but it continued cloudy, however, the remainder of the day.

Charges were preferred yesterday afternoon against Police Captain William Strauss of the East Sixty-seventh Street Police Station, as a result of the recent trouble with the Cherokee Club. The charges were made by Acting Inspector Cortright under instructions from the Police Commissioners. They, read as follows:

The first in order was the receiver, or treasurer. He had the duty of receiving and accounting for the rents of the abbey farms. His office in later days, when from various causes the religious houses grew poorer, must often have been an onerous, if not a painful, one, and on him fell the perpetual strain to make ends meet, while sadly insufficient resources were at his command.

The report from Madrid, by way of London, that Gen. Martinez Campos has declared the Cuban insurrection to be far more serious than at the date of his last report may not be true. But it is so circumstantial and intrinsically so probable that its statement will be generally accepted as the fact.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Sept. 18. -- The Fourth Judicial District Democratic Convention was held to-day. The district includes the Counties of Warren, Saratoga, Washington, Essex, Franklin, St. Lawrence, Clinton, Montgomery, Hamilton, Fulton, and Schenectady, which comprise the Republican stronghold of Northern New-York, and in which a Republican nomination is equivalent to an election.

" From some of the reports circulated in the East," said Mr. German P. Tetnew of Galveston, Texas, last night, "one is led to believe that the Western, particularly the far Southwestern, citizen is a pretty bad man, whose chief amusement and means of gaining a livelihood consist of highway robbery.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- Advices to-day reached the Executive Committee having charge of the national Irish conference, to open in this city Tuesday next, that a number of the leading delegates from the East and the far West will arrive next Saturday, for the purpose of conferring informally concerning the policy that the convention will be asked to indorse.

NEWARK, Sept. 18. -- This city may be said to have been fairly bicycle-crazy to-night, for it is years since there was such a pushing, shoving, jostling crowd on the streets as there was to witness the annual lantern parade of the Essex County Wheelmen. It was truly a gorgeous exhibition, and showed that the wheel is susceptible of the most extraordinary decoration without impairing its usefulness.

PRINCETON, Sept. 18. -- The long Summer vacation of Princeton University closed yesterday, and to-day the opening exercises off the one hundred and forty-ninth year of the institution took place in Marquand Chapel.

At the meeting of the Police Commissioners yesterday the lists of persons submitted by the regular parties for appointment as Inspectors of Election were taken up, and the following resolution was adopted:...

There is a plague of snakes in Hacklebarney Township, Somerset County, N.J. There are always plenty of big snakes in season in and around Hacklebarney, but the recent dry weather has caused them to swarm the mountain ledges in unprecedented numbers, until now the warning noise of the rattler is as frequent as the songs of the locusts.
The Shepard organization -- the independent Democrats of Kings County -- held its Assembly District Conventions last night and elected delegates to the State Convention.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- The State Department this morning received cable information from China effectually disproving the accuracy of dispatches recently published alleging that the work of the commission engaged in the investigation of the Ku-Cheng massacre had been blocked by the refusal of the Chinese to execute those found guilty unless all future demands should be waived.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 18. -- Over 20,000 persons crowded the grand stand and filled the place along the track at State Fair Park to-day to see the race between Joe Patchen, John R. Gentry, and Vera Capel. The race was for a purse of $3,000, and was won by John R. Gentry in straight heats with apparent ease. The first heat was a neck-and-neck race.

The malady which has confined Richard Mansfield, the actor, to his home, in West Eightieth Street, for a fortnight, is typhoid fever. It has been a comparatively mild case, in the view of his physicians, Drs. Dillingham, Allen, and Lincoln, but the patient is scarcely out of danger yet, though the crisis of the fever has passed.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- Philip S. Ryder, one of the most popular men in the Democratic Party of Onondaga County, was nominated in the County Convention to-day for State Senator. There was no opposition to Mr. Ryder, it being generally conceded that he would be the best man to run against Horace White, the Republican nominee.

Under a decision handed down yesterday by Justice Stover, in ,the Supreme Court, Joseph B. Atkinson, at present living in England, will lose property valued thirty years ago at $200,000, and now worth about $500,000.

ALBUQUERQUE, New-Mexico, Sept. 19. -- The National Irrigation Congress, after a number of congratulatory speeches and a few remarks by the President, adjourned sine die to-day to meet next year in Phoenix, Arizona. An address and resolutions were adopted substantially as follows:

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 19. -- After an interval of thirty-two years the blue and the gray met around the crescent of Snodgrass Hill, on the battlefield of Chickamauga, but not amid the mist and leaden hail which marked those dreadful days of 1863, making the conflict the most disastrous in its casualties to those concerned which history knows.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19. -- A defalcation of $19,600 on the part of the receiving and paying tellers of the National Bank of Illinois was admitted this morning by the officers of that institution. The shortage has been made good, and it is understood there will be no prosecution.

Mrs. F.H.
