Throop, who was influential in arranging the pilgrimages from this country to Lourdes this year and last, has returned to her home, 412 Clermont Avenue, Brooklyn, and has brought with her some remarkable evidences of the esteem of the Holy Father at Rome and different clergymen of the Roman Catholic Church. Through them the miracles of Lourdes may be repeated in this country.

At Democratic Conventions reference is occasionally made to "the Cassidy resolution" in connection with discussions upon representation in Democratic State Conventions. At the Rochester Convention, Oct. 5, 1871, William Cassidy of Albany, at the morning session, said:

That ex-Mayor William R. Grace may reenter polities this Fall was made apparent last night when he was elected a delegate to the Democratic State Convention from the First Assembly District. No explanation was offered as to why he was not chosen in his own district. He is now out of the city.

J. Pierpont Morgan voluntarily made the announcement yesterday that he had purchased the control of the New-York and New-England Railroad. He bought the stock during last Spring in the open market at current prices, and the certificates are now in his possession.

Cricket has taken the fancy of the young women of Staten Island, for yesterday, at Livingston, they again opposed a team of men, and, although this time they were defeated, they made a most creditable showing in "handling the willow," "trundling the sphere," and in the field.
Some startling revelations may be made when the suit of W.H. A.G. Lockwood furniture dealers, against John E. Greaney, contractor, comes to trial in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn.

LONDON, Sept. 19. -- The steamer Edam, from New-York Sept. 5 for Amsterdam, foundered off Start Point, on the southern coast of England, this morning, after a collision. Her passengers and crew were saved.

The thirty-second anniversary of the ordination of Archbishop Michael Augustine Corrigan to the priesthood occurred yesterday. There was little celebration of the event, however, and the day was marked by no special services.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 19. -- Many reunions of regiments of veterans were planned for this occasion, and where a sufficient number of comrades have answered muster happy meetings have taken place on the battlefield. Favorite spots for these gatherings were positions held during the battle.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst was a passenger by the White Star steamship Germanic, which arrived yesterday from Liverpool. Representatives from the newspapers met the ship at Quarantine. A bundle of morning papers had been put on board the Germanic by the pilot boat. Dr. Parkhurst had secured one, and had made himself acquainted with the recent doings at Saratoga.
BUFFALO, Sept. 19. -- It is altogether likely that Buffalo banks may decide to follow the example set by those of other cities in assisting the Government with a portion of their accumulated gold.

Ten Greek pushcart peddlers saved themselves from a fine or imprisonment for violating city ordinances by handing Magistrate Wentworth, in the Tombs Police Court yesterday, a letter composed by them during their night's stay in the Elizabeth Street Station. Policeman Breen arrested the ten lucky ones and five others at Chambers and Centre Streets.

So turbulent were the recent Republican conventions for the election of delegates to the State Convention that the representatives of the Grand Old Party of moral ideas decided last night at the meeting of the Republican County Committee to call upon the police to maintain order at the conventions to be held next week for the election of delegates to the Republican County Convention.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- No friction was manifested at the Democratic primaries held in Erie County to-night to elect delegates to the conventions which will meet Saturday to elect the delegates to the State Convention. The tickets named by the organization won everywhere. The vote was light, because there was no contest. The Cleveland Democrats participated as largely as the Hill Democrats.

When the Rev. Dr. CHARLES H. PARKHURST reached the city yesterday on the White Star steamer Germanic he gave to the representatives of the press a rather elaborate statement of his views in regard to some points of the local situation. One passage in particular we recommend to the prayerful consideration of the Republican leaders, who imagine that their declaration at Saratoga has won the support of all those who attach any value to "morality."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- The court-martial of Capt. Sumner of the cruiser Columbia for permitting his ship to be injured through imperfect docking at Southampton, may be followed soon by an inquiry relating to a mishap said to have befallen the cruiser Newark while on her recent voyage from Rio de Janeiro to Cape Town, Africa.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19. -- Ross C. Van Bokelen, receiving teller of the Merchants' Loan and Trust Company, is missing with about $50,000 of the money belonging to the institution. Mr. Van Bokelen is supposed to be in Mexico.
A big Mexican mining speculation that was to have made everybody concerned enormously rich has suddenly developed into a tangle of litigation.

Patrick H. Flynn, President of the Nassau Electric Railroad Company, has begun suit against Park Commissioner Squier of Brooklyn, and charges him with paying $2,500 an acre for land that was not worth $1,200, and in some cases only $700.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- A fire, which was of incendiary origin, at 4 o'clock this morning destroyed the large red barn of John D. Rockefeller, which was situated on the Bedford Road, near the Berkeley Inn, the Summer home of many prominent New-York people.
A letter written by a young Boston girl to her brother, under date of Aug. 27, 1824, is very interesting reading just at this time. She wrote:

Gen. Benjamin F. Tracy on one side and Col. John R. Fellows on the other yesterday took up two hours of Judge Fitzgerald's time in the Court of General Sessions in arguing as to whether Sheriff Tamsen can properly be tried under the two indictments found against him last month in connection with the escape from Ludlow Street Jail on July 4 of Allen, Killoran, and Russell, the Post Office robbers.

The entries for the Westchester County Horse Show Association's fifth annual show, to be held at White Plains the first week in October, have closed, with about 325 nominations for the 56 classes. This number of exhibits is larger than the association has received for any of its previous exhibitions, and includes, besides several new candidates for show-ring honors, many horses which have been prize winners at other shows.

MANASQUAN, N.J., Sept. 19. -- Miss Page and Miss Rosalie Cook, at Point Pleasant Beach, were rescued from drowning this morning by George Harley, a boy of fifteen, and his companion. Miss Cook and Miss Page were bathing in the surf. The ropes had been removed from the bathing grounds several days, and there was nothing to hold on to that would prevent them from being carried beyond their depth.

Three months ago the man who traveled about the State with his ears open heard little else than talk about the free coinage of silver. Now he may travel and listen all day without hearing the noise of the fifty-cent-dollar orator. The people apparently have come to the conclusion that free silver is not wanted.

Chances of further gold exports were lessened materially yesterday by a decline in the rate of sterling exchange to $4.89 for demand bills. At this rate, gold may be forwarded to Europe without loss. Since bills were sold as early as Tuesday for shipments to be made by to-morrow's steamers, it is possible that withdrawals for that purpose may be made to-day.

It was a Spanish scholar, who, about ten years ago, published the interesting little pamphlet, "English as She Is Wrote." Secretary Morton has received a letter from one of the South American diplomats, well known in Washington, who has apparently been a close student of the handy little volume referred to. Writing from a South American point, he says:

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 19. -- John W. Griggs, the Republican nominee for Governor of New-Jersey, was born July 10, 1849, near Newton, Sussex County, N.J. His early education was obtained in the Collegiate Institute of Newton, whence he went to Lafayette College, Easton, Penn., which he entered in 1865.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 19. -- This has been a busy day at Newport, with many social events. Miss Whitehouse and Miss Clapp gave a picnic to-day at Vaucluse. Among their guests were Miss Burden, Townsend Burden, Jr., Miss Fair, Miss Sherman, Reginald Brooks, Miss Consuelo Vanderbilt, Harry Whitehouse, Miss Davies, Miss Gertrude Vanderbilt, Cornelius Vanderbilt, Jr., Miss Hoffman, Miss Preston, J. Ellis Hoffman, Miss Stillman, James A. Stillman, Miss Brice, Stewart Brice, and H.R. Taylor.
Common sense is not out of place even in discussions of the Sunday excise law. Magistrates may use it fearlessly in compounding their opinions. It will do them good.

SARATOGA, Sept. 19. -- The Saratoga Democratic Convention, held at Ballston Spa this afternoon, was one of the most harmonious and enthusiastic political gatherings that ever met in this county. Walter I. Cavert of Chariton presided.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of The New-York Times.

Not many things more beautiful have we ever seen than a fine sailing yacht with white sails spread like wings, and flying over the green surface of the wide sea. The sea itself is never so beautiful as when animated and dominated by a sail. The yacht race in the New-York waters had great attractions for us.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 19. -- This is Georgia Editors' Day at the exposition, and they are present nearly two hundred strong. The attendance cannot yet be estimated, but will probably be as great as on the opening day.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Sept. 19. -- At the picnic of the Union soldiers, held here a few days ago, Mrs. Tinkey was sitting under a tree chatting with her husband when a very handsomely dressed young woman approached with a babe in her arms and asked Mrs. Tinkey if she would hold it for a few moments while she went to talk with a friend in another part of the grove.

NORWICH, Sept. 19. -- At the Chenango County Republican Convention held here today Jonathan P. Allds was nominated for member of the Assembly. Albert F. Gladding as renominated for County Judge and Surrogate, and W.B. Matterson for District Attorney.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 19. -- The earnestness and enthusiasm of the friends of the various candidates for Governor resulted in keeping to-day's Republican State Convention in disorder from the time it met until it adjourned.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Sept. 19. -- A conspiracy against Alfaro, led by Gen. Plutarco Bowen and by Gen. Frevino, has been discovered.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- The State Department has urged our Minister to Switzerland to press to conclusion the international question which has grown up between the United States and that country over the abduction of an eight-year-old girl named Constance Madeleine His. This controversy is a heritage from the Blaine Administration, and was first introduced to the attention of the State Department people by Congressman John De Witt Warner.

In a previous communication, (see The Times of Sept. 4,) I attempted to describe the great natural wealth of the Island of Cuba, and the facilities which its configuration, abundance of harbor, and the proximity to the great consuming markets of the United States afford for turning that wealth to good account.

GOV. Sheldon has received a communication from William D. Riley of Philadelphia, who tackles the Russian thistle question with all the confidence of a man who doesn't know anything about the subject. He states that he has instructed the Governor of North Dakota to give orders to have every thistle cut in that State before the seed crop is spread for another year.
HEAD QUARTERS, EL CANEY, Aug. 28. -- My esteemed and good friend:

There continues to be considerable discussion in commercial and shipping circles concerning the suggestion, made by The New-York Times that the time is now ripe for the construction of a ship canal from Lake Erie to the Hudson River.

The sixth special race for thirty-four-raters was sailed yesterday off Larchmont. There was to have been a race for twenty-one-footers also, but the Vaquero was the only one on hand, and she raced against the Dragoon and Acushla. In addition to this race, the Acushla and Vaquero sailed a match race for a fifty-dollar cup, the Acushla giving the Vaquero 20 minutes' time allowance.

Spruce IV., the English challenger for the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club's new international challenge cup for small yachts, and Ethelwynn, the defender, were sailing in company in the Sound off Oyster Bay yesterday afternoon, but as there was very little wind no comparisons of value could be made.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Sept. 19. -- Preparations have begun for the trial of the Ammen ram Katahdin, which will take place off this port about the 1st of October. The United States steamers Dolphin and A.D Roche have arrived here and have begun to arrange the buoys and marks along the course.

READING, Penn., Sept. 19. -- The race meet of the Penn Wheelmen in this city to-day was a great success. Over 3,000 wheelmen saw "Tom" Cooper make almost a clean sweep of the day's events. Cooper won the three open events, and thus tied the record of Bald for the National Circuit. Cooper has now won twenty-eight firsts.

The Brooklyns received a most severe thrashing yesterday at the hands of the Baltimores in the baseball game at Eastern Park. It was ladles' day at the grounds, and the fair sex were on hand in large numbers. But even their presence failed to inspire the home team to hit the ball as freely as their opponents were doing.

The city man's desire to hunt is based neither on affection nor on mimicry. Americans do not hunt foxes or ride across country because it is done in England. The strain of English blood may show itself, perhaps, in American horsemanship, but Americans ride across country because that is a far livelier and more interesting form of riding than riding on the road, even when it is a park road or a paved street.

HUDSON, Sept. 19. -- Louis F. Payn, the "boss" of Republican politics in this county, is in hot water in his own county. He was moved deeply the other day when he read in The New-York Times that some of the citizens of this place accused him of trying to remove the county seat to Chatham.

Nominally there were two stake races at the Brooklyn Jockey Club's races at Gravesend yesterday. They were the Willow Handicap for two-year-old fillies and the Seabreeze Stakes for three-year-olds. The latter was a selling race under a stake name.

Thomas Cooper, a colored waiter, twenty-five years old, of 495 Seventh Avenue, and his wife, Mary, were arraigned in Jefferson Market Court yesterday by Policeman Rohrs of the West Thirtieth Street Police Station on the charge of disorderly conduct. Cooper's head had been clubbed by a policeman, and presented a horrible appearance.

PARIS, Sept. 19. -- The review of the French army, which has been manoeuvring during the week in the Department of the Vosges, took place at Mirecourt to-day in the presence of an enormous crowd of spectators.
While on a tour of the Coast Range mountains during the past month, Charles Burckhalter, a surveyor of this city, secured some remarkable photographs.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 19. -- The Republican State Convention to-day, from the six candidates who had persistently made a campaign for five months, nominated John W. Griggs of Passaic County for Governor. His merits were set forth by Garret A. Hobart of the National Republican Committee, whose generalship had much to do with the success of his candidate.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 19. -- Hobart Krum of Schoharie County was nominated for Senator in the Republican Convention for the Twenty-seventh District this afternoon, on the four hundred and eighty-sixth ballot, the entire Montgomery delegation going over to him.

BOSTON, Sept. 19. -- An informal conference of some of the Union Pacific Directors was held in this city yesterday, when the views of Government Director Coombs, who has recently been over the property, were the subject of consideration. The Directors con cluded not to adjourn until December, as is customary, but to convene again on Oct. 30.
The Police Commissioners decided yesterday to try Capt. Strauss of the East Sixty-seventh Street Station on Sept. 27 for neglect of duty and conduct unbecoming an officer.

HAVANA, Sept. 19. -- The Spanish warship Shanchez Barcaiztegui, with Admiral Delgado Parejo on board, was struck by the incoming coasting steamer Mortera in front of Moro Castle, at midnight last night, and sank almost instantly.
MADRID, Sept. 19. -- The Imparcial has a dispatch from Havana giving the following particulars of the loss of the warship Sanchez Barcaiztegui.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 19. -- The Morris County Golf Club began its invitation tournament this afternoon on the club grounds, near Convent Station. The games were scheduled for yesterday afternoon, but owing to the moist condition of the turf it was decided to postpone play until to-day. The players engaged in the tourney include most of the Orange cracks, with a sprinkling of home talent, which, however, disappeared after the first two rounds.

The council of the University of the City of New-York considers that the institution is fortunate in having secured Prof. Samuel Weir for the Chair of the History of Education and Ethics in the School of Pedagogy. He succeeds to the position filled for a long time by the late Jerome Allen, and during the last year by Prof. George F. James, who recently resigned.

Theodore Roosevelt spoke last night before Good Government Club P, at 27 West One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street, on the excise and other questions of the day. He had an audience that was remarkable in numbers, respectability, and spontaneity of sympathy with the speaker's views.

No play at any of the theatres was more thoroughly enjoyed last night than was the "Dressed as We Were" meeting given by the Salvation Army in the large auditorium of its building in West Fourteenth Street. Not even in the balcony or gallery was there standing room, more than half the room being filled by those not members of the army, who paid a small admission fee.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19. -- Negotiations are almost completed for the purchase by the Atchison Reorganization Committee of its own terminal property, the title to which is now held in part by the Chicago Elevated Terminal Company, which is practically synonymous with Gen. Joseph T. Torrence of this city.

President Roosevelt of the Police Board received a communication from Washington, D.C., yesterday relating to excise laws and clubs. Mr. Roosevelt declined to say who the author was. The letter is as follows:

Republicans in this city and Brooklyn, in their efforts to adjust themselves to local conditions, are very much dissatisfied with the action of the Republican State Convention on the excise question. It is the old story. As members of the party in the State they say one thing at their States conventions, and another thing when they get among their constituents.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19. -- The bulletin issued to-day for the Racing Board by Chairman Gideon contains the following items of interest:

Some days ago Collector Kilbreth, in consequence of representations that were made to him by warehousemen and others who hold tobacco on storage, issued "General Order No. 57," which precluded importers of leaf tobaccos from opening bales of tobacco in storage warehouses, and there exposing their goods for inspection and close examination by would-be purchasers.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- The football season opened here on Sept. 10, with Capt. Wyckoff in charge of about fifteen candidates. Daily practice in tackling the dummy, punting, and dropping on the ball was indulged in until Coach Marshall Newell arrived on the 16th. The last week has shown an increase in the number of candidates, so that there are now about twenty-five men in all on the field every day.

Mr. PLATT, in his convention at Saratoga on Tuesday, devoted a very considerable proportion of his platform to National questions. A good deal of space was necessary to cover views on so large a variety of subjects, some of which were so inconsistent with others. It is not easy to see what the question is that Mr. PLATT proposes to put to the voters of New-York.

As to this matter of the 20,000,000 of church communicants in the country, the reader may be interested in seeing how they are distributed according to the census report of the churches. Here are the figures:

Resolved, That we demand the simplification of our system of internal revenue, the abolition of useless and inquisitorial taxes, and the reduction of the whole volume of taxation now in excess of the wants of the Government, and the exigencies of the public credit.

A movement is on foot to dispense with the prayer at executions hereafter at the State Penitentiary. Deputies Dawson and Stackhouse both favor the change on the ground that in the time occupied by the prayer prisoners often lose their nerve who otherwise would go through the trap perfectly cool.

Parrots are all right and very amusing unless they happen to be too intelligent. They are charming creatures so long as they will repeat only what you teach them, but when they begin to think for themselves and to voice their thoughts the matter changes complexion, and may end as seriously as did an affair at Stamford, this State, the other day.

Jacob Worth and Theodore B. Willis, the leaders of the two factions in the Republican Party of Brooklyn, are of the opinion, and have frequently said that Mayor Schieren would not be the Republican candidate for Mayor. There are, however, many active Republicans who differ with these leaders, and who have refrained from making public their views.

Bookmaker Charles H. Thompson, best known to the frequenters of race tracks and poolrooms "Butch" Thompson, underwent a severe operation last Tuesday. For two years he has been treated for supposed liver and kidney troubles without avail, and from a big, powerful man has shrunk to an apparent physical wreck. Winter before last he sought relief at Hot Springs, Ark.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 19. -- Gen. Granville M. Dodge, President of the Society of the Army of the Tennessee, presided over the reunion of the survivors of the army of that name who served in either the Union or Confederate ranks, which closed the proceedings of the first day of the dedication of the Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Park.

William Brooks is fighting in court to prevent the removal of a monument and railing from the plot in Greenwood cemetery where the bodies of his wife and daughter are buried. Charles E. Taintor Co. erected the monument and railing, under a contract with Mr. Brooks, for $1,850. He paid them $500 in cash and gave his notes for the rest.
A new challenge for the America's Cup has been received for a match to be sailed next year on conditions satisfactory to the America's Cup Committee.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- The two fires on the property of John D. Rockefeller, the Standard Oil magnate, by which two barns were leveled with the ground this week, have thoroughly alarmed not only the owner and his Superintendent, F.A. Bolze, but all who live in the vicinity of the Pocantico Hills.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Sept. 20. -- An effort is being made to establish a naval engineering school here similar to that at Vooiwith, England, which is recognized as the most important institution of its character in the world, where the engineering problems confronting the profession may be properly investigated and the Interests of the navy thereby advanced.

As a plot-inventor, Mr. Crockett has surpassed himself in this venture. He starts in Galloway, where he is always at home, and every sound-hearted, sympathetic reader is delighted to be with him. Then he darts off to the Bayswater district of London and puts himself on a footing with George R. Sims.

Richard Croker, the former leader of Tammany Hall, returned to this city yesterday, after six months' absence in England. He arrived on the Hamburg-American liner Columbia, which reached her dock in Hoboken shortly after noon. Mr. Croker's brother-in-law, Dr. W.T. Jenkins, ex-Health Officer of the port, boarded the Columbia at Quarantine.

Patrolmen James Hastings and William Fitzpatrick of the Mercer Street Station were put on trial before Commissioners Grant and Andrews at Police Headquarters yesterday afternoon on charges made by Mrs. Matilda Herremann, the Lexow witness who was the principal complainant against Capt. Eakins recently on charges made by the Parkhurst society for failing to suppress disorderly houses in his precinct.
LONDON, Sept. 20. -- A dispatch from Shanghai to a news agency here says that China expects to reoccupy Liao-Tung in October, and that Russia is pressing Japan to immediately evacuate that territory.

A pretty and very pathetic incident occurred in connection with the preparation of the programme for the Marine Band concert in the White House grounds last Saturday. Prof. Fanciulli, be it known, receives every day in his mail half a dozen or more letters from persons who request him to play certain selections at these open-air concerts.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 20. -- Gov. Morton was formally put in nomination for the Presidency by Senator Edmund O'Connor, at a serenade tendered to Morton last night by all the New-Yorkers present in Chattanooga, at the residence of F.G. Montague, with whom he dined. His policy as Governor was approved by Senator Cantor. Speeches were also made by John B. Stanchfield of Elmira, Speaker Hamilton Fish, and Archie Baxter, Clerk of the New-York Assembly.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 20. -- The short, sharp, and incisive contest to determine the extent of the probable Republican majority in Ohio under normal conditions has been opened by the party in power, and their opponents will formally accept the challenge at a meeting to be held in this city Sept 28. The year is known in Republican annals a the fatal sixth.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 20. -- Thomas F. Oakes, H.C. Paine, and H.C. Rouse, receivers for the Northern Pacific Railroad, filed a report of their trust in the United States court this afternoon. The report recommends that provisions be made for extraordinary expenditures during the next five years to the amount of $9,085,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The Italians of Washington to-day celebrated the anniversary of the unification of their country. The celebration began with a street parade and was conducted by the local society known as the Unione e Fratelanza Italiana.

It was learned yesterday that the members of the Canal Committee of the New-York Produce Exchange are deeply agitated over the discussion that has been carried on in the columns of THE NEW-YORK TIMES respecting the proposed construction of a ship canal between Lake Erie and the Hudson.

There are two pelicans, some gray herons, and a cormorant, which, with three white storks, make every afternoon a quaint group on the green bank on the eastern side of the Round Pond, in the Zoological Gardens. The rest of the birds are fed in the early morning on bread and grain; but these eat fish, and their daily dole is brought to them by the keeper about 3 o'clock in the afternoon.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 20. -- The representatives of the Sovereign Grand Lodge of Odd Fellows are nearly through with their deliberations. The fifth day's session was devoted to the adoption of the reports of committees. A resolution providing that memorial pages of deceased members of Grand Lodges be placed in the revised journal, introduced by Representative Grassman of New-Jersey, was reported favorably by the Committee on Legislation, and adopted.

The Directors of the Milk Dealers' Protective Association met yesterday afternoon at the law office of Agar, Ely Fulton, 31 Nassau Street, elected officers, and completed other details necessary to a permanent organization. The Directors were chosen at the meeting of wholesale milk dealers, held last Tuesday, at the Mercantile Exchange.

Some radical differences of opinion arose in the discussion of the new rate agreement at the meeting of railroad Presidents yesterday, thereby putting to flight Mr. Depew's cheerful expectations that the agreement would be promptly and unanimously adopted.

The semi-annual exhibition by the Merchant Tailors' Society, which was opened on Thursday at 241 Fifth Avenue, will be closed this evening, and the plum-colored evening suit which graced the collection of garments for men will now be relegated to the shop window of J.C. Weiss, who is responsible for its creation.

The following official letter, signed by the Vicar of Moush and three other prominent clergymen, members of the Armenian Relief Committee of Moush, has appeared in the Armenian papers of Tiflis, Russia:

In return for the kindness of Henry C. Miner, Congressman from the Eighth District, to the pilots of this port, in putting at their disposal his Fifth Avenue playhouse for a benefit performance in aid of the fund for the widows and orphans of deceased pilots, a dinner was tendered to him last evening at the Hotel Marlborough, Broadway and Thirty-sixth Street. Covers were placed for seventeen.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 20. -- The criminal libel suit of Judge C.G. Foster of the Federal court against Editor J.K. Hudson of The Topeka Capital will begin Monday in the Topeka court, and will be prosecuted by the County Attorney, assisted by David Overmyer, who was the Gubernatorial candidate on the Democratic ticket last year.

BUENOS AYRES, via Galveston, Sept. 20. -It is officially announced that French troops, against the expected invasion of which the Governor of Amapa asked for assistance from Brazil, have not disembarked on territory of Amapa. Two French vessels are cruising along the coast.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- The Chittenango and White Sulphur Springs Railway Company was incorporated to-day with the Secretary of State, with a capital of $150,000, to construct and operate a street surface road about five and seven-eighths miles long in Madison County.

LYONS DEPOT, Sept. 20. -- The Wayne County Democratic Convention, held here this afternoon, proved to be the most inharmonious meeting held in several years. There were two sets of delegates from the Town of Lyons, and the bone of contention was which one should be recognized.

Philip Ryan, known as one of the rough characters in "Mixed Ale Row," Killed his wife last night. He narrowly escaped lynching before he was locked up in the West Forty-seventh Street police Statiton.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Sept. 20. -- The First Ward of this city was filled in about twenty years ago to a depth of many feet; the streets were paved and sewers were built. The improvements cost nearly $2,000,000, and that sum was assessed against the property in the ward.

That is a very queer sequel of the failure of the cup races whereby a firm of English bankers has offered 1,000 for a race between the Valkyrie and the Defender in British or in neutral, only not in American, waters. Of course, there is not the least likelihood that anything will come of it.

With the noisy demonstrations of Spithead and Portsmouth, and the speech of Baron Blanc, the secret of the support given to Francesco Crispi for the last year and a half by the English press is at least partially divulged and explained. Africa is the mot d'enigme. With no other Minister than Crispi could Italy be seduced into continuance of that policy of aggression and adventure which has emptied her treasury and impoverished her people.

The average girl, as Ruth Ashmore knows her, is "between eighteen and twenty-four, whole-hearted, happy, generous, pretty and pleasant to look upon, and very anxious to do what is right." It is to help this average girl out of her small perplexities and into a sphere of womanly activity that this little book is written. Miss Ashmore says:
CHESTER, Penn., Sept. 20. -- Miss J.N. Irwin, sixty years old, of Brooklyn, N.Y., made two attempts at suicide here to-night.

Brooklyn politicians were engaged yesterday in discussing the exposures made by Contractor John E. Greany, in which he charged certain politicians and office holders with having failed to return to him money that he had loaned to them, as he alleges, in order to get them to sign certificates on which he received his pay from Kings County.

A meeting was held at the office of Richard K. Fox yesterday morning for the purpose of selecting a referee for the Corbett-Fitzsimmons prizefight. Joe Vendig, representing the Florida Athletic Club, and Martin Julian, who is manager for "Bob" Fitzsimmons, were the only men present, as Corbett was not represented, but telegraphed to postpone the meeting for a day, and Brady would be on hand.

The English Board of Agriculture has just issued a curious and suggestive report, showing what a great and sudden change has come over British agriculture. The report is for the year ending on June 4 last, and it establishes that within the year the area of Great Britain devoted to wheat has been diminished by over one-fourth.

BROCKWAYVILLE, Penn., Sept. 6. -- Coal mining occupies a large share of the attention of the public as an industrial factor of Pennsylvania, but the public generally has little knowledge of the various processes employed before a ton of bituminous coal is placed upon the market.

In his speech before the Saratoga Convention Mr. WARNER MILLER took pains to make it clear that the declaration in favor of "the maintenance of the Sunday laws" meant opposition to local option, or home rule, on the question of regulating, restricting, or forbidding the sale of drinks on Sunday.

" Well, no. I didn't believe in them -- that is, I didn't give much credence to the matter; I didn't give much thought to the miracles, anyway. I don't give much attention to the extraordinary. I like to see things for myself. I had no great desire to go to Lourdes."

Unless there is a vast improvement both in the racing and attendance the present meeting at Brighton Beach will prove a big failure. The attendance yesterday was exceptionally small, and the racing furnished anything but a satisfactory afternoon's sport.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- Forty-nine survivors of the sunken steamer Edam arrived at Paddington station at 5 o'clock this afternoon. They were received by the agents of the Netherlands American Steamship Company, who provided them with food and saw them off by the night mail train en route for Holland. Men, women, and children alike looked comfortable and contented.

VINELAND, N.J., Sept. 20. -- Two Italians who started out last night to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of the capture of Rome, and then drank five gallons of wine within an hour on a wager, are in danger of dying. A third man, who did his share of the drinking, was not affected in the least.

A deserved honor awaits Gen. H.V. BOYNTON, the historian of the Chickamauga-Chattanooga National Military Park. Ex-Gov. JAMES E. CAMPBELL of Ohio, in an address incidental to the ceremonies attending the formal dedication of the National Park, acknowledged the obligation which Ohio and the country owes to Gen. BOYNTON for its opportunity to dedicate such a reservation and set it aside for a perpetual memorial.

Senor Pi y Margall, the chief of the Federal Republican Party of Spain, in an article published in Don Quijote of July 12, says: "No nation has any right to occupy a territory without the consent of the people who live in it. If a nation occupies it by violence, the conquered have a perfect right to fight all the time until they expel the tyrants from their native soil.
BORDEAUX, Sept. 20. -- The fire in the exhibition buildings last night was confined to the pavilion devoted to the display of electrical apparatus, which was totally destroyed.

BUENOS AYRES, via Galveston, Sept. 20. -The Italian colony made a splendid festival in parades, speeches, and banquets to-day,' in celebration of Victor Emmanuel's entry into Rome and the unity of Italy.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20. -- The only point at all favorable to Durrant brought out thus far in his trial for the murder of Blanche Lamont was brushed aside by the prosecution to-day. This was the statement of Organist George R. King that he detected the odor of gas upon entering the church on the day of Blanche Lamont's murder.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- A report received at the Department of State from Consul General Ellis Mills, stationed at Honolulu, on the diversion of trade from San Francisco to New-York, states that during the six months which ended June 30, 1894, the total exports from Honolulu to the United States were invoiced at $5,001,538. For the corresponding period of this year merchandise valued at $4,949,916 was shipped, a decrease of $51,622.

It is an obvious and unnecessary error to suppose that the advocates of a canal fitted to carry its share in the commerce of the continent from the great lakes to the seaboard must oppose the expenditure of a few millions of dollars upon the improvement of the present canal system. It is quite as gratuitous a mistake for the advocates of the latter blindly to oppose the essential preliminary steps toward the greater enterprise.

ROME, Sept. 20. -- The buildings throughout the city are literally covered with decorations. The streets have been thronged with people eager to witness the ceremonies of this principal day of the series of celebrations commemorative of the entry of the Italian troops into Rome.

The New-York public has been extremely apathetic this year over baseball, and no wonder. In fact, desirable as it is to encourage local pride, the manifestation of local pride in the performances of a "team" whose members may have been divided last year, and may be divided next year, among half a dozen other towns is rather absurd.

ALBANY, Sept. 20. -- Warner Miller has started in his race for another term in the United States Senate. He counts, of course, upon unhatched eggs, for the State Senate, which will be elected this Fall, and the Assembly, which will be chosen a year hence, may not be of the political complexion which will suit the politics of the wood-pulp statesman.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 20. -- Managers Day and Wade of the Yale track team left here for New-York to-day, where they will make final preparations to-morrow for the coming Yale-Cambridge games, and also witness the New-York-London athletic games to-morrow afternoon.

Catalina Island has had an unusual run for sportsmen this year. Early in the season a gntleman of the name of Stuart M. son a gentleman of the name of Stuart M. leisure and an ardent sportsman, took up his residence there and made rare sport of what has hitherto been an almost exclusively business transaction, or fish murder.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The condition of the Newark's engines will lead to her recall to the United States, her place being taken probably temporarily, by the gunnery ship Lancaster, commanded by Capt. William R. Hoff, which will sail soon from Newport with relief crews for the Yantic and Newark. The machinery of the Newark is said to require extensive overhauling.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 20. -- The Scranton Baseball Club of the Eastern League, or what purported to be that aggregation, came to the Orange Oval this afternoon and was easily defeated by the Orange Athletic Club players in a loosely played game. The score:

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 20. -- Mrs. Brayton Ives gave one of the most charming dances of the season at Windyside this evening. The attendance was greater than at any previous dance, because there were so many large house parties in Lenox, composed of persons who have come on to attend the golf tournament next week. It was the first

Mr. S.B. Rogers has sold for Frank Herter, at about $20,000, the five-story brownstone flat 334 East Forty-ninth Street, 25 by 100, and for M.L. Rickerson, at $15,500, the three-story brownstone dwelling 503 Manhattan Avenue, 15 by 80.

Democrats of prominence from up the State were in this city yesterday, and, with local leaders, discussed the probable doings at the Syracuse Convention. Among the visitors were Senator David B. Hill, who arrived in the city from Albany Thursday night; Major James W. Hinkley of Poughkeepsie, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, and Railroad Commissioner Samuel A. Beardsley of Utica.

The Cunard steamship Campania arrived at the bar at 2:59 yesterday afternoon after having made a fast voyage of 5 days 11 hours and 34 minutes, which is only about two hours behind her record. She brought 725 cabin and 709 steerage passengers. Prominent among her passengers was Sir Julian Pauncefote, the British Ambassador to Washington.

There were few busier men in the city yesterday than the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst, who returned from Europe Thursday. From early morning until late at night there was a constant stream of visitors to the reverend gentleman's home, 133 East Thirty-fifth Street. All callers were admitted, and were accorded a hearty welcome by the doctor.

Three Justices of the Supreme Court are to be voted for in Brooklyn this Fall. Two of the nominations in each party will come from that city itself, and the third will go to one of the other counties in that Judicial District. There are also to be elected in Brooklyn two County Judges, a Surrogate, and a District Attorney.

The locomotive engineer is a remarkably placid fellow, with a habit of deliberate precision in his look and motions. He occasionally turns a calm eye to his gages and then resumes his quiet watch ahead. The three levers which he has to manipulate are under his hand ready for instant use, and when they are used it is quietly and in order, as an organist pulls out his stops.

One of Tammany's little olive branches to the German-American Reform Union has been rejected, very politely. At the convention for the selection of delegates to the Democratic State Convention, held in the Sixth Assembly District Wednesday night, E.B. Amend, a relative of Herman Ridder and a prominent member of the German-American Reform Union, was elected a delegate.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20. -- The first of the two games which the Oxford and Cambridge team of cricketers is scheduled, to play with the Gentlemen of Philadelphia was commenced here to-day on the grounds of the Germantown Cricket Club, and a grand exhibition of cricket was seen. The day was uncomfortably warm, without a breeze and with plenty of humidity, and the Englishmen suffered not a little on this account.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 20. -- There are 107 entries for the one-hundred-mile open handicap race of the Century Cycle Club of this city, which will be run on the Elizabeth-Rahway course, starting from Earl's Roadhouse, near Elizabeth, at 8:30 o'clock to-morrow morning. The club expects that the hundred-mile record will be broken.

Withdrawal of gold from the Sub-Treasury yesterday for export to-day amounted to only $150,000. A jeweler's firm took it for remittances. Intimations in THE NEWYORK TIMES that Friday's decline in the rate of sterling exchange would check outside speculation found entire confirmation. The firm that has been active in this line, and that had sold bills early in the week against intended shipments to-day, decided to cover the sales by purchases, which were made yesterday.

The old contest over the millions of dollars left by Charles Bathgate Beck is to be reopened. Howe Hummel, as counsel for Mrs. Matilda B. Carter, took the initial proceeding in the contest yesterday and began suit in the Superior Court to have Mr. Beck's will declared invalid.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 20. -- Two trains on the Long Island Railroad were approaching each other last night at the rate of twenty miles an hour. The trains were on the same track, and each carried many passengers.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 20. -- The proceedings of the third and last day of the dedication of Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park, judging from the crowd which thronged the streets, were the most attractive of the series. This was possibly, however, for the reason that there was nothing going on at the battlefield, and every one's attention was centred upon the meetings in the city tent.

" The only remedy for existing ills lies in home rule," said Frederic R. Coudert, as he yesterday discussed with a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES the excise question in the light of the plank on that subject which at the eleventh hour was incorporated in the Republican platform. Mr. Coudert's views are as follows:

Great Britain and America will be represented in a struggle for athletic supremacy at Manhattan Field this afternoon. Twenty-two athletes wearing the colors of the London Athletic Club will meet twenty-two young men representing the New-York Athletic Club, though several members of each team are more closely allied to other clubs than to that which they represent on this occasion.

It was remarked of the Republican State Convention at Saratoga that while it appeared to be made up of a body of men comparing favorably, on the average, with former Republican Conventions, it lacked the presence of men of distinction in public affairs. After DEPEW, MILLER, HISCOCK, FASSETT, and LEXOW had been named, there were present no other Republicans of sufficient prominence to provoke applause on their appearance or interest in their remarks.

Three thousand persons at Eastern Park, Brooklyn, yesterday saw the game of baseball between the Brooklyn and Baltimore Clubs. It was clearly Brooklyn's day, and they showed it by their free batting. Each run they scored proved of value, as they only won the game by a single run.

The item recently published in The New-York Herald, Telegram, and Tribune reflecting upon me in connection with the sale of some of the assets of the old Staten Island Dyeing Establishment, of which company I am receiver, does me great injustice, and I request that in fairness to me, you publish this letter in regard thereto:
OSWEGO, Sept. 20. -- The Democrats of Oswego County held no fewer than five conventions to-day, and there are more to follow to-morrow.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- To-day's session of the fifth annual convention of the American Numismatic Association was devoted to executive business. The old officers of the association were re-elected.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Sept. 21. -- The Peary relief steamer Kite arrived here this afternoon, Bringing Peary, Lee, and Henson safe home. The expedition party endured much hardship last Winter, but, undaunted, started northward again in April, in an attempt to make a new record. It succeeded in reaching Independence Bay, where tents were pitched.
Charles Creegan, twenty-eight years old, a painter, of 200 Avenue C, will go upon the records of the Police Department as one of the coolest small burglars on the lists.

A paper written by Miss Abigail Dodge (Gail Hamilton) was read in the church in Hamilton last Sunday evening. It was entitled "In the Valley of the Shadow of Death." Miss Dodge refuses to give the manuscript of the paper, but a short sketch of what was said has been obtained. She tells in the paper of reading her own obituaries.

Who was Sutekh or Sutech? Egyptologists believe that after the reign of the ideal Kings of the Twelfth Dynasty, a foreign race took possession of the Delta, and then conquered Egypt. So far their nationality has not been made clear. At first their seat of government was at a city called Hatu'ar, and their god was Sutekh.
A pretty girl in bridal dress, accompanied by about twenty men and women, took Magistrate Crane by surprise In the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning.

All editors are astonished at the poor English written by many of their would-be contributors, whose spelling and penmanship indicate that they have had a fair degree of education. Usually this stupidity in the use and choice of words seems to arise from a lack in the sense of humor. Even a university course, as every one knows, cannot make up for this essential quality, which is absolutely necessary to literary success.

Two hundred and fifty enthusiasts saw the deciding heats between Lettie K., owned by F.W. Brady, and J. McGuire's Lady Crerand. Last week these two had two races to road wagon and sulky, Lettie K. coming out ahead each time. Mr. McGuire was not satisfied, however, and another race was arranged for yesterday afternoon. This time professional drivers were put up.

As far as the published transactions are concerned, the past week has beeen a featureless one among real estate men. The sales reported include some lots to builders, a few dwellings, and several tenements and flats. The auction offerings, few in number, and almost without exception in legal proceedings, were adjourned for the most part.
A recent article in The New-York Times told of the revolutions and uprisings in Cuba between the years 1822 and 1868. The present article wil cover the period from 1868 to 1878.

The work of extinguishing the horse and putting him in company with the pterodactyl and the megatherium goes on as well as could fairly be expected. Steam and electricity have begun to supersede him for public transportation, the bicycle has smitten him sorely in his capacity as a means of locomotion for exercise or pleasure, and the perfection of the horseless carriage will render him useless with respect to several of his remaining functions.

PARIS, Aug. 31. -- Dead, dead -- not as one door nail, but as one hundred doors all full of nails -- such is Paris. It seems even more so than any other year. The faint echo of that idiotic Boulevard warcry, "En voulez-vous des-z-homards," sounds tame.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Sept. 21. -- Hot Springs is still made pleasant by the many social events and outdoor pastimes.

The annual prospectus of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, which has just been issued for the season 1895-6, has in it the promise of satisfying the needs of every intelligent seeker of knowledge through the medium of the lecture hall, as well as of gratifying the desires of those who simply want humane recreation.

A local tribunal of limited criminal jurisdiction is generally known as a Court of Special Sessions -- a title of no particular significance, derived from the old English judicature, yet, as is common with symbols, taking its strength from the thing represented. "The Sessions" is a very definite entity to those familiar with it.

Cricketers took full advantages of yesterday's heat, and three good matches were brought to a conclusion. The final game of the Manhattan Club, between married and single members, was played at Prospect Park. The bachelors, after E.E. Wadbrook and W. Beardall had made a good showing, were easily vanquished by the Benedicts, for whom H.B. Coyne and A. Smedley played in grand style. The following ic the score:

Charles W. Brooke, the lawyer, announced yesterday that he intended to file a formal complaint against Coroner Hoober in connection with the death of Clara Newman, at her home, 1,100 Second Avenue, on Aug. 7, and the inquest held by the Coroner.

The demonstration of the United Societies for Liberal Sunday Laws, which will take place next Wednesday and Thursday, promises to be of such magnitude as to eclipse the anticipations of its promoters. The parade, which will be on the east side of town, will start promptly at 2 o'clock Wednesday afternoon from Forty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept 21. -- The adjourned meeting of the Society of the Army of the Cumberland was held this morning. Among the distinguished men present were Gens. Stone, Robinson, A. Wiley of Ohio, Boynton, Fullerton, John T. Wieder, Parkhurst, J.W. Burke, D.S. Stanley, W.D. Whipple, Thomas, Chief of Staff: Col. J.W. Steele, Col George S. Rober, Col. W.D. Wickenham, and Judge R.H. Cochran, Gen. J.D. Morgan presided.

It is a peculiar delusion that country people are wiser and better than the inhabitants of cities; that they are not only capable of regulating their own local affairs better, but that they must take a hand in regulating those of the cities in order to save them from material or moral ruin.

The tiny representatives of the yachtsmen of England and America, the Spruce IV. and the Ethelwynn, met in a race for the first time yesterday, but owing to lack of wind were unable to finish in the required time and so the contest was declared off.

LONDON, Sept. 21. -- Mr. Charles Day Rose, son of Sir John Rose, of the banking firm of Morton, Rose Co. of London and owner of the yacht Satanita, sent his informal challenge for the America's Cup last week. The New-York Yacht Club acknowledged the challenge, but cabled in reply that it would be necessary for Mr. Rose to challenge formally for the cup through a yacht club.

When I lived in Queensland there were two great strike: The marine officers and sympathizers, and the shearers and sympathizers. During these strikes the total number of outrages alleged by rumor was three. Two of them (alleged attempts to poison soldiers) were found, after a diligent investigation by Government officials, to be canards.

Mr. Goodwin came to town last week and settled quietly at the Fifth Avenue theatre. He brought an old play that serves his purpose as well as a new one, and will doubtless be profitable for many years to come. In the last half of his eight weeks' engagement Mr. Goodwin will put forward a new piece by the author of "A Gilded Fool," called "Ambition." Meanwhile he is drawing crowds and entertaining them hugely.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- The Fourteenth Battalion, Major Collin of Cohoes commanding, N.G., S.N.Y., late this afternoon finished its week's service of field duty, after marching nine miles under an intensely hot sun. The concluding march was from White Sulphur Spring, south end of Saratoga Lake, to this place.

ALBANY, Sept. 21. -- Will Tammany Hall and the State Democracy share the representation from New-York City in the State Convention in such a way as to bring harmony between the two in campaign work and at the polls? is the most perplexing question which Democrats are discussing in connection with the approaching convention.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- Archbishop Satolli, Apostolic Delegate to the United States, in speaking of a recent telegram from London, in reference to reported negotiations between the Vatican and the Quirinal, said to-day:

Richard Croker was elected a delegate to the Democratic State Convention, to be held in Syracuse Sept. 24, from the Twentieth Assembly District, last night, and his election was followed by a scene of uproarious enthusiasm.

In his address before the American Association of General Passenger and Ticket Agents in Boston on the 17th inst., W.A. Turk, General Passenger Agent of the Southern Railway, gave some interesting information about the function of the General Passenger Agent in worldmaking. He said:

Night came on while I was in a long, dreary gorge. There were several little pools of rainwater, bits of quercus scrub, and pretty little flowers of the crocus family growing beside my path. But there was no sign of a human habitation. Toward midnight I saw two lights ahead of me, and heard dogs barking.
ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 21. -- The morning opened auspiciously for the great event which marked the celebration of the Blue and Gray Day.

An extraordinary letter purporting to have been recently written by ex-Sultan Murad in his prison to his brother, the reigning Sultan, Abdul Hamid, on the American question, has been published in the Arabic newspaper Al Mushir of Cairo, Egypt, edited by Selim Serkis, who had to flee from Beyrout to escape persecution by the Turkish Government for expressing too liberal views.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 21. -- The body of Allen Dale, the aged clerk of the Pennsylvania Railroad, whose body was found in the canal at Princeton, has been taken to Pennsylvania for burial. Allen's mother, who is nearly ninety years old, and in very feeble health, is at the Arch Street House, in Philadelphia.
GREENPORT, L.I., Sept. 21. -- To-day was the hottest of the season here. The thermometer at 3 o'clock this afternoon registered 96 in the shade.

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 21. -- Lovers of cricket among the fair sex in Bayonne enjoyed a social afternoon Thursday, when the first match was played here between teams of opposite sexes. The New-Jersey Athletic Club cricketers made up the men's team, captained by James L. Robertson, Sr. It was composed of F.B. Hunter, Archie Gunn, F.F. Kelly, F.C. Calder, Edward Jenkins, F. Edwards, E.L. Vredenburgh, E.R. Grant, H.F. Fox, A.C. Redwood, and G.R. Cooper.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- To the student of New-York politics there is an interesting lesson to be learned in the fate of George F. O'Nell. At the Third Ward caucus in this city recently his own ward repudiated him.

Donkeys have only been common in the island since the days of Queen Elizabeth, yet in that time we have brought the donkey to a condition only matched elsewhere by the ass of India, condemned to be the beast of burden of the low-caste potter, and identified -- of all horrible attributes -- with the god of smallpox.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- More interest will be taken in football at the Military Academy this year than ever before, though there will be no game with Annapolis.

The profits of the Government bond syndicate were distributed yesterday by checks issued by Messrs. Morgan and Belmont. The amounts sent out represented an allowance of 1 3/4 per cent. for interest on advances made from February to June, being at the rate of 4 per cent. a year and 4.9 per cent. for profits.

The annual drive of spruce logs on the Connecticut River ended on Friday, Aug. 20, and the twenty-five men and twenty-two horses have finished this season's job. The last camp was made at the east end of Hadley Bridge, where for three days the five tents, the campfire, and the long row of strong horses picketed in the bushes have attracted much attention.

The special committee of eight to which the trunk line railroad Presidents intrusted the task of revising the new traffic agreement met in the Jersey Central Building in Liberty Street yesterday and spent several hours in discussing the plan. There are twenty-five sections in the agreement, and the members of the committee were unable to act on them all yesterday. The committee will meet again to-morrow and possibly on Tuesday also.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21. -- William B Curtis arrived from the Orient yesterday of the steamship Gaelic. He came directly from China, tarrying but three days in Japan.

It is fortunate that with the fast failing bass and trout fishing in this vicinity those fishermen of this city who are willing to try for less exalted prey can still find some good sport. In fresh water the game this month is the pickerel, and in a score of ponds less than two hours' journey from New-York royal fun can be had from now on until the ice shuts in the water.

Col. George Moore Smith of the Sixty-ninth Regiment has just issued his first order to that command since he has been commissioned as Colonel. He pays a high tribute to the record of the regiment, and hopes its members will do all in their power to advance the interest of the organization.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 21. -- When the Supreme Court opened this morning Judge Lippincott announced that he was ready to hear the various applications for writs of certiorari in regard to the Jersey City water contract.

LONDON, Sept. 21. -- The America's Cup continues to be a topic of discussion. The Pall Mall Gazette alludes to the offer of a firm of London bankers to give 1,000 for a race between the Defender and Valkyrie III. outside of American waters as ridiculous, and the press generally ignores the offer as having dubious features and likely to come to nothing.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 21. -- Democrats who have come here to be present at the convention believe a good many portions of the State which have been troublesome in some other years will not have any grievances this year which will take much time of the convention or its committees. Few contests are expected.

HAVANA, Sept. 21. -- Cable advices from Madrid give additional details regarding the pontoon service elaborated by Admiral Berenger, Minister of the Navy. The number of pontoons has been fixed at thirty. They are large floats, each with crew and cannon. They will be manned by men from the royal navy, and will form a new and important part in the coast defenses.

It was one evening in the early Summer that Harold Edwards, a young author of more merit than recognition, left his lodgings in the suburbs of the metropolis for a stroll through the quiet byways of the park. He had written steadily during the day, with scarcely a respite for a bite and both body and mind were sorely fatigued.

The present activity in enforcing the law for milk inspection is a point of great satisfaction to all persons intelligently interested in the health of the city. It emphasizes anew, too, the prolific source of danger which is harbored in this fluid, than which in its unadulterated and sterilized state no article of food is more valuable and life-sustaining.

Martin Engel, the Tammany leader in the Eighth Assembly District, was in a state of fear yesterday as to the outcome of his brutal assault Friday night on William Lawrence, at the rooms of the Engel Association, Grand and Ludlow Streets.

Controller George W. Palmer of Brooklyn, who is opposed to civil service reform, dismissed from his office last February Robert Crummey, the assistant warrant clerk, who was a veteran fireman, and who was protected by the civil service laws.

It was at Cambridge that I had the privilege of meeting the late Lowndean professor of astronomy, John Couch Adams, the discoverer of the planet Neptune. It was about five years ago. He was then ailing, suffering from insomnia; still, his dark-brown eyes were peculiarly bright, and his complexion ruddy.

The wonderful results of the snake cure of Si Forman, the old negro snake charmer, were shown yesterday morning, when he cured himself of the bite of a rattlesnake. Forman was exhibiting his collection of ratlers at the corner of Hogan and Bay Streets, and while handling a large rattler that he captured at Fort George a few days ago, the snake struck at him and managed to inflict two wounds on his left hand.

The hot wave, which has caused the people of this vicinity to suffer so intensely for the last three days, did its level best yesterday, and succeeded in producing a genuine record breaker. Yesterday was not only the hottest day of the year, but it was the hottest 21st day of September of which any record exists in the Weather Bureau.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 21. -- The first annual one-hundred-mile handicap road race arranged by the Century Cycle Club of Newark was rub on the Elizabeth-Rahway course to-day, the men riding five times over the twenty-mile circuit. A large crowd of enthusiasts gathered at Earl's Half-Way House, between this city and Rahway, to see the men start at 9:25 A.M., and many more assembled to applaud the survivors when they came along six hours later.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 21. -- The East Orange Cyclers held their annual twenty-six-mile road race this afternoon, the roads being in fine condition and the weather suitable. A big crowd of bicylists, among whom there was a large proportion of ladies, witnessed the contest, which was spirited from the start.

LONDON, Sept. 21. -- There is no longer any uncertainty regarding one all-important point of the Government's legislative programme. In entering office free from positive pledges, the Conservatives had an advantage over the Liberals, who were pledged to numerous fads, besides legitimate reforms.
STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 21. -- There have been many more arrivals than departures in this pleasant country town recently, and the cottages, hotels, and boarding houses are filled with guests.

Seth Low, President of Columbia College, got back from Europe on the St. Louis yesterday. When seen by a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES last night his face was ruddy with health and he semed in good spirits.

The subject of the free transportation of bicycles on the railroads, spoken about in Thursday's NEW-YORK TIMES, has been discussed quite extensively since then by thinking wheelmen. Those who have had occasion to travel on railroads which demanded a fixed charge for transferring wheels are among the most enthusiastic supporters of the free plan.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 21. -- This has been comparatively quiet week in Lenox, as people seem to be waiting for the festivities of the golf tournament week, when there are to be a number of dances, dinners, and other social functions. Mrs. William D. Sloane gave the chief dinner of the week for her guests, Mavroyeni Bey and Raymond Le Ghait.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Sept. 21. - The good people of this town are going to elect a Mayor. Though the election does not take place until November, the entire population is already deeply interested in the probable candidates and the outcome of the contest. Long Island City is a political town.

The rise of capitalism in the Middle Ages is illustrated in the most striking manner by the story of the celebrated family of Fugger, of Augsburg. We are accustomed to think of the political and social power attained by the financial families of our day as something peculiar to the present century.

ALBANY, Sept. 21. -- There will be no contesting delegation from Albany County at the Syracuse Convention. The four Assembly Democratic District Conventions were held to-day, and in each the proceedings were harmonious. It was expected that the usual dispute between the Grogan and Boylan factions in the Fourth District would develop, but it did not.

In Orkney the ebb and flow of the tides was attributed to the breathing of a sea monster which lay outstretched on the confines of the world. So gigantic was he that the simple acts of expiration and inspiration took twelve hours to perform. The resemblance between this nature myth and that of the Greeks is very remarkable.

Mr. GLADSTONE declares, in regard to the bimetallist controversy, that at his age and with his disabilities he "cannot be anything more than an individual and ineffective well-wisher to what" he believes "to be right." But his views are entirely clear. They are unchanged since he announced them two years and a half ago in the House of Commons.
Weeks W. Culver, a lawyer at 93 Nassau Street, is under arrest in Ludlow Street Jail for contempt of court.
ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 21. -- The Llewellyn Sons of Temperance had an enjoyable meeting, at which Grand Worthy Patriarch Ross Slack and other grand officers were present, this evening.

It is interesting, with each recurring Autumn, to watch the city fill up again with its returned residents. The clientele of the New-York shops in July and August is as different from that which throngs their doors through the rest of the year as the strollers on Murray Hill in the dog days are unlike the usual frequenters of that aristocratic neighborhood.
Longton Police Court. John Flannagan, charged with assaulting Mary Sheen. He knocked her down and kicked her, and struck her over the shoulders with a poker. Fined 20s, and costs, or one month.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Sept. 21. -- Mr. and Mrs. John H.C. Church gave a very pleasant drive whist party this week. Mrs. O.M. Ackenburg and Mrs. Anderson captured the women's prizes, which were a silver tea strainer and a spoon holder. Mr. G.W. Peters took the silver-handled knife, which was the men's first prize, and Mr. Sanford was well satisfied with the silver matchbox, which was the second prize.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 21. -- The best attended, of the three Summer dances given by Plainfield's younger set was that held Monday night at the Casino of the Union County Country Club. The committee who had charge of the dances was made up of Howard Beebe, Frederick Walz, and Laurens Van Buren.

LONDON, Sept. 21. -- [Copyright, 1895, by THE NEW-YORK TIMES.] -- Cynics are pointing out that on the day it was announced that the Russian Minister of Foreign Affairs was coming over from Contrexville to pay a state visit to the French President at the headquarters of the French manoeuvres, the news was also published of a further Russian loan, to be issued in Paris Nov. 1.

Just at a time when Francatelli's work, having gone through several editions, had become the textbook of all in England who aimed at a higher class of work than that exemplified in the ordinary domestic cookery book, an artist then at the top of his profession -- Jules Gouffe -- produced his classical work, "Le Livre de Cuisine," in Paris.

Five thousand persons visited Eastern Park, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, where they witnessed a very exciting game of baseball between the Brooklyn and Baltimore Clubs. It was a most interesting game, and inning after inning closed without a run being scored on either side.

UNION COURSE, L.I., Sept. 21. -- After many years of effort the Methodists of this village have at last succeeded in raising funds sufficient to build a suitable house of worship, and a cozy little structure is now nearly completed.

ELLICOTT CITY, Md., Sept. 21. -- Senator German was to-day the star attraction at an all-day mass meeting in Lorenzo Warfield's Woods, at Glenelg, a central point in Howard County, and the scene of many big political demonstrations in days gone by. Senator C. Gorman made a memorable address there in the Presidential contest of 1892, in which he eulogized Mr. Cleveland.

"It tells how Pinon Bill gets a hoss on Jack Moore, leaves the camp bogged up to the saddle girths in doubt about who downs Burke, an' stakes the deef woman so she pulls her freight for the States.

The teredo is the most destructive marine animal we have. It enters the submerged part of the piling of wharves or railroad trestles, and bores into the interior. When it penetrates the surface of the wood it is about the size of a pin, but increases in size, always lengthening, but never leaving any part of the hole it bores until its full mission is accomplished.

STAPLETON, S.I., Sept. 21. -- Conventions were held this afternoon by the regular Democratic Party organization, and by the organization of Richmond County Democrats, which was formed three years ago to fight the ring in the County Government. The regular convention was held at the German clubrooms, at this place, and was largely attended and harmonious.
The Reinhard Assembly committee met in the Aldermen's room, in the City Hall, yesterday and resumed its investigations as to the treatment of girls in stores and factories.

Kew, as a great finishing school for Brit'sh gardeners, has been established more than a century. It was founded as a royal garden by Augusta, Dowager Princess of Wales, the mother of George III. This was in 1759.

BOSTON, Sept. 21. -- The League season closed to-day with one of the most exciting games this season. Two new men to League company were the star performers. Davis of Pawtucket, if he continues to play as he did to-day, is a treasure. He tied the score in the eighth with a three-bagger with the bases full.

" What of it," asks Bishop Messmer of Wisconsin, "even if the people of Rome did vote not to have the Pope for their ruler?" Well, about the most obvious consequence of it is that the Pope does not rule the people of Rome. The good Bishop might with profit reflect on this fact for a considerable period, and even longer.

The committee of Tammany Hall having in charge the transportation of delegates, friends, sympathizers, and followers to the Syracuse Convention met at the Wigwam yesterday afternoon and made the final arrangements. The braves will leave to-morrow morning in two special trains, which will start from the Grand Central Station at 9:40 o'clock A.M. and 9:45 o'clock A.M.

Robert Graham of this city, General Secretary of the Church Temperance Society, has just returned from a visit of three months to Great Britain, having been commissioned by the society to investigate the various remedial agents adopted in the large cities of that country for the evils of intemperance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- Reports have been received at the Treasury Department which show that Lieut. G.L. Carden of the United States Revenue Marine Service has been distinguishing himself out near Port Townsend, Washington.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, via Galveston, Sept. 21. -- A great mass meeting was held here last night to protest against the mob's attack on the printing rooms of the journal El Globo.

During the recent prolonged depression which has extended over most of the civilized world, the artists, and particularly the painters, have had the hardest of hard times. As one of them recently remarked: "There is really no branch of production that has suffered more, unless it be the manufacture of traveling bags.

BERLIN, Sept. 21. -- Prince von Hohenlohe, who joined the Emperor on the imperial train at Dantzic, Sept. 16, in obedience to the Kaiser's summons to the Chancellor to report to him the results of the Prince's mission to St. Petersburg, had a conference with his Majesty covering three days, each day's audience being prolonged for several hours.

There have been indications during the last week that Mayor SCHIEREN may be renominated by Mr. JACOB WORTH as the Republican candidate in Brooklyn. These indications come from both sides. Politicians claiming to be "near" to Mr. WORTH have taken occasion to deny that that leader is unalterably opposed to Mr. SCHIEREN'S renomination.

There was no reason why the American eagle should not have done as he did last evening. Finding the topmost branch of the topmost tree, he perched there just as the sun was going down, and, flapping his wings, he screeched defiance to the whole world.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 21. -- The stay here of Lord Dunraven and the several social functions in his honor were the features of the week. Lord Dunraven's host and hostess, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Vanderbilt, who were entertaining Lady Boughey as well, did all in their power to make his visit here enjoyable and restful.

LONDON, Sept. 21. -- The mystery of the disappearance of Mrs. Langtry's jewels has not yet been cleared up. The noted solicitor Sir George Lewis, who has charge of Mrs. Langtry's case, affirms the truth of the story, although Mrs. Langtry is uncertain as to the exact value of the missing jewels, first placing it at 75,000 and then at 40,000.

Mr. John Drew will begin his engagement at the Empire Theatre to-morrow night with a new play written for him by Mr. Henry Guy Carleton, called "That Imprudent Young Couple." The piece has been very successful in other cities, and is said to provide excellent characters for Mr. Drew and Miss Maude Adams.

Men are being converted every day to the belief that New-York and Brooklyn should be consolidated. Indeed, the opinion is becoming general that unless Brooklyn becomes part of the Greater New-York, her future will be a miserable failure.

The century run which will take place to-day under the joint auspices of the Gramercy and Metropolis Wheelmen will take a large number of local wheelmen out of the city for the day. Over 300 entries had been received up to last evening, and the late entries, together with the large number which is certain to enter at the ferry this morning, will no doubt bring the total close to 400.

Society folk have begun to wend their way toward the city. The cold weather of the early part of the week caused many people to return to the city earlier than they would otherwise have done. Lenox is now the chief attraction for those who remain in the country for the Fall season, although Newport is still quite gay, and will be so until the end of October.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 21. -- A large and fashionable crowd attended the international cricket match here to-day, and during the afternoon it was computed that between eight and ten thousand persons were on the ground. The heat was again intense, but it afforded the Philadelphia belles an opportunity of coming out in their gayest Summer attire, and they made the grand stand very attractive with their bright costumes.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 21. -- Syracuse will put on its gala attire for the Democratic State Convention. It has been definitely decided by the leading business men, regardless of party affiliations, to make as elaborate a display of flags and bunting as possible in honor of the visiting Demorcrats. Railroad Street, from the Central Station, will be gay with patriotic emblems, and even the City Hall will be festooned for the occasion by the Republican officials.
