The Bavarian peasant players, known all over Europe as the Schliersee company, will reach here at the end of this week, and will open in the Metropolitan Opera House on or about the 30th inst. They will bring with them all the scenery, cos tumes, and properties they have used abroad in the various cities and towns in which they have played.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 21. -- The rumor current here that the St. Louis manufacturers of tobacco and cigarettes and the Tobacco Trust have agreed upon a division of business, has given an added interest to the case brought yesterday before Attorney General Hancock, by C.A. Whelan Co. against the American Tobacco Company.
One of the peculiarities of the late Edward B. Harper, late President of the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association, comes out strongly in his will, which was filed yesterday in the Surrogate's office.

The part which New-York and New-Yorkers have taken in building this Nation and preserving it is to be told in a State history, authorized during the last days of the last legislative session. Thus early after his appointment to the newly created position, the State Historian has outlined a plan of work and zealously entered upon it.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept 22. -- Dr. Talmage is spending a few days at his country home in this village pending the termination of the negotiations now in progress that may result in his settlement in Washington, D.C., as co-pastor of the First Presbyterian Church in that city. It is believed that during the present week Dr. Talmage will receive a formal call and will accept it.

SING SING, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- The Democratic County Convention, which will be held, very probably, the second week in October, will be much smaller than those held since 1891. The representation is based on the Democratic Gubernatorial vote, which was heavy in 1891 and light in 1894, hence the decrease in representation by delegates.

David H King, Jr., James A. Roosevelt, Augustus D. Juilliard, and George G. Haven, the four Commissioners of Public Parks, have handed in their resignations to Mayor Strong, to take effect Oct. 1, according to a statement printed yesterday.

Oscar Roswell, thirty-five years old, a watchman for Terry Tench, the iron contractors who are building the draw of the new New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad bridge at Park Avenue and the Harlem River, is missing, and the indications are that his body lies at the bottom of the river.

Evidently Excise Commissioner Harburger has a deep and accurate knowledge of American history, both ancient and modern, and is, therefore, particularly well qualified to tell us all about Sabbath observance here, as it was, as it is, as it will be, and as it should be. In addressing a meeting of Harlemites, he told them that the Sunday which made this country great and grand was not the Puritanical one.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- The forty-sixth year's work of the University of Rochester has begun with one of the largest freshman classes in its history. When all have registered it will number about ninety, and of these more than half reside in Rochester. The new instructor in English, Roland F. Gray, who comes from the University of Nebraska, was present at the opening exercises in Anderson Hall Thursday morning.
The Woman's (Club of Watertown, Mass., extended to Miss Harriet Hosmer the hospitality of her native town at a reception held in the Unitarian Building recently.

The State offices to be filled at the November election have not often awakened the ambition of men of first-rate capacity. But they are really important and honorable. Those who hold them have a good deal of power and influence. They ought always to be held by men of ability and high character.

The Shakespeare Society of New-York held its first meeting yesterday, in the Poe Cottage, at Fordham. The principal feature of the occasion was an address by President Appleton Morgan. The particular object of his remarks was to get those individuals who wish to perpetuate the memories of Edgar Allan Poe sufficiently interested to contribute toward purchasing the Poe cottage.
PANAMA, via Galveston, Sept. 22. -- Recent advices from Bogota say that there will probably be more changes in the Ministry of the Republic of Colombia.

An arrest for violation of the excise law was made in Brooklyn yesterday. Carl Christensen, whose saloon is 319 Atlantic Avenue, was selected at 12:45 A.M. from more than a thousand who were equally as guilty as he.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Sept. 22. -- The supplementary Summer season that set in a few days ago has proved of great financial benefit to resort proprietors on Long Island. Many places that had prepared to close up found sufficient inducement to remain open.

Thomas A. Fulton, Secretary of the Excise Reform Association, of which Dorman B. Eaton is President, talked with a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday afternoon on excise matters and the opportunity of making a suitable record on that subject which has been thrown away by the Republican Party. Mr. Fulton said:

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- The cyclists of this city and suburban towns have engaged in the work of constructing a cinder path that is designed to be about twenty-five miles in length. To accomplish the object an organization has been formed, known as the Oneida County Wheelway League. It has for officers prominent business and professional men, and about $400 was subscribed for the work on the evening the league was formed.
ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 22. -- Gov. Atkinson gave a dinner to half a dozen Governors and twenty other guests at the Capital City Club last night. An unusual incident occurred during the dinner.

The Democrats at Syracuse must not rush at the excise-law issue like a bull at a gate. Their party will win, and on that issue, if they put it into their platform right. If they put it in wrong they will lose the State.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 22 -- Princeton University began its one hundred and forty-ninth year last Wednesday afternoon, with a slightly increased attendance over any former year of her history. During the long Summer vacation, beginning June 14 and ending Sept. 17, the campus gardeners have been busily engaged making alterations and improvements upon the college park.

The riders entered for the joint century run of the Gramercy and Metropolis Wheelmen gathered at the ferry at the foot of West Forty-second Street at 5 o'clock yesterday morning. Of the 350 entries received almost 300 crossed to Weehawken on the 5:30 o'clock boat, and a sufficient number appeared later, taking the next boat, to bring the total number of starters to exactly 326.

WASHINGTON CROSSING, N.J., Sept. 22. -- Antonio Frazey, an Italian laborer in the Rocktown quarries, while walking on Saurland Mountain yesterday morning had a painful adventure with a bull. The bull took him unawares, and tossed him several times. Finally the bull tossed the man upon a rock, and from the top of this he managed to grasp the lower branches of a tree, into which he climbed.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- The convention will be called to order by Charles De Freest, Secretary of the State Committee, at noon on Tuesday. He will announce that Perry Belmont is the choice of the State Committee for Temporary Chairman.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 22. -- James McCarthy of 251 Grove Street went to Union Hill to-day. On his return he boarded trolley car No. 8 of the North Hudson line. The car was crowded, and he stood on the platform.

BERLIN, Sept. 22. -- The next grand State function will be the unveiling of the monument to the memory of Emperor Frederick III. at Woerth. The programme of the ceremonies has been enlarged far beyond the original idea, the Kaiser seemingly being desirous of making the occasion almost as important as the Sedan Day fetes.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 22. -- The Republican Party has settled one trouble, as it has disposed of small and large booms, and has selected a candidate for Governor. The fight was intense, and has left its scars. Gen. Sewell wisely, as a matter of self-protection, let it be "any man's fight."

CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- The hottest September week which the people of Chicago have experienced in over twenty years was followed to-night by a sudden cold. The temperature all day was as high as on any day during the phenomenal hot spell, the thermometer at 3 P.M. registering at the United States Bureau 91.

Considerable prominence has been given to the sentimental side of the notable events which have occurred in the South during the last few days, but not too much. There can be no doubt that they have had a decided influence in developing and promoting good feeling between the North and the South.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 22. -- Judge Joan D. Teller of Auburn is in the field for the nomination to the vacant post on the Court of Appeals bench. Henry L. Storke, Postmaster at Auburn, who is in charge of his canvass, is here and will open headquarters to-morrow. James C. Stout, Agent and Warden of Auburn Prison, and other prominent Cayuga Democrats, will be here in the morning to held Mr. Storke.

GLASGOW, Sept. 14. -- The Defender-Valkyrie contest for the cup was regarded with a keener interest in Glasgow than anywhere else in this country, and its unexpected wind-up has created consequently the keenest vexation. At the same time Clyde yachtsmen do not attach blame to Lord Dunraven for what may seem the high-handed course he has taken.

The triennial report of the Pennsylvania Commissioners of Fisheries shows that during the last three years 282,878,771 fish were placed in the streams of this State, which number included 45,517,000 shad distributed by the United States Commission. The distribution of brook trout was 8,592,040; other trout and salmon, 3,430,400; white-fish, 59,800,000; pike perch, 161,450,000; lake herring, 4,040,000, and miscellaneous fish, 49,331.

BOSTON, Sept. 22. -A wrestling match between the Republican Party and the American Protective Association, with the Democrats and Prohibitionists as spectators, the former egging on the Republicans and the latter the other people. This is the spectacle presented to the observer of the political situation in Massachusetts to-day.

There is more than one regrettable aspect of the Democratic situation in Maryland, a situation that has been apparently developing the most extensive division of the Democratic Party in that State that has ever occurred, not excepting that of the campaign of 1894, resulting in the election by the Republicans of half the delegation to Congress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- At this writing the temperature at Chicago is 84 and the maximum temperature during the day was 90, and by the time readers have received their morning papers the much retarded and long wished-for cold wave will have extended over Illinois, causing a fall of from 30 to 40 in temperature.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 22. -- The Asbury Park Wheelmen are arranging for their semiannual century run to Trenton on Tuesday. Over 100 cyclers will participate, and the first half of the run will be completed on the track of the Inter-State Fair Grounds. The route will take in Eatontown. Freehold, Hightstown, Hamilton Square, and Trenton.
Two firemen of Hook and Ladder Company No. 11, Brooklyn, were seriously injured at a fire at 1,434 Broadway, Brooklyn, at 1:30 o'clock yesterday morning.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 22. -The two interesting points about the forthcoming convention are the contest for the New-York City seats and the adjusting of the excise questions.
Dr. Edward Worthington Burnette of 115 West Thirty-fourth Street died in Mrs. Kerr's boarding house, at 120 West Thirty-fourth Street, yesterday afternoon, of cancer of the face.

Mr. Dunn's cheerful prediction that yesterday would be cooler than its torrid predecessor was verified. It was cooler. An impartial and incorruptible thermometer shows that it was. The mercury in the official instrument found its way Saturday to the degree marked 97. Its vaulting ambition yesterday carried it no higher than 96.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- Democrats are coming this way in numbers that bid fair to swamp the town, with the convention still two days off. The hotel proprietors are at their wits' end in their efforts to take everybody in. Stacks of telegrams are piling up under the noses of the clerks, and as hotel walls are not made of india rubber, the requests for rooms remain unanswered.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 22. -- Mr. Laycock's steam yacht Valhalla arrived to-day. It is the largest yacht, save the Valiant, that has ever visited here. H. Maitland Kersey came up in her. Lord Dunraven and his two daughters went aboard this afternoon and remained aboard till nightfall. Dunraven will sail for home in the Valhalla on Wednesday direct from Newport.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- There are few politicians in town to-night. This is because all roads to Syracuse do not run through Albany, as is the case with Saratoga. When the convention was held at the spa last year hundreds of politicians of all degrees stopped over here, some of them for a day, and much of the work of the convention was planned before Saratoga was reached.

Lord Salisbury's assertion in his speech on the address, namely, that Turkey's independence "exists by reason of the agreement of other powers that they will not interfere with it, and that they will maintain it," may sound well to the ears of Turkey's detractors, but, if true, the same assertion may also be considered as applying with equal force to every power on earth.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 22. -- A swarm of perspiring politicians reached this city to-night on the trains from New-York and Buffalo, and relieved the monotony of one of the hottest days of the year. Although it lacked but two days of the State Convention, until this evening there was not a sign of the visiting crowd.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 22. -- "New-York may not want us to come down to tidewater with our unbroken cargoes of grain and merchandise, but New-York does not always know what is best for herself. We believe that what is good for the great West is good for New-York, and we propose to come."
LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Sept. 22. -- The trolley found another victim in this city this afternoon in the person of James Gorman, eighteen years old, of 333 East Thirty-first Street, New-York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Fort Mackinac, which, in accordance with a provision of the last Sundry Civil Appropriation bill, has been turned over to Gov. Rich of Michigan, was of great importance in the early days of the country.

As a reader of THE NEW YORK TIMES. I have been interested and somewhat amused at the discussion concerning the proper construction of the new Sunday excise law in New-York, owing to our having had a similar controversy in Pennsylvania, which has now been settled by our Supreme Court upon the same lines as your editorial in yesterday's issue.

Police Commissioner Andrew D. Parker spoke last evening on the excise law in the Trinity Methodist Church, 323 East One Hundred and Eighteenth Street. The church was crowded in spite of the intense heat.
The Torrey Botanical Club held its second Fall field meeting Saturday.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- The accident yesterday to the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott, pastor of Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, is not so serious as at first supposed. There is only a slight fracture of the left collarbone and an arm and leg somewhat bruised. There are no internal injuries.

LONDON. Sept. 22. -- The Graphic to-morrow will say that Sir George Newnes, formerly a member of Parliament, has expressed his intention to build a cutter to compete for the America's Cup, provided arrangement can be made to have the races sailed where interference by excursion steamers will be impossible. Sir George formerly represented the Newmarket Division of Cambridgeshire in Parliament.

A sermon that was printed yesterday from advance sheets has caused great annoyance to the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst and the Rev. Dr. J.A.B. Wilson, pastor of the Eighteenth Street Methodist Episcopal Church. The sermon was prepared by Dr. Wilson on the basis of a newspaper interview with Dr. Parkhurst on excise matters.

It is Very significant that so large a number of men active in the reform movement of last year have declared themselves strongly in favor of home rule for this city, as much in the regulation of the liquor traffic as in other matters. Such a course is unquestionably logical, but this particular matter is one as to which departure from logic is easy and natural.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 22. -- The complications in the Gubernatorial and Senatorial races in this State still remain tangled. P. Wat Hardin, since that famous Democratic conference in Louisville Aug. 30, has continued his free silver campaign in the rural districts, despite the kindly advice given in the address issued by the Campaign Committee to drop the financial question and confine discussion to the State issues that really exist between the two parties.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Sept. 22. -Jacob Parbell, formerly official dog catcher of this city, committed suicide to-day by shooting himself through the head. Parbell lived with his wife and five children, and his mother, at 1,184 Van Alst Avenue.

Satisfactory results were obtained again yesterday by the police in the enforcement of the excise law. The police, in fact, had a comparatively easy task, as the disposition shown recently on the part of saloon keepers to yield to the excise law was more marked, if possible, than ever before.

OXFORD, Penn., Sept. 22. -- John Lowry, one of the most eccentric characters of Pennsylvania, was buried from the residence of his sister in Oxford yesterday afternoon. He was eighty-one years old, and had never done a day's work in his life. When eleven years of age, he left his home in Oxford and disappeared through a cornfield surrounding the house.
" Will Charles A. Schieren be renominated by the Republicans of Brooklyn for Mayor?"

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 22. -- Under the impression that this was the one hundred and third anniversary of the birth of Joseph Field, the farmer who is known as "Uncle Josie" throughout Monmouth County, many of his friends called on him to-day. He appeared in excellent health, and welcomed those who called, but took great pains to correct the impression that this was his anniversary.

ONEONTA, Sept. 22. -- The delegates to the Republican Convention of the Sixth Judicial District will assemble next Tuesday in Binghamton to nominate a candidate for Supreme Court Justice to fill the position of the additional Justice created by the Constitution. There are eleven delegates to the convention, and these, it is thought, will be six and five on the final ballot.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- Senator Hill, John Boyd Thacher, Charles R. De Freest, John Bowe, and Norton Chase of Albany, and Judge W.C. Lamont and County Treasurer De Witt C. Dow of Scnoharie left on an early train for Syracuse.

Muskmelons have played a part in history. They caused the fall of Arques and led Mack to the capitulation of Ulm. One day the Abbe Bernis came to dine with the Marquise de Pompadour, who was furious because the maitre d'hotel had forgotten to serve melon. "Shall I get two muskmelons for you, Madame?"

SYRACUSE, Sept. 23. -- There are many candidates for places on the Democratic State ticket, and to-day, with the crystallizing process not yet begun, the friends of the different aspirants have been making more or less vigorous efforts to manufacture sentiment in their favor. This is the list of candidates as it stood this afternoon prior to the meeting of the State Committee:

SYRACUSE, Sept. 23. -- A canvass of the delegates to the convention who have arrived here shows that the opinion is almost unanimous that the platform should be moderate, reasonable, straightforward, and simple in dealing with the excise problem. E. Prentiss Bailey of Utica expresses the opinion of many Democrats in declaring that the editorial in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of to-day very accurately and admirably set forth what the platform should repeat.

Sir: The word "absent-mindedness" is used by some of your correspondents as equivalent to "heedlessness." Adopting this wide construction of the term, I hope I may trespass on your space once more by repeating two "bulls" mentioned by the late Prof. Hodson in his "Errors in the Use of English."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23. -- Dr. Jose Congosto, Spanish Consul at this port, to-day denied the report that the Spanish cruiser Barcaistegui, which was sunk with a loss of forty-six lives, last Wednesday, in the harbor of Havana, was destroyed by a torpedo launched against her by venturesome insurgents.

The first sensational development in the investigation proceedings of the old Dock Department, which has been in progress for the last three months, under the direction of the Commissioners of Accounts, came out yesterday in open session in Room 123 Stewart Building.

HAVANA, Sept. 23. -- The Spanish Government has arranged for all the money necessary to carry on a very aggressive policy in Cuba, looking to the prompt ending of the rebellion. Cable advices of Sept. 14 from Madrid say that final measures have not been devised by the Government; that is, measures that will be put in force when the rebellion has ended.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 23. -- "I object! I object!" said Col. Fellows, hurrying up to ex-Mayor Gilroy, in front of the Yates House this morning, with as much excitement as a yachtsman would show when running up his protest flag.

The Assembly Cities Committee resumed its investigation into the affairs of the Kings County Charities Department yesterday. They met in the Supreme Court room. It was the first session held in five weeks.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23. -- The Board of Trade won its big fight against the elevator men to-day.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 23. -- The Executive Board appointed at the silver conference in Washington met in this city to-day for the purpose of naming Chairmen for the several States, whose duty it shall be to superintend the organization of the silver forces, with a view to securing control of Democratic County, State, and National Conventions next year.

The Knollwood Country Club at Elmsford, Westchester County, is going to be kept unusually lively during the coming few weeks with golf matches and other social amusements. The ladies' teas, which have been given fortnightly during the Summer, have proved very successful, having been attended by most of the Westchester County residents in the immediate vicinity.
The order issued by the President yesterday regarding future appointments of Consular officers whose compensation is not more than $2,500 or less than $1,000 is a step in the right direction.

BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- The arrest at Cologne last week of a Frenchman and his female companion on suspicion that they were spies has developed into a matter of much importance, and numerous similar arrests are impending in Cologne, Magdeburg, Brunswick, and Essen.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Sept. 23. -- From even a cursory view there is no reason to doubt that the present campaign in Utah is destined to become intense in the extreme. The Republicans formally inaugurated their campaign last Monday, with Heber M. Wells as candidate for Governor, Clarence E. Alien nominee for Congress, and Frank J. Cannon orator.

SAN JOSE, Cal., Sept. 23. -- Hip Sing Lee, a wealthy Chinese merchant of this city, offers a half interest in his business and $5,000 in cash to any reputable young American who will marry his daughter, Moi Lee.

The only honest thing about the Republican platform resolution concerning the Sunday laws is its authorship, and its author was deluded if he honestly believes that his party can maintain the present Sunday laws. The Republican declaration in favor of the maintenance of these laws is, in the bright light of experience, a declaration for an immoral policy and one contrary to the public welfare.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- The President has issued an order under date of Sept. 20 placing all grades of the Consular Service with compensation between $1,000 and $2,500 under a modified civil service, which provides for class, but not competitive, examinations. This order will affect a little more than one-half of all those engaged in the Consular Service of the United States.

" It is the most magnificent proposition that has ever been made in the United States," remarked Edward P. North yesterday to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES, as he discussed the suggestion recently made by THE TIMES for the construction of a ship canal connecting Lake Erie with the Hudson of dimensions sufficiently large to permit of steamships passing without interruption from the lake ports to Europe.
The most important subject discussed last week at the meeting of the Association of Official Agricultural Chemists in this city was a new discovery which may fairly be termed sensational.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 23. -- The Democratic State Committee to-night, after an hour's discussion, decided to admit the members from the two delegations in Kings County, in accordance with the harmony agreement entered into in that county. There was some opposition to this proposition at the beginning by Tammany.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 23. -- John Flannagan, member of the Democratic State Committee, is here, with County Judge J.H. Metcalfe, who will be nominated for the Senate in the Ontario-Wayne District, to make the fight against John Raines.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 23. -- James Garlo, a young Italian barber of 21 Crane Street, was locked up this morning on the charge of throwing a bomb last night in the yard of Justice of the Peace Bucacanco, at 16 Factory Street. The bomb exploded and blew out all the windows in the house of the Justice.

A lady reader appeals to me to notice a letter in the journal of the Humanitarian League respecting the atrocious cruelty which is practiced on animals in the Island of Teneriffe. The writer affirms that the cruelty there surpasses anything he has ever seen even in other Spanish colonies, and he gives some sickening details of the torturing of dumb creatures in everyday work, and at bull fights, and other spectacles.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 23. -- There are contesting delegations from Oswego. The factions headed by William A. Poucher, representing the old Cleveland element, and Charles N. Bulger, representing the old Hill element, after harmony by contract for a year, could not agree this year, and the result of bitter wrangling is two delegations.

Considering that it was an off day at Gravesend yesterday, there being no stake feature on for decision, and the card being made up of "overnight" events, the attendance was quite large. The original programme promised an interesting afternoon's sport, but the many withdrawals resulted in a tame day's racing, the only contests that furnished anything like a horse race being the second and fourth events.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 23. -- The New-York City delegates, friends and sympathizers of Tammany, and the State Democracy arrived in town early this evening, without any special demonstration and without brass bands. Tammany came on two special trains, and the State Democracy on one.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 23. -- Judge Hudspeth this morning called the attention of Sheriff Toffey and Prosecutor Winfield to the fact that a poolroom is being conducted openly at Weehawken, notwithstanding repeated efforts have been made to close it. It was a remarkable fact, he said, that although the Sheriff and Prosecutor had several times sent officers to close the place, they had discovered nothing.

Among the Republican politicians at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last evening was one from Albany. He is of the Platt stripe, still he does not agree with everything that Mr. Platt advances. As a matter of fact, he was more than put out with orders which went to Albany last week.
Predictions come, but hot waves linger. That languid visitant from the West which came idling toward the Atlantic seaboard Friday to stay for a day or two, it was said, was still here yesterday.

Justice Jerome, in Special Sessions, yesterday reopened the discussion of the removal of excise cases from his court to General Sessions which he began a week ago by asking Assistant District Attorney Berlinger to find out what disposition had been made of the cases.

Mayor Schieren returned to Brooklyn yesterday, after a month's vacation. As soon as he visited the Mayor's office he was asked whether he will be a candidate for renomination. He declined to answer the question, and said he did not care to discuss that matter at the present time.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23. -- A large crowd was present at the Germantown Cricket Club grounds, at Manheim, to-day, to witness the conclusion of the international cricket match between the Oxford and Cambridge teams and the gentlemen of Philadelphia. A close and exciting finish was expected, and it was brought off.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 23. -- Senator Hill came to Syracuse this afternoon confident that the Democratic State Convention will do its work so well that it cannot fail to command the approval, in November, of a large majority of the people of this State.

The Massachusetts Association Opposed to the Extension of Suffrage to Women has sent out the following manifesto relating to the vote which is to be taken in November upon the question of granting municipal suffrage to women:

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 23. -- The trials of the printers indicted for conspiracy to defraud the State in the matter of printing contracts, evidence concerning which was first made public during the sitting of the Senate Investigating Committee, opened in the Mercer County Court this forenoon. John L. Kuser, the Principal defendant, was represented by James Buchanan, Samuel Kalisch, and Judge Chauncey Beasley.

Gen. Fullerton has one child, a most interesting little daughter. Mary, who affords no end of amusement to her father's friends by reason of her quaint sayings and bright ways generally. This little daughter is at present about six or seven years of age, but has already discarded the term nurse from her vocabulary, and dubbed as her maid the attendant who has piloted her through the nursery days.

Mr. A.W. ABBOTT, Secretary of the City Vigilance League, has taken the trouble to send us a somewhat impassioned letter, denying that the man who on Friday caused the arrest of a messenger boy for throwing a banana peel on the sidewalk is a member of that worthy organization, or is in any way known to its officials.
A number of society women of Harlem have organized a literary, social, and educational club, to be known as the Women's Wednesday Club.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23. -- The portion of the address of Mowbray, the English Anarchist, which caused Inspector Schaack to call a halt yesterday was as follows:

The family of the Secretary of War is still enjoying the cool, bracing air of Sorrento and seems in no hurry to break up the pleasant associations of the Summer by packing up for removal either to Washington or elsewhere.

In communities where the sweeping Warner Miller Sunday law declaration is not palatable to Republicans there are symptoms of a concerted effort to convince voters that it will not stand in the way of local option as a means of disposing of the Sunday selling question. These appear especially in this city, Brooklyn, and Buffalo.

Long ago Gen. E. BURD GRUBB, in a speech at Asbury Park, announced that Spain would pay an indemnity for the Ponape outrages and would agree to let the missionaries go back there. As Gen. BURD GRUBB had been our Minister to Spain, this assurance was received as next to official.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23. -- New theories have developed in the Durrant case concerning the probable line of defense the attorneys will seek to establish.

It is doubtful if any one is better known at race meetings in Kansas, Missouri, and Iowa than Miss Mina Ann Wilson, who was born fifteen miles west of Topeka, and has always had her home in the Sunflower State. In years gone by her father, Andy Wilson, was one of the prosperous stockmen in Kansas, his estate at one time being valued at $250,000.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 23. -- Members of Yale University to-day returned for the annual school year, which begins Thursday in all the departments but the Medical School. Entrance examinations for the freshmen classes of the academic and scientific departments began this afternoon and will continue two days. The Law School examinations will begin Wednesday and last one day.

If the waters of the Passaic River were as clean and pure from Paterson to Newark Bay as they are from the river's source, in Morris County, N.J., to Paterson, there would not be the grumbling and dissatisfaction there now is all along its winding course.

The intense heat of yesterday did not prevent many persons from enjoying the beautiful display of Autumn millinery, capes, and dress goods at the store of H. Batterman, Broadway, Graham and Flushing Avenues, Brooklyn. The millinery department presents a wonderfully pretty scene, being hung with green vines and flowers.

Mr. Drew, accompanied by Miss Adams, Mr. Harwood, Mr. Byron, and the other members of his company, began an engagement at the Empire Theatre last night which is to last well into the Autumn. He was welcomed cordially by a large audience. Perhaps these are trite sentences with which to begin an account of an event so auspicious, but they must serve. The night was hot.

The sale of the 176 lots belonging to the Bathgate estate, announced for Thursday, by Peter F. Meyer Co., has been adjourned temporarily. Notice will be given of the time to which the sale has been postponed.

The canalboat men, as represented by their lively and interesting organ, The Canal Defender, are opposed to the construction of a ship canal from Lake Erie to the Hudson. This is perfectly natural. Half a century ago the reapers in Ohio went about smashing the grain-reaping machines.

Mayor Strong said yesterday to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES that nothing would be definitely settled in regard to the resignation of the four Commissioners of Public Parks until after he had had a conference with them.

BUENOS AYRES, Aug. 22. -- The exportation of live cattle is assuming greater importance. The industry is in the experimental stage, but no doubt is entertained that its future will be brilliant. This must be the outcome of the patient efforts made by the majority of the breeders.

RICHMOND, S.I., Sept. 23. -- The Richmond County Circuit Court opened at this place to-day with Justice Edgar M. Cullen presiding. After the Grand Jury had been sworn in, Justice Cullen called its attention to the case of ex-Assemblyman Michael McGuire, who is alleged to be several thousand dollars short in his accounts as Town Collector of Taxes, which office he held in Middletown in 1892.
The Rev. Dr. B.B. Tyler read a paper yesterday at the regular weekly meeting of the Baptist ministers, at 149 Fifth Avenue, on "The State of the Righteous Dead."

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 23. -- The fifty-fourth exhibition of the Queens County Agricultural Society will be held on the fair grounds here to-morrow, and continue for the remainder of the week. The exhibition will include trotting races each day on the society's half-mile track, fine exhibits of horses, cattle, swine, sheep, poultry, and pigeons, besides displays of flowers, farm machinery, carriages, and the handiwork of Long Island women.

It is safe to say that city voters are favorable to the policy of local home rule. Whatever their party preferences, they believe in municipal self-government as well as rural self-government, and whatever their opinions about liquor selling on Sunday, they are in favor of allowing the people of the cities to determine the question for themselves.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 23. -- The first line-up of the season of the Yale 'Varsity football team took place this afternoon on the Yale Field, and was witnessed by several hundred people. A good many of the students who are already in town for the opening of Yale University on Thursday were present and had an opportunity of sizing up the material from which the 'Varsity team for 1895-6 will be selected.

The Medical Society of the County of New-York was thrown into temporary excitement last evening by the revival of the question as to whether the society should hold itself responsible for the remarks of individual members made at its meetings.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company is in a quandary as to the disposal of $2,000 which is due on a policy issued on the life of William Harding, who died several months ago. The widow and Margaret Atcheson are fighting over the money, and the company is the defendant in an action brought by the latter.
New-York's new Manual Training High School was opened for its first term yesterday in the beautiful new Macy Manual Arts Building of Teachers College with the other divisions of the institution.
The biggest confidence game ever seen in the politics of New-York State has been begun by the Republicans.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Late advices from Central America indicate a growing sentiment in that country favorable to a federal union of the five republics. The agreement reported at Amapala last Spring between the Presidents of Nicaragua, Honduras, and Salvador, to form an offensive and defensive alliance in all matters concerning the outside world will be referred to the Congresses of these republics when their respective sessions begin next Winter.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- At a meeting of the congregation of the First Presbyterian Church (known as the President's church) the following was sent to the Rev. T. De Witt Talmage of Brooklyn, calling him to the associate pastorship with the Rev. Dr. Byron Sunderland:

SYRACUSE, Sept. 23. -- At the Tammany headquarters, in the Yates House, to-night there is great indignation among the braves over the proposition to allow the State Democracy a share of the seats in the convention. It is noticeable that all of the Croker men among the district leaders are the most bitter in their condemnation of the proposition, and it is evident that they are following his suggestions in the matter.

Noonday prayer meetings have been held at 113 Fulton Street and in the old North Dutch Church, that formerly stood at the same place, for thirty-eight years. The meeting yesterday rounded out that period, and was made more or less of celebration of the event. It was presided over by Charles M. Earle and was unusually well attended.

The Ethelwynn, the champion of the American fifteen-footers, beat the Spruce IV., the English visitor, by 7 minutes 41 seconds in a twelve-mile race on the Sound yesterday. The race was the first of a series for the Seawanhaka-Corinthian International Challenge Cup for small boats, and, judging by the way the two yachts sailed yesterday, the Seawanhaka trophy will keep the America's Cup company in this country, at least until another challenger arrives.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 24. - The ocean tug James Woodal proposes to leave here to-morrow, and the sensational feature of her departure is the open announcement that her mission is to take a large consignment of arms to the Cuban insurgents. The arms are said to be waiting near the mouth of the river.

Patrick McCanna, Chief Engineer of the county buildings at Flatbush, was the chief witness yesterday before the Assembly committee which is investigating the administration of the Brooklyn Department of Charities and Corrections.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 24. -- The band in Alhambra Hall struck up "Praise God, from Whom all Blessings Flow" at 12:25 o'clock, and as soon as it was over Chairman Hinkley rapped on the table and announced that prayer would be offered by the Rev. Mr. Fahnestock of this city.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 24. -- Many of the Senatorial districts got together as delegations after the session of the convention to-day, and selected their members of the new State Committee.

Bristow, Opdyke Willcox, counsel for Howard S. Jaffray, Augustus D. Juilliard, and James G. Cannon, receivers for E.S. Jaffray Co., filed in the County Clerk's office yesterday the report of William W. Ladd, referee, upon the accounts of the receivers.

The details of the parade of the United Societies for Liberal Sunday Laws, this afternoon, were completed yesterday. If the weather is favorable, the indications are that all the expectations of the promoters of the parade will be more than realized, as many societies have been added within the last two days to the list published in THE NEW-YORK TIMES on Sunday.

HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- The spectacle of a man wrapped in a snow-white sheet and without any other garment whatever was what startled the guests in Cranston's Hotel about 8 o'clock this morning. Several ladies rushed pellmell down to the office, their faces blanched with terror, and begged Clerk Harry Scott to have the fellow arrested and taken away.
GLEN EYRE, Penn., Sept. 24. -- There were two fires on the grounds of the Blooming Grove Park Association early this week, and by one the clubhouse and other buildings were in peril.

J. Arthur Brand and Spruce IV. were in hard luck yesterday. The Spruce raced against the Ethelwynn in the second contest for the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club International Trophy. The race was sailed over a triangular course.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 24. -- The fight between Tammany and the State Democracy is on hot and heavy. The principal Tammany leaders here have been working among the country delegates to capture votes to enable them to retain all the New-York County seats. Deals with delegations having candidates for places on the State ticket are being projected.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Sept. 24. -- Prof. Salisbury of the University of Chicago, second in command of the Peary relief expedition, left here yesterday, passage bring offered to him on the cable steamer Mina, bound for Sydney as it is imperative that he reach Chicago by Tuesday next.

" A Democratic State Convention may, nevertheless, look outside the limits of its own State,' said Mr. PERRY BELMONT in his speech as temporary Chairman of the Syracuse Convention yesterday. "The relations of the Democratic Party to its associates in other States, to the National issues and Federal legislation ought not to be neglected."

SYRACUSE, Sept. 24. -- The Syracuse Journal this evening gives THE NEW-YORK TIMES full credit, not for its early arrival in Syracuse, something which it characterizes as unprecedented in the history of the so-called enterprises of New-York journalism, but also for having won the prize as a record-breaker in railroad traveling. It says:

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 24. -- The address at the annual reunion of the Twenty-second Connecticut Regiment, which was held at Grand Army Hall in this city this afternoon, was delivered by Lieut. Eli P. Ellsworth of Brooklyn, N.Y. An interesting comparison was drawn between Jefferson Davis and Abraham Lincoln, as representatives of the "irrepressible conflict."

Fire destroyed the big six-story brick building at 305 and 307 East Sixty-first Street, known as the Globe Storage Warehouse, yesterday afternoon. The loss to A.B. Yetter, the occupant of the building, was $100,000, $50,000 on the building and a similar amount on the contents. The insurance was small.
When Mr Simpkins's three tons of stove coal were delivered, the driver of the cart dumped the whole upon the sidewalk.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 24. -- The Fall exhibition of the Queens County Agricultural Society would not be complete without the presence of Bloodgood H. Cutter, the Long Island farmer-poet, and fortunately for the success of the fifty-fourth annual exhibition of the society that opened to-day on the Fair Grounds here Mr. Cutter arrived this morning from Europe, and reached the fair shortly after the opening.

Opposition to the renomination of Mayor Schieren has sprung up in an unexpected political quarter in Brooklyn. Not only are the Worth forces in the organization openly against him, but now it appears that the so-called Willis, or anti-Worth, element in the organization is equally opposed to him.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 24. -- The Committee on Credentials to-night, after a protracted discussion, decided to admit one-fifth of the State Democracy's contesting delegation. On the proposition to admit one-third, the vote was 33 to 13 against allowing one-third.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 24.--The Committee on Platform of the Democratic Convention will offer a platform that will denounce the violation of laws in Republican localities that are strictly enforced in Democratic localities.

BATH, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- The Republican Senatorial Convention for the new Forty-first District, comprising the Counties of Steuben and Yates, met at Bath to-day. There are three candidates for nomination -- William H. Nichols of Bath, Franklin D. Sherwood of Hornellsville, and John S. Sheppard of Penn Yan.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 24. -- The first line-up of the Varsity football against the scrub for the season took place at the university field to-day. A two hours' preliminary light practice was given all the candidates before the line-up, then a sharp series of scrimmaging followed, during which good gains were made by Ayres, '99, and Rosengarten, '97, and a pretty goal was kicked from the twenty-yard line by the promising freshman, Full-back Baird.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 24. -- The trial of John L. Kuser, Charles S. Robinson, Otto Heintz, and Emil Krauettler, the printers indicted for conspiring to defraud the State in the matter of German printing contracts, was before Judge Conover, in the Mercer County Circuit Court, to-day.

Thomas E. Wright, sixty years old, of 70 West Eleventh Street, a wholesale milk dealer, pleaded guilty in Special Sessions yesterday to selling adulterated milk, and was sentenced to pay $200 and to serve thirty days in prison.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 24. -- Temporary Chairman Perry Belmont occupied about forty minutes in making his speech. It was as follows:

When, at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, the Board of Aldermen's weekly meeting was called in Room 16, City Hall, there were just ten members present, and they were all seated on the Republican side of the house.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept.21. -- The baseball game this afternoon between the Summer residents and the permanent residents proved to be a big society affair, and a victory for the cottagers, led on by Dick Peters.

A novel play, written by Miss Marie T. Stone, who found all of her plot and much of her dialogue in a story by Miss Elizabeth Phipps Train, published in Lippincott's Magazine, was remarkably well-staged, and acted with sympathy and skill by the Holland brothers, Edmund M. and Joseph, and members of Mr. Mansfield's company, at the Garrick Theatre last night.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 24. -- The State Committee took a step this morning which has long been in contemplation. It decided to adopt the Senatorial district as the basis of representation for members of the State Committee. This means that the membership of the State Committee will be increased from thirty-four to fifty.

It is very discouraging news in its kind that the new challenger for the America's Cup has repeated the absurdity of challenging with a cutter-rigged boat of eighty-nine feet on the water line. As we have frequently had occasion to say, such a boat is a monstrosity. She is a racing machine pure and simple.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- A decision just handed down by Secretary of the Interior Hoke Smith gives the State of Illinois more than 20,000 acres in Lake County. The value of this land, at a moderate estimate, is between $3,000,000 and $4,000,000. Should the courts uphold the claims of the State, in accordance with the views of Secretary Smith, hundreds of prosperous farmers in Lake County will be ruined.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 24. -- Chairman Belmont, when he had concluded his speech, turned to Secretary De Freest, who began the call of the roll of delegates. There are 450 all told, not including the double delegation, of 63 from Kings County, and 105 from New-York County, and other contestants. There were some changes in the roll.
President Roosevelt of the Police. Board gave a characteristic talk last night in the rooms of the Lenox Republican Club, at 122 West One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street.

The world's record for railroad speed was again broken on the New-York Central Road yesterday. In sending THE NEW-YORK TIMES special newspaper train from Albany to Syracuse -- a distance of 148 miles -- in 134 1/2 minutes the operating officers of the Central eclipsed all previous efforts at speed making on a railroad in this or any other country.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Stafford saved the game for New-York to-day by making a great catch of Demont's hard liner in the eighth inning after 2 runs had been scored. James James, a new player from the Virginia League, pitched for Washington to-day, and while extremely wild was hit safely only five times.
The Rev. Dr. T. De Witt Talmage yesterday received a formal call to the co-pastorate of the First Presbyterian Church of Washington, D.C. It reads as follows:

The decision of Judge BEEKMAN requiring the Board of Aldermen to correct the division of the Thirteenth Senate District of this city into three Assembly districts is valuable as a precedent to impress the public mind and the authorities concerned with the idea that the Constitutional restriction upon local apportionment must be closely complied with in all cases.

BOSTON, Sept. 24. -- Miss Annie Londonderry arrived in this city this morning, after a trip around the world on a bicycle. Miss Londonderry is nursing a broken arm, the result of a bad fall sustained in one of the Western towns. On June 20, 1894, she started on her trip around the world. She was given a good send-off by several hundred friends, who were at the State House, where the start was made.

TOKIO, Sept. 13. -- Two Japanese cruisers, the Yoshino Kan and the Naniwa Kan, noteworthy for their achievements during the war between Japan and China, have recently added to their record some valuable services in the Formosan campaign. Steaming along the west coast of the Island of Formosa they have bombarded barracks, shelled strong positions, and landed parties of marines to capture villages held by the insurgents, thus materially facilitating the operations of the troops.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 24. -- At the close of the first day of the Democratic State Convention the work for which it assembled is advancing satisfactorily, not without some friction, but in a spirit that augurs well.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- THE NEW-YORK TIMES determined to give the delegates and the host of other Democrats here a surprise this morning.

PANAMA, via Galveston, Sept. 24. -- Panama has had an intensely alarming hour to-day, through the insubordination of troops of Cauca, which have been incorporated in the regular line regiment of Colombia.

FORT WAYNE, Ind. Sept. 24 -- The annual meeting of the Fort Wayne Driving Club was begun yesterday. The weather was fair, but chilling, and the attendance was light. Dollikens was a favorite in the 2:23 trot, but made no showing for three heats, and in the fourth Sweringen was taken from the sulky and McDowell was put up.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 24. -- A star, the plain, strong, inspiring emblem recommended to the Democracy of the State of New-York for its ballot emblem, was the most conspicuous and striking feature of the decorations of the Alhambra, in which the State Convention this morning held its first session.

L. Vogel, Secretary of the Swiss Legation at Washington, who is at the Holland House in this city, spoke to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday about the excise question and the regulation of saloons, as considered by the people of his native country.

Not many weeks ago Mayor SCHIEREN of Brooklyn was declaring that there would be no prospect of his renomination if he wished it, and that he did not wish it. Perhaps the latter part of the statement was a consequence of the belief implied in the former part, but recently his renomination has become a subject of serious consideration, and he has ceased to make statements about its possibility.
An important decision, involving the liability of the Sheriff in taking bail which subsequently proves to be worthless, was rendered by Justice Giegerich, in the Court of Common Pleas, yesterday.

Thomas F. Oakes, Henry C. Payne, and Henry C. Rouse have resigned as receivers of the Northern Pacific Railroad. Their joint resignation was presented to Judge Jenkins of the United States Circuit Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin, and an order was issued by that Court directing all persons interested to appear before him next Friday morning at 10 o'clock to submit suggestions respecting the appointment of receivers.

Much regret was expressed yesterday at the postponement of the sale of the lots belonging to the Bathgate estate, which was to have been held by Messrs. Peter F. Meyer Co. to-morrow. Mr. Meyer, besides advertising the fact of the postponement, has sent postal cards to the same purport to all who have sent for circulars of the sale.

The body of Hugh N. Camp, who died suddenly of heart failure Saturday morning, was taken from his home, Fairlawn, on Morris Heights, yesterday morning, after an impressive ceremony, and buried in the family plot in Woodlawn Cemetery.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 24. -- Arguments were made in the Yale-Storrs controversy before the Board of Arbitration in the Supreme Court room to-day. The board consists of ex-Judge Dwight Loom's of the Supreme Court, and the Hon. Henry C. Robinson of this city, and ex-Chief Justice John D. Park of Norwich.

When Mayor STRONG last February appointed three Park Commissioners, with power to name a fourth who should be permanent President of the board, and its only paid member, we pointed out to him that he was violating the spirit if not the letter of the law. This rash and unconsidered action has borne its proper fruit.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 24. -- The condition of Mr. Harry Wright, the veteran baseball manager, is not improved to-day. Prof. William Pepper of Philadelphia arrived here this morning, in response to a telegram, and held a consultation with the several other physicians who are in attendance upon Mr. Wright. The patient is in an exhausted condition, and even his relatives are denied admission to his room at the Sanitarium.

Two very sensible expressions on the excise question are reported from Syracuse. One is Mr. THOMAS G. SHEARMAN'S, who, in behalf of the delegates of the Shepard Democracy of Brooklyn, drafted a resolution addressed to the Committee on Resolutions urging "that no attempt shall be made to define in the platform, applying to the whole State, the policy to be adopted in matters thus referred to the decision of the local authorities."

It has been made very clear by the opinions of the most distinguished American jurists, as well as the decisions of the Federal courts, that citizens of the United States have the unquestionable right to freely manufacture, vend, and export arms and munitions of war, even if well knowing and intending that the same are to be used by insurgents in other countries, provided that they are not engaged in hostilities against their own country.
The effect of the intensity of the heat of the last four or five days has been exhibited in some of the orchards on Long Island, where the fruit has been actually baked upon the trees.

For the first time in several years Presiding Judge Col. W.L. Simmons was missing from the judges' stand at a race-track near New-York. The genial and gallant Colonel who has placed so many running horses was sick abed at the Hoffman House, suffering from an attack of gastritis. Mr. McDowell acted in his place.

The Rapid Transit Commissioners met yesterday at their offices, 256 Broadway, for the first time since June 18. Commissioners Alexander E. Orr. President; William Steinway, Seth Low, John Claflin, and John H. Starin were present.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- The twenty-second annual convention of the Women's Christian Temperance Union of the State of New-York began this morning. There were over 500 delegates present, representing the different counties of the State.

The Juvenile Asylum, One Hundred and Ninety-sixth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, has been under quarantine nearly two months for an epidemic of diphtheria, but on the authority of Dr. Charles S. Benedict, Chief Inspector of Contagious Diseases, it is probable that the quarantine will soon be removed. Dr. Benedict said yesterday:

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 24. -- The first annual convention of the International Deep Waterways Association was opened this afternoon. Gen. Edward C. O'Brien of New-York, President of the New-York Dock Commission and ex-Commissioner of Navigation of the United States, was selected temporary Chairman. He said:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- A report has been received at the Department of State from Minister Clifton R. Breckinridge giving a copy of the laws and regulations bearing upon the admission of foreign Jews into Russia.

ESCANABA, Mich., Sept. 24. -- During the prevalence of Sunday night's gale the schooner Charles R. Williams sank, and all on board are reported to have been lost. The crew consisted of Capt. Hunton, Maggie Bennett, stewardess; the mate, and four sailors.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 24. -- Ex-Deputy Controlled Calvin J. Huson of Yates County said, in speaking of the general political situation in Yates County: "Yates is a Republican County by a majority of about 1,300, but we are firmly of the opinion that this majority will be materially reduced this year. There are no contests among the Democrats, which is unusual.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 24. -- The Shepard Democracy met this afternoon to consider various matters in connection with the convention. Under the arrangement with the Bell Democracy, the Shepard Democracy will have two members of the State Committee, and this afternoon's meeting unanimously decided to name as their State Committeemen A. Augustus Healy and S. Perry Sturges.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 24. -- Attorney Henry Stoddard, representing Horace Chittenden of New-York, assignee for the benefit of the creditors of the estate of A.S. Hatch and F.H. Hatch, which did business under the firm name of A.S. Hatch Co., today filed an application in the Superior Court to intervene in the suit of Collis P. Huntington against the Newport News and Mississippi Valley Railroad.
ALBANY, Sept. 24. -- The special train bearing Gov. Morton's party and the legislative delegation returned from Atlanta at an early hour this morning.
The Fall term of the University of the City of New-York was opened at the institution's new grounds, on University Heights, yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- Following is the full text of the order of Secretary Olney constituting the board for the examination of candidates for Consular positions:

The annual convention of the Episcopal Church in this diocese began at the Church of the Holy Trinity, Madison Avenue and Forty-second Street, yesterday morning, with the celebration of the holy communion and the address of the Bishop. In his address, Bishop Potter said:
Mr. George R. Read has sold, in conjunction with Messrs. De Blois Eldridge, the four-story brick dwelling 44 Fifth Avenue, 25 by 65 by 100, at $72,000, for William B. Dana, to Capt. Charles F. Roe.

At the annual meeting of the shareholders of the New-York, Ontario and Western Railway, held in this city yesterday, nearly 400,000 shares of common stock, out of a total of 581,000 shares, were represented. William B. Carter of Philadelphia presided.

It does not clearly appear why yesterday should have been selected for the procession of societies, mostly composed of citizens of German nativity or descent, to signalize their demand for a more liberal excise law. The date was too late to enable the demonstration to have any effect upon the Democratic State Convention, which had already passed upon the question involved before it could have had any tidings of the extent of the demonstration.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 25. -- The State Democracy delegates went directly to their headquarters at the Vanderbilt House after their withdrawal from the convention. On their way out of the hall they were chaffed by the Tammany men.

John B. Manning was expelled from the Stock Exchange yesterday by the Governing Committee of that body. The charge against him was related in detail in THE NEW-YORK TIMES when it was brought -- about a fortnight ago. Five Union Pacific first mortgage bonds of $1,000 each, payable to bearer, were said to have been sold by him as clean or fresh bonds, when, in fact, they had passed through various hands.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 25.--There is an unusually large gathering of Democratic statesmen here to-night, preparing for the State Convention to-morrow. There are more on hand than were really expected, and considerable enthusiasm prevails. United States Senator Smith is the centre of attraction.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 25. -- The permanent residents, beaten Tuesday at baseball by the cottagers, have challenged for-another game, and it will be played next Tuesday. The proceeds, by mutual consent, are to be devoted to the fund for an old ladies' home.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 25. -- The fight over the New-York City seats was not over in the Stale Convention until 1:30 o'clock and the report of the Committee on Permanent Organization was read, while the confusion attending the departure of the State Democracy delegates prevented anything like order.
Mayor Schieren publicly declared yesterday that he is not a candidate for the Republican nomination for Mayor of Brooklyn and that under no circumstances would he accept a renomination.

LIVINGSTON, S.I., Sept. 25. -- Staten Island society, reinforced by a hundred or so visiting tennis enthusiasts, made a brilliant showing on the courts of the Staten Island Ladies' Club yesterday afternoon. The annual open tennis tournament of the club was the attraction, and nearly all the star lady tennis players of the country gathered to battle for the handsome prizes offered by the club.

MONTREAL, Sept. 25. -- The statement of Dominion exports and imports for August shows that the total exports for the month were $12,448,823, an increase of $1,340,931 over August last year. The imports for the month were $11,028,665, a decrease of $494,067 from last August.

BOSTON, Sept. 25. -- The Republican primaries held throughout the State last night and to-night disclose a remarkable rallying about Gov. Greenhalge for renomination. The convention will be overwhelmingly in his favor, despite the secret but systematic endeavors of the A.P.A. to compass his defeat.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 25. -- The Constitutional Convention spent the day discussing the proposed sections on the executive department and municipal corporations and police regulations. The section on the executive department was agreed upon, and ordered to a third reading.

Funeral services over the body of John D. Jones, late President of the Atlantic Marine Insurance Company, were held yesterday in Trinity Church, the Very Rev. Bishop Littlejohn, the Rev. Dr. Seabury of the Church of the Annunciation, New-York; Dr. C.G. Wiley of the Episcopal Church, Massapaqua, L.I., and the Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix of Trinity officiating.

Gen. Horatio C. King, candidate for Secretary of State, was born in Portland, Me., Dec. 22, 1837. His father was Horatio King, postmaster General under President Buchanan. Gen. King received his earliest education in Washington. He was graduated from Dickinson College, Carlisle, Penn., in 1858.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 25. -- The developments today are directly in line with the statement made in these dispatches last night, that the many candidates for the few nominations were in a state of worriment.

The proceedings in the investigation of the old Dock Department, resumed yesterday by Commissioners of Accounts Seth Sprague Terry and Rodney S. Dennis in Room 123 of the Stewart Building, brought out sworn testimony to the effect that the old Dock Commission had awarded a contract for the placing of spiles in the East River to one bidder, and then revoked the contract, offering it to another bidder without any apparent good reason.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

What has come to be looked upon by the admirers of cycle road races as the crowning event of the Fall will be decided on the Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn this forenoon. It is a ten-mile contest, known as the Citizen Handicap, and unless many of the entries back out at the last moment there will be a field of fully two hundred starters.
The drought in the milk-producing counties of New-York and New-Jersey has materially affected the supplies of the wholesale dealers in this city.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 25. -- The only thing left in the hands of the Chairman of the Contested Seats Committee was the New-York contest, and it was with an almost dramatic interest that the crowd listened. Chairman Bell said that the committee recommended the seating of the sitting delegates, in accordance with the terms of a resolution which the committee had adopted.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 25. -- The summing up in the trial of Kuser, Robinson, Krauettler, and Heintz for conspiracy to defraud the State in connection with a printing contract, was finished this noon. Counselor Kalisch making a final argument for Kuser, and Prosecutor Stockton closing for the State.

The second and concluding day of the sale of Edwin Bartlett's books took place yesterday at Bangs Co.'s warerooms. As on the first day, a number of old and rare examples of printing were disposed of. Some of the prices obtained were:

SYRACUSE, Sept. 25. -- Senator Hill, before leaving town this afternoon, said: "The platform is excellent. The State ticket is a good one. They are new men, young men, and bright men. The ticket represents all shades of the party. No loyal Democrat can find any objection to the ticket. I should have preferred that a larger representation should have been afforded the State Democracy, but the twenty-one votes accorded it was a recognition.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- The State Department has succeeded in settling an indemnity claim against the Guatemalan Government, in behalf of three American laborers, W.H. Argall, Henry Thomas, and Robert Pardee. The matter has been pending for about a year, and the correspondence on the subject was included in the last volume of foreign relations laid before Congress.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 25. -- The Democratic Convention becomes memorable from a newspaper as well as a political point of view. For two mornings in succession copies of THE NEW-YORK TIMES have been delivered in this city in season for breakfast.

LONDON, Sept. 25. -- The United Press has obtained information concerning Mr. Charles D. Rose, who, through the Royal Victoria Yacht Club of Ryde, Isle of Wight, has challenged for the America's Cup. Mr. Rose is the second son of the late Sir John Rose, Bart., of Canada. His mother was formerly Miss Emmet-Temple of Rutland,Vt.
Hall Caine, the Manxman, whose literary genius is acknowledged wherever the English language is read, arrived in New-York yesterday as a passenger by the White Star steamship Teutonic.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 25.--The Democrats have nominated a clean State ticket.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 25. -- In the Deep Waterway Convention to-day this paper, by Alexander R. Smith, Secretary of the Executive Canal Committee, State of New York, was read:

There was a trifle more life in the play on the West Side Tennis Club's courts yesterday afternoon. The handicap singles were begun, and the scratch singles were pushed as far as the semifinal. An excellent practice match between Fischer and C.E. Sands, the Hudson River champion, excited considerable interest, though Fischer, playing on his own ground, completely outclassed the New-Hamburg crack.

In offering its counsel upon party procedures, five or six weeks ago, to the leaders and managers of the Democracy, THE TIMES ventured to say that "brains can be employed in politics with advantages equal to those resulting from their employment in other callings." THE TIMES also made this prediction in respect to the Syracuse Convention:

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 25. -- Fully 10,000 persons passed through the fair ground gates here to-day, while the number of carriages that entered the grounds ran up into the hundreds. It was considered a big crowd for the second day, and the managers were confident that had it not been for the threatening weather in the morning, the number of visitors would have been much larger.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 25. -- Chairman A.P. McQuirk of Davenport, Iowa, presented the report of the Committee on Credentials at the morning session of the Deep Waterways Convention to-day. It indicated that over 300 delegates were present. President Howland invited Lieut. G.P. Blow, United States Navy, and Thomas Munro, an engineer, of Canada, to seats on the platform as representatives of the two Governments.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- There is a good deaI of interest In the Vr Department regarding the result of the triaI by courtmartial at a Western post of a young army oeer, Lieut. N. H. Cowles, of the Sixteenth Infantry. He has been acting as Regimental Quartermaster for two or three years.

It was fortunate for people who went to the Brighton Beach race track yesterday that nine of the twenty horses entered for the first race were scratched. If they had not been, the programme would probably not have been concluded in time to prevent a violation of the law by racing after sunset.

ALBANY, Sept. 25. -- A letter was received at the State Controller's department to-day from Corporation Counsel Francis M. Scott, officially notifying the State authorities that New-York County would appeal from the recent decision of the General Term sustaining the levy upon it of two years' back taxes for State care of the indigent insane.

It is not for nothing that the bullfight is the national pastime of Spain. To enjoy a bullfight one must be indifferent to or must take positive pleasure in the wanton infliction of pain. It is the sport of a cruel people, such as every traveler knows at first hand and every reader of history at second hand that the Spaniards are.

For the purpose of permitting its readers to compare the platforms of the Democratic and Republican Parties, as adopted in their respective State Conventions, THE NEW-YORK TIMES presents them in the following form:

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 25. -- Harvard College began its new academic year to-day. The number of freshmen admitted by examination is 465, of whom 362 passed the June examinations, and 103 those held in September. Last year the number admitted was 332 in June and 94 in September, a total of 418.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- "Revolution" written in big, flaming letters, was the text of today's proceedings of the Irish National Convention, and when the body adjourned this evening to await the report of the Committees on Resolutions and Ways and Means, there did not remain a lingering doubt in the mind of a single delegate regarding the exact purpose and policy of those whose call had summoned him to Chicago.
The big parade arranged by the United Societies for Liberal Sunday Laws was held yesterday afternoon. It was computed that 30,000 persons took part in it.

It is gratifying to learn that the examinations and surveys of the Rapid Transit Commission's engineer with reference to vaults, pipes, , under Broadway have resulted in a conclusion that the cost of constructing the rapid-transit road on that part of the route will be less than was at first estimated.

-- N.W. Harris Co. offer $400,000 5 per cent. gold bonds of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company of Kansas City, Mo. The mortgage covers the principal surface street railway business of Kansas City, which has been consolidated. The combined net earnings of the surface street railways in Kansas City, now owned by this company, for the year ending June 1 last, are stated to have been $637,219.

ALBANY, Sept. 25. -- The Empire State Express rolled into the station while the New-York State Democrats' train was still here. A large delegation of Albanians came on the express, among them Senator Hill and Senator Parker and Mayor Molloy and Senator Murphy of Troy. All expressed their satisfaction with the result of the convention.

Spruce IV. won a race from the Ethelwynn yesterday by 23 seconds. It was the second contest that was completed for the Seawanhaka international trophy for small boats, and now the record stands a win each for the American and English boats. The Spruce won the race by superior handling on the part of Mr. Brand.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 25. -- President Flower, as soon as the convention had disposed of the resolutions, declared that nominations were in order and that the first nomination to be made was that for the high office of Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals. Mr. H. Greenfield of Cayuga stepped to the platform and placed ex-Judge John D. Teller in nomination for that office.

BOSTON, Sept. 25. -- Though the trotters and pacers were kept at it from 10 o'clock this morning till dark, with only an hour's intermission, two of the eight classes still remain at issue. Of the nineteen heats ten were taken by the two fast classes, the one for trotting stallions being the most interesting. It brought about 4,000 persons to Mystic Park, and as the favorite.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- There were many among the older delegates at the convention to-day who, when the members of the State Democracy, after their defeat, walked from the hall, recalled the turbulent Democratic State Convention held in this city Sept. 11, 1879. On that occasion the Tammany cohorts, led by John Kelly, when they found that they were unable to control the convention, marched from the hall.

There was reason for complaint when the Bostons kicked over the traces yesterday at Umpire Murray for calling the Brooklyn-Boston game at Eastern Park on account of darkness, as the sun was shining bright in the West, even though there were heavy clouds overhead. About 1,600 persons witnessed the game, and while they were anxious to see the Brooklyns win, they were nevertheless almost as much surprised as the Bostons when Umpire Murray called "game."
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25. -- Attorney Duprey of counsel for the defence in the Durrant case, made his opening statement this morning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- Commissioner of Indian Affairs Browning, in his annual report, issued to-day, says the placing of Indians in the State public schools has not been encouraging, as prejudice exists to the mingling of the races upon the part of the whites as well as the Indians.

PARIS, Sept. 25. -- Dispatches from Madagascar report a great victory for the French troops. According to these advices, the French, without loss, completely routed the entire Hova force Sept. 19 and captured the pass across the Ambohimena Mountains.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 25. -- The Democratic State Convention adjourned this afternoon at 2:20 o'clock, and no sooner were the delegates able to extricate themselves from the crush than they ran to their hotels to get ready for departure to their homes. Ten minutes later a long line of delegates stood at the approach to the cashier's desk in each of the big hotels where they had been staying during the convention.

Out of the Saratoga declaration in favor of maintaining the present law prohibiting liquor selling on Sunday everywhere in the State, and the declaration of the Syracuse Convention in favor of the home rule and local option principle, the issue emerges clearly. Everybody will know what it is and what it means.

WEDNESDAY, P.M. The stock market to-day continued in control of professional operators. In the morning stocks were sold because Messrs. Crossman Brothers were suspected of an intent to ship $1,000,000 gold; in the afternoon stocks were bought because the gold had been engaged for shipment, and the bad news being out the market was entitled to a rally.

After a futile attempt to establish a mission in East Africa, in which effort $10,000 was expended, the American Missionary Society was compelled to abandon the project, and the remnant of a large fund which had been accumulated for the purpose will now be distributed pro rata among the donors.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 25. -- Thomas C. Clarke, in his address to the Deep-Waterway Convention, said:

SYRACUSE, Sept. 25. -- Members of the Committee on Platform denounce as an outrageous "fake" the alleged platform sent out by The Chicago Associated Press last night, and published in The New-York World and other papers this morning. They say that it misrepresents the position of the party on nearly every matter.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 25. -- In twelve hours political alliances of years' standing have been subjected to such strains that they might break were it not that the men between whom these alliances exist are politicians, who are not yet ready to retire from the game.

There has thus far been, and probably will continue to be, a good deal of confused statement and discussion upon "home rule" and "local option" due to the absence of any specific proposition for dealing with the question of liquor selling on Sunday, the sole question which has given rise to the present agitation.

LONDON, Sept. 26. -- The Duke of Cambridge, whose retirement as Commander in Chief of the Forces was recently announced, and who was succeeded by Lord Wolseley, made a long speech at a luncheon which was given in his honor to-day in Edinburgh.

It was a day of slaughter for the plungers at the Brooklyn Jockey Club's track yesterday. But a single favorite in the speculation won a race and that one. Ray el Santa Anita, only came to the rescue after such a series of body blows that the talent let him severely alone, though he was, on form, one of the surest winners of the day.

After the Cambridge-Yale athletic games Saturday, Oct. 5, the teams will be given a complimentary dinner by prominent Yale Alumni of this city. The dinner will be held at 8 P.M. at Sherry's, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street. The subscription is $10, entitling the subscriber to one dinner ticket, including wine. Applications must be sent to Otto T. Bannard, 18 Wall Street, before Oct. 1, inclosing check, The Following comprise the committee in charge:
The celebration of the Jewish fast of Yom Kippur, or the Day of Atonement, will begin at sunset this evening and continue for twenty-four hours, ending at sunset to-morrow.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- Cornell University was formally opened in all branches to-day. President Schurman, in his annual address, said that up to noon to-day there were 104 more new students registered than at the same time last year. There are between 300 and 600 new students entering the university this year.
