TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 26. -- The State Convention adopted its platform immediately after the opening of the afternoon session. It is as follows:

Judge Pryor took occasion, in the Court of Common Pleas yesterday, to give expression to his opinion that "next to rum, mischievous mothers-in-law are the chief source of matrimonial broils that come before the courts."

A luncheon, to which a good deal of political significance is attached, was held yesterday afternoon in the rooms of the Lawyers' Club, in the Equitable Building. At the invitation of Charles Stewart Smith, who was Chairman of the Committee of Seventy, eleven representative leaders of the principal anti-Tammany organizations gathered and discussed the idea of uniting this Fall in opposition to Tammany Hall.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Dr. Talmage's formal acceptance of the call tendered by the First Presbyterian Church of this city, has been received, and he will preach his first sermon as co-pastor on Sunday evening, Oct. 27.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 26. -- Alexander T. McGill, the Democratic nominee for Governor, was born in Pittsburg, Penn., about forty-nine years ago, but in 1854, when he was in his eighth year, his father was elected to a chair in Princeton Theological Seminary, and the family moved to Trenton. Since that time he has been a resident of New-Jersey, and as a Jerseyman he attained his present eminence.

The position of Mr. SHEPARD of Brooklyn in the politics of the State, as shown by his course in the recent Democratic Convention, is a very interesting and peculiar one. It may be very simply described. He is the chief representative of a strong and energetic organization of Democrats who are united by a pledge to support Democratic principles and to oppose unfit Democratic candidates.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26. -- The usual weekly bulletin of the Racing Board of the League of American Wheelmen, issued to-day by the Chairman, George D. Gideon, contains the following items of interest to cyclists generally:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The funeral of Mrs. Crook, widow of Major Gen. George Crook, United States Army, will take place to-morrow at Arlington. The selected pallbearers are Secretary J. Sterling Morton, Gen. M.R. Morgan, Gen. T.H. Stanton, Col. H.C. Corbin, Col. C.B. Schofield, William Crook, John F. Waggaman, Lieut. L.W.V. Kennon, Lieut. Lucitn Young of the navy and Logan Carllsle.

The death of Dr. Edward W. Burnette from cancer on Saturday has aroused an unusual amount of interest among medical men in this city owing to the belief that the disease was directly communicated in this case through an operation which Dr. Burnette performed upon a cancerous patient about seven months ago.

ALBANY, Sept. 26. -- Gen. Howard Carroll, the Chief of Artillery on Gov. Morton's staff, was in town to-day to consult with the Governor and other State officers with the object in view of securing a larger appropriation next Winter for the artillery arm of the National Guard. Gen. Carroll believes that the State does not show the artillery the attention it should.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 26. -- Lord Dunraven is still a guest here. The Weather was very thick to-day, and the Valhalla was thus prevented from sailing. The vessel will leave on Saturday, if nothing happens. Mr. Laycock, owner of the Valhalla, entertained H.O. Bax-Ironsides and Lord Westmeath of the British Embassy, and Miss Fannie Tailer and Mr. and Mrs. Michael H. Herbert at luncheon to-day.

No one need be much surprised that the series of races for the America's Cup results in a victory for the New-York cutter. America has twice startled the world by a sudden and successful advance in designing ships. On each occasion the fact was presented with a dramatic effect which will never be forgotten on this side of the Atlantic.

The Excise Reform Association is as much opposed to the present excise law now, as it has been in the past, when it tried to have the law changed and local option established, the business of the saloon keeper placed on a strict business basis, and the question "for the sale of wine and beer only" on Sunday presented to the voters of the city.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

The Democrats of New-Jersey have done the best possible thing in nominating Chancellor McGILL for Governor. He is a Democrat in the highest and best sense of the term and a man of unquestionable ability and integrity. He has not been connected with political management and is not identified with party contests, and no one can doubt that as an executive officer he would be free to act, and would act, upon his convictions.

Mrs. Hannah Keener, twenty-four years old, of 330 East One Hundred and Seventeenth Street, either fell or jumped from the light-shaft window of her apartments on the fifth floor of the building early yesterday, and sustained injuries from which she died in the Harlem Hospital.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 26.--The corridors of the hotels, which were yesterday filled with a throng of Democrats who attended the State Convention, were filled with Republicans this morning, who began an unseemly scramble for a place on the Supreme Court bench.

LYNBROOK, L.I., Sept. 26.--A thunderstorm of unusual severity passed over this place about 5 o'clock this afternoon, accompanied by terrific flashes of lightning, which struck houses and trees and knocked a woman senseless, probably causing fatal injuries.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 26. -- Mrs. Theresa Daly of Linden was brought here to-day for confinement in the county jail under peculiar circumstances, and Detective Keron of the Prosecutor's office is making an investigation.
LONDON, Sept. 26. -- The Yachting World, in an article on the yachting situation, says:

The Spruce IV, won another race yesterday for the Seawanhaka International Trophy. She defeated the Ethelwynn so badly in the first half of the race that Mr. Field decided he had had enough, and sailed the Ethelwynn home. The wind was blowing about twelve miles an hour from the south southwest.

The New-York Athletic Club will hold its fifty-fifth games at Travers Island to-morrow afternoon. The games are open to all amateurs and the members of the London Athletic Club team have accepted an invitation to compete.
A document drawn up by three members of a Good Government Club, whose names are at present not made public, was received Tuesday last by Mayor Strong.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Capt. Perry, in command of the Castine, who has been engaged in diplomatic work on the European stations, started for Montevideo yesterday to join his old station, the South Atlantic, with headquarters at that port.

Hugo Hirsh yesterday resumed the examination of Chief Engineer Patrick McCanna of the Kings County Department of Charities before the Assembly committee, and secured several more bits of information as to the strange ways in which county affairs were conducted.

It would seem that such eminent Republicans as Edward Lauterbach, Chairman of the Republican County Committee, and ex-Senator Warner Miller of Herkimer do not agree as to the meaning of the Miller Sunday observance plank in the Republican platform.

The Bureau of Ethnology believes that it has now solved one of the greatest problems which have ever bewlidered the American historian. It has at last come to a point where it can answer the question: "Who were the mound builders?" This question has been debated by archaeologists and ethnologists the world over for a hundred years or more.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 26. -- John Sexton, a hostler employed by Andrew J. Post, was terribly beaten in an Erie Railroad car while coming from Middletown, N.Y., last night. Mr. Post has been summering with his family at Middletown. He sent Sexton yesterday with two horses to this city. They were placed in a freight car and Sexton, who had his trunk with him, made himself a bunk in a corner of the car.

BOSTON, Sept. 26. -- Though the breeders' meeting at Mystic Park was delayed for nearly three hours to-day on account of the condition of the track, seventeen heats were got off before dark, and six of the seven classes were finished. The two contests left over from yesterday were called as soon as the mud had dried sufficiently to make the footing safe, but the course was still slow.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 26. -- Democratic politicians, like the politicians of all other parties, are apt to say the day after a convention of their party that the platform adopted and the ticket nominated are good -- that one is a sound statement of party belief and the other entitled to cordial support.

The annual ten-mile handicap on the Coney Island Boulevard, in Brooklyn, yesterday, got in ahead of the electric storms, and naturally was a big success. During the progress of the race and for some time afterward the weather was perfect, and fully 5,000 persons watched it. A majority of the spectators were cyclists who visited the scene of the sport on their wheels.

Mrs. Elizabeth De Witt Leonard, a daughter of the late Jeremiah P. Robinson, the millionaire warehouseman, and one of the heirs to a large estate, is unable, she declares, to pay a dressmaker's bill of $2,397.95, for work done in 1892 and 1893. Margaret A. Howard, the surviving partner of Mary H. White, fashionable dressmaker of this city, is endeavoring to collect the money.

LEADVILLE, Col., Sept. 26. -- Sixty-five pounds of giant powder exploded this afternoon in the Belgian mine in Adelaide Park, five miles from this city, killing six miners and fatally injuring two. The killed were as follows:

True merit in a song is a passport which no sentry will question, and long before peace had been declared, James R. Randall's "Maryland, My Maryland," that fiery bit of rhymed eloquence, had crossed the enemy's lines, and exacted its meed of praise from the literary circles at the North. Oliver Wendell Holmes says of it: "It was the best poem produced on either side during the war."

The Brooklyn police have in custody Frederick Morgan, thirty-five years old, of 43 Hoyt Street, Brooklyn, who has been identified by Dr. George Drury of 115 Johnson Street as one of the men who decoyed him to the unoccupied house, 65 Nevins Street, July 27, bound and gagged him, and then robbed him of money and Jewelry.
The Consolidated Gas Company has put in many new flat houses what are known as "prepared gas meters."

Charles Frederick Rix, who is wanted in Chicago on a charge of embezzlement and forgery, and who fought extradition proceedings for eight months in the courts of Germany, was a passenger on the Hamburg-American steamship Patria, which arrived from Hamburg yesterday. He was in charge of Detective K.C. Kric, who chased him to Germany, and caused his arrest there.

Some idea of what the modern newspaper is may be obtained from an examination of THE NEW-YORK TIMES of yesterday. On Tuesday the Democratic State Convention met at Syracuse, and THE TIMES printed nearly three pages of matter relating to the meeting, in all about 300 inches of reading matter, to say nothing of headlines and cuts.

SHELTER ISLAND, Sept. 26. -- The cottagers who lengthened their Summer stay here are returning to their city homes. None of them regrets the sojourn into the latter part of September, as the hot wave was a testimony to their judgment.

An interesting experiment is about to be tried on the east side, when a brigade of boys of the neighborhood will take under its protection the fountain recently built in Rutgers Square, at the intersection of East Broadway and Canal Street, by Jacob Schiff and presented to the city.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 26. -- What is perhaps one of the most, if not the most, notable gathering of negroes ever held in America is that in progress in the Friendship Baptist Church of this city. The entire negro population of the United States is represented.

Conventions were held by Republicans in the various Assembly districts last night to select delegates to the County Convention, which will be held Oct. 3. In spite of the undoubted efforts that have been made at reconciliation between the factions representing the Platt and the Brookfield, or Administration faction, it was evident that the delegates at least were not parties to any peace methods in more than one district.

The fact that the Valkyrie is to be laid up for the Winter on this side of the ocean has given rise to a theory that she is to be raced against the Defender again next season, provided the unbuilt new challenger, which has precedence of her, should not prove good enough to regain the cup.

The weather interfered seriously with the celebration of the United Societies for Liberal Sunday Laws yesterday in Sulzer's Harlem River Park. It was intended, had the day been a pleasant one, to hold a jubilee on account of the extremely successful outcome of the events of the previous day, as both the parade and picnic resulted far beyond the fondest anticipations of the promoters of the project.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 26. -- Joseph Field is probably the oldest person in New-Jersey. To-day he celebrated his one hundred and third birthday. He is a Middletown farmer, and his appearance is that of a man of about eighty years.
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 26. -- The Democrats of New-Jersey, in an enthusiastic convention, to-day, nominated Chancellor Alexander T. McGill as their candidate for Governor.

Dockmaster Thomas Brady was before the Board of Dock Commissioners yesterday, charged with an irregularity in depositing a check for wharfage in his own name instead of placing it to the account of Edwin Einstein, the Treasurer of the board.
A meeting was held last night in the St. Bartholomew Mission rooms, in East Forty-second Street, at which Policeman William Nesbitt was the chief speaker.

A call was sent out yesterday afternoon to the members of the Executive Committee of Tammany Hall to attend a meeting at Tammany Hall at 4 P.M. to-day. At that time the forthcoming election will be discussed, and a plan of campaign decided upon.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26. -- Birth was given by the Irish National Convention this afternoon to an organization which has for its avowed object the independence of Ireland and the founding of a republic by a policy of physical force.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- A report has been prepared at the Department of State on the foreign trade of China for the year 1894. The material is mostly taken from a report made by the Secretary of the British Legation at Pekin to his Government. The most remarkable feature of the trade reports for 1894 was the fact that good results were obtained and promising revival of commercial prosperity set in.

BUFFALO, Sept. 26. -- Judge C.W. Hinson has resigned as a member of the Democratic State Committee from the Forty-eighth Senate District. It is understood that Augustus F. Scheu, State Committeeman from the Forty-ninth District, has also tendered his resignation to the State Committee in the interest of harmony.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 26. -- The committee appointed formally to notify John W. Griggs of his nomination for Governor met at the State Committee's rooms. All the members of the State Committee, which reorganized between 1 and 2 o'clock, were present, and also a number of prominent Republicans and some of Mr. Griggs's personal friends.
HAVANA, Sept. 26. -- The following are the particulars of the accident off El Morro, Cuba, on Wednesday last, when the Spanish war vessel Sanchez Barcaiztegui sank:
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 26. -- Allan L. McDermott, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, was cheered when he appeared on the platform to call the convention to order.
Mr. Julius Friend has sold, for Simon Herman and Max Danziger, the five-story iron-front warehouse 28 Howard Street, 25 by 87.1.

The closing session of the annual convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church in this diocese was held yesterday afternoon at the Church of the Holy Trinity, Madison Avenue and Forty-second Street. The proceedings began with prayers, offered by the Rev. Dr. Thomas R. Harris, the Secretary of the convention; the Rev. Dr. Mansfield, and the Rev. Victor Smith, rector of St. James's Mission.

The American Tract Society was assessed last Spring by the Commissioners of Taxes and Assessments on $300,000, the estimated value of the society's then half-finished office building, at Spruce and Nassau Streets. The tax was about $6,000, but the society was exempted for 1895.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Norman Wiard laid some rather remarkable propositions before the Army Board of Fortifications at its meeting to-day. He offered to convert an old Rodman smooth-bore cast-iron gun by the Reading-Wiard process into a twelve-inch rifle, which could be fired one-third more rapidly and exhibit greater endurance than the best of the modern steel-rifled guns.

The annual report of the New-York Central Railroad for the year ended June 30, 1895, was issued in pamphlet form yesterday. It shows that during the year the gross income was $42,489,537, from the following sources: Freight, $24,268,709.50; passenger, $12,965,112.44 ; rents. $1,716,779.82; mail, $1,551,901.14; express, $1,222,961.36; telegraph, $14,456.58; interest, $665,186.76; miscellaneous, $84,429.46.
A miscellaneous collection of books, including some lots of merit and interest, were sold at auction by Bangs Co. yesterday. Some of the books sold and the prices obtained were as follows:

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 26 -- Among the papers read to the Deep Waterway Convention to-day was the following, on the "Effect of Deep Water Between the Great Lakes and the Sea on Domestic Shipbuilding," by George Tunell, B.S., Fellow in Economics, Chicago University:

EDGEWATER, S.I., Sept. 26. -- The death by drowning of Robert W. Inman, at the time of a collision between his yacht Adelaide and the steamboat Perseus, on Aug. 26, was the subject of an inquest to-night by Coroner Schaffer and a jury.

A sensation was produced in Brooklyn yesterday by the reported announcement of some of the members of the independent Democracy that Edward M. Shepard was a candidate for the Democratic nomination for the Mayoralty.

The resolution adopted by the diocesan convention of the Episcopal Church upon the matter of liquor selling on Sunday is one with which nobody can possibly quarrel who is not ready to avow himself a lawless and disorderly person. The resolution sets forth that, whereas the opening of saloons on Sunday is contrary to law, therefore the closing of the saloons by the officers of the law is to be commended.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 26. -- The one hundred and ninety-fifth year of Yale University was begun this morning, when the academic, law, and scientific departments the main schools, began their Fall terms. Within a week the Medical, Divinity, Art, and Music Schools will open for the year.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 26. -- Delegates to the Deep Waterways Convention removed from Army and Navy Hall to the finely decorated rooms of the Chamber of Commerce this morning.
Oh-o-o! isn't It beautiful!"

The warmth shown by Col. Ashley Cole in his sweeping reply to those who have lately insinuated that Gov. Morton's health is not good enough to permit him to be a Presidential candidate has aroused considerable interest among those who keep their eyes steadily fixed on next year's Republican National Convention.

Photography is the standing wonder of modern science and art. True, the mechanism of the camera has recently been so simplified that a child can "touch the button" and perform the miracle of taking a photograph; yet it may be truly said that late as well as former discoveries in the scientific bypaths of this very important branch of knowledge furnish material for much thought and reflection.

Game in general is reported to be uncommonly plentiful in Vermont. The conditions for the growth of young birds have been more than usually favorable, and they are said to be large and plump for this season of the year. The game upon which Vermont sportsmen chiefly rely are partridge and woodcock.

Lovers of the rare and unique in literature will be greatly interested in examining a volume which is found in the large collection which that enthusiastic book lover and collector, Charles E. Lauriat, has recently brought from Europe. This is a copy of the famous "Breeches Bible," in the edition of 1599.

UTICA, Sept. 27. -- Senator Henry J. Coggeshall is developing more strength in his independent canvass than was expected when his delegates bolted from the Republican Convention. Up to the present time the fight has been between Coggeshall and the regular Republican nominee, Frederick G. Weaver, and it is by no means certain that it will not so continue to the end.

If it be true, as ex-Congressman FINERTY asserted, that he and the other vehement persons who have been holding a National Convention at Chicago this week, "are the friends of every enemy England has, and the enemies of all her friends," then the question arises as to what may be the relation of the FINERTY and his associates, and the great army he is about to raise, toward these United States.

Advance knowledge in the financial district that $1,500,000 in gold would be withdrawn from the Sub-Treasury prevented anything like uneasiness among holders in the security market when the announcement came that the gold had been taken.
Capt. Allen Thompson, proprietor of boarding house at 137 West Forty-seventh Street, summoned Policeman William Wegman early Thursday morning to remove a drunken woman from his premises.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Paymaster W.M. Maynadier, stationed at San Francisco, and Surgeon Washington Matthews, stationed in this city, were to-day placed on the retired list of the army, on account of disability.

The committee which had charge of the Gramercy-Metropolis century run, last Sunday, completed yesterday the count of the checks deposited at various points along the route to New-Brunswick. The amount of labor which this task entailed can hardly be appreciated, but an idea can be given when it is considered that over 2,500 little papers, in various stages of dilapidation, had each to be carefully scrutinized.

By a vote of 102 to 2 the Executive Committee of the New-York State Democracy last night indorsed the ticket nominated by the Democratic State Convention. The two opponents of this action were John De Witt Warner and Isaac H. Klein. The resolution indorsing the Democratic State ticket was passed after a discussion in which John J. Quinlan and Capt. John Murphy threatened to leave the organization unless that action were taken.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 27. -- As Engine 442 of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, drawing ten freight cars, was on its way to Packerton, Engineer Hosier saw a tree, sixty feet long, across the track at Stony Creek, between White Haven and Mauch Chunk. It had fallen from the adjacent mountainside. There was just time to reverse the engine, and for the train hands to jump.

The conference between the harmony committees of the two Democratic organizations in Brooklyn, which were suspended two weeks ago by the preparations for the State Convention, will be resumed at 2 o'clock this afternoon in the Clarendon Hotel, Johnson and Washington Streets.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Adjt. Gen. Ruggles to-day sent the following circular notice to officers of the army on duty in Washington:

These who follow with interest the work of the United States Fish Commission will learn with satisfaction that a competent successor to the late Commissioner Macdonald is talked of in the person of Tarleton H. Bean, at present in charge of the Aquarium at the Battery.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- A railroad-crossing fight took place here this afternoon between the employes of the Harlem Railroad Company and those of the White Plains Trolley Company. The electric company is completing its line in order to provide for the traffic of the county fair, which will open Monday.
ALBANY, Sept. 27. -- The Court of Appeals to-day decided the Westchester annexation cases, holding the law to be constitutional.

The great Mojave desert is no longer to be a trackless waste. The loss of hapless prospectors who have perished from year to year has finally moved the Board of Supervisors of San Bernardino County, which includes within it 20,000 square miles of the desert, to take some action to make it possible for prospectors to travel that arid region in comparative safety.

Mrs. Hetty Green was early on hand yesterday afternoon at the office of Henry E. Anderson, in the Mills Building. Mr. Anderson is the referee in the action brought by Henry A. Barling as executor of the estate of Edward Mott Robinson, Mrs. Green's father, to have his accounts approved.

Ex-Supervisor at Large John A. Quintard, who appointed Messrs. Gott, Nolan, and Murphy Commissioners of Charities of Kings County, was the principal witness yesterday before the Assembly committee that is investigating the affairs of the Charities Department.

BOSTON, Sept., 27. -- As the course at Mystic Park got another soaking last night, the harness races were again delayed. For this reason only three of the six classes were started, and the breeders' meeting goes over until Saturday.

Albert Gray, sixty years old, who lives with his wife and several grown children at 32 South Portland Avenue, Brooklyn, a fashionable part of the city, was locked up in the Oak Street Police Station yesterday afternoon, and later taken before Magistrate Wentworth, in the Tombs Police Court, who remanded him back to the station house to enable Capt. Thompson's men to procure further evidence against him.
Capt. William Strauss of the East Sixty-seventh Street Police Station was placed on trial before the Police Commissioners on the following charges:

" I am not here to make any stay in Boston," said Chief Justice Melville W. Fuller of the United States Supreme Court to a Herald representative when he came down to meet the latter in Hotel Brunswick yesterday afternoon.

Bradstreet's review of business failures for the nine months of the year. which will appear to-day, shows that there have been 9,299 failures in the United States. being 48 more than for the corresponding period last year The review says:

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

The Ethelwynn yesterday beat the Spruce IV. 1 minute 10 seconds over a triangular course. The race was sailed in a strong northwesterly breeze and over a rough sea. Under similar weather conditions on Thursday the Spruce beat the Ethelwynn nearly 9 minutes in a race three miles to windward and return, and then the Ethelwynn retired. That the Ethelwynn should have won yesterday was rather a surprise.

Michael F. McGee of 201 West Sixtieth Street is President of the West Side Liquor Dealers' Association, and is familiarly known as the "Little Mayor of Amsterdam Avenue." He has a saloon at 20 Amsterdam Avenue, corner of Sixtieth Street. It is a common saying in the Twenty-fourth Precinct that "What Mike McGee says goes."

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 27. -- The Kentucky editors were in complete possession of the exposition again to-day. After they grew weary walking over the grounds and seeing the show, they repaired to the pavilion and reveled in a Georgia barbecue.

We have already called attention to the advanced position taken by the Democratic Convention of this State in advocating the gradual retirement and extinction of the greenbacks and the limitation of legal tenders to gold and silver. We have no wish to attach undue importance to this action.

The western coast of Madagascar belongs to the Sakalavas. This tribe is subdivided into an infinity of fractions, independent from one another, governed by chiefs without authority. Every village is at war with its neighbor. The Sakalava, being nomadic, brutal, and lazy, spends his whole life sleeping, drinking, and stealing.

Search out and tell me of the victor of Epsom, where in my soul his name standeth written; for that the season of harvest, bearing apace with it after four moons the festival on the Town Moor favored of the goodly Tykes, hath minded me how that I owe him a deep debt -- aye, and no lesser to myself, who have hitherto failed to make me anything out of him.

Copies of the annual report of the Illinois Central Railroad were distributed yesterday. This is the forty-fifth annual report to the stockholders of this company, and it makes a very satisfactory showing, considering the unfavorable business conditions that prevailed during the year which ended June 30.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Secretary Herbert has not decided who will christen the Brooklyn. This armored cruiser will be launched Wednesday, Oct. 2, the Secretary and Mr. Cramp having had another conference relative to the matter this morning.

That an international rifle range will be established at Savannah on the same general principles as that at Sea Girt may be regarded as a foregone conclusion. The military men have all made up their minds to this, and with the prestige gained by the Savannah team at the recent contest at Sea Girt there is no doubt of the co-operation of the business men and citizens generally.

The semi-final round in the women's singles of the Staten Island Ladies' Club open tennis tournament at Livingston was marked by a fine contest between Miss Atkinson and Miss Hellwig. It was champion against ex-champion, and after three sets of rattling tennis, the ex-champion triumphed.

Age does not stale nor publicity wither the infinite variety of Judge WILLIAM J. GAYNOR'S candidacy for Mayor of Brooklyn. At great risk of seeming irreverence we have recently been forced to comment upon Judge GAYNOR'S declaration that he was in the hands of Providence, and so, of course, liable to a sudden transfer from the bench to the Mayor's chair.

Negligence on the part of an employee in the Water Department, it is said, is responsible for a spread of typhoid fever in and around Pullman. Thirty or forty cases have been called to the attention of the Health Department, and a careful investigation brings to light a startling state of affairs.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 27. -- Judge Jenkins has accepted the resignations of the receivers of the Northern Pacific Railroad, and will appoint their successors to-morrow morning.

TUNNELTON, West Va., Sept. 27. -- The sleeping car of Passenger Train No. 4 on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad was wrecked this morning, and a number of people were injured. Train No. 4 had taken a siding to permit Train No. 1 to pass. The sleeping car was not clear of the main track, and one side of it was crushed in by the engine of Train No. 1.

Since the early days of the conquest of America by the Spaniards, this isthmus became famous for its gold, so much so that the province was then called "Golden Castile,'' (Castilla de Oro.) Indeed, the first settlements, Santa Maria la Antigua and Acla, founded near the mouth of the Afrato River, were calculated to become great mining emporiums on account of the large number of mines which were discovered in their vicinity.

POUGHKEEPSIE; Sept. 27. -- Lou Payn, who was so badly thrashed several years ago by "Tom" Newbold of Hyde Park, against whom he ran for Senator as the nominee of the Republican Party in this district, is running for the Senate again in the Twenty-fourth District, but this time by proxy.

The Colored Republican Organization el the City and County of New-York met last night at 114 West Fifty-third Street, to adopt a new constitution and by-laws. It was one of the stormiest meetings ever held by the organization, and the energetic Sergeant-at-Arms had his hands full in trying to keep the members from fighting.

A remarkable and tragic story of the army is related by Col. John A. Clous, the authenticity of which be he can vouch for from personal familiarity with the facts and acquaintance with the principal actor.

MEDIA, Penn., Sept. -- John A. Silbey, agent at Chadd's Ford for the Pennsylvania Railroad Company and the Adams Express Company, was arrested yesterday on the charge of robbing the station safe of $221. He was held in $500 ball by Justice of the Peace Greene of this place for a further hearing Monday.

There is but one opinion among those who have an intelligent interest in the waterway question as to the first thing to be done. The improvement of the Erie Canal contemplated by the nine-million-dollar scheme should be carried out as speedily as possible. The interest awakened by the ship-canal proposition and the discussion which it has excited have tended only to confirm that opinion.

Republicans of the Platt stripe looked over the results of Thursday night's primaries and came to the conclusion yesterday that they were in control by a sufficient majority to prevent the County Convention from taking any steps in favor of a union ticket in this city if they so desire.
ALBANY, Sept. 27. -- Another strike for spoils developed in the Executive Chamber to-day, when charges against Superintendent of Prisons Lathrop were made known.

The Atlanta Exposition is above all else an exposition of the new industrial South, which is as yet scarcely thirty years of age. All the minor and specific exhibits that are to be seen there are mainly of interest as they conduce to an understanding of the change that has been wrought since the close of the war in the temper and disposition and habits of the Southern people.

The Court of Appeals has sustained the lower courts in all the cases affecting the annexation of a part of Westchester County to the city and the treatment of the annexed section in the apportionment of representation. This upholds the action of the City Board of Aldermen in the apportionment matter, and requires the Supervisors of Westchester County to reverse their action.

City of Mexico Letter to The Washington Star. Pulque, the native drink, is extracted from the maguey plant, a species of the American aloe, that grows readily in an arid soil. Webster calls it of the genus agave. An incision is made into the innner side of the thick, pointed blades, growing upright four or five feet, to the number of a dozen or so, from a common stalk.
The Fail meeting of the Brighton Beach Association ended yesterday. The racing was, as has been the case throughout tile meeting, tame and uninteresting.

Every man remembers the old schoolboy trick of patting the head with one hand and at the same time rubbing the stomach with the other. If any one thinks it is easy just let him try to do it, and see what a botch he'll make of things. But Director Studley of the Bostonians was seen last week unconsciously performing a more difficult feat.

A conference was held at Police Headquarters yesterday afternoon between a committee of police surgeons and representatives of the various hospitals. The conference was the result of a letter sent to the Police Board by Dr. Stimson of Bellevue Hospital, suggesting that police surgeons should be summoned to the station houses to attend trivial accident cases requiring surgical or medical attendance, and called for consultation with ambulance surgeons in serious cases.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 27. -- The anthracite coal situation seems to be rapidly working out its own salvation, and what the coal Presidents failed to accomplish after numerous conferences and fierce and disastruos cutting of prices is being brought about by the increased demand for coal and reinforced restriction in production caused by the prolonged drought.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27. -- The last of the international cricket matches of 1895 was commenced here to-day on the grounds of the Mercer Cricket Club, and another large and fashionable crowd was present. The fact that of the two games played in this city so far both the Englishmen and the Philadelphians have each won one makes the third contest unusually interesting, and both sides are striving their utmost to gain the decisive victory.

The two games of baseball played at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon between the New-York and Baltimore clubs attracted about 8,000 spectators. As much as the games were needed by the Baltimore club in their great battle with the Clevelands for the League championship, the best they could do was to split even with the New-Yorks, each club taking a gme.

MONTCLAIR, Sept. 27. -- There was an exciting meeting of the citizens of this place last night in the Opera House, and the women of the town took a lively interest in the proceedings. The meeting was called by the Town Council to discuss the question whether the North Jersey Street Railway Company should have a franchise to run trolley cars on Bloomfield Avenue.

Mr. Platt's Republican State Committee will meet at noon to-day in Parlor D R, at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, and organize for the campaign. A half dozen members were in the city last night, among them Gen. W.S.C. Wiley of Catskill, George W. Dunn of Binghamton, Barnett H. Davis of Palmyra, Lewis H. Vail of Poughkeepsie, John R. Hazel of Buffalo, and Chairman Hackett of Utica.

" When I was studying law down in New-York State forty years or more ago," said the Judge. between the puffs of his after-dinner smoke, "the 'anti-renters' were stirring up a great excitement. You've read about it. Almost all Delaware County and other lands in the most fertile part of the State were held by farmers on ninety-nine- year leases.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 27. -- In the Constitutional Convention to-day the Committee on Corporations reported an article covering that subject in nineteen sections, most of which are wholly novel in the organic law of this State, the old Constitution having touched very lightly upon the regulation of corporations.

A number of prominent golfers from the St. Andrew's Club left the city yesterday for Boston. They will play to-day the second match with the golf team of the Brookline Country Club, near Boston. The St. Andrew's team consists of fifteen men, and is a particularly strong one, practically all of the crack golfers of the club having been brought together.

Uncle David Gray, one of the most upright and highly esteemed citizens of Oneida County, died at his home in Marcy last evening at 8:22 o'clock. He had been failing for a long time, the troubles incident to old age bearing hard upon him. His life was despaired of several weeks ago, but he rallied and his friends hoped that he might recover a measure of health.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27. -- Placing dutiable merchandise in bond in the name of the United States to protect the interests of the Government is an every day affair at the Custom House, but the bonding of two human beings is something entirely new in the annals of the Philadelphia Custom House.

Five thousand American citizens within the coming week will receive circulars asking them to co-operate with Robert Flaherty of 365 Broadway, this city, in a grand, dazzling scheme to erect, somewhere in New-York, a silver palace, to be constructed of the silver bullion in the United States Treasury, in which a musical exhibition and festival may he held in 1900 to celebrate the opening of the twentieth century.

BLOOMFIELD, Sept. 27. -- A number of small boys living at Glen Ridge went out for a good time, and having read how college youths often have great sport with their paint pots, resolved to try it themselves.
Messrs. Frederick Southack Co. have sold for Meyer Kahn, to Henry Corn, at $112,500, the four-story brick building 834 Broadway, 25 by 95.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- The More draft has been paid, and the money is now subject to the order of Secretary Olney. The Spanish Minister, Dupuy de Lome, gave the draft on the Spanish finance agent in London to Acting Secretary of State Adee Sept. 14, the time for its delivery, according to the demands made by Secretary Olney, expiring Sept. 15, which date happened to fall on Sunday.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Sept. 18. -- Official reports from Guantanamo say that on Sept. 16 a Spanish column attacked the rebel camp Piedra, between the Felicidad and Rio Sew, occupied by 800 insurgents, under Leader Gil, and killed eight rebels before driving them from their position. Three Spanish soldiers were wounded.

Reports from the wool market for the week, as reported to The Textile Manufacturers' Journal, show increased activity. Sales of the week in the Boston, New-York, and Philadelphia markets aggregated 6,204,000 pounds domestic, and 4,086,400 pounds foreign, a gross total of 10,290,400 pounds, as compared with 3,435,600 pounds domestic, and 3,266,500 pounds foreign, a gross total of 6,702,100 pounds last week.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 27. -- The Valhalla, with Lord Dunraven aboard, will sail for England to-morrow at noon.

The regular Kings County Democratic organization held primaries in the 685 election districts last night, when delegates were elected to the city, county, Senatorial, Assembly, Aldermanic, and ward conventions.

The legal status of the Court of Special Sessions, as at present constituted, has been attacked again, in an action brought in the Supreme Court by James P. Keating, who was the Clerk of the court under the old regime.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- The Guatemalan Minister, Mr. Lazo Arriaga, makes an unqualified denial this morning of the dispatch sent out last night by The Chicago Associated Press with reference to himself and his diplomatic colleague, Mr. Dupuy de Lome, the Spanish Minister.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 27. -- There was a small tornado in Middlebush a few miles from this city, yesterday afternoon. No very serious damage was done beyond that occasioned by blowing down and tearing apart corn sheafs, which were standing in the fields. A few fences also blew down and a few hay stacks were deranged.

Gen. Jo Shelby received some welcome news recently, which he made known to friends. He is of the opinion that the news will ultimately result in his securing again the gold watch that was once his father's, and was stolen in 1848 at Lexington, Ky.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 27. -- Henry Kimber, a member of the English Parliament and a stockholder and Director of the Anglo-American settlement at Rugby, Tenn., arrived directly from London in Pittsburg three days ago. He closed a deal with the Standard Oil Company to-day and leased to it the 35,000 acres of land in the Rugby tract, in Tennessee.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 27. -- The Republican Convention for the Fifth Judicial District is in a dead-lock over the nomination for the additional Judgeship, and has been throughout the entire day.

Prof. J.L. Wortman, who has charge of the field exploration work under Prof. Henry F. Osborn of the paleontological department of the American Museum of Natural History, is expected back in New- York in a few days, after a trip of six months along the northern and western lines of Colorado.

At the celebration of the fifty-eighth anniversary of Dr. Edward McGlynn's birthday, in the Murray Hill Lyceum, last night, Dr. McGlynn made public for the first time the correspondence which took place between himself, Archbishop Corrigan, and Apostolic Delegate Satolli at the time he was deposed.

-- The art display at the St. Louis Exposition and Music Hall Association this year is much above the average, judging from the criticisms of the press of that city. A daintily bound and handsomely printed catalogue of small and convenient form has been issued, that might well be taken as a model for our own exhibitions, in lieu of the formidable and unwieldy books so frequently issued.
HAVANA, Sept. 27. -- A dispatch from Guantanamo says that Col. Canellas's column on Wednesday surprised a camp of about 1,000 rebels under Gil Perequito and Perez at Bayameso.

" A crying need in the telephone business," said J.R. Malloy, of the Central Pennsylvania Telephone Company, after an examination of the Washington Telephone Exchange, "is a talk-meter -- that is, some sort of an automatic arrangement by which language can be measured off by the yard. Philadelphia is approaching the idea.

It was a field night for Tammany Hall. Its General Committee met last night in the Wigwam and did enough business to keep the tongues of the politicians wagging for some days to come. Most of the wagging will be done over the selection of the permanent committees and their Chairmen, ostensibly made by Chairman Augustus W. Peters of the General Committee, but really made by the men who are just now controlling Tammany's destiny.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 27. -- New-York Lodge of Elks was given a brilliant reception and rousing welcome here to-night by Elizabeth Lodge and the people of this city. The home lodge, headed by Drake's Zouave Band, met the visitors, and also Newark Lodge, at the station, and marched with them to the Zouave Armory.
AUSTIN, Texas, Sept. 27. -- Gov. Culberson issued the following proclamation at midnight last night for a session of the Legislature to pass a law prohibiting prizefighting:

The Sinking Fund Commission held a lengthy meeting yesterday in the Mayor's office. The Mayor called the commission to order shortly after 11 o'clock, and until after 1 o'clock the problem of separating the Department of Charities and Correction was discussed.

The New-York Electrical Society held its opening meeting for the season 1895-6 at Columbia College at 8 o'clock last night, when Mr. T.C. Martin, editor of The Electrical Engineer, entertained a small audience with a lecture untitled "Niagara on Tap."

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 28. -- The races of the Sahodalica Wheelmen for the benefit of Memorial and All Souls' Hospitals, were held on the track of the Morristown Driving Park this afternoon. A large number of persons were in attendance. Summaries:

Samuel Gompers, ex-President of the Federation of Labor, and Peter J. McGuire First Vice President of the Federation of Labor, who were delegates to the Labor Union Congress of Breat Britain, recently held in Cardiff, Wales, arrived here yesterday on the steamship New-York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28.--A negro burglar was shot and killed just at daybreak this morning by Dr. Andrew Stewart, a young physician at 1,420 Q Street, Northwest. The fatal termination of the affair was preceded by a desperate fight.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 28. -- A fine day, a fine course, with greens in excellent condition and excellent playing made the men's handicap golf tournament at the Morristown Golf Club a complete success this afternoon. All the crack players were entered, and a large field of new ones.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 28. -- One hundred and sixty-eight ballots were cast in the Republican Fifth District Judicial Convention, which has been in session here for three days, before the vote juggling resulted in a majority for one of the six contestants for the nomination to the additional Judgeship on the Supreme Court bench of the district.

The work of the Department of Public Instruction in connection with the American Museum of Natural History, of which Prof. Albert S. Bickmore is Superintendent, has received an additional impetus from the law passed last April to provide additional facilities for instruction in natural history and geography in the common schools of this State.

It was announced yesterday that Miss Ida May Schieren, daughter of Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn, had been selected by Secretary of the Navy Herbert to perform the ceremony of christening the new cruiser Brooklyn, which is to be launched Wednesday at Cramp's shipyard, in Philadelphia. Mayor Schieren, in behalf of his daughter, has accepted the Secretary's invitation.

At a meeting of the said committee, held at Tammany Hall on the 13th day of September, 1895, the following call and resolutions for the election of delegates to the several nominating conventions, reported from the Committee on Organization, were read, unanimously adopted, and ordered to be published:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The facts in regard to the Venezuelan dispute, as nearly as they can be ascertained from the best sources of information, are these:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The rank of Lieutenant General of the army will expire with the retirement at noon to-morrow of John McAllister Schofield, he then having attained the age limit of sixty-four years. This title was revived in favor of Gen. Schofield by a special act of Congress last February, and had previously been bestowed but three times -- on Grant, Sherman, and Sheridan.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 28. -- The Democratic State campaign was opened here to-night with an imposing demonstration. It is believed that the procession of clubs was the greatest in point of numbers participating ever seen here on a similar political occasion. The procession was in seven large divisions, and was composed of sixty-six different clubs, representing the principal cities and towns of the State.

Vendors of rotten fruit will hereafter feel the heavy hand of the Health Department. That the practice of selling decayed eatables under various concealments has become alarmingly general is known to Commissioner Kerr, and he proposes to stop the traffic, which is as deadly in its way as that in impure milk.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 28. -- The Woman's Improvement Society of the Oranges is preparing for the establishment of its Training School for Domestics this Fall, which it is proposed to have in full operation by the first of the year. As soon as the building is secured the present day nursery will be moved into it and be made a part of the school.

In Banbury Church, Essex, there are three effigies all clad in chain armor. Two of them lie under arches in the north wall, and the other is placed against the east end of the north aisle. They are all cross-legged, and their feet all rest on lions; but each man and each lion is in a different position.
" How did you guess," asked the musician, with an ecstatic light in his black eyes, "that I was interested in The London Daily Telegraph's letter's about the age of love?"

A more desirable day for baseball could scarcely be asked for than the New-Yorks and Baltimores had yesterday. By winning the game the Baltimores placed themselves beyond the possible reach of the Cleveland Club. There were about 8,000 spectators present.

The polo season that came to a close on Friday last, when the Myopia Club of Hamilton, Mass., defeated the Rockaway Club in the contest for the W.W. Astor gold cup, has been in every respect a successful and a delightful one.

Though the weather was raw and cold, and it was a cheerless day for racing, the card offered by the Brooklyn Jockey Club yesterday attracted not only the regulars, but a large number of the half-holiday pleasure seekers.

It may be worth while to call attention to the similarity of the conditions and resources of the two communities, California and New South Wales; equal in population, equally blessed by a climate which can hardly be rivaled, it would be difficult indeed to decide which of these communities takes the first rank in the extent and infinite variety of national resources.

The funeral of Policeman John T. Delehanty of the East Thirty-fifth Street Station, who died on Wednesday last from a fracture of the skull received in the performance of his duty on Monday last, took place at 1:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Next week there will be, in this city, some of the most important meetings which the Catholic Church of this country has ever known. These meetings will be held in connection with the dedication of the new McMahon Hall of Philosophy at the Catholic University, and will serve to draw together a large and distinguished gathering of Catholic prelates and priests.

To coax the same Tommy to eat a certain sort of dried bread with his milk last Spring, his mamma told him of some one she had heard of who, not being well, could not eat ordinary food, and really lived on these crusts and little else. Tommy listened, but did not seem much impressed. Last week, however, when the family returned from the Summer outing, the familiar bread reappeared on the table.

A Summer visitor who spent a few days in the little town of Ellicottville, Cattaraugus County, N.Y., was attracted by the peculiar and pleasing tone of the bell in the tower of St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church, and was thus led to make an inquiry as to where the bell was procured.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- The tenth annual fair of the Society of Agriculture and Horticulture Westchester County will be held all next week on the fair grounds, about a mile from this village, on the Tarrytown Road, and it promises to be a very successful event.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 28. -- An even dozen of heats disposed of the balance of the card at Old Mystic Park to-day and brought the breeders' meeting to an end. The chilly weather handicapped the trotters considerably, though both Adra Belle and Alcedalia improved their records. They were favorites in their respective classes, but Adra Belle had to go five hard heats before she could dispose of such cracks as Celaya, Nosegay, and James L.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y. Sept. 28. -- Monday morning a group of travelers, each equiped with a neat little basket of lunch, will fill the last through parlor car that goes from here this season. Henry Miller will gently close the Spring House door behind them, and the boarding season of 1895 will be a thing of the past in Richfield.

The beginning of October usually marks the commencement of the active season in real estate dealings. This is hardly the case this year, however, since there was really little if any cessation during the hot months. There have been fewer sales than are expected during the coming months, but inquiry has been active, and negotiations have been many in number all through the Summer season.

SANDY HOOK, Sept. 28. -- Corpl. Doyle and Private Conway, artillerymen, were instantly killed here this afternoon by the premature explosion of a shell in the 4 7-10-inch Canet gun, which was being tested. Privates Coyne and McDonald were also injured seriously, the former fatally, it is thought, while Lieut. Montgomery, who was in charge of the squad, had a narrow escape, but was not hurt.

PANAMA, via Galveston, Sept. 28. -- Bishop Peralta leaves Colon for Mexico City, via Vera Cruz. It is said that he is to represent Colombia at the great religious festival in honor of the Virgin of Guadalupe.

The majority of people do not worship, and the fault is largely on the side of the Church, which has not fitted the means to the times. The words, the forms, are to-day those which helped the people of 300 years ago. They remain the same, although the fashions, the thought, the whole organization of society, has been changed.

In an illustrated interview with "Q." (Mr. Quiller Couch) in The Young Man for October, the novelist tells us that since he has resided at Fowey there has been no danger of overworking. "You see, I am fond of the water; I keep two or three boats, and we have a good yacht club, in whose affairs I am much interested.
The Rev. T. De Witt Talmage, who has accepted the call to the First Presbyterian Church, at Washington, D.C., will preach twice before he leaves Brooklyn.

There still lingers a widespread belief in the North of Scotland that the "fair folk" or "gweed neebors," as the fairies are called, have a craving for human milk, and during the first days of convalescence a mother must be zealously guarded lest one of the "wee people" come and rob the child of its nourishment.

There is an article in the October number of The Forum by Mr. Louis WINDMULLER, entitled "The Resuscitation of Blue Laws," which may be taken as presenting a German-American view, if not the German-American view, of the Sunday excise question. The title of the article and some of its reasoning seem to us quite irrelevant to that question.

The failure of Civil Engineer PEARY'S latest attempt to march further poleward will call out abundant sympathy, not only on account of the keen disappointment which the gallant explorer must feel, but because it is evident that the failure was due to no lack of energy, but only to that hard luck which has beset so many of his predecessors in arctic researches.

The words "genuine green-gage plums" were to be seen occasionally on the fruit stands near the big markets yesterday. The necessity of placing the word "genuine" over plums was readily explained by the wholesale dealers.

The Seawanhaka International Trophy will remain in this country for the present. The Spruce IV., after making a gallant struggle for the cup, was beaten in the final race yesterday by C.J. Field's Ethelwynn. It took seven days to decide which yacht should have the cup. Five races were completed, and in two of these the Spruce IV. finished first and Ethelwynn won three.

The American Missionary Association of Congregational Churches has obtained an opinion from one of the most eminent constitutional lawyers in Massachusetts that the so-called "Cheats law," passed by the Florida Legislature last Winter, cannot stand in any United States court.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 28. -- In the Constitutional Convention to-day the first final action on any one article of the new Constitution was taken. The article on the executive department, after having gone through the tearing process of three readings, was adopted and was sent to the Committee on Style and Revision, becoming thereby a part of the new document.

So much has been said about the adulteration of milk and so sweeping have been the terms of accusation of milk dealers that the public has come to look upon dealers as an unreliable class. The unjustness of this conclusion is, of course, recognized by the dealers themselves. While many, however, knowing the real facts, do not pay any attention to the popular opinion, others feel acutely the position in which they are unfairly placed.

It has been generally held in England that the "caucus" and the still more highly developed directing instrumentality in politics known as the "machine" are peculiarly American, and so, no doubt, they were originally. But with the extension of the suffrage in England organization has been found necessary, and the contending parties in that country are now equipped with machinery of an extremely elaborate character.

KISSINGEN SPA, Germany, Sept. 14. -- This watering place, where a prominent New-York merchant brought upon himself an imprisonment of fourteen days for venturing to remonstrate against the insolence of a junior officer, is a quaint and interesting spot in spite of its ridiculous and arbitrary government and rules.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 28. -- A few more cottagers, including Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt, Miss Consuelo Vanderbilt, and Mrs. William Astor, have departed during the week. It will, however, be two weeks yet before any serious inroad on the cottage colony will be noticeable.
A School Street lawyer tells the following story as characteristic of the late Judge McCafferty:

" You are growing more disobliging and cranky every day, old man," said Philip Morrison to his friend and fellow-clerk, Henry Enos, one morning when, in a rear office of the Asbestos Trust Company, they were compensating for the meagre lunch furnished by violating the rule against smoking.

Edwin W. McHenry of St. Paul, for many years chief engineer of the Northern Pacific system, and Frank G. Bigelow, President of the First National Bank of Milwaukee, were yesterday appointed receivers of the Northern Pacific property, to succeed Thomas F. Oakes, Henry C. Payne, and Henry C. Rouse, resigned.

Beginning on Oct. 8 there win be a big sale of hunters, saddle, and harness horses at the American Horse Exchange. Broadway and Fiftieth Street, that should attract buyers from all sections. The occasion will be known among horsemen as the Silver Cup sale, for Manager Grand has offered a handsome trophy to the consignor obtaining the highest average for six horses.
There was another Democratic harmony conference in Brooklyn yesterday. The conference was not concluded, but was adjourned until Monday afternoon.

The annual convention of military wheelmen at the Broadway Central Hotel, on Oct. 15, promises to do much for cycling, and also the National Guard and the army. The purpose of the promoters of the organization is to unite wheelmen who have a knowledge of military drill into bodies of such size as to test the practicability of moving and manoeuvring large bodies of troops with the bicycle.

BOSTON, Sept. 28. -- Bishop Lawrence of the Episcopal Diocese of Massachusetts was seen to-day regarding the resolution at the Diocesan Convention in New-York yesterday of the Rev. Frank M. Glendennin calling upon Bishop Potter to instruct the delegates to the General Convention to urge that the name of the Church be changed from the Protestant Episcopal Church to something more truly descriptive of its character.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 28. -- This was the last day of the Fall exhibition of the Queens County Agricultural Society, and the attendance was fully 15,000. Everybody was in excellent humor, and the good nature prevalent even reached the politicians, and Democrats and Republicans discussed the issues of the coming campaign just as if they were all for the same ticket.

The drill season in the National Guard of New-York, with the exception of a few organizations, begins next week, and will continue until April. A very busy and profitable season can be looked forward to.

It is not known what Hendrik Hudson said about the Palisades when he sailed up and down the Hudson River, and left the indelible impress of his name upon it. But there is little doubt that his eyes lingered with admiration upon the western shore of a part of the river, long admired as one of the remarkable natural beauties of the North American Continent.
The retirement of Lieut. Gen. Schofield Sept. 29 makes Major Gen. Miles the highest officer on the active list of the army.

With two new records established over the fifth-of-a-mile track, and with the largest number of people present that was ever at the Travers Island home of the New-York Athletic Club, that club may well feel that their fifty-fifth games, held yesterday, were successful.
OGUNQUIT, Me., Sept. 28. -- "They've ketched it over to New-York, Barick, sure's you're born," remarked Mr. Larrabee to his friend Marstin.

Seldom has there been witnessed in New-York such a spectacle as that which marked the funeral, yesterday afternoon, of Major Alexander T. Smith of the Salvation Army. Funeral services were held in the army's headquarters, in Fourteenth Street, near Sixth Avenue, and about 800 soldiers of the army marched in attendance on the body through the streets.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- A dispatch received by the State Department from Minister Denby this morning shows that good progress has been made in the matter of the investigation of the Cheng-Tu riots, and that the Chinese officials have directed the necessary assistance to be given to the American Commissioners.

An unusual conflict has arisen between two United States courts of equal jurisdiction over the affairs of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company. Judge JENKINS, sitting in the United States Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin, appointed three receivers of the Northern Pacific property two years ago, and his appointments were promptly confirmed by each of the seven other Federal courts having jurisdiction over the territory traversed by the company's lines.

Assistant District Attorney Battle announced yesterday that the Grand Jury had indicted Stanley Glass, thirty years old, of 202 East Seventh Street, and M. Pearlman of 31 Montgomery Street, for swindling, on the complaint of Gustave Hammer, a merchant of 338 East Fifth Street.

The new terminal station of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge will be opened to the public this afternoon. It was expected that the station would have been opened in the latter part of July, but the delay of the elevated railroads in making their connections caused postponement.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 28. -- Charles Gore assistant cashier of The New-York Herald, who robbed that paper of $10,000 July 17, was arrested in this city this afternoon by officers from New-York. He went to the Chemical National Bank July 17 to draw money as usual, but failed to return. The Herald people at once notified the authorities of Gore's disappearance, but they were unable to find any trace of him.
The People's Party of Kings County is the first in the field to make nominations, and this is the list of candidates selected:
Many Republicans are anxious aspirants for the Mayoralty of Brooklyn. Each day finds new candidates in the field, but one after the other their little booms fade away.

The preparations for the New-York City room, which will occupy a prominent place in the Woman's Building at the Atlanta Exposition, are entirely completed, and the result promises to be a dream of beauty worthy of the efforts of the two indefatigable workers, Mrs. Joseph Bradley Read, Chairman of the Woman's Department of New-York City, and Mrs. Frank Northrop, the Vice Chairman, who have personally solicited and selected all the furnishings and decorations.

Senor Don Rafael Montoro, a leader in the Autonomist, or Home Rule, Party in Cuba, and one of its Deputies in the Spanish Cortes, arrived in this city a few days ago. His visit is devoid of any political interest. As a member of the Cuban bar, he is here in the interests of a client.
Country weddings are gaining in favor in the social world, and there will be an unusual number among society folks next month.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28. -- Philadelphia and Brooklyn played two games this afternoon, and the visitors won both by the same score -- 6 to 3. In the first, Orth was batted freely, particularly in the sixth inning, and he lost his first game since joining the Philadelphia club. The local team barely escaped a shut-out in the first contest.

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 28. -- Chief among the social attractions in Bayonne during the coming week will be the first fair of Company I of the Fourth Regiment, recently equipped and stationed here. This fair will be opened Monday night, in a tent at the corner of Avenue C and West Thirty-fourth Street.

Henry N. Pillsbury, the world's chess champion, arrived yesterday morning on the steamship New-York from England. He was met at the pier by a party of friends and members of the Brooklyn Chess Club, to which he belongs, who escorted him to his home in Brooklyn. Mr. Pillsbury is not twenty-four years old, and is smooth-shaven.

BERLIN, N.J., Sept. 28.--Farmer George Beidler lives on a farm near here, and on Wednesday night went out to look for a lost cow. While in chase of the errant cow he fell into a disused well. The well was twenty feet deep, and contained two feet of stagnant water.

SARATOGA, Sept. 28. -- The Twenty-eighth Senatorial District Democratic Convention, representing the Counties of Saratoga, Schenectady, and Washington, was held this afternoon at Ballston Spa. M.H. O'Brien of Whitehall and G.W. Marlette of Schenectady were respectively Chairman and Secretary.

Then we were ushered into a vast empty antechamber hung with tapestries, with a brazier of charcoal in the centre, where the Chamberlain presently came and chatted with my friend and the sisters who were there before us. Soon we were moved forward (like chessmen, I thought) into the audience chamber, where some nuns were kneeling in a row, and a sprinkling of bright uniforms relieved their blackness on the opposite side.

Among the badges of office that Mr. Casper Whitney has brought from the far North there is one, a pair of buffalo horns mounted on a staff. Recalling the constancy of horns as the emblem or symbol of office or indicating in the person parading horns a certain dignity, it may be remembered that the German nobility still use horns as a part of their coat of arms.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28. -- The continuation of the international cricket match here to-day was witnessed by 12,000 persons. It was another ideal day for cricket, a little warmer, if anything, than yesterday, and the big crowd thoroughly enjoyed the game.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 28. -- The firemen of Bloomfield held a picnic in Glenwood Park Wednesday evening.
" It can be done," said this energetic woman, positively, "for Polly and I did it! Actually lived decently and in order, and thrived last Winter on $7 a week for the two of us!"
PARIS, Sept. 28. -- Prof. Louis Pasteur, the distinguished chemist and discoverer of the Pasteur treatment for the cure of rabies, is dead.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 28. -- The golf tournaments of next week are attracting a great deal of attention. Every incoming boat and train brings persons interested. All the rooms in the fashionable boarding houses are engaged for the week.

The Harlem Independent Schuetzen Corps is one of the many prosperous sharpshooters' clubs of this city. The German-Americans sustain a large number of institutions -- social and benevolent -- and many literary clubs. There have been called into existence on this continent not a few secret orders by this class of citizens, and, as a rule, they are more than ordinarily succesfull.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Sept. 28. -- Hamilton Fish's ears must tingle to-day. He is being denounced on all sides by Republicans here for his conduct before the assembling of the Twenty-fourth District Republican Senatorial Convention in this city yesterday. As the inside facts come out, they put Mr. Fish in the position of attempting to bunko both Gov. Morton and the Republican leaders in Dutchess County.

The Platt Republican State machine proceeded with the good work of shutting out Brookfield Republicans from its membership at a meeting held at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. In doing so it succeeded in settling two contested districts in this city in such a way as to leave the contestants in a very ugly frame of mind.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The somewhat theatrical arrest last night of Capt. George A. Armes, a retired cavalry officer, by order of Gen. Schofield, has been the chief topic of conversation to-day among army officers and those to whom Armes is well known. He was taken from his home in the suburbs by an officer and a file of soldiers, and confined over night at Washington Barracks, an army post within the city limits.

Golfers throughout the United States, and their number has more than doubled during the last year, are all looking toward Newport this week with interest and expectancy, for there, within the next few days, will be determined the amateur golf championship or the United States. The coming tournament will begin Tuesday morning, at 10 o'clock, and in many respects will be the most important golf meeting that has ever been held in America.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Bishop John J. Keane, Rector of the Catholic University, has prepared a long letter, which he has signed, and which sets forth, on the eve of the opening of the two Faculties in McMahon Hall, the special advantages to be offered to student youth by the course of study now offered to them.

This is a story of an indignant mother, a naughty boy, and swift if perhaps untimely retribution. The mother was pushing a baby carriage along a quiet block up town, while a second child, a small youngster in abbreviated knickers, capered by her side. This "by her side" is not strictly true, for his capers were chiefly away from her, and out in the roadway, whither the parent could not follow him.

The races of the small boats for the international challenge cup have ended as most of us hoped, before Lord DUNRAVEN had shown himself so bad a loser, that the races for the America's Cup might end. That is to say, after challenger and defender had scored two races each, the odd and deciding race fell to the American boat.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Secretary Lamont has under consideration a project which, if adopted, will revolutionize the military establishment, and will be in that service the sensation of the Administration. It has been suggested to him by some of his advisers that he make the commanding General of the army a chief of staff.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- The first car will be run to-morrow over the Elmsford and White Plains Electric Railroad. The injunction issued to ex-Police Commissioner McLean of New-York restraining the railroad company from stringing its wires in front of his premises was dissolved by Justice Cullen, in Brooklyn, yesterday, and in consequence a large force of men was at work to-day completing the roadbed and the circuit of the wires.

The Westchester Racing Association is not merely content with retaining the grounds as it received them at Morris Park, but it has made substantial improvements that cost many thousands of dollars, materially adding, not only to the value of the property, but which will conduce to the enjoyment and convenience of its patrons.
LIMA via Galveston, Sept. 29. -- There have been conflicts between the Peruvians and Bolivians over the Desaguadero River, at Cojata, near the frontier.
PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Sept. 29. -- Edward Crudden, a coachman, ran for the office of Mayor eighteen months ago. He received but sixty votes, but he was greatly elated by even such a showing.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Sept. 29. -- Interest in Queens County politics will be greatly increased this week. Many of the conventions of both factions of the Democracy and the Republicans will be held, and, as the time for nominations draws near, the aspirants for political honors are particularly active.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- Although the President has not formally notified Gen. Miles of his choice as successor of Lieut. Gen. Schofield, there is little doubt that Gen. Miles will be placed in command of the army. It is understood here that several days may elapse before formal notification of Gen. Miles's advancement is forwarded to him.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 29. -- Dartmouth College has opened with an auspicious outlook. The largest freshman classs in the history of the college has just entered, numbering 135, and new acquisitions among the upper classmen will make the number 160. The Faculty is stronger than ever, and few changes have been made. President Tucker is pushing the new Dartmouth idea with more vigor than ever.
Impressive services were held yesterday at St. Matthew's English Lutheran Church, the partially erected edifice which stands at Sixth Avenue and Second Street, Brooklyn.

No hostile demonstrations seem yet to have followed the arrest of HOLLOW-HORN BEAR for his turbulence and threats against Agent WRIGHT, but as the time approaches which the malcontent Indians are alleged to have fixed for burning the agency buildings, doubtless a careful watch will be kept on them.
