WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- Secretary Herbert's reprimand of Admiral Kirkland, commanding the European squadron, it is understood, has been approved by President Cleveland, and the incident is thereby probably closed. Admiral Kirkland is an old personal friend of the Chief Executive of France, and when M. Faure was elected to the Presidency of that republic, the former wrote him a congratulatory letter, signed in his official capacity.

EUREKA, Cal., Sept. 29. -- The steamer Humboldt is on the rocks off Point Gorda and is a total wreck. A.H. Buhne and Purser Laird, who got ashore in a small boat, yesterday afternoon, have reached this city. The passengers were all taken safely to shore in lifeboats yesterday morning, probably before the first boat containing the purser and his men landed.

ALBANY, Sept. 29. -- Gov. Morton spent one day at Albany last week, and then returned to Ellerslie, where he intends to remain until the first week in October. By that time the Executive Mansion will have been delivered from the hands of the artisans who have been employed there all Summer.
The new Brooklyn terminal station of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge was opened at 12:30 o'clock P.M. yesterday. There no ceremony whatever to mark the event.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Sept. 29. -- Secretary Herbert has awarded the contract for building one of the new torpedo boats to Moran Brothers of Seattle, Washington, at their bid of $160,000. This boat is the last to be contracted for under a recent act of Congress, which provided for three sea-going torpedo boats, one to be built on the Mississippi River, one on the Atlantic Coast and one on the Pacific Slope.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29. -- The International Navigation Company's new steamship St. Paul left Cramps' shipyard, Philadelphia, this morning at 7:10 o'clock for her trial trip, and made the run of forty miles to Reedy Island in four hours. When the vessel arrived there anchor was dropped to await the high tide.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 29 -- An agent of the Cuban revolutionists in Catawba County attempting to enlist a company of men to go to Cuba. He has offered a commission as a Lieutenant and makes other liberal propositions. Not one man has been found who will enlist. Efforts made at other points an North Carolina to secure recruits have likewise failed, though there is general sympathy for the Cubans.

TAMMANY HALL, Sept. 16, 1895. At a meeting of the said committee, held at Tammany Hall on the 13th day of September, 1895, the following call and resolutions for the election of delegates to the several nominating conventions, reported from the Committee on Organization, were read, unanimously adopted, and ordered to be published:

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 29, -- Every department of Yale University is now in full blast, except the Medical and Art Schools, and these will be opened in a few days. President Dwight and his family returned from Litchfield, Conn., the day before the University opened and the President presided over the exercises in Battell Chapel Thursday morning, when the university formally resumed its work for the present term.

A subject that has engaged the attention of naval experts for a number of years is the testing of naval vessels in advance of their construction. Experimental tanks, as they are called, have been established in almost every country in Europe, in which the models of both war and commerce ships are subjected to preliminary trials as to their speed, stability, friction, and turning qualities, before the work of actual construction is begun.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- There were several additions to the animal population at the National Zoological Park last week. A lioness gave birth to four whelps, a kangaroo brought forth a baby jumper, and a lot of new rattlesnakes came into the world. The birth of the rattlers is said to be the first case of the kind known in captivity.

The interest that is being manifested by the people of this city in relation to the observance of Sunday, the enforcement of law, and the subject of local option has become so general that many are calling upon the pulpit for an outspoken declaration of what their religious leaders think and advise in relation to those matters.

WALTHAM, Mass., Sept. 29. -- Two new world's records were made on the Waltham cycle track yesterday afternoon. "Eddie" McDuffee of Malden and "Nat" Butler of Boston, always the bitterest of rivals, mounted the same tandem twice and pushed it faster each time than a similar wheel ever before had gone under the conditions.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 29 -- Count Celestino Olozaga of bowling fame won the ten-mile club handicap road race of the Atalanta Wheelmen, which took place over the Elizabeth-Springfield course yesterday afternoon. The road was in very bad condition in several places, where repair were being made, and the contestants were obliged to pedal through loose, cracked stone for some distance.

The English athletes will leave for Canada to-morrow, where they will Compete in the Canadian championships, which are to be held Oct. 5. A parting dinner and reception will be tendered the London men to-night in the gymnasium of the New-York Athletic Club. The start is to be made on Tuesday in order to give the visitors a chance to visit Niagara Falls.

ST. JOSEPH, Mich., Sept. 29. -- The storm which has raged here since Saturday morning has as yet abated but little. No steamers have left here since Friday night, and much fruit is now lying on the docks awaiting transportation.

William C. Redfield, President of the League of Loyal Citizens, an organization opposed to consolidation, called on Mayor Schieren Saturday, and had an interview with him on the subject of the tax rate. Mayor Schieren has publicly stated that, as Mayor of Brooklyn, he was opposed to consolidation, but that as a New-York leather merchant he was for consolidation.
What, rum sold in Herkimer? And on Sunday, with doors wide open, and all day long? Oh, Warner, Warner, you stay in New-York too much! They need you at home to "maintain" the Sunday law.

With such inviting conditions as prevailed yesterday, it is little wonder that almost everybody who has mastered the art of cycling went a wheeling. A close observer who pedaled on Riverside Drive, the Boulevard, and in Central Park, said he never before saw so many cyclists enjoying the favorite pastime on Manhattan Island.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 29. -- The Manhattan Bicycle Club of New-York held its annual races on the Crescent Oval yesterday. They afforded a good afternoon's sport for the members. The weather could not have been more favorable. The most exciting of the races was the half-mile scratch. The finish was close between Oatman, Staubach, and Bartsch, Oatman winning after a hard struggle.

Major Gen. Nelson A. Miles was notified last week by Secretary Lamont that he would succeed, as Commander of the United States Army, Lieut. Gen. John M. Schofield, whose term of office expired yesterday through age limitation.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- Instruction for the twenty-seventh year at Cornell University began Thursday. Entrance examinations commenced on the 18th, and since then new and old students have been flocking here in larger numbers than ever before. The registration of freshmen has already passed the 550 mark, and the prospects are that the entering class will reach 650.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29. -- Fifty men, armed with rifles and revolvers, were guarding all last night the receiving vault in Oakwood Cemetery, as a mob of colored men was expected hourly to storm the cemetery gates and break in the vault in order to get possession of the body of Thomas Holbrook.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 29. -- The increasing ability of American manufacturers to compete successfully in the markets of the Old World has just been demonstrated by the Baldwin Locomotive Works of this city, whose managers are rejoicing in a large contract for engines for Russian railroads.

The extract from a letter said to have been written home by Charles A. Bradley, the 100-yard sprinter of the London Athletic Club, on the eve of the games, which was published in the cable dispatches from London yesterday, caused considerable amusement at the New-York Athletic Club and wherever else the result of the international games was discussed.

BERLIN, Sept. 29. -- The prolonged stay in Berlin of M. de Witte, the Russian Minister of Finance, simultaneously with the visit to the German capital of an agent of the Bank of St. Petersburg, has given the appearance of truth to reports that Russia is endeavoring to induce Germany to participate in her politico-financial projects in China.

A case, which the law records of fifty years show to be unprecedented, comes up this morning in the Superior Court, before Judge Dugro, when Mary Bough will be called on to show cause why an injunction granted by Judge McAdam Saturday night, restraining her from burying the body of her brother, George Bough, until further order of the court, should not be made permanent.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 29. -- Arizona Charley, the cowboy who participated in the Cripple Creek bullfights, came to grief in Denver to-day. He had advertised a wild-west show to be concluded by a genuine bullfight, and a large crowd assembled at the Denver Wheel Club grounds to witness the exhibition. Humane Agent Thompson entered the ring just as the bullfight began, and the crowd, seeing him, began to hoot and yell.

BELLEFONTE, Penn., Sept. 29. -- The bright outlook in the iron industry, which is an important factor in the prosperity of Central Pennsylvania, has brought out some interesting figures from J.W. Gephart. He is Superintendent of the Valentine Iron Company and Superintendent of the Central Railroad of Pennsylvania. Until recently he was ex-Gov. Beaver's law partner.

Everything is ready for the normal reopening of the New Manhattan Athletic Clubhouse to-night. Painters, decorators, and other artisans have completed the work of rebeautifying the "Cherry Diamond" Palace.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- Law officers of the Government are interested in a rumor which was printed last week, to the effect that the Southern Pacific Railroad Company had notified the Union Pacific Railroad Company that after November it would refuse to run trains from Ogden to the Pacific coast in connection with the Union Pacific trains, thus practically shutting out the latter from Pacific coast business.
It looks as if the Good Government Clubs would meet to-night and adjourn after appointing a conference committee to arrange nominations for the county and judicial ticket.

PRINCETON N.J., Sept. 29. -- The usual game between the 'Varsity and scrub football teams was played yesterday. A hard practice of twenty minutes was given the men, and one touch-down was made by the first eleven by Rosengarten, '97. The general play was the poorest seen here this season, the 'Varsity falling to gain repeatedly. Fumbles were frequent, and the whole game was characterized by loose work.

Prof. Alexander Graham Bell, the inventor, who has been in France and Belgium four weeks, returned to this city yesterday on the French Line steamship La Bourgogne, and is staying at the Gilsey House.

Investigation is being made by the Fire Marshal to determine the cause of a fire at 1:45 o'clock yesterday morning at 691 Columbus Avenue. The building is only two doors from the Colonial Bank building, which was burned last Spring in one of the many fires on the west side which were feared to be incendiary.

LYONS, Sept. 29. -- The Wayne County Republican Convention was held at the Court House here yesterday. There was a lively contest for the nomination for Superintendent of the Poor between Melvin P. Gates of Ontario, the present Superintendent; J.D. Reeves of Newark, and L.D. Wood of Savannah, but Gates had the backing of the county machine, and received a large majority on the first ballot.

Not much liquor was sold yesterday in this city. Some saloons were open, but they did business on the sly, and the receipts could hardly have been sufficient to make it a profitable experiment. Several saloon keepers who ventured to defy the police were caught, and others, against whom positive evidence could not be obtained, had their places under constant surveillance by policemen who prevented would-be customers from entering.

Sir Augustus Harris's company, which is to present "Hansel and Gretel" at Daly's Theatre next week, sailed from Liverpool on the Aurania last Wednesday, and should arrive here next Wednesday. Sir Augustus Harris, who is coming over to rehearse the opera, sailed on the Lucania Saturday, and is due here next Friday.

The facts in relation to the escape and subsequent recapture of two military prisoners from Castle William, the military prison on Governors Island, came to light yesterday. The escape was made a week ago, but the statements of the men themselves were not made public until yesterday.
There was an invigorating Fall crispness in the air Saturday, and the botanists, after their weekly field meeting, returned home laden with Autumn spoils.

The modest, manly, and really affecting little speech made by the Duke of CAMBRIDGE in Edinburgh on Thursday will doubtless go far toward disarming all the personal hostility to him, in or out of the British Army, that had not already been disarmed by his retirement from the chief command.
There does not seem to be the least change in the local Democratic situation in Brooklyn concerning the nominees for Mayor and District Attorney.
HERKIMER, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- Sunday in some parts of Herkimer County, which is the home of Warner Miller, is a lively sort of day.

William Steinfort, eighteen years old, and his brother Gerry, a nine-year-old pupil of the public schools, were drowned in the North River at One Hundred and Fifty-second Street yesterday morning when the rowers of nearly a dozen boats were almost ready to rescue them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29.--Consul General Jernigan, stationed at Shanghai, reports to the Department of State that a cotton mill under British management will soon be erected at Shanghai. The erection of the mill was made possible by the treaty of peace between China and Japan. The announcement of the prospectus for the first cotton mill was greeted with applause when announced in the Shanghai Chamber of Commerce.
LONDON, Sept. 29. -- Lord Lamington has been appointed Governor of Queensland.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Sept. 29. -- Hugh Hart, a dockbuilder, living at Blissville, was assaulted near the entrance to the Thirty-fourth Street Ferry in this city at 3 o'clock this morning by four men. One of the men stole Hart's watch, valued at $300, and succeeded in making his escape.

ANNAPOLIS, Sept. 29. -- The list of the new fourth class, Naval Academy, is now complete. It includes all the cadets admitted at the May and September examinations. The class is quite large, and the instructors consider it made up of an unusually good set of youths.

HILLSDALE, N.J., Sept. 29. -- The theatrical entertainment and charity ball held last night at Wildhurst, the country residence of Walter Stanton, the New-York banker, was a novel social affair. Mr. Stanton's villa, which is one of the largest and handsomest in Bergen County, is on Woodcliffe Heights, overlooking the Pascack Valley.

In the absence of any definite statement by Lord SALISBURY or Prince LOBANOFF as to their intentions in regard to Turkey, the press of England, Europe, and this country is engaged in marking out the plan which it is supposed will be adopted. In general this plan is very simple.
A well-known New-Yorker who has studied and followed athletics for many years takes the following view of the Yale-Cambridge meeting, which will take place at Manhattan Field Saturday, Oct. 5:

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 29. -- Mrs. Calvin S. Brice gave a luncheon to-day in honor of Sir Julian Pauncefote, the British Ambassador, whose chief secretary, H.O. Bax-Ironsides, also was present. Senator Brice, who is at his home over Sunday, assisted Mrs. Brice in doing the honors of the occasion.

The two concerts given by Mr. Neuendorff at Madison Square Garden, of which the second took place last night, did not excite a large amount of popular enthusiasm. This was probably expected by most persons conversant with musical matters in this city. It is a little too early in the season to hope for large audiences anywhere, and the Wagner caldron is certainly not yet boiling.

MARQUETTE, Mich., Sept. 29. -- The barge Kershaw, together with the schooners Moonlight and Kent, which she had in tow, were beached this morning at 3 o'clock. The Kershaw and her consorts were making harbor safely when a steampipe broke, and the boats were at the mercy of the heavy seas and strong wind which were prevailing.

We printed yesterday an interview on Cuban affairs with Senor MONTORO, a leader of the Autonomist or Home Rule Party in the unhappy island. We regret that it should have turned out to be of so unsatisfactory and uninforming a character. Unquestionably, in the opinion of intelligent American observers, a substantial and progressive home rule for Cuba must seem the most promising and humane solution of the problem there presented.

WILLET'S POINT, L.I., Sept. 29. -- A large crowd gathered here to-day and witnessed the opening of the football season. The game was between the United States Engineers and the Catholic Club team of Paterson, N.J. Although the Catholic Club made a strong effort, it cannot be said that the game was exciting, as the home team had everything its own way from the start.

" Christian Stratagem" is the title of the sermon which the Rev. T. De Witt Talmage has prepared for THE NEW-YORK TIMES this week. In it Dr. Talmage discusses a subject which is of special interest to Sunday school teachers and scholars, being Gideon's battle with the Midianites near Mount Gilboa.

Mirecourt is, says our Paris correspondent, the centre of the cushion, lace, and embroidery industry of the Vosges. The five arches of triumph under which the President drove there on Wednesday were decorated with lace embroidery trophies. When the Empress Eugenie went to Nancy in 1866 to celebrate the anniversary of the annexation of Lorraine to France, she accepted there some presents of beautiful Vosges hand-embroidery, and made it fashionable.
AMSTERDAM, Sept. 30. -- The Democratic Senatorial Convention for the Twenty-seventh District was held in this city this afternoon. Ex-State Senator Edward Wemple presided.

Two Chicago wheelmen will start from the City Hall to-day on the longest record ride of the year. San Francisco is their destination, and, if they win, their time must be better than forty-eight days and eighteen hours.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 30. -- The Asbury Park Wheelmen's second century run to Trenton and return is scheduled for to-morrow. Over 100 wheelmen from this place will participate, together with delegations from Red Bank, Long Branch, Ocean Grove, Belmar, Manasquan, and Freehold.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 30. -- The alarming spread of diphtheria in this city has called the attention of the Indianapolis Health Department to a serious state of affairs arising from the practices of the Christian Scientists. In some cases Sanitarian Wynn has been refused admission to homes where children were dying and no effort was being made to save them except by faith doctors, who knelt at the bedside and prayed until life had departed.

The semi-annual session of the New-York Presbytery was held yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street. The Rev. Dr. Jesse F. Forbes of the Adams Memorial Church was re-elected Moderator. The Rev. Thomas Douglass was chosen temporary Clerk.

Gen. E.P. Alexander, a well-known resident of North Carolina, has recently written an open letter to Mr. Henry B. King of the same State, in which he expresses himself very forcibly as against the free coinage of silver. He says among other things: "A very considerable part of my small means is invested in silver mines in Colorado and Mexico.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Sept. 30. -- A premature explosion occurred in a rock quarry seven miles northeast of this place at 6 o'clock last night, five men and a boy losing their lives. The dead are:

The British, it seems, have been entirely successful in obtaining from China all the redress of which the case admitted for the massacre of British missionaries. In doing this they have also rendered a substantial service to civilization and have furnished an excellent example for our own Government to follow.

Col. JOHN R. FELLOWS sees fit to assume an attitude of gay and jaunty defiance in the face of the arraignment that Magistrate JEROME has made of him. The Magistrate's arraignment is sober, well considered, well fortified. He charges the District Attorney with nullifying, by his neglect to do his sworn duty, the efforts of the Police Commissioners and of the Police Magistrates to enforce the law in this city.

Unexpected and unreasonable vexation is betrayed by Republican newspapers in the State over the adoption by the Democrats of the resolution expressing sympathy with the Cubans in their struggle for independence. The only consolation to these critics, who know that the Republicans said nothing on the subject, is that the resolution is not a part of the platform.

The sale of the library of the late William Berrian was begun yesterday by Bangs Co., and will continue for four days more. A large number of buyers were present at the sale, and fair values were generally obtained. Some of the prices were:
PANAMA, via Galveston, Sept. 30. -- Gen. Casablanca intended to leave the Isthmus Tuesday, but postpones his departure in obedience to official advices from Bogota.

Mr. Fidel G. Pierra, a prominent Cuban, who is well known in the commercial world in this city, was asked yesterday by a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES for his opinion of the statements made by Senor Rafael Montoro concerning the present troubles in Cuba in an interview published in the Sunday issue of THE TIMES.

We very particularly commend to Mr. WARNER MILLER the description which appeared in yesterday's TIMES of the "American Sunday" as observed in the town of his residence. Mr. MILLER sees no reason why the Sunday habits of the cosmopolitan population of New-York should be allowed in any way to vary from the pious customs of the native and semi-rural population of Herkimer.

CORNING, Sept. 30. -- The Republican Senatorial Convention in the Forty-first District reconvened in this city to-day, having adjourned from Bath last Thursday. After being in session all the afternoon, the convention adjourned until to-morrow morning. Two hundred and fifty-two ballots have been taken, and every one has resulted in six votes each for William H. Nichols of Bath, Franklin D. Sherwood of Hornellsville, and John S. Sheppard of Penn Yan.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- The Civic Federation of this city has been engaged since last June in affording an object lesson in street cleaning that cannot fail to be of interest to New-York. Especially will Commissioner Waring find the Chicago experiment of interest in connection with his recent crusade against the wanton littering of streets by citizens.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- The Government has received information that China has yielded to the pressure of the British ultimatum, by degrading the Viceroy of Sze-Chuen, and according in full the other demands of Great Britain.

ELIZABETH, Sept. 30. -- Signs of returning industrial and business prosperity are beginning to increase here. The announcement is made to-day that an English syndicate has leased Postmaster Sheridan's large factory on South Broad Street for five years, and will manufacture paper boxes. The plant has been idle nearly two years.

Whether Frederick D. Tuthill, Assistant Dairy Commissioner, watered the milk which he sold to Adam Heppenheimer, on Sept. 24; whether the milk was watered on its way over the Chambers Street ferry, or whether the officers of the Health Board of this city made a mistake in their analysis of the milk, is a question the Justices of Special Sessions may have to decide tomorrow.

There was little interest taken in the baseball match at the Polo Grounds yesterday between the New-York and Baltimore clubs, owing to the fact that Saturday's game settled the League championship. There were less than 500 people present, and slight attention was paid to the game.
An exciting convention for the nomination of Republican candidates for the Supreme Court was held in the Kings County Court House, Brooklyn yesterday.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 30. -- Henry O. Tallmadge, Secretary of the Golf Association, arrived to-day, and, assisted by Winthrop Rutherford and H. Mortimer Brooks, of the Green Committee of the Newport Golf Club, they drew the pairings for the amateur tournament to be begun to-morrow. A score or more of golfers also came in to-day, and all are here to-night.

The suffrage provision has not yet been submitted in any final form before the Constitutional Convention of South Carolina, but the reported conclusions of the committee having it in charge have been stated in this peculiar language: "A modified Mississippi scheme, with a loophole for a limited time, and a straight educational qualification, with a property qualification after the first registration of voters."
The New-York Baptist ministers held their weekly meeting yesterday at 149 Fifth Avenue. There was a large attendance. The Rev. Dr. Halsey Moore presided.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 30. -- The Cambridge athletes, who have been in this city at practice on the Yale field since Sept. 6, and who are to meet the Yale athletic track team in New-York on Oct. 5, bade good-bye to New-Haven and the Yale men this afternoon, and left for New-York City, where they will continue their practice at Berkeley Oval until the day of the meet.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30. -- Already calculations are being made for Durrant's safety, should the verdict of the jury be unsatisfactory to a portion of the community. It is believed that unless he should be convicted, an attempt at violence will be made. Everything will be ready to meet such an emergency, should it arise.

A special meeting of the Association of Medical Officers of the National Guard and Naval Militia of the State of New-York was held in the armory, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue, yesterday afternoon to take steps toward a separate organization of the Hospital Corps and the submission of a plan with that end in view to the next Legislature. Gen. M.O. Terry presided, and Lieut. Daniel S. Burr of Binghamton acted as Secretary.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- The Grand Jury of the District concluded its labors to-day, and was discharged. A recommendation, in its final report, that the whipping-post be established in the district for the punishment of wife-beaters and petty thieves created much surprise, not to say astonishment. It was signed by sixteen members of the Grand Jury, and reads as follows:
One of the most noteworthy events of the new college year is the publication of the University Hymnbook for the Appleton Chapel services. The plan of the book is best set forth in the preface:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- The case of Capt. G.A. Armes, the retired army officer who was so sensationally arrested by Gen. Schofield, grows in interest. The occurrence is for a time before the civil courts, and later in the week it will be decided whether the arrest of Capt. Armes was legal.

ALBANY, Sept. 30. -- The moves in the political field in this county to-day indicate that the Democrats will make a most excellent showing this Fall. The Democrats harmonized their differences and the Republicans placed in nomination an exceedingly weak lot of nominees for county officers, which, with the flimsy city ticket named last week, cannot possibly make any kind of a showing against the natural Democratic majority in the city and county.

Never before in the history of piscatorial sport on the Potomac River has there been known such a wonderful run of black bass as that now in progress, and which has been delighting the votaries of live bait and flies for the last three weeks. From Sycamore Island, below Great Falls, up to Harper's Ferry has been the favorite water during this time for the gamest fish that swims, and it is yet.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--The following order announcing officially to the army the retirement from active service of Lieut. Gen. John M. Schofield was published today:

At a recent meeting of the Board of Directors of the Oregon Improvement Company, it was decided to default on the October interest on the consolidated second mortgage 5 per cent. bonds, which issue amounts to $6,468,000. A resolution was adopted declaring the payment of the said interest at this time would be inexpedient and impolitic, as the money would have to be borrowed.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 30. -- Cottagers in large numbers attended the auction to-day of the estate of Harriet N. Pond of New-York on Ridge Road. It contains about sixteen acres of land, with a cottage and other buildings, used a year ago by the Golf Club. The larger portion, a little more than ten acres, fronts on the ocean, opposite the Dumplings, and affords an excellent site for a Summer residence.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 30. -- Soft-voiced sons of the Spanish Americas form a prominent part of the foreign contingent in Atlanta these days, and the President of the exposition company proudly wears in the button of his coat the emblem of "Busto del Liberador." Pan-Americanism is the central theme of the South's great show -- the idea around which the exposition movement has been formed.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30. -- The case of Charles H. Jones, editor and manager of The Post-Dispatch, against the Pulitzer Publishing Company, wherein the latter was temporarily enjoined from interfering with the former's management of the paper or deposing him from his position, came up for final hearing to-day before Circuit Court Judge Wood.

There was a case of highway robbery in the City Hall Park last Thursday night at 9 o'clock, and when the victim reported it to Acting Sergt. James J. Cullen, who was at the desk in the police station in the basement of the City Hall, he was astounded to hear Cullen say: "It might occur here every night."
BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- It looks tonight as if the factions of the Democratic Party in Erie County will get together within a few days and make one of its old-time fights against the Republicans.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Dr. William T. Harris, United States Commissioner of Education, to-day made public his fifth annual report, covering the school year ended Nov. 30, 1893. It comprises three parts, the first of which is devoted to statistics.
The will of John D. Jones, late President of the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company, was filed yesterday in the Surrogate's office.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 30. -- The relation of the shipbuilding industry on lake and ocean to the proposed ship canal from lake to ocean furnished one of the most fruitful topics among the many discussed in the International Deep Waterways Convention, which adjourned here Friday. The discussion developed many interesting facts that will be new to the great majority of readers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- Surrounded by patriotic mottoes, with the American flag as a background, the Declaration of Independence as a textbook, and the spirit of liberty as an inspiration, 4,600 persons yelled themselves hoarse to-night in the cause of Cuban independence. There could scarcely have been more enthusiasm had the meeting been held in Cuba itself.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 30. -- The reorganization of the Democratic Party in New-Jersey is now in progress. The first step was taken at the Democratic Convention held last Thursday, when, with a great deal of unanimity, a resolution was passed changing the basis of representation in the State Committee.
The trial of Capt. William Strauss of the East Sixty-seventh Street Station, on charges growing out of the Cherokee Club trouble, was continued before President Roosevelt at Headquarters yesterday.

ORANGE, N.J. Sept. 30. -- The Maplewood and South Orange Railway Company will begin the operation of its new electric fine between South Orange and Tremont Avenues to-morrow. The power is to be furnished by the Suburban Traction Company, with which the new company will also have a traffic arrangement.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Sept. 30. -- William Hunt of this city was arraigned before Police Justice Duffy this morning, charged with abducting Edna Applegate, six years old, of 310 Fifty-third Street, Brooklyn. The complainant was the child's mother, and the charge grew out of an advertisement in a New-York newspaper offering an infant for adoption.

MONDAY -- P.M. Speculation to-day was extremely narrow and was almost entirely professional. There were no developments of an unfavorable character, but traders were disposed to regard a reaction as likely, and they governed themselves accordingly.

At auction in the Trinity Building salesroom yesterday, Mr. Peter F. Meyer sold, under foreclosure, at $29,500, to J.G.C. Hupfel, the five-story brick flat, with stores, 1,789 Amsterdam Avenue, east side, 74.11 feet south of One Hundred and Forty-ninth Street, 25 by 100.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 30. -- Allan L. McDermott to-day applied to Judge Hudspeth for an order requiring Edward W. Woolley, City Clerk of Jersey City, to publish the precinct lines of the new wards, as required by law. He said that the plan devised by Mr. Woolley of putting up two notices at each polling place was not in accordance with the law, nor with the public need.

Railway traffic has been increasing steadily since the first of the month just closed, and, with a few exceptions, the railroad companies are enjoying a degree of financial prosperity such as they have not known within the last two years. The earnings of nearly all of the Western roads show important increases, as compared with the same period last year.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 30. -- The question of Sunday opening was settled by an overwhelming vote at the Directors' meeting on the exposition grounds this afternoon. There was a full meeting of the board, and Mr. Cabaniss, manager of The Atlanta Journal, moved that the grounds be opened and the Midway closed on Sundays.
Mrs. Irene A. Fleet alleges that the late Timothy C. Cronin, a well-known lawyer, did not account to her for large sums of money collected by him while acting in the capacity of her counsel.

HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- A letter from a historical society in Albany to Assemblyman Louis F. Goodsell in relation to the skeleton of a supposed Hessian soldier who was killed over 100 years ago at the battle of Sinnipink, one of the outposts of Fort Montgomery, came here in this morning's mail.

Now is the season when cycling, if not the sport of kings, is, for a month at least, the king of sports. At no other time can the wheelman find so much virtue in his steed as in the Fall. Now the roads are at their best: the air is cool and more charged with ozone, inciting zest, and nature reveals her golden glories. This preeminently is the time for touring.

The Board of Aldermen met in special session yesterday and reapportioned the Thirteenth Senate District under the order of the Supreme Court, contained in the recent decision of Judge Beekman. The Aldermen were called to order at 10:30 A.M., and took a recess until 1:30 P.M. after referring the matter to the Committee on County Affairs.

The New-York Athletic Club tendered a dinner to the members of the London Athletic Club team last evening. It was a thoroughly informal affair, and very enjoyable to all concerned. The tables were spread in the gymnasium of the Fifty-fifth Street clubhouse, which was elaborately decorated for the occasion.

Mrs. William Trenholm, known on the stage as Alice Hood, was examined in supplementary proceedings yesterday by Herbert A. Heyn, counsel for Mrs. Catherine D. Lynch, who obtained a judgment against her last July in the City Court for $1,528.

Democratic harmony in Brooklyn has been effectually and honorably accomplished. The party now stands united on a platform which appeals not only to all classes of Democrats, but to all sorts and conditions of honest and patriotic citizens.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 30. -- An old-time county fair was opened here to-day under the auspices of the Society of Agriculture and Horticulture of Westchester County, and under circumstances which promise to make it very successful.

While the body of George Bough was on its way to Calvary Cemetery yesterday, escorted by a long train of mourners, the woman who insists that she is his widow was being carried from Judge Dugro's courtroom in a dead faint.

BUFFALO, Sept. 30.--The Democratic Senatorial Convention for the Forty-fifth District was held at Niagara Falls to-day. Judge David Millar of Lockport was nominated by acclamation for Senator. The district comprises the counties of Niagara, Orleans, and Genesee. Judge Millar carried Niagara County, which is the largest of the three, two years ago, when he was elected County Judge.

Several business men and bankers in Chicago are reported as criticising sharply the policy of the United States in regard to light gold coin, which has come from abrasion to be below the standard in weight.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Sept. 30. -- The Democratic Senatorial Convention for the Twenty-fourth District, comprising the Counties of Columbia, Dutchess, and Putnam, was held at the Court House, in this city, to-day. The convention was called to order by James W. Hinkley, a member of the Senatorial Committee, and Chairman of the Democratic State Committee.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 30. -- "The Wizard of the Nile" was produced here to-night by Frank Daniels and his company before a large audience, which was vigorous in its applause of the musical numbers. It is apparently a popular success.

OYSTER BAY, D.I., Sept. 30. -- The Democratic Senatorial Convention for the Second District, which is Queens County, will meet at Jamaica next Thursday morning. From present indications, it will nominate Edward N. Townsend of Oyster Bay. Mr. Townsend is admitted to be a very strong man politically in Queens County.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--Ex-Senator William Mahone had a slight stroke of paralysis this morning. He has been stopping at Chamberlain's Hotel, and this morning his son, Butler Mahone, calling at his father's room, found the General still in bed and apparently very drowsy. Not suspecting anything wrong.

Unless the blunder committed last night by the adjourned convention of the Good Government Clubs can be in some way corrected, the clubs will play but a minor and not very creditable part in city politics this Fall. There were several mistakes the clubs might have made, but easily the worst was the nomination on their own hook of such a ticket as their convention put forth last night.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 30. -- The Democratic Justice Convention for the Seventh District was held here to-day. Benjamin Franklin of over Smaoc County, was Chairman and Ira L. Ward of Pittsford and George L. Krein of Dansville secretaries.

Mrs. M. Tyms of 413 First Avenue went out July 5 to do some shopping. She returned to find her flat broken open and two men ransacking her bedroom. They rushed for the staircase, and she attempted to hold one of them. He knocked her down. Both men made their escape. Mrs. Tyms found that they had taken $70 in money and a quantity of jewelry.
The City Magistrates held their monthly meeting last night in the Jefferson Market Police Court. There was a full attendance. Magistrate Flammer presided.

HERKIMER, Sept. 30. -- The showing in THE NEW-YORK TIMES this morning of the possibilities of securing a drink of liquor at licensed saloons and hotels in this county may have been a surprize to some of the good people who do not want drink on Sunday.

Justice Jerome of the Court of Special Sessions yesterday read a formal statement from the bench, charging the District Attorney's office with neglecting to prosecute excise cases in such a manner as to keep up the work of the Police Board in enforcing the laws. The Justice directed his address to Assistant District Attorney Berliner, who is prosecutor in the Court of Special Sessions.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The debt statement issued this afternoon shows a net decrease in the public debt, less cash in the Treasury, during September, of $1,834,686,42.

The cricketers of New-York of Irish and Scotch birth had a great contest yesterday on the grounds of the St. George Cricket Club, Hoboken, and, as on the previous occasion upon which they met, the Irishmen proved victorious by a margin of 33 runs.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The last weekly weather crop report for the season of 1895 was issued to-day by the Weather Bureau. It contains the following information:

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1. -- In the course of the Durrant murder trial to-day, a threat to hang a juryman was brought to the Court's attention. As a result of the threat against the jury, H.J. McCoy, Secretary of the Young Men's Christian Association, will be cited for contempt of court Thursday, and Judge Murphy has intimated that his punishment will be severe.
SHANGHAI, Oct. 1. -- Admiral Buller, Commander in Chief of the British fleet in Chinese waters, has arrived here on board the dispatch boat Alacrity.

A clever young woman has been posing for some time in New-York as Mrs. Theodore Sutro of 20 Fifth Avenue, also as her daughter Ethel, and again as the daughter of Theodore Sutro's brother, E.S. Sutro of 60 West Forty-ninth Street.
Some of the men who were most active in the Committee of Seventy last year sharply criticised yesterday, the action of the Good Government Clubs in nominating a ticket of their own Monday night.

PARIS, Oct. 1. -- The body of Prof. Louis Pasteur was placed in a coffin at his late residence, at Garches, at 2 o'clock this afternoon. Mme. Pasteur wept profusely while the Abbe Angely read prayers over the body.

Bostwick proved a rather easy winner in the final match in the scratch singles of the West the Tennis Club yesterday at Central Park West and Eighty-ninth Street. He lost only one set to Crowninshield. Bostwick will play Fischer. The club champion, on Thursday. His prospects of victory re rather small.
Trouble lies straight ahead for District Attorney John R. Fellows unless he changes his tactics in regard to the excise violations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Bids were opened at the Navy Department to-day for the construction of six composite gunboats, authorized by the last Naval Appropriation bill. The act limited the cost of the vessels to $230,000 each, and provided that not more than two of them should be built by any one firm.

The ingenious Mr. LABOUCHERE, in the latest issue of his amusing paper, devotes an article to "Yankee Yachting," which is mainly noteworthy for the new evidence it affords that some British publicists care no more what they say about the United States than if we were a Central African tribe, who could not read English and could be lied about with complete impunity.

Prof. L.L. Dyche, who went on the Peary rescue party as an agent for the American Museum of Natural History, and Mathew Henson, Lieut. Peary's colored servant, arrived here yesterday on the Red Cross steamship Sylvia, from Halifax. They brought with them a large number of museum specimens of arctic animals, minerals, and meteorites.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 1. -- The Democratic State Convention will be held here to-morrow, and large numbers of delegates have already arrived. It is believed George Fred Williams will be nominated for Governor without opposition.

ALBANY, Oct. 1. -- The ten railroad corporations operating the 423 miles of railroads, surface and elevated, on Manhattan Island and in the annexed district, do not show as good returns for 1895 as they did the previous year. The reason seems to have been beyond the control of the corporations, however, for the passengers did not present themselves with their five cent fares as during the twelve months ending June 30, 1894.

The cause of the bootblacks and that of the news-stand owners was championed yesterday afternoon in the Board of Aldermen, and, as a result, they will not have their property seized and be driven out of business.

The tenth annual fair of the Westchester County Agricultural Society was opened yesterday on the fair grounds at White Plains. A representative crowd of farmers and their friends gathered to admire the fine stock and fruits and vegetables exhibited.

TUESDAY -- P.M. Further weakness in the foreign exchange market was the interesting feature of the day. Rates are now well below the normal gold-shipping point, and, as the supply of bills in the market has increased to an amount sufficient to meet all ordinary demands for a fortnight, it may fairly be said that the outward movement of gold has ceased for the year.

The last attempt of the old Board of Police Justices, which was legislated out of office by the last Legislature, to upset, on constitutional grounds, the act that cut short their official careers, has failed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The Catholic University of America to-day signalized its admission of lay students and the inauguration of two new lay Faculties by the dedication of the McMahon Hall of Philosophy, a magnificent new building, which will form the nucleus of the extension of educational advantages which the university will afford.

Not much has yet been said regarding the holding of next year's National bicycle race meet at some point in the Empire State, but in due time the New-York Division will make itself heard in the matter. Toledo and Louisville have both gone to work to secure the prize, and one is making as much noise as the other, which is a good deal, to say the least.

Street car mail service was begun in this city yesterday at 5 o'clock in the morning, when a gaudily painted car was started over the Third Avenue cable road. The first day's trips were an unqualified success. There were no hitches, and the delivery of mail was greatly facilitated. Half-hourly trips north and south were made throughout the day, and that time schedule will be maintained for the present.

FLUSHING, L.I., Oct. 1. -- The twenty-eight-foot sloop yacht Osprey of Bayside, with a party of young men of this village on board, was driven on a bar at Sands Point last night. William Annis, the owner of the yacht, with a party of guests, including Charles Lewis, Samuel Dummer, Frank Travis, Walter Scott, and Joseph Mangles, left Bayside yesterday morning for a cruise up the Sound.

About the only issue in the State canvass in Iowa seems to be that of regulating the sale of liquor, and it is presented in such a way that there would appear to most people in this part of the world to be only one side to it.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 1. -- The most serious allegations ever made against the officials of an insurance company in this city are contained in the findings of Judge George Wheeler of the Superior Court of this State in the case of Dr. Austin Fuller of this city vs. the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company of New-York.
The Tammany men are hard at work. They have mapped out their policy in the campaign, so far as the city, county, and judiciary tickets are concerned, and they are going right ahead with their work.
There was the sound of a volume of song coming from the schoolroom of the beautiful new Five Points Mission Building, at Paradise Park, yesterday afternoon.

AUSTIN, Texas, Oct. 1. -- The members of the Legislature, which has been called in special session to pass an anti-prizefighting bill, have been arriving singly and in groups for the past twenty-four hours.

Mrs. Lizzie Erb, the young wife of a timekeeper on the Broadway cable road, was burned to death, and her bed-ridden mother was badly scorched in a fire in the big five-story tenement, 294 Henry Street, last night.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 1. -- Capt. Lea of the Princeton 'Varsity eleven to-day posted the names of the men who will be taken to the training table to-morrow. Of the sixty or more men who have been trying for the team for the present only twenty-nine are taken to the tables, six going to the 'Varsity table at the Osborn Clubhouse and twenty-three remaining at the scrub table at Struves.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 1. -- Among the indictments returned by the Grand Jury in the common pleas division of the Supreme Court to-day, was one against David F. Lingane for assault with a dangerous weapon on Osceola Cook. Lingane is the editor of a local paper, and the indictment was the outcome of a street row between him and Cook, who is a colored man, in which Lingane shot Cook.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 1. - Chancellor McGill was formally notified to-day of his nomination for Governor by the Democratic Convention which met at Trenton Sept. 26.

Mr. Newbigging agrees with the majority of literary men rather than with Rousseau in his estimate of the value and usefulness of fables. Rousseau said fables were lies without "medicinable quality," good enough to furnish amusement to men, but not fit for children to read, because the truth should be told to children. Rousseau has had to take many rap for saying this.

The New-York Historical Society held its first meeting of the season at the society's building, Eleventh Street and Second Avenue, last night. Several new members were admitted to the society. Afterward, the event of the evening took place, which was the reading of a paper by Mr. Frederick Windell Jackson, entitled "The Early Settlement of Throgg's Neck, New-York."

The hasty action of the Good Government Club Convention is not likely to prove a serious obstacle to those who are intent upon effecting an anti-Tammany combination in this city, but in their effort to bring this about upon the lines of last year's arrangement they will do well to consider the great change that has taken place in the situation since then.

There were intimations yesterday that the visits of Mr. Richard Croker to the Gravesend races during the last two days were not merely to see the races. He was there for a purpose, according to the gossip of the race track. That purpose was the purchase of the splendid sprinter Rey del Carreres, who by many is believed to be the fastest sprinter ever seen in this country.

PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 1. -- Lieut. Peary arrived here this morning, and proceeded at once to his mother's residence in Cape Elizabeth, where he now is. He spent the forenoon in conversation with his mother. He is looking well, and is in excellent health.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1. -- James Benjamin, the most recent acquisition to the leper ward at the Municipal Hospital, escaped fully a month ago, and is at large now. The fact that he escaped has been withheld, it being the desire of the hospital authorities to keep the matter a secret.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 1. -- Secretary Wililam M. Hahn of the Republican National Executive Commitee, recently received a copy of a circular letter that has been received by many prominent Republicans in Texas. It has several suspicious features. G.W. Foster signs the letter, and he does it both at the National Republican Committee rooms at Washington and at Dallas, Texas.

ASBURY PARK, Oct. 1. -- The century run today of the Abury Park Wheelmen, from this place to the Inter-State Fair Grounds, at Trenton and return, was a success. The start was made at 5 A. M., with eighty-seven in line, including five women. The cyclers rode in the face of a strong and cold westerly wind for thirty-five miles, but the first half of the Journey was completed on schedule time, with eightyfive survivors.

Mr. Willard has given in this little volume a short and intelligently written account of the life of a modern Italian painter who is little known on this side of the water. It is infrequent for a man to live to see his career the subject of a book, to read another man's ideas of his motives and the influences that have shaped his study.

The annual season of German plays at the Irving Place Theatre, under the direction of Heinrich Conried, was begun auspiciously last night. The house was crowded by such an appreciative and attentive audience as the German theatre commands nowadays more frequently than the playhouses where English is spoken.

Mr. FLINDERS PETRIE read a very remarkable paper on "Civilization" before the British Association at its recent meeting. Had he been a politician seeking the votes of the uncivilized races, and bent upon "arraigning" their opponents, he could not more vigorously and more tellingly have performed his self-allotted task.

This book contains twenty sermons, preached on consecutive Sunday evenings, by the Rev. Dr. MacArthur in the Calvary Baptist Church of New-York, of which he is pastor. They were delivered also in Music Hall, Boston, during the Rev. Dr. MacArthur's vacation ministry of two seasons with the Tremont Temple Church.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- The Republican Senatorial Convention for the Thirty-third District, comprising the Counties of Herkimer and Otsego, was called for to-day in this village, and by reason of the contest over the representation to be accorded the two counties, which began in Albany last August, the convention was not organized.
The Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners met at its offices yesterday to consider locations for stations along the different routes that it has adopted.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Dr. J.S. Billings, Director of the Army Medical Museum, availing himself of the law which permits an officer to apply for retirement at the expiration of thirty years' service, to-day retired from the army, with the rank of Lieutenant Colonel and Deputy Surgeon General.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 1. -- The Suffolk County Agricultural Society opened its forty-fifth annual exhibition to-day with all the glory of a regular old-fashioned country fair. There is a fine display in all the departments. There was considerably more than the usual first day's crowd in attendance.

NEENAH, Wis., Oct. 1. -- James Smith was arrested last night charged with being one of the men who wrecked and robbed a train on the Wisconsin Central Railroad at Waupaca a few nights ago. Smith and Jack Connors, better known as "Diamond Jack," came into Neenah yesterday evening and started on a debauch. They had not got far, however, before Sheriff Petersen got on their track. He arrested Smith, but Connors got away.
A man who attempted to commit burglary at the Hotel St. Lorenz, at 127 East Seventy-second Street, early yesterday morning, fell from a window on the fire escape to the area, and was killed.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 1. -- The usual football game between Williams and Cornell, which was to have been played in Buffalo, N.Y., Thanksgiving Day, will be played in Albany at an earlier date, as the Williams Faculty has interfered with the Buffalo scheme. The Faculty claims that the distance is too great for the team to travel, and that for that reason it will not permit the game.

The trial of Capt. Stauss of the East Sixty-seventh Street Station, against whom charges were made growing out of the Cherokee Club trouble, went on again before Commissioner Roosevelt, at Headquarters yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Capt. Henry W. Howgate was this afternoon admitted to bail, pending the action of the Court of Appeals upon his appeal from the judgment of the Criminal Court of the District sentencing him to a term of imprisonment for crimes committed while acting as disbursing officer of the Signal Service about fifteen years ago.

The Bar Association, which will next May occupy its new building, extending from Forty-third Street to Forty-fourth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, has sold the land and buildings now occupied by it at 3 to 7 West Twenty-ninth Street, 74.6 by 98.9. Mr. S. Sidney Smith, the Chairman of the association's Building Committee, said yesterday they were not at liberty to give the name of the buyer or the amount paid.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 1. -- There was a fatal accident this morning on the Jamesburg branch of the Pennsylvania Railroad at Monmouth Junction, a few miles from this city.

The General Committee of the Democratic Party in Kings County last evening, in the Brooklyn Athenaeum, ratified the action of the Executive Committee in declaring in favor of harmonious action in conjunction with the regular organization at the various nominating conventions, to be held during this week and next. There was not a dissenting voice, so that harmony of action during the campaign is assured.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Oct. 1. -- After a pleasant and uneventful run from the Delaware Breakwater the International Navigation Company's new liner, the St. Paul, dropped anchor off here this afternoon. When the St. Paul weighed anchor on Sunday evening in the Delaware Breakwater the wind was gathering force, and before she had proceeded far a stiff gale astern was helping her along at a rapid gait.
NEWBURG, Oct. 1. -- The Republican Senatorial Convention for the Twenty-third District met here to-day and placed in nomination Clarence Lexow of Rockland County. There was no opposition.

CORNING, Oct. 1. -- The Democratic Senatorial Convention for the Forty-first District, comprising the counties of Steuben and Yates, met at Bath this afternoon. There was a full attendance of delegates, and much interest was manifested.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 1. -- There was a financial crisis in this city to-day. Nearly all the employes of the City Government, from the Mayor down to the janitor of the City Hall, were forced to go home without their September salaries, there not being enough money in the Treasury to pay them.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- The settlement of the Whisky Trust troubles, as announced late this evening, is as follows:
NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- It was Fireman's Day here to-day, and from midget cadet to the vamp of fourscore, the knights of the red shirt owned both town and village.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 1. -- Miss Helen N. Winslow of Boston, President of the Woman's Association of Press Clubs of New England, and one of the Exposition Commissioners from Massachusetts, has issued a statement to the press in which she says:

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 1. -- The report of the Suffrage Committee was presented to the Constitutional Convention this afternoon. The committee has had many stormy sessions, and it has been difficult to arrive at an agreement. The one reached is embodied in the following provisions:

The first witness in the Dock Board investigation, which was resumed yesterday before the Commissioners of Accounts, in the Stewart Building, was William S. Hillman of 15 West Twenty-fifth Street. Mr. Hillman was appointed to the department in 1891, and served until 1895, first as Collector of Wharfage.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 1. -- The new year at the Hartford Theological Seminary will begin to-morrow with a total of seventy-five students. The incoming class will include three ladies -- Miss Sanderson and Miss Caskey of Mount Holyoke Seminary and Miss Norton of Elmira, N.Y. They will take special theological courses, preparing for missionary work.
The Board of Health, at its regular weekly meeting yesterday, adopted the following rules for the prevention of the spread of contagious diseases among public school children:

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- The sixth annual convention of the Societies for the Prevention of Cruelty in New-York State opened this morning in the Assembly Parlor of the State Capitol. Elbridge T. Gerry, President of the societies, opened the session and delivered his annual address, which was unusually brief.

BERLIN, Oct. 1. -- The Augsburg Abend-Zeitung says that Prince Luitpold, Regent of Bavaria, has refused to pardon Mr. Louis Stern of New-York, recently condemned to a fine and imprisonment for insulting Baron von Thuengen, Deputy Commissioner at the Spa at Kissengen.

Mr. Platt and his machine are getting ready for a union ticket, if one can be arranged satisfactorily in this city. From yesterday's developments in the political field the chances last night were that the Republicans will not nominate a straight party ticket.

NEWBURG, Oct. 2. -- At the Democratic Convention for the Twenty-third Senatorial District Francis A. Wilkard of Newburg was Chairman, George H. Thompson of Middletown, and Michael McCabe of Haverstraw, Secretaries. George R. Dickey of Rockland County was nominated unanimously to oppose Senator Lexow.

Such distressing accidents as those which were reported Wednesday morning direct attention to the existence of many very dangerous grade crossings within a short distance of this city, even on our most prominent railroad lines, but it should also be noted that the number of them is being reduced by the voluntary action of the companies themselves.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- There must be a great deal of expert investigation into the gunboat bids received yesterday at the Navy Department before Secretary Herbert can decide to whom the contracts shall go. The consideration of one bid, as already stated in these dispatches, is relieved by the fact that an ancient treaty with Great Britain prohibits building a warship on the great lakes.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 2. -- The celebration of the holy communion with which the triennial convention of the Episcopal Church was ushered in this morning was the most imposing event ever witnessed in a church of that denomination on this continent.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 2. -- Henry G. Newton of this city, a member of the Connecticut General Assembly for 1895, read a very interesting paper before the New-Haven Historical Society Monday night on the subject of "New-Haven's Blue Laws." Mr. Newton said in part:

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Oct. 2. -- While Warner Miller was sitting at Palmer Falls, Herkimer County, working one end of the wire, Platt was tightening his clutches on the faithful little band of Miller's followers at the other.
HAVANA, Oct. 2. -- Col. Oliver's column had a battle with a band of rebels near Zulueta, in the Remedios district, Sept. 29, in which four rebels were killed and many were wounded.

James McDonald, a laborer, twenty-five years old, living with his family at 291 Tenth Avenue, was fatally shot last night at Sixth Avenue and Eighteenth Street by James Cassidy, fifty-two years old, of 141 West Twenty-first Street, the night watchman at the building being erected at that locality by Siegel, Cooper Co., the dry goods merchants of Chicago.

ALBANY, Oct. 2. -- The total deaths in New-York State in August last were, according to the monthly bulletin of the State Board of Health, 11,050, or 1,400 above the average for the month. The maritime district furnished 6,897 of the total number. From the statistics the following are taken:

LYONS, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- Judge J. Henry Metcalf of Canandaigua was nominated for State Senator to oppose John Raines, in the Forty-second Senatorial District, by the Democrats, in their convention held here to-day.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 2. -- Balmy skies and clear weather made this a great day at the Inter-State Fair. In the afternoon the turnstiles showed that 30,000 people were on the grounds. The fakirs are a special attraction this year. There are about 300 of them.

The inquest into the cause of the death of Mrs. Bessie Marcou in her flat, at 160 West Thirty-fifth Street, Sept. 15, was held before Coroner Hoeber yesterday. Daniel McGillagh of 304 West One Hundred and Thirtieth Street, who was arrested on the charge of having administered the opium which caused the woman's death, was present, and was represented by Lawyer Daniel O'Reilly.

Ex-Senator Warner Miller of Herkimer came to this city yesterday. He devoted his time during business hours to his private affairs. In the evening he was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, where there were many politicians.

The reports of the corporations which operate the surface and elevated railroads of this city, covering the year ended June 30, present some items of peculiar interest. The most striking fact presented is the falling off in the number of passengers carried by the elevated roads and the increase in the number traveling by the principal cable lines.

The Cleveland Leader, which has assiduously cultivated the candidacy of McKINLEY and for some years has been his foremost organ in Ohio, is somewhat disturbed by the recent assertion of Mr. JOHN C. NEW that, if ex-President HARRISON could have his say about it, "neither REED nor McKINLEY" would be nominated by the Republican Party.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Secretary Olney, late this afternoon, received the following dispatch from Minister Terrell:

Those who have been told repeatedly by Republican newspapers that the woolen and worsted industries were paralyzed by the new tariff, and who are informed even now by the same journals that the condition of those industries continues to be deplorable, must find it difficult to understand why English capitalists who have made their fortunes in the manufacture of woolens and worsteds are investing money in American factories.

While the market was till professional, the trading was more evenly distributed, and the undertone was decidedly firm. Business was also on a much larger scale than on recent days. The Granger stocks led the railway list and scored advances from 3/8 in St. Paul to 1 1/4 in Burlington. Their strength was due to covering of shorts and also to buying for an advance.

It is hardly four years ago that the yield of half a million ounces (494,869) by the Witwatersrand gold mines started, and rather mildly, the speculation that has since grown to such astonishing proportions. But the yield of 1890 was steadily exceeded, as the following table of monthly production, brought down to the close of August this year, will show:
