We might answer that The Western Associated Press has established an unenviable reputation as the father of fake dispatches, but there are other differences, which are clearly set forth in the following authentic statement, which we publish for the information of the general public:

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 2. -- The twelfth annual session of the Georgia Bar Association met this morning at 10 o'clock in the Auditorium, at the Exposition grounds. The session is presided over by the Hon. William H. Fleming of Augusta.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 2. -- The convention which nominated George Fred Williams was large, enthusiastic, and harmonious. The banquet of the Young Men's Democratic Club, held here last night, brought together all the leading lights of the party, and insured a conspicuously brilliant and distinguished gathering to-day.

The feature of yesterday's play in the Fall handicap tournament of the Kings County Tennis Club was the close match between Colwell and Thurber. The former won only after an exciting struggle of three sets, and many now believe he will prove the winner of the men's singles. Some of the finals will probably be reached by Saturday afternoon.

The reports which are being promulgated anent the extortion practiced in Atlanta upon visitors are calculated to do serious injury to the exposition and to deter people from voluntary offering themselves to be thus preyed upon by hotel proprietors and others.

READING, Penn., Oct. 2. -- Judging by the fire companies coming in to-day, Reading will to-morrow witness its greatest demonstration. Some thirty companies arrived this afternoon. The city is crowded with visitors.
The action of the convention of the Good Government Clubs in making nominations has been widely criticized. Be good enough to allow me space to ask a few questions.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 2. -- The platform was presented to the Democratic Convention at the conclusion of Chairman Quincy's speech by ex-Mayor Coughlin of Fall River. It had the unanimous indorsement of the Committee on Resolutions and the sanction of the candidate and other leaders. The feature of the declaration of principles was the elaborate programme marked out for regulating the business of quasi-public corporations which enjoy valuable franchises through legislative action.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 2. -- The golf tournament of the National Association, which was continued here to-day, was narrowed down to two men, Charles B. McDonald of Chicago, and Charles E. Sands of the St. Andrew's Club of New-York. Unless all signs fail, the championship will go to the Chicagoan, who struck his gait to-day, and a very fast one at that.

The 200 or 300 passengers on the ferryboat Washington of the Pennsylvania Railroad, which left Jersey City at 4:25 o'clock yesterday afternoon for the Cortlandt Street slip, were a thoroughly frightened lot before they arrived at their destination.

SIDNEY, Oct. 2. -- One of the most disappointed men in this county is Abram C. Crosby, ex-Chairman of the Republican County Committee, a lawyer practicing his profession at Delhi; and one of the most disappointed men in this Senatorial District, the Twenty-sixth, is John W. Church of Norwich.

The offerings of books at the second day's sale on Tuesday by Bangs Co. of the library of the late William Berrian consisted mainly of works on botany, of which Columbia College was a heavy buyer, largely for the interests of the Botanical Garden, it was reported. The American Museum of Natural History also bought largely.
J. Ablowich Co., manufacturers of cloaks at 403 Broadway, failed yesterday, and Deputy Sheriff Carraher took possession of their place of business on claims from Herman Joseph for $1,854.

Discussion continues to increase in the Good Government Clubs concerning the action of the convention of those organizations in nominating an independent ticket Monday night. It was learned yesterday that there was a very strong probability that Good Government Club F one of the most influential bodies in the organization, was likely to refuse to support the ticket, and Withdraw from the convention.

The leading delegates to the machine Judiciary Convention assembled long before noon in the office of the Commissioner of Jurors, in the Kings County Court House, in order to come to some definite understanding on the nominees.

Following is a list of the Directors elected at the annual meeting of the shareholders of the Louisville and Nashville, in Louisville, yesterday: August Belmont, J.D. Probst, H.E. Garth, John I. Waterbury, J.A. Horsey, William Mertons, E. Mora Davison, G.M. Lane, J.L. Helm, J.D. Taggert, M.H. Smith, Attila Cox, and Rudolph Ellis.

CLEVELAND, Ohio. Oct. 2. -- " The most exciting ball game that was ever played on any grounds," was the verdict of men who have followed baseball for years, after the first of the series of contests for the Temple Cup between Cleveland and Baltimore to-day. For four innings it was a pitcher's battle between Young and McMahon, both men pitching superbly.

In appointing Gen. MILES to the command of the army the President has not only followed usage as to senior officers, but has conferred a distinction which had been well earned by a career of extraordinary service. In soldierly traits and bearing, in executive ability, and in the brilliancy of his record of field services Gen. MILES is certainly worthy of those who have preceded him in the command of the army.
BOSTON, Oct. 2. -- The annual meeting of the Vessel Owners and Captains' National Association was held to-day. The meeting was largely attended, there being 160 vessels represented.

It does seem a little queer that when the King of Italy, having heard that the Queen of England contemplated a visit to Naples, was hospitable enough to put a palace at her disposal, rent free, the royal lady should have shown her appreciation and gratitude by at once dispatching an agent to see what condition the structure was in, to examine the plumbing, and to investigate the neighbors.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES of yesterday contains a two and a half column letter from its special correspondent detailed to spend last Sunday in the little village of Herkimer, with a population of 4,000, overlooking which, on the top of a high hill, is the residence of Mr. Warner Miller, the champion of "maintenance of Sunday laws in the interest of labor and morality."
In the issue of The Elmira Advertiser of Sept. 30 there appeared an editorial which had for its main object the scoring of Edward G. Riggs, the political reporter for The New-York Sun.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Sept. 2. -- The Republic of Haiti, like Jamaica, being practically independent of the sugar industry, although naturally to some extent affected by the present crisis in the sugar markets is by no means sharing the untoward experiences of most of the other West Indian islands. On the contrary, a period of prosperity quite unprecedented in her history appears to be beginning.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 2. -- Six persons were injured this afternoon by an explosion of Roman candles in the fireworks factory of Detwiller Street, in West Side Avenue, near the Morris Canal. One of the injured will die.

The Board of Officers of the New-York Commandery of the Loyal Legion appointed to investigate charges against William S. Andrews, formerly Commissioner of Street Cleaning, reported at the meeting of the Loyal Legion, held at Delmonico's last night, that they had found Mr. Andrews guilty of three charges out of the four.
AUSTIN, Texas, Oct. 2. -- Corbett and Fitzsimmons must find another place than Texas in which to have their fight for the championship of the world.

ALBANY, Oct. 2. -- President H.C. Ford of the Pennsylvania Commissioners of Fisheries met President Barnet H. Davis of the New-York Fisheries, Game and Forest Commission by appointment to-night to settle upon a matter which bids fair to deplete the waters of the Delaware of their game fish.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 2. -- Mr. Williams, on being presented to the convention, was greeted with such an outburst of applause that he was unable to make himself heard for several minutes. After thanking the convention for the nomination, he said:

The publicly announced determination of the Justices of the Court of Special Sessions to many things interesting for District Attorney John R. Fellows unless he changed his tactics in relation to the transferred excise cases bore fruit yesterday.
ALBANY, Oct. 2. -- Another deadlock was broken to-day by the election of Augustus Sherman of New-Baltimore to the thirty-five-hundred-dollar Secretaryship of the new Prison Commission.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment will soon begin the preparation of the preliminary budget for 1896. Speaking in reference to the possible expenditures of the city next year, Controller Fitch said yesterday:

That Acting Inspector McCullagh, who has charge of the police investigation in the case of Mrs. Mary Alice Almont Fleming, or Livingston, under indictment on the charge of having caused the death of her mother, Mrs. Henry H. Bliss, has information which he deems of importance was evident from his movements and manner yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 2. -- The Post will to-morrow publish a dispatch from Constantinople saying it is believed that ten persons were killed and forty wounded in the streets during the rioting which occurred Monday. Five hundred persons have been arrested on the charge of participating in the rioting.

Alleged actions by Mrs. Clara Weich's mother gave Judge Pryor of the Court of Common Pleas the opportunity last week to express his belief that "next to rum, mischievous mothers-in-law are the chief sources of nearly all the matrimonial broils which come before the courts."

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 2. -- The action of the Board of Aldermen in adopting articles impeaching City Treasurer Lucien Knapp has aroused the people of this city, and there is a prospect of lively times. It was said to-day that the Aldermen had violated the provisions of Section 16 of Chapter I. of Title 3 of the city charter, which relates to the legislative powers of the Common Council.

The immigration authorities on Ellis Island have for a long time been cognizant of an indisposition on the part of her Britannic Majesty's Consular Service in this city to care for, or in any way interest itself in the well-being of British subjects who reach this port as emigrants to Canada.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 2. -- Bonfires and music accompanied the nomination of Patrick Jerome Gleason for Mayor to-night. The convention was held in the Queens County Court House, and long before the hour for assembling the big courtroom and the gallery held many spectators. A crowd filled the open space in front of the building and listened to the band until the hour for opening the convention arrived.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The Times this morning says that the Catholic Archbishops in secret session will discuss the expediency and propriety of arraigning Secretary Hoke Smith of the Interior Department, upon the complaint of Mgr. Stephan, head of the Catholic Indian Mission in this city, for unjust discrimination in the administration of Indian affairs.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 2. -- Arrangements have been practically completed for the elaborate banquet which will be tendered by Yale Alumni to the Cambridge track team in New-York. It will take place on Saturday evening, Oct. 5, after the Yale-Cambridge game, at Sherry's, and arrangements have been made for a thousand college men to attend.

" Resolved, That it is the sense of this committee that a sincere effort should be made to effect a union of all citizens who do not wish this city to again become subject to the rule of Tammany Hall."

It is expected that the Chamber of Commerce will take action at its meeting to-day looking toward the effecting of a combination of all political parties and organizations in the city opposed to Tammany.

The West Presbyterian Church, in West Forty-second Street, which has been practically without a pastor of its own for nearly two years, has entered upon a new chapter of its existence, which those who are interested in its welfare declare will be a very bright and useful one.

" What!" editorially exclaims THE NEW-YORK TIMES of to-day, "rum sold in Herkimer? And on Sunday, with doors wide open, and all day long? O Warner, Warner, you stay in New-York too much: They need you at home to 'maintain' the Sunday law."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 2. -- Over 6,000 people saw Clinton R. Coulter, the transcontinental tourist, lower the record for one-third of a mile, unpaced, at the close of the National Circuit meet at Fountain Ferry track to-day. The weather was perfect for racing and record-breaking. "Tom" Cooper twice defeated Bald in the mile open by a length in a hard run and in the quarter, where Murphy was disqualified for fouling Bald.

The fair for the benefit of the Fritz Reuter Home fund was opened last night at the Lexington Avenue Opera House. The early visitors found that the ladies and committees had kept their promise, everything being in readiness when the doors were thrown open at 6 o'clock. Not a single feature was incomplete, and the beautiful arrangement of the twenty-nine booths and the charming decorations elicited lavish praises from those present.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 2. -- Brig. Gen. O.M. Poe, Colonel of Engineers of the Northwest District, died at his residence here this morning aged sixty-three years. The immediate cause of death was erysipelas.

William B. Curtis will referee the Yale-Cambridge games to be held at Manhattan Field Saturday. Mr. Curtis, after an examination of his files and records, says the official lists are as follows, and the best performances of each team, so far as known, are:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The official announcement has finally been made that raises Gen. Miles to the command of the army, and places Gen. Ruger in command of the Department of the East, with headquarters at New-York. The delay in issuing this order has been due alone to the desire of the Secretary of War to make the necessary staff adjustment incident to the advancement of Gen. Miles.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The annual report of Capt. P.V. Cooper, Superintendent of the Naval Academy, shows that during the year past twenty-six cadets failed to pass the examinations, and were permitted to resign, no vacancies being caused by death or dismissal. The Superintendent says that the limit of age permitted by law for the entrance of cadets is too great, and urges that it should be established between fifteen and seventeen years.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- Coach Newoll is working the football men hard now every day. Most of the practice is taken from 3 to 5 in the afternoon, with morning practice for the backs, who can go to the field at that time. Since the opening of the university there have been about fifty men out every day. There is no end of new material, but it is all of the light order.

Harmony received a severe set-back in Brooklyn yesterday, and the result is that two tickets have been placed in the field by the Democrats for Justice of the Supreme Court for the Second Judicial District, representing Kings, Queens, Suffolk, Richmond, Westchester, Orange, Dutchess, Rockland, and Putnam Counties.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 2.--The Constitutional Convention consumed the entire day in a fight over two brief sections of the article on municipal corporations and police regulations. The first of these sections, providing for general laws for organization and classification of municipal corporations, was adopted.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 2. -- The nomination of a candidate for Governor was the first thing in order after the convention had adopted its platform. John E. Russell of Liecester arose amid enthusiastic applause. He was forced to the platform, where he moved that the convention proceed to nominate candidates for Governor and Lieutenant Governor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The Eucharistic Congress of the Catholic Church began this morning with the celebration of a solemn pontifical high mass at St. Patrick's Church. It was a most impressive occasion, and drew an audience that crowded the handsome edifice to the doors.

The law school of the University of the City of New-York opened yesterday with the largest registration in its history. In the day department 275 have already matriculated. The consolidation of the old Metropolis Law School with the university gives the latter a new evening department, which met last night with about 125 students.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 2. -- The recent convention of the International Deep Waterways Association, which closed its session in this city last Friday, was in many respects a most notable gathering.

PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 2. -- New records were made to-day for several horses at the meeting at Rigby Park. In the first heat of the pacing class. Mascot, Jr., took a record of 2:10 1/2, and in the second, Last Request one of 2:11 1/2. When the trotters commenced, Fanny Wilcox took a mark of 2:10 1/4, and Nemoline one of 2:12.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The pilot chart for the North Atlantic, issued by the Hydrographic Office, Navy Department, gives the following forecast for October: "Frequent gales between the New-England coast and the British Isles, and as far south as the fortieth parallel. Tropical cyclones or hurricanes very probable. South of 40 degrees north and east of 60 degrees west weather generally moderate.
Who were there?
The second session of the forty-fourth semi-annual meeting of the Homeopathic Medical Society of the State of New-York was held yesterday in the Berkeley Lyceum, 21 West Forty-fourth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2. -- Prominent Republicans from every section of the State were here to-day, and the liveliest sort of activity prevailed at the headquarters of the Republican State Committee. The occasion was a meeting of the State Committee, and a conference of the Executive Commitee of that body, which was recently appointed by Chairman Quay. Mr. Quay arrived this morning.

The Oxford and Cambridge team of cricketers sailed for England yesterday morning on board the New-York. They were driven down to the pier, at the foot of Fulton Street, on a stage, and plenty of attention was drawn to them, with their straw hats, which they still adhered to Capt. Mitchell said to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES:

The Fall meeting of the Queens County Jockey Club, which began at Aqueduct yesterday, was favored with mild and pleasant weather, a large crowd, and an interesting afternoon's racing. The only drawback to the sport was the long and tedious delays at the post.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 2.--Cannon boomed as the Duke of Marlborough, Miss Consuelo Vanderbilt, Oliver H.P. Belmont, Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt, and Col. and Mrs. Jay crossed the ferry from Garrison's at 1 o'clock to-day. The Duke thought the salute was for him, and his countenance beamed as the party rode up the hill in carriages.

Mr. JOSIAH QUINCY put the Cuban case in a nutshell when, in speaking of the proposition that we recognize the brave rebels as belligerents, he said to the Massachusetts Democratic Convention yesterday:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2. -- The United States armored cruiser Brooklyn was launched from Cramps' shipyard into the Delaware River at 1:08 o'clock this afternoon with the usual accompaniment of the noise furnished by shrieking steam whistles and the cheers of at least 15,000 spectators.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. -- Whether the Democrats of Massachusetts win or lose in the coming campaign, it may be fairly said that seldom in their history have they more deserved success than they do at the present moment. The ticket which they nominated to-day and the platform upon which their candidates stand are worthy of the highest impulses and best traditions of the party.

The regular Democratic Judiciary Convention yesterday placed in nomination for the Supreme Court bench Messrs. MARTIN J. KEOGH of Westchester, JAMES W. COVERT of Queens, and ALMET F. JENKS of Kings. A committee of conference met a like committee from the Reform Organization, pending the session of the convention, but no agreement was reached, the reform Democrats persisting in their refusal to accept the name of Mr. JENKS.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 2. -- Ten thousand dollars has been appropriated by the Bureau of Ordnance for a new set of boilers for the torpedo boat Cushing. She will go out of commission in December, that they may be put in.

LONDON, Oct. 2. -- Sir Halliday Macartney, counselor of the Chinese Legation to Great Britain, gave information to-day that the punishment of the Viceroy of Sze-Chuen for neglecting to protect the missionaries in his district had been decided upon by China before the British ultimatum was issued.

Enough Bavarian beer is annually consumed in New-York to create a bond of sympathy between the "hustlers" of this western metropolis and the simple folk of the Black Forest. Moreover, it is something of a fad now to admire the charming novels of Baroness Tautphoeus, new editions of which are in demand.
NEWARK, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- The twenty-eighth annual session of the Central New-York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church convened this morning at 9 o'clock in the Methodist Episcopal Church.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The relations between Great Britain and Brazil in regard to the Island of Trinidad, according to advices received here, are still such that they are far from an amicable adjustment.
An interesting feature of the Exhibition of Food Products in Madison Square Garden, which was opened last night, is the educational exhibit.

Judge Cowing adjourned Part II. of the Court of General Sessions yesterday morning for the September term without taking any further action on the excise cases on his calendar. In the District Attorney's office it was said that the work of disposing of the excise indictments would be resumed Monday, when the October term of the Court of General Sessions opened.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 3. -- Oliver H.P. Belmont and his coaching guests arrived this afternoon. One of the horses cast a shoe at Wappinger's Falls, and the coach was drawn up in Courier Square, where the party waited while the horses were detached and the troublesome shoe replaced at a blacksmith's shop near by.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Oct. 3. -- The obsequies over the late, if not lamented, Senatorial boom of Warner Miller were concluded this morning with appropriate exercises; and an undertaker brought across the country by the Otsego delegation was in attendance on the Republican Convention to properly inter the overweaning ambitions of the man from outside the breastworks.

It is not generally known, but the Utah Sugar Company has begun a novel use for the waste product from the works at Lehi, known as by-product, or molasses. Roads are actually being constructed with the syrups, which are valueless as sugar producers, the life having been extracted. The molasses is used as a cement, the body of the road material being made up of fine gravel.

Whatever "combination" may be effected in this city, it will only concern local offices and the administration of local affairs. It should not be allowed to stand in the way of the united support of Democrats for the State ticket and for candidates for the Legislature, nor should it be regarded by Democrats "up the State" as a menace to party success.
Uncle Sam enlisted his daily army recruit yesterday.

BOSTON, Oct. 3. -- A drill in Faneuil Hall at 8 o'clock to-morrow evening, by the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company of Boston, will complete the preparations for the trip to Richmond. The start will be made from Commercial Street Saturday afternoon, and Mayor Curtis will view the troops at 4 o'clock.

About two months ago Senator LEXOW remarked, in an interview which The Tribune published, that "this increase of wages" was "only a temporary thing." "If it is otherwise," he continued, "we [meaning the shining lights of the Republican Party] are all wrong and have been in the wrong all the time."
ALBANY, Oct. 3. -- Attorney General Hancock has written the following opinion, in response to a communication from Clerk K.P. Shedd of Rochester, regarding the folding of official ballots:

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 3. -- John Czech, alias "Fish John," who killed "Fish Mary," his wife, in this city June 3, was hanged in the Hudson County Jail this morning. The drop was sprung at 10:09. Czech's neck was not broken. The knot slipped to the back of the head, and he was slowly strangled. At 10:33 Dr. W.W. Varick pronounced him dead.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- But for its position on the lakes, Chicago would not be the great city it is. Yet Chicago takes surprisingly little interest in lake commerce, owns but a small fraction of lake shipping, and is but dimly aware that to the foul-smelling creek known as the Chicago River it owes most of its past achievements and future possibilities.
WHITESTONE, L.I., Oct. 3. -- The Whitestone Republican Club met to-night and passed by an almost unanimous vote the following preamble and resolution:

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3. -- A monotonous morning session in the Durrant murder trial to-day was relieved by the contempt of court proceedings in the case of Secretary H.J. McCoy of the Young Men's Christian Association, who last Thursday remarked to a juror in the case that he would be hanged if he did not vote to convict Durrant.

William Walker, a colored caterer, living at 439 West Thirty-ninth Street, with his wife, went into the restaurant of John Stark, at 436 and 438 Ninth Avenue for supper several weeks ago. Walker alleged that the proprietor snatched the bill of fare from his wife's hand, and told both that he would not serve them because of their color.

The boxing entertainment at the New Manhattan Athletic Club to-night should result in some excellent sport, as the bouts arranged by the management give promise of being hotly contested. Interest is centred in the Erne-Skelly fifteen-round event.
Frederick W. Wurster, Fire Commissioner, was named early this morning for Mayor of Brooklyn by the Republicans.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3, -- Capt. and Brevet Major George A. Armes will be court-martialed. The charges and specifications have been prepared by Gen. Lieber, Judge Advocate General of the army, and are as follows:

Americans who visit London are naturally fond of picking up curiosities of the old country to carry with them to the new, and all attempts to deceive them, or to palm off spurious specimens, ought to be fully exposed. Let them, therefore, beware of purchasing postcards alleged to be from Mr. Gladstone, unless they are sure of the source whence they come.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3. -- The following bulletin has been issued by Chairman Gideon of the League of American Wheelmen's Racing Board:

CORNING, Oct. 3. -- All Corning has been given over to politics and politicians to-day. The Democrats held four conventions, and the Republicans continued their dead-locked Senatorial Convention, which certainly is the most remarkable convention ever held in this part of the State.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 3. -- Charles B. MacDonald of Chicago won his match to-day in the finals in the national tournament with Charles E. Sands of St. Andrew's Club of New-York, and therefore took the United States championship. On the whole the Westerner's task was a light one, Sands utterly failing to push him to any great extent, and the match amounted to a practice game for MacDonald.

The great monument to Garibaldi, inaugurated with so much ceremony yesterday by the King of Italy at Rome, is a somewhat incongruous memorial of the event it is intended to celebrate -- namely, the evacuation of the Eternal City by the French troops, and its final incorporation with the Italian monarchy.

PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 3. -- Bingen, the two-year-old son of May King, by Electioneer, went an exhibiton mile to-day in 2:12 1/2 faster than any colt of his age has trotted this year, and, with the exception of Arion's mile in 2:10 3/4 to the high wheels, the fastest mile a two-year-old ever trotted.

It was pretty poor sport that the Brooklyn Jockey Club provided for race-goers yesterday. There were three sprint races for two-year-olds and a six-furlong dash for older horses, and but two races at fair distances, one at a mile and another at a sixteenth of a mile further. The latter, of course, proved the best race of the day.
LONDON, Oct. 3. -- The Westminster Gazette, in an article under the caption "Turn About Is Fair Play," says:

LONG ISLAND CITY, Oct. 3. -- Patrick Jerome Gleason, who was nominated last night by the Gleason Democrats for Mayor of this city, has issued a challenge inviting all his political opponents to meet him on the stump and debate with him the issues of the campaign.

A Boston visitor to Crabbet Park, the home of Mr. Wilfrid Blunt and Lady Anne Blunt, in Survey, brings home a lively impression of the picturesque and poetic life of this gifted pair of people. Lady Anne is Lord Byron's granddaughter, the daughter of Ada, the "sole daughter" of his heart and house, who became Lady Lovelace.

After a three months' rest beside the placid waters of Switzerland's lakes, the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst spoke last night for the first time this Fall, in behalf of the movement of the City Vigilance League, of which he is President.
Property belonging to two members of the Seventh Regiment was stolen from the armory last night while Companies B and I were at drill.

The work of the Handicapping Committee of the Kings County Tennis Club showed to better advantage yesterday, most of the games played on the club's court at Kingston Avenue and Dean Street, Brooklyn, being remarkably close. The results:

Word has just reached here from Kara-Hissari-Charki that a band of Armenians attacked Nedjib Effendi, substitute to the Attorney General, when on his way to Sivas, accompanied by gendarmes and by Rami Effendi, chief of the correspondence at Tchoroun. Rami Effendi, as well as the gendarmes, were dangerously wounded, while Nedjib Effendi was carried to the woods and murdered.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3.--Minister Romero of Mexico, speaking without official information on the subject, inclined to the belief this afternoon that the Corbett-Fitzsimmons fight might be brought off within the Mexican borders if all parties concerned so agreed. The place said to have been selected is in the State of Tamaulipas, which touches the southern border of Texas on the Rio Grande, and is convenient to the railroads.

Routine business, which had accumulated in the Summer recess, received the attention of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday in advance of the action in behalf of good city government. President Alexander E. Orr, in his address of welcome, referred to the loss of twelve members by death, and pronounced eulogies on Ambrose Snow, Josiah O. Low, Hugh H. Camp, and John D. Jones.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 3. -- While the Democrats were nominating municipal candidates at the Lyceum Theatre to-night the Republicans were settling the rivalries of candidates at Raines's Hall. Both conventions attracted big crowds of partisans, but the greater amount of interest was shown in the Republican meeting.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- The Standard will tomorrow publish a dispatch from Constantinople saying that on Wednesday a large number of shops were closed and the streets were patrolled by the police. The whole city is virtually in a state of siege. The dispatch adds that a witness of the occurrence states that a respectable-looking Armenian was arrested by two gendarmes on Tuesday while walking in the Galata quarter.

ELGIN, Ill., Oct. 3. -- The General Conference of the German Evangelical Church opened in this city this morning with a full attendance. Mayor Wayne delivered an address of welcome, which was responded to by Bishop Breyfogle. Bishop Bowman opened the conference in English and Bishop Horn in German.

HAMMONTON, N.J., Oct. 3.--What may prove to be a murder occurred at Winslow, near here, early this morning, when Charles Roller, a well-known citizen of Winslow, was shot down by an Italian named Tony during a quarrel.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Oct. 3. -- When Frederick H. Curtis of West Norwell, Mass., stepped up to register at a hotel in this city the other day he remarked to the clerk that he had not been in this vicinity for thirty-three years, although it was within a mile of Newport News that the most thrilling incident of his life occurred.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 3. -- Cleveland won the second game of the Temple Cup series in a walk to-day. They made enough runs in the first inning to win the game, and Haalon's men had no chance to win at any stage. Cuppy pitched a wonderful game. He was hit safely but five times, and two of these were of the scratch order. He had great speed and control, giving but two bases on balls.
LONDON, Oct. 3. -- A dispatch from Constantinople to the Central News says it is officially announced that Kiamil Pasha will replace Said Pasha as Grand Vizier.

From Paris the death is reported at the age of fifty-three of M. Alfred Marchand, who was for twenty-six years on the staff of the Temps. Our correspondent telegraphs: "The deceased was graduated at the Strasburg School of Theology, but from conscientious reasons did not enter the ministry as a pastor.
The Republican County Convention last night went on record as being violently opposed to the appointment of a committee to "confer with other organizations" with a view to a union ticket.

Formal application was made before Judge Lacombe, in the United States Circuit Court, yesterday for the removal of Receivers Oakes, Payne, and Rouse of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company and for the confirmation of the appointment of Edward H. McHenry and F.C. Bigelow as receivers by Judge Jenkins of the United States Circuit Court of Wisconsin, which appointments were recently confirmed by Judge Sanborn in St. Paul.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 3. -- The twenty-fourth annual statement of the affairs of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company for the year ended June 30 last was issued to-night. The most interesting part of the statement, perhaps, is the following paragraph:

There was a Cupid in nearly every corner of Edward Brannan's house last night. Where there wasn't a Cupid, there was something else that suggested his presence. For two years the little fellow has been busy with his darts among the Brannans, and his plans then culminated. The Brannans live in a very modest little cottage at 228 West Market Street.

RIVERHEAD, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- The forty-fifth annual exhibition of the Suffolk County Agricultural Society closed to-day. The exhibition has been a grand success. The weather was all that could be asked for, and the attendance large. The racing was very interesting to-day, and there was plenty of excitement. In every heat of the free-for-all the track record of 2:20 1/4 was broken. Summaries of races:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3. -- The old cracked Liberty Bell, which will be exhibited at the Atlanta Exposition, was this afternoon removed from Independence Hall to the Pennsylvania freight station, where it will remain under guard until to-morrow morning, when the journey South will be begun. A parade took place this afternoon when the bell was removed, Mayor Warwick and the heads of the different municipal departments reviewing the procession from the Union League Clubhouse.
MILFORD, Penn., Oct. 3.--Justice Henry Newberger of Tafton, Pike County, was shot in the head and fatally wounded, and Henry Quick was dangerously wounded, yesterday by Christopher Houseman.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- There will be no arraignment of Secretary Smith's administration of the Indian Bureau by the Catholic Bishops, either in the form of charges to be investigated by Congress or otherwise. Cardinal Gibbons, in an interview to-day, said:

Saratoga Letter to The Hartford Times. One of the most chamring and delightful evenings we have spent was in listening to the Rev. Theodore L. Cuyler, D.D. He gave an off-hand talk on the broad veranda of the hotel, and a most interested and absorbed audience he had, for more than an hour. His subject was, "Some People I Have Seen in the Last Fifty Years."

There was evidence yesterday that the more intelligent leaders of the regular Democracy in Brooklyn were much concerned over the situation created by the obstinacy of the Judiciary Convention in forcing the nomination of Mr. JENKS. Their concern was not lessened by the conviction that this stupid action was due to the reappearance of the venerable HUGH McLAUGHLIN as the boss of the machine.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- Col. R.E.A. Crofton, U.S.A., was shot at and wounded this afternoon at Fort Sheridan by First Lieut. Pague. The Colonel was reviewing dress parade when Lieut. Pague, who had been confined in the hospital, came upon the grounds and deliberately fired three shots at his superior officer. The first shot went wide of its mark, the second went through the Colonel's coat, and the third grazed his abdomen.

There was no diminution of either the attendance or receipts yesterday, the second day, at the Fritz Reuter Fair, now being held at the Lexington Avenue Opera House. The Plattdeutsche of this city and environs are working heart and soul for the project, and every effort is being made to realize a sum sufficient to erect the asylum for the aged and indigent, and to create a fund for its maintenance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The Priests' Eucharistic League ended its congress to-day by the adoption of resolutions pledging the league to do everything in its power to cause the veneration of the Sabbath, and indorsing the decree of the Plenary Council of Baltimore on that subject. The Plenary Council's decree urges pastors to secure the sanctification of Sunday, and specifies the opening of saloons as one way of its desecration.

George Appo, the half-breed Chinese, who figured so prominently as a Lexow witness last year, yesterday received a sentence of six months in the penitentiary. The sentence was imposed by Judge Cowing in the Court of General Sessions, before whom Appo pleaded guilty to assaulting Policeman Michael J. Rein.

The action taken by the Chamber of Commerce yesterday was quite consistent with its action of last year and in accordance with the principle then avowed. It was not political action, but the Chamber recognizes the fact that the material and commercial interests of this city are bound up with an honest and businesslike administration of its government, and it takes the ground that such administration must be non-partisan.

Without a dissenting vote, the Chamber of Commerce yesterday decided upon the formation of a committee of fifty for the purpose of uniting citizens in an effort to bring about the nomination of a combination anti-Tammany ticket at the coming election.

Because of his love of this country and its institutions, Isaac Michael Wittkowsky of 73 East One Hundred and Ninth Street will hereafter be known as Michael Witt, Judge Pryor, in the Court of Common Pleas, having granted him permission yesterday to change his name.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- An extraordinary case of removing a landmark has been brought to the attention of Attorney General Harmon. The landmark in question is in fact the boundary line between the United States and Canada in Franklin County, N.Y. The facts as reported to the Attorney General by F.G. Paddock, District Attorney for Franklin County, N.Y., are these:

The Executive Committee of the Council of Good Government Clubs met last night at the City Club. All the candidates of the Good Government Clubs were present except Lewis L. Delafield and Hamilton Odell.

Visitors to the Westchester County Fair to-morrow will witness some rattling good cycle races. The third annual meet of the Westchester Cycling League will be held, and a programme of six races has been arranged, and 305 entries have been made for these events. One hundred and twenty-seven riders have made entries, several of then entering for two or more races.

Without a dissenting vote, the Chamber of Commerce yesterday decided upon the formation of a committee of fifty for the purpose of uniting citizens in an effort to bring about the nomination of a combination anti-Tammany ticket at the coming election.

Because of his love of this country and its institutions, Isaac Michael Wittkowsky of 73 East One Hundred and Ninth Street will hereafter be known as Michael Witt, Judge Pryor, in the Court of Common Pleas, having granted him permission yesterday to change his name.
He Was Struck Down in the Street and His Skull Broken -- Witnesses Who Testified for and Against the Acrobat.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 3. -- Mrs. Robert Goelet entertained at luncheon to-day aboard the steam yacht Hermione. Her guests were Mrs. H. Mortimer Brooks, Mrs. Royal Phelps Carroll, Mrs. Grenville Kane, and Mrs. E.H. Slater.

HUDSON, Oct. 3. -- The Columbia County Democratic Convention held in this city today was largely attended and proved the most harmonious political convention held in this county in years, there being no contest of any sort. The two wings of the party had about equal representation in delegates and on the ticket nominated.

At the fourth day's sale of the Berrian Library yesterday by Bangs Co. a large number of books of and upon epigrams, from classic times to modern dates, sold for an average of 75 cents each, and a collection of epitaphs sold for 80 cents each.

The Food Show at Madison Square Garden opened last evening with all the eclat -- general brilliance of color, music, and large crowd, to which a well-organized food show should aspire. The Madison Square Garden Company presented its compliments to its friends, and the opening was a general reception in their honor.

SING SING, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- The Democrats of the First Assembly District, comprising the towns of East Chester, Greenburgh, Mount Pleasant, and Yonkers, held their convention this afternoon in Tarrytown, to nominate a candidate for member of Assembly. Francis Gibson presided.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 3. -- The Democrats had a rather stormy time at their County Convention this morning, not on the subject of nominations, but on the adoption of rules for the government of the party in Monroe County, a set of rules was proposed, and after long debate and excited discussion, adopted.

Tammany's Executive Committee met yesterday afternoon, and the seventy seats of the district leaders and their associate leaders were all filled, either by the leaders themselves or their proxies. Chairmen Sheehan, Cumming, McClellan, and Daniel F. Martin were all present, and James J. Martin, Chairman of the Executive Committee, presided.

The population of Minnesota on June 1, 1895, according to the State census, was 1,573,350. In 1890, by the Federal census, it was 1,301,826, an increase of 271,524. The heaviest growth has been in the Sixth District. Not only in Duluth, but in all the counties in the pine forest and mineral district, it is 44 per cent.
WARREN, R.I., Oct. 3. -- The mill of the Warren Manufacturing Company was destroyed by fire to-night, and a good deal of property surrounding it also was destroyed.

The Ladies' Committee and officers of the Heine Monument Fair Association held a meeting last night at Arion Hall, at which much of the preliminary work for the fair, which will be held in the Lenox Lyceum Nov. 16 to 24, was transacted. The ladies reported presentations of money and valuable articles including an upright piano from a Chicago manufactory.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Oct. 4. -- In her trial run of four hours to-day, between Cape Ann, Mass., and Cape Porpoise, Me., a distance of 44.96 knots, the International Navigation Company's new steamer St. Paul averaged 20 1/2 knots per hour, and earned the privilege of carrying the United States mails to Europe.

Frank Ives Thursday night gave a wonderful exhibition of skill at balk-line billiards. In one run he scored between 700 and 800 points. Unfortunately, an exact count was not made, and the total of the break can only be approximated. One spectator counted 434, and then lost the count because he was impelled to ask a friend if anybody had ever before seen such marvelous billiards.

NEWBURG, Oct. 4. -- The Democrats of the First Assembly District of Orange to-day placed in nomination for Assemblyman Henry Garner of Newburg. There was no opposition. The district is heavily Republican, but occasionally lands a Democrat, and Garner was selected with a view to getting the vote of the city from local pride.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 4. -- James J. Van Alen left to-day for Rhinebeck, where he will spend ten days with Col. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor. He will soon go to Egypt, and will charter a steam yacht to cruise in the warmer latitudes during the Winter.

In the feverish excitement aroused in France by the presence of high Russian officers at the manoeuvres in the Vosges, on the frontier of Germany, it is refreshing to hear one quiet and firm voice directing attention to facts of the past and the present which the Russomaniacs and the Prussophobes are wholly ignoring.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- Commissioner S.W. Lamoreux of the General Land Office to-day submitted to the Secretary of the Interior his annual report. There was a decrease in the number of original entries of land of 3,016,685 acres, as compared with the previous year. In receipts there was a decrease of $734,370.

Jacob Worth again "bobbed up serenely" last night, when all his candidates for office were nominated at the County Convention of the Republican Party in Kings County, which was held in the old Fourteenth Regiment Armory, in North Portland Avenue, Brooklyn.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 4. -- Plainfield society people suffered a shock to-day when the announcement was made of the marriage of Herman Simmonds, Jr., son of Herman Simmonds, a coffee importer of New-York and New-Orleans, who lives here, to Mrs. Mamie Hammond, a divorcee.

LIMA, Peru, via Galveston, Oct. 4. -- In view of persistent statements made in Sucre and circulated by the press of Buenos Ayres, the Government has asked Minister Lopez to explain the article of the Hualgayoc privilege which refers to other railway lines.

John B. Ireland, owner of the West Broadway building that collapsed on Aug. 7, when fifteen workmen were killed or fatally injured, was severely censured yesterday by the outgoing September Grand Jury, in a presentment handed up in Part I. of the General Sessions Court.

Those whose minds are intent upon the election of two county officers and a number of Judges in this city, on account of the relation of that election to the question of municipal reform and to the conduct of certain local organizations, seem to be anxious to thrust aside the leading issue of this year's campaign in the State.
MADRID, Oct. 4. -- The cruisers Alfonso XII are Marquis de Ensenada have been ordered to proceed immediately to Cuba.

One of the best things that have happened for Brooklyn for many a year is the defeat of JACOB WORTH at the City Convention of the Republican Party on Thursday. WORTH is a survival, not merely of the old, tricky, spoils-mongering politics, but also of the village period of Brooklyn affairs. In point of character and aims there is nothing to choose between him and McLAUGHLIN.
BOSTON, Oct. 4.--Will the Republican Party of Massachusetts openly disavow all connection with the A.P.A., and thus eliminate sectarianism and religious bigotry from the politics of the State?

The inquest into the cause of death of Charles E. Tainter, who was found dead in the bathroom of his residence, 11 West Eleventh Street, in the night of Sunday, Sept. 22, was held yesterday before Coroner Fitzpatrick in the new Criminal Court Building. At the time of the death reports were circulated that Mr. Tainter had committed suicide, but the evidence presented yesterday entirely disproved this.

A State Convention of the Democratic Party Reform Organization was held in the Clarendon Hotel, Brooklyn, last night, and was attended by about 200 delegates and others. This is the organization that nominated Everett P. Wheeler for Governor last year. The purpose of the convention yesterday was to perpetuate the existence of the organization under the new law.

The authors of this history are Southern men, all three being connected with the public schools of Texas, and unquestionably their aim has been to write a history for use in Southern schools. They offer their book as a non-sectional work, and express the belief that there has been "need of a textbook on the history of the United States which would present fairly and impartially all sections of the Union."

The New-York Tribune has been attacking a list of increases of wages published by several of our contemporaries on Sept. 2, and has undertaken to show that it contained many duplications and other errors. Our neighbor asserts that the list in question was compiled by a club or similar organization, from which it was obtained by the journals that printed it.

The situation last night in the effort to crystallize all the anti-Tammany sentiment in another local union was perplexing. Oswald Ottendorfer's declaration for a third ticket that would have nothing to do with Platt, made on his arrival from Europe, complicated matters, and left the possibility of the German-Americans supporting a general union as solidly as they did last year in grave doubt.

CORNING, Oct. 4. -- The deadlock in the Republican Senatorial Convention in the Forty-first District was broken just before 6 o'clock this evening by the nomination of John S. Sheppard of Penn Yan, Yates County. Only one ballot was taken throughout the day, and that was early this morning. A motion was made at 11 o'clock by Sherwood delegates that the delegations from each district be released from their pledges by their respective candidates.

ALBANY, Oct. 4. -- Norton Chase, Republican candidate for Attorney General, and State Committeeman John Bowe matched steel to-day in an open contest, and Mr. Chase won out with fifty delegates to Mr. Bowe's twenty-six.

MOUNT VERNON, Oct 4. -- St. Paul's Church. East Chester, celebrated its third centennial to-day, this occasion being the one hundredth anniversary of the reincorporation of the parish, and the giving to the church of its present name.

Bostwick, the scratch man in the West Side Tennis Club's handicap singles, had a tough fight with H.S. Elliott on the courts at Central Park West and Eighty-ninth Street yesterday afternoon. Bostwick was on the owe-thirty mark and gave Elliott fifteen to boot, but he managed to get one set and draw another at 8 -- 8 before darkness stopped the game.

Tammany Hall is the most powerful force now at work for non-partisan government in the City of New-York. The plan of governing the city as a business corporation without regard to politics makes converts slowly, and does not hold all that it makes. Indifference is one great obstacle to the progress of the cause, backsliding through disappointments at imperfect results is another.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 4.--Starting from Philadelphia this morning, the Liberty Bell to-night, amid a blaze of red fire, invaded the very heart of the one-time Confederacy. In quaint old Alexandria there was marked reverence for the bell, and many heads were uncovered as the train pulled slowly through the town.

MUNICH, Oct. 4. -- In the Landtag to-day Baron von Crailsheim, President of the Council of Ministers and Minister of Foreign Affairs, replying to an interpellation in regard to the case of Louis Stern of New-York, said that Stern's appeal for a pardon had been refused after being heard by the Council of Ministers.

The Board of Estimate, at its meeting yesterday, decided to begin the consideration of the preliminary budget for 1896 on Oct. 16. The estimates of the Department of Public Works, Mayor's office, Board of Aldermen, and Mayor's Marshal will be taken up on that day. The Police, Fire, Law, and Building Departments will be taken up on Oct. 17, as will also the Bureau of Elections.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, via Galveston, Oct. 4. -- The Banco Union at Quito, whereof Manuel Palacios is manager, is reported to be in a critical condition because of a doubt that the new Government will assume the indebtedness of the old.

Considerable testimony of interest and importance was brought out yesterday, when the investigation by the Commissioners of Accounts into the Dock Department methods under the Tammany regime was resumed.

The movement for municipal reform begun at the meeting of the Chamber of Commerce on Thursday took definite shape yesterday when the Committee on Municipal Reform of the Chamber selected forty-six representative men -- merchants, bankers, and lawyers -- who, together with the four members of the committee, will direct their energies toward the fusion of all elements in politics opposed to Tammany rule.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is take by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

WINFIELD, L.I., Oct. 4. -- While A. Lievenday, a tinsmith, was doing some repairing around a chimney of a house belonging to Mrs. J. Hartley, a widow, this morning, his tinkering pot was upset. The burning charcoal embers soon ignited the dry shingles, and in a few minutes the roof was on fire.

The September Grand Jury, which went out of existence yesterday, was much displeased because some of its actions had been anticipated in the city newspapers. In order to remedy this, if possible, the jury yesterday handed up the following presentment:

-- To accommodate the increased travel to Atlanta, Ga., on account of the Cotton States and International Exposition, beginning to-morrow, in addition to the two limited trains now in operation between New-York and Atlanta, via the Pennsylvania Railroad and Southern Railway, "Piedmont Air Line," a third train will be put on, which will be known as the Exposition Flier, leaving New-York daily at 11 o'clock A.M., reaching Atlanta the following morning at 10 o'clock.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 4. -- City Treasurer Lucien Knapp did not appear before the Board of Aldermen to-night to explain his failure to comply with their resolutions regarding the transfer of balances in the department funds and the issuing of bonds. The board adjourned from Tuesday night, in order to give the City Treasurer a hearing before presenting to the court the impeachment articles adopted against him.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 4. -- "Money for Misisons" was all day the theme of the two houses of the Episcopal Convention, which, in accordance with the constitution, sat together as the General Board of Missions. Some of the narrations were pathetic, others were pleading, but the majority bristled with criticism of the failure of the American Church adequately to hold up the hands of its representatives in other lands.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 4. -- Candidate Patrick Jerome Gleason is a busy man nowadays. Between showing his historic axe to visitors and holding consultations with his axe-men, the aspirant for Mayoralty honors has few minutes to spare.

CHARLES W. DAYTON, Postmaster of this city, is a candidate for one of the Supreme Court Judgeships. His character and his attainments, his standing in the community, amply justify this honorable ambition. Mr. DAYTON is strong in the Democratic Party of the city. A great number of the district leaders of the Tammany organization favor his candidacy, although he is not a member of Tammany Hall.

Oswald Ottendorfer, who arrived in New-York yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner Normannia, after five months among the watering places of Germany, was interviewed last night by a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

The first number of a new monthly magazine, entitled International Trade, has just been issued by Henry Glassford, 66 Broad Street. Its aim is to call attention to the foreign markets of the world where the manufactured products of the United States may be sold at a profit.

-- The edition de luxe of Hall Caine's "Manxman," announced by the Messrs. Appleton, will comprise two volumes. There will be forty gelatine prints of actual scenes, and each copy will be signed by the author.

Complete failure has resulted from the attempts made by Brooklyn's detectives to discover who it was that murdered CHARLES HENRY. The crime was committed four months ago, and to-day the case is as mysterious as it was on the day when the so-called "good son" led the police to his father's mangled body, and, standing beside it, charged his shiftless brother with parricide.

The Executive Committee of the Democratic Party in Kings County at 12:30 this morning announced positively that an amicable agreement had been reached by committees representing that organization and the other wing of the Democratic Party.
The West End Auxiliary of the Woman's National Republican Association, and the Harlem Auxiliary held their first October meetings yesterday.
([he St. James's Budget, (weekly edition of The St. James's Gazette,) London, one of the most conservative and authoritative of literary periodicals, says of the Funk Vagnalls Standard Dictionary:

The brewers of this city are disturbed by a recent ruling by Judge Pryor, in the Court of Common Pleas, that a liquor license is not property in a legal sense and cannot therefore, be transferred or assigned.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 5. --During the terrible second Winter no one did more to save the Plymouth Colony from starvation than Squanto, a good Indian, whose name has since been given to one of the high knolls which overlook Boston Harbor on the southern side. Squanto was one of several Indidans whom Capt. John Smith captured when he explored Boston Harbor in 1614.

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- Though the Foreign Office professes to be satisfied with the full and prompt acceptance by the Pekin Government of the ultimatum forwarded to it by the British Government, demanding the degradation of Liu Ping Chang, Viceroy of Se-Chuen, for his connection with the Se-Chuen riots, the trouble growing out of the overt hostility of the Chinese to British subjects is not over.

Last week at the theatres was not dull, for we had a comparatively new Hamlet, who was the topic while he lasted; the Peasant Players from Schliersee made their first appearance here, and the season of German plays in Irving Place was opened auspiciously. Mr. Conried, as usual, has a competent company, and Sudermann's new play is so clever that it is likely to be soon seen in an English translation.
A mass meeting of the McKinley Club of the Sixth Assembly District, in the Germania Assembly Rooms, on the Bowery, last night was startlingly interrupted.

Prince Kropotkin we know of principally for his scientific writings, which he presents quarterly. These are highly interesting articles, and frequently quoted in American journals. We know, too, why he has chosen England s a country of refuge, for were he ever again to put his foot in Russia he would be sent to Siberia. Once having suffered a long incarceration, he naturally dreads a second one.

Judge PRYOR'S decision that licenses to sell liquor are not property has very naturally created a fluttering among the brewers, whose security for money advanced often depends in part upon the negotiableness of a license. It is to be hoped that a final decision may be had as speedily a possible upon the question thus raised, and Judge PRYOR has shown every disposition to facilitate this decision.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore, professor in charge of the Department of Public Instruction of the American Museum of Natural History, resumed yesterday at the museum his course of lectures to the teachers of the City and State of New-York, which are given under the auspices of the State Department of Public Instruction. The subject of this lecture was "The Atmosphere."

The last of the unusually long list of international contests of 1895 is now ended. It was the intercollegiate trial at athletics between teams from Yale University, the American champions, and Cambridge University, the English college champions. As in all the others, the American representatives won and the American eagle roosted high last night.
" It is $3 for a hand, $3 for a foot, but you can't have your head cast at any price."
MILLBROOK, Oct. 5. -- One of the finest school buildings in the State has been erected in this village, and is about to be opened for use.

Two little American girls -- Frances I. and Constance Fairchild, the daughters of Mr. G.M. Fairchild, Jr., a well-known merchant of this city, who owns a beautiful country seat, Ravenscliffe, near Quebec -- are just now the most talked of persons in all Canada. They caused to be erected a handsome marble tablet in honor of some of Gen. Montgomery's brave volunteers who fell at the siege of Qebec.

Widespread public interest was aroused by the article recently published in THE NEW-YORK TIMES showing the nature and rapidity of the destruction being done on the face of the Palisades. Few persons were aware of the fact that most of the serious damage had been done within the last five years, and many were under the impression that the work of the quarrymen had been going on steadily for at least twenty-five years.

The coming week will see the reopening of many of the women's clubs in this city and Brooklyn. In most of them the work for the next year was all planned before the gavel fell for the last time last Spring, and the first meeting of the Autumn will set no record of incompleteness.

WOONSOCKET, R.I., Oct 5. -- South-bound train No. 1,657, the New-York boat freight, the fastest freight on the Worcester Division of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Road, ran through an open switch at Blackstone Junction, at the State boundary, this afternoon, and ran into a turn-table pit, wrecking the engine, nine loaded cars, and the turn table. The dead are:

" Democratic Party Reform Organization" is the name adopted last year by the men who put Mr. EVERETT P. WHEELER in nomination for Governor, and as that organization polled more than 10,000 votes last year it was entitled to nominate a State ticket this year by convention. It has done this, retaining the same designation and adopting a full-rigged ship as its emblem.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 5. -- The first tournament of the National Golf Association closed yesterday with the open meeting. The wind blew half a gale over the links, and the air was cold. Fine play, therefore, was quite impossible. But under the circumstances, the scores were remarkably good, and had the professionals played under the conditions of Thursday big records would have been made.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 5. -- The United States Naval Academy will have completed fifty years of existence Oct. 10. Friends of the institution have suggested that there should be some celebration of this event, but so far there has been no organized effort to bring it about.

There is a possibility of a hitch in the proposed transfers of Police Captain Delaney from Charles Street to Tremont and Capt. Schmittberger from the latter station to Charles Street. The changes were decided upon at a secret meeting of the Police Board on Friday, and Acting Chief Conlin was directed to transfer the two Captains early next week.
ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 5. -- The first Fall meeting of the New-England Society was held this evening in the Music Hall Building.

LONDON, Oct. 5.--[Copyright, 1895, by THE NEW-YORK TIMES.]--The prevalent sense of an impending disturbance with which last week closed has had its prompt and emphatic justification. England, it was felt, had become ready to substitute deeds for words, and was on the point of delivering a blow somewhere.

If John Howard, the noble prison reformer of the last century, could step from his sacrificial grave and walk around and about the world, his soul would be filled with a great and holy joy. For he would see that the foundation he laid of humane and progressive treatment to those "in durance vile" has been fittingly built upon by all civilized countries.

BOSTON, Oct. 5. -- In the Republican State Convention at Music Hall to-day the tail wagged the dog and wagged him most effectually and energetically. On a formal ballot for candidate for Governor the supporters of Greenhalge polled 1,363 votes, while the secret societies opposed to him could muster only 391 votes. Yet the minority dictated the platform, and the tone and temper of the speech delivered by the presiding officer.

Sales of property during the past week have not been many, despite the numerous negotiations on foot, and several of the best of them were first brought to public notice yesterday. Broadway realty still seems to be in most demand by investors and builders. An especially notable instance is that of the southwest corner or Broadway and White Street, 49.10 by 150.2 1/2 by 50 on Franklin Alley by 150.3.

In your issue of the 16th uit. I observe under the caption of "D{'. Depew's Trip Abroad," a statement of the Doctor's on English politics and statistics which rather surprises me, and I can only account for it on the supposition that his informants were Radicals and faddish. The following sentence I take issue with, viz.; "That the strength of the Tories is in the cities."

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 5. -- The Board of Trustees of Princeton University has determined upon another reform, and to-day and yesterday saw-the first practical and successful test of the new step. This time it has attacked the liquor habit.

PARIS, Oct. 5. -- The funeral services over the body of Prof. Louis Pasteur took place in the Cathedral of Notre Dame to-day. About 9 o'clock this morning the first group of delegates arrived in the Rue Dutot, in front of the Pasteur Institute, where the body had been lying in state, and thereafter there was a steady stream of people to take part in the obsequies.
I beg the use of your columns to express my thanks to those who sent kind letters and cable messages to me in England and telegrams and letters since my return home.

BAYONNE, N.J., Oct. 5. -- Society folk in Bayonne devoted much of their attention to Company I's fair and bazaar, conducted in a huge tent, throughout the week. This local company of militia labored earnestly to provide attractions. As the company does not possess quarters in the new Jersey City armory, although attached to the Fourth Regiment, Company I held this fair to raise funds toward securing an armory or quarters in Bayonne.
A plan for the new consolidated library building of the Astor, Lenox, and Tilden foundations has been put forward by Jean Fuerst, an architect whose offices are at 160 Fifth Avenue.

The report which is to be laid before the stockholders of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company at their annual meeting is unusually interesting, because of its announcements concerning the New-England Road, the experiments with electric motors on the Nantasket Branch, the Stamford trolley system, and the steamboat lines.

BOSTON, Oct. 5. -- Capt. Thomas Olys of the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company, which left this afternoon to observe its Fall field day in Richmond, Va., this morning received the following letter:
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5. -- Gen. Russell A. Alger of Michigan arrived here yesterday. He was asked about the outlook in the East for the next campaign.
Montclair, N.J., Oct. 5. -- A musical tea was given in Club Hall this afternoon. The Misses Lerch, banjoists, and Miss Harvey as Trilby were the principal attractions.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Oct. 5. -- One man was killed and three injured, the upper part of the city was left in darkness, and the traffic on one branch of the North Hudson Railroad was suspended through the bursting of the flywheel in the power house of the Hudson Electric Light Company, at Fifteenth and Bloomfield Streets, at 3:30 o'clock this morning.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 5. -- The Democrats of Onondaga County are organizing for an aggressive campaign. In three Assembly District Conventions to-day they nominated men of prominence and ability. The First District Convention was held at Camillus, D. Munro Hill of Elbridge, ex-Supervisor of that town, was nominated for member of the Assembly, Robert E. Dorchester of Marcelius making the nominating speech.

A lady, let us say, wants to open a school for her ex-serfs. She surmounts the many, varied, and unexpected obstacles put in her way by all sorts of functionaries; she obtains by prodigies of diplomacy the permission to open the school, and looks for a lady teacher. Naturally she applies to one of the teachers' seminaries, or to a pedagogical school for girls.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- Judge Showalter, in the United States court, to-day entered an order which effectually reconciled the contending factions of the Whisky Trust, and puts an end to all litigation in connection therewith. This is the order which has been for some time pending, and which was asked for by both parties to the controversy.
Efforts to procure the nomination of a fusion anti-Tammany ticket were transferred yesterday to the headquarters of the Republican County Committee, in West Thirty-eighth Street.
The Reinhard Assembly committee, appointed to investigate the condition of girls working in shops and factories, met yesterday in the Aldermen's Chamber, City Hall.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5. -- Sanford Robinson, an American, President of the Champerico Railroad, in Guatemala, and M.J. Pinol, agent of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company for Guatemala, who arrived here on the San Juan yesterday, are highly indignant over the treatment they received at the hands of Mexican officials while at Acapulco.

NEWPORT, Oct. 5. -- Beautiful weather and the unusual attraction furnished by the golf tournament is giving Newport its longest season in years. Next week, however, will see a great change, undoubtedly, for, with nothing else on the season's programme to keep cottagers here, there is likely to be a speedy exodus to New-York and Boston.

The knowledge that France would fly at Germany's throat as soon as it seemed safe to do so has been a permanent factor in all international bargainings and controversies; the terror that some untoward accident might precipitate the always-threatened conflict, even against the desires and best judgment of the combatants, has never ceased to haunt the imaginations of men.

LONDON, Oct 5.--With the growth of distrust in the Armenian propaganda, caused by the reports of responsible correspondents that the stories of the outrages at Sassoun and elsewhere were greatly exaggerated for political purposes, the pressure of strong party influence on the Salisbury Government in favor of modifying the demands that have been made on the Porte also increases.

BUFFALO, Oct 5. -- Senator Henry H. Persons, whose home is in the town of East Aurora, was the boss of the Erie County Convention here to-day. He broke the slate made by the regular organization and knocked out two members of the Executive Committee, who were candidates for the most important offices to be filled, nominating men of his own choice for those places.

The advocates of a "short campaign" might as well desist. The Democrats began campaigning about as soon as they found that the tax rate had been increased 50 per cent. Their work was pretty well in hand when they nominated the star ticket at Syracuse. Has the Republican campaign begun; or is it to be the only "short" one? There had not been any Warner Miller "maintenance" meetings in Herkimer up to last Sunday.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 5. -- This week the cards of invitation were issued for the wedding of Miss Caroline Allison Reinhart and Edward M. Van Buren. The wedding will be one of the society events of the Fall, and will take place in Grace Church Wednesday evening, Oct. 23. -- The bride to be is the eldest daughter of Joseph W. Reinhart, ex-President of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad.

ALBANY, Oct. 5. -- Monday is the last day for filing party nominations with the Secretary of State. The nominees on the Democratic State ticket were certified to-day. A messenger had to be sent to where ex Gov. Flower is stopping in the woods to get his signature to the Democratic certificate, and it was returned to-day properly signed.

The history of the Beth Israel Hospital shows that not all philanthropic work undertaken by charitably inclined Israelites of the metropolis has smooth sailing. Since its inception, and up to the present time, this most worthy charity of the most densely populated section of the city has had a hard and continuous struggle for existence.

Notice came from Albany yesterday that the East Side Bank of 135 Grand Street, this city, had formally declared itself in voluntary liquidation. Such a course had been decided on several months ago, Superintendent Preston of the State Banking Department having found in February last an impairment of $11,897.75 in the bank's capital of $100,000.

MISSOULA, Mon., Oct. 5. -- A number of Northern Pacific officials were in this town yesterday. There were Assistant Superintendent G.W. Dickinson. Receiver McHenry, ex-Senator Sanders, Counsel McNaught, and others, all factions being represented. Senator Tom Carter came from Helena, in response to telegrams. Mr. Sanders arrived from Seattle last Thursday.

Doubtless there are few among what may be called the laity who are aware of the utility of the science of astronomy. That it is of any use at all is hard to believe for those who only look at the pursuit of the subject as a dilettante occupation followed by men who are usually a little queer in their habits of living and careless in their dress and general appearance.

Will the bicycle supersede the horse in the army? The gentlemen identified with the organization of the United States Military Wheelmen believe it will. They are enthusiastic in the matter and predict, when the organization is perfected, on Oct. 15, in this city, a measure of success commensurate with the possibilities.
Justice Willard Bartlett of the Supreme Court and Public Administrator William B. Davenport of Brooklyn returned from their trip to Japan Friday night. They left Brooklyn July 27.

It must often be mortifying to a writer of true genius to find how much more interesting he is than his books to the people whom he addresses with pathetic irony as his "readers." Many authors, no doubt, derive their principal gratification in life from this fact. Their so-called "works" are nothing but the advertisement of the peepshow which they are longing to open to the eyes of all and sundry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Assistant secretary McAdoo of the Navy Department has had occasion to rebuke a naval court-martial which tried a young naval apprentice who was charged with desertion. The conduct of the court is a fair example of the carelessness and incompetency of naval courts-martial, and the inadequacy of the administration of justice in the service.

ALBANY, Oct. 5. -- Yale and Union opened the football season here on the Ridgefield Oval this afternoon In a decidedly one-sided game, vhieh was witnessed by 2,500 persons. From the start Capt. Thorne saw that he had an easy adversary, and did not put up the game he otherwise ould have done. This is shown by the fact that he kept his men about.

BUENOS AYRES, Oct. 5. -- A dispatch from Rio de Janeiro to the Diario says that Great Britain, France, and Italy have decided upon a plan of combined action with a view to obtaining satisfaction of their respective claims in Brazil.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- "Old Mackinac" has passed from the possession of the War Department to that of the State of Michigan. The place is famous as binding the Old army with the new and as the scene of so much that is historical and legendary. The formal abandonment of Fort Mackinac, Michigan, as it has been known officially, was announced in an order to the army by Secretary Lamont recently.

Capt. John Barr arrived from Glasgow yesterday on the steamship City of Rome. He has been sailing Howard Gould's twenty-rater Niagara in English waters during the Summer, and has come back to spend the Winter with his family at Marblehead. Capt. Bart said that he was glad to get home again, though he had nothing but praise for English yachtsmen generally.

Mme. Modjeska will begin a two weeks' engagement at the Garrick Theatre to-morrow night, with a revival of "Measure for Measure," which will be acted also Tuesday, Wednesday, and Saturday nights. "Mary Stuart" will be presented Thursday and Friday nights, and "Camille" Saturday afternoon. Tuesday of the second week Modjeska will produce a new play, written for her by Clyde Fitch, and called "Mistress Betty."

The eighth year of the Artist-Artisan Institute opened Oct. 1 and will continue until June 1. The classes begin under the most favorable auspices, with much enthusiasm on the part of both pupils and instructors. The large and well-lighted rooms at 140 West Twenty-third Street are open daily from 9 o'clock A.M., to 5 o'clock P.M., and at night from 7:30 o'clock to 9:30 o'clock P.M.

The will of the late Mrs. Elizabeth T. Eldredge of West Newton was allowed in the Probate Court at East Cambridge this morning without opposition, although it had been announced that there would be a contest. The will disposes of property estimated to he worth over $1,000,000, and a codicil makes a further disposition of the additional sum of about $400,000.

Of the half million Italians that are in the United States about 100,000 live in this city, and including those who live in Brooklyn, Jersey City, and the other suburbs the total number in this vicinity is estimated at about 160,000.

Confidence in the business outlook was strengthened yesterday by the bank statement, which showed the transfer of $8,000,000 from idleness to activity in the period since the last previous weekly report. Expansion of loans and substantial decrease in legal tenders and deposits reduced the surplus reserve by nearly $6,000,000, to $10,471,525.

The new era in commercial circles, of which The Globe has spoken, was emphasized by THE NEW-YORK TIMES in a recent three-column article, giving a series of interviews with leading advertising agents, pointing toward an era of business prosperity greater than any which this country has enjoyed in many years.

PANAMA, via Galveston, Oct. 5.--The audacious claim against the Colombian Government of the English railway contractors continues to be the all-absorbing topic of discussion in the press and of excitement among all classes.

The question has sometimes been asked by persons whose enthusiasm for golf is greater than their knowledge of it, whether old people can play the game. The query is not so surprising in this country, where the royal game is yet in its infancy.

PHOENIX, Arizona, Oct. 5. -- The stage from Florence was stopped by a lone Mexican horseman at the crossing of Dry Lake, eight miles west of Case Grande Station, on the Southern Pacific Railroad, Thursday afternoon. Through the bravery of A.J. Doran. President of the Territorial Legislative Council, the highwayman was all but captured and forced to make a hasty flight without stopping to secure his booty.

In two previous articles in THE NEW-YORK TIMES the history of the various uprisings and revolutions in Cuba has been traced from 1818 down to 1878. The present article will treat of the period from 1878 to the present year.
