ALBANY, Oct. 5. -- The resignation of John Vanderpoel as Lieutenant, junior grade, and Surgeon in the First Naval Battalion, has been accepted by the Commander in Chief. Surgeon Vanderpoel has held the office from which he now retires since July 8, 1891. He is a native of Albany.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Oct. 5. -- The fine stone drinking fountain presented to this town by Col. W.L. Brown of New-York will be formally dedicated and presented to the town Thursday, Oct. 10. An invitation has been extended to all citizens of Berkshire to be present Gov. Greenhalge and other distinguished men are expected.

Amos J. Cummings was unanimously nominated last night for Representative in Congress from the Tenth Congressional District by the Tammany Convention, which met at the Pequod Club, in West Twenty-fifth Street. The nomination is for the vacancy caused by the death of Congressman Campbell, Republican, a few weeks after the last election.
A romance that had its inception three years ago in a pretty little city on the River Rhine came to a climax in the Supreme Court, in this city, yesterday.

Ex-Register Hugh McLaughlin, now, as ever, the absolute boss of the machine organization of his party, yesterday put an end to Democratic harmony in Brooklyn and Kings County. At his instigation every candidate for the Mayoralty and other offices put forward by the independents at their conferences with the so-called representatives of the regulars was rejected.

" Which w're shorely gettin' into the shank of the year," observed the old cattleman, as he puffed meditatively at his cigar. "Yere it is October already. When I'm a yearlin' I'm a Ute if time flies so fast. Things is a heap more dreamy then, an' a week last longer'n a month does now. I reckon it's because I'm gettin' aged that away.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 5. -- Cleveland administered a severe drubbing to Baltimore to-day in the Tem pie Cup series. Young was a complete puzzle to Hanion's men, and they faced him like de- feated men from the first inning. The only chance the pennant winners had to score was in the eighth inning, when they bunched three singles and Keeler orossed the plate.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 5. -- The Rev. H.E. Chapman, Moderator of the Hartford Baptist Association, which comprises most of the churches of that denomination in Northern Connecticut, has resigned the pastorate of the Baptist church in New-Hartford and will remove to Haverhill, Mass., becoming the pastor of the Baptist church in that place.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 5. -- This has been a charming week in Lenox, and the bright, breezy October days have been utilized for many driving parties. The cottagers who come here year after year are proud of the beautiful scenery, and delight to take their guests, especially those who are strangers to the beauties of Berkshire, out driving to show them the matchless coloring of the foliage.

I had just completed my college course, and was somewhat leisurely considering the choice of a profession, when my father, Judge Paxton of Mayville, died suddenly, and at once I was brought face to face with the more practical question of earning my daily bread. He had been a celebrated lawyer, charming, brilliant, improvident, with a large income from his practice, and a larger expenditure from his generous style of living.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- The King Street Methodist Episcopal congregation, whose church stands in King Street, at the summit of the hill overlooking Long Island Sound, celebrated to-day its freedom from debt by special jubilee services.
LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 6. -- A raging gold fever has settled down on this section of country over a startling discovery of placer treasure in Seward County, about twenty-five miles west of this city.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 6. -There are a few miserable men in this city. They are the delegates to the Republican City Convention and the delegates to the City Convention of the Jefferson wing of the Democracy.

BERLIN, Oct. 6. -- Although Chancellor von Hohenlohe and most of the members of the German Ministry will resume their departmental duties in Berlin to-morrow, consideration of the legislative programme for the coming session of the Reichstag will not begin until the Emperor shall return to Potsdam, which he will do Oct. 21. During his stay in Rominten the Kaiser has busied himself far more with foreign affairs than he has with domestic matters.
Earth, air, and sky combined to make a perfect day for the ramble in Van Cortlandt Park yesterday by the members of the Torrey Club and Brooklyn Institute botanists.

LORAIN, Ohio, Oct. 6. -- An accident attended the laying of the cornerstone for the new St. Mary's Catholic Church in this city this morning, which caused the death of a little girl and injuries to over twenty persons, of whom it is believed ten are hurt fatally.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- It is probable that three monitors will be added to the active force of the navy in a short time. Secretary Herbert has given instructions that work shall be pushed on the Terror, the Monadnock, and the Puritan. These ships have been a long time under way, and there appears to be no effort making on the part of the constructors to have the ships ready for service.

An interesting portion of Mr. Giffen's report on the wages of the manual-labor classes is that relating to indoor men and women servants. The figures show that out of 213 indoor man servants employed, the wages of half -- butlers, valets, coachmen, -- range from 30 to 60 per annum, in addition to board and lodging, and that 55 is the average of the total number.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- Much interest has been shown here in the articles published in THE NEWYORK TIMES looking toward the saving of the Palisades of the Hudson from ruin. The remarkable natural beauties of the Palisades are appreciated by all Washingtonians who have viewed them, and there would be great satisfaction here if steps could be taken to preserve them for all time to come.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 6. -- When antitoxine was announced, some of the first to arrive in this country came to the Johns Hopkins University. Dr. William H. Welsh, pathologist to the Johns Hopkins Hospital and Professor of Pathology in the university, gave special attention to the matter and delivered a notable paper on it at the convention of the Association of American Physicians in Washington a few months ago.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 6. -- All sorts of athletic sports have now begun at Harvard, with the single exception of baseball. No call for candidates has been issued as yet. There is no Captain, and not even a temporary Captain has been appointed. This accounts for the failure to do any Fall work.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Oct. 6. -- William Starr, twenty-nine years old, assistant steward of the Down-Town Association, New-York, who said he lived at 334 West Seventeenth Street, New-York, while attempting to board a Second Street horse car in Hoboken to-night, was pushed off by a person whose name is not known, and thrown in the street, where he was found by two policemen.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- The new students of Vassar College were tendered a reception, Friday evening, by the Young Women's Christian Association of the college. Miss Margaret Campbell Brown, President of the association, received with Dr. Taylor and Mrs. Taylor, and Mrs. Kendrick. As a great majority of the students are members of this organization, it is one of the strongest in college.

Last year a considerable number of the members of a company in one of the Pennsylvania regiments were infected with typhoid poison while attending the annual encampment, and became ill after they had returned to their homes. If our memory serves us, two or three of the cases were fatal.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Oct. 6. -- The week just past has been one of the quietest opening weeks that Stevens has seen for some time. This is due, in a great measure, to the stand taken by the Faculty against rushes in the halls and on the campus, several members of the class of '98 having been suspended for some time last Spring for engaging in a disturbance in one of the halls.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- Secretary Morton has issued the following order under the act of March 2, 1895:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- The first of the new battleships will shortly go into commission. The Indiana is ready for her trial trip, which is slated to take place Oct. 15. A thirty-two-mile course off the Massachusetts coast, between Cape An and Cape Porpoise has been selected. The line officers and the engineers who are to conduct this trial have been instructed in the technical details of the test.

The revival of business has quite perceptibly stimulated the "foreign-estate" industry. The latest product is the Poultney estate, which, we think, is brand-new. It is situated in England, but whether in the Bank of England or in the Court of Chancery we are not at present informed.

The second annual century run yesterday of the Lexington Wheelmen was a decided success as far as general management was concerned, although the attendance was not at all as large as had been expected. This was due to the fact that several other runs of a like nature were scheduled for the same day, notably that of the South Brooklyn Wheelmen.

The recent erection of a modest slab over the grave of Salmon Portland Chase by friends in the East called forth the remark from a local paper that "citizens of Cincinnati were too thoughtless -- we will not say too mean, for that would not be true. It remained for somebody in New-England to send a humble slab to be placed on that grave."

We called attention last week to the very remarkable and rapid increase in the product of the South African gold mines, which had advanced in four years (1890 to 1894) from a volume of $10,000,000 to $38,000,000, with a pretty sure prospect of reaching $50,000,000 this year and $60,000,000 in 1896.
HAVANA, Oct. 6. -- Gen. Echagne reports from Holguin that his command, numbering 1,600 men, routed, on Sept. 25, about 3,800 rebels under Antonio Maceo.

The steamship Paris once the queen of the transatlantic race course, brought her belated passengers into port last night. The vessel was sighted off Fire Island at 4:35 o'clock in the afternoon, but it was not until nearly 11 o'clock that her gangplank was got over.
BUENOS AYRES, via Galveston, Oct. 6. -- The Committee on the Interior of the Senate has reported favorably a bill granting a subsidy of $100,000 yearly to a steamship line.

If MARTIN LUTHER were again one of us, and of the Committee of Fifty, he would be the right man in the right place. We cannot feel quite so sure of Mr. CHARLES STEWART SMITH. He may risk and forfeit everything for the sake of the empty achievement of beating Tammany, even though he have to throw over all his moral baggage and make his committee a mere annex to the Platt machine.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 6. -- A week has now passed since the opening of the college year, and some idea of the year's work is obtainable. There is every prospect of a very successful year in all the educational departments. There is an unusually large registration, especially in the scientific branches.
ALBANY, Oct. 6. -- Chapter 79 of the Laws of 1895 contains this clause:
The Rev. Dr. T. De Witt Talmage preached a farewell sermon to his Brooklyn friends at the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church last evening.

COLLEGE POINT, L.I., Oct. 6. -- The handsome new Catholic church here was dedicated this morning by Bishop Charles E. McDonnell, with imposing ceremonies, A procession, headed by the New-York Protectory Band and including the Bishop in full canonicals, followed by a number of acolytes and priests, passed around the church, inside and outside.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 6. -- In 164 towns out of 168 in the State, elections will be held to-morrow, This includes city elections in four cities, but does not include the larger cities of New-Haven, Hartford, and Bridgeport. The elections to-morrow are what are known as the little town elections, and, as a general thing, attract little or no attention outside of the limits of the town.

A recent communication in THE TIMES has dispelled much of the confusion and uncertainty prevailing in the public mind on the subject of neutrality. A representation of what seems to be the law and consensus of opinion among jurists about the questions involved in belligerency may be of equal interest at this moment.

" A Point Blank Question" is the subject of the sermon that the Rev. T. De Witt Talmage, D.D., has prepared for THE NEW-YORK TIMES this week, the text being taken from Second, Kings, x., 15: "Is thine heart right?" The sermon follows:

Henry Gower Hose of 234 Forty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, was a prisoner at the Tombs Court yesterday, charged with the extortion of $5 from Marc Moustaki, an interpreter of the court. Hose says he is a reporter, and has been interested with John H. Jewell in the publication of The Excise Herald.

Chairman Charles S. Fairchild of the New-York State Democracy received, yesterday morning, a protest from the Thirty-fifth Assembly District, bearing 600 signatures. The protest is an appeal to the people of the district against the action of three members of the New-York State Democracy Executive Committee in overruling a protest against the legality of a primary election held Sept. 16 in the Thirty-third District.

BRESLAU, Oct. 6. -- The Congress of the Social Democrats opened here today. The railway station and the streets were crowded from an early hour in the morning, and making the congress one of the most suc cessful that the Socialists ever have held. The arrivals seemed to be far more numerous than usual. Enthusiastic greetings were exchanged between the delegates and their friends at the offices of the party.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct6. -- The Liberty Bell sped through the lovely Roanoke Valley, over the rugged Blue Ridge Mountains, and down through the picturesque valley of East Tennessee, on this October Sabbath. There has been no firing of guns, no blaring of brass bands, no wild hurrah, but the country that furnished so many Union soldiers during the rebellion demonstrated beyond question its intense loyalty and patriotism.

There was published in Dun's Review yesterday an interesting table, showing the movement of prices during the last few months as compared with prices in October, 1890. The decline is represented by percentages, the prices of October, 1890, serving as a basis and being indicated by 100.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Oct. 6. -- Said Pasha, formerly Grand Vizier, or Prime Minister, who was removed to make room for Kiamil Pasha, has been appointed Minister of Foreign Affairs, the position occupied by him before he was made Grand Vizier, Turkham Pasha retiring from the post.

Seth Sprague Terry, Commissioner of Accounts, made public yesterday at his residence, 41 West Twenty-fifth Street, the result of an investigation of the Register's office made by himself and Commissioner Rodney S. Dennis.

The Grand Jury, in presenting Mr. JOHN B. IRELAND and in expressing its regret that it cannot find an indictment against him which would be likely to result in a conviction, has fairly reflected the opinions of those who have followed the investigation that was occasioned by the collapse of Mr. IRELAND'S building.

" Boss" McLaughlin, the rehabilitated leader of the "regular" Kings County Democracy, sat in his house in Remsen Street yesterday and gloated over the wreck he has made of the hopes of all good Brooklyn Democrats for party harmony. He viewed the lamentable situation with intense satisfaction, for it was an evidence of his own personal power in the organization he has ruled so many years with an iron hand.

Frank Thorn, an engineer, was killed shortly after dawn yesterday by the bursting of a boiler in Alexander J. Howell Son's soda manufactory, on the banks of Westchester Creek, in the village of Westchester. The engine room was wrecked, and it will cost $5,000 to repair damages.
Major Gen. E.A. McAlpin, Adjutant General of the State of New-York, was a passenger on the steamship City of Paris, which arrived yesterday.
HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 6. -- The election of B.A. Kimball, '55, to the Board of Trustees to fill the vacancy caused by the death of ex-Gov. Prescott is gratifying to alumni and undergraduates.

In the Church of the Divine Paternity yesterday, the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Eaton spoke on "The Real Issue -- Shall the Laws Be Enforced?" There was a large attendance, and the doctor's remarks were followed with close attention.

No definite agreement was made yesterday about a fusion ticket by the anti-Tammany forces. Five members of the Chamber of Commerce Committee sat all the afternoon in the City Club in conference with a delegation from the State Democracy, with Mr. Lauterbach representing the Republicans, and with seven members of the Good Government Clubs. After nearly five hours' continuous sitting an adjournment was taken until this morning at 9 o'clock.
ANNAPOLIS, Oct. 6. -- The Naval Academy opened on Tuesday its fifty-first academic year, with Capt. Philip H. Cooper as Superintendent.

Seven distressed mariners, whose little vessel, the schooner William Frederick, was wrecked in an October gale, reached this port yesterday on board the fruit steamship Franklin. The craft was overwhelmed by the seas, pitched her masts overboard when the turmoil was at its height, and was barely able to lift her drowning decks above the water, when rescue came.

In point of attendance and interest it is expected that the tenth annual convention of the New-York State Societies of Christian Endeavor will surpass any that the societies have held, with the exception of the National conventions. The arrangements have now been perfected by a comnlittee composed of the following members:

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 6. -- The Divinity School was formerly opened Wednesday, and started on a firm basis. An opening address was made by Prof. Stevens in the Marquand Chapel. His subject was "Scientific Theory in Theology." Following the opening speech an informal address was made to the students by Prof. George P. Fisher, now Dean of the Faculty in place of Prof. Day.

MONDAY -- A.M. The course of the stock market last week was somewhat irregular, but, as speculation was largely confined to the professional element, the movement of prices had little significance. Those who have acquired stocks during the Summer snow no disposition to part with them at the present level of prices, notwithstanding that the average is within a fraction of the highest of the year.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 7. -- By a viva voce vote which was sufficiently large in volume to restrain the minority from challenging a division, the House of Deputies of the Episcopal Convention to-day placed itself on record as being willing to surrender one of its most valuable prerogatives, and practically the only one that enables it to hold the whip hand in preventing the House of Bishops from making of itself.

The building of the Yorkville Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, 153 East Eighty-sixth Street, was wrecked by a fire at 3:30 o'clock yesterday morning. The fire started in the gymnasium in the rear of the main building, and alongside the bowling alley.

The late John R. Bolles of this city used to relate a very good story of witchcraft, digging for buried treasure, and the robbery of a Spanish galleon, all of which occurred inside the limits of New-London, within 150 years. The last two features of the story are facts in history.

A meeting was held under the auspices of the City Vigilance League of the Twenty-ninth Assembly District, in the First Union Presbyterian Church, last night. The church was crowded to the doors. A large number of women were in the audience. All were anxious to hear the Rev. Dr. Parkhurst, President Roosevelt, and Joseph Murray, President of the Excise Board, who were the principal speakers of the evening.
The preliminary work at Barnard College began yesterday with the registration of students for the coming year.

In the Supreme Court yesterday Judge Barrett handed down a decision denying the application of Augustin Daly for the continuation of an injunction against Lillian Walrath, restraining her from producing Sudermann's play, "Honor," and also dissolving the temporary injunction obtained against her.
CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 7. -- Five armed and masked men halted an electric car in the outskirts of the city between 8 and 9 o'clock to-night, and searched the passengers in regular train-robber fashion.

NEWTOWN, L.I., Oct. 7. -- The forty days and forty nights' fair announced to open to-day on the Maspeth race track did not have an auspicious introduction. About the time that the exhibitors were arranging their exhibits at the race track Supreme Court Justice William J. Gaynor opened the October term of the Queens County Court of Oyer and Terminer at Long Island City, and the fair opening was postponed on account of the weather.

UNIONTOWN, Penn., Oct. 7. -- Baron Hengemuller, the Austrian Minister at Washington, accompanied by Consul Dessewil of Pittsburg, General Manager Thomas Lynch of the Frick Coke Company, a representative of the Carnegie Steel Company, and Fred A. Kail, a Slav banker and editor of Connellsville, made an investigation into the condition of the 10,000 Slavs in the coke region Saturday.

Pursuant to notice issued several weeks ago, the stockholders of the Bank of America met yesterday to pass upon the proposition to reduce the bank's capital from $3,000,000 to $1,500,00. The subject had been well canvassed even before it received publicity, for the notice for the meeting indicated plainly that the owners of a majority of the stock favored the change.
Tammany Assembly nominations were made in most of the thirty-five districts last night. A number of the conventions met only to adjourn until to-night or to-morrow.
The New-York Section of the Society of Chemical Industry, a branch of the well-known English body, met at a dinner last night in the new banquet hall of the Hotel Empire.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 7. -- The General passenger Agents of the Southwestern lines engaged in Texas interstate traffic have adopted the agreement previously submitted for the maintenance of rates and regulation of passenger business. The meeting elected for Chairman W.W. Kent, General Passenger Agent of the Chicago, Peoria and St. Louis line.
Stop and think before you invest money in a dazzling scheme, the projectors of which promise a dividend of 60 per cent. the first year.

One of our McKinley contemporaries attempts to answer our question why Englishmen who have been engaged for years in the manufacture of woolens and worsteds are now investing their money in American worsted factories, if, as some of our Republican friends assert, the woolen and worsted industries here were paralyzed by the new tariff and continue to be in a deplorable condition.
The Methodist ministers of this city are incensed because of the conduct of the leaders of various anti-Tammany organizations in holding conferences on Sunday to arrange for a fusion ticket.
Sorosis's first meeting in her twenty-seventh year was a housewarming at the Hotel Waldorf yesterday, where hereafter she will have her headquarters, and the members entered into it with zest.

GLASGOW, Sept. 25. -- Challenges for the America's Cup fill the air for the moment. These, no doubt, are inspired by the result of the Defender-Valkyrie meeting. Sir George Newness, it is rumored, is prepared to challenge, as are also Mr. Rose, who has purchased the first-class racing cutter Satanita, and an unknown English millionaire.

BUFFALO, Oct. 7. -- The Republicans of the Fifth Assembly District to-day took issue with the State platform, and gave expression to views on the excise question which may be regarded as "liberal" in the extreme. The resolutions say:

PANAMA, via Galveston, Oct. 7. -- The contractor who is to supply 1,000 native laborers to the Panama Canal Company sailed to-day for Cartagena and Savanilla to recruit his men. The first laborers under his contract are expected to arrive at the beginning of November.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 7. -- The residents of the northern part of this city were startled at about 4 o'clock this afternoon by a tremendous roar, followed by a rocking of the earth, which seemed at the time to have come from beneath them. It was but a few moments later when many of them knew what it meant.

Dr. Daintree of Lewiston started Monday for Twin Dams, down East, with the intention of setting out bright and early Tuesday to hunt deer. Several local hunters are of the opinion that deer are more numerous this year than they have ever been in the memory of the hunters of this day and generation.

The registration rooms at the Academy of Music in Brooklyn were thronged yesterday with delegates to the tenth annual State Convention of the Societies of Christian Endeavor. The out-of-town members began to arrive yesterday morning, and several hundred were registered by early afternoon.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 7. -- The Democrats of New-Jersey have completed a new organization -- one in keeping with the personal dignity and political cleanliness of Candidate Alexander T. McGill. His acceptance of the nomination was made contingent on the very change that has been produced, and, while he did not have any voice in the selection of the Democratic General State Committee, the selection of the Committeemen at Large was entirely made by him.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 7. -- The articles published in THE NEW-YORK TIMES in reference to the preservation of the Palisades have elicited universal praise throughout Hudson County. There is but one opinion on the subject, and that is that the Palisades must be preserved, and that if New-York and New-Jersey are not able to devise ways and means to secure the desired object, then National aid should be invoked through Congress.

The one hundred and forty-second collegiate year of Columbia College began yesterday, when all the departments of the university were set in activity. Students have been gathering during the past week from far and near, and yesterday morning the college chapel was thronged with young men eager to hear President Low's opening address.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors met here to-day for the purpose of reapportioning the county into Assembly districts, under the recent decision of the Court of Appeals, which decided that for Senatorial, Assembly, and Judiciary purposes the towns of Westchester, East Chester, and Pelham, which were annexed to New-York, will remain in Westchester County until the next census.

That is a pleasant rumor which sets forth that Great Britain is inclined to treat with "JAMES I. of Trinidad" for the purchase of the island whereby he has acquired his princely title and with it the right to issue postage stamps and to bestow decorations upon deserving persons destitute of the same.

TRENTON, Oct. 7. -- It is generally conceded here by those who are familiar with legislation that no action will be taken by the legislators until the subject of the preservation of the Palisades is clearly understood by the members from South and West Jersey. During the last session it was almost impossible to get the members from the lower end of the State to read the bills that were pending.

David Hannigan, who killed Solomon H. Mann, to avenge his sister, Mamie Hannigan, will probably never be tried. Assistant District Attorney John P. McIntyre practically confessed yesterday that Hannigan would be let off on a plea of insanity. In fact, Mr. McIntyre fairly forced this plea on the defense, and the question seems simply to be whether Hannigan is to be discharged outright or sent to an insane asylum.

The approaching convention of the United States Military Wheelmen should be a memorable affair, since it may mark the beginning of a new era in the army. It will be held at the Broadway Central Hotel next Tuesday, and no doubt will be attended by Gen. Nelson A. Miles, commanding the Army of the United States, and many others prominent in military affairs.

Of at least three of the changes of bill in the city theatres last night, it was difficult to say which was the most important. But Mme. Modjeska's portrayal of Shakespeare's Isabella was at least, held vividly in the memory of all who saw her notable revival of "Measure for Measure" five or six years ago, while Mr. Drew had done "Christopher, Jr.," as near to the metropolis as Brooklyn.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 7. -- The Democratic County Convention for Dutchess County assembled at the Court House, in this city, this afternoon, and named the following ticket: County Judge -- Daniel W. Guernsey, Poughkeepsie, renominated; Surrogate -- Charles Morschauser, Poughkeepsie.

BERLIN, Oct. 7. -- The Tageblatt says that the Turkish populace is inflamed against England, and that the appearance of a British fleet before Constantinople is feared, as it would doubtless lead to sanguinary scenes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Commissioner Browning of the Indian Bureau has taken decisive steps to prevent the Carrbett-Fitzsimmons fight from taking place in the Indian Territory. He addressed the following letter of instructions to Indian Agent Wisdom at Muscogee, Indian Territory, this afternoon:

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- During the Revolutionary War, Gen. Washington's headquarters was above these picturesque rocks part of the time. Because of the many historical facts clustering about the rocky formation, if for no other reason, the Federal Government should secure and preserve the place in as nearly its original condition as possible.

KINGSTON, Oct. 7. -- At the Republican Convention for the Second Assembly District of Ulster County, held at New-Paltz this afternoon, James Lounsberry was nominated as a candidate for the Assembly. Dr. W.E. E. Little, his Democratic opponent, announced positively to-day that he would not accept the nomination.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The report that the War Department intended to abandon Madison Barracks, at Sackett's Harbor, N.Y., was received with some surprise at the department. While it is the plan of the Secretary of War to withdraw troops from stations no longer needed for the protection of the surrounding country, there are some stations which are likely to remain garrisoned.
The Sinking Fund Commission placed itself on record at a meeting in the Mayor's office yesterday as being in favor of the speedy improvement of the water front on the Upper Harlem.

Without a vestige of history to remember him by, the oldtime St. Lawrence River pilot has disappeared. Who he was or where he came from was all forgotten years and years ago. When writers penned the histories of Jacques Cartier, Paul de Chomedy, and the other historic figures of early Canada, the more humble pilot was forgotten.

Some seventy-five years ago a middle-aged gentleman might occasionally have been seen in a London byway, astraddle upon a low wooden frame fitted with two clumsy wheels; his tall hat upon a crown of curls, his coattails flying from his waists, and his meagre legs pegging along the ground as he oared his ungainly machine into the pace of a modern perambulator.

Notwithstanding that it was an off day for racing at Gravesend yesterday, there being no stake events down for decision, and that the weather was anything but inviting, the attendance was up to the average. The races resulted in tame affairs. The only semblance of a contest was in the fifth event, in which Belle Amie beat Wild Violet in a ding-dong finish by half a length.

UNION HILL, N.J., Oct. 7. -- Considerable talk was created last night by the fact that a policeman in uniform was a conspicuous figure at the Union Place Methodist Church. No one knew what he was there for, nor would the officer say.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The North Atlantic squadron of evolution, now at Hampton Roads, has completed the programme arranged at the beginning of the Summer, but it is probable that the movements will be continued through the Winter, the fleet remaining intact.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- Major James B. Burbank of the United States Army, detailed for duty with New-York's National Guard, said to THE NEW-YORK TIMES representative that he was glad that there was some agitation going on to preserve the picturesque Palisades. The plateau on the top of the natural wall of rocks made famous in history by the Revolutionary Army in 1776, Major Burbank says, could be used for military instruction.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- There is a nice international law question imbedded in the gunboat contract pending in the Navy Department. As related in these dispatches, there is an ancient treaty, the result of our war with Great Britain in 1812, which has given us some trouble in recent years.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- Considerable interest is manifested in the Second Assembly District Democratic Convention, which will be held in William's Bridge Thursday morning, because John Sheehan, one of the Board of Trustees of this village, is making a determined effort to secure the nomination for Assemblyman.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 7. -- The intercollegiate tennis tournament begins here to-morrow morning at 10 o'clock. Play will probably last until Saturday. All the larger colleges will be represented. Yale is thought to have the best chance of first honors in both singles and doubles, as the present champions, Chace in singles and Chace and Foote in doubles, will represent the college again this season.

The regular Democratic Senatorial Conventions of Kings County were held in Brooklyn last night. Ex-Register James Kane, up to the last moment was a candidate for the nomination in the Third District, but he was prevailed upon to withdraw.

NORTH TONAWANDA, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- A double murder was committed on P.W. Scribner's lumber docks at an early hour this morning, and up to the present time fourteen men have been placed under arrest and search is being made for others.

You are thrown in with a veritable expert in sanitation. You are bent on acquiring certain information relating to the purification of water. Pump him you must. Pretty soon you will find that he declines being worked, or, to change metaphors, will give you no opinion at all. Generally the greater his reputation, the more reticent is he.

Messrs. Terence Farley's Sons have bought of George W. Reddell four lots on the south side of Eighty-seventh Street, 100 feet east of Riverside Drive, and will at once begin the erection of five four-story dwellings on the plot.

The anti-Tammany forces spent yesterday in making and breaking political slates. Every hour between 9 o'clock in the morning and 8 in the evening some man who expected to be called upon to serve the people was elated by the news that his name had been put upon the slate. About the same moment the candidate whose name had been taken off to make room for the new man was correspondingly depressed in spirits.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 7. -- Receiver Frank Bigelow of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company says there is no truth to any of the press dispatches from Seattle and St. Paul regarding the demanding of the resignation of General Counsel William Nelson Cromwell, and the alleged agreement between Judge Jenkins's receivers and Judge Hanford's receiver, Mr. Burleigh.

Probably more than a thousand people stopped by the Frog Pond on Boston Common between 5 and 6 o'clock in the evening and looked up into the trees. It was apparent that something unusual was going on. The air was filled with birds uttering sharp cries, and the din was kept up for over half an hour.

Commissioners of Accounts Terry and Dennis, the report of whose investigation of the Register's office was published yesterday morning, paid a visit to Magistrate Mott at the Tombs Police Court yesterday afternoon.

The Figaro gives, apropos of the Channel Islands, some interesting details of "un rot en exil" but of a King who never reigned and an exile who never wandered. The monarch in question is Prinet I., and the last of that dynasty. He reigned over the Ecrehous Islands, a small group lying to the northeast of Jersey.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 7. -- Col. Waring, New-York's Street Cleaning Commissioner, and Mrs. Waring closed their cottage to-day and went to New-York for the Winter.

BRESLAU, Oct. 7. -- All of the leaders of the Social-Democratic Party were present at the opening of to-day's sitting of the Socialist Congress. Herren Singer and Seylitz were elected presiding officers and were welcomed in a song by a selected choir as they took their seats. The hall was decorated with red and blue drapery, the red predominating.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Oct. 7. -- Three indictments were to-day returned by the Grand Jury against Dominick Wagner, the priest. They are for assault, seduction, and abduction, but it is probable that they will be nolle prossed, as the priest, having married Miss Steidel Saturday night, she cannot be compelled to appear against him.

Some of the Good Government Clubs are properly enough concerned with the nomination of candidates for the Legislature, on the ground that State legislation is necessary to prepare the way for municipal reform and good city government. But it is difficult to see why they should consider the question of joining with the Republican organization in making any nomination for the Senate or Assembly, or give support to any candidate of a Republican Convention.

ALBANY, Oct. 7. -- Edmund H. Smith of Albany was appointed to-day State Reporter by the Judges of the Court of Appeals, to succeed the late Hiram E. Sickels. The salary of the office is $5,000, and the perquisites are reckoned equally large.

ALBANY, Oct. 7. -- Gen. Austin Lathrop, Superintendent of State Prisons, called upon Gov. Morton to-day in company with his counsel, Charles E. Brackett of Saratoga, and conferred with him regarding the charges which have been filed against him by ex-Congressman Wever of Plattsburg.

The Cooper Union Labor Bureau was opened yesterday in Room 15, Cooper Union. It is under the management of the New-York Association for the Improvement of the Condition of the Poor, and will supply places for men out of work free of cost.

Upon demand of Edward M. Grout, the McLaughlin Democratic candidate for Mayor of Brooklyn, Almet F. Jenks yesterday afternoon withdrew from the "regular" Judiciary ticket, and Josiah T. Marean was substituted as a candidate for Justice of the Supreme Court.

HAVANA, Oct. 7. -- Further details have been received of the loss of life and damage caused by the heavy rains Sept. 30. Several localities in the Vuelta Abajo, the great tobacco-growing district, were inundated. It is known that fifty-six persons were drowned, and it is feared that the number may be increased when the remote hamlets are heard from.

The Scott habeas corpus proceedings, begun in such a sensational manner last Saturday, came to a most tame ending yesterday, before Judge Beach, in the Supreme Court. Lloyd Mifflin Scott appeared in court, accompanied by his young wife, whom he had been accused of "abducting," in order that she might not be able to appear against his father, John C. Scott, in the Philadelphia court, where she is plaintiff in a suit for $100,000 damages.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7. -- After deliberations extending over a period of two months, the big traction amalgamation was finally consummated at noon to-day, when the three extensive local street railway systems -- the Philadelphia, Electric, and People's -- were joined together under the title of the Union Traction Company of Philadelphia.

Facts submitted to a candid world will enable that judicious being, the average voter, to make up his mind about the candidates put in nomination last night by the Republican City and County Convention.

The Cambridge athletes were tendered a reception by the Harvard Club at the Clubhouse, 27 West Forty-fourth Street, last night, and they had a rattling good time. It was a strictly informal affair. In the absence of President J.C. Carter, Vice President Henry S. Van Duzer made a short address welcoming the Cambridge men and the Yale men who defeated them on the athletic field last Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- "The Heart of Maryland," which was to have been produced at the Grand Opera House to-night, has been postponed until to-morrow evening. In order to insure a perfect first performance.

The October Grand Jury was sworn in yesterday by Judge Allison in part I. of the Court of General Sessions. It was the first Grand Jury Judge Allison has charged. The Judge was very brief. He devoted himself almost exclusively to the question of the overcrowding of the Tombs and the necessity of finding relief from this condition.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 8. -- It was stated here to-night on the very best of authority that the burglars who have been visiting in this city all the Summer, and have taken such a liking to the place that they are still here, are going to call on the Improvement Commissioners and ask them what they mean by threatening to call out the militia to drive them out of the town.

GLASGOW, Sept. 27. -- Lord Dunraven has quite eclipsed his last sensation by his latest, which was cabled here yesterday. His arrangement to retain the Valkyrie at New-York, and issue another challenge for the America's Cup has left Glasgow under a suspicion that the New-York Yacht Club is responsible for putting his Lordship off his balance.
The Aldermen held their regular weekly meeting yesterday. The Law Committee reported that the Police Commissioners had agreed not to molest stands until Nov. 15.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 8. -- The Democratic City Convention, held here to-day, resulted in a big surprise -- something unheard of in the history of the party in this section. Out of the contest for the Mayoralty arose a division of the local Democracy on an entirely new line -- a strife between the old blood and the young.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The President has refused to interfere further in the case of Thomas St. Clair, convicted in California of murder on the high seas and originally sentenced to be hanged Sept. 21, 1894. He has been respited four times, the last carrying the date of execution to the 18th inst. In his indorsement, the President says:

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Oct. 8. -- The football season has opened very auspiciously at Lehigh. With most of the players of last year's team to rely upon, Capt. Trafton should be able to produce an eleven this year that will do honor to its alma mater. The team has been under the coaching of McClung until Oct. 1, and he has infused into it the fast and snappy play for which Lehigh is noted.

Several hundred persons, including real estate brokers and speculators, and quite a fair sprinkling of outsiders, were present in the New-York Real Estate Salesroom at noon yesterday, grouped about the stand of Mr. Peter F. Meyer, who sold in Partition that portion of the late George G. Sickles's estate which lies in this city.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Oct. 8. -- The situation here is unchanged. The patrols have been materially increased by infantry and cavalry, but the presence of the additional troops fails to restore public confidence. The streets are completely deserted at night. All efforts to persuade the Armenians to leave their churches have proved fruitless, the refugees declaring that they would not trust to the Government's promises of protection.

John H. Stoddart and his cousin, Alexander Stoddart, who own two of the most beautiful residences on the Palisades, are greatly in favor of the purchase by the State of that tract of land lying between the edge of the river and the bottom of the cliffs. John H. Stoddart said yesterday:

The Southern New-York Baptist Association began its twenty-fifth annual meeting in the Riverside Baptist Church, at Ninety-second Street and Amsterdam Avenue, yesterday afternoon. The association comprises sixty-six churches, the pastors of nearly all of which were present, the few who were absent being represented by laymen.

One of the new provisions of the election law, that part of Chapter 1,034 of the Laws of 1895 which provides that in the registration books there shall be columns for "Personal Description," was generally regarded yesterday as an encroachment on self-respect and personal liberty, and offensive.
HERKIMER, Oct. 8. -- The home of ex-Senator Warner Miller and the "place" kept by "Tony" Mackin are about three miles distant from each other.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 8. -- The farmers of Monmouth County who dispose of their truck in Asbury Park during the Summer months will hold an indignation meeting here next week, to protest against the action of the Asbury Park authorities in arresting several of their number for refusing to take out licenses for the sale of their products.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 8. -- Thomas M. King, Second Vice President of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company, and President of the Cleveland Terminal and Valley Railway, in discussing the report that the Baltimore and Ohio will expend $1,000,000 for terminal facilities in Cleveland, said: "There is valuable terminal property in Cleveland, which has never been improved.

Acting Chief of Police Conlin sent to the Board of Police yesterday a formal account of his stewardship as executive head of the department since May 27, 1895. The report was read at the executive session of the board, but no action was taken.

Register LEVY, in his reply to the "criticisms and insinuations" of the report of the Commissioners of Accounts, succeeds in showing that in some points that was an unfair and one-sided document, but it is a very lame reply nevertheless. Neither the Commissioners nor the Register make clear the comparison between the expenses of the office now and several years ago, and it is not evident that there has been either improvement or the reverse.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 8. -- It took the Jefferson Democracy three hours to-day to nominate a candidate for Mayor. The delay was not due to a scarcity of candidates, but to the desire of some of the parties interested to secure the nomination by the convention of Dr. Benjamin G. Strong, the Republican candidate for Mayor.

JAMESBURG, N.J., Oct. 8. -- The Monmouth Presbytery was in session here to-day as an ecclesiastical court, and, after deliberating for the greater part of the day, decided that it would try the case of the Rev. Howard T. Widdemer, formerly pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Asbury Park.

The sharpshooters were very much in evidence last night at the Lexington Avenue Opera House, and the ladies who are toiling for the benefit of the Fritz Reuter Home fund were, in consequence, kept busy selling chances and articles to the liberal Schuetzen folk. It was Schuetzen day at the fair, and the rifle clubs were so largely represented that all the available space in the different halls and rooms was occupied by them.

Tammany held conventions in all the city Senatorial districts last night. At some of the conventions the excitement ran at the highest pitch, and the scramble to get on the Senatorial ticket was so great that there is great dissatisfaction to smooth over.

Although all the candidates have not yet been nominated, and a great deal of preliminary work remains to be done, the members of the Executive Committee of the Democratic Party in Kings County are already preparing for a vigorous and aggressive campaign in the cause of good government.

CHATHAM, N.J., 0ct. 8. -- There will be one more big road race before the season closes, and the Chatham Wheelmen will have charge of it. It will be a twenty-five mile handicap, open to all, and owing to the nature of the prizes, it will undoubtedly attract many high-class entries. This event is not a money-making scheme, for every cent derived from entrance fees will be spent for trophies.

The conference of the Good Government Clubs, which had already been twice adjourned, met last night in the United Charities Building, with Charles Stewart Davison in the chair, to hear and vote upon the report of their Executive Committee and to decide finally whether they would support the fusion ticket nominated by the Republicans, or would fill the two vacancies in their own ticket and put it as a third straight ticket in the field.

BOSTON, Oct. 8. -- It was a rather inhospitable, although eminently characteristic, greeting which the weather of New-England gave to the visiting members of the Cambridge athletic team to-day, but this was more than made up for by the warmth with which the visitors were entertained, both by the members of the Boston Athletic Association and by the students of Harvard College.
NEWBURG, Oct. 8. -- The Orange County Democratic Convention met at Goshen to-day. Every town and ward was represented.
The following letter from the Honorary President of the St. Petersburg Chess Club was received by Mr. Pillsbury at the Brooklyn Chess Club, yesterday:

NEWBURG, N. Y., Oct. 8. -- The annual council of public-school Superintendents of the State of New-York will be held in the Board of Education Hall in this city next week, commencing on Wednesday, and continuing three days, with three sessions each day. The officers are Dr. R.V.K. Montfort of Newburg, President: A.B. Blodgett of Syracuse, Vice President, and Emmet Belknap of Lockport. Secretary and Treasurer.

BRESLAU, Oct. 8. -- At to-day's session of the Socialist Congress, Herr Autrick of Berlin moved that the election of the expelled delegate, Herr Ruedt, be formally invalidated. The motion was adopted.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The record of the court-martial in the case of Col. James Forney, second ranking officer of the Marine Corps, recently tried at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, was made public by Acting Secretary McAdoo to-day. He was charged with falsehood, embezzlement, making and using false papers, and culpable inefficiency in the performance of duty.

ALBANY, Oct. 8. -- The State of New-York, as provided by the new Constitution, will be divided Jan. 1, 1896, into four, instead of five, judicial departments; the General Terms, Superior Courts, and Courts of Common Pleas will cease to exist, and there will rise in their stead the appellate divisions of the Supreme Court.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 8. -- The city election to-day resulted in the election of the entire Democratic ticket by an average majority of 4,000. The election was fought strictly on party lines.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Gen. William Mahone died at Chamberlain's Hotel at o'clock to-day from the effects of a paralytic stroke sustained a week ago, Monday, Sept. 30. He had been totally unconscious for more than forty-eight hours previous to his death, and passed away seemingly without pain.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 8. -- The Temple Cup goes to Cleveland, and, as last year, the champions must content themselves with second place in the contest for the prize. Tebeau and his Spiders took to-day's game with something to spare. Neither side scored until the seventh inning, but, despite the goose eggs and cold weather, there was lots of enthusiasm because of numerous brilliant plays.

Various stories of renewed attempts to reorganize the Union Pacific Railroad Company have lately been in circulation. There is without doubt a strong disposition on the part of some of the large holders of Union Pacific securities to get together and try to place the property on a solvent basis.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct 8. -- Editor Thomas F. Lane of The Summit Record and Orange County Herald, who last week married Senator Blackburn's daughter, had to postpone his wedding trip in order to appear here to-day in the Union County Court as a defendant in a libel suit brought against him by Dr. William H. Lawrence, Town Treasurer of Summit.

Charles Eliot Norton, who edited this slender volume of bequests from Mr. Lowell's muse, might have been less chary of words in his introductory note. He states that the book contains those of the author's latest poems which he himself might have wished to preserve. "Three of them were published before his death.

Whatever may be said or claimed for the "fusion" ticket as a ticket, the Republican County Convention displayed a violently partisan spirit in all its proceedings, and the party which it represented will claim it is a party victory if the ticket is elected. So much may as well be recognized before the election as afterward.
E.A. Edsall, as counsel for the heirs of James J. Bailey, yesterday made a bitter attack before Surrogate Fitzgerald on J.H. Muller, one of the clerks of the Surrogate's court.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The following is a list of the baseball players of the League reserved for next season, or already under contract: ...

The Democrats put themselves squarely in favor of Sunday whisky during their convention at Syracuse. Under the pharisaical plea of personal liberty the orators of the occasion took advantage of every possible opportunity to express their sympathy with the saloon keepers of New-York City, who are just now smarting under the rigid enforcement of the Sunday-closing law by Police Commissioner Roosevelt and his brother Commissioners.***
ALBANY, Oct. 8. -- The Attorney General rendered several opinions relative to election and the duties of election officers to-day.
At the book sale by Bangs Co. yesterday, the following were some of the prices obtained:

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 8 -- Miss May Goelet, daughter of Ogden Goelet, returned from New-York to-night, where she had been to be fitted for her bridesmaid's gown, which she will wear at the wedding of Miss Consuelo Vanderbilt to the Duke of Marlborough. Mr. Goelet's son, who has been ill several months, though somewhat improved, is yet unable, to leave his bed.

What a howl of contemptuous laughter must have gone up yesterday from the limbo, wherever it may be, now occupied by the late Mr. TWEED and his associates! New-York officials with access to public funds arrested for larceny, for petty larceny, and for such extremely petty larceny! A wretched $1.10 to be divided among two -- surely that is an amount which in the old days even office boys would have regarded with scornful derision.

The City Civil Service Board has called examinations for two of the important positions in the Fire Department, recently opened to competition by Mayor Strong. The positions are those of Auditor, at $3,000 a year, and Fire Marshal, at $2,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The Rev. Dr. T. De Witt Talmage formally accepted to-day the call of the First Presbyterian Church of this city to be its co-pastor, and became a member of the Washington Presbytery. The proceedings incident to his acceptance took place at Kensington, a suburb of Washington.

JAMAICA, L.I., Oct. 8. -- At the Republican County Convention for Queens County held in the Town Hall here to-day, the following delegates to the Republican Senatorial Con vention, to be held in this place Thursday, were elected:
The Rev. Dr. Parkhurst made a religio-political address last night to 7,000 Christian Endeavorers at their State Convention in the Academy of Music and Plymouth Church, Brooklyn.

William F. La Rose, thirty-nine years old, who for some time has been robbing houses, to which he gained entrance by posing as a collector of gas bills, was arrested Monday night. He was remanded in the Essex Market Court yesterday morning until this afternoon at 2 o'clock. La Rose is an ex-convict, who is registered as 2,259 among the photographs in the Rogues' Gallery.

Louis I. Musliner and Alfred Katz, the two clerks in the Register's office for whom warrants were issued Monday at the Tombs Police Court, went to the court yesterday morning, accompanied by their counsel, Abraham Levy, and gave themselves up. The warrants were in the hands of Policemen Gavagan and Dixon, and they were at once served.

It was a decidedly unpleasant day for racing at the Gravesend track. The weather was raw, and the bleak wind chilled the few people at the track all through. The favorites performed so badly, save in two of the races, as to complete the chilling business, and bettors went home cold as to their blood and frost-bitten as to their finances.

In several Western States, notably in Minnesota and Iowa, the health authorities -- municipal as well as State -- have been led by the experience of New-York and Massachusetts to inquire concerning the prevalence of tuberculosis in their dairy herds, and to take measures for the protection of the people by attempting to eradicate the disease.

Germany has been enjoying Egbert Humperdinck's fairy opera, "Hansel und Gretel," for more than a year. Americans have from time to time heard excerpts from it performed by local orchestras -- Mr. Damrosch leading the way with the prelude on Dec. 7, 1894 -- and these have whetted curiosity. Of course, it was bound sooner or later to reach America, for our managers eagerly snap up anything that has been a success anywhere.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The plank of the Democratic platform in Massachusetts directing attention to the increased exports of manufactures under the new tariff, will receive added force when the returns for the eight months ending with August are officially made public by the Bureau of Statistics of the Treasury.

By a vote of 27 to 4, and after a long discussion in the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday afternoon, the Committee of Fifty indorsed the fusion ticket nominated on Monday evening by the Republicans and the State Democracy.
The leaders of the German-American Reform Union have called a meeting of their General Committee, to be held in Maennerchor Hall, 205 East Fifty-sixth Street, at 8 o'clock to-night.

Tammany's City and County Convention will be held to-night. There will be no postponement. There are no outside bodies of importance to confer with in the case of the Wigwam, and, besides, there is no time for delay. The Tammany ticket will be put in the field, and it will read very much as follows:

The Committee of Fifty ate its leek without much swearing yesterday. The Rev. Dr. PARKHURST couldn't trust himself, so he fled to Brooklyn and passed the day among the Christian Endeavorers. The Good Government men, sorely perplexed between duty and expediency, decided to stand their ground for principle.

ALBANY, Oct. 8. -- A decision of much importance to policy holders of insurance companies was to-day handed down by the Court of Appeals in the case of the People of the State of New-York against the American Steam Boiler Insurance Company of New-York City.

The St. Andrew's Golf Club will begin to-day its annual Fall tournament, and the various contests will last throughout the week, play beginning each morning at 10:30 o'clock, and continuing in the afternoon. The tournament will be opened this morning with the competition for the President's Cup, presented by John Reid, for "two-year-olds."

BUFFALO, Oct. 8. -- An independent Democratic city and county ticket was put in the field to-night by the leaders of the Cleveland Democracy. The candidates are excellent men, who will poll a big vote and will probably be elected if indorsed by the regular organization to-morrow. But there was much dissatisfaction with the way the nominations were made.
HAVANA, Oct. 8. -- A dispatch from Madrid says that the Government has increased to $50,000 its fund for the relief of the sufferers by the inundation of the Vuelta Abajo district.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 8. -- The Exposition City to-day gave the Liberty Bell the most cordial greeting that the historic relic has ever received. It was literally an outpouring of the people, such as has never been witnessed in this town, and it would be impossible to conceive a more notable exhibition of patriotism.

ALBANY, Oct. 8. -- The Democrats of Albany County held their Assembly Conventions to-day. There were no contests for the nominations in any but the Third District, which was made strongly Democratic by the Republican Supervisors when they reapportioned the county last Spring. This convention was held this evening, the other three at noon.

W.D. Grand's silver cup sale of high-stepping bangtails turned out to be much more of a success than even Mr. Grand had hoped. In spite of the exceedingly disagreeable weather, a large crowd was present at the Exchange at Fiftieth Street and Broadway, from early morning till dusk. Representative horsemen were present from almost every important city in the Union.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct 8. -- The last week on the gridiron at Princeton has brought out the strong and the weak points of the team more than the previous days of training of the season, and the students are beginning to make up their minds pretty positively concerning the prospect for winning team this year.

Having obtained control of the New-England Road, the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company will now proceed to improve its Air Line Division -- the road from New-Haven to Willimantic -- and it is announced that there will be a new train between this city and Boston, going by way of this Air Line and covering the distance in five hours.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 8. -- The Republicans of the County of Westchester held their County Convention to-day in St. John's Hall. Two hundred and one delegates were present.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The following-named applicants, having successfully passed the September examination, have been appointed cadets at the Naval Academy:

ALBANY, Oct. 8. -- Senator Hill to-day read the platform adopted by the Republican County Convention in New-York with an amused look on his face. A correspondent of THE NEW-YORK TIMES asked him what he thought of it and the ticket nominated as the "fusion" ticket.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 8. -- President Cleveland has declined the escort tendered him by the Second Company, Governor's Foot Guards of this city, on the occasion of his visit to the Atlanta Exposition about the middle of this month. The President, in his letter, which bears date of Oct. 6, says:

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

Lord SACKVILLE, who became very well known throughout this country seven years ago as Mr. SACKVILLE-WEST and as British Minister at Washington, is still dissatisfied with the treatment he received upon that occasion. He has written a pamphlet for the sake of vindicating himself and of exposing the American officials who were constrained to send him his passports.
Assistant District Attorney Vernon M. Davis began yesterday the work of putting in the testimony that he declares will send Morris Schoenholz to prison for forty years or more on a charge of arson.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9. -- The six alleged counterfeiters, Greenberg, Rosengarten, Friedman, Friendburg, Silberman, and Traukel, who were arrested on information furnished by David Firestine of Landisville, N.J., had a further hearing before United States Commissioner Craig this afternoon. Five were bound over to court under $1,000 bail, that of Traukel being increased from $500 to $1,000, notwithstanding the appeal for mercy made by his attorney. Greenberg was held under $2,000 bonds.

Mayor Strong yesterday notified the heads of the various city departments that when they appear before the Board of Estimate and ask for appropriations for the ensuing year economy should be considered. Following is the letter the Mayor sent to the heads of all the city departments:

There is said to be much fear among the supporters of tickets more or less straight, especially "up the State," lest losses occur at the election through the mistakes of voters in using the new ballot. For instance, in consequence of the action of the reform Democratic organization in Brooklyn, the Democratic candidates for State offices will head two different columns on the blanket ballot.

A tremendous explosion caused great alarm to the people living in the neighborhood of One Hundred and Fifteenth Street and Pleasant Avenue at 6:30 o'clock yesterday morning. As the Standard Gaslight Company occupies the territory between One Hundred and Fourteenth and One Hundred and Sixteenth Streets, from Pleasant Avenue to the Harlem River, it was at once supposed that the works of the company had exploded, and that dire destruction had been caused.

An additional complication has been added to the Northern Pacific receivership tangle. The United States Circuit Court at Helena has appointed Edward Bonner of Missoula and Capt. J.H. Mills of Deer Lodge receivers of the Northern Pacific property in the Montana district, besides confirming the appointment of Andrew F. Burleigh by Judge Hanford in the Washington district.

Bax Ironsides is in town from Newport, and is much in evidence at the Waldorf, where he always put up when here. Of all the attaches of the numerous Legations at Washington, Mr. Ironsides is undeniably one of the most sought-after, and at Bar Harbor and the City-by-the-Sea during the season of outing was a welcome guest at all the fetes, dinners, and other functions.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 9. -- Henry C. Miner, J.H. McVicker, and Joseph Brooks to-day completed the plans for a syndicate in the control of theatrical matters that will have an important bearing on the future of the stage. After the meeting to-day the three men interested gave out for publication the details of their plan, which differs somewhat from the rumors that have been published concerning that enterprise.

President Thomas T. Eckert's report of the operations of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the year ending June 30, submitted at the annual meeting of the company yesterday, showed an increase in gross revenue over the preceding year of $365,364, an increase in expenses of $9,183, an increase in net revenue of $348,904, and an increase in surplus of $439,842.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 9. -- An imposing civil and military parade this morning escorted the liberty bell to Exposition Park. The procession was two miles long. It was watched by countless thousands of spectators along the line of march. Public school children were present in immense crowds. There were fully 40,000 people on the grounds.

Mr. Daniel B. Freedman has sold for the Sixth Avenue Railway Company to Henry Corn the plot 100 by 100 at the northwest corner of Sixth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, adjoining the site of the New-York Athletic Club's new building. Mr. Freedman bought for himself last Saturday from the railway company the southeast corner of Sixth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street.

The tenth annual State Convention of the Christian Endeavorers, which has been in session for the last two days, was brought to a close last night, with simultaneous meetings in the Academy of Music and Plymouth Church.

Mr. PURROY is the typical Tammany man of the Tammany ticket. All the foes of Tammany ought to fall upon him if any exemplary punishment is to be administered to the organization this Fall. It is unfortunate that his opponent, the fusion nominee for County Clerk, is put forward as the representative of the Platt machine, and that he is reported to be a protege of Mr. FREDERICK S. GIBBS.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 9. -- A religious canvass of Poughkeepsie, which has just been completed under the direction of the Rev. A.P. Vangieson of the First Reformed Church, shows that in this city of 25,000 inhabitants there are 12,391 churchgoers, of whom 5,236 are Roman Catholics. The Methodists number 1,836 and the Episcopalians 1,923.

The Independent County Organization, otherwise the Stecklers, decided at the County Convention held in Cooper Union last night to nominate a county ticket. A committee of thirty-five, including one member from each Assembly district, was appointed to attend to this matter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- The arrangements by Secretary Olney for the payment of the Mora claim have been nearly perfected, and the actual distribution of the great amount obtained from Spain is a matter of a very short time. Mr. Olney's method of distribution may cause some dissatisfaction among assignees, but it will be strictly in accordance with law.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 9.--One man was killed and twenty-five persons were injured at Manor Station, on the Pennsylvania Railroad, twenty-four miles east of here, at 7:30 o'clock to-night, by a car on a westbound mail train, No. 13, jumping the track.

The friends of the late Abram C. Bernheim, who died from the effects of typhoid fever at his home at Arverne, L.I., on July 24, after a career supposed to have been marked only by the strictest business integrity, have been hearing strange rumors to the contrary of late that have made them fairly gasp with amazement and horror.

The Larkin family promises to become the special bugaboo of the officials of the Long Island Railroad. Frank J. Larkin was badly injured in the accident that occurred on the Long Island Road, at Parkville, on the night of Aug. 28, 1893. Larkin was at that time nineteen years old.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- The threatened trouble between American Protestant missionaries and the Catholics residing in Mexico, which was averted by the prompt action of Minister Ransom, is another illustration, say the State Department people, of the hurtful influence which may be exerted by injudicious and intemperate missionaries.

This is Tammany's ticket. It was put in the field last night at the biggest City and County Convention, in point of attendance that has been held in the Wigwam in recent years. It is precisely the same ticket that was forecast yesterday in THE NEW-YORK TIMES. Personal liberty and self-government were the themes of all the speeches.

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- A representative of The United Press called to-day upon Ambassador Bayard, who is the guest of the Marquis of Bath at Longleat, Warminster, Wiltshire, in reference to the attack made upon him by Lord Sackville, in a pamphlet printed for private circulation. Sackville's charge is that Mr. Bayard, in asking for the British Minister's recall in 1888, was actuated by political motives solely.

ALBANY, Oct. 9. -- Gov. Morton has pardoned Pasquale Bouchette, who was convicted in Westchester County in 1890 of murder in the second degree and sentenced to Sing Sing for life. The pardon, which becomes operative to-day, was requested by Judge Dykman, who wrote to Gov. Morton, saying that Bouchette acted in self-defense, and that his conviction and sentence were unjust.
Controller Fitch put up for sale by auction yesterday the franchise known as "the People's Traction Company franchise." The bidding lasted for several hours, and was in some respects remarkable.

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- The great Fall handicap, the Cesarewitch Stakes, was won at Newmarket to-day by C.J. Blake's filly, Rockdove, a 10 to 1 shot, by a half length from A. Taylor's colt, Bard of Avon, a 20 to 1 chance, who beat Col. J. Lloyd's colt, Count Schomberg, by a length and a half, the latter being at 25 to 1 in the betting.

EASTON, Penn., Oct. 9. -- The General Council of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in North America began its semi-annual session at St. John's Lutheran Church here at 10 o'clock this morning. In the absence of the President, the Rev. Dr. C.A. Stensson of Kansas City, the Rev. Dr. T.L. Seip of Allentown, President of the ministerium of Pennsylvania, presided and will officiate until the new officers are elected.

ELIZABETH, Oct. 9. -- Thomas F. Lane, editor of The Summit Record, scored a victory this afternoon in the libel suit brought against him by Dr. Lawrence of Summit, and which suit prevented his wedding trip.

ROME, Oct. 9. -- The letter recently written by the Pope to Cardinal Rampolla, Papal Secretary of State, protesting against the fetes in celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of Italian unity, has greatly stirred up the Liberals, and isi likely to add to the warmth of the popular reception of King Charles of Portugal.

ALBANY, Oct. 9. -- The nomination by the Democratic Reform Party in Brooklyn of a State ticket and the adoption by the State Convention of that organization of a full-rigged ship as a party emblem have troubled the managers of Democratic canvasses in many counties of the State.
Senor Henrique Jose Varona, who is considered by his countrymen to be one of the most eminent living Cubans, arrived here yesterday from Havana on the steamer Seneca.

BOSTON, Oct. 9. -- Owing to a heavy track, causing delay in the starting, but two races were completed at Mystic Park to-day. This will give the talent a chance to get their breath, for in both races the favorites were bowled over with case.

The bears who sold stocks yesterday covered to-day at advancing prices, and the whole list closed at a higher level. The trading, however, was almost wholly professional and more than a third of the day's business was done in Chicago Gas. In the early trading, Chicago Gas was depressed to 65 3/4, but from that point it rallied to 65 3/8, and closed at 65 1/4, a net gain of 1 1/2 points.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9. -- The sensation of the defense in the Durrant case was introduced to-day when Theodore Durrant took the stand. He walked to it with a firm step, and related his story of what transpired April 3, the day of Blanche Lamont's murder, with characteristic coolness. He was permitted to trace his movements from the time he left his home in the morning until he retired at night.
UTICA, Oct. 9.--There has never been such a political fight in this section of the State as the one which is now in progress for the election of a Senator in the Thirty-fourth District.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- The Western freight situation is becoming worse instead of better. Although no open tariffs were made to-day, further reducing the rates, it was openly reported that the lines were again secretly slashing, 35 cents now being quoted as the lowest figure, with an intimation that one road will make a twenty-five-cent rate to Colorado points within a few days at the most.

In an interview held recently with Gen. Nelson A. Miles at Washington. Frank G. Carpenter asked that distinguished officer where he thought would be the next advances in army matters. The General's answer will particularly interest cycling-enthusiasts and doubtless cause a lot of talk among the conventional men of the army. Here is his answer: "It will probably be in the line of transportation of men and equipment.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 9. -- The triennial Council of the Congregational Church met in this city to-day. The representative men of the denomination are present, and the Council will be in session until next Monday evening.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9. -- The steamship Australia arrived from Honolulu shortly before 7 o'clock this morning. She was placed in quarantine.

The General Committee of the German-American Reform Union resolved last night by a vote of several hundred to sixty-seven to support the Tammany ticket. The resolutions in favor of this course were prepared and moved by Edward Grosse, and the amendment to these, in favor of a neutral attitude, was moved by Theodore Sutro.

There were few busier men in New-York City yesterday than Edward Lauterbach, the Chairman of the Republican County Committee. He was so busy with political conferences that he was unable to reach his office in the Farmers' Loan and Trust Building, until 5 o'clock. He found time, however, to read the editorial in THE NEW-YORK TIMES entitled "A Scratcher's Year."

CROTON LAKE, N.Y., Oct. 9. -- The Republican Convention of the Third Assembly District of Westchester County met in Palmer's Hotel to-day and nominated for Assembly, by acclamation, James William Husted, son of Gen. James W. Husted, the "Bald Eagle of Westchester," who for twenty-two successive years represented the district in Albany.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- A dispatch to The Central News from Constantinople says that massacres of Christians have occurred at Rodosto, in Roumelia; at Silivri, forty miles west of Constantinople, and at Ismid, in Asia Minor, fifty-six miles southeast of Constantinople.

So many misstatements have been made in regard to negotiations for harmony between the two branches of the Democratic Party in Brooklyn, that two of the reform leaders, Charles J. Patterson, candidate for District Attorney, and Edward M. Shepard, candidate for Mayor, yesterday issued a statement denying them.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 9. -- A meeting has been called by the Soldiers' Memorial Association for Friday evening of all citizens of New-Rochelle interested in the soldiers' monument which is to be erected at Main and Huguenot Streets. The meeting is to be held in Lambden's Hall.

The University of Pennsylvania football eleven showed that it is already in good condition by the victory it won yesterday from the team of the Crescent Athletic Club. The score was 32 to 0, and only twice were the Crescents anywhere near making a touch-down. At those times the Pennsylvania team rallied, and, by fine passing and running, carried the ball away from their goal.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- The Rev. T. De Witt Talmage expresses much satisfaction with the change in his affairs which makes him a resident of Washington. He says:

The Sinking Fund Commissioners held a meeting in the Mayor's office yesterday afternoon to hear arguments concerning the proposed New-York and New-Jersey bridge over the North River. Mayor Strong presided.

Among the excursions into Chicago Saturday was one from points in Iowa. There were all sorts and conditions of men among the excursionists, and they were discussing the crops, the chances of Gen. Drake being elected Governor, and some of the sights they would see in Chicago. Two old men who occupied a seat together were dealing in reminiscences, and one of them told a particularly laughable story about his town.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- The Hawaiian Minister, Mr. Castle, said to-day that his appointment at Washington was but temporary, and that he accepted it with the understanding that he should be relieved by Dec. 1

MOHANK LAKE, N.Y., Oct. 9. -- The thirteenth annual Indian conference began its sessions here this morning. President Gates of Amherst was chosen President of the conference, but, in his absence, the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott presided. In his opening address, Dr. Abbott said that the conference had already accomplished valuable results.

It is unfortunate that almost at the outset of an enormous increase in freight traffic the Western roads should find themselves unable to maintain the standard rates. So great will be the eastbound traffic during the next few weeks, in consequence of the movement of the crops, that most of the railway managers in the West are scouring the country far and wide for freight cars.

The position which the German-American Reform Union took last evening is undoubtedly significant of the position of the large majority of the local voters of German descent. That organization has undoubtedly given up its entire past and will evidently find it extremely difficult to fall back on its old programme.

Mrs. Babet Karl executed two wills within one week, and as a result some bitter litigation is threatened, involving the Rev. Dr. Aaron Wise, rabbi of the Congregation Rodoph Sholom, and his son, Otto Irving Wise, the lawyer, who has an office in the Stewart Building.
