WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- The extracts from the pamphlet printed by Lord Sackville-West, reviewing his diplomatic career in this country, which ended in his receiving summarily his passports in the Fall of 1888, after the publication of the Murchison letter, have caused much amusement in Washington, where the ex-diplomat is well known. It would be hard to conceive of a more ridiculous publication.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 9. -- Paul Cushman, who accused Police Captain Corbett and Detectives Cosgrove, Jaeger, and Carroll of accepting money from keepers of disorderly houses, and who, when he failed to substantiate his charges, was committed to jail on a charge of perjury made by Chief of Police Hopper, was to-day removed from the jail to the City Hospital.

ALBANY, Oct. 9. -- One of the most spirited conventions held in this city in years was that of the Democrats to nominate city officers this evening. About two weeks since the two factions of the Democracy patched up their differences and agreed to divide up the places on the city and county ticket. The new Democracy wanted the assurance that John Boyd Thacher should be the nominee for Mayor.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 9. -- "I am very glad THE NEW-YORK TIMES has started to agitate this matter," said Paterson's Democratic leader, Prosecutor William B. Gourley, as he swung around in his easy chair and gazed at a campaign lithograph of Chancellor McGill, hanging upon the walls of his office.

BUFFALO, Oct. 9. -- The threatened war in the convention of the Commercial Travelers' Association has been averted. Mayor Green of Binghamton, Chairman of the board, anticipated the storm, and his frank statement of affairs, together with a clever coup in securing a committee to which the report of the Board of Managers was referred, won the day.

The Fall tournament of the St. Andrew's Golf Club, which will be continued every day throughout the remainder of the week, was begun yesterday morning. The bright red coats worn by many of the men over the course gave at least an appearance of warmth, even if they did not actually possess that quality. President John Reid was at the links, and H.O. Tallmadge, Secretary of the United States Golf Association, was there of course.

Several times within the past fortnight the stock market in this country has been treated to a rumor of an impending crash in the speculation in South African gold-mining shares, known in London as the "Kafir Circus." There has as yet been no marked effect from these rumors, but they show what is expected.

Bowling will be a popular form of amusement among the wheelmen this Winter, judging from the interest displayed in arranging the details of the tournament to be held under the auspices of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs. Last evening the committee in charge held a meeting at 21 Park Row and decided several important matters, the principal one being that the games should be rolled on neutral alleys.

Minister CASTLE, the newly arrived representative of Hawaii at Washington, says that the "present" Government is increasing in popularity "with everybody except the Kanakas" Americans, English, and Germans all like it. In 1890, out of a total population of 89,990, there were 1,928 Americans, 1,344 British, and 1,034 Germans.

Englishmen are nothing if not patriotic. A certain clannishness, thoroughly characteristic of the race, is ever apparent, and is a trait that other nations might well emulate. With a dogged persistence they cling to customs, habits, and ways that have become by unwritten laws to be almost a part of the British Constitution. And we call them insular.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- One of the exasperating incidents in international affairs has been closed after much persistence by our legation in Constantinople. The controversy grew out of the depredation by Turkish subjects at Marsovan in destroying a college building, the property of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions at Boston.

ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 10. -- It is stated here that Japan has agreed that the supplementary indemnity to be paid to her by China for the Japanese evacuation of the Liao-Tung Peninsula shall be reduced to 30,000,000 taels, the evacuation to take place within three months of the payment of the indemnity.

Charles Rouselle was arrested yesterday as a suspicious character in the banking office of T.E. Ward Co., 59 and 61 Wall Street. He went there to sell 100 shares of Canadian Pacific Railroad stock which he says he purchased in Paris.
Sketches of the candidates nominated by Tammany Hall. Wednesday night are printed herewith, in the order in which the names appear upon the official ticket:

The leaders of the German-American Reform Union are very indignant at the stories about the organization put in circulation by Gustav H. Schwab, Arthur Von Briesen, Theodore Sutro, and others through the medium of yesterday afternoon's papers.
A larger crowd than usual was at the Brooklyn Jockey Club track yesterday afternoon to see a very good lot of races decided over a good track.

It is likely that a general protest will be made if any action is taken toward carrying into effect a proposition of the Committee on County Affairs at the meeting of the Board of Aldermen last Tuesday, to transfer the City Library, which now occupies a room on the southeast corner of the main floor of the City Hall, to the Governor's Room, which occupies the front of the second story.

Police Commissioner Roosevelt addressed an audience of nearly 2,000 persons last night in Columbus Hall, in West Sixtieth Street, gathered there to participate in the celebration of the birthday of Father Mathew, held under the auspices of the Young Men's and Young Women's Societies of the Church of St. Paul the Apostle. Father Cassely presided.

The statement which we published yesterday morning, in, which Messrs. PATTERSON and SHEPARD give a detailed account of the efforts to secure harmony in the Democratic Party in Kings County, fully justifies the course of the independent organization. The leaders, or, more properly, the representatives, of that organization did all that was in their power to secure such an agreement as could honorably be supported by both organizations.

There was a meeting of the Municipal Consolidation Inquiry Commission yesterday morning at 214 Broadway. President Andrew H. Green presided, the other members present being John H. Brinckerhoff, George J. Greenfield, John L. Hamilton, and Secretary Albert E. Henschel.

The Tammany convention in the Twentieth Senatorial District turned out to be the hottest kind of a fight. For 137 ballots there was a dead-lock, 136 of them giving the same result -- 43 votes for John Long of the Thirtieth Assembly District, 42 for John J. Ryan of the Thirty-second, and 41 for Patrick F. Ferrigan of the Thirty-third.

After nearly seven hours of discussion yesterday the Presidents of the Eastern Trunk Lines and their Western connections managed to get the new traffic agreement into such shape that it received the unanimous approval of the representatives of all of the roads concerned. The document was thereupon referred back to a committee for proper arrangement and final engrossing. It will come before the Presidents again, the latter part of this month.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Capt. G.A. Armes, the retired army officer who was arrested some days ago on the order of Lieut. Gen. Schofield, while the General was acting as Secretary of War, was discharged from custody this morning in Judge Bradley's court, on the prisoner's application for his permanent discharge, on a writ of habeas corpus.
Controller Fitch was about to continue the sale of the People's Traction Company franchise at noon yesterday when he was served with an injunction signed by Justice Beach stopping the proceedings.

The Masons kept in line with the other fraternities who have attended the Reuter Home Fair at the Lexington Avenue Opera House and filled all of the auditoriums to overflowing last night. The ladies were exceedingly busy, and correspondingly successful, making the day's receipts one of the heaviest so far.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Col. George H. Mendell, the senior officer in length of service of the Engineer Corps, will be placed on the retired list Saturday next, on which day he will reach the age limit -- sixty-four years.

The papers outside of the State have a standing joke about the aversion which Kentuckians have to that wet article called water, but just now the most expert and confirmed tipplers in the State would be willing to trade off a few million gallons of Bourbon for as much rain. Every mail continues to bring in reports of the drought.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 10. -- A National convention and two State Editorial Associations enlivened things at the exposition to-day. B.F. Clayton of Iowa presided over the Farmers' Congress in the Auditorium this morning. Speeches were made by President Clayton, Secretary Stahl of Illinois, Mayor Porter King of Atlanta, G.M. Ryals of Savannah, and Prof. Hunnicutt of the University of Georgia.

Whether a woman is any the less eligible for the domestic circle by being intellectually developed to the extent of her capacity is a question that has vexed many debating societies and many thinkers from the time of ST. PAUL to that of Dr. DIX. It is a first-rate question for the debating societies, because there is no answer to it.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- An inquest was held this afternon by Coroner Banning over the body of Roger Williams of New-York, who died in Tuckahoe last evening at 9:30 o'clock.

The five-story brick factory 334 and 336 East Twenty-third Street was destroyed by fire at 4:30 o'clock yesterday morning. Tenants of adjoining buildings rushed, panicstricken, to the street, Salvation Army soldiers were routed out of their barracks, and nineteen prisoners and lodgers in the East Twenty-second Street Police Station were taken out not more than two minutes before a falling wall crushed the place of their confinement.
PANAMA, via Galveston, Oct. 10. -- Gen. Rafael Reyes, Minister of the Government, invested with civil and military powers, arrived at Cali, Cauca Department, Oct. 4. He was cordially received.

The Democratic State campaign is well under way. The headquarters at 27 Madison Avenue took on a very business-like air yesterday, and from to-day until the day of election, there will no no let-up in the hard work.

A queer outcome of the recent raid by the Board of Health on dealers who sold adulterated milk is a suit for $5,000 damages begun by Henry Lekey against John Rudd. Lekey is a young fellow of nineteen years who, by thrift and industry, had built up a comfortable retail milk business at 425 West Forty-fourth Street.

PARIS, Oct. 10. -- The War Office has received a dispatch from Andriba, under the date of Oct. 9, stating that Antananarivo, the capital of Madagascar, was taken by the French troops Sept. 30. The dispatch further says that the Queen of Madagascar has made peace with the French, and Gen. Metzinger has been nominated as Governor of Antananarivo.

GLASGOW, Oct. 2. -- The new challenger for the America's Cup, Mr. C.D. Rose, has exploded like a meteor on our old country yachting world. His connection with yachting here comes through his sister, Mrs. Sloane-Stanley, wife of Mr. Sloane-Stanley, who commissioned the late Michael Ratsey of Cowes to build for him in 1878 the Formosa, a cutter of 108 tons, which he raced.

The French project of colonial expansion is almost avowedly borrowed from the British achievements in that way. It seems to foreign observers to overlook the great differences between the conditions of an increasing population on an island too small to support it and a stationary population in a country upon which it can support itself, as well as several other important differences between England and France.
Among the books sold at auction yesterday by Bangs Co., the following were the most noteworthy:
The women of the Church Settlement House of the Church of the Redeemer were the hostesses at the high tea at the Madison Square Garden Banquet Hall last evening.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 10. -- The second day of the meeting of the Huntington Driving Park was a successful one. The racing was of a good class, though the attendance was small. This latter fact was due to the failure of the Long Island Railroad to run trains which would enable visitors to reach New-York after the races. Patrons either have to leave in the middle of the programme or stay all night.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 10. -- The complete returns from Tuesday's election show that Taggart, (Dem.,) for Mayor, received a plurality over Trusler (Rep.) of 3,722, in a total vote of 31,260. Stuckmeyer, (Dem.,) for City Clerk, has a plurality over Nixon (Rep.) of 917, and Cox, (Dem.,) for Police Judge, defeats Stubbs (Rep.) by 1,186.

By an arrangement commonly called a deal the State Democracy of the Twelfth Senatorial District last night indorsed ex-Inspector Williams, the Republican candidate for Senator, and the Republicans in turn indorsed William F. Grote and Jacob Kunzemann, the State Democracy candidates for the Assembly in the Sixteenth and Fourteenth Districts, respectively.
That Othello's passion is a state of malady nobody doubts, if the word malady means what makes one suffer.

Instead of presenting the usual Thursday novelty, Manager Conried showed that he has been rummaging about in the dramatic attic after antique bric-a-brae, by putting on the stage of his theatre in Irving Place last evening a play which, in other days and several languages, attained more than once the ultimate and conclusive verdict of approval--a long run. It was "Ferreol," now exactly twenty years of age.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Oct. 10. -- A magnificent drinking fountain was presented to the Town of Great Barrington to-day by Col. William L. Brown of New York, who has a country mansion here. The fountain is about fifteen feet high, and is surmounted by a life-size bronze figure of a newsboy selling a paper. The main shaft is of polished Quincy granite, and the remainder of Dolomite granite.

The Tammany Hall Assembly Convention for the Thirtieth Assembly District, which met at the hall of the Algonquin Club, 227 East Eighty-fourth Street, at 11 o'clock yesterday morning, was unanimous in its action, and on the first ballot nominated George William Myers, a real estate broker of 409 East Eighty-fourth Street, for Assemblyman.

JAMAICA, L.I., Oct. 10. -- The will of the late James Cruikshank of Hempstead was offered for probate Wednesday before Surrogate Weller at this place. The will is one of the most peculiar ever offered for probate in this county. It is a voluminous document, and describes in detail every piece of property named.

Considerable interest was manifested yesterday in the public discussion of the excise question before the Aldermanic Committee on Excise. It was the first of a series of hearings which the committee will give to all New-Yorkers desiring to express their views, and who are ready with suggestions looking to a bill to be indorsed by the Committee on Excise and drafted by the Aldermanic Committee on Law.

-- Blanks are out for the sixty-fifth annual exhibition of the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts, which will be held from Dec. 23 to Feb. 22, the architectural section closing Feb. 1. The exhibition will consist of work in any medium coming within the scope of the fine arts. Entries must be sent in before Nov. 23, and works must be at the academy by Dec. 7.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 10. -- The Kentucky trotting horse breeders' meeting was continued to-day. Chief interest was taken in the Transylvania Stake of $5,000 for 2:15 trotters. Bouncer finally won.

The Commercial has received from a well-known Buffalonian the letter printed below, which it publishes on account of its interest, and in the hope that it will give wide circulation to what appears to be a deserved tribute to the memory of a remarkable genius, whose deserts were not fairly recognized or rewarded during his lifetime:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Acting Secretary McAdoo to-day received a telegram dated San Francisco, sent by Capt. J.J. Read of the United States cruiser Olympia from Lahaina, Marei Island, Hawaii, with reference to the cholera situation at Honolulu. The dispatch evidently came by a slow vessel, as it was dated Sept. 17.

It really looks as if Mr. PLATT contemplated imposing upon REUBEN L. FOX, the Secretary of the State Committee, a task too great to be performed even by so loyal, sanguine, and industrious a laborer in the G.O.P.

The expected return of the President to Washington at an early day is interesting to many persons who have their eyes upon appointments within his gift. The opinion has lately been expressed that Mr. Cleveland will soon name the successor to the late Associate Justice Jackson of the Supreme Court of the United States.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Oct. 10. -- John Schmidt, who was known hereabouts as "the wild man of the woods," was arrested last Spring and sent to jail for three months. He was discharged yesterday, but he found the jail such a nice habitation, that he refused to leave it, and say that the jailer cannot drive him out with anything smaller than an axe.

Mr. Thomas A. Edison arrived in this city last evening, and was met by several gentlemen prominently connected with electrical enterprises, among whom were Mr. W.W. Gibbs, President of the United Gas Improvement Company, and Prof. William D. Marks, President of the Edison Electric Light Company.

LONDON, Oct. 10. -- The Chronicle will to-morrow publish a dispatch from Vienna stating that Tokio II., the winner of the Austrian Derby, will go to England to compete for the Cambridgeshire Stakes. It is stated that a match between Tokio II, and Lord Rosebery's Sir Visto, the winner of the English Derby this year, is being arranged.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 10. -- The Traffic Association has taken up one specific feature of the freight problem, and in another week or ten days will place itself on record regarding it. This is the fight now being carried on by various railroad companies for Utah's business.

ALBANY, Oct. 10. -- The pay rolls of the several revolutionary regiments of New-York State, which have been kicking about the Controller's offices for a century, are being put into shape for preservation and reference.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- A very pleasant Fall and Winter social season has been planned by the women of New-Rochelle who have charge of the women's department of the New-Rochelle Association, which has its headquarters in the beautiful gymnasium at Main and Centre Streets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- The October returns to the statistician of the Department of Agriculture make the general condition of corn 95.5 per cent., against 95.4 per cent. for the month of September. In most of the Southern States the condition has fallen since last report.
Messrs. Heilner Wolf have sold to Firmin V. Gaines, for improvement, the six lots at the southwest corner of Columbus Avenue and One Hundred and Ninth Street.

As the week passes, it becomes more and more apparent to every one that ex-Senator Jacob Worth is working hand in glove with Fire Commissioner Frederick W. Wurster, and is using every influence he commands to secure the election of the latter as Mayor of Brooklyn.

The charge in the Tammany platform that there was a "shameless bargain" between the Republicans and the State Democracy, that "as the price for the naming of three candidates on the county ticket candidates for legislative offices are to be nominated in the several Senate and Assembly districts by such Democratic faction," appears to have been based upon a report that has been quite general since the fusion ticket was agreed to.

KEY WEST, Fla., Oct. 10. -- The Collector of Customs and the Spanish Consul of this city have received information that there are between fifty and sixty men, Cubans, on Big Pine Key, thirty miles eastward of this place, and that they are armed with repeating rifles, revolvers, and machetes. These men are awaiting the arrival of a steamer to convey them to Cuba.

An esteemed pastor in Massachusetts quotes from a recent article in The Examiner the statement that "fraudulent pensions are authoritatively stated to make up one-third of the amount annually paid." This statement he challenges, and asks us to give our authority for it.

Chickering Hall was not big enough to hold the enormous crowd that surged through its doors last night to attend the annual meeting of the Cubans of New-York in commemoration of the uprising for independence on Oct. 10, 1868.

The trial of Bernardo Foglia for the alleged murder of his wife was continued yesterday before Justice Ingraham, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer. Assistant District Attorney Seaman Miller made the opening address for the people. After he concluded he produced a crayon sketch of a room showing a young woman lying on a sofa, her hair hanging down, her clothes disarranged, and blood flowing from her breast to the floor.

ALBANY, N. Y., Oct. 10.--Chief Protector Pond of the State Fish, Game, and Forest Commission in his report for the month of September, states that Harry Lippman of Washington Market, New-York, whose duty it is to watch the sale of fish and game in that market, does not appear to be interested in his work.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10. -- Chairman Gideon issued his usual bulletin to-day, showing the work of the Racing Board during the past week. The statement includes the following items:

BOSTON, Oct. 10. -- There was a lot of high-class racing at Mystic Park to-day, with horses three and four in a bunch at the wire, and the winners hard to pick. In the unfinished 2:24 trot, Speedwell won all but one heat to-day, that one being lost because of several breaks. He had the speed and the gameness of the party.

Armenia will keep forever a grateful remembrance of the intelligent attention and sympathy with which the United States press has been following the development of events in Turkey since the Sassoon massacre. The latest phase of this development is marked by the Armenian demonstration against the Turkish Government in Constantinople and the subsequent disturbances.
ALBANY, Oct. 10. -- The Executive Committee of the New-York State Cleveland League will meet in this city next Thursday evening.

BUFFALO, Oct. 10. -- The Democratic County Convention was held this afternoon. All the candidates nominated yesterday by the Independent Democratic Convention were nominated in accordance with the agreement between Franklin D. Locke and John Cunneen. The convention did not, however, take up Mr. Locke's proposition for the reorganization of the County Committee by substituting a campaign committee for the present campaign and arranging for caucuses in the Spring.

Morris Schoenholz's career as an alleged incendiary and as an "all-round" criminal was further ventilated yesterday before Judge Fitzgerald in the Court of General Sessions, where he is on trial for arson.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Oct. 10.--The Porte's reply to the joint note of the six powers relative to the recent rioting here has been made public. The Government enumerates the steps that were taken to maintain order, and declares that Mussulmans were not the aggressors in the rioting. It further says that Armenians killed inoffensive Mohammedans, and that in certain cases the Mohammedans had to defend themselves against their attacks.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 10. -- A man walked into Candidate Gleason's office last night armed with an immense battle axe. The weapon was one for ornamentation and not for use, but it was received by the candidate and his followers with due ceremony and respect.
The following announcement was issued yesterday by authority of the Good Government Clubs:

Speaking of the fact that the Republicans of New-York City have adopted a beer plank, and that the Republicans of the Fifth District of Buffalo have repudiated the Sunday plank in the Saratoga platform, a Republican at headquarters yesterday remarked:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- A remarkable ending of an army court-martial has occurred at Fort Leavenworth, Kan. The officer under trial was Capt. J.T. Kirkman of the Tenth Infantry, stationed at Fort Reno, Oklahoma Territory. Kirkman had serious charges made against him by the wife of an army officer, and an investigation was conducted by Major E.H. Crowder, the latest-appointed Judge Advocate, who was stationed in Omaha.

Mr. James J. Van Alen, for some reason or other, is not partial to town life, for, as a general rule, he spends his Winters abroad. Very shortly he will leave this country for Egypt, where he intends spending the Winter. Mr. Van Alen is always a welcome guest at all social functions, and those who entertain him or are entertained by him at Wakehurst, his Newport home, miss him during the season in town.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- Much interest was manifested in the second day's proceedings of the triennial council of the Congregational Church, now in session here. The Rev. Dr. Charles R. Palmer of Connecticut of the Committee on John Robinson Memorial Church at Gainsborough, England, reported progress, and it was decided to send a delegation to attend the dedication of the church.

MOHONK LAKE, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- At this morning's session of the Indian Conference the principal speakers were D.M. Browning, Commissioner of Indian Affairs, and ex-Senator Dawes of Massachusetts. They discussed the working of the law providing for the allotment to the Indians of lands in severalty.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., Oct. 10. -- All college work at Lehigh University was suspended here to-day, and the usual founder's day celebration in honor of Asa Packer, founder of the university, was held in the Packer Memorial Church. The programme was one of special interest, in anticipation of which the building was well filled with students of the university and their friends. A number of visitors from out of town were also present.

The possibility that the Sherman Bank, at Broadway and Eighteenth Street, may resume business was suggested yesterday at the office of John E. Ward, 59 Wall Street. Mr. Ward had been appointed referee on application by the Directors of the bank for a formal dissolution. Yesterday was set for the first hearing. A number of stockholders attended.

The McKinley newspapers continue to assert that the woolen industry is in very bad condition, in spite of the abundant evidence to the contrary which they have published in their own news columns. We find an interesting manifestation of this Republican policy in The Boston Journal of the 8th inst.

Strenuous efforts are being made by the managers at the Republican State headquarters in the Fifth Avenue Hotel to raise a big campaign fund, especially for use in legislative districts. Thomas C. Platt wants to make certain of the Legislature. He is paying attention especially to the Senators. Much of the money that is to be raised will be spent in the city Senatorial districts.

Assistant District Attorney Battle received a dispatch yesterday frown Detective Sergeant Cuff of the District Attorney's office that he had arrested in Chicago Horace J. Hoffman, the President of the Hoffman Office File Company of Pittsburg.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 11. -- Major Frederick H. Cruso of South Orange was found dead in his room this afternoon. While in the cellar of his house this morning, he struck his head against a beam and inflicted a deep gash, after which he was stricken with apoplexy. When found, he was lying upon the floor, having fallen from his chair. His head struck against the leg of a stove when he fell.

ALBANY, Oct. 11. -- Secretary of State Palmer gave a hearing this afternoon on the objections made by William C. Daley, the Republican candidate for Senator in the Twenty-fourth District, to the filing of the certificate of nomination of William Church Osborn, for Senator from that district, by the Democratic Party Reform Organization.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- County Judge and Surrogate E.A. Nash of Livingston County, who is a candidate for election to the Supreme Bench, has forwarded to Gov. Morton his resignation from his present office, to take effect Nov. 1.

It is the opinion of The Buffalo Express that, if the Republican State Committee has decided to make a silent campaign, and to dispense with stump oratory to arouse enthusiasm, the committee is making a mistake, as stump orators dispel apathy. Is The Express sure that PLATT desires to dispel apathy?

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Senator Sherman arrived in Washington to-day, and will return West to-morrow. He says Ohio will elect a Republican Governor, and that the Legislature will also be Republican; that in this regard much depends upon Hamilton County, and that the indications there are favorable to the Republicans.

In nominating a straight ticket upon a nonpartisan platform the Good Government Clubs have called down upon their heads the abuse and ridicule of the politicians and the public press. Before criticising their action we should ascertain what their principles are and learn whether or not they have deviated from these principles. If they have not, they cannot justly be blamed for their action, unless it can be shown that their principles are wrong.
ST. PAUL, Oct. 11. -- The annual report of the St. Paul and Duluth Railroad, presented at the annual meeting yesterday, makes this showing:

Police Commissioner Leonard R. Welles of Brooklyn yesterday added twenty-two policemen to the force. Mr. Welles is working hard for the election of Fire Commissioner Wurster, the Republican candidate for Mayor, who has promised to reappoint him to the head of the Police Department if he is elected next month.

All the nominations of local candidates having been made, the Democrats of this city are beginning to take an active interest in the campaign for the State ticket. The best judges of political conditions in this city give it as their sincere opinion that the Democratic majority in New-York County will be astonishing to the Republicans. They have good reasons to give for such predictions.

Typhoid fever prevails "to an alarming extent," as the local newspapers say, in the City of Washington. During the five weeks ending with Oct. 5 there were sixty-six deaths from this cause, and on the 7th inst. the Health Officer expressed the opinion that there were at that time "between 400 and 600 cases" of the fever in the city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Secretary Olney, although several times questioned about the matter, declined to-day to discuss the report that the Administration has notified Minister Dupuy de Lome that "there is a necessity that Spain should act promptly in her efforts to crush the insurrection in Cuba."

The indorsement of ex-Police Inspector Williams by the State Democracy for the Senate in the Twelfth District, in return for the Republican indorsement for the Assembly of State Democracy leaders W.F. Grote in the Sixteenth and Jacob Kunzenmann in the Fourteenth Assembly District, is looked upon by men of all parties as one of the vilest bits of "practical politics" ever attempted in this city.

There has not been a time in many years when the Democrats of this State were so completely united in support of their State ticket as now. Wherever there are factional differences over local questions or questions of local organization there is entire unanimity on State issues.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., Oct. 11. -- The President has finished his vacation, so far as Gray Gables is concerned, and left at 5:15 this afternoon, on the steam yacht Oneida, as the guest of Commodore Benedict. Private Secretary Thurber accompanied him. Mrs. Cleveland, the children, and other members of the family will leave next Tuesday in a special car.

A pretty and patriotic scene was witnessed in the handsome new building of Grammar School No. 10, at One Hundred and Seventeenth Street and St. Nicholas Avenue, yesterday morning, when Judson Kilpatrick Post, 143, G.A.R., presented to the school a handsome stand of five flags, with appropriate ceremonies.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 11. -- The Southern Pacific Railroad station at Baden, ten miles south of this city, was entered last night by two masked men, who ordered the telegraph operator, Mrs. Leva Marshall, to hand over what money there was in the office.
CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- In an editorial under the caption "The Associated Press Still at It," The Evening Press to-day says:

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- It is reported that a secret meeting of executive officers of the Chicago Western railroads was held yesterday at the Union League Club to consider the present desperate situation of rates West. Although the proceedings are said to have been entirely informal, yet it took eight hours to discuss the situation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Mrs. Belva Lockwood, lawyer and one time Presidential candidate, appeared in the Police Court here this morning to meet a charge of libel, preferred by a lawyer named White, formerly having offices in a building owned by her. He complained that Mrs. Lockwood had posted scandalous notices on his office door, one being as follows:

NEWBURG, Oct. 11. -- An effort is being made here by the Democrats, backed by independents and dissatisfied Republicans, to break the O'Dell control that has been maintained for years. The Democrats to-day placed in nomination for Mayor against Benjamin B. O'Dell, the Republican candidate, John D. Van Buren, who was one of the committee in charge of the Tweed investigation in New-York. He is one of the leading surveyors and engineers of the State.

Messrs. M. Hess have sold for Albert Wagner, to an investor, at $325,000, the six-story semi-fire-proof stone, iron, and terra cotta business building 134 and 136 Spring Street, and 84 to 88 Wooster Street, forming an L. Each floor contains about 10,000 square feet, and the rent of the building is $25,000.
Some rare and curious books were sold yesterday by Bangs Co., including the following:

Aqueduct racegoers were treated to something in the nature of a surprise yesterday, as three favorites won their races, these being Thyra in the first race. Ostler Joe in the fourth, and Dungarven in the fifth. Each of these won the event handily enough, and Marshall, favorite for the second event, was only beaten a scant length by Drum Major.

ALBANY, Oct. 11. -- The new Capitol Commission, which has the supervision of the construction work on the new Capitol Building under the four-hundred-thousand-dollar appropriation made by the last Legislature, held a special meeting to-day. The meeting was called to dispose of alleged charges of blackmail upon a number of the stonecutters working on the building.

A remark that Mr. Edward Jenks makes here is about true. "The Englishman discovers nothing and invents nothing." What he possesses "is a marvelous knack of adopting and developing the discoveries and inventions of others." It is the talent of appropriation. "When once the existence of lands hitherto unknown had been established, no perils, no threats could prevent the English from swooping down upon the prize."

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 11. -- Interest in the H.H. Holmes case was revived here to-day by the reappearance of Detective Geyer of Philadelphia. Going to the house in Irvington where Howard Pietzel was murdered and his body burned, Geyer fitted a key from his pocket in the front door night latch.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The report of Samuel Blackwell, Auditor of the Treasury for the Interior Department, for the year ended June 30, 1895, has been submitted to Secretary Carlisle. Mr. Blackwell formerly was designated as Third Auditor of the Treasury, but, under the reorganization of the department effected by the Dockery commission, which went into effect Oct. 1, 1894, he became Auditor for the Interior Department.

The Cuban meeting held on Thursday evening was very useful and timely as a demonstration of the extent, the nature, and the cause of Cuban sympathy with the insurrection. It was all the more valuable for being an exclusively Cuban demonstration, and for leaving out the American politicians who in other cities have been the most conspicuous figures at meetings in aid of the independence of Cuba.

To-day will be a great day over Arden way. Mr. Harriman, who has a very fine country establishment there, is giving a country horse show, or what skeptical people might call a horse circus, for there are to be amateur pony races, jumping contests, and all sorts of things that will make it interesting for Mr. Harriman's guests.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 11. -- A Cleveland paper to-day publishes an article regarding the development of the sulphur industry in Calcasieu County, La. The mines are being developed by a syndicate of Cleveland men, among them Frank Rockefeller and F.B. Squire of the Standard Oil Company, and the Vanderbilts.
Edward M. Grout, candidate of the regular Democracy of Brooklyn for Mayor of that city, issued yesterday his letter accepting the nomination.

" You all know me as a chronic political fighter," said Mrs. Mary L. Hall, President of the Colored Woman's Auxiliary, at the first grand anti-Tammany rally of the season last night, at Central Hall, on Thirty-second Street.
Michael Putzel, a produce merchant at 209 Duane Street, fell dead, presumably from heart disease, in front of 245 Washington Street, at 9 o'clock yesterday morning.

The Campaign Committee of the Confederated Good Government Clubs met at 8:30 o'clock last night at the City Club, 677 Fifth Avenue, and almost immediately afterward adjourned to headquarters at 1,180 Broadway, where it remained in session until 12 o'clock.
The first monthly "at home" of the Alumnae Association of the Normal College for this season was held yesterday afternoon in the library of the college building.

There will be a revival of an exciting and popular bicycle competition at Rahway, N.J., this afternoon. Several years ago team racing among the larger clubs was the very essence of cycle sport, but it was permitted to die out. The contest to-day will be a ten-mile affair for clubs belonging to the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 11. -- William R. Hilton died in the Cooper Hospital this morning from the effects of a blow on the head. Edward Lynch, a resident of Gloucester, is in the county jail, charged with murder.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The Health Officer of Washington says an epidemic of typhoid fever exists in this city, and that, unless sanitary precautions are observed by the inhabitants generally, a serious condition of affairs may shortly be expected. Health Officer Woodward estimates that at least 600 cases are under treatment in the District to-day.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 11. -- The Episcopal Missionary Board decided to-night, by a vote of 161 yeas to 37 nays, to elect a Bishop of Alaska, and thus ended a controversy that had been going on for a long time, and had given rise to a good deal of bitter feeling.

Edward M. Shepard and Charles J. Patterson of the Democratic Party in Kings County yesterday replied to the misstatement that they had declined to discuss Justice Gaynor as an available candidate for Mayor.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- Ex-Mayor Thomas E. Kinney, as Democratic State Committeeman for Oneida County, with credentials from the May convention held at Syracuse in 1892, has issued a call to the Democracy of Oneida County for a conference, to be held to-morrow afternoon, in relation to the nomination of Henry J. Coggeshall for Senator by the Democratic Executive Committee. The call, in part, says:

The extent of the good work done by Assistant District Attorney Davis and the police authorities in uprooting the gang of incendiaries which operated in this city for years was made manifest yesterday in the trial of Morris Schoenholz.
The Board of Education's Committee on School System held its third session yesterday afternoon to hear arguments on proposed legislation.

It is instructive as well as amusing to note the various comments made by the Republican papers of the interior of the State upon the general question of the excise laws, the platform of their party adopted by the State Convention, and the very different platform worked up by Mr. LAUTERBACH for the party in New-York City.

BUFFALO, Oct. 11. -- The Democratic situation was further complicated to-day by the refusal of the leading candidates of the independent ticket to accept the regular nominations tendered to them yesterday. Franklin D. Locke, who named the independent ticket, worked with the candidates so successfully that they fell in with his proposition to decline the regular nominations and stand on the reform ticket alone.

The German-American Reform Union situation is still very confused, as the strength of the element which is to meet next Tuesday night has not been disclosed, and as those in favor of repudiating the action taken by the General Committee last Wednesday assert that their numbers are constantly growing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- An order has been issued for Commodore Thomas O. Selfridge, President of the Naval Inspection Board, to report in person at the Navy Department to-morrow for examination for promotion to the grade of Rear Admiral. Rear Admiral C.C. Carpenter will complete his period of active service next February, and his retirement will create a vacancy in the list of Admirals on the active list.

A gathering of the fairest of Brooklyn's maids and matrons -- members of the Woman's Health Protective Association, the Civitas Club, and the Daughters of the Revolution -- and their friends last evening made the high tea at the Madison Square Garden a grand success.

Louis Stern, the well-known merchant of this city who was arrested last August at Kissingen, charged with insulting Baron von Thuengen, Deputy Commissioner of the Spa, was a passenger on the steamship St. Louis, which arrived yesterday.

Jurors are not to serve on trust hereafter before Judge Bookstaver in the Court of Common Pleas. The Judge made an announcement to this effect yesterday, declaring that people who want jury trials will have to put down $15 in good American money before a single juryman is sworn.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 12. -- A social event of the last week was the entertainment given by the Dorcas Society. King's Daughters, at the home of Miss Maude Lowrie, in Park Avenue, Monday evening. It was titled "The Circulating Library," and was given for the purpose of raising funds for the benefit of the poor of the city.

Three big tournaments were finished yesterday at the St. Andrew's Golf Club. It was a big golfing day, and, although the rain did dampen the greens and wet through a score or more fine golfing suits, the enthusiasm of the players did not suffer in the least, and the games went right on.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- The Supreme Court' will convene for the term of 1895 at noon on Monday next. All the Justices are in the city. Justice Gray was the last to reach here. He had an unpleasant experience while in Canada, having been bitten by a vicious dog. The injury confined him to the house for several weeks.

The meeting this week of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions, in Brooklyn, is an event of more than usual interest. These gatherings are always significant; this one more so perhaps than any other, except that of twenty-five years ago, in the same place. Those who come will review not merely eighth-five years of mission work, but a quarter of a century of work conducted by the Congregational churches alone.

COLD SPRING, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- Gen. and Mrs. Daniel Butterfield gave an at-home party this afternoon at their beautiful residence, Craigside, Cold Spring-on-Hudson, in honor of Gen. and Mrs. Louis Fitzgerald. The pretty parlors were crowded. Gen. and Mrs. Fitzgerald and Miss Fitzgerald were among the earliest arrivals. The halls and parlors were beautifully decorated with ferns and palms, and the lunch table was artistically arranged.

" It is just after Short Creek Dave gets to be one of them evangelists," remarked the old cattleman, as we made company for each other one evening, "an' has been exhortin' of us Wolfville people over in the warehouse of the New-York Store, as Dan Boggs confides in me how once he mebby half way makes up his mind he'll be religious.

With its binding of lemon-colored silk, and ornamented with the blackest of printing, this collection of six short stories by Emile Zola gives, in outward appearance at least, due credit to that land of yellow-covered novels whence the translator drew material if not inspiration. Therefore is one the more surprised, on glancing over the book, to find its pages fairly swarming with startlingly familiar Saxon and Irish colloquialisms.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- Cornell defeated the Western Reserve University here to-day in her third game of the season by a score of 12 to 4. Cornell's two touch-downs were both made in the first half. Western Reserves' in the second half. Cornell was unable to gain much through the line, but went down the field steadily by gains around the ends.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- The executive officials of all the important railroad systems between Chicago and the Missouri River, in special session in this city yesterday, unanimously agreed that all secret rate cutting would be stopped at once, and that all the present low tariffs now in effect between Chicago and Colorado points would be withdrawn and canceled as soon as legal notices could be given.

This is a silort story for so long a title and so big a book, for, although there are few pages in "1Jnc' ]dinburg " -- only [iftyi three, to be exact, be,wldes those devoted to .Mr. Cllnedinst's attractive pictures -- it, is of the large octavo size. It is a capital thing of its kind, though, and wortiy of its handsome setting.

The scandalous indorsement of ex-Police Inspector Alexander S. Williams, the Republican candidate for the Senate in the Twentieth Senatorial District, by the State Democracy's Senate Convention in return for the Republican indorsement of William F. Grote and Jacob Kunzenman for the Assembly in the Sixteenth and Fourteenth Assembly Districts, was unanimously repudiated by the Executive Committee of the State Democracy yesterday afternoon.

ALBANY, Oct. 12. -- Secretary of State Palmer is receiving letters daily from candidates for public office throughout the State asking for copies of the law passed by the last Legislature amending the Penal Code by declaring the soliciting of a candidate for an elective office to purchase a ticket for a ball or any sort of entertainment to be a misdemeanor.

The projected withdrawal of water from Lake Michigan by the Chicago Drainage Channel at the rate of 600,000 cubic feet per minute has stimulated discussion both in this country and in Canada concerning the effect of this withdrawal upon lake levels and with respect to certain projects for lake control.

Although Mr. Hopkins is credited, on the title page of this new volume of the Holts' Buckram Series -- to which a dull book is never admitted -- with the authorship of two other stories, yet we believe we are right in the inference that his name is comparatively unfamiliar. This slight, piquant, and fairly ingenious tale, however, will give him his share of fame.

The most interesting event on the tapis this week is the convention of military wheelmen. It will be held at the Broadway Central Hotel on Tuesday, and may mark the beginning of a new era in the United States Army. Gen. Nelson A. Miles will be in attendance, and has promised to say something on the relation of the bicycle to future wars.

Now that society (so called) has its thoughts turned from the gayeties of Newport and Bar Harbor, and the period of rest has arrived, the time "between the seasons" is taken up with gossip regarding the coming events, and there are many of them to think about, including several weddings of importance.

WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 12. -- This city next Tuesday, the 15th, will be the rendezvous of 5,000 Odd Fellows from all parts of Connecticut, other New-England States, and New-York, the occasion being the dedication of a handsome one-hundred-thousand-dollar Odd Fellows' building which has just been completed.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 12. -- The first week of the present Lakewood season has done as much to advance the prospects of this "village in the pines" as has been accomplished in a month in former times. The first hotel to open its doors (the Laurel House) has already an unusual complement of guests, and the cottagers have returned early to their Winter homes.

TUXEDO CLUB, TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- The season of gayety here will in reality commence with the ball which is to be given at the clubhouse on Friday evening, Nov. 1, for which invitations will be sent out within the next few days. The clubhouse has been filled with guests since the close of the Newport and Bar Harbor season, and nearly all the cottagers are entertaining house parties.

A Baptist minister named POTTER appeared before a Magistrate on Friday with a truly touching tale of woe. It appears to have touched even the judicially flinty heart of the Magistrate, but he had to plead powerlessness to remedy the grievance of his petitioner. His petitioner's troubles have been brought into courts, though not into police courts, before.

Norton Chase, who has been presented to the voters of this State by the recent Democratic State Convention as its candidate for the office of Attorney General, was born in Albany, Sept. 3, 1861. He is a son of Nelson H. Chase, one of Albany's leading and most respected citizens. From his earliest youth he was inclined to study.

It becomes increasingly plain from day to day to any one following the record of political doings in the City of Brooklyn that the only hope of good government or a continuance of municipal reform in the next two years lies in the success of the Shepard Democracy. If there is no hope of that success, then is there certainty of a lapse back into the mire of bossism and machine politics.

If it had not been for Chicago Gas, we might have shut up shop for all the market did certain days last week. Trading was horribly dull, and if prices have much more decline before the next big upward movement, it will certainly be mainly because holders of stocks get disgusted with waiting, and throw over their holdings.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct 12. -- The prospect of a debate between Candidates Gleason and John P. Madden is the all-absorbing topic in political circles in this city. It is getting all the attention centred in the fight over the Mayoralty.

The hotel keepers of this city have been complaining for a long time of the exorbitant rates charged by the wholesale dealers for foreign champagne. No action has been taken by the Hotel Men's Association.

St. Louis, Mo., Oct. 12. -- The charge against The Chicago Associated Press of circulating a rumor of the assassination of President Cleveland, coming so soon after its notoriously false reports of the international yacht race, is causing much concern in offices of newspapers dependent upon it for telegraphic intelligence.

It seems incredible that human nature should fall to such depths of unnatural wickedness as to be willing to inflict a slow, painful death upon a little child for the sake of obtaining a few dollars. Yet not only in England, where for years such atrocious cruelty has been practiced extensively, but in this country, too, it has reached a stage that has attracted serious attention.

On the bulletin board of a cycle clubhouse up town hang some clippings from THE NEW-YORK TIMES, giving hints on the care and repair of wheels. The member who placed them there has been riding two years, yet he makes this confession and suggestion: "There are a number of pointers in those articles that I never knew before, although I thought I was well up in the game.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- Mrs. Charles F. Seifert, living on the Sleepy Hollow Road, was beaten by a tramp yesterday. The tramp called at Mrs. Seifert's house and begged something to eat. He asked for it in such a threatening manner that Mrs. Seifert picked up a broomstick and drove him from the house.
" I can't come down; I'm cooking."

No artist in America to-day is better qualified to speak authoritatively of dramatic art than Mine. Helena Modjeska, Countess of Bozenra, and she generally has something to say on the subject that is worthy of preservation. That was the case on a day last week, when she talked in her rooms at the hotel with a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

Frank Barrett, who imagined and wrote so well the story of "The Great Hesper," involving the theft of a prodigious African diamond, and the singular actions of art owl-eyed man, blind by day, but sharp-sighted at night, now gives us another well-wrought, plausible, and exciting tale of adventure.

Riddersville lies in a hollow which would be a ravine were not its base so broad and the encompassing slopes so gradual. Nor has it any inherent gloom: for though the sun sinks full an hour earlier than the season demands, it compensates by touching the greens and grays and yellows of the diversified verdure with a peculiarly soft and gracious brilliance.
The Advisory Council for Military Drill in the Public Schools held its first meeting of the season last night in the Grand Central Palace. Lexington Avenue and Forty-third Street.
We favor the maintenance of the Sunday laws in the interests of labor and morality.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12. -- The Russian steamer Kotik arrived from Petropaulovski yesterday after a fair return voyage of thirty-three days. She brought one of the most valuable cargoes that has come to San Francisco this year. It consisted of 17,920 sealskins, 227 sea-otter skins, 13 land-otter skins, and 16 sable and 17 fox skins.

Republican managers were in consultation at local headquarters, in Thirty-eighth Street, yesterday, trying to determine on a name to be placed on the fusion ticket in the place of James W. Hawes, the candidate for City Court Justice. Mr. Hawes has withdrawn from the ticket.

ALBANY, Oct. 12. -- The State Civil Service Commission, at its meeting next month, will appoint a Chief Examiner, at a salary of $3,500, to succeed Thomas F. Carmody of Penn Yan, Yates County, who resigned some time ago, his resignation to take effect on the appointment of his successor. At the competitive examination held recently there were sixteen candidates for the position, fourteen of whom passed.

The Reinhard Assembly Committee, appointed to investigate the condition of girls and others working in shops and factories, resumed its sessions yesterday in the Aldermen's Chamber, City Hall. Miss Minnie Rosen, the first witness, said that women usually do the finishing work of the garments, and sew on the buttons and sleeve linings.

Edward M. Grout made his first public appearance as a Mayoralty candidate before a Democratic audience last evening in Andrew Jackson Hall, in Kent Avenue, near Myrtle, Brooklyn. The occasion was a ratification of the regular Democratic ticket and a banner raising by the Andrew Jackson Club of the Seventh Ward.

The next and concluding rifle contests at Creedmoor range will be the Adjutant General's Match, which is to be shot next Wednesday, and the Governor's Match, which is to be shot for on Thursday. The first-named contest is a new one, and is calculated to draw a large entry list, as well as to introduce military marksmen to the new and untried 800-yard range.
SUMMIT, N.J., Oct. 12. -- The Ladies' Benevolent Society of the Springfield Presbyterian Church held an interesting meeting on Thursday afternoon, when some instructive papers were read.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 12. -- The fiercest football battle seen here this season took place to-day on the university gridiron between the Lafayette eleven and the home team. The Tigers had expected a stiff practice game with the boys from Easton, but were hardly prepared for the severe struggle which the experienced at the hands of the Lafayette athletes.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 12. -- The Newport season, after a period of waning of two weeks' duration, is now quite dead. Quite a number of families yet linger here, but they are doing practically nothing in a social way, being engaged principally in packing up and otherwise preparing to depart.

BOSTON, Oct. 12. -- Rain prevented the completing of the programme at Mystic Park to-day. In consequence, the 2:21 trot and 2:14 pace will be finished on Monday. All of the horses that have raced here, and several new ones, will race at the Saugus track next week. Owing to a bad break by Caprice, there was little trouble for Fanny Wilcox winning the one heat necessary to complete her victory.

The attention of President Roosevelt of the Police Board was called yesterday to a statement printed in a morning paper to the effect that the policemen in the city might lose their votes election day, and that there would be less than 500 patrolmen available to protect life and property.

There were so many elements and factors in the city election yesterday as to make it difficult to analyze the result. The result itself is sufficiently emphatic. Mainly, it was a protest of the people against the measures and methods of the administration of Mayor Denny and his boards.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 12. -- The pacer Joe Patchen, 2:04, and W.W.P., 2:06 1/2, have been matched at half-mile heats, best two in three, to load wagon, owners to drive. The race will be decided here next week.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 12. -- Vast crowds attended the Coronation of the Virgin of Guadalupe this afternoon. The Collegiate Church was filled as early as 7 o'clock this morning. As a consequence, even the Bishops had great difficulty in getting through the crowd, and many well-known people were unable to got in.
Frederick W. Wurster, the Republican candidate for Mayor of Brooklyn, yesterday issued his letter of acceptance.

The Fall racing meeting of the Brooklyn Jockey Club was brought to a close yesterday, the weather being the worst the club has had this Fall. The meeting, which lasted fifteen days, was not such a financial success as was the Spring meeting, though the sport was good as a whole that in the early days of the meeting being absolutely first-class.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- The Tarrytown police were notified to-day of a case of supposed kidnapping.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 12. -- The ladies of the Church of the Sacred Heart, Bloomfield, held a grand autumnal bazaar in Union Hall Thursday evening, last evening, and this evening, which was a great success financially and artistically.

SING SING, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- Frank M. Decker, a convict sentenced to Sing Sing Prison Aug. 16, 1893, for four years and three months, on a charge of grand larceny, in New-York City, escaped from the prison to-night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- The Naval Ordnance Bureau has arranged for the manufacture of 100,000 rifles invented by James P. Lee of Hartford, Conn. This gun is supposed to be the best of the small-calibre arms yet invented. The calibre of the gun will be .236.

The Italian settlement at the foot of Franklin Street, Oakland, was agitated Wednesday morning by the capture of another monster of the deep. An Italian fisherman gave battle to the queer fish, and he says he will long remember the encounter. The capture was made near Goat Island early in the morning.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- All the indications, point to a brilliant social season during the Winter and coming Spring. The long session of Congress will contribute materially to this result. Mrs. Cleveland, it is said, will entertain more frequently than last year, and the wife of the Secretary of State, whose receptions and dinner parties were among the most notable events of the past season, will, it is understood, outdo her previous record.

Conditions now existing in several of the Senate districts of this city are such as to warrant earnest Democrats in believing that the Democratic State Committee ought to take some action at its meeting at State Headquarters on Tuesday night.

For many years the Chinese and Tibetans have professed to have no objection to the resumption of commercial intercourse between Tibet and the neighboring countries, but as soon as it has been sought to bring these amiable professions to a practical test, difficulties have arisen. The Bhutanese, indeed, appear to have taken an independent stand in the matter.

The British Public Schools and Universities Association is the title of an organization that was started in New-York last week. Coming so soon after the defeat of the universities at athletics, and cricket, it seems to indicate that Britons in America recognize the need of organization, and intend to show a thing or two to those who still remain in the "benighted island."

Louis Frederic Delisle, who kept a restaurant in Fulton Street, near William Street, in this city, and who was well-known by the merchants of lower New-York, was in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, when proceedings were taken to have him declared incompetent to care for himself and his estate.

John Ulrich, thirty-seven years old, of 523 East Fifteenth Street, who does not work for a living because his old mother supports him, and who frequently thrashes her when she is not prompt in attending to his wants, was arraigned before Magistrate Brann, in the Yorkville Police Court, yesterday, charged with brutally assaulting her Friday night.

BERLIN, Oct. 12. -- Toward the close of the proceedings of the Socialist Congress at Breslau to-day Dr. Arons, a member of the Reichstag, raised the vexed question of reform in the composition of the Socialist parliamentary delegation, and also in the construction of the Executive Committee of the Socialist Party, and a spirited debate ensued.

RAHWAY, N.J., Oct. 12. -- Owing to the heavy downpour of rain this afternoon the long-looked-for team race of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs was a fizzle. Only one team was fully represented, and that "walked over," for the prize. This was the King County Wheelmen's team, and its action, while technically just, was characterized by many present as very unsportsmanlike.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- [Copyright, 1895, by THE NEW YORK TIMES.] -- Lord Salisbury did not complete his holiday abroad after all. He was to have returned to-day, but Tuesday he privately crossed the Channel by the least traveled route and went without observation through to Hatfield, where his secretaries were awaiting him with dispatch boxes.

The "boiler plate" department of Mr. PLATT'S silent campaign headquarters is at work filling the country newspapers with assurances that the times are not better, that they would have been better with the McKinley law in force, and obviously the attention of the voter is being directed from that "vital issue" which Mr. MILLER secured by assault.

Dr. Stebbins of San Francisco, who is counted California's brainiest preacher, spoke for local civilization in an odd way on a recent Sunday, when he was delivering a sermon on the thirty-three years of his occupancy of the pulpit that was once Starr King's. Our vital need, according to the doctor, is to bid farewell to 1849, and accommodate ourselves to the spirit of 1893.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- Mandamus proceedings to test the legality of the apportionment of Assembly districts in Westchester County by its Board of Supervisors was set down for hearing before Justice J.F. Bernard here to-day. The proceeding is instituted by John L. Mapes against the Board of Supervisors of Westchester County, and the details of the alleged, gerrymander are fully set forth in his petition.
ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 12. -- Prof. Scott lectured on "Dynamical Agencies" before the University Extension Society in Association Hall last evening.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 12. -- Lieut. Peary, the arctic explorer, and Mrs. Peary, arrived in Lenox Tuesday afternoon. They went directly to Belvoir Terrace, the country place of Mr. Morris K. Jesup, whose guests they are. The mercury dropped ten degrees the first afternoon Lieut. Peary was here, which caused many joking remarks about his bringing arctic weather with him.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 12. -- Mrs. Calvin S. Brice gave her closing dinner of the season to-night. The floral decorations were made up of an abundance of American Beauty roses. There were twenty-four guests.

In the new play at the Empire Theatre the skill and talent of John Drew are brought well into use. He has an old-fashioned, grateful role, devised for him by an experienced actor -- one that Lester Wallack would have delighted to play in the palmy days of his lingering juvenility and d'Orsay whiskers.

HARRISON, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- The volunteer fire company of this village is preparing to celebrate the opening of its new engine house. Some work yet remains to be done on the interior, but it is thought that everything will be ready for the big celebration in two or three weeks.

The old carriage establishment of James B. Brewster Co., with a factory at 319 West Forty-third Street, and a salesroom at 489 Fifth Avenue, suspended business yesterday and made an assignment to John A. Garver of 46 Wall Street.

LONDON, Oct. 12. -- The Right Hon. George J. Goschen, First Lord of the Admiralty; the Duke of Devonshire, President of the Council, and the Right Hon. Arthur J. Balfour, First Lord of the Treasury, have been summoned by Prime Minister Salisbury to a conference in London. The officials named, with the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, Secretary of State for the Colonies, form a council within the Cabinet.

Humanity is as conservative as civilization is radical. As soon as a new occupation is produced by inventions and altered environments, a process of selection begins, through which the best man fitted to do the work is evolved. In other words, nature seeks a type, and this tendency is more potent than sumptuary laws or the restraints of society and trade.
CONSTANTINOPLE, Oct. 12. -- Osman Bey has gone to Besika Bay, a roadstead between the coasts Asia Minor and the Island of Tenedos, to survey sites for forts.

Just as the schools are well opened and New-York and Brooklyn boys and girls have settled down to a year of work, a number of busy men, some of them world famous, have stopped their work forever. The death of Louis Pasteur, the great French scientist and physician, is a historical event.

We cannot too strongly impress upon the minds of those interested in the coming election, as all citizens should be and all "good citizens" must be, the importance of becoming thoroughly familiar with the requirements of the new provisions of law affecting the ballot, and of seeing that all voters know how to use the ballot without making mistakes.

Ways and means to put a stop to the general practice of rebates on life insurance premiums were freely discussed and considered at a meeting at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday morning, when the executive officers of all the large life insurance companies came together, with Commissioner Merrill in the chair. The meeting was not open to the public.

C.E. Tebbs and Haydon Jones, the artists, came into town from Southwestern Oregon yesterday, loaded with a sack containing the skin of a black bear, an animal which in life weighed 720 pounds, and measured 7 1/2 feet in length.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 12. -- On Oct. 16 and 17 Milwaukee will celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of its birth as a city. This is a little ahead of time. The exact date would fall in January, but as the weather at that date would not permit of a big celebration, it was decided to have the semi-centennial celebration in the golden days of Indian Summer.

ALBANY, Oct. 12. -- Secretary of State Palmer to-day received from the printer the sample blanket ballot which is to be followed by the County Clerks throughout the State in the preparation of the blanket ballots to be used at this Fall's election.

In mud and rain the members of the Yale football team met one of their hardest games of recent years when they went against the Crescent Athletic Club yesterday at Eastern Park. The rain, which fell all day, kept the expected large crowd of spectators away; there were not more than 150 on hand when play was called.

The failure of one of the best and bestknown and most fashionable firms of carriage builders in this or any other country would at any time attract. attention. But it attracts particular attention at this time because it seems to be a natural result of a new order of things in the way of locomotion.

The Rev. Anicetus Vanoli, D.D., a graduate of the Roman Propaganda, where Papal Delegate Satolli was his instructor, and, for the last three years, Missionary Apostolic in Constantinople, gave his reasons at a meeting last night for renouncing the priesthood and withdrawing from the Roman Catholic Church.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Oct. 13. -- Franklin Leonard Pope, the famous electrician, a resident of Elizabeth, N.J., for twenty-five years, was killed accidentally to-day by electricity at his home in this place, where he had lived for the last year.

Brooklyn politicians took a day off yesterday and rested from their labors of the last week. Some of them went to church. It was the last full day of rest they will have before election day, and they did not go near their respective political headquarters.

BERLIN, Oct. 13. -- Emperor William will leave Hubertusstock with regret. He has had vastly finer sport than he had at Rominten. Deer and other big game have been plentiful, and the weather has been cooler and more enjoyable. Herr Friese, the animal painter, has been a member of him suite, and has made some splendid sketches of the more notable of the quarry which has fallen victim to the Kaiser's gun.
HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 13. -- Folsom, '95, the celebrated end rush on the Dartmouth team in '93 and '94, is coaching the University of Colorado eleven.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 13. -- The Clark Thread Company, which employs about 4,000 persons in its big mills in this city and Kearny, directly across the Passaic River from each other and connected by private bridges, is taking a new departure, which in a measure will be an experiment in mills of that kind.

TRENTON, Oct. 13. -- The belief prevails very generally throughout the State that Chancellor McGill will be elected by at least 10,000 plurality, and that Democratic Assemblymen will be elected in many counties that last year went Republican. There has been no estimate made by the Democratic Committee, but a scheme is now under contemplation to have a canvass made the last week of this month.

Rumors astir during the last few days to the effect that friends of alleged incendiaries have collected over $40,000 with which to bribe the jury in the Morris Schoenholz case have acquired some degree of importance since District Attorney Fellows set special detectives to watch the jurymen.
In dealing with the excise question from the pulpit yesterday, the Rev. R. Heber Newton of All Souls' Church stood alone in advocating the modification of the excise law and a more liberal Sunday.

WHITESTONE, L.I., Oct. 13. -- "Nat" Gray, who has served four months in the United States Engineers Battalion at Willet's Point, went to John Murray's saloon about 3 o'clock this morning, armed, it is supposed, for vengeance on Henri Carll, a Deputy Sheriff who had given him a severe clubbing.

BERLIN, Oct. 13. -- The social disorder which is prevalent on the Russian frontier of Armenia is indicated by advices received to-day from St. Petersburg. According to these reports the Kurdish chief, Nabi, is levying tribute by force in the Russian district of Erivan, where he is seizing cattle, murdering men, Christian and Moslem alike, and carrying off women and children.

Mrs. Partington's reproving utterance about, bad weather being better than no weather at all, will not be coincided in by those who have experienced the sort of weather that has been apportioned to this locality throughout the last two days.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 13. -- The long controversy between Harvard and Yale on the athletic question is at an end. Harvard refuses to have any athletics of any sort with Yale, because Yale will not play Harvard at football until Harvard apologizes. Accordingly, the two universities will now have time to cool off, and when they do come together again, will do so in a more friendly spirit.

In the Madison Avenue Reformed Church, corner of Fifty-seventh Street and Madison Avenue, last night, the Rev. Dr. Abbott E. Kittredge preached on the "Duty of the Christian Citizen in the Coming Election."

The decision of Secretary HERBERT that the bids for the Kearsarge and her mate should not include alternative proposals for supplying the armor as well as the machinery and hulls, as Chief Constructor HICHBORN had recommended, may prove to be the subject of some discussion in Congress.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 13. -- The political harangues delivered by President Joseph F. Smith and George Q. Cannon of the Mormon Church at a secret meeting of the priesthood last Monday have caused great excitement among the Utah politicians.

No reliable estimate of the number of boxes of oranges Florida will produce this year is obtainable. It is certain, however, that the yield will be sufficiently large to surprise those who have had the impression that all the orange groves of the State were destroyed by the freeze last Winter. There are a great many groves on the west coast that were scarcely touched by the frost. They promise to yield well.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 13. -- Rodman Wanamaker of the class of '86 of Philadelphia has presented the Chancellor Green Library of Princeton University with a unique gift in the shape of a collection of busts of the monarchs of Europe. The collection is now being prepared for exhibition and will soon be placed among the treasures of the university. This collection is the only one of its kind in existence.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- Work in the various departments of the university is now well under way, and everything points to a particularly prosperous year for young Cornell. The total registration has not been officially announced yet, owing in part to the illness of President Schurman, who has been confined to his house with a bad cold for the past week.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct. 13. -- A well-dressed, prepossessing young man, giving the name of Stewart, visited this place a few days ago, and canvassed among the well-to-do people, selling dress goods, silk hoisery, towels, kid gloves, The dress goods he carried with him, while the other goods he sold from samples -- the hose at $3 per dozen, and the gloves and towels at $1 per dozen each.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 13. -- A ferryman's yawlboat, in which six persons were crossing the eastern branch of the Patapsco River to-day, was capsized and four of its occupants were drowned. The dead are:
DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 13. -- Chairman H.G. McMillan of the Republican Central Committee has given out the following interview on Senator Allison's Presidential candidacy:

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Oct. 13. -- Major Elijah Halford, United States Army, who was President Harrison's private secretary, is in the city attending the twelfth anniversary of the Young Men's Christian' Association. He was asked to-day if Mr. Harrison was a candidate for the Presidency.

Unless something unforeseen happens, the cable cars on the Lexington Avenue line, which is controlled by the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, will be run for the accommodation of the public to-day. Superintendent Rounds was not prepared to state last evening just how many cars would be put in use the first day.

The Republican State Committee is having some difficulty in holding all its candidates down to the machine groove. Frank D. Pavey and his probable course in the Senate, if he is elected in the Fifteenth Distract, have been the objects of anxious thought on the part of Mr. Platt and his lieutenants.
Why do Dr. PARKHURST and Mr. ROOSEVELT speak of the Tammany Tiger as "she"? Wasn't it long ago decided that the beast is a Tom?

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 13. -- The School of Music of Yale University has just begun its second year. There is a largely increased attendance, the courses offered are larger than before, and the corps or instructors has been augmented by the addition of Harry B. Jepson of this city, of the class of '93, in the academic department, as instructor in organ playing. The other instructors are retained.

WILLET'S POINT, L.I., Oct. 13. -- John Santa Rosa, a private in B Company, United States Engineers, was surprised last night by the receipt of an honorable discharge. His term of service had not half expired. The discharge was issued under special orders at the Adjutant General's office in Washington.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 13. -- Three persons were killed outright and nine others injured by a runaway trolley car on the West End electric line, jumping the track and going over an embankment at 6:20 o'clock to-night. The killed are:

A committee of the Good Government Convention met yesterday in the City Club and prepared an address to the citizens of New-York, justifying the course of the Good Government Clubs in keeping their county and judicial ticket in the field. W. Harris Roome, James W. Pryor, Preble Tucker, M.D. Rothschild, Boudinot Keith, J.H. Klein, George M. Cassat, and John Brooks Leavitt drafted and revised the address.

EASTHAMPTON, L.I., Oct. 13. -- The recant sale of a large tract of land on Montauk Point to Austin Corbin and his associates has raised a question as to the ownership of the roads running through the property. The roadways are relics of the Indian occupation of the land, having been made mostly by the redmen or by herds of cattle that for years pastured on Montauk Point.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 13. -- The nearer the General Convention of the Episcopal Church approaches final adjournment the more improbable does it appear that sufficient progress can be made on the consideration of the revised constitution and canons to enable the completed document to be submitted to the various dioceses, and thus enable them to certify their approval or disapproval to the triennial convention at Washington in 1898.

SING SING, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- Frederick W. Decker, who escaped from Sing Sing Prison last evening, was returned to his cell at 8 o'clock this morning. Albert Delaney of the Tarrytown police will get the $50 reward, but the real captor of the convict is a mastiff that belongs to Sergt. Listmann of Tarrytown, and is the pet and pride of the department.

A wet Sunday yesterday made little difference in the vigilance of the police intrusted with excise duty. While complaints were louder than usual about the oppression of "Roosyfelt," and about blue laws in general, there was no relaxation in the enforcement of the law, and saloon keepers did a quiet business at a big risk.
