It is a thoroughly commendable step that the gentlemen connected with the State Racing Commission, The Jockey Club, and the Westchester Racing Association have taken to test the constitutionality of the law governing the racing of horses, known as the Percy-Gray law.

PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 13. -- The friends of Candidate Reed are greatly disturbed by the letter Senator Chandler of New-Hampshire has written to the Secretary of the Republican State League of Colorado. In that letter, in which Mr. Chandler comes out for bimetallism and predicts that the Republican Party will declare for bimetallism in its next National Convention, the Reed boomers find confirmation of what they all along have feared.

DULUTH, Minn., Oct. 13. -- It is reported throughout the Northwest that the wheat growers have formed an organization for the purpose of advancing the price of wheat so that it will pay them to take the grain to market.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- Judge John L. Thomas, Assistant Attorney General for the Post Office Department, has submitted to the Postmaster General a report of the operations of his office for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1895.

In what respects does the State Democracy believe that good government would be promoted and the safeguards of life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness made surer by the election of any or all of its legislative candidates?

Senator SHERMAN may change his mind in a day or two, but on Friday it appeared to be tolerably clear on four subjects -- the Republican prospect for success in Ohio, the dependence upon the President for a continuance of what Mr. SHERMAN reluctantly admitted were "better times," the delicacy of the financial situation, and his preference for Col. BRIGHT as a compromise Sergeant at Arms of the Senate.

ALBANY, Oct. 13. -- The Albany County Republicans have been in a state of excitement for the last four weeks because of the attitude of Albany's reform Mayor, Oren E. Wilson, who has been backed by persons who are anxious to witness the downfall of Albany's young Republican leader, William Barnes, Jr.

A meeting of the New-York City Marshals was called for 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon at 271 Grand Street. Only six Marshals were present, and the meeting was adjourned until some time after election day, the date to be determined by Henry Loewe, the Chairman pro tem.

In the sermon which the Rev. T. De Witt Talamge, D.D., has prepared for THE NEW-YORK TIMES this week, he has chosen for his subject Abraham's supreme trial of faith and the rescue of Isaac from being offered by his father as a sacrifice. The text selected is Genesis, xxil., 7: "Behold the fire and the wood, but where is the lamb?" The sermon follows:

The Connecticut Board of Health has undertaken such an inspection of the sources of ice supply as should be made by the sanitary authorities of every State. The local agents or representatives of the board have been instructed to examine all the ponds or other bodies of water in their towns from which ice is taken for consumption, and to ascertain whether the water is contaminated or exposed to pollution.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- The weather yesterday did not prevent the enthusiasts of golf assembling at the Knoll Wood Country Club grounds near White Plains, to participate in the contests for several cups offered by Mr. and Mrs. Paul G. Thebaud of White Plains. There was a fair attendance of guests, who witnessed the contests with keen interest.

Democrats at the headquarters of the State Committee, at 27 Madison Avenue, were discussing the make-up of the official ballot yesterday with some apprehension. The question was raised whether the fusion ticket in this city would appear on the blanket ballot in any except the straight Republican column, under the names of Republican State candidates.
The West Farms Presbyterian Church. One Hundred and Eightieth Street, near Boston Avenue, celebrated three anniversaries yesterday afternoon.

CAMBRIDGE, Oct. 13. -- The following 165 undergraduates were the recipients of scholarships at a recent meeting of the Faculty, the amount of the scholarships varying from $400 to $150, and averaging about $250:

There is little reason for expecting anything but a favorable decision as to the constitutionality of the Percy-Gray racing law when the matter comes up before the court this morning. That, at least, is the belief of the members of the State Racing Commission, of the officers of the Westchester Racing Association, and of The Jockey Club, which have combined to make a thorough test of the matter.

-- This week does not promise much of consequence socially, and the smart set already in town preparatory for the coming season of gayety will by no means find themselves fatigued owing to a round of pleasure. The six days to come will not be marked even by weddings, for the latter will be unimportant and but few in number.

There was no field day for the botanists Saturday, although there might have been a delightful one if any one had been sufficiently daring to run the risk of damp shoes and clothes and a possible cold.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- The meeting called by ex-Mayor Thomas E. Kinney to protest against the Democratic indorsement of Mr. Coggeshall's candidacy for the Senate was held in Mr. Kinney's office yesterday. The attendance was large.

Thomas A. Edison went back to his house in Orange, N.J., last evening. He spent the day very quietly in the office of the Edison Electric Light Company. As he did not have anything in particular on his hands, and wasn't wrestling with any big problem, he just sat around and talked to President William D. Marks and the men.

The zeal of the governing officers of the New-Jersey Division of the League of American Wheelmen to free that body from debt has brought it into disfavor with many cyclists in that State. It appears that a postal card issued at the head quarters of the league is the cause of the dissatisfaction.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 13. -- "Oct. 21 will mark an epoch in the history of the negro race," said I. Garland Penn, Commissioner of the Negro Department at the Cotton States Exposition to-day. "To-morrow, one week, will be negro day. Our race will then formally present our building to the exposition company.

The Eighth Battalion, N.G.N.Y., is about to be strengthened by the addition of a new company, the papers for which will be presented at Brigade Headquarters this evening. A fortnight only will then expire before the date when the ceremony of mustering-in will take place in the armory of the Eighth, at Ninety-fourth Street and Park Avenue.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 13. -- Information has reached here from a reliable source of the purchase of vast quantities of land in the vicinity of Butler, the county seat of Bates County, Mo., by the widow of Lord Scully. This process of acquisition has been going on for a year or more, and has already attracted general attention in that part of Missouri.

HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- Lieut. Albert M. Darmit, a brilliant young army officer, died at West Point yesterday after a short illness from remittent fever. He was buried in the post cemetery this afternoon with military honors.

At the present day the supply of amber is chiefly obtained from the dreary and desolate region of Samland, on the eastern Baltic, a strange, weird land of blowing sand, shifting sand-dunes, and poverty-stricken amber hunters. It is a cold northern Sahara. The district produces absolutely nothing but amber; vegetation it has none, and from Konigsberg, its capital, to the end of the promontory, scarcely anything subsists that a man could live upon.

In short, in his matrimonial relations his motto may be said to be, "What's thine is mine, and what's mine is my own."

CADIZ, Oct. 14. -- There was a procession of the Rosary here last night that resulted in a somewhat serious attack on the processionists. As the procession, which was headed by the Bishop of Cadiz, was passing through the streets, a crowd of idle workingmen were met who did not approve of the religious parade.

The committee appointed by Mayor Strong on July 5 to arrange for public baths and lavatories has been actively at work throughout the Summer, and its report upon plans for such conveniences was approved by the Board of Health on Oct. 1.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 14. -- Unofficial information has been received at the torpedo station to the effect that the Lancaster will arrive here late this week for her torpedo outfit. She will be followed by the Maine the week after, the Texas in November, the Indiana in December, and the Oregon in January.

BURLINGTON, N.J., Oct. 14. -- In this country there are twenty-four Burlingtons, all more or less celebrated, but none so interesting as the Quaker town down on the Delaware River, just fourteen miles below Trenton. It was originally called Birdlington. That was when spelling was bad. Orthographical evolution naturally improved this, and it was changed to the spelling now to be found on the railroad tickets.
The German-American politicians spent yesterday manoeuvring for favorable positions before to-night's meeting of the faction opposed to supporting the Tammany Hall ticket.
The trial of Morris Schoenholz, the fire-bug, is practically over. His case will probably go to the jury this afternoon.

Elevators at the Appraiser's warehouse were stopped yesterday on a report to Collector Kilbreth from the Inspector of Steam Boilers that the boilers in the building could not be used except with risk.

English operetta is much the most artistic that we get in these days, and it was, therefore, with much hope that a large audience assembled last night in the Broadway Theatre at the first performance of "His Excellency." This work is the result of the combined labors of W.S. Gilbert and Dr. Osmond Carr, the latter one of those numerous English composers whose glory is great at home, but not abroad.
The Reform Party in Kings County will start its campaign to-morrow night, when a rousing meeting will be held in the Criterion Theatre, Fulton Street, near Grand Avenue.

The conduct of a litigant is not to be commended who, instead of taking an appeal from a judgment which is unfavorable to him, tries to get some extraneous person to interfere in his behalf. That is what has been done by the counsel for the supporters of disreputable horse racing against the Westchester Racing Association.

Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn who nominated James Howell for re-election to the Presidency of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge, has at last, near the end of his term, awakened to the fact that President Howell has permitted the bridge plaza, which cost $1,000,000, to be used as a storage place by the elevated railroads, and at a meeting of the bridge trustees yesterday he made a mild protest against it.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 14. -- With the exception of an international gathering in Chicago while the World's Fair was in progress, the first National assembly in America for the discussion of purity and moral questions opened here to-night. Some of the men and women who are to take part in the congress have National reputations. Aaron Macy Powell, who has been a reformer all his life, called the meeting to order.

Deria Ali was our swarthy chef; a little wizened-up old fellow, much given to complaining of and quarreling with the other members of the outfit, but, on the other hand, a first-class jungle cook. He had seen a good deal of the world, having visited Melbourne and other places in Australia; not finding them to his liking, however, he had returned to his native jungle.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 14. -- Detective Frank P. Geyer of Philadelphia, who has been trying to fasten a murder charge upon H.H. Holmes, the Philadelphia insurance swindler, arrived here to-day from Detroit to secure witnesses as to the presence of the Pietzel children in Toronto, their movements while here, and the finding of the bodies in the cellar of the St. Vincent house.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

Ex-Senator Warner Miller of wide-open Herkimer County, the father of the Sunday plank in the Republican State platform, is going to make a speech in Cooper Union to-night. He is to be the principal speaker at a mass meeting under the management of the Republican Club.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Considerable attention has been given the last few days to the question whether the Republicans will attempt to reorganize the Senate this Winter. Senator Sherman has said there ought to be a combination between the Democrats and Republicans which would give the Republicans the Secretaryship of the Senate, and permit Col. Bright to remain Sergeant-at-Arms.

The ten candidates on the Tammany city and county ticket now know officially that they have been nominated. They were told so yesterday afternoon in the parlor of the Union Square Hotel, where they met the Tammany Committee on Notification and received the formal proffer of their nominations.

The erroneous idea that the darkest hour immediately precedes the dawn is so common that it has passed into a proverb. Light comes as gradually in the morning as it dies away in the evening. It would be as correct to speak of "the brightest hour before the sunset."
The Autumn meeting of the Queens County Jockey Club was brought to a close at Aqueduct yesterday, with a tame and uninteresting day's racing and before a small crowd.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment met yesterday at noon in the Mayor's office. There were present Counsel to the Corporation Francis M. Scott, President of the Department of Taxes and Assessments Edward P. Barker, Controller Ashbel P. Fitch, and President of the Board of Aldermen John Jeroloman.

A large number of young women, members of the Business Woman's Auxiliary of Harlem met at the house of Mrs. Cornelia S. Robinson, 221 West One Hundred and Twenty-eighth Street, last evening to be instructed in the political way in which they should go, according to the principles laid down by the Republican Party.

President Roosevelt of the Police Board yesterday investigated the story told by George Saul, a bartender at 736 Eleventh Avenue, about his arrest on Sunday because he sold brandy to save a child's life. After making inquiries, the Commissioner declared that the story was false.

-- Town society is migratory, so migratory, in fact, that it is quite like the will-'o-the-wisp. A letter addressed to a fashionable woman is liable to follow her from town to Newport, from Newport to Lenox, from Lenox to some town along the Hudson, and from the latter section of the country to Tuxedo, and, possibly, to some colony of fashionable folks down on Long Island.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 14. -- Murphy fought Bald so hard to-day in the mile open race at the National Circuit meet of the Capital City Cycling Club that that rider was compelled to ride his very best clear to the tape. The two open events, the half and the mile, went to Bald, and the quarter-mile to Cooper.

If Tammany would desist from its hungry and dreadful pursuit of the municipal offices, then the State Democracy would be permitted to relax its unselfish vigils, and a vast store of good Democratic energy would be released for State and National uses.

The great picture of the season is undoubtedly the portait of Lady Mulgrave, which appeared in the James Price sale of the 15th of June, and realized 10,000 guineas, the second highest price ever paid for a Gainsborough, and only 100 guineas less than the amount paid for the celebrated Duchess of Devonshire in 1876.

At a meeting of the Executive Committee of the Committee of Fifty at the Chamber of Commerce yesterday afternoon a resolution was unanimously passed to the effect that it had nothing whatever to do with Senatorial nominations. The members of the Executive Committee, however, are unanimous in denouncing the nomination of ex-Police Inspector Alexander S. Williams as being wholly unfit and decidedly detrimental to the public.
A grand lecture, replete with many grand truths and great ideas, was that delivered last evening in Chickering Hall by Dr. Greene of 35 West 14th St., New-York City.
There were lively times at the meetings of Good Government Clubs F and X last night. Warm discussions and strong words characterized both meetings.

The Executive Committee of the State Democracy met yesterday afternoon and unanimously voted to suspend Jacob Kunzenman as a member of the Executive Committee for his part in the notorious Williams - Grote - Kunzenman "deal," by which ex-Inspector Williams was indorsed by the Twelfth Senate District State Democracy Convention, and the Republican Assembly District Conventions indorsed Grote and Kunzenman for the Assembly.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 14. -- The steamship China of the Pacific Mail Company came into port last night with a clean bill of health, but was placed in quarantine.

ATLANTA, Oct. 14. -- The Farmers' National Congress to-day declared for the free coinage of silver at the ratio of 16 to 1. The Committee on Resolutions had a dozen propositions, differing very little, except in their wording, and there was a long debate, but without leadership on either side. The committee's report favored free coinage of both metals at the present ratio, guarded by an import duty upon foreign coin.

The Democratic State Committee will meet to-night at headquarters, 27 Madison Avenue. Reports will be received from all sections of the State as to the progress of the canvass. It is probable that all the candidates on the State ticket will be in the city during the day, and that they will hold a meeting.

Modern critics, puzzled by the enigmatic smile on the compressed lips of the "Joconde," have sought, like myself, to read the thought lurking behind that smooth, dark forehead. Not one, however, has gone so far as to give his suppositions a precise form. Taine asks whether the lovely woman's smile has not a twofold meaning -mockery toward her elderly husband and tenderness toward the artist.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 14. -- Some excitement was created in Greenville to-day by the employment of a colored teacher, Miss Daisy Fearing, in Public School No. 14, on Union Street. A number of pupils in the class to which Miss Fearing was assigned reported the matter to their parents, and were told, it is said, that if Miss Fearing was in charge of the class to-morrow to leave school and return home.

As the road turned around the hill I came upon a mule and a cart and a man. The wheels of the cart had sunk down into a mud hole, and the mule stood with head down and ears lazily working to and fro. As for the man, he lay in his back in the shade of a tree and seemed to be taking solid comfort.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 14. -- There is a scarcity of steel rails, which fact is evi-danced by several Eastern and far Western railroad representatives, who are in the city endeavoring to contract for early deliveries of an immense quantity of steel rails. The price of rails has gone up, owing to the choked condition of the Eastern mills.

The estate of the late George G. Sickles, in the village and town of New-Rochelle, was sold at auction in partition proceedings by Mr. Peter F. Meyer yesterday for about $170,000. The property included the old homestead and farm of over 100 acres, fifty-six yilla plots, and the right, title, , of the estate in several lots and a large plot in Petersville.

Mme. Modjeska was the guest of honor at the monthly reception of the Professional Woman's League yesterday afternoon. It was a particularly high festival, for not only was Modjeska's distinguished figure, in a handsome black satin and white lace gown, conspicuous on the little platform in the reception room, but at the other end of the platform sat Lotta, one of the league's Vice Presidents and a charter member, and also an always-honored guest.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 14. -- An election in Dutchess County would not seem natural without two or three fights in the courts. This Fall's campaign is no exception to the rule. Issue was first joined over an attempt by the Democrats to use the machinery of the Democratic Reform organization to help the regular Democratic candidates on the Senate, Assembly, and County tickets.
ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 14. -- There is a controversy in the local militia as to what organization shall act as an escort to President Cleveland during his stay here next week.

Senor PIERRA'S temperate and sensible letter, which we print in another column, may be accepted as evidence that the attitude toward our Government of the insurgent party in Cuba is not that of insistence upon immediate recognition, as might be inferred from the passionate utterances of some of their advocates in this country who daily cudgel the Administration for its non-action.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- Francis Wilson, his two young daughters, Frances and Adelaide, and some friends were playing polo on bicycles to-day at "The Orchard," as Mr. Wilson calls his home in New-Rochelle.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 14. -- After securing the adoption of a resolution providing for final adjournment on Tuesday of next week, the opposition to revision in the House of Deputies of the Episcopal Convention made another strenuous effort to-day to lay over the new constitution and canons for three years, or until the triennial convention at Washington.

Joseph Jefferson began an engagement, which is to last four weeks at the Garden Theatre last evening. He was received with a great demonstration of applause. The audience which had assembled to greet him was well dressed, of course, and in holiday mood. It fitly represented the typical American theatre-goer, who, at the present moment, is surely the least trustworthy human being in the world.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- The closing session of the triennial council of the Congregational Church opened this morning, and a varied amount of business was transacted. Resolutions denouncing the outrages on citizens and missionaries in foreign countries were adopted.

F.G. Pierra, whose address at the Cuban mass meeting in this city last week was the chief feature of the occasion, has written a letter to THE NEW-YORK TIMES in acknowledgment of an editorial which appeared in last Saturday's issue commenting on the mass meeting and the Cuban cause. Following is the letter:

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 14. -- When the two pacing mares, Miss Rita and Josie B. went a mile this afternoon, double, in 2:12 1/4, they made a new world's record by shaving a half second from the 2:12 3/4 that Effie Powers and Prestoria Wilkes made over the State fair track at Springfield, Ill., three weeks ago. The last half was made in 1:04 1/2, a 2:09 gait, last quarter in 0:31, a 2:04 gait.
The Nominating Committee of the Anti-Tammany Democracy held a lively meeting last night, which lasted from 8 o'clock until midnight, at its headquarters, in the St. Cloud Hotel.

The campaign for Edward M. Grout, the regular Democratic nominee for Mayor of Brooklyn, was opened last night in the Academy of Music, in Montague Street, under the auspices of the Citizens' Party, which formally indorsed Mr. Grout's nomination.

Knauth, Nachod Kuhne, the Broad Street bankers, will have to pay Paul Dupont and Maurice Vernier of Turcoing, France, $6,861.17 by the terms of a report filed yesterday in the Supreme Court by Hamilton Odell as referee.
William A. Reed, a well-known hardware merchant at 229 Bowery, committed suicide in his store some time between 2 o'clock Sunday afternoon and 3 o'clock yesterday morning.
Leaders of the State Democracy said yesterday that competent legal adviser's were confident the State Democracy would have a party column on the blanket ballot under its emblem -- the rooster.

Thurlow Weed Barnes makes himself understood quite as plainly a Frank D. Pavey. Mr. Barnes, who is a member of the State Republican Committee, wrote to Mr. Pavey, who is a Republican candidate for the Senate, asking if he intended, if elected, to go into and abide by the Republicans caucus. Mr. Pavey replied that he would not be "catechized" by Mr. Barnes on that subject.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Oct. 14. -- The Democratic State Committee was in session all day and evening. It is announced that but one feeling prevailed in regard to taking action on the alleged interference of the high officials of the Mormon Church in political affairs, and that was that heroic measures must be taken and the question of the political liberties of the people of Utah, irrespective of party, be settled once and for all.

Another series of yacht races for the international championship will undoubtedly be sailed next year. Such was the decision of the New-York Yacht Club at a special meeting held last night to consider the challenge sent by Charles D. Rose through the Royal Victoria Yacht Club. That the challenge would be accepted there was no doubt, and the only question was as to the terms.

Though the Church of England is still the Church as by law established, a secular function to which much importance was once attached has now become nearly extinct. Attendance in the House of Lords is not now expected of a Bishop unless he is acting in his turn as Chaplain, or there is some ecclesiastical question before the House.

He is a wary old stager, your veteran solitaire, and even more difficult to discover than he is to stalk. In the daytime he lies perdu in the shadow of some overhanging rock, only emerging in the early morning and evening to feed. Like his human congener, the elderly buck dines late -- at his club, I was about to say, but at any rate in some sequestered nook where the ladies cannot bother him.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The news from the Hermit Kingdom makes Prince Pak, recently Prime Minister of the Government, the central figure of interest in Washington, where he has been for the last few weeks. He is impatiently awaiting an expected summons from his friends, the members of the progressive party in Cored, of which he is the leader, asking him to return and resume his mission of reforming the Government.

Cheese cookery was the subject of Mrs. Rorer's talk at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon, and three dainty dishes were skillfully prepared and placed on a small table in front of the audience, while tempting odors filled the room.

The Fall days are rapidly passing, and before long Winter will be upon us. Now is the time to consider whether we are prepared to withstand the dangers to which we must be exposed during the coming season. Even perfectly healthy people feel the change from Summer heat to the coolness of Fall and early Winter.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 14. -- Cottage entertainments were numerous to-night. Mrs. James H. Beekman gave a dance, and Mrs. Louis G. Jones, Mrs. J. Watts Kearny, Mrs. Joseph Stone, Mrs. George B. De Forest, Mrs. George Gordon King, Mrs. Charles M. Oelrichs, and Mrs. William Grosvenor gave dinner parties.
The anti-Platt sentiment among Republicans broke out last night, notwithstanding the nominations are made and the campaign is under way.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 14. -- The prospect of a game with Harvard has greatly increased the football enthusiasm at Princeton. To-day's practice on the Varsity field was the most spirited seen this season. The whole college went down to the field, and the cheering was the best yet heard. The undergraduate body was overjoyed to see Wheeler, the veteran guard, in his old place on the Varsity in to-day's game.

The heavy machinery in the power house of the Metropolitan Company's Lexington Avenue cable road was set in motion between 2 and 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and the eight-mile cable, extending from One Hundred and Fifth Street and Lexington Avenue to Broadway and Twenty-third Street, began its journey.
SPEONK, L.I., Oct. 14. -- The Post Office authorities have changed the name of this place to Remsenburg. The change means a new church, to cost $10,000, and a whole lot of bad feeling.

-- County Clerk John D. Walsh of Albany was turned down by the Republicans in nominating a candidate to succeed him. He, however, expects to go out of office with flying colors. He has contracted for 540 oak sticks, one inch square and 3 1/2 feet long, for which he will pay 5 cents each. Each stick is fixed so that a small American flag can be attached to it.

-- Gabrielle D. Clements, a well-known Philadelphia artist, has been appointed teacher of drawing in the Bryn Mawr School, on Maryland Avenue, vice Miss Lindsay Hunt, deceased. Miss Clements is a pupil of Tony Robert Fleury and Bouguereau, in the Paris schools, and an exhibitor in the Salon and home exhibitions.
